title: Goldsmith Says Bid For B.A.T. in Snag
description: Sir James Goldsmith, who is leading the hostile takeover bid for B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., said a British regulatory panel must extend its deadline or his takeover attempt will fail. Britain's Panel on Takeovers and Mergers requires that all conditions of a bid, including United States regulatory approvals, must be completed within 81 days after the bidder's offer document is delivered.

title: Badillo, Former Koch Rival, Backs Mayor for Re-election
description: Herman Badillo, a prominent figure in New York City's Hispanic community who once described Mayor Edward I. Koch as a ''petty racialist who fans the flames of racism,'' yesterday endorsed the Mayor's re-election bid.

title: Fordham Prepares To Take Major Steps
description: Fordham will play a game against a major college opponent for the first time in 35 years tomorrow as the Rams begin their association with the Colonial League and Division I-AA.

title: As Drug Violence Increases, Foreigners Leave Colombia
description: Colombia's drug traffickers continued their war against the country's establishment today with a powerful bomb in Medellin, their main base of operations, that caused extensive damage.

title: Our Towns; A Prep School That Teaches Drug-Free Life
description: Fall is coming and the autumn sense of expectancy is in the air on the 140-acre campus of Phoenix Academy here. Bryant Norman is looking forward to computer classes.

title: Koreans Get Libya Job
description: A South Korean company has won a Libyan contract to build a water pipeline, the largest construction contract ever awarded in the Middle East, a company spokesman said today. The spokesman for the Dong Ah Construction Industrial Company said the value of the 90-month contract for the 683-mile pipeline totals $5.3 billion. The pipe will bring water from underground reservoirs in the Sahara to the Tripoli area. It is the second phase of a project to supply water to densely populated coastal areas.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Improvising by 12

title: Brazil Is Offering a 6% Bond
description: The Brazilian Government issued exit bonds today to reduce interest payments on its foreign debt by $40 million a year. Marcelo Ceylao, a director at the nation's central bank, said $1.5 billion worth of the bonds were delivered to financial markets in New York and London for distribution on Friday.

title: U.S. Can Promote Central American Peace; Dying for Nothing
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; When Grandmother Is a Hungry Monster
description: Roberto Cossa's comedy ''La Nonna'' is sometimes dark, and often its humor may be too robust for delicate sensibilities. But in the production by Repertorio Espanol, the Argentinian writer's play at the Gramercy Arts Theater is very funny; the laughter it brings from the audience is gleeful and utterly unashamed.

title: RABBI TO BOYCOTT WARSAW SERVICE
description: Citing a dispute over the presence of a Roman Catholic convent at Auschwitz, Poland's only rabbi said today that he would not join in a prayer service commemorating the start of World War II.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Drop 1.4%
description: Prices that farmers were paid for raw products dropped 1.4 percent from July to August, putting the monthly average just where it was a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: U.S. to Train Colombians
description: The Pentagon said it would dispatch 50 to 100 military personnel to train Colombians to operate and maintain the $65 million worth of arms and equipment promised by President Bush. Page A6.

title: Hilton on Red Sea
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation will take over management of the luxury hotel at Taba, the Red Sea resort once disputed by Egypt and Israel, a spokeswoman for the hotel chain said. Nazima Raffa, public relations manager for Hilton in Egypt, said the company would take over the hotel Friday from Sonesta International Hotels.

title:
THE LAW;
Rural Lawyers: Representing 'Folks Not Entities'
description: LEAD: Here at the foot of the Olympic Mountains, between the tall firs of the Olympic Peninsula and the misty inlets of Puget Sound, 300 lawyers descended on this tiny fishing and timber town last week for the annual Small Town Lawyer Made Good Award.

title: Another Soviet Area Rejects Russian
description: Soviet Moldavia established Moldavian as its official language today despite the complaints of tens of thousands of Russian speakers on strike within the republic that the law would increase tension.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BancOklahoma Corp., Tulsa, Okla., a bank holding company, named Stanley A. Lybarger president and chief operating officer of the parent company and its principal subsidiary, Bank of Oklahoma.

title: Promoting Connecticut's Home-Grown TV
description: Deep in the heart of Connecticut, television broadcasters here believe, there is a Texas-sized sense of state identity just waiting to kick off its Topsiders and come out fighting. The best means of expressing it, they suggest, is the remote-control channel switcher.

title: Airlines to Install System by Plessey
description: The Plessey Company, the British electronics concern, said six airlines were about to install its new in-flight entertainment system enabling passengers to play games, call home, shop or telex the office. The company did not identify the airlines. Plessey will pay for the installation costs of the system while profits will be shared with the airlines.

title: Prices for Notes and Bonds Ease
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very thin trading yesterday, as traders shrugged off two developments that could have produced a rally.

title: Topics of The Times; A Quiet Victory
description: After months of noisy debate, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted last week to ban amplified and other loud music from subway platforms, while allowing it to continue in the mezzanine areas of stations. The compromise isn't music to everyone's ears - but that's the beauty of it.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 464 money market mutual funds increased by $53.7 million, to $343.4 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 142 institutional funds decreased by $380.9 million, to $85.33 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were up by $124.3 million, to $109.91 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $310.3 million, to $148.16 billion, the institute said.

title: Music Danceable And Brash
description: In the early 1970's, the name ''salsa'' began to be applied to the brash and bright urban music of Cuban and Puerto Rican New York City. While the music drew on all sorts of sources, Hispanic and other, it often tried to retain what was called tipico - traditional - flavor while experimenting within the forms.

title: U.S. Can Promote Central American Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: China Hails Mazowiecki
description: China has congratulated Poland's new non-Communist Prime Minister and wants to continue friendly relations with that country, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: Allstate Discounts Offered for Brakes
description: The Allstate Insurance Company announced that it would offer a 10 percent discount on three leading auto-policy coverages for drivers of cars equipped with anti-lock brakes. The only other United States insurance company offering an anti-lock brake discount is U.S.A.A. of San Antonio, which insures military personnel and their dependents.

title: U.S. Renews Attack on Noriega, Offering Evidence of Ties to Drugs
description: In a new effort to turn world opinion against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the United States asserted today that the Panamanian strongman continued to play a major role in the laundering of drug money and the shipment of narcotics through his country.

title: Merger Law Is Challenged
description: The High Voltage Engineering Corporation asked the Supreme Court today to decide whether Wisconsin's takeover law is constitutional. If the case is accepted, it would be the Court's first hearing on the latest generation of state takeover legislation.

title: The New Times Square Design: Merely Token Changes
description: Wednesday's announcement of a new design for the four towers planned for Times Square was a stunning public reversal, less an architectural event than a marketing one, a sort of architectural equivalent of the Coca-Cola Company's abrupt replacement of New Coke. The Times Square towers, too, bombed in the marketplace; though construction had not even begun, critical and public reactions to Philip Johnson and John Burgee's original design were so negative that the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the New York City Public Development Corporation, the vast project's co-sponsors, felt that a dramatic change was necessary to get the long-stalled project off the ground.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Akzo N.V., Sassenheim, the Netherlands, a chemical company, completed the acquisition of Reliance Universal Inc., Louisville, Ky., a coatings concern, from Tyler Corp., Dallas, for $275 million.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Bistro d'Adrienne

title: Bryan Smith, 93; Headed Liberty Mutual
description: Bryan E. Smith, a former chairman and president of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the Fairport Baptist Home, where he had lived for the last year. He was 93 years old.

title: U.S. ADOPTS LIMITS ON USE OF BENZENE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today imposed tough restrictions on the industrial use of benzene, a major chemical that has been linked to leukemia in adults.

title: Review/Art; The Many Ways of Turning Wood Into Bowls
description: It is always refreshing to come across a category of art objects that is new and unknown, that reaches one's field of vision relatively unencumbered by big reputations, advance publicity, critical theory or plain old word of mouth. The silence of such experiences can be truly golden. It accentuates, by default, the extenuating noise that accompanies most visual encounters in the New York art world and gives the viewer valuable practice in hearing more clearly the inner voice of his own esthetic response.

title: Arab and Israeli Die Of Wounds Suffered In Uprising Violence
description: An Israeli tax collector died today, 17 days after he and three other Jews were wounded in a firebomb attack as they drove through the West Bank town of Ramallah, and Palestinians said a Gaza youth died this morning after being beaten by soldiers.

title: Rate Freeze By Niagara
description: The financially troubled Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation agreed today to freeze its rates, to cut the salaries of its top executives and to not pay a dividend to stockholders under an agreement announced by state officials.

title: Inflation Spurt in Brazil
description: Brazil's consumer prices rose by 29 percent in August, the second-largest monthly rise ever, the Government said today. The increase was exceeded only by the January inflation rate of 70 percent, which covered 45 days rather than one month.

title: A Parting for Solidarity and the Church?
description: LEAD: The remarks of Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic primate, delivered last Saturday at the holy shrine of Czestochowa throw into relief the question of the relations between Solidarity and the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Promotional Agency Gets A Crossover
description: ALTHOUGH the vogue in advertising is to speak of integrated communications, practitioners of public relations, direct marketing and advertising tend to remain apart, even antagonistic.

title: Qaddafi's Rule Is Celebrated; Libya and Chad in Peace Pact
description: Clad in flowing white robes, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi opened celebrations tonight to observe his 20th anniversary as Libya's leader while his Government signed an agreement with Chad to end 16 years of hostility.

title: Search Intensifies for Missing Radioactive Gas
description: The Energy Department said yesterday that it had formed a team to track down tritium that remains missing after a two-month search. Officials said the search had failed to resolve all discrepancies over how much of the radioactive gas was sent to commercial customers.

title: 7 AGENCIES JOINING IN CLIMATE WATCH
description: The Bush Administration set priorities today for all Federal research on global warming, ozone depletion and other potential environmental disasters.

title: Dent Is Positive Despite Poor Start
description: The losses are never easily forgotten. Bucky Dent still recalls 1985 as if it had taken place last week. It was his first season as a manager, at Class A Fort Lauderdale, and he had a group of young, brash players tasting professional baseball for the first time.

title: Heavy Bombardments Continue in Lebanon
description: Heavy clashes continued in Lebanon today, and Gen. Michel Aoun, who commands Christian forces battling Syrian troops and their Lebanese Muslim allies, said he would carry the fight ''until the end.''

title: Summer's Farewell Party: Everyone Is Invited
description: LABOR DAY first marched onto the calendar more than a century ago as a celebration of working-class solidarity, yet today the holiday has become summer's bittersweet finale. While other seasons may fade in and out, governed more by climate than calendar, summer comes to an all-too-abrupt end with the arrival of the first Monday in September.

title: China Rejects Charges
description: The Chinese Government responded angrily today to accusations from Amnesty International that it had ordered secret executions of dissidents and imprisoned more than 10,000 people involved in the crushed democracy movement.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a steel process using nitrogen as an alloy misidentified the parent company of Garrett Automotive. It is Allied Signal Inc., not General Signal Inc.

title: U.S. Is Sending Military Specialists to Train the Colombians
description: Detailing a more ambitious role for United States servicemen being sent to Colombia, the Pentagon said today that it would dispatch 50 to 100 military personnel to train Colombians to operate and maintain the $65 million worth of arms and equipment promised by President Bush.

title: Black Gains Right to Shed White Label
description: A light-skinned black woman has won her battle to stop the illusion that she was white, even though her parents listed her as white on her birth certificate in an attempt to help her overcome racial bias.

title: Jets Looking Good But Aren't Up to Par
description: Feeling healthier and looking better, the Jets end their exhibition play Friday night against the Chiefs, a club that could probably use another month of camp.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Here are Labor Day holiday schedules. Because of the Labor Day Parade in Manhattan, Fifth Avenue between 44th and 72d Streets will be closed from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Because of the West Indian Day Parade in Brooklyn, Eastern Parkway between Utica and Washington Avenues will be closed from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit trains and buses on holiday schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Italian Party Chief Quits
description: Former Prime Minsiter Ciriaco De Mita said today that he had resigned as president of the Christian Democrats, thus ending seven years in the leadership of Italy's dominant political party. Mr. De Mita said he was concerned the party ''gives the impression of being in a different frequency from mine.''

title: Pro Bono
description: * The National Multiple Sclerosis Society has introduced a television public service campaign emphasizing the achievements of people with multiple sclerosis. The ads are part of a campaign by Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Pavilion Buys Stake in RKO
description: Pavilion Communications Inc., a company founded by two former actors, has acquired a majority interest in RKO Pictures, which in Hollywood's heyday produced classic films like ''Citizen Kane,''

title: Labor Day Celebration in Three-State Region; Connecticut
description: Connecticut will celebrate Labor Day looking back through its long history and up into the sky over Long Island Sound at two dozen hot-air balloons. From farm animals at a fair to a fish fry by the shore, other end-of-summer traditions in this tradition-minded state will endure as well. WOODSTOCK FAIR.About 150,000 people are expected to converge on Connecticut's rural northeast corner over the three days of the 129th annual Woodstock Fair, making it the largest single event of the weekend. Features include farm-produce and animal competitions, home arts from quilting to food preservation, midway rides and family-oriented musical entertainment including authentic hurdy-gurdy performers. The spirit of the fair's 19th-century roots is to be evoked by a traveling medicine show. And there will be lots to eat. The fair will run tomorrow, Sunday and Monday from 8:30 A.M. to 9 P.M. Admission is $4 for adults, except tomorrow, when the elderly may enter at half price. No charge for children under 12. To get there, take Interstate 95 to Interstate 395 north to Exit 97. Follow Route 44 west to Route 171 and watch for the signs. Information: (203) 928-3246. REVOLUTIONARY WAR BATTLE IN GROTON.In Groton, volunteers in authentic dress are to re-enact the Battle of Groton Heights, a fight won by the British on Sept. 6, 1781, during a bloody British invasion of Connecticut led by Benedict Arnold in his first military foray as a turncoat. Spectators may watch from British lines outside Fort Griswold, or from within the fort itself, where a sort of play-by-play of the British advance is to be broadcast by public address system. The battle, using cannons and muzzle-loaders firing blank charges, is to begin about 1 P.M. on Sunday, but spectators are encouraged to come early to inspect the Colonial battle encampment and they should be at the fort by noon to get in place for the re-enactment. There is no admission charge and the fighting is to last about 45 minutes. To reach the site, take Interstate 95 to Exit 87 in Groton and follow the signs to Fort Griswold. Information: (203) 889-6275. BALLOONS ON THE SOUND.On a more serene note, 25 to 30 hot-air balloons are to lift off tomorrow morning at dawn from Taylor Farm Park in Norwalk to drift majestically across Long Island Sound if the wind is right - or inland toward downtown Bridgeport if it is not. The event, called the Annual Flight of the Beautiful Balloons, is sponsored by a nonprofit group working to improve water quality in the Sound, with all proceeds going to education and beach cleanup programs. Suggested donation is $2 for adults and $1 for children. Gates open at 6 A.M., with balloon flights to begin shortly after that until about 7:30 A.M. Rain or winds above 15 miles per hour will scrub the launch until Sunday morning, same time and place. To reach the site, take Interstate 95 to East Avenue in Norwalk (Exit 16) and follow the signs to Taylor Farm Park. Information: (203) 579-1045. AUTO RACING AT LIME ROCK.In the state's northwest corner, the annual BMW Vintage Fall Festival at Lime Rock Park will feature more than 250 cars, from a 1928 Bugatti to a 1959 Corvette Stingray prototype. The four-day festival is to begin today, with racing events today, tomorrow and particularly on Monday, when the centerpiece of the festival is to take place at 4 P.M. That race, a re-enactment of a Formula Libre Race held at Lime Rock Park in 1959, is to feature most of the original cars back on the track once again for 12 laps around the 1.53-mile loop. On Sunday, mint-condition antiques considered too valuable to race are to be on display in an event called the Concours d'Elegance, and a swap meet held on the park's grounds all four days is to feature parts and car memorabilia for sale or trade. Adult admission is $25 in advance for a full four-day ticket, $35 at the gate. One-day admission prices vary: $5 today, $10 tomorrow, $5 on Sunday and $15 on Monday. No charge for children under 12. To reach the park, take Interstate 684, which turns into Route 22 north, which turns into Route 44. Then turn on Route 112 and watch for the signs. Gates open at 7:30 A.M. Information: (203) 435-0896. RAFT RACE IN NEW PRESTON.An even more rustic mode of transportation is to be featured in New Preston, south of Lakeville, where the ninth annual Huckleberry Finn Raft Race is to be held on Lake Waramaug on Monday. Entrants are to compete around a one-mile course on homemade rafts that cost no more than $25 to construct. Winner for the last two years and reigning champion: the Cider Barrel Six, a six-person raft made entirely of old cider barrels. Race rules allow paddles, but no oarlocks. Admission is free and the paddling begins about 3 P.M. To reach the site, take Interstate 84 to Exit 7, then Route 7 north to Route 202 east to Route 45 north and follow the signs to the Inn at Lake Waramaug. Information: (203) 868-0563 or (800) 525-3466 (outside Connecticut). FISH FRY IN MYSTIC.In Mystic, the aquatic action is to be served on plates, at Mystic Seaport's first Labor Day Weekend Fish Fry. Dinners of Yankee flatfish (fillet of sole), potato salad, coleslaw and iced tea, plus frankfurter platters and seaport chowder will be served under tents on the seaport grounds tomorrow, Sunday and Monday from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Admission to the seaport to tour the grounds and restored sailing ships costs $12.50 for adults and $6.25 for children 5 to 18 years. Lunch costs another $6.50 for the fish and $5 for the frankfurters. To reach the seaport, take Interstate 95 to Exit 90 and follow the signs. Information: (203) 572-0711.

title: TV Weekend; The Passion and the Pain Of the Painter Frida Kahlo
description: During Frida Kahlo's life, she and her paintings existed in the formidable shadow of her husband, the great Mexican muralist Diego Rivera. Since her death in 1954, however, the passion and pain that this remarkable woman poured onto her canvases has brought recognition to her work and fascination with her courageous life, which is admiringly treated in ''Frida Kahlo: Portrait of an Artist,'' on Channel 13 at 10 P.M. on Monday.

title: INSIDE
description: Pilots May Buy United Air The union plans to make a $6.5 billion bid for the airline, Wall Street sources said. In the deal, worth close to $300 a share, British Airways would be a leading investor. Page D1. Deal on East Germans Bonn and Budapest have worked out a plan to allow up to 20,000 East Germans now in Hungary to leave for West Germany, according to West German officials. Page A9. Koch Criticizes Con Ed Mayor Edward I. Koch accused Consolidated Edison of misleading New York City about the danger of asbestos contamination from a fatal steam pipe explosion. Page B1. Baseball Owners Must Pay An arbitrator awarded $10.5 million to 139 players who were the victims of a conspiracy by club owners against free agents. Page A25.

title: Shifting Sands, Instant Forecasts
description: Just one month ago, most economic forecasters employed by banks and brokerage houses were warning of an imminent recession; now they are celebrating continued growth. Economic miracle? Hardly. Such sudden shifts have more to do with the nature of a forecaster's job than with what is actually happening to the economy.

title: No Headline
description: With legislative elections six days away, the South African Government's confrontation with anti-apartheid forces sharpened today. Hundreds of demonstrators were repelled with tear gas and rubber bullets, and the police searched the offices of the country's largest predominantly black trade union federation.

title: Bleeding Cambodia
description: The bitter breakdown of the Paris peace conference on Cambodia opens a horrifying possibility. If Vietnamese forces withdraw as scheduled this month, Pol Pot's genocidal Khmer Rouge army could once again shoot its way into power.

title: 5-1 Victory Puts Jays At the Top With Orioles
description: George Bell drove in three runs, two with a home run that extended his hitting streak to a club-record 22 games, as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Chicago White Sox this afternoon, 5-1, to complete a sweep of a three-game series.

title: Robert Schakne, 63, a CBS News Reporter
description: Robert Schakne, a writer and correspondent for CBS News for 33 years before he retired in 1988, died of cancer yesterday at Sibley Hospital in Washington. He was 63 years old and lived in Washington.

title: On Stage
description: 'Willy Sings the Blues'

title: Pilots Said To Plan Bid For United
description: The pilots union at United Airlines plans to make an offer to buy the carrier that could be worth $6.5 billion, a Wall Street executive and an investor with major holdings in the airline said yesterday.

title: U.N. Panel Puts China on List Of Human Rights Defendants
description: A United Nations panel today placed China on a list of countries accused of seriously violating their citizens' human rights.

title: Labor Day Celebration in Three-State Region; Hudson Valley
description: The major events in the Hudson Valley this weekend are the opening today of a new visitors' center at the United States Military Academy at West Point and the reopening of a newly refurbished West Point Museum, depicting the history of warfare, weapons and the Academy itself.

title: Review/Film; Shared Virtue vs. Great Evil In 'Weapons of the Spirit'
description: Faced with the unfathomable evil of the Holocaust, the French town of Le Chambon-sur-Lignon responded with deep and mysterious goodness. From 1940 to 1944, the 5,000 people of Le Chambon - a community of profoundly religious Protestants - sheltered 5,000 Jews. Individual farmers and pension owners took in refugees; a Swiss-run school received Jewish children from French internment camps; a safe house sheltered Jews heading for the Swiss border. This activity continued even after a hotel in Le Chambon was commandeered and used as a hospital for Nazi soldiers.

title: DEAL IS REPORTED ON EAST GERMANS
description: Hungarian and West German officials have worked out a plan that will let up to 20,000 East Germans leave for the West over the next few days, West German Government and opposition officials disclosed today.

title: F.B.I. Profits on Seat Sales
description: Federal agents apparently reaped at least $52,000 in profits when they sold seats on Chicago's big futures exchanges. The seats had been bought to help the agents pose as floor traders during an undercover investigation of the markets.

title: Bensonhurst: A Tough Code In Defense of a Closed World
description: Banners and lights of red, white and green - the colors of the Italian flag -hang along 18th Avenue in Bensonhurst for the Feast of Santa Rosalia. Normally the neighborhood's biggest event of the year, the feast is overshadowed now by the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black youth who had ventured into the neighborhood to look at a used car and was surrounded by a crowd of white youths and gunned down.

title: Topics of The Times; New York's Taxing Question
description: Faced with a queasy economy and the burdens of drugs and AIDS, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York has begun to ask out loud whether the state can afford next year's scheduled tax cut. It's the right question.

title: Walesa Rejects Soviet-Style Communism
description: As Solidarity celebrated its ninth anniversary, Lech Walesa told a Soviet interviewer today that Poland should pull away from Soviet-style Communism and create its own model of society drawing from both socialism and capitalism.

title: Review/Art; 2 Distinct Visions of 19th-Century America
description: The National Academy of Design has the best exhibition twin bill in town. It is not that they are the two best exhibitions, although they are solid enough. What makes them so valuable is the way they complement each other and underline essential aspects of 19th-century American art. Each retrospective is devoted to an important academy member.

title: Loitering in New York, With Intent to Observe
description: Summer weekends, and especially holiday weekends, are particularly good times to explore New York City. With many of the city's residents out of town or holed up in their apartments, the streets can seem eerily empty - all the better to venture out on one of a number of guided walking tours.

title: Gdansk Journal; Shelling Began, and Nothing Was Ever the Same
description: On Sept. 1, 1939, the German battleship Schleswig-Holstein bombarded the Polish garrison of what was then Danzig, a free city, setting off World War II.

title: Hawks Re-sign Wilkins
description: Dominique Wilkins, the Atlanta Hawks' All-Star forward, became one of the highest-paid players in professional basketball when he signed a five-year, $14.5 million contract yesterday. Under his former contract, Wilkins, 29 years old, earned $1.4 million per season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES The pilots' union at United Airlines plans to offer $6.5 billion for the carrier, a Wall Street executive and an investor with major holdings in the airline said. The offer, worth close to $300 a share, will be presented to UAL's board today, and approval is expected. British Airways would be a major investor. [ Page D1. ] Eastern Airlines proposed to emerge from bankruptcy with more flights and less cash to cushion it in any economic downturn than it had previously proposed. [ D1. ] Alcott & Andrews filed for bankruptcy protection. The chain of clothing stores that caters to working women was founded by Michael Jeffries, who in the early 1980's developed the concept of large specialty stores aimed at the burgeoning market of well-paid women working in offices. [ D1. ] The worries of domestic wine makers are mounting, along with disagreements over how to respond. Shipments of domestic wines, which declined 4.9 percent last year after falling 1 percent in 1987, have dropped 7 percent in the first six months of this year. [ D1. ] Times Mirror named a new publisher of its flagship paper, The Los Angeles Times, appointing David Laventhol, a former Newsday executive editor, to replace W. Thomas Johnson Jr. [ D4. ] El Diario/La Prensa's publisher led a group of investors that bought the newspaper from Gannett. Terms were not disclosed, but executives valued the deal at more than $20 million. [ D4. ] Anne Mollegen Smith was named editor in chief of McCall's. She has been editor in chief of Working Woman magazine since 1984 and held top editorial positions at Redbook and Glamour. [ D4. ] Procter & Gamble agreed to sell Crush International to Cadbury Schweppes for $220 million in cash. [ D3. ] Saab-Scania refused to confirm or deny a report that Ford was negotiating for an interest in its car division. [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY Orders to American factories slumped 1.7 percent in July, to the lowest level in eight months. In other signs of sluggishness, shipments of manufactured goods fell 1.9 percent and inventories shot up 1.1 percent. [ D1. ] The nation's biggest retailers issued mixed sales reports for August, with apparel retailers and department stores faring better than mass merchandisers during the back-to-school season. [ D2. ] Prices paid to farmers for raw products dropped 1.4 percent from July to August. [ D2. ] Some regulators warn that they have found a provision in the savings and loan bailout law that could force owners of institutions to build up large cash reserves faster than it was believed the law required. [ D2. ] MARKETS Stock prices chalked up modest gains, except in the transportation sector. Trading was relatively thin in advance of the Labor Day weekend and volume shrank to one of its lowest levels in recent months. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.12 points, to 2,737.27. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very thin trading, as traders shrugged off a stronger dollar and a report showing a 1.7 percent drop in factory orders during July. [ D5. ] Copper futures prices surged in late trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York on supply jitters prompted by plans for a strike at a mine in Chile, the world's largest producer. [ D14. ] The dollar rose sharply against all major currencies and reached a two-month high against the yen. [ D14. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The really exciting thing about the American economy is that there is no excitement. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] American Airlines' strong assets make it an attractive target that is determined to resist overtures. Market Place. [ D6. ] William H. Maynard Jr. is switching to a position in sales promotions. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D6. ]

title: Racial Pattern Is Found in Boston Mortgages
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston criticized mortgage lenders in this city today, saying that the percentage of loans for properties in predominantly black neighborhoods was substantially lower than that in white neighborhoods.

title: Labor Day Celebration in Three-State Region; New Jersey
description: Although vacationers will be packing their bags and signaling the unofficial end of summer this weekend along the New Jersey shore, the Labor Day holiday still promises a variety of activities in all parts of the state. FLEMINGTON FAIR.The Flemington Fair, the state's oldest agricultural fair (133 years) and one of the East's largest, is again offering its mixture of music, midway rides, auto racing and 4-H animal judging. Today, the annual firemen's parade will open the holiday weekend followed by competitions among area volunteer departments, including ladder-climbing and a tug of war. Stock cars, sprint cars and trucks will race from 2 to 8 P.M. tomorrow, Sunday and Monday. The racing program will end with a demolition derby on Monday. Musical offerings will include country-and-western, tunes of the 40's and 50's and a gospel performance at 11 A.M. Sunday. Some of the performances will be in a large barn on the 60-acre fairgrounds where visitors can sit on bales of hay. There are rides, games of chance and food stands throughout the fairgrounds. There will be animal judging each day, a petting zoo for youngsters and sheep-shearing exhibitions. Parking will cost $2 today and $3 the rest of the weekend. Admission today is $3.50 for adults and $1.50 for youngsters 7 to 13. Younger children will be admitted free. For the remainder of the weekend, admission for adults will be $4.50 and $2 for children over 6. Admission to the grandstand for the racing events is $6.50 today and $7 starting tomorrow. To reach the fair, take Route 22 west to Route 202 south to Flemington Circle, then take Route 31 north to the fairgrounds, or take Route 78 west from the Garden State Parkway to Exit 17 and go south on Route 31. Information: (201) 782-2413. COLONIAL ENCAMPMENT IN PORT MONMOUTH.A Colonial military encampment with a re-creation of a battle that took place on the banks of the Raritan Bay will be at the Spy House Museum Complex in Port Monmouth tomorrow and Sunday. Colonial militia units from Maine to South Carolina are coming to the 13th annual encampment. Visitors will be able to walk among the tents of the encampment and watch cooking demonstrations, Indian dancing and games played in the 1700's. Colonial crafts and scrimshaw will be on sale. Muskets and cannons will be fired, a skirmish will be enacted at 2 P.M. Saturday and the Battle of Shoal Harbor, in which local militia units foiled a British attack, will be staged at 2 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $2 for adults and $1 for children 12 and younger and the elderly. Hours are 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. tomorrow and 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Sunday. To reach the site, take the Garden State Parkway to Exit 117 and head east on Route 36 to Wilson Avenue and follow signs to the museum. Information: (201) 787-1807. BIRD WATCHING AT CAPE MAY.People who enjoy watching flights of birds migrating south can visit Cape May, where many of the birds rest and feed. Warblers and shore birds are already in full flight, and the hawk migration, which will peak later this month, has begun, says Pat Sutton, a teacher and naturalist at the Cape May Bird Observatory. The shore birds favor Higbee Beach. Other good locations are the bird refuge at the end of Sunset Boulevard, South Cape May Meadow and the north shore of Lily Lake off Lighthouse Avenue. On Sunday, starting at 7:30 A.M. from 1 Sunset Boulvard, the observatory staff will lead interested visitors to the places where many birds can be seen. To reach the site, take the Garden State Parkway to its southern end in Cape May. Information: (609) 884-2736. JAZZ AT WATERLOO.The New Jersey Jazz Society will reprise last year's successful Sunday afternoon concert at Waterloo Village when it offers six traditional jazz bands playing in the village's main tent and in the gazebo starting at noon. The lineup includes Marty Grosz's Little Orphan Newsboys; Warren Vache Sr.'s Syncopatin' Seven; the Condon Gang, with Ed Polcer; Randy Sandke's New York Jazz Band; Tex Wyndham's Red Lion Inn Jazz Band, and Jack Harkavy's Lost River Hellcats with the vocalist Carol Leigh. Admission is $15 in advance and $18 at the gate. Youngsters under 12 are admitted free. To reach the concert, take Interstate 80 west to Exit 25 and follow signs to Waterloo Village. Information: (201) 347-4700.

title: Princess Anne and Husband Agree to Separate
description: Princess Anne and her husband, Mark Phillips, have agreed to separate after nearly 16 years of marriage, Buckingham Palace said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Architectural Record to HDM New York, with a budget of $500,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the guilty plea entered by Salim B. Lewis and his investment firm, S. B. Lewis & Company, on criminal charges of securities violations reversed the roles played by two lawyers in the case. Gandolfo V. DiBlazi represents S. B. Lewis & Company; Stanley Arkin represents Mr. Lewis.

title: I.O.C. Moves to Keep South Africa Out of Competition
description: The International Olympic Committee passed three resolutions today restricting the eligibility of athletes in Olympic Games. Two of the measures further isolate South Africa from international competition; the third places limits on the soccer tournament.

title: Pavarotti Vows Not to Sing At Lyric Opera of Chicago
description: Luciano Pavarotti said yesterday that he would not sing again at the Lyric Opera of Chicago and suggested that he and the Chicago company were bad luck for each other.

title: VW Quits Albany Port
description: Volkswagen of America has moved its Northeast distribution center from the Port of Albany to Rhode Island, the second major shipper the Albany port has lost in two months, officials said. Volkswagen said Wednesday that it was transferring its shipping center to Davisville, R.I., effective immediately.

title: At the Bar; The Ronan case: a giant legal battle over a tiny company.
description: It began simply enough as a power struggle between two co-owners over control of a tiny paint company in the South Bronx.

title:
About Real Estate;
Rockaway Area Seeks Housing Curb
description: LEAD: The potential of developing housing close to oceanfront beaches in Queens has attracted builders to Rockaway Park and Belle Harbor in the Rockaways in recent years, but the incentive to build such housing could be reduced under a rezoning proposal.

title: Books of The Times; How Shakespeare Became a Man for All Centuries
description: Reinventing Shakespeare A Cultural History From the Restoration to the Present By Gary Taylor Illustrated. 461 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $29.95.

title: Review/Art; Words and Symbols From Matt Mullican
description: Matt Mullican's installation at the Museum of Modern Art is a disappointment. Over the last decade, Mr. Mullican has developed a considerable reputation as a performance artist and a maker of posters, banners, oilstick rubbings and stained-glass pieces on which he has emblazoned obscure pictographs. Like other Conceptual artists today, he is enraptured by language. His images are derived from road signs and scientific codes, from maps and architectural plans. As part of a series of posters he designed in 1984, Mr. Mullican used the concentric circles that typically connote a target, but placed underneath them the word Heaven. An ''i'' in white against a black field appeared above ''Death.'' ''Life'' accompanied the same letter in black against white.

title: 14 Hurt as Capital Highway Bridge Collapses
description: A bridge being built over a major roadway collapsed in the morning rush hour today in this suburb of Washington, injuring 14 people, the state police said.

title: Eileen W. Hesse Becomes a Bride
description: Eileen Weinberg Hesse, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Weinberg of New York, was married yesterday to Larry Sherman Toulouse, a son of Mrs. Thomas Toulouse of Topeka, Kan., and the late Mr. Toulouse. Judge Doris T. Friedman of Westchester County Family Court officiated at the ceremony, at La Reserve Hotel in White Plains.

title: El Diario Sold by Gannett To Group Led by Publisher
description: A partnership led by the publisher of El Diario/La Prensa acquired the newspaper yesterday from the Gannett Company, the parties said yesterday.

title: A Pritzker 'Hobby' Is Expanding Abroad
description: ''I love going through factories,'' said Robert A. Pritzker. ''Everybody has his own hobbies. That's mine.''

title: Mrs. Pollard's Unnecessary Ordeal
description: LEAD: A two-member board has again recommended that Mrs. Anne Pollard, the ailing wife of the convicted spy Jonathan Jay Pollard, be denied parole. Following a hearing Aug. 22 at the Federal prison camp in Danbury, Conn., the examiners said they would recommend to the regional parole commissioner that Mrs.

title: China to Tighten Controls
description: Vice Premier Yao Yilin said today that the Government would take even tougher retrenchment measures in the next three years to reduce inflation and restore market order.

title: John H. Williams, Executive, 76
description: John H. Williams, retired president and chief executive officer of Buck Consultants Inc., an actuarial concern with headquarters in Secaucus, N.J., died Monday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla., after a short illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Regulators in Quandary Over Part of Bailout Bill
description: Some regulators in the Treasury and the Office of Thrift Supervision are warning that they have found a provision in the savings and loan bailout law that could force institutions to build up large cash reserves faster than it was believed the law required.

title: Israeli Reservist Denies Links to Drug Dealers
description: Yair Klein, an Israeli mercenary, is at the center of an international clamor.

title: Idaho Shuts Border to Nuclear Waste From Colorado Weapons Plant
description: Fulfilling a vow he made in February, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus has closed Idaho's borders to shipments of radioactive waste from the Government's only plutonium processing plant, a move that could force the plant to halt production early next year.

title: McCall's Gets Editor In Chief
description: Anne Mollegen Smith, who has been editor in chief of Working Woman magazine since 1984 and has held top editorial positions at Redbook and Glamour, was named yesterday as editor in chief of McCall's magazine.

title: Grumman at Work On China Project
description: Work is continuing on a $250 million contract to modernize avionics on Chinese-made F-8 fighter jets despite the United States Government's suspension of military sales to China, said John O'Brien, the chairman and chief executive of the Grumman Corporation.

title: Mayoral Rivals Differ on Race Relations, Patronage and Charter Revision
description: The challengers to Mayor Edward I. Koch assert that he has contributed to racial tensions in New York City. Beyond the criticism, however, they offer few specific proposals to promote racial unity.

title: Ruiz's Ballot Removal Upheld
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday released a decision that removed former State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr. of the Bronx from the ballot because of Mr. Ruiz's felony conviction in February.

title: A New York During the 'World of Tomorrow'
description: When you and I were young, Maggie, there were El trains over Third and Sixth Avenues, cafeterias that were social centers for the otherwise unoccupied, demonstrations in Union Square, burlesque on 42d Street and such Mayors as Jimmy Walker and Fiorello H. La Guardia, who were nothing if not colorful, although not in the same way. That was a long time ago, 50 years and more back, but, art being art, it has not all vanished with time, and you can see it all hanging out on the main floor of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.

title: What Divides U.S. and Canada? Hint: It's Red and Has Big Claws
description: They voiced support for Colombia's efforts to deal with drug traffickers. They agreed that further assistance to Poland was crucial. And they concurred that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega must yield power as Panama's military leader.

title: Fuess Moves West
description: For Billings S. Fuess, the copywriter who created the line, ''Hershey's, the great American chocolate bar,'' Ogilvy & Mather's Fifth Avenue office was home for 23 years. But last month, Mr. Fuess left the agency to start his own advertising shop in Summit, N.J. Mr. Fuess is currently working on the second edition of a best-selling book, ''How to Advertise,'' with his co-authors, Kenneth Roman, chairman of the Ogilvy Group, and Jane Maas, president of Earle Palmer Brown/New York.

title: Red Ransom Is Running Like Top 2-Year-Old
description: The paddock scene before the sixth race at Belmont Park yesterday had the look of major stake. Fans crowded eight deep for a look at the runners, and owners such as Paul Mellon and Ogden Phipps watched intently as their horses were saddled.

title: New York's Roads and Bridges Falling Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Rose Implicated
description: Thomas P. Gioiosa bragged he was sheltering Pete Rose's track winnings from taxes, the mother of Gioiosa's former girlfriend testified in Federal court in Cincinnati yesterday.

title: Club Owners Ordered to Pay $10.5 Million to Players in Collusion Case
description: Including a strong reminder that major league baseball clubs engaged in ''conspiratorial conduct,'' an arbitrator awarded $10.5 million yesterday to players he said were financially damaged for the 1986 season as a result of the owners' collusion.

title: The City Council, Old and New: II
description: Unusual weight attaches to the choice of City Council members in Manhattan, as in the other borough races discussed yesterday. The proposed City Charter would make the Council larger and stronger, and members elected this fall would become its nucleus. These are our choices for Manhattan contests (one partially in the Bronx) in the Sept. 12 tests (one partially in the Bronx) in the Sept. 12 Democratic primary for which no serious general Democratic primary for which no serious general election challenges are in sight.

title: Argentina and Britain Move To Restore Diplomatic Ties
description: Argentina and Britain formally recognized the obvious today - that each country has continued to maintain a diplomatic presence in the other's capital despite the rupture in diplomatic relations during the war over the Falkland Islands seven years ago.

title: Factory Orders Post 1.7% Decline for July
description: Orders to American factories slumped 1.7 percent in July to the lowest level in eight months, the Government said today, in a report indicating that growth remains subdued.

title: Trio at Bradley's
description: The trio of Kenny Barron on piano, David Williams on bass and Ben Riley on drums is performing tonight through Saturday at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). There is a $10 cover and an $8 minimum.

title: Wine Makers Face Hard Truth
description: With the sales decline that began in 1987 accelerating ominously, the worries of domestic wine makers are mounting, along with disagreements over how to respond.

title: Housing Index At 4-Year Low
description: An index measuring the ability of the typical American family to buy a house fell in July to the lowest level in nearly four years. The National Association of

title: Alcott & Andrews Seeking Protection From Creditors
description: Alcott & Andrews, a chain of clothing stores that caters to working women, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.

title: Helen Johnson Dies; Ex-Union Lawyer, 68
description: Helen Johnson, a lawyer and former trustee of the Experiment for International Living, a student exchange group, died of colon cancer Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 68 years old.

title: Bankruptcy Plan Revised By Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines proposed to its unsecured creditors yesterday that it emerge from bankruptcy with more flights and less cash than it had previously planned.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Monday listing the previous week's active stocks misstated the earnings of C. R. Bard Inc. In the previous 12 months the company earned $1.49 a share, for a five-year annual growth rate of 20 percent.

title: Chicago Merc Suspends 4
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange today suspended and fined four traders in its Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures pit, accusing them of prearranging trades on the day of the October 1987 stock market crash.

title: Measure Protecting S.R.O. Housing Is Lifted
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday lifted a temporary legal measure blocking the demolition or conversion of single-room-occupancy housing in New York City.

title: Frustrated Strawberry Admits He's Struggling
description: Darryl Strawberry has finally broken his silence after refusing to speak to reporters for the last month. He admitted today that he was ''very disappointed the way I've been playing all season'' and promised a new effort to help spark the Mets.

title: Excess Alarms Feared From Bomb Detector
description: A new bomb detector that the Government has ordered airlines to install at large airports cannot reliably spot the type of bomb that caused the crash of a jetliner over Scotland in December, critics say.

title: Leaping Slowly From Theater to Cabaret
description: ''Doing a cabaret act is a very heavy exposure of who you are, both as a person and an artist,'' Christine Andreas said the other day. ''Before putting together an act that I knew would have to be quite autobiographical, I figured I'd better collect some more information about my life. In the last few years, having a baby and the experience of 'Legs Diamond' made me feel I was finally ready to call the shots myself.''

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Norman Takes One-Shot Lead: Greg Norman shot an eight-under-par 64 yesterday and took a one-stroke lead after the first round of the Greater Milwaukee Open in Franklin, Wis. Wayne Grady, Phil Blackmar, Curt Byrum and Steve Pate were one shot behind on a windy, overcast day at the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course.

title: Marathon For Proud Mother
description: Next to running for United States President, playing the United States Open is one of the cruelest tests of character and endurance ever devised. Just to get through the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary of the first two rounds is a triumph of body and soul.

title: The Arrival of World War II: An Anticlimax
description: LEAD: I was in my home in Paris the day the Second World War began, Sept. 1, 1939, but I do not remember much about it - not because I was too young (I was 10) but because it was almost an anticlimax.

title: Addenda
description: * Wishner-Cody Corporate Communications has formed an associate relationship with First Financial Advertising Ltd., a British financial communications firm.

title: Labor Day Celebration in Three-State Region; Westchester
description: The Labor Day weekend in Westchester County will be celebrated with a good measure of leisure, both outdoors and in. There will be a song-filled salute to the work ethic in America, nature walks in search of butterflies - even a horse show and a chess tournament open to novices and experts alike. CONCERT IN SOMERS.In a tribute to laborers everywhere, Muscoot Farm Park in Somers will present a musical revue on Monday called ''Songs of the Working Class,'' led by Jeffrey Main, a guitarist. Among the songs will be Bruce Springsteen's ''River,'' the Rolling Stones's ''Salt of the Earth,'' Woodie Guthrie's ''Deportee'' and the folksy anthem ''This Land Is Your Land.'' Visitors are encouraged to bring a lunch and join in the singing. The concert will begin at 1 P.M. On Sunday, from noon to 4 P.M., country and western music will take center stage with a performance by the four-piece band Southern Cookin'. During the concert, visitors may swing their partners during a square dance, to be directed by Slim Sterling. There will also be bread-baking and bee-keeping demonstrations on Sunday. The county-owned turn-of-the-century interpretive farm may be reached from Exit 6 of Interstate 684. Turn west on Route 35, and south on Route 100. The park is about one mile down the road. Admission to all events is free. Information: (914) 232-7118. HORSE SHOW IN BEDFORD.Jumping, trotting, velvet-trimmed equestrian outfits and braided manes will make up the rich tableau in Bedford where the Coker Farm Labor Day Horse Show is scheduled for Monday. The free competition, from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., is open to all ages; participants need only bring a horse or pony and a trailer. Of course, most will prefer to watch from the sidelines as the sleek animals demonstrate their jumping ability and overall grace and grooming. A jumping derby, the show's highlight, will start at 11 A.M., carrying a $5,000 prize. Revlon, the cosmetics concern, is sponsoring the show. The Coker Farm is on Stonehill Road and may be reached by taking Route 22 north and then heading north on Route 121. Proceed for about one mile and turn right onto Stonehill Road. Information: (914) 234-3954. BUTTERFLY SAFARI IN CROSS RIVER.A butterfly expedition on Sunday at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River will attempt to spot monarchs, viceroys, fritillaries, mulberry wings and other species as they float over open fields. Led by Alex Shoumatoff, a lepidopterist, the free program will leave from the reservation's Trailside Nature Museum at 2 P.M. The butterflies are to be observed, not collected. With 4,700 acres, Ward Pound Ridge is the largest of the county's parks and is open daily for hiking and picnicking from 9 A.M. to dusk. Also of interest is the nature museum, open from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission to the park and museum are free, but parking costs $4. The reservation is at the junction of Routes 35 and 121 in Cross River; take Exit 6 of Interstate 684, turn east on Route 35 and south on Route 22. Information: (914) 763-3993. CHESS TOURNAMENT IN KATONAH.At the John Jay Homestead State Historic Site in Katonah, mental labor will be wrought during a free chess tournament on Monday. The 14th annual tournament, open to all ages and abilities, commemorates John Jay, who, besides being the first Chief Justice of the United States and the second governor of New York, was a fine chess player as well. Registration starts at 9 A.M., and the competition will last until 4:30 P.M. Participants should take a board, chess pieces, a clock and lunch. Tours will be given throughout the weekend of the first floor of the 66-room mansion, whose modest beginnings date to 1787 when it was built by the Jay family as a six-room farmhouse. Jay retired there in 1801, and the house - handsomely added to over the years - remained in his family until 1953. The homestead is open today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Sunday and Monday from noon to 4 P.M. Tours leave every half-hour. Admission is free, and picnics on the 60-acre grounds are welcomed. To reach the site, take Exit 6 from Interstate 684, turn east on Route 35 and south on Route 22. Information: (914) 232-5651. FIREWORKS IN RYE.Playland, the Art Deco amusement park on Long Island Sound in Rye, will be the scene this weekend of fireworks, high-diving feats and live musical revues. The fireworks will burst over the park's man-made lake tonight at 9:15. The diving performances, highlighted by an 80-foot plunge, will be performed five times daily, today through Monday, starting at 1:45 P.M. A musical retrospective of tunes from the last five decades will also be performed five times each day, beginning at 2:30 P.M. Playland is open from noon to midnight today through Sunday, and noon to midnight on Monday. Admission is free, and an 11-ride ticket book costs $12.50. The beach and pool are open every day, with beach prices $2.25, except for children under 50 inches in height who pay 50 cents. Pool admission is $3.50 for adults, $1.50 for children under 50 inches. Beach and pool admission is free for infants. Parking is $2.50 today, $4 tomorrow and Sunday, and $5 on Monday. There is a Playland exit, No. 19, on Interstate 95. Information: (914) 921-0370.

title: Joe Collins, Former Yankee, 66
description: Joe Collins, a first baseman for 10 years with the New York Yankees, died today at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: Review/Operetta; Romberg's 'Desert Song' In City Opera Revival
description: ''The Desert Song'' has an infallible plot, a perfunctory but assured book and a score that is sturdy and sufficient but (''One Alone'' apart) scarcely more. It is not a masterpiece of operetta, but it is a sure bet in the theater, and holds up well even under the hard-boiled, lackluster treatment accorded it in the current revival of the New York City Opera's 1987 production.

title: Sanchez and Mayotte Outdo Debris and Din
description: Out in the breeze and sunshine on Court 16, the man who had suffered the worst Grand Slam defeat in his storied career just the night before within the gloom of the cavernous Stadium Court contemplated a shot and doubled up in a convulsion of laughter.

title: Envoys' Spouses Learn What a Man's Place Is
description: Practicing the etiquette of a diplomatic spouse, a Washington real estate lawyer stepped up to President Bush at a recent White House reception and introduced himself as ''Mr. Julia Chang Bloch.''

title: Suspect in Brooklyn Slaying Surrenders
description: An 18-year-old white youth who investigators say was the gunman in the racial killing of a black teen-ager in Brooklyn walked into a police station in Oneonta, N.Y., early yesterday and surrendered, the police said.

title: Seymour Krim, Author And Critic, Dies at 67
description: Seymour Krim, an author and critic, was found dead, apparently of a drug overdose, in his Manhattan apartment Wednesday night, the police said. He was 67 years old.

title: Abboud Partners Raise Bank Stake
description: A/C Limited Partnership, which is controlled by A. Robert Abboud, chairman and chief executive of the First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., and Frank C. Cimak, First City's vice chairman and secretary, has raised its stake in the Houston-based bank holding company to the equivalent of 8.8 percent, from 6.5 percent, based on its holdings of both stock and stock options.

title: French Sign LeMond
description: Greg LeMond, the new world professional road racing champion and the two-time Tour de France winner, has agreed to a three-year, $5.7 million contract with a combined French team.

title: Bryant May Miss Year
description: Kelvin Bryant, the Washington Redskin running back who has been sidelined all summer because of injuries suffered in a car accident, has been advised by doctors to sit out the entire 1989 season, the team announced last night.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SEW WHAT,'' a workshop that teaches children ages 5 to 11 and their families how to make belt pouches, bean bags or pillows, 1 to 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in Central Park, at Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, south of the Great Lawn at 79th Street. Free. Reservations and information: 772-0210. ''THE RED LION,'' a story by Diane Wolkstein, as told by Terry Miller, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen Statue in Central Park, Fifth Avenue and 72d Street. Free. ''TOY BOOKS EXHIBITION,'' a show of century-old toy books - small-format publications for children - printed by stationers in the South Street Seaport, on view through Labor Day, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, at Bowne & Company Stationers, 211 Water Street. Free. Information: 669-9419. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. THE INTREPID, the aircraft carrier sea-air-and-space museum, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays, with the last tour at 4 P.M., at Pier 86, 46th Street and the Hudson River. Admission: children, $2.50, the elderly, $4; others, $4.75. Information: 245-2533. BOSCOBEL RESTORATION, the refurbished, authentically restored 18th-century home of States Morris Dyckman, surrounded by fruit groves and gardens, open daily except Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; last tour, 4:15 P.M. In Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y. Admission: ages 6 to 14, $2.50; under 6 free; the elderly, $4; others, $5. Information: (914) 265-3638. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden, 8:30 A.M. to sunset daily, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971. THEODORE ROOSEVELT SANCTUARY, a preserve of 12 wooded acres, with trees and vines planted to attract birds, 134 Cove Road, Oyster Bay, L.I. Admission: $1.50. Information: (516) 922-3200.

title: Film Maker Is on Board of Arab Group
description: The maker of a pro-Palestinian documentary about the uprisings in the Israeli-occupied territories said yesterday that she has served for more than two years on the board of an organization supported by Arabs. The organization, the Arab American Cultural Foundation, has promoted itself as a sponsor of the film.

title: The Hidden Issue
description: LEAD: Mary will not vote in the mayoral primary or in the general election. She is not a voluntary participant in New York City's political process. Her life, however, is a powerful reminder of the central issues in the mayoral race.

title: Review/Music; Rolling Stones Open in Philadelphia
description: Strutting, preening, pointing his toes and spitting out lyrics, Mick Jagger led a lean, efficient Rolling Stones in the opening stadium show of the band's first tour since 1981. If the 46-year-old Mr. Jagger feels his age, he wasn't showing it Thursday night at Veterans Stadium here; even between songs, he stalked the stage and jittered with energy, with gestures that were both balletic and funky. Behind him, the Stones pounded out trim, hard-riffing versions of both the expected songs - like ''Start Me Up'' and ''Honky Tonk Women'' - and less likely choices, including ''Shattered'' and ''Undercover of the Night.''

title: White House
description: It may be a variation of the ''good-cop, bad-cop'' routine. It may be a subtle political ploy. Or it may be only symbolic of the way George Bush conducts business.

title: Dow Gains 9.12, but Airline Stocks Retreat
description: Stock prices chalked up modest gains yesterday, except in the closely watched transportation sector, where they slumped.

title: Koch Asserts Con Ed Misled City on Blast
description: Consolidated Edison ''misled the city and residents of Gramercy Park'' about the danger of asbestos contamination from a powerful steam-pipe explosion and criminal charges may be warranted, Mayor Edward I. Koch said last night.

title: Study Doubts Depression Raises Cancer Risk
description: Although psychological depression is suspected of reducing the body's immunological defenses, researchers now say it does not appear to increase the risk of cancer.

title: Auctions
description: If America's fascination with automobiles can be termed a love affair, then what started last night in Auburn, Ind., is an orgy of national proportion. Something like 150,000 people are expected to drop in.

title: Sol Greitzer, 63, Longtime Violist in Philharmonic
description: Sol Greitzer, a prominent violist and the New York Philharmonic's longtime principal player until he resigned in 1985, died of a stroke yesterday in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: A Killing That May Alter an Election
description: The death of a 16-year-old black youth at the hands of a white gang in Brooklyn last week has indelibly marked the 1989 mayoral primary and is likely to intensify the racial polarization of the electorate in the days to come, many political consultants and politicians say.

title: Cadbury to Acquire P.&G.'s Crush Drinks
description: The Procter & Gamble Company agreed today to sell its Crush International beverage operations to Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British candy and beverage company, for $220 million in cash.

title: More Children Are Living With Stepparents
description: The number of American children living with stepparents has risen sharply as women have children before marriage and parents change spouses, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: Aloha Airlines, a subsidiary of privately held Aloha Airgroup, said it had ordered four Boeing 737-300 aircraft, with options on an additional four. The transaction has a potential value of about $250 million, the airline said. Aloha said it would begin receiving deliveries of the aircraft in November 1992. The 737-300's will be powered by CFM International 56-3 engines. CFM International is a joint venture of the General Electric Company and Snecma of France.

title: Correction
description: Yesterday's editorial on World War II was illustrated with a cartoon by Bill Mauldin. The line crediting Mr. Mauldin was omitted in error.

title: Juror's Illness Delays Longest Criminal Trial
description: What is probably the longest criminal trial in United States history was delayed again today because a juror was ill.

title: Black Leaders Travel To Brooklyn Meeting
description: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan and several other black political and religious leaders traveled to the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday to meet with white community leaders in an effort to repair the damage done to racial relations by the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: 3d Generation Ascends At Marks Bros. Jewelers
description: Marks Brothers Jewelers, which estimates that it is the nation's fifth-largest retail jewelry chain, will soon be getting a new president and chief executive, Hugh Marks Patinkin.

title: KEY RATES
Basses in Filing On Sensormatic
description: An investment group led by Sid R. Bass and Lee M. Bass, two members of the wealthy Fort Worth family, has filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise its stake in the Sensormatic Electronics Corporation to 14.9 percent from 7.8 percent.

title: Topics of The Times; Joe Alsop's Kith
description: To his critics, Joseph Alsop was a rabid cold warrior and a snob who cultivated only the high and the mighty. To others, his death this week at 78 recalled the years when Washington's swaggering columnists enjoyed a spotlight not yet dominated by TV news celebrities. Yet Joe Alsop was more interesting than his caricature.

title: Economic Scene; The Difficult Task Facing the Fed
description: THE really exciting thing about the American economy at this point is that there is no excitement. Despite everything - the near-record seven-year longevity of the expansion, the anxieties about recession and inflation, the mounting national debt, which has been exacerbated by the bailout of savings and loans, the relatively high level of interest rates and the high cost of the dollar in international markets - the United States economy continues to climb doggedly upward.

title: Irish Begin Season in Classic Style
description: The coach had wondered aloud if this Notre Dame team would win more than two games this season. Lou Holtz had spoken of the greatness of the 1989 Fighting Irish, but the problem was that he had used his superlatives in the past tense.

title: Restaurants
description: Auntie Yuan, the midnight-cool, elegantly modern Chinese restaurant on First Avenue, is the most enduring and consistent member of the David Keh clan (Pig Heaven, David K's, David K's Cafe). Chinatown aficionados may inveigh against the uptown prices here, which are largely a function of neighborhood rents. Yet there are times when I'd happily pay $18 for a platter of terrific orange beef served professionally in a quiet, upholstered setting rather than be herded into a fluorescent-seared, crashingly loud Chinatown block party.

title: People
description: * Patricia Doyle has been promoted to managing director of LGFE, formerly Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.

title: 'Day of Outrage' March Ends in Violence
description: The vanguard of a mile-long protest march against racism and the recent killing of a black youth clashed with the police last night as it tried to force its way through lines of helmeted, riot-equipped officers on the Brooklyn approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 Latvian nationalists will demand that Moscow grant their region ''special status'' within the Soviet Union, said leaders of Latvia's largest political movement. Page A1

title: Wall St. Is Playing The Jobs Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: What Do Museums Owe Donors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Photl Advances, Deftly Defeating Fitzgerald
description: In his decade of competition at the United States Open, Ivan Lendl has acquired much more than his three singles titles. Over the 10 years and through the countless interviews, he has gained a sense of both perspective and humor, honed a sharp wit and crafted an altogether engaging smile.

title: Labor Board Workers to Get New Training
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ordered its regional offices to provide new training to employees who handle inquiries about workers' rights, a move stemming from a study by an anti-union group that said the board often provided inaccurate information.

title: College News Service
description: Apple Computer Inc. and the Gannett Company, which publishes USA Today, said Wednesday that they were starting a daily electronic news service for college newspapers. The companies said the USA Today-Apple College Information Network would offer graphics and news stories drawn from USA Today and other dailies in the Gannett newspaper chain. Susan Bokern, a Gannett sales and marketing executive, said the project had been tested at 45 colleges and would go into operation next month.

title: Browns' Mack Gets Four-Game Suspension
description: Kevin Mack, the Cleveland Browns' running back, was suspended for four games by the National Football League yesterday for violating the league's substance-abuse policy.

title: Newspaper Hearing Set
description: The United States Supreme Court has scheduled arguments for Oct. 30 on whether The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press may merge some operations to cut costs.

title: Bakker Committed for Psychiatric Tests
description: Jim Bakker was committed to a mental institution in handcuffs and leg shackles today after a psychiatrist and his defense lawyer reported that he was hallucinating and cowering in a fetal position under a couch in the lawyer's office.

title: Dining Out Guide: Bargains on the Upper East Side
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Anatolia

title: John Steptoe, 38, Illustrator, Dies; He Also Wrote Children's Books
description: John Steptoe, a writer and illustrator of children's books who won several awards for his work, died of AIDS on Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Saab Is Silent On Ford Report
description: The Swedish auto maker Saab-Scania A.B., facing mounting losses, today refused to confirm or deny a news report that the Ford Motor Company was negotiating to buy an interest in its ailing passenger car division. After a board meeting today, Jan-Erik Larsson, head of Saab's auto division, declined to respond to a report in the Stockholm newspaper Expressen that a takeover deal with Ford was imminent.

title: LATVIANS TO SEEK A 'SPECIAL STATUS' WITHIN THE U.S.S.R.
description: Defying a warning from the Kremlin to curb separatist and nationalist calls in the Baltic republics, the leadership of the largest political movement in Latvia said today that it would demand that Moscow grant the republic ''special status'' within the Soviet Union.

title: Burlington Journal; Homeless Cite '27 Will In Demanding a Haven
description: The school that Elihu B. Taft's money built is an impressive structure, red brick with white columns facing west toward Lake Champlain from its perch in Burlington's affluent hill section.

title: Washington Mayor Assails U.S. Officials on Reports of Drug Use
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., stung by new allegations that he has used drugs, denied tonight that he had ever done so and charged that the allegations resulted from ''blatant'' disclosures to reporters by Federal officials who wanted ''to get headlines and to assassinate my character.''

title: Even in Absence, Koch Draws Most Debate Fire
description: Even in his absence, Mayor Edward I. Koch was the target of most of the spirited exchanges among his three Democratic opponents at a debate conducted yesterday by Spanish-language radio and television stations.

title: When Mom Gets Sick, We Don't Cut Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Not Trivialize The Woodstock Era
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY THE LAST LAUGH

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Blythe in the Village

title: At The Movies
description: Romero Films Poe

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The President was big on lobsters today. I was big on pork.'' - Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada. [ A18:5. ]

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: For Giants' Cooks, It's Time to Fret
description: The week leading up to the final squad reductions is always an anxious one in the National Football League. And 13 of the 60 players sharing the locker room here at Giants Stadium will be gone by next Tuesday, when the teams set their rosters at 47.

title: Out of Towner's Series Returns With Dance
description: Dance Theater Workshop's Out of Towners series is devoted to the proposition that New York City is not the cultural capital of the world. Canceled last summer in the face of increasing financial problems, the series is back this year with dance, music and theater from as close as Providence, R.I., and as far away as San Francisco, Seattle, Africa and New Zealand.

title: U.S. Is Blamed for Fatty Lunches in Schools
description: School lunchroom cooks are hampered in efforts to provide nutritious meals because the Government donates mainly ''fat-laden foods'' like ground beef, pork and luncheon meats, a consumer health group said Wednesday.

title: Comparing Their Answers: Setting a Tone for the City
description: In separate interviews last month, The New York Times asked the six New York City mayoral candidates to discuss some of the major problems facing the city in 1989 and how they would deal with them. This is the fifth of six articles comparing their responses. Excerpts from the interviews appear [ below ] .

title: Market Place; Looking for Value In Airline Assets
description: AMERICAN AIRLINES, considered by Wall Street to be a prime takeover target, has substantial assets that could generate huge amounts of cash to finance a bid. But the airline is also headed by an executive who could mount a strong defense.

title: Morris Dalitz, 89, Ex-Bootlegger And Owner of Las Vegas Casinos
description: Morris Barney Dalitz, a Prohibition Era bootlegger and prominent figure in the casino industry in Las Vegas, Nev., in the 1950's and 1960's, died yesterday at his home there. He was 89 years old and had been ill for some time.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Publisher at Los Angeles Times
description: LEAD: The Times Mirror Company, in an unexpected shift, today named a new publisher of its flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, appointing David Laventhol, the company's president, to replace W. Thomas Johnson Jr. Mr. Johnson, 47 years old, who had been the publisher of The Times for ror vice chairman, was given the new positions of chairman of The Los Angeles Times and chairman of the Times Mirror newspaper management committee.

title:
Labor Day Celebration in Three-State Region;
Long Island
description: LEAD: A clambake to benefit the Montauk Lighthouse, an international Jewish arts festival, an Indian powwow, a rodeo and Sesame Street characters are Long Island fare for the Labor Day weekend. CLAMBAKE ON MONTAUK. The fund-raising clambake, to be held in the shadow of the historic lighthouse at the state concession stand in Montauk State Park, begins at 7 P.M.

title: Tandy's Grid Unit Adds to Computer
description: The Grid Systems Corporation of Fremont, Calif., a unit of the Tandy Corporation, said it had shipped the first CD-ROM drive specifically designed for battery-operated laptop computers. CD-ROM stands for compact disk read only memory. The drives store large amounts of data using the same technology that compact disk players use to store music.

title: Anne E. Shusted Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Elizabeth Shusted, the daughter of Assemblyman and Mrs. Thomas J. Shusted of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday to William Joseph Barker Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barker of Wynnewood, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Graham at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Haddonfield.

title: Wellington Powell, 89, Executive for A.T.&T.
description: Wellington Powell, a retired vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died of cancer Thursday at the Washington Hospice. He was 89 years old and had moved to Washington from Manhattan three years ago.

title: Communists in Baltics Shying From Kremlin
description: Faced with the threat of disastrous defeat in coming local elections, Communist Party leaders in the Baltic republics are maneuvering to distance themselves from the central party leadership in Moscow.

title: Sterling Motor Increases Rebates
