A likely effect of the plan would be to channel many of them to Israel, whose Government has long sought such a move.

title: The 49ers' Standard, With a New Twist
description: Jerry Rice is the epitome of the National Football League player who emerges from a small town and a small school and wonders if he fits with his new team in his new city. Rice was born in Starkville, Miss., and grew up in nearby Crawford. He played football at a Division I-AA school, Mississippi Valley State.

title: Susan Rose and Joanna Ferrone - Entrepreneurs
description: Since his humble birth on a cocktail napkin in a New York bar four years ago, Fido Dido has grown into an international superstar. The deceptively simple cartoon character now appears on T-shirts in Manhattan, yo-yos in Australia, lunch boxes in Japan and even television commercials in Europe and Hong Kong.

title: 'America Is Still a Primative'
description: SECRETARY of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner recently launched an ambitious program to develop a well-articulated national transportation policy. His effort will be appraised in no small measure by his ability to find the right role for high-speed rail in some of the nation's saturated corridors.

title: Christine Lahti Tries to Fashion A Spunky 'Heidi' Daniel Sullivan, the director, with Ms. Lahti and the actor David Pierce during rehearsals (Michael O'Neill): Christine Lahti in the film ''Running on Empty'' (pg. 9)
description: To Christine Lahti fans, there is something incorrigibly winning about the actress's lopsided grin, with the upper lip tilting rightward and the longish nose angling left, those sharp dimples, the auburn curly hair bobbing over one eyebrow, the dark eyes switching from mischief to grief in a second. Her trademark is a scarred, savvy look. ''Even at 10 years old I wasn't an ingenue,'' she says with a laugh. Her voice has a sardonic edge, an Ida Lupino huskiness; and, like Lupino, she most often plays, as Pauline Kael puts it, ''a woman who holds her own, who's too strong and too proud to turn helpless around men, and sometimes furiously regrets it.''

title: Shanley's 'Volcano' Bubbles With Burning Angst
description: On a hot, smoggy morning at the old M-G-M back lot (turned Lorimar-turned-Warner Brothers), it's easy to spot John Patrick Shanley inside Sound Stage 30. All you have to do is listen for the laughter. Sometimes gleeful, sometimes caustic, it lofts above the misty, cavernous sound stage where a raging typhoon is getting almost everyone wet, except Mr. Shanley, the director. As a very drenched Tom Hanks, who is wearing a safari jacket and khaki shorts (and a wetsuit), leaps off the side of a luxury schooner to rescue Meg Ryan in a deep tank of water where Esther Williams once paddled her way into American hearts, Mr. Shanley cracks up.

title: College Invites Public to Study the Constitutional Issues Science Raises
description: LEAD: THE accelerating developments in science and technology are creating new issues in society, many of which may affect basic Constitutional provisions and protections. In an effort to broaden public understanding of some of these issues, the Center of Science, Mathematics and Technology Literacy at Westchester Community College in Valhalla is offering a three-lecture series, ''Science, Technology and the Constitution,'' starting Sept.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE PERFECT PLACE. By Sheila Kohler. (Knopf, $15.95.) Cast as a psychological mystery, Sheila Kohler's first novel is mainly a portrait of a woman. The central figure is an anonymous narrator who recounts for us her gradual recollection of an incident she had apparently forgotten: a schoolmate's death years before, in which she was somehow involved.

title: In Israel, a Way to Woo More Soviet Jews
description: IN a meticulously appointed business complex here on the outskirts of the city, a large waiting room decorated in black, gray and shades of pink separates the Russians from the Westerners.

title: Diana Dorfman, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Diana Brooke Dorfman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Dorfman of Brooklyn, and Westhampton, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. James Alan Deutsch, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Deutsch of Brooklyn Heights, and Burrville, Conn. Rabbi A. Stanley Dreyfus performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Feuds in G.O.P. Force Supervisors Into Primary Contests
description: LEAD: THE incumbent Republican town supervisors in Cortlandt, Somers and Yorktown all have one thing in common: they failed to win their party's nomination to run for another term.

title: County Announces Playwriting Contest
description: LEAD: AT least one aspiring playwright will see his work on stage in the near future. The county is holding its third playwriting contest, and the winning work will be given a staged reading at Pace University in White Plains next winter or spring.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Massachusetts; 3 Police Horses Are Put to Work As 'Ice Breakers'
description: Two days in the saddle and already the new mounted police unit at the University of Massachusetts is a crowd pleaser.

title: Diving's New Image Is Keeping Classes Full
description: A new breed of scuba diver, drawn by lighter, safer equipment and diving's new, less masculine image, is helping to increase the sport's popularity. And diving is a skill that can be learned now and taken to tropical waters on winter vacations.

title: InYonkers, Flowers Lend Cheer to an Urban Landscape
description: LEAD: YONKERS has been planting tens of thousands of flowers, cleaning up graffiti and trash, restoring historic places and seeking good design in its redevelopment of downtown as the symbolic center.

title: Stephen Burrows: Sportswear Designer
description: Stephen Burrows has leapt back into the fashion world after a seven-year sabbatical with new ideas and up-to-date versions of his signature sportswear.

title: Plusses and Minuses for Jets
description: This weekend was good, mostly, for the Jets. Last weekend wasn't so good. And next week, when it really counts? The Jets' exhibition season ended with a 2-2 record, a so-so mark indicating perfectly that sometimes they were good, sometimes they weren't, and that they could have troublesome times ahead.

title: Millions for Muppets
description: As corporate takeovers go, it was not just another Mickey Mouse deal. Miss Piggy was also involved. Last week, the Walt Disney Company said it would acquire Henson Associates Inc., the company that created and owns the Muppets, in a deal that analysts valued as high as $150 million. It will combine Miss Piggy, Kermit the Frog and the other Muppets with Disney's roster of characters for use in Disney's theme parks, on television and in movies. The Muppets, who first appeared on a Washington television show in 1955, were created by Jim Henson, 52 years old. Mr. Henson, who is the voice of Kermit, will become a consultant to Disney as part of the deal, which a Disney executive called ''a business association made in family entertainment heaven.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Tennessee; New Course Offers 'Balanced' Debate On Abortion Issue
description: While the subject of abortion has often been addressed in college courses, the University of Tennessee has made the controversial issue into a three-credit course of its own that is being offered this fall. It is called ''Abortion: Moral Dilemma and Legal Debate.''

title: Question Of the Week; Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: Maybe. It has been legal for years to bet on baseball in Las Vegas, and Oregon has recently passed legislation to allow an N.F.L. football lotto betting system. So who are we kidding?

title: At Rally, Jackson Endorses Dinkins
description: LEAD: With the New York City mayoral primaries less than two weeks away, candidates spent the first day of the Labor Day weekend aggressively seeking support on street corners, in housing projects, at churches and at ethnic rallies.

title:
GARDENING;
The Well-Managed Compost Pile
description: LEAD: GARDENERS who have used newspaper as a mulch know that it eventually breaks down and is easily tilled into the soil. Much of the breakdown seems to result from earthworms that devour and digest their way through the layers of paper.

title: Cambodia Has Exhausted Every Step Short of War
description: A MONTH of peace talks on Cambodia ended in failure last week with the warring factions seeming intent on going back to the battlefield to settle matters there. Diplomats struggled to put the best face on the negotiations by saying they would reconvene the talks in a few months, but no one expects that to happen until the Cambodian armies have tested each other's strength.

title: The Fine Art of Delaying the Tax Cut
description: TWO and a half years ago, when New York State leaders announced agreement on a four-year plan to cut taxes, state politicians described the idea as if it heralded a new era. It was, they said, a tremendous step, sending a ''strong signal'' to the state's businesses, and, in the words of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, it was ''good for the people'' of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Numismatics column on Aug. 6 misidentified the statue in Grand Army Plaza in Manhattan and misstated the plaza's location. The statue is of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, and the plaza is at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. The column also misstated the site of Augustus Saint-Gaudens's home in 1907. It was in the White Mountains in New Hampshire.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Southeastern Connecticut: Old Melds With New
description: Nearly 20 million people visit Connecticut each year, but tourism officials in the southeastern part of the state are quick to boast that the majority of them come to this area.

title: A Party to Aid Venice
description: Prince Andrew and the Duchess of York danced into the early hours Friday at a gala organized by Save Venice Inc., an American organization that raises money for preserving the art treasures of this city.

title: Lilco Cheered For Ending Hunt
description: In response to your article on Lilco annulling the fox hunt (Aug. 13), I find it appalling that this kind of activity still goes on in this day and age.

title: Drug Ring Bombs Newspaper in Bogota
description: Colombia's narcotics traffickers brought the drug war to the capital today with a bomb that heavily damaged the offices of a leading newspaper, shattering windows and ripping off roofs of buildings in a two-block radius.

title: Advice On Picking Counselors
description: LEAD: UNSCRUPULOUS career consultants are bilking New Jerseyans out of thousands of dollars, says James J. Barry Jr., the director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Mail Call

title: 'No Author Is a Man of Genius to His Publisher'
description: They're a triumvirate: the agent is the person who doesn't call you back; the editor is your friend but he keeps getting shot out from under you; the publisher is a great guy before the book comes out, a cheapskate and a scoundrel after that. So go the familiar complaints of authors.

title: The World Has Never Been Quite The Same
description: THE DAY ON WHICH Western Europe took the final step into the most disastrous war in history was a fine one in London. The sun was bright and warm on Sept. 3, 1939, and the sky that Sunday morning was cloudless. But the news from Poland was bad. As I ate my eggs and bacon, I read that German panzers were knifing through the Polish defenses. Then the telephone rang. ''Better get in here, Chamberlain's broadcasting at 11,'' an Associated Press colleague reported. ''This may be it,''

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Shore Resorts Strive for an Endless Summer
description: LEAD: THE clusters of single-family homes and condominium projects that have been built along the beaches in New Jersey's coastal towns in the last decade are telltale signs that the towns themselves are no longer just summertime destinations. Now, hotels that traditionally played host to seasonal vacationers are following suit.

title: A BRAHMS TO FIT THE HALLE'S HALL
description: Solid, imposing and a little grim, the Halle Orchestra has for most of its 132 years reflected Manchester, England-the city that is its home. Yet as with industrial Britain in general, things seem to have slipped, to have worn a bit at the edges and lost their outer shine. The Halle which has veen led by such men as Hans Richter, Sir Thomas Beecham and Sir John Barbirolli, is no longer the international name it was before and just after World War II. Today it is conducted by Stanislaw Skrowacewski, and the respected and much-traveled professional seems intent on making the world a little more Halle-conscious.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Offering Rent-Buy Deals in a Soft Market
description: LEAD: THE housing market rebound that Long Island builders hoped for earlier this year did not materialize, and prospects for the fall and winter appear equally glum.

title: Triathlon Report Had Missteps
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Challenge Of Putting a Home On the Map
description: In August I celebrated a special anniversary: 10 years as a county resident.

title: OTB Plans Look to Race Track and Beyond
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fight on Indian Reservation As Casinos Divide Mohawks
description: Pro- and anti-gambling factions of Mohawk Indians fought today in a seven-hour confrontation on the St. Regis Akwesasne Indian Reservation, but there were no arrests and only minor injuries, the state police said.

title: TALKING: Sales Pitches; Looking Behind The Deals
description: ANYONE in the market for a new house or condominium, or one that has been converted from a rental, is probably being showered with a panoply of incentives as a result of the weakened marketplace.

title: Jan Lewis Weds Steven B. Elliott
description: Jan Marie Lewis, a daughter of Lieut. Col. William J. Lewis, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lewis of Hudson, Fla., was married yesterday to Steven Burton Elliott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Elliott of Brooklyn. The Rev. Converse P. Hunter, a Presbyterian minister, performed the interdenominational ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: It's Aikman for Dallas
description: Troy Aikman officially became the Dallas Cowboys' starting quarterback, beating out Steve Walsh in the duel of the high-priced rookies. Aikman, the first player taken in last April's draft, was introduced with the starting offensive unit in the Cowboys' exhibition game with Houston last night. That was the method that the new coach, Jimmy Johnson, had said he would use to make known his decision on which quarterback would start in Dallas's season-opener at New Orleans next Sunday.

title: Career Changes Are a Reflection Of Changing Times
description: LEAD: FOR reasons that have as much to do with economic change and technological advances as with a desire for personal fulfillment, many New Jerseyans are changing careers, a trend that is expected to continue in the coming decade.

title: Tribute of Sorts For Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Truro, Mass.;
Projects Halted In the Seashore
description: LEAD: WHEN Kenneth R. Loiselle bought two-thirds of an acre of oceanview property here for $450,000 last March, he knew he could not put up a house that cost more than the land.

title: Total Immersion in France
description: TRYING to learn French by taking one class a week is like trying to crawl to California from New York; it's possible, but chances are you'll probably give up midway. At least that was the conclusion I came to last winter after struggling for months at the French Institute/Alliance Francaise in New York. Somehow I could never manage to carve out enough time to study; there were always late nights at work, or errands to do, or something.

title: Festival's Fun Is a Test of Brawn
description: FRASIER PEHMOELLER showed how to toss the 100-pound, 13-foot-long tree trunk. ''You cup your hands,'' he said. ''You don't need to run. Just take a nice walk. When you're ready, let it go.''

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''There are lots of economists back at university jobs or driving trucks who did not have the guts to stick their necks out.'' - Scott Pardee, vice chairman, Yamaichi Securities.

title: Executives' Toolbags
description: Remember the jokes about the tuna sandwich in the attache case? These days, the sandwich is chic - wholesome fuel for those with better things to do than indulge at lunchtime - and the attache case isn't.

title: The Selling of Steinbrenner's Yankees
description: Yankee fans are mad at George Steinbrenner, again. Or still. Or more than ever.

title: Sarah Nichols Married to C. G. Duffy
description: Sarah Kirkland Nichols, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Nichols of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher George Duffy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Duffy of Hackensack, N.J., and Brewster, Mass. The Rev. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
College Football in the Era of Celebrity
description: LEAD: Any of us who has attended a college football game in the last decade knows how easy it is to coach. Heck, why not throw the bomb on first down? Shouldn't Perry Caruso be playing quarterback? (He is the backup quarterback, of course.) Why punt on fourth and 1? Why doesn't he throw more to the tight end?

title: Acceptance From John
description: Tommy John, who has been throwing baseballs almost every summer since he was 10 years old in the Terre Haute Little Leagues, says he would rather still be pitching, but the former Yankee has accepted that his career as a hurler is over.

title: THINKING MAN'S MINIMALIST: HONORING BARTHELME
description: ''The proper work of the critic is praise, and that which cannot be praised should be surrounded with a tasteful, well-thought-out silence.''

title: 6 Mayoral Rivals Turn to TV Game Shows in Effort to Win Gracie Mansion
description: Everybody loves a good game show. That includes Ed, Dave, Jay, Dick, Ron and Rudy. All six major-party mayoral rivals have spent tens of thousands of dollars to broadcast their campaign messages in between turns of the ''Wheel of Fortune,'' at roughly $3,600 a 30-second shot.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RUBBER DUCK RACE

title: Scouting Report For Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Menagerie Show Mixes the Bland And the Stunning
description: A VISIT to the menagerie show at the New Jersey Designer Craftsmen Gallery is like a frolic at the zoo, minus the roars and peanuts.

title: Freddie Redd Sums It Up in Three Blue Notes
description: There's a notion that if a jazz musician records for a decent record company and makes a reputation for himself, he'll receive, along with a contract, some health insurance, a retirement fund, keys to a new car and a happy prosperous life. Not so, and it wasn't so in 1960 and 1961, when the pianist and composer Freddie Redd recorded three albums for Blue Note Records - two of which are hard-bop classics - and then vanished into the same obscurity, partly self-made, he came from.

title: How Fighting Global Warming Could Be Painless and Profitable
description: UNWELCOME as it is, the prevailing view of energy and climate experts who fear a catastrophic warming of the globe is that Americans must make drastic sacrifices in their comfortable way of life. Already, Angelenos are on the cutting edge of this brave new world without leaf blowers and drive-through burger stands, facing new controls on everyday life just to clean up the breathing air, never mind the stratosphere.

title: The Commissioner Who Went One for One
description: In the course of explaining his decision on Pete Rose, A. Bartlett Giamatti permitted himself a digression that showed what kind of commissioner he might have been in the long run.

title: Julie A. Steinberg Becomes a Bride In Philadelphia
description: Julie Ann Steinberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin E. Steinberg of Merion Station, Pa., and Lieut. John Batterson Stetson 5th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stetson 4th of Haverford, Pa., were married yesterday at the Hotel Atop the Bellevue in Philadelphia. The civil ceremony was performed by Judge Judith J. Jamison of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas.

title: It's Off to College, in the Nick of Time
description: DOES experience help one conquer obstacles the second time around? Let's hope so. It seems that only yesterday (it was exactly 360 yesterdays ago) we were preparing to take our son to embark on his first year of college.

title: Washington Sets New Limits on the West's Water Tap
description: THE South Platte River begins as a rivulet in the snow peaks of the Rockies in Colorado and tumbles down the mountains to Cheesman Canyon south of Denver, where it broadens and quickens between steep slopes. Trout thrive in the icy waters. Hawks and eagles ride the updrafts from sun-baked canyon walls.

title: Towns Seek Limits on Plastic Use
description: AFTER the General Assembly failed to act this year to ban the use of plastic foam food packaging, more than a dozen communities have started to take the matter into their own hands.

title: INSIDE
description: Refugee Riot in Hong Kong

title: CONSUMER RATES
Profitable Year For the Pirates
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates say they will turn a modest profit this season even though the team is winning fewer games and drawing fewer fans.

title: One Team By Land, the Other By Sea
description: LEAD: AMPUTEES, paraplegics, blind people and those with other disabilities will race on land, able-bodied individuals will skipper boats on the Hudson, and the 52 Association for the Handicapped will benefit when the yearly 52 Regatta is held Sept. 9.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Madeleine Pelner Cosman; A Broker in Medical Practices
description: ARTIFACTS from the 15th and 16th centuries surround Dr. Madeleine Pelner Cosman in her office. Dr. Cosman says that the items, like a stained glass window depicting St. Luke, patron of physicians, and a carved wooden chair from Henry VIII's time, are a diversion and solace for her clients.

title: Assessing New York's Charter Change
description: THE proposed overhaul of New York City's charter would bring sweeping changes in the way planning and land-use decisions are made, but experts say they do not expect the revision to quicken the pace of development or dramatically shift the balance of power among City Hall, neighborhood advocates and New York's economically potent real estate industry.

title: Opera Orchestra Series To Be Carried on Radio
description: The three 1988-89 performances of the Opera Orchestra of New York will be broadcast on WNYC-FM (94.7) on three consecutive Sundays, starting today, at 7 P.M.

title: POSTINGS: Preservation an Issue; Opponents Fight Hartford Plan
description: A plan by a Canadian land development company for a $320 million project on the site of two historic buildings in Hartford faces an uncertain future as a result of opposition by preservation groups.

title: Jewish Reaction to Glemp Comments Is Mixed
description: American Jewish leaders had reactions ranging from shock to guarded optimism yesterday over the Polish Primate's call to renegotiate a 1987 agreement to move a Catholic convent from the site of the Auschwitz concentration camp.

title: S.M.U.'s Mustangs Gallop To Nowhere in Comeback
description: Years before a succession of parties this weekend welcomed tonight's return of football to Southern Methodist University after a two-year void brought on by scandal and disgrace, Ownby Stadium, a storied piece of the southeast corner of the S.M.U. campus, stood as a symbol of a university's attitude toward the game.

title: A French Presence in Lebanon, A Lebanese Presence in France
description: FOR months, French television viewers have watched scenes of Lebanese cowering in basements, bleeding in hospitals or lying dead amid the ruins of East Beirut under the firepower of Syrian and Muslim militias. Even though the victims are not French, the intensity of French news coverage of the civil war resembles the American obsession a decade ago with the Iranian takeover of the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: FASHION: On the Street; What the Well-Dressed Puddle-Jumper Wears
description: Rain has been a way of life this summer and a strain on fashion, no matter the length or looseness of dresses and skirts. New Yorkers and practiced visitors took it all calmly, breaking their stride only to make suprisingly graceful leaps at flooded Fifth Avenue corners. Tight short skirts rode up a bit, while long, loose ones were more likely to sweep dangerously close to a puddle and turn into a mop. Shoppers learned how to clutch bags and colorful umbrellas. When the water was too much even for gazelles to leap, some people just sloshed in and on. After all, getting there is the point.

title: Me and Machiavelli
description: ''BUENOS dias,'' I sang out one sunny morning in the suburbs of Washington. My wife looked up in surprise at my sudden eruption in a foreign language. I smiled innocently. ''Buenos dias,'' I sang again. But my greeting was anything but nonchalant. It was my opening move in a carefully constructed and covert strategy, and strategy was something I had come to appreciate during decades of diplomatic reporting and a couple of years at the State Department. Henry Kissinger would have been proud of me.

title: Tradition to Prevail at Jewish Festival
description: LEAD: IF the International Jewish Arts Festival of Long Island, which takes place today and tomorrow in Commack, is about tradition, then Shelley Ava Handler of West Islip and Judd Weisgal of Levittown should fit right in.

title: Outdoors; If You're Casting About for a Good Read
description: Fly fishermen who focus on trout are prone to regard all other forms of angling with disdain, and those who favor the dry, or floating, fly believe that theirs is the purest endeavor of all.

title: Mormons Oust First Indian in the Hierarchy
description: The Mormon Church has excommunicated the only American Indian who ever achieved a leading position in its hierarchy.

title: To Dress for Success, Try a Dress
description: The power suit seems to be losing some of its muscle.

title: Once Again, Racism Proves to Be Fatal In New York City
description: EARLY this summer, when Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing'' opened, some commentators, white ones, mostly, nervously predicted that the film's portrayal of racial divisions in Brooklyn might provoke riots by blacks. It didn't.

title: 'I HAD BOTCHED THIS CASE BEYOND BELIEF'
description: LEAD: LOVE'S EXECUTIONER And Other Tales of Psychotherapy. By Irvin D. Yalom. 270 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Turkic Republics Press Soviets to Loosen Reins
description: While world attention is focused on the Baltic Republics' steady independence march, a strange thing is happening along President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's southern flank.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: Sure, and reward his incredible denials, his total lack of remorse and his shady life style. Pete Rose's television huckstering of manufactured, overpriced ''memorabilia,'' on the very day of his suspension, should keep him out of baseball forever. Baseball will survive without Charlie Huckster. GERALD STERN New York

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Skidmore; New Dorm Option: Floor That Shuns All 'Substances'
description: Students of Skidmore College have a new dormitory option -living on a ''substance free'' floor -and the initial response indicates that the floor will be crowded for some time to come.

title: Timothy Goodell, A Lawyer, Weds Karen A. Jackson
description: Karen Ann Jackson and Timothy Bartlett Goodell were married yesterday in the Hall of Philosophy at the Chautauqua (N.Y.) Institution. The Rev. William H. Terry, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Despite the Gray, A Child of the 60's
description: Even though you consider me middle aged, Mr. Wolfsohn, I don't. Middle age is always leaping another 10 years ahead of me. Even as gray begins its relentless march across my head, I still consider myself a child of the 60's. During those turbulent and exciting times, I examined and re-examined my values. The glory of dropping out of society has faded as a childlike illusion, but the freedom to make choices that don't hurt other people is still with me.

title: What Am I Doing at Home?
description: AS September rolls around, I realize that I will not be returning to school. As a recent college graduate I must accept the responsibilities of the real world. I will find a job, buy a car and live, once again, with my parents.

title: Giants Take a Step Backward
description: The Giants, who had seemed to be making so much progress, regressed tonight in their final preseason game.

title: As Schools Open, Kean's Impact Iss Assessed
description: AS the 1989-90 school year begins this week for New Jersey's 1.08 million children in public schools, the barrage of educational reforms that have come from Trenton for almost eight years has finally abated.

title: A Seismic Shock for Education
description: The annual Gallup education poll sponsored by the professional educational fraternity Phi Delta Kappa often yields startling results.

title: Writer's Anger Is Misdirected
description: If the article by Karon Cooney was meant to be humorous, it was not. Thousands of people who are overweight - and especially those overweight since before puberty - have or will have, an extremely hard time losing and keeping off weight, according to Dr. Kenneth H. Cooper, the noted fitness guru and author.

title: Sandra Mossblad Is Wed in Omaha
description: Sandra Ann Mossblad and Francois Marcel Luethi were married yesterday at the Augustana Lutheran Church in Omaha. The Rev. Victor Schoonover performed the ceremony.

title: THE FOLLY AND THE SQUALOR
description: WARTIME Understanding and Behavior in the Second World War. By Paul Fussell. Illustrated. 330 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Ellen Clare Gillespie Is Wed in Capital
description: The marriage of Ellen Clare Gillespie and Scott Eric Dreyer took place yesterday in the Navy Chapel at the Naval Security Station in Washington. The Rev. Kenneth Roeltgen, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Harold White officiated.

title: Ohio Fair Is Rocked by the Specter Of Bogus Winner in Steer Division
description: It has come to this: Two fairs where generations of future farmers have stood with pride and joy beside their winning livestock fear that they have been duped into awarding a top prize to the same steer under different names.

title: FOR HER PAINS, SHE WAS CALLED OLD SHAMEFUL
description: I MYSELF AM A WOMAN Selected Writings of Ding Ling. Edited by Tani E. Barlow with Gary J. Bjorge. 361 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.

title: Potential Milestones
description: Steve Largent, Seahawks, needs 2 touchdown receptions to tie Don Hutson's record of 99. Eric Dickerson, Colts, could become the first player in N.F.L. history to gain 1,000 rushing yards in seven consecutive seasons. He, Franco Harris and Walter Payton each had six consecutive 1,000-yard seasons. Nick Lowery, Chiefs, needs one field goal of 50 yards or more to become the career leader in that category. He shares the record of 17 with Jan Stenerud. Jim Breech, Bengals place-kicker, needs to score at least a point in each of the first 15 games to establish the consecutive-game record for scoring. Fred Cox holds the mark at 151 games. Ed (Too Tall) Jones, Cowboys: If he plays this season, he will become the first player in Cowboy history to play 15 seasons with the team.

title: Reducing the Labor Shortage
description: AMERICA'S economy and certainly New Jersey's economy are built on the foundation of a quality work force. That's why a severe and growing shortage of qualified workers threatens New Jersey's continued economic growth.

title: Coming to Grips With Gaelic
description: THE Gaeltacht, or Irish-speaking district of Ireland, exists as a scattered fringe around the country's perimeter, with small concentrations of native Irish-speakers found only in the most remote areas - in the Dingle Peninsular of Kerry, on the Aran Islands off Galway, and in Donegal, that most northern and distant county of the Irish Republic.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our toilet tank is 25 years old, and we have a terrible time with it ''sweating'' on the outside during hot weather. This ''sweating'' is so bad that we have to replace the bathroom carpet under the tank. Can anything be done to stop this?

title: FIGHTING WOMEN
description: WEAK LINK The Feminization of the American Military. By Brian Mitchell. 232 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $17.95.

title: Giving Special Workers a Chance
description: THE work ethic that built our nation is dead. So say the pessimists who mourn the passing of a ''hungry and hard-working'' America this Labor Day. We have lost our competitive edge, they say. We take the bounties of our labors for granted. We are lazy.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the International Olympic Committee Congress gave incorrect soccer eligibility requirements for the 1984 and 1988 Games. The only players, regardless of age, not eligible for the Olympics were those who had played for a European or South American World Cup team.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: Fair judges use precedent. Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League suspended two players, Paul Hornung and Alex Karras, for one year for placing bets on their own teams and other N.F.L. games. Not only did they return to the N.F.L., but Hornung has also been inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame and Karras remains a candidate. Are all our hometown writer-judges telling me that integrity is the exclusive commodity of baseball? HY FENSTER New York

title: They Also Serve Who May Only Wait
description: EACH week, about 1,000 people in Nassau County are summoned to jury duty, the right and privilege of every American. Most respond with a spirited, ''How can I get out of this?''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THERE is a bird, and it is migrating, and today it will stop in New Jersey. It is a small bird, tiny actually, and when those early explorers arrived in the New World, they could scarcely accommodate their first glimpses of the creature with Old World notions of reality.

title: Public TV Juggles A Hot Potato
description: By its treatment this week of a much-disputed documentary, public broadcasting finds itself grappling once again with its basic obligations. How can it serve as a forum for all manner of opinions, including those that are bound to irritate many viewers, yet retain its financial support? How can it open its schedule to independent documentary makers, yet take care that controversial issues are treated fairly? The answers on view on WNET Wednesday evening at 9 may compel us to think about why public television exists.

title: Volunteers Open Homes To Families of Patients
description: LEAD: DURING the last weeks of his life, Pat Veillette's husband, Paul, was at the Westchester County Medical Center receiving a new form of treatment for lung cancer. The Veillettes lived in Milford, Conn., and Mrs. Veillette knew that if she wanted to see her husband, she would have to commute daily to

title: Giants, Vikings and Rams Look Tough
description: The following National Conference preview was prepared and written by Frank Litsky. Teams are listed in the predicted order of finish. EASTERN DIVISION Giants

title: Ethiopia Releases Prisoners From Haile Selassie's Family
description: The Ethiopian Government today released 87 political prisoners and 820 others convicted of common crimes, according to an announcement by the Government radio.

title: Wider Exposure for Tasty Thai Dishes
description: THERE'S a sizzling new Homer's Oriental in Centereach. Homer Lee's ninth restaurant and first foray into Suffolk County caps a string of Nassau successes, including traditional Chinese restaurants, an international extravaganza complete with Mongolian barbecue and two other Homer's Orientals.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: Yes. With conditions: if he apologizes publicly and if he performs public service to the youth of our nation for a specified period. BERNARD FREEMAN New York

title: Four More Ways to Say It
description: LEARNING to speak a foreign language abroad first requires a bit of patient comparison shopping in the United States. The best places to start are national tourist offices and travel agencies. Both usually have up-to-date brochures. Most important, they can provide feedback from satisfied and dissatisfied customers.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about public television's handling of controversy examines the decision to broadcast ''Days of Rage: The Young Palestinians,'' a pro-Palestinian documentary that is scheduled for Wednesday night on PBS.

title: Fryar Finally Signs
description: AFTER weeks of tumultuous negotiations, Irving Fryar has agreed to a new contract with the New England Patriots. The five-year contract reportedly calls for Fryar to earn $4.2 million in base salary and a potential $2.5 million in incentives. The wide receiver is expected to begin practice tomorrow.

title: House Panel Warns Howard U. About Spending
description: Howard University, whose reputation as one of the nation's premier black educational institutions is attributable in good part to heavy Federal financial support, has been warned by Congress to reduce its dependence on Government money and to spend more wisely.

title: The Case for Ed Koch - and His Duty
description: Our last words in endorsing Mayor Koch for re-election in 1985 were: ''When we cheer for Mr. Koch, we cheer for his demonstrated willingness to make choices and take responsibility. May he now show himself to be as skillful in advancing harmony as he has been in winning votes.''

title: Christmas Is Just a Few Choir Rehearsals Away
description: IT may seem a bit premature to worry about Christmas music, but for those interested in taking part in singing the seasonal fare, now is the time to do something about it. The county's avocational choirs are preparing for action and almost all of them are ready to welcome new members.

title: Review/Music; John Zorn and 'Cobra'
description: Watching John Zorn conduct a performance of his ''Cobra'' at P.S. 122 on Friday evening, one was put in mind of a precocious brat let loose in a room full of fancy sound equipment, with a gang of his friends willing to follow his whims.

title: How New Yorkers Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Wait! Don't Burn That Mortgage
description: As an attorney involved in real-estate law, I'd like to tell your readers not to burn their paid mortgages (''The Mortgage Is Paid Up. Hurrah?,'' Opinion page, Aug. 6).

title: Rhode Island Offers Scholarship Plan for Poor
description: Rhode Island will offer full state-college scholarships for low-income pupils under a sweeping plan that will also provide academic help to pupils from the third grade through high school, Gov. Edward D. DiPrete says.

title: LIFE STYLE: Some Greet Fall With Sweaters; Some With Elbows; In Cambridge, Thoughts Turn to Woolens
description: As summer heads toward fall and students exchange shorts and T-shirts for tweed jackets and sweat suits, the city of Cambridge is preparing for the annual onslaught of new students and back-to-schoolers.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Max Bruch Gets a Deserved Dusting Off
description: LEAD: Max Bruch, whose name is far better known than the bulk of his work, was one of the prominent bridge figures of 19th-century music. Born in 1838, while Cherubini was still alive, he lived until 1920, outlasting Debussy by more than two years. In his heyday Bruch was one of the most respected German composers in many genres, including symphony, string quartet and opera.

title: Sabatini Defeats Meskhi Handily
description: Although the year has been somewhat disappointing for Gabriela Sabatini, she played a superb match at the United States Open yesterday. She was upset at both the French Open and at Wimbledon, so yesterday's third-round match became a momentum builder in a tournament that could turn her season much brighter.

title: Baseball Over 30? Softball Up to 70's
description: I was very much amused at the Aug. 20 article ''Game Remains Young in the Over-30 League.''

title: Capital Mayoral Race Turns Murkier
description: The race for mayor of Washington in 1990, a bettor's nightmare, is growing even more confused.

title: Giants Bewilder Viola and Mets
description: Frank Viola, who threw a three-run home run to a .211 hitter, put it this way: ''It's there for the taking. But right now we're not making an effort to take it. And that's the sad part. You can't say turn it on. We'd better step out real quick, or it'll be gone.''

title: New School Outfits, Plus Encouragement
description: WHEN 12-year-old Tasha arrives for the first day of school this week, her new denim skirt, turtleneck, brand-name sneakers and bright pink backpack should help her fit right in. But she thinks arriving by cab might undercut the effect, and so plans to ask the driver to stop a block away.

title: Tax Tinkering Won't Help the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA BANK: Sept. 3, 1989
Why Certain Performers Are a Breed Apart
description: Thom Fogarty walked across Lincoln Center Plaza one recent afternoon and took his place behind a battered clothes rack, playing portly dresser to other dancers. The piece was ''The Angle of Ascent,'' created by Tamar Rogoff and Anthony Tsirantonakis. Before it was finished, Mr. Fogarty had served as neatener of the universe, straightener of costumes and comforter of the troubled. His chores were never done, though he did steal time to smooth his disheveled hair into a bun and do weighty yet graceful barre exercises with a typically earnest, knowing air.

title: Small Tribute to a Musical-Comedy Tradition
description: THE opening number of ''Jerry's Girls,'' the musical melange of Jerry Herman songs at the Darien Dinner Theater, evokes the composer's flamboyant theatrical creations (Dolly, Mame and Mabel, among them) as well as the glittering originators of those roles (Carol Channing, Angela Lansbury and Bernadette Peters).

title: The Bargain in Angola Doesn't Look So Clear Now
description: TWO months ago, before 17 other African leaders, President Eduardo dos Santos of Angola reluctantly extended a hand to the rebel leader Jonas Savimbi after the two arranged a cease-fire in an effort to end their 14-year civil war. But today, those present differ widely over what the two men had actually agreed on.

title: PUBLIC ENEMY No. 1 What the Plan Would Aim to Do
description: HERE are the main elements in the drug package that President Bush is scheduled to present Tuesday night: Enforcement

title: Dr. Carol Langford Marries in Florida
description: The wedding of Dr. Carol Langford, a pediatrician at the Joseph Smith Community Health Center in Boston, and George B. Wolfenden, the retired founding headmaster of the Tampa (Fla.) Preparatory School, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Winter Park, Fla. The Rev. Ronald Reese, a Presbyterian minister who is a brother-in-law of the bride, officiated.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Aug. 19 MANHATTAN Battery Park City $237,100 200 Rector Place (Liberty Court) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 633-sq.-ft. condo in a 2-year-old building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, marble bath, terrace, health club and pool; common charge $372, 100% tax-abated (Broker: D. J. title:
ART;
In Dr. Freud's Collection, Objects of Desire
description: LEAD: If nothing else, Sigmund Freud was a man of his words. The great confessionalist applied a rich metaphorical language to the methods and aims of psychoanalysis and spoke of himself as an explorer and discoverer of new worlds, a wanderer in a maze, a voyager, a decoder, a medical healer and a judge.

title: Lust, Suicide And Baby-Theft On Eaton Place
description: After 50-odd episodes of ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' plenty of them involving crisis in the drawing room and turmoil in the kitchen, it's hard to believe that the family closets at 165 Eaton Place have any more secrets to reveal. But they do, they have. And some pretty dark ones, too. Did you know, for instance, that back in 1906 one of the Bellamys' scullery maids hanged herself in her tiny attic bedroom? Or that Mrs. Bridges, the plump and reliable cook, was hauled off to court for stealing a baby? Or that Marjorie Bellamy, lady of the house and model wife and mother, had a raging love affair with one of her son's friends?

title: Once-Feared, Albany Ethics Law Leaves Mainly Annoyance
description: Eight months after New York State's sweeping new government ethics law took effect, both critics and supporters of the measure say it has had only a marginal impact on the way state government works.

title: All Nannies Want Is a Little Respect
description: IT'S like the Rodney Dangerfield routine of not getting enough respect, but Merryl Woodard, a nanny, does not find the situation funny. The lack of respect by employers for nannies is so prevalent, she says, that ''it's often a thrill to be considered an equal human being.'' As a result, Ms. Woodard decided to write a guidebook on the subject, ''Handbook for Attracting and Holding the Right Nanny.''

title: Spring Wedding For Nan Gaines
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gaines of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nan Gaines, and Robert D. Foster. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Foster of North Woodmere, L.I. The couple plan a spring wedding.

title: One-Design Fleet Sailing for Rye to Compete for '89 Trophy
description: NEXT Sunday, nearly 53 years after the International One-Design sailboats made their debut on Long Island Sound, the fleet's 1989 world championships will be held in those waters, with the American Yacht Club in Rye as the host.

title: Alger Hiss's Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: The advertisement usually includes lighting with a pink glow effect, fresh flowers and either the presence of an attractive male or some clue that he's nearby waiting. But the focus is on the woman, a glamorous creature in a gossamer nightgown, with or without matching negligee.

title: Susan Kelty to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Kelty of Bronxville, N.Y., and Shelter Harbor, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ellen Kelty, to Charles Blair Law Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Blair Law of Lyons Falls, N.Y. Ms. Kelty, an associate at the New York law firm of Brown & Wood, graduated from the Bronxville School, the University of Virginia and St. John's University School of Law. Mr. Law, an associate at Raoul Lionel Felder, a New York law firm, graduated from the Lawrenceville School, St. Lawrence University and the Albany Law School. The couple, both 29 years old, plan to wed later this month.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WHITE PLAINS HIGH SCHOOL;
The Welcoming Smell of Floor Wax and New Textbooks
description: LEAD: THE smell in the halls is unmistakable: Back to School. As recognizable as some famous perfume, this blend of floor wax and new books permeates White Plains High School at this time of year, a mere three days before the beginning of you-know-what.

title: A Dig Yields Clues to Colonial L.I.
description: LEAD: Digging, scraping, hauling and sifting dirt, a group of teachers expoloring an archeological site on the grounds of a 300-year-old house near Orient Point feel they have helped advance the knowledge of Colonial life on Long Island.

title:
GARDENING;
The Well-Managed Compost Pile
description: LEAD: GARDENERS who have used newspaper as a mulch know that it eventually breaks down and is easily tilled into the soil. Much of the breakdown seems to result from earthworms that devour and digest their way through the layers of paper.

title: Kate O'Kelly Weds Richard A. Doyle
description: Kathy Lynn O'Kelly, the daughter of Eleanor M. Shutt of Wayne, Pa., and Samuel G. O'Kelly Jr. of Deerfield, Ill., was married yesterday to Richard Anthony Doyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Doyle of New York and Roxbury, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Robert Gordon, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Daniel Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the interfaith ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Wayne.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: History is the discovery of connections. Two postal items sat in a collector's file with other offbeat stuff for a year until research on one lead the researcher to fish out the other and connect them.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: EDGING WOMEN OUT: Victorian Novelists, Publishers, and Social Change. By Gaye Tuchman with Nina E. Fortin. (Yale University, $30.) Received critical wisdom has it that English women novelists came into the full sunlight of recognition in the high Victorian years, the 1860's and 70's. ''Edging Women Out,'' a sociological study of numbers (elaborately extracted from the British Dictionary of National Biography and the archives of the publishing firm Macmillan), offers a depressing counterfinding.

title: PUBLIC ENEMY No. 1; A War on Drugs Is a Necessary Risk for Bush
description: PRESIDENT BUSH will deliver his first prime-time televised address this week, and the nation's state of mind has given him a politically irresistible topic: a strategy for battling drugs.

title: L.I. Power Authority Weighs Alternate Plans for Shoreham
description: LEAD: ALTERNATIVE plans for the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, including refitting to generate electricity using natural gas as fuel, are under discussion among the trustees of the Long Island Power Authority.

title: George Steiner's Distinctions
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language; Haunted Words
description: ETYMOLOGY - THE study of the origin and development of words, affixes and phrases - is populated by all manner of ghoulies and ghosties and long-leggety beasties. Spook etymologists would rather invent a dramatic word origin than trace a word to its source, and it was such fanciful etymologizing that fired Mark Twain to pen his satirical derivation of Middletown from Moses: by ''dropping the -oses and adding the -iddletown.''

title: Orioles' Olson Ties Record
description: Gregg Olson tied an American League record for saves by a rookie as the Baltimore Orioles used five pitchers to beat the Chicago White Sox tonight, 2-1, and keep pace with front-running Toronto in the American League East.

title: Waltrip Driving Toward Big Payoff
description: If Darrell Waltrip wins the Southern 500 today in Darlington, S.C., he will earn a bonus of $1 million.

title: STREETSCAPES: Variety Photo Plays Theater; Marquee's Lights Are Dark on 1914 'Nickelodeon'
description: IT'S hard to put your finger on what was special about it. Perhaps it was the aura of the early days of the movies, but the 1914 Variety Photo Plays Theater at 110 Third Avenue was unforgettable when it was in operation.

title: Julie Weiss Is Married
description: Julie Sara Weiss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Weiss of Waban, Mass., was married last evening to Michael William Levine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Levine of Roslyn, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alvin I. Lieberman at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston. Mrs. Levine is a freelance legal interpreter in Spanish in Lawrence, Mass. Mr. Levine is a project manager for Fidelity Investments in Boston.

title: West Point Gynecologist Denies Seducing Patient
description: A gynecologist at the United States Military Academy has denied seducing a patient earlier this year, as she accused him of doing, but he admitted having an affair with a former patient at Fort Sill, Oklahoma, which would be a breach of the same regulations he is accused of breaking at West Point.

title: 'If The Deal Sounds Too Good, Beware!'
description: NEIL H. COHEN is the president of MBA Associates, a jewelry appraisal concern in Hartford and 1 of just 85 appraisers in the country certified as a master gemologist appraiser.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Englewood
description: LEAD: WITHIN its 4.9 square miles, Englewood offers enough contrasts -opulent mansions and public housing, art galleries and thrift shops, chic restaurants and a church soup kitchen - to come close to being a microcosm of the small American city.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on page 10 of the Travel section today with an article about Ottawa mislabels the month for which weather statistics apply. It is September.

title: Updating Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: UNSPORTSMANLIKE CONDUCT?
description: INTERFERENCE How Organized Crime Influences Professional Football. By Dan E. Moldea. 512 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Boy Caged in Pen; Grandparents Are Charged
description: The grandparents of a 4-year-old boy have been charged with keeping the child in a pen during the day outside the motor-home vehicle in which they lived. He had no toilet and only a bottle of water in the pen, the authorities said.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Eisler: Lieder Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, baritone; Aribert Reimann, piano. Teldec 8.44092; CD only. Unexpectedly good stuff here, at least for those of us who haven't previously taken Eisler for a subtle song composer. The songs were composed between 1939 and 1956; the texts are from Pascal, Anacreon, Shakespeare and others but mostly from Brecht; the idiom varies (sometimes erratically) from something related to the cabaret to 12-tone density. ''Thoughts on the Duration of Exile'' has a nattering, pattering quality that captures the poem exactly. ''To a Portable Radio'' is an adorable, plaintive miniature that should find its way quickly into the encore repertory. There are other strong pieces, and some that betray a lack of reliable musical invention. Mr. Fischer-Dieskau is sometimes vehement where irony might suit better, but when a light touch is wanted, he is excellent. The piano playing is specific and imaginative. - Will Crutchfield 'The Piano Album' Stephen Hough, piano. Virgin Classics VC7 90732-2; CD and cassette. Here are 20 short pieces generally heard (if at all) as recital encores. Some were very popular at one time (Paderewski Minuet, Levitzki Waltz in A). Some are little known (Palmgren's ''En Route,'' Godowsky's ''Gardens of Buitenzorg''). Some are songs in Hough's own transcriptions (Woodforde-Finden's ''Kashmiri Song,'' Rodgers's ''My Favorite Things''). But all are effective pianistically, and some are of unusual difficulty. Mr. Hough is a powerful technician, very effective when his fingers can keep moving. Stylistically he can be mannered, especially in music that demands a singing line. There he starts fooling around, adding unnecessary ''expressive'' devices. His performance of the Levitzki waltz is an outrageous exercise in self-indulgence. He must learn to play such pieces simply and naturally, as Levitzki did in his own recording 50 years ago. - Harold C. Schonberg Gilles: 'Motet a St. Jean Baptiste,' Three Lamentations Veronique Gens, soprano; Jean-Paul Fouchecourt, Douglas Nasrawi, tenors; Jean-Louis Paya, baritone; Le Concert Spirituel conducted by Herve Niquet. Adda 581119; CD only. For years, those fortunate enough to have stumbled upon the occasional recording of the Requiem by the Provencal composer Jean Gilles (1668-1705) have craved opportunities to hear other substantial portions of his work. Here is more choral music, and it is every bit as delicious as one expected - perky, quirky and as oddly irrepressible in the three Lamentations for Holy Week as in the Mass for the Dead. While one has yet to hear great profundity from Gilles, this further evidence of his remarkable ingenuity makes one only more determined to keep up the search. Despite uneven solo efforts, the performances are always adequate and often better. - James R. Oestreich 'The Earliest Disks' Berliner Gramophone Recordings, 1890-1901. Symposium 1058; CD only. This is strictly for curio and amusement value, but as such not inconsiderable. Where else can you hear the Royal Bucks Hussars Band playing ''The Deep Blue Sea'' with piccolo solo? Or Vess L. Ossman (''America's Greatest Banjoist'') in the ''Smokey Mokes Cakewalk''? There is even an 1896 audio advertisement for Plant's Baking Powder. A charismatic Spanish singer called ''El Muchuelo'' and a gypsy band from Budapest, both recorded in 1899, have some evocative power, as does an impassioned intonation of the 23d Psalm. The selection of 39 disks begins with ''Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,'' shouted over ferocious surface roar by a voice that may well be Emile Berliner's own. - W. C. Beach: Mass in E flat Daniel Beckwith, organ; Michael May Festival Chorus conducted by Michael May. Newport Classic 60008; CD and cassette. This is a frustrating recording. Amy (Mrs. H. H. A.) Beach (1867-1944) was one of the more imaginative American composers of the late 19th century, and this richly operatic, extroverted, joyous Mass is a fine example of her assured way of using - and spicing up - the musical conventions of her day. Composed for full orchestra, it is presented here in a workable transcription for organ, harp and percussion. The performance is little more than adequate, however, and the dry clarity of the recording exposes the thinness of the choir and the unhomogeneity of the solo ensembles. Still, it is worth attempting to ignore the shortcomings and concentrate on the music. - Barrymore L. Scherer POP/JAZZ John Coltrane: 'Coltrane Plays the Blues,' 'Ole Coltrane' Atlantic. 1382-2, 1373-2; all three formats. At his worst John Coltrane played for more than an hour, transfixed, rocked by an endless, lulling pattern of modes. This was also Mr. Coltrane at his best, a mystic who heard the drone of eternity. ''Ole Coltrane'' (1961), which highlights the sluggish, withdrawn player, is one of his poorest records. ''Coltrane Plays the Blues'' (1960) is one of his best. Here he is blunt to the point of rudeness, his hard-nosed attack waking up old chord changes. The teacher of every tenor player since 1960 can be heard, as he cracks through to the otherworldly sound so many have imitated. But the student of Coleman Hawkins and Lester Young, apparent on every cut, is just as impressive. - Richard B. Woodward George Clinton: 'The Cinderella Theory' Paisley Parker/Warner Bros. 25994; all three formats. Crisp rhythms, mildly eccentric melodies and unpredictable overlays - jazz, rap, stray voices and choruses - mark ''The Cinderella Theory'' as the work of George Clinton, the mastermind of Parliament-Funkadelic, the most influential funk group of the 1970's. But despite Mr. Clinton's high standards, it's a thin album; too many songs are straightforward funk workouts, lacking the illuminating juxtapositions and polymorphous carnality of the best P-Funk. ''Goin' On,'' ''The Cinderella Theory,'' ''There I Go Again'' and ''Tweakin' '' (with guest raps by Public Enemy) live up to Mr. Clinton's catalogue, but there's too much filler. - Jon Pareles Dresser, Feldman and Roberts: 'Arcado String Trio' JMT 834 429-2; all three formats. The trio - Mark Dresser, bass; Mark Feldman, violin, and Hank Roberts, cello - moves from achingly melodic compositions that synthesize jazz with minimalism to noisy pieces that last for about 30 seconds. The group's members, part of just about every important new-music band on the downtown scene, are virtuosos, able to sift through the best elements of European classical music, pop and jazz and bring them to a rapprochement that sounds new. At once rigorous and rhythmic, the group, delicately balanced and precise, has found a lush sensuality in the midst of New York's urban clangor. - Peter Watrous Eurythmics: 'We Too Are One' Arista 8606; all three formats. A strong current of irony has always run through Eurhythmics' chilly pop romanticism, but it has never been as scaldingly direct as on their new album. Almost all the songs contemptuously examine examples of modern-day hubris, with images of love and salvation used as metaphors for malign political power. The golden couple exalted in ''King and Queen of America,'' a blaring rock-and-roll strut, turn out to be ''king of nothing and the queen of rage.'' The oracular ''Day Goes Down'' laments the decline of humanistic values in the age of Reagan and Thatcher. Melodically, this is the duo's strongest album. - Stephen Holden The D. O. C.: 'No One Can Do It Better' Ruthless 91275-4; all three formats. It's odd that rap can be painfully stupid and bigoted, yet still be brilliant formally, terrific dance music. The latest Los Angeles rapper to arrive on the charts, D. O. C. (Tray Curry, age 21), isn't blessed with much more on his head than a Los Angeles Kings hat, and keeping the misogyny and antihomosexual commentary down to a temperate one or two incidences a side, Mr. Curry sticks to a topic closer to his heart: himself. And he does it in style; his rapping, made up of short, clipped bursts, double-time flurries and syncopations that keep things on a rhythmically elevated level, floats on tremendous rhythm tracks that smudge samples together faster than nearly any other record. - P.W.

title: Ms. Rodkin Wed To Rob Rotering
description: Nancy Ann Rodkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rodkin of Chicago, and Victor Robert Rotering, the son of Mrs. William Laird of Edina, Minn., and the late Victor S. Rotering, were married yesterday at the Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago. The interfaith ceremony was performed by Rabbi Allen Secher and the Rev. Patrick Quinn, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Sharon Patricia Cooney Has Wedding
description: Sharon Patricia Cooney and Thorpe Shuttleworth, a son of the late Margaret W. Shuttleworth of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Jack Shuttleworth of Clearwater, Fla., were married yesterday at the Bronxville, N.Y., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George K. Cooney. The Rev. William M. Naughton, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Washington State; Arrive Early And Party Hard At Waterbust
description: The first partygoers started arriving around 7 A.M., and by the time the first band went onstage about noon, the festivities were in full swing. Jeffrey Spane, a junior business major at the University of Washington, said it was ''the biggest party I've ever been to.''

title: How the Little Guy Is Playing the Market
description: AS the Dow Jones Industrial Average broke through to record highs last month, Stephen A. Swets, a 38-year-old manager with a Chicago housing firm, switched some of his savings out of a Fidelity Investments bond fund and into one of the firm's stock mutual funds. Mr. Swets said he made the switch because he is ''optimistic'' about the current bullish stock market's long-term prospects, but he cautioned, ''This is not the time to be fully invested in stocks.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD: HISTORIC CARS

title: Calamitous Flier
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara Phelps Becomes a Bride
description: St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Barbara Wilder Phelps, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Phelps of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Chatham, and Joseph Garside 4th, the son of Mr. Garside 3d of Westwood, Mass., and the late Mrs. Garside. The Rev. Paul Hunt performed the ceremony.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Case Western; New Smoking Ban Gives Few Refuges For Lighting Up
description: Smokers at Case Western Reserve University who want to light up will have to go outdoors; a new campus-wide policy bans smoking in virtually all university buildings.

title: Merriment Is In Short Supply
description: To the Editor:

title: Seniors Tourney Shifts Its Site
description: The Senior Golf Classic will move to a new public golf course here next year, tournament officials announced today.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Some Flowers Wait Until September
description: LEAD: To many gardeners, September brings sad regrets that the flower year is nearly at an end. Those plants, which have survived this summer's rain, appear bedraggled. Only the annuals look their best, especially impatiens.

title: Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine McGill, Student, Is Wed
description: Catherine Debo McGill, a daughter of Susan Claydon of Boulder, Colo., and Douglas F. I. McGill of Steamboat Springs, Colo., was married yesterday to David Malcolm Durning, a son of Ronald B. Durning of Alford, Mass., and the late Doris Charbonnet Durning of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Craig S. Milco performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Amherst, N.H.

title: Miss Foster Wed To Mark Brooks
description: Susan Kent Foster, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Foster of Bronxville, N.Y., and Mark William Brooks, a son of Phyllis A. Brooks of Brewster, N.Y., and the late Robert W. Brooks, were married yesterday at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The Rev. Carter Via performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CELEBRITY LECTURE

title: Maine's Secluded Island Inns
description: AFTER a late afternoon rain shower the sky cleared just enough to make a radiant spectacle of sunset over the distant Camden Hills. From the rock ledges at Robinson Point on Isle au Haut, we could see across Penobscot Bay to Vinalhaven and North Haven Islands in the foreground and the dark blue humps of Mount Megunticook and Ragged Mountain on the luminous horizon. As evening fell, first one, then two and three lights began to blink across the water in steady, comforting rhythm, signals from Saddleback Ledge, Green Island and another light we failed to locate on the Coast and Geodetic Survey chart of Penobscot Bay and Approaches. When the Isle au Haut light at Robinson Point next to the Keeper's House, added its pink revolving flash, it seemed another link in a connecting chain, threads of light that stretched in both directions, tying together the islands off the coast of Maine.

title: George S. Kane Weds Ms. Doyle
description: Anne Forbes Doyle, a sales representative for the Designtex textiles company in Boston, and George Stuart Kane, the book marketing manager for the Appalachian Mountain Club there, were married yesterday in Hingham, Mass. The bride's father, Edward L. Doyle, a deacon of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. John F. Arens at St. Paul's Church.

title: Technology Spreading Like Ivy in Academia
description: To survive the rigors of higher education, college students are packing some high-tech gadgetry into their luggage this fall. A survey of campuses nationwide indicates that most students are taking enough stereos, computers, refrigerators and television sets to make their rooms pass for appliance stores.

title: Hanoi Now Says Ho Died on Different Day
description: Vietnamese leaders have asserted that they falsified the date of Ho Chi Minh's death and changed portions of his will, putting the leader's body on display in a glass mausoleum when his initial wish was to be cremated.

title: Announcer Wed To Betsy Knight
description: Elizabeth Spalding Knight, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Spalding Knight of Madison, N.J., and Robert Edgar Blanchard Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blanchard, also of Madison, were married there yesterday at the Grace Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert W. Ihloff performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John H. Branson of St. Paul's Episcopal Church of Chatham, N.J.

title: Nigel Atkinson - Textile Designer
description: Nigel Atkinson always liked fabric. ''When I was small I liked looking in my mother's wardrobe and seeing all the fabrics hanging down, particularly the paisleys,'' he recalled.

title: Flight Insurance
description: To the Editor: After buying flight insurance (strictly life) for many years at various locations from Mutual of Omaha, on June 16, 1989, at the Pan American terminal at Kennedy International Airport I was confronted with a surprise.

title:
ART;
A Study in the Art of Drawing
description: LEAD: THE current exhibition at the Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport, ''A Fine Line: The Art of Drawing,'' includes works by 10 artists that illustrate a diversity of drawing styles and techniques.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BORDERLINES: A Journey in Thailand and Burma. By Charles Nicholl. (Viking, $18.95.) ''In writing, as in much else, it's not what you go looking for that counts, it's what you find.'' So writes the British author Charles Nicholl in ''Borderlines,'' a travel book that reads as a series of thoughtful, even mesmerizing reflections on Everyman's personal quest.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
A Fresh Look at the Forgotten I.R.A.
description: LEAD: BACK in the mid-80's, millions of people socked away $2,000 each year in Individual Retirement Accounts. I.R.A.'s were hot. Banks and brokerage firms scrambled for these new investors; and investors scoured the markets for the year's best investment.

title: Cuban Ex-Official Sentenced in Drug Case
description: A Cuban military court has convicted and sentenced a former Interior Minister to 20 years in prison for abuse of office and other charges related to a Government drug-trafficking scandal, the Cuban press agency reported Friday.

title: WHAT A CHILD IS GIVEN
description: ON THE AUGUST MORNING IN 1971 when Marietta Spencer first met the birth family of her adopted son, Paul, she was prepared to be nervous. In the four years that she had worked as a social worker for the Children's Home Society of Minnesota, in St. Paul, Spencer had arranged and guided many such meetings. She had seen firsthand the fears and confusion stirred up when strangers, joined at the heart by adoption, examine the potent ties among them. But what Spencer wasn't prepared for, as she and Paul and the rest of the family spent a day swapping stories with a score of her son's birth relatives in their home in northern Germany, was how familiar all these strangers would seem.

title: Chinese With an Indonesian Accent
description: THE name of one of New Canaan's newest restaurants, the Little Kitchen of New Canaan, could be a little misleading. Instead of the homey image of pot roast and Mom's apple pie that such a name might evoke, this small restaurant is a study in the sophisticated use of minimum space and intelligent decorating. Two tiny rooms are made light and sunny by the choice of color - salmon pink, bright blue, kelly green and white - in the rattan furniture, posters and walls.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $370,000 37 Evergreen Row 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old raised ranch; family room w/ fireplace, patio, 2-car garage, 1.4 acres; taxes $3,968. Chappaqua, N.Y. $535,000 70 Annandale Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, family room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $9,684. title: A Week On the Beat Of the Dollar
description: THE dealing room at Chase Manhattan Bank is open and noisy. As I began my first day as a trader, I quickly discovered that when the dollar is moving rapidly, the rhythm in the room echoes the movement in the market. But it took precious time to learn the beat.

title: Redeveloping the Redevelopment of Times Square
description: FOR more than 20 years, business and government officials have talked about ''doing something'' with Times Square. Once a bright, clean entertainment district that attracted tourists and New Yorkers alike, the area is still bright and still attracts tourists and theater-going New Yorkers, but is overrun by pornography, drugs, sleaze and crime.

title: Hilary Bing Wed To Dean Butera
description: Hilary Anne Bing, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford B. Bing of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married last evening to Dean McNeilie Butera, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Butera of Branchville, N.J. Rabbi Morton Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Hun School in Princeton, N.J.

title: Mr. Nickerson Wins Boojum
description: Mr. Nickerson claimed temporary leadership of New York's sprinters by surviving an early speed duel and then drawing away through the stretch to post a 2 1/4-length victory over Sewickley in the $113,000 Boojum Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.
