title: NIAGARA MOHAWK AND STATE IN PACT
description: In an effort to bring about some political and financial stability, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has signed an agreement with New York State officials to freeze its electric rates, cut the salaries of its top management and suspend dividend payments to holders of common stock.

title: Visitors Stream Back to Yellowstone After the Fires of 1988
description: A full year after the famous fires that devastated large parts of the nation's oldest national park, Yellowstone displays unmistakable signs of recovery, both on its natural and its human sides.

title:
GARDENING;
The Well-Managed Compost Pile
description: LEAD: GARDENERS who have used newspaper as a mulch know that it eventually breaks down and is easily tilled into the soil. Much of the breakdown seems to result from earthworms that devour and digest their way through the layers of paper.

title: Teaching Kids to Bowl On Lanes Without Gutters
description: Bowling proprietors are counting on a host of new products and promotions to fill their alleys with recreational bowlers during the long winter ahead. ''It's much more work than it used to be,'' said Sandy Hansell, a bowling consultant. ''With an abundance of league players signed up for 35 weeks a year you could loaf while they played.''

title: Polish Cardinal Terms Agreement On Auschwitz Convent 'Offensive'
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, has described as ''offensive'' an agreement to move a convent away from the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Court Decides Who's on the Primary Ballot
description: Less than two weeks before the Sept. 12 primary, the State Court of Appeals last week affirmed the removal of a Brooklyn City Councilman from the ballot, reinstated another Councilman, left a Liberal Party candidate for Civil Court judge unopposed in Manhattan and insured a three-way race for Brooklyn district attorney.

title: Tiran Nersoyan, An Archbishop, Scholar and Author, Is Dead at 85
description: Archbishop Tiran Nersoyan, a former Primate of the Diocese of the Armenian Apostolic Church of America, died of cancer early Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in New York City.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Kansas; Campus Cafeterias Won't Be Using Plastic Foam Cups
description: After eight months of meetings and 2,600 signatures on petitions, the University of Kansas has decided to ban plastic-foam products on campus.

title: FICTION
description: PELLE THE CONQUEROR. Volume One: Childhood.

title: POSTINGS: Historic Properties; On the Block
description: An auction of eight historic properties - including the only yacht listed in the National Register of Historic Places - will be held later this month at five sites across the country by Kennedy-Wilson Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Making the Most Of Parkland In an Era of Limits
description: A DECADE ago, Westchester's five public golf courses were losing $360,000 a year, not including another $100,000 in equipment costs. Players who had to tee off from rubber mats and suffer rough fairways were hardly pushing past each other to get onto the greens.

title: Some Greet Fall With Sweaters; Some With Elbows; Watch Your Back: It's Autumn in New York
description: The leaves haven't begun to change. The Mets and some of the Yankees have yet to call it a season. Some of those cool breezes are still being supplied by Friedrich. So why does it seem like fall already? Perhaps because it's New York, that hurry-up town. Let the rest of the country wait until Sept. 22; the signs of autumn have been seen and felt throughout the city for weeks now. The summer stroll has turned into a strut. The mail has picked up: catalogues from L. L. Bean and Macy's, campaign fliers, schedules of the New York City Ballet and the Philharmonic, not to mention friendly reminders of fuel bills left unpaid. Some Queens residents look out over the skyline, see the lights at Shea and Louis Armstrong Stadiums and know that the boys of summer will be moving on and that it's United States Open time again.

title: In Search Of Values
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; All Over Manhattan, From Park Avenue to Ninth
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Barney Greengrass

title: A Shakeout For Software
description: ASK Willard (Pete) Peterson, executive vice president of the Word Perfect Corporation, how and where his company's software is sold and he will probably laugh. ''We try to keep track, sure, but it seems every week we're adding 100 names to our dealer data base, and deleting another 100,'' he said. ''Everyone is price cutting everyone else, and it's as though there's a shakeout every day.''

title: N.F.L.'s Goal: Another Rozelle
description: Paul Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' vice president and general manager and a National Football League patriach, chuckled and leaned back in his chair. Brown was recalling those long days that turned into longer nights in January 1960 in Miami when N.F.L. owners toiled for 10 days and 23 ballots while electing a new commissioner.

title: Copy Editor Wed To Miss Hagerty
description: Kathleen Marion Hagerty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hagerty of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Lawrence Wilson, a son of Col. William Lawrence Wilson, U.S.A., and Mrs. Wilson of West Point, N.Y. Msgr. Harry J. Byrne performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: THE ARTIST AS ART
description: Those familiar with Gilbert and George as a team of contemporary British artists are apt to be nonplused by the laborious ideology applied to their quirky work by Wolf Jahn in his critical study, THE ART OF GILBERT & GEORGE: Or, An Aesthetic of Existence (Thames and Hudson, Paper, $24.95). First celebrated in 1968 for presenting themselves as ''living sculptures'' that proclaimed the artist as art, Gilbert Proesch and George Passmore - who have lived and worked together since graduating from a London art school in 1969 - have continued to appear as photographic images in the large-scale paintings and gridlike collages that have marked their output ever since. But where others have detected a sense of irony in their redefinition of sculpture and art, Mr. Jahn's relentlessly sobering view is bound to alienate more readers than it might attract. No mere Gilbert and George groupie, Mr. Jahn, a German critic, emerges as an apostle with unabashed adoration. Their work resides ''outside the scope of normal art history,'' he declares. ''It is not for us, any longer, to try to grasp and comprehend them; they stand, wall-like, and contemplate us.'' Their work is discussed primarily in terms of its tendency to recapitulate ''the world's Genesis and man's primal imaginative act. . . . They create, just as in the beginning the world was created from the corpse of a sacrificed deity.'' Indeed, according to Mr. Jahn, Gilbert and George are on nothing less than ''a crusade to reconquer human values.'' If they were not always in service to his fanatical and inflated theory, Mr. Jahn's technically detailed descriptions of the many artworks represented, well served by David Britt's translation, would perhaps be more compelling.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: Pete Rose should learn the three ''R's'': no remorse, no rehabilitation, no reinstatement. CAROLE MARTIN New York

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Wrestling Gold Medal for Monday: The Olympic champion Ken Monday of the United States beat Arsen Fadzaev of the Soviet Union to win the gold medal in the 74-kilo (163 pounds) category at the world freestyle championships yesterday in Martigny, Switzerland. Monday, a 27-year-old from Stillwater, Okla., scored a 6-1 points victory over Fadzaev, who moved up a weight category this season after winning world and Olympic titles at 68 kilos (149.5 pounds) in 1987 and 1988. Including Fadzaev's silver, the Soviets picked up one medal in each of the five categories contested yesterday. Next came the United States wrestlers with three medals while Iran and West Germany picked up two each. In the 130-kilo (286 pounds) title match, Ali Reza Soleimani of Iran upset the Olympic silver medalist Bruce Baumgartner of the United States in the day's most exciting encounter. Soleimani came from behind to tie the score with 10 seconds left in the match. In overtime, he threw Baumgartner, the world's top-ranked heavyweight freestyler, to win by 5-4.(AP) Cycling Briton in Lead: Mauro Gianetti of Switzerland and Robert Millar of England broke away from the pack yesterday to dominate the fourth stage of the Tour of Britain, which ends today in London. Gianetti, who rides for the Helvetia team, won the 141-mile stage from Birmingham, England, to Cardiff in 5 hours 46 minutes 33 seconds. Millar, a member of the Z-Peugeot squad, finished second in the same time as Gianetti, while the main pack was more than five minutes behind. The second-place finish pushed Millar into the overall race lead with a time of 18:19:59. Gianetti was second, eight seconds behind.(AP) Soccer Victory for West Ham: Mark Ward's goal in the fifth minute kept West Ham atop the Second Division of the English League with a 1-1 tie at Hull in a soccer game that ended in a brawl yesterday. Watford scored a 3-1 home victory at home over Leicester to move into second place, and Blackburn also stayed undefeated with a 2-2 tie at home against Oxford. (AP) Golf 4-Shot Lead for Norman: Greg Norman attacked the Tuckaway Country Club course in Franklin, Wis., with another flurry of birdies yesterday, shooting a six-under-par 66 to take a four-stroke lead after three rounds of the Greater Milwaukee Open. Norman, who began the day tied for the lead with Wayne Grady and Mark Lye, birdied four of the first six holes and finished with a tournament-record 54-hole score of 17-under 199. Wayne Levi, Bob Lohr and P.H. Horgan III were next at 203.(AP) McBee Leads by 1: Rives McBee scored an eagle and three birdies over the final eight holes to charge to a one-stroke lead yesterday after two rounds of the Senior Golf Classic in Lexington, Ky. McBee, of Dallas, shot a five-under 65 on the second day to take a seven-under 133 into today's final round at Marriott's Griffin Gate course.(AP) Gerring Leads L.P.G.A. Field: Cathy Gerring recovered from a first-hole bogey yesterday to shoot a four-under-par 68 and take the first-round lead in the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Rail Classic in Springfield, Ill. Six players, including Beth Daniel, were tied for second at 69. Several others made runs at the lead, as 25 golfers broke or matched par. Gerring, who lost the 1986 Rail Classic in a sudden-death playoff, bogeyed her opening hole, No. 10, after putting her second shot into a greenside bunker. But she birdied the next three to finish the first nine at a 2-under-par 34. (AP) Harness Racing Goalie Jeff Wins Pace: Goalie Jeff, the top-rated 3-year-old pacing colt in North America, won an elimination race and the final heat with equal ease yesterday to capture the $377,650 James B. Dancer Memorial Pace at Freehold Raceway in New Jersey. Driven by Mike Lachance, the son of Cam Fella won the $113,295 elimination division by 2 3/4 lengths in 1:56. He went on to take the $151,060 final, leading from start to finish and winning again by 2 3/4 lengths in 1:56 2/5. Goalie Jeff clocked a 27.4-second final quarter to hold off Resonator, who won his elimination division in 1:55. The victory pushed Goalie Jeff, from the Centre Ice Stable of Ontario, Canada, over the million-dollar mark in earnings this year, giving him $1,068,317. Goalie Jeff returned $2.60, $2.20 and $2.10 for $2 across the board.(AP)

title: Criminal Personality Relates to Others by Attacking and Taking
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Music Is as Old As Today
description: Periodically I have complained in this space of my inability to detect much expressive content in many of the ''original-instrument'' performances now being offered by early-music specialists. In concentrating so heavily on trying to re-create the sounds and textures of the past, our 20th-century crusaders easily lose sight of the larger purposes music is supposed to serve. And so, slaves to what we have been taught is historical truth, we sit solemnly listening to a Beethoven symphony that sounds like Hummel or a Mozart piano concerto that tickles the music instead of tackling it.

title: Peachy Keen
description: THERE ARE MANY WAYS TO REPORT ON wine, but only two count. One is to gather lots of bottles, divide them into logical categories - for instance, red and white - then open them up and taste.

Chilies play a central role in the film, which takes place in an isolated village in colonial India, where Sonbai, a comely spice factory worker, becomes the object of a subedar's (or feudal overlord's) amorous attentions.

title: Keeping It Simple and Fresh
description: MY mother once said that living with a small child was like having a permanently drunk houseguest. Never did this ring more true than one weekend recently when I tried to cook dinner for eight adults in the company of six children confined indoors because of rain. Just as I was trying to sort out last-minute details, one child wanted spaghetti with butter - and not in a bowl but on a plate like a grownup; another was turning over his carefully strained chicken and mashed potatoes on his head and a third needed a bottle of milk warmed immediately. Meanwhile the eldest girl stood in the middle of the kitchen and announced ''I'm bored. With a capital B. B-O-R-E-D!''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SPRING WILL BE OURS. By Sue Gee. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Sue Gee's first work of fiction, ''Spring Will Be Ours,'' is a mammoth historical novel about modern Poland that reads much like a grade-school history book. In wooden prose and with a penchant for the unrevealing detail, Ms. Gee marches the reader through the lives of three generations of exemplary Poles.

title: Confessions of a 'Fed Watcher'
description: THE world of private financial institutions is permeated by people who got their professional start at the Federal Reserve - the Board of Governors in Washington or one of the 12 District Federal Reserve Banks. Occasionally, these high-class technicians become top executives or entrepreneurs, but more typically they continue as professionals - chief economists and senior advisers to top management, or key participants in day-to-day securities trading and asset/liability management. Collectively these people are inelegantly dubbed ''Fed watchers'' - a term that somewhat denigrates their frequently active role within private companies but does describe accurately an important part of their input to decision-making.

title: Do Numbers Lie About Audio Gear? Just Listen to What Your Ears Say
description: Wisdom, as contrasted to common sense, has been linked by skeptical philosophers to a distrust of the obvious. Accordingly, an early essay by Bertrand Russell argues against the persuasiveness of numbers and ferrets out the limitations of their meaning.

description: Claire Luce, a 1920's Ziegfeld star who left the musical stage for the classical theater, died Thursday at her Gramercy Park home in Manhattan after a lengthy illness. She was 85 years old.

title: Putting the Program Back in Program Music
description: In Beethoven's time, the conductor Roger Norrington pointed out during his recent ''Beethoven Experience'' at the Pepsico Summerfare, it was altogether customary for a music critic to ''analyze'' a new piece with repeated reference to subjective content. That even instrumental music should carry an extramusical meaning - a ''program'' of some sort - seemed perfectly natural. In our own century, it has been acceptable to analyze music only in objective, technical terms. ''But,'' Mr. Norrington observed, ''the tide is turning.'' Interest in program music - on the part of composers, audiences and writers about music - has historically ebbed and flowed. Beethoven is said to have remarked already in 1823 that audiences were no longer so poetically sensitive as they had been a few decades earlier. The lowest ebb, however, occurred in the 20th century, between the two world wars, a period dominated musically by the figure of Igor Stravinsky. As a young man, Stravinsky understandably resisted Wagner, and he detested Richard Strauss and everything that composer represented. What the post-Romantic Strauss represented as much as anything, of course, was program music, which the 1920's, largely given over to Stravinskian Neo-Classicism, therefore rejected.

title: Who Is Going to Pay For Airport Security?
description: BY ordering the airlines to begin screening passenger luggage with a new type of bomb detector, the Government hopes to prevent terrorist attacks like the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people last December. But the new procedures, which were announced last week, are also expected to intensify the debate over who should shoulder the growing cost of airport security: the Government, the airlines or, most likely, the passengers.

title: Dr. Demond Marries Dr. Kim Hayes
description: Dr. Avery Holliday Demond and Dr. Kim Ford Hayes, assistant professors of environmental engineering at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, were married in Ann Arbor yesterday at the Leslie Science Center. The Rev. Kenneth Phifer, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: What's Doing In Ottawa
description: It's not often that a 19th-century capital city gets two dramatic additions to its spirit and skyline in a single year. But that's what has just happened to Ottawa. A year ago, the granite and glass National Gallery of Canada, designed by Moshe Safdie, opened on a spectacular site overlooking the confluence of the Rideau Canal and the Ottawa River. At the end of June, the capital welcomed an even bolder newcomer positioned just across the bridge in Hull, Quebec - Douglas Cardinal's eccentric and visionary Canadian Museum of Civilization. Both are new homes for existing collections of international importance: it's as if the contents of the Smithsonian and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, inadequately housed for more than a century, finally got the buildings they deserved.

title: Overcrowding at a Jail Leads To a Prison Without Bars
description: A SLOPPY dirt track behind the Secaucus Prison Annex on County Road Extension here is the twisted path that leads to the newest correctional site in the state. The encampment is called Tent City 161 by the Department of Corrections, although it has also been dubbed Camp Humphreys after the Superior Court judge who helped hasten its creation.

title: Iranian President Quits as Chief of Armed Forces
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran has resigned as Commander in Chief of the armed forces, saying he is too busy with other matters, the Teheran radio reported today.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Iowa; Scholarship Winner in Iowa Finds That Homelessness Is No Barrier
description: Gerald Winterlin does not mind studying 80 hours a week to maintain his nearly perfect grade point average. The University of Iowa senior said he works hard because the three years he spent as a homeless person taught him never to quit.

title: Ms. Zimmerman Plans to Marry Geoffrey Chazen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin David Zimmerman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jamie Rachel Zimmerman, 29 years old, to Dr. Geoffrey David Chazen, 31, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Chazen of Nashville. A November wedding is planned.

title: Q and A
description: Party Wall

title: Dr. Eric Hochberg Weds Ms. Berman
description: The wedding of Amy Beth Berman, an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, and Dr. Eric Mitchell Hochberg, a chief urology resident at Mount Sinai Medical Center, took place last evening at Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Ezra Finckelstein officiated.

title: Lerzan Kizilay, Medical Student, Weds
description: Lerzan Suzanne Kizilay, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dogan Kizilay of South Orange, N.J., and Christopher Patusky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Patusky of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday at the Memorial Church at Harvard University. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John MacInnis, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Megan Walker, Banker, Is Wed
description: Margaret Anne Walker, an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, and James Garland Rose Jr., a vice president in merchant banking at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, both in New York, were married yesterday in Richmond. The Rev. Dr. William Lewis Sachs performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: THE CAMPAIGN, FOR PRINTHEADS
description: WHOSE BROAD STRIPES AND BRIGHT STARS? The Trivial Pursuit of the Presidency 1988. By Jack W. Germond and Jules Witcover. 478 pp. New York: Warner Books. $22.95.

title: The Pros and Cons of Keeping a Lawn
description: As a member of the American Forestry Association, I must commend Pete Dunne on his indisputable contrast of lawns versus trees (''In the Natural State'').

title: The Pros and Cons of Keeping Up a Lawn
description: ''In the Natural State'' (Aug. 6) is the second article I've read about lawns; the other asked, ''Why mow?'' Both of them were silly space-fillers.

title: Where Are the Worthy Opponents?
description: THIS year both major political parties in the county have failed the public by not running candidates for office in all the 17 legislative districts. Five of the candidates, two Democrats and three Republicans, are running without opposition in the November elections.

title: Wide Open Spaces
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SCAPEWEED GOAT. By Frank Schaefer. (Poseidon, $17.95.) In a remote mountain cabin, a dying old hermit, known only as J, sits down to give his account of a fateful encounter long ago with a secret utopian community called Home. J's ''short history'' begins in 1845, the frontier cabin J has erected for himself and his bride.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE MAN WHO MADE THE BEATLES: An Intimate Biography of Brian Epstein. By Ray Coleman. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) At the height of the Beatles' popularity, their manager, Brian Epstein, was almost as much of a star as they were - and with good reason, as Ray Coleman's carefully researched biography documents. Epstein's belief in the carefully researched biography documents. Epstein's belief in the Beatles and his hands-on role in molding their image - against considerable odds, he persuaded the scruffy and obstreperous Liverpool rockers to clean up their act - were the keys to their worldwide fame. But Mr. Coleman, who has also written biographies of John Lennon and the rock guitarist Eric Clapton, overstates Epstein's historical significance when he claims that he ''provided the springboard for a social revolution.'' Epstein's role in the ''social revolution'' the Beatles helped ignite had as much to do with luck as with design; and is undercut by the fact that almost none of his other management clients achieved lasting success. Grandiose claims aside, ''The Man Who Made the Beatles'' is a fascinating look at a remarkable entrepreneur. It is also surprisingly short on sensationalism. While he deals candidly with Epstein's homosexuality and his problems with drugs and alcohol, Mr. Coleman discounts the two most prevalent rumors about him: that his drug-related death in 1967 was a suicide rather than an accident, and that he had an affair with Lennon. The evidence he offers to prove that Epstein and Lennon were not lovers, however, is circumstantial; ''firm declarations of John's heterosexuality from Cynthia [ his first wife ] and many other women'' hardly rule out the possibility that Lennon might have had a homosexual fling or two.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE BLIND CAUDILLO
description: To characterize former Dominican President Juan Bosch as a ''symbol of Dominican political instability'' is simply farcical (''In the Land of the Blind Caudillo,'' by Mark Kurlansky, Aug. 6). Bosch was the first democratically elected president of the Dominican Republic. In the short period of his Government, the Dominican people experienced political freedom, hitherto and since unknown, and respect for human rights was the norm.

title: 'Eureeka's Castle': New Niche for Preschoolers
description: ''Eureeka's Castle,'' the first nationally distributed series designed for preschoolers since ''Sesame Street'' appeared on public television in 1969, makes its debut tomorrow, Labor Day, the workers' holiday. As it happens, the target audience is those children who are in day care most weekdays precisely because their parents are at work.

title: Hollywood Actor Finds A New Stage in Chester
Little League Team That Could Fills a Town With Heroes
description: BEFORE he managed a game this summer, before he ordered a player to bunt and long before his players celebrated their final victory by shaving off his hair, Tom Galla of the Trumbull National Little League All Stars was thinking about winning the Little League World Series.

title: Paige Robbins Has Wedding
description: Paige Robbins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Robbins of Kings Point, L.I., and New Milford, Conn., was married yesterday to Eric Nerenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Nerenberg of Rockville, Md. The ceremony, at the Windows on the World restaurant in New York, was performed by Rabbi David Benedict and the Rev. Peter Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: China Rebuffs Pope
description: China has denied permission for Pope John Paul II to fly in Chinese airspace on a visit to the Far East in October, an Alitalia Airline spokesman said Friday. The Beijing Government did not give an official explanation for the decision, said the spokesman, Gianpiero Piva. The Italian carrier is to fly the Pope to Seoul on Oct. 6, the first stop on a 10-day trip.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE PLAYER, by Michael Tolkin. (Vintage, $7.95.) In the cutthroat world of Hollywood, a studio executive finds that random murder seems a logical extension of his job. Last year our reviewer, Janet Maslin, called the book ''a shrewd, entertainingly dark Hollywood novel.'' MISSING BEAUTY, by Teresa Carpenter. (Zebra, $4.95.) In this true story of obsession and murder, a middle-aged medical school professor resorts to homicide to kick an expensive habit: Robin Benedict, a prostitute from Boston's Combat Zone. In this account of the 1983 case, Teresa Carpenter ''has fulfilled the subject's promise,'' David Black said here last year. ''She has been indefatigable in her research, and she has diligently reconstructed the events leading up to the crime, the crime itself and the community's reaction to it.'' THE UNIVERSE, AND OTHER FICTIONS, by Paul West. (Overlook, $10.95.) In one of these stories the protagonist is a neuron - more specifically, the 9,999,999,999th cell in Shakespeare's brain. Other characters in the collection include God, the sun and Moby Dick, author of the novel ''Captain Ahab.'' ''In Mr. West's fiction, weird, beautiful and unimaginable scientific facts apparently stand in for the banished ultimates, providing us with a sense of something outside ourselves,'' Linda Bamber said here in 1988. ''Again and again we are confronted with the huge spaces of astronomy, the vast sweep of geological time.'' THE EAGLE AND THE LION: The Tragedy of American-Iranian Relations, by James A. Bill. (Yale University, $13.95.) A foreign policy scholar re-creates the drama of America's failed attempt to manufacture its own Middle Eastern ally by propping up the precarious kingdom of the Shah. Last year our reviewer, Fouad Ajami, called the book ''the most detailed and vivid account yet of America's encounter with Iran. . . . Running through the book is a touch of nostalgia for a more innocent time.'' ACTS OF WAR: The Behavior of Men in Battle, by Richard Holmes. (Free Press, $12.95.) Plucking details from the long, slow sweep of military history, Richard Holmes tells what it was like to be cannon fodder in the world's various wars. ''The result is satisfyingly exhaustive,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt wrote in The Times in 1986. ''A random list of odd topics covered would include: insects, cigarettes, suicide, venereal disease, pack-weights, 'Dear John' letters, battle cries, plunder, the sounds different weapons make, the smell of decomposing bodies, fatigue, the most-feared types of wounds, the ability of women to kill and the role of rumor on the battlefield.'' THE BIG NOWHERE, by James Ellroy. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) In the midst of the 1950's Hollywood red scare, homosexuals are stalked by a serial killer. The Times's John Gross said last year that ''the mood of the period is adroitly conjured up, and some choice real-life characters put in an appearance: Howard Hughes, Johnny Stompanato, the ganglord Mickey Cohen.'' POOR SUPPORT: Poverty in the American Family, by David T. Ellwood. (Basic, $9.95.) By deciding what values the Government should reinforce, welfare can be used to break instead of perpetuate the cycle of poverty, a professor at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government believes. He ''argues persuasively that although poverty is not a disease caused by a flawed welfare system, a major overhaul of our social-spending policies could go a long way toward curing it,'' Tamar Lewin said in The Book Review last year. THE RUB OF THE GREEN, by William Hallberg. (Bantam, $8.95.) After an aspiring golf pro breaks out of a love triangle and lands in prison, he makes a comeback by helping turn a swamp into a two-hole green. This is a ''poignant, beautifully written first novel'' composed in ''a style that is at once lyric and spare,'' David Stout said here last year. SOMERSET HOMECOMING: Recovering a Lost Heritage, by Dorothy Spruill Redford with Michael D'Orso. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) A black woman from Virginia tells how, inspired by Alex Haley's ''Roots,'' she traced her ancestral lineage back to Africa. The story is ''as much about a remarkable woman as about an American people,'' Carl Senna said here in 1988. THE POET AT THE PIANO: Portraits of Writers, Filmmakers, Playwrights, and Other Artists at Work, by Michiko Kakutani. (Peter Bedrick, $8.95.) During the last decade, Michiko Kakutani says in introducing this collection, she has learned that writers and other artists have many different motives for talking to a member of the press. Her subjects include Saul Bellow, Milan Kundera, Ingmar Bergman, David Byrne, Brian De Palma, Sam Shepard and Laurence Olivier. Most of these pieces were written for The Times. FIREFLY SUMMER, by Maeve Binchy. (Dell, $4.95.) An American millionaire comes home to rural Ireland with a plan to build a luxury hotel. Last year our reviewer, Michele Slung, said this is ''the best Binchy yet, and it should send new readers back to her previous works, 'Echoes' and 'Light a Penny Candle' '' (now also available from Dell, $4.95 each). DOVER ONE, by Joyce Porter. (Foul Play Press/Countryman, $4.95.) To get him out of the building, Scotland Yard sends Inspector Wilfred Dover to find the killer of a promiscuous young housemaid. Later, in DOVER TWO ($4.95), the obnoxious detective is dispatched to investigate the case of a woman who may have been murdered twice. ''The novel, like its predecessor, is plotted with the technique of a virtuoso,'' Anthony Boucher said in The Times in 1965.

title: Professor Slain; Student Held
description: A professor at the University of Florida's School of Medicine was shot to death Friday, and the police charged one of his students with the slaying. The body of the victim, Arthur Kimura, a 41-year-old associate professor of pathology, was found in his home soon after deputies had received a call that a burglar alarm had gone off there. The student, Jens Peter Hansen, also 41, was taken into custody from a car seen leaving the home, the police said. The motive for the slaying was under investigation.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; In a Season Of Garden Excess, Be Flexible
description: Lucky recipients of someone else's garden surplus need to be flexible to appreciate the assortment of fresh vegetables and occasional fruits that come their way at odd times of the day and night.

title: Will Biotechnology Finally Deliver?
description: INVESTING in biotechnology stocks is a little like picking up mercury with your fingers: just when you think you have it, it slips away.

title: Old Dictator Looks Better To Guatemala
description: When a civilian government took office here in 1986 after three decades of almost uninterrupted military rule, it appeared to close a bloody chapter in Guatemala's history.

title: Paris Manners
description: To the Editor: A few words in defense of Paris, with reference to the letter of Mary Frieman (July 23), not that the city isn't perfectly well able to defend itself.

title: The Talk of Tripoli; The Innocents From Abroad Hail Qaddafi
description: The man from Naples had come to Libya, he said, to debate the problems of the world - the environment and so forth. And Peter Furek, from a Zurich assemblage of leftists and others who call themselves ''autonomous,'' thought he might meet the Libyan people.

title: Action by Chase Kills Plan for Hispanic Bank
description: A two-year effort by former Congressman Herman Badillo and others to create a bank mainly for New York City's Hispanic community collapsed Friday when Chase Manhattan Bank pulled out of the deal in which it was to sell the enterprise seven of its branches.

title: POSTINGS: 71 Low-Income Units; Doing Rehabs
description: A Brooklyn community group that has been renovating abandoned and dilapidated buildings in the Williamsburg section is to open three rehabilitated apartment houses near the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway at 10:30 A.M. Friday in a ceremony at 344 Rodney Street. The Rodney Street building and two nearby buildings, at 334 South Third Street and 778 Driggs Avenue, have been redeveloped into a total of 71 apartments: eight three-bedrooms, 44 two-bedrooms, 13 one-bedrooms and six studios. Eight of the 71 apartments will be reserved for the homeless. The redevelopment program was carried out by the Southside United Housing Development Fund Corporation, more commonly known as Los Sures, which means ''southside neighbors'' in Spanish. Los Sures has renovated almost 500 apartments and manages 450 others in 31 buildings.

title: HOW TO MAKE LOVE LIKE A MARTIAN
description: NIGHTSHADE By Jack Butler. 276 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Vietnam Refugees Riot in Hong Kong
description: In the second major refugee riot here in a week, a Vietnamese man was killed today and 11 others were injured during a disturbance that began with a dispute over a gambling debt. The riot reflected a growing tendency toward violence among the frustrated Vietnamese boat people crowded into Hong Kong's detention centers.

title: Center Is Offering More Assistance to the Blind
description: LEAD: SOMETHING new has been added to the services available to New Jersey's blind and visually impaired residents - the first educational and rehabilitation center equipped to handle both commuters and residential students.

title: Seven Brides For Seven Berbers
description: EVERY year in a remote valley deep in the Moroccan Atlas mountains, Berbers of the Ait Hadiddou tribe gather at a Moussem, the equivalent in Morocco of a country fair. There, they sell their sheep, goats, mules or camels, and buy shovels, plastic buckets, tea, sugar and other supplies to support their lonely existence in the mountains for another year.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Dishes Featured in Croton Falls
description: LEAD: THE news that Victoria Zeph had joined the kitchen staff of Mona Trattoria was interesting enough to send us back with great expectations. A partnership of this skillful chef - responsibile several years ago for putting the Long Pond Inn on the map - with the creators of some of the best pasta around promised much.

title: Dr. Nancy Ryan Has a Wedding
description: Dr. Nancy Lyn Ryan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Ryan of New Canaan, Conn. and Stuart, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Harris Lowitt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Lowitt of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. J. Peter Cullen, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Allan L. Press jointly performed the ceremony at the New Canaan home of the bride's parents.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Donora, Pa.;
Glassmaker Plans a Plant
description: LEAD: A DETROIT businessman is working with officials of the Middle Monongahela Industrial Development Association to buy land in an industrial park to establish a 400,000-square-foot glass-production plant.

title: Beethoven Festival Lists a Lost Work
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Ludwig von Beethoven has been dead for 162 years, the Friends of the Arts will begin its 10th Beethoven Festival Friday by presenting the world concert premiere of part of Beethoven's lost, and then almost found, Oboe Concerto in F. The three-day program will take place at Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster

title: Greed Is No Laughing Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: The Car-Seller, Too, Feels Racial Killing's Impact
description: The used car that attracted Yusuf K. Hawkins and his friends to Bensonhurst is no longer for sale and its owner, 25-year-old Nick Hadzinas, still struggles with the knowledge that his innocuous newspaper ad played a role in the tragedy of a family, a community and a city.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: When the 29th Bermuda Bowl begins next weekend in Perth, Australia, there will be 10 teams in contention. Two of them, United States and Poland, as the number one teams in the two biggest zones, will be exempt until the semifinal stage. The other eight, Canada, France, Egypt, Taiwan, Colombia, Brazil, Australia and New Zealand, face a week of qualifying play with two to survive.

title: Ennosuke Rattles Kabuki's Venerable Bones
description: A man is not what he seems. At first he appears to be a hero's loyal comrade, but actually he is a fox in disguise. The tension builds on stage as characters unfold their true identities, baring deep psychological truths. One's friends could be one's enemies, yes, but they can become friends enlisted to fight still other enemies. Life is destined to be confused, tragic and lonely.

title: My Son Is Better Off Learning At Home
description: MY 7-year-old son quit school last year.

title: Serious Crime by Juveniles on Rise
description: LEAD: THE stories made banner headlines: ''10-Year-Old Crack Dealer Arrested.'' ''13-Year-Old Girl Stabs Boy Next Door.'' ''Kindergarten Student Brings Loaded Pistol to School.'' Are children turning to crime at a younger age? According to professionals in the criminal-justice system, while the number of young people engaging in these types of crimes is not enormous, it is on the increase, up nearly 50 percent on Long

title: Ann Kelly Weds Bernard Brennan
description: Ann Kelly of Kinderhook, N.Y., and Bernard T. Brennan of Kinderhook and Delray, Fla., were married yesterday at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Valatie, N.Y., by the Rev. John Caldara.

title: DATA UPDATE: September 3, 1989
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars) July 89 July 88 Change New York 189.1 162.8 +16% New Jersey 209.8 352.0 -40% Connecticut 116.5 175.3 -34% (Source: F.W. Dodge Division, McGraw-Hill Information) MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.48 10.41 11.00 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.88 8.78 8.18 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.24 10.16 10.79 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.64 8.61 8.16 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.29 10.30 10.95 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.76 8.78 8.45 Co-ops (N.Y.)
