Treasury security 8.36 8.30 8.28 National Mortgage Contract Rate 10.10 10.10 8.98 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title: 3 Running to Succeed Leland
description: Three men have announced their candidacies for the seat of the late Representative Mickey Leland, who was killed in a plane crash on a relief mission to Ethiopia last month. They are Anthony Hall, a Houston City Councilman; State Senator Craig Washington, and State Representative Al Edwards. A fourth candidate, City Councilman Rodney Ellis, has not announced his plans, but Mr. Leland's widow, Alison, has said she will support him. Mrs. Leland said this week that because of family concerns she would not seek the job. The election is Nov. 7.

title: Gail K. Negbaur, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: At the Tower Suite of the Time & Life Building in New York, Gail K. Negbaur, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hal K. Negbaur of New York, was married yesterday to Philippe A. Cavat, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Cavat of Versailles and Grenoble, France. Judge Millard Midonick, who retired from the Surrogate Court of the County of New York, officiated.

title: A Grown-Up And Proud of It
description: I have seldom been as annoyed as I was by the Opinion piece ''Why Can't Grown-Ups Act Their Age'' by Edward T. Wolfsohn (Aug. 6). Clearly I am one of the grown-ups Mr. Wolfsohn deplores: I am more than middle-aged, being in my 60's, and I wear a whole gamut of (according to Mr. Wolfsohn) unsuitable garments - the least offensive being several T-shirts with slogans of NOW.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Elmont $153,000 727 Connie Lane 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, attic, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Franklin Square $200,000 1043 Wool Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Farmingville $159,600 457 Adirondack Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new colonial; dining room, basement, 60-foot by 120-foot lot; taxes $3,000. Glen Cove $225,000 28 Crescent Beach Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; den, dining room, screened porch, 50- foot by 125-foot lot; taxes $2,700. Massapequa $165,000 110 Rhode Island Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $3,800. Williston Park $200,000 24 Remsen Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, attic, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. OTHER AREAS Torrington, Conn. $110,000 177 Beechwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 62-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, no garage, needs work, 47 ft. by 142 ft. lot; taxes $806. Howell, N.J. $165,000 490 Windeler Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; deck, eat-in-kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,800. Chappaqua, N.Y. $535,000 70 Annandale Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, family room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $9,684.

title: Pamela A. Block Planning to Wed
description: October wedding plans have been announced by Dorothy Block of Boca Raton, Fla., for her daughter, Pamela Anne Block, and John Bentley Works, a son of Edwin M. Works of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Barbara L. Works.

title: Deborah Ellen McAlister Is Engaged To Wed Christopher Jones in Autumn
description: The engagement of Deborah Ellen McAlister to Christopher M. V. Jones, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Gareth Jones of Cambridge, England, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Andrew C. Hilton of New York and Weston, Conn., and Dr. Edward Hays McAlister of Rochester. A November wedding is planned.

title: Food; Beyond the Burrito
description: MY ONLY VISIT TO MEXICO WAS MORE THAN 10 years ago, but I can still taste the seviche I ate there. The fish was firm and bright, the flavors of lime, spice and peppers were clean and sharp. That flavor had just about nothing in common with the Mexican restaurants I've visited north of the border. At most of them, the only fish on the menu is camarones - or shrimp. These are not the succulent, marinated, grilled shrimp I remember, but ones that are often overcooked and hidden in thick, undistinguished sauces.

title: CALM, COOL AND BELEAGUERED
description: I was disappointed but not surprised to find Faye Wattleton as the subject of the cover story in your magazine. The real story, however, is about those who have waged a 16-year battle against Roe. v. Wade. A more appropriate assignment would be to run an article on how an underfinanced, grass-roots movement has gotten the Supreme Court to reverse itself - despite Faye Wattleton. SCOTT R. WALLER Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ICE TIME: Climate, Science, and Life on Earth. By Thomas Levenson. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) Acid rain, the greenhouse effect, potential atmospheric changes from wide-scale deforestation - these disquieting revelations have made us very aware that climate is not a global abstraction, but a highly complex, volatile, far-reaching interaction of land, atmosphere and water, vulnerable to human influence.

title: Whose Security?
description: To the Editor:

title: Four 'Jerry's Girls' in Darien Revue
description: THE opening number of ''Jerry's Girls,'' the musical melange of Jerry Herman's songs at the Darien Dinner Theater, evokes the composer's flamboyant theatrical creations (Dolly, Mame and Mabel, among them) as well as the glittering originators of those roles (Carol Channing, Angela Lansbury and Bernadette Peters).

title:
GARDENING;
The Well-Managed Compost Pile
description: LEAD: GARDENERS who have used newspaper as a mulch know that it eventually breaks down and is easily tilled into the soil. Much of the breakdown seems to result from earthworms that devour and digest their way through the layers of paper.

title: Timothy Sullivan And Penny Rolfe Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Penny Rolfe to Timothy Paul Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Sullivan of Shrewsbury, Mass., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, N. Anthony Rolfe of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Susan Sulzberger Rolfe of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: Argentine Court Moves to Extradite Ex-Nazi
description: The Federal Appeals Court in the city of La Plata has agreed to extradite the accused Nazi war criminal Josef Schwammberger to West Germany for trial, but he still has resort to the Argentine Supreme Court.

title: Love, Lies and Murder in 1944
description: On march 8, 1945, Pvt. Karl Gustav Hulten, a 22-year-old American G.I. from Cambridge, Mass., was taken from his prison cell here and hanged by the neck until he was dead. The crime for which he was executed was the murder of a London taxi driver named George Heath, whose official police description gave the trial the tabloid tag of ''The Cleft Chin Case.''

title: Lesson in the Baltics: Gorbachev's Tolerance Only Goes So Far
description: HE'S complaining darkly now, but Mikhail S. Gorbachev once found the Baltic republics' high-spirited yearning for something better to be so contagious that he could not help celebrating it during a tour of his Western realm two years ago. The national leader saluted the ''revolution of expectations'' he found there. It was just what he was looking for as a role model for the sort of general desire for ''a speedy social and material return'' that he needed then, and now needs more than ever, to motivate the Soviet nation's far less emboldened masses.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: Denial is a classic symptom of an addiction and Rose will not begin the long road back until he recognizes the need for professional help. Three years would seem an appropriate amount of time to prove the success of any rehabilitation program. STEVE BERGMAN Brooklyn

title: Works in Progress; Keeping Up the Pressure
description: IF YOU LIVE IN A TALL BUILD-ing and you're not getting a good strong shower,'' Wally Rosenwach says, ''you're too close to the tank.'' Rosenwach, 67, is the chairman of one of New York City's two primary installers of those wooden water tanks that sprinkle, so to speak, the city skyline; up to 300 new and replacement tanks are erected annually by the Rosenwach Tank Company. In those buildings whose plumbing requires the help of gravity to create sufficient water pressure, a tank, Rosenwach explains, needs to be elevated at least 25 feet above a building's highest standpipe. ''You get about a pound of pressure for every two feet in height,'' he says.

title: PHYSICIAN, BEHAVE THYSELF
description: LORD BYRON'S DOCTOR By Paul West. 277 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Regretful Recruiter
description: Bo Schembechler of Michigan, in his new book, ''Bo,'' says that recruiting is the worst part of being a college football coach and that he no longer looks forward to it. ''You would be appalled at the things I have to do to recruit,'' Schembechler said. ''A man my age.''

title: Don't Turn Old Glory Into a Portrait of Mao
description: To the Editor:

title: Calamitous Flier
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter the Peacemaker Now Turns to Ethiopia
description: For the second time this year, former President Jimmy Carter, more active and visible than at any time since he left office, is about to play a central mediating role in the affairs of another country.

title: Streaking Yanks Win On Hall's Homer in 9th
description: It is past the point in the season when the home run could have left an indelible mark. After all, the life span of drama in the Bronx these days is painfully short. With the pennant race all but offically over for the Yankees, climactic home runs can produce cheers, but not hope.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: RICHARD CAMERON-WOLFE;
Crossing Soviet Musical Boundaries
description: LEAD: LAST year, Gregory Korchmar, a composer from Leningrad, came to the State University of New York at Purchase as a visiting musician. Last spring, Richard Cameron-Wolfe, the music director of the Purchase campus's dance division and a composer himself, paid a reciprocal visit to Leningrad. Now the two composers have teamed up to begin an ongoing program of exchange visits between American and

title: High-Speed Rail Can't Pay for Itself
description: ANYONE who is a transportation expert has heard, time and again, from people who have ridden on the fast Japanese Shinkansen or the faster French Train a Grande Vitesse, called the T.G.V. ''Why can't we have that in America?'' they ask. My answer is: Because it's an outrageous boondoggle. With one possible exception, no high-speed rail system in this country could pay for itself, and the claimed external benefits - cleaner air, energy saved, eased pressure on airports - are nonexistent.''

title: Tonier Alleys With Day Care and Dining
description: Bowling has not seen any significant growth since the boom that followed the introduction in 1946 of automatic pin-spotting technology, which sets pins in the familiar triangular configuration. Between 1965 and 1975, the number of lanes in the United States doubled to an all-time high of more than 169,000.

title: Swimming With Dolphins Isn't a Carnival Ride; 'Elective Captivity'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Hydroelectric Project Offers Benefits
description: The Aug. 6 article ''Plan for Hydroelectric Project at Old Mine Upsets Residents'' discussed the Mount Hope Waterpower Project with respect to Rockaway Township, but it did not touch on its significance with respect to New Jersey's energy problems.

title: Connecticut's Condo Capital Deals With Boom Gone Bust
description: In the long housing boom of the 70's and 80's, this bustling town on Long Island Sound became known as the condominium capital of Connecticut. More than 3,200 town houses and apartments sprouted in fields and forests and along the rocky shore.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CHANGES IN LATITUDE: An Uncommon Anthropology. By Joana McIntyre Varawa. (Atlantic Monthly Press, $19.95.) Joana McIntyre Varawa is an anthropologist, a former Honolulu harbor master and the founder of the Jonah Foundation to save whales. At the age of 54, dreaming of love in a grass hut with ''a great dark man,'' she flew to the Fiji Islands.

title: No Violence as 300 March Into Bensonhurst Again
description: In the fourth such protest since the killing of a black teen-ager 11 days ago, about 300 demonstrators bearing African liberation flags and chanting ''Yusuf, Yusuf,'' marched through the heart of the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

title: All Aglitter: Tennis's Top Stars And French Glass
description: A trio of parties before this Labor Day weekend hinted at the explosion of social events that will follow. Monday evening's Tennis Ball and awards ceremony honored leading players in the United States Open, now under way at the National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens. The evening in the ballroom of the Plaza was sponsored by the Women's International Tennis Association for the benefit of the March of Dimes Birth Defect Foundation.

title: Sarah Watson Engaged
description: Sarah Ann Watson and Joseph M. Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley T. Anderson of Binghamton, N.Y., plan to be married later this month. The prospective bride is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Watson of Darien, Conn. Ms. Watson, 36 years old, was until recently a social worker with a community program of the Health and Hospitals Corporation in New York. Mr. Anderson, 33, is the associate art director of Motor Magazine, a Hearst Corporation publication in Garden City, L.I.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Howell $165,000 490 Windeler Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; deck, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,800. Jackson $225,000 571 Abbey Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, family room, c/a; taxes $4,000. Lakewood $65,000 56-C Buckingham Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, w/w carpeting, screened porch; taxes $1,294. Livingston $169,000 3 Torrance Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 44-year-old colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $4,707. Millburn $174,000 690 Ridgewood Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, enclosed porch, full basement; taxes $2,590. Springfield $145,000 17 Berkeley Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 44-year-old split level; patio, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,561. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $967,500 Spy Rock Road 5-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, library, family room, 3.9 acres; taxes not yet assessed. Torrington, Conn. $110,000 177 Beechwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 62-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, no garage, needs work, 47-ft.-by-142-ft. lot; taxes $806. Elmont, L.I. $153,000 727 Connie Lane 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, attic, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000.

title: West Virginia Rolls, 35-10
description: Garrett Ford, a sophomore running back who was redshirted last season, gained 127 yards on 16 carries and scored two touchdowns today as the West Virginia Mountaineers defeated Ball State, 35-10, in the opening game for both teams.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: ''Yikes,'' said Alice the Aspiring Photographer over the phone, ''I've just noticed that my new lens has a big scratch on it. What can I do?''

title: If There's a Nostalgia Boom, The Charts Don't Show It
description: With the announcement this summer of major concert tours by the Rolling Stones, the Who, Jefferson Airplane and Paul McCartney, along with the hoopla surrounding the 20th anniversary of the Woodstock Music and Arts Fair, 60's rock nostalgia may have reached a high tide.

title: At Auschwitz, Decency Dies Again
description: It appears that Auschwitz has lost none of its power to derange. Nobody dies there anymore; but decency still does.

title: Wrona's Homer Powers Cubs, 10-3
description: Rick Wrona's three-run homer capped a six-run first inning and Greg Maddux posted his 16th victory as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Atlanta Braves, 10-3, tonight.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Because of the Labor Day Parade in Manhattan, Fifth Avenue between 44th and 72d Streets will be closed from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.

title: Men's Style; The Mild Ones
description: IN THE OLD DAYS, IT WAS EASY. YOU stepped into a pair of beat-up blue jeans, snapped on some leather chaps, oiled up your tattoo and roared off toward the open road.

title:
MUSIC;
Lute Songs Evoke Elizabethan England
description: LEAD: Performing the intimate repertory of 16th- and 17th-century lute songs, which were originally written for private settings, requires significant adjustments by the contemporary performer so that the subleties of the music and words are not lost.

title: Arlene Rosenberg Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Arlene Michele Rosenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seligman Rosenberg of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. David Howard Henick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Henick of Albertson, L.I., took place last evening at the Park Avenue Synogogue in New York. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, assisted by Rabbi David Lincoln and Rabbi Myron Fenster, officiated.

title: Rodeos
description: To the Editor: In Sister Jane Patricia's letter (Travel, July 23), her lack of knowledge about rodeos was obvious. She speaks of cruelty and cited a picture of the bull rider (Travel, June 18). The flank strap, which she calls a ''tight belt'' that ''pains him so,'' is only a mild irritation that encourages the bull to buck and twist. The main reason that the bull tries to unseat the rider is because a bull by nature is mean and easily irritated.

title: Boy Is Mauled to Death by Family Leopard
description: A 16-month-old boy strapped into a car seat was mauled to death Friday by a 200-pound leopard that escaped from its cage at the family's farm, the authorities said.

title: The Statistics Lean to the Positive
description: The economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the Government said, revising an earlier estimate of 1.7 percent. That and other positive reports last week helped further cool the early-summer speculation about an economic downturn. For example, sales of new homes were up 14.4 percent in July, reaching their highest level since December 1986. Personal incomes posted their best gain in four months in July, and consumer spending had its strongest rise in three months. The index of leading indicators was up two-tenths of 1 percent in July, its first rise in three months. The civilian unemployment rate for August was unchanged at 5.2 percent, and job growth, adjusted for strikes, was a sizable 218,000.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Japanese List Hotels as Cheap As $26 a Night

title:
DINING OUT;
A Popular Place With an Ocean View
description: LEAD: Strange though it may seem, there are relatively few restaurants at the Jersey Shore that offer a good view of the sea.

title: Not a Stranger To World Series
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Swimming With Dolphins Isn't a Carnival Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: Nureyev and Topol Help Bushnell Turn 60
description: BUSHNELL MEMORIAL HALL in Hartford is celebrating its 60th anniversary with a schedule that includes new productions of ''The King and I,'' starring Rudolf Nureyev; seven children's shows, and performances by the Vienna Boys Choir, Warsaw Philharmonic and Orchestre National de France.

title: Big Contributions Fueling Koch Race
description: Big contributions played a major role in Mayor Edward I. Koch's fund-raising surge in the last two months, despite a new law in New York City that was intended to keep big money out of election campaigns.

title: Alert for Parents on Toxic Plants
description: LEAD: WITH the phone ringing an average of 110 times each 24-hour period, no day is really slow at the Connecticut Poison Control Center in Farmington, which offers telephone advice to the public. But it is this month and next that are the busiest time, said the director, Dennis Crean, with an increase of 15 to 20 percent in the number of calls taken daily, mostly attributable to young children ingesting the poisonous pokeweed berries and yew berries that ripen at the end of each summer.

title: Sunset on Another Season at the Beach, My Second Home
description: AS the sun settles below the horizon, the sky over the ocean becomes rich with hues of purple and orange that are reflected in the slowly moving water. Flocks of gulls and other marine birds skim the surface of the water, diving lazily into the waves in search of their evening meal.

title: NEW SCHOOL TERM IN CHICAGO PUTS PARENTS IN SEAT OF POWER
description: With the start of the new school year, Chicago will begin what education experts say is the most radical attempt in this country to revamp a big-city school system by shifting power almost overnight from downtown bureaucrats to parents and community people at each of the city's 600 schools.

title: Amelia Zurcher Is Married
description: Amelia Anne Zurcher and Mark Steven Sandy were married yesterday at Christ Church in Pelham, N.Y. The Rev. David Stewart Hoag performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Fewer Hooks, Straighter Rolls And a Passel of Perfect Scores
description: With little equipment needed and the cost of playing one game as low as 50 cents, bowling is certainly an inexpensive form of entertainment.

title: Clergy in Bensonhurst Lead March To Lay Wreath at Site of Slaying
description: Declaring that ''the church can heal,'' the Roman Catholic clergy of Bensonhurst led 200 people, virtually all of them white, in a solemn procession through the Brooklyn neighborhood's streets yesterday and laid a wreath of roses and carnations at the site where a 16-year-old black youth was gunned down 11 days ago.

title: Sorg Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included a loss of $658,000 from discontinued operations. The latest fiscal year results included a write-off of the remaining balance of $2,591,000, of the goodwill relating to the company's acquisition of Kellow Brown in July 1987.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amerifax Inc., Overland Park, Kan., a facsimile service center chain, named Richard J. Emerine chairman and chief executive.

title: Question Box
description: Milers Setting Pace

title: Ferry Your Way To Fun and Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombian Policemen and Soldiers Are Reportedly Tipping Off Drug Figures
description: Three weeks after President Virgilio Barco Vargas declared all-out war on Colombia's narcotics traffickers, many leading drug figures are believed to have escaped to vast areas of the country under their control after being tipped off by corrupt Colombian police officers and soldiers, Colombian and United States officials say.

title: Cubs Have a Team Within the Team
description: LEAD: Shortly before his first-place Chicago Cubs left here last Thursday on their current seven-game road trip, Jim Frey, the executive who serves as general manager, marveled at the performance of the team's manager, Don Zimmer. ''He's done a terrific job,'' said Frey. ''He's got great baseball ability, and the thing about Don is that he doesn't manage with a lot of fear.

title: Journeys End Resorts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bush Ends a Vacation by Getting His Fish
description: ''The jinx is broken!'' exclaimed President Bush.

title: APARTHEID FOES MARCH ON A BEACH
description: Thousands of blacks marched, picnicked and waded peacefully at a whites-only beach today in another in a string of recent anti-apartheid protests. The police made 58 arrests, but waited more than two hours before breaking up the demonstration.

title: Our Native Species Deserve Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS CHOOSE CANDIDATE
description: The Nicaraguan opposition has chosen Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, one of its most prominent figures, to run for President in the elections scheduled for Feb. 25.

title: Bridge; The cornerstone of America's favorite system is the two-level response.
description: A survey of the system preferences of serious tournament players would certainly show that the largest group favors ''Two Over One,'' which might be called Modern Standard American. The cornerstone is the two-level response in a suit to guarantee game, with the possible exception of a minimum rebid in the same suit.

title: U.S. Seeks to Stem Wave of Defections by Polish Fishermen
description: Immigration officials say they are trying to stop Polish fishermen from jumping ship in Alaska and then using their status as political refugees to skirt immigration retrictions and get good jobs on American boats.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock, bond and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the Labor Day holiday. Government offices and most banks will also be closed.

title: Limousine Import Fight
description: The United States International Trade Commission has agreed to look into complaints by American stretch-limousine makers that Canadian manufacturers are dumping the limousines at unfairly low prices. The complaints were filed in July by Southampton Coachworks Ltd. of Farmingdale, L.I., one of the largest makers of stretch limousines in the United States. It asked the commission to investigate whether the Canadian limousines were unfairly subsidized.

title: Campaign Matters; If It's a Race For Mayor, Why No Local Issues?
description: Here's a quick campaign quiz. The positions of each of the six candidates for mayor of New York City on six different issues follow. Name the denominator common to them all:

title: Jets Have a Youthful Look
description: The Jets cut 10 players today, but the intriguing aspect of the move was who stayed rather than who went.

title: Central Sprinkler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Animosity Is On Display As Giuliani Meets Lauder
description: In the first and very likely only joint encounter of the Republican mayoral primary campaign, Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that even though he is the Liberal Party nominee, he would support Ronald S. Lauder if Mr. Lauder won the Republican primary.

title: The Reagan Court - Child of Lyndon Johnson?
description: Liberals may lament the emergence of a conservative majority on the Supreme Court. But they should not forget that one of their own, Arthur Goldberg, played a major role in shaping the political complexion of the current Court.

title: Sparkling Weather as Rainy Summer Wanes
description: On the weekend that serves as an unofficial punctuation mark at the end of summer -never mind that the seasons do not change for another 18 days - Aaron Fay's answering machine summed up what was on thousands of minds.

title: Security Pacific's Asian Strategy
description: The word ''Pacific'' stands out in the name Security Pacific Corporation these days.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know what I think the whole issue is for Congress when we get back? Money. On 80 percent of the issues to come up this fall, there will be a general consensus that we ought to do some things and no consensus on whether we spend the money. And that's frustrating.'' -Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. [ 9:1. ]

title: Uganda Opens Wildlife Parks
description: Uganda has created three national parks to protect wildlife and promote the tourist industry it is reviving after 18 years of neglect. A spokesman for the Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife said today that the parks had been set up in the Ruwenzori mountains (the Mountains of the Moon) bordering Zaire, in the Bwindi forest in Kigezi district in the southwest, and in the Muhavura mountains bordering Rwanda and Zaire.

title: Apartheid Protest at a Beach
description: Thousands of blacks marched, picnicked and waded peacefully at a whites-only beach in an apartheid protest in South Africa. Page 6.

title: Armenian Pianist Is Winner
description: Sergei Babajan, a 28-year-old Armenian pianist, has won the first prize in the eighth Robert Casadesus International Piano Competition in Cleveland. He will receive a $10,000 cash award and concert appearances in France, Italy and the United States, including one as soloist with the Cleveland Orchestra. Nicholas Angelich, 18, of the United States has won the second prize of $4,000 and a number of concert appearances. The third prize of $3,500 was awarded to Megumi Kaneko, 26, of Japan.

title: Giants Tower Over the Mets
description: The Mets brought their West Coast trip to a crashing close today when they lost their third straight game to the San Francisco Giants, 4-0, and lost for the sixth time in nine games on a calamitous swing through California.

title: Firm Ousted By N.A.S.D.
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has expelled one brokerage firm and taken lesser disciplinary action against 16 others.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Still Shunning the Black Doll: What a TV Special Said About Self-Image
description: ''Black in White America,'' the ABC News documentary shown Tuesday, opened with a segment that could have been shot 50 years ago. Confronted with two images identical except for skin color, black children were asked which was prettier, cleaner, smarter. Today, as in Dr. Kenneth Clark's famous doll experiment two generations ago, most pointed to the white-skinned image.

title: Tax Watch; Right Way to Pay Business Owners
description: MANY owners of small businesses believe it makes sense to plow earnings back into the business so it will grow, while limiting what they pay themselves. But the Internal Revenue Service does not see things that way, warns Mary Smalligan, a partner in Deloitte Haskins & Sells, who points out that the agency has taken action against owners who pay themselves what it views as too much or too little.

title: Asbestos Coats Eight Blocks Of 8th Avenue
description: Nearly 50 pounds of asbestos were scattered over a half-mile stretch of Eighth Avenue in midtown Manhattan early yesterday after flood waters surging from a broken main stripped the cancer-causing fiber insulation from two underground steam pipes.

title: Books of The Times; Simenon and the Dark Corners of the Heart
description: Maigret and the Fortuneteller By Georges Simenon Translated by Geoffrey Sainsbury. 140 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95. The Man With the Little Dog By Georges Simenon Translated by Jean Stewart. 169 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: Leonore Guttmacher, 84, in Family Planning
description: Leonore Gidding Guttmacher, who was active in family-planning work for many decades, died of cancer at Mount Sinai Medical Center Thursday. She was 84 years old and lived on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Carl Hovgard, Tax Adviser, 83; Founder of the Research Institute
description: Carl Hovgard, who founded the Research Institute of America, an advisory service for tax professionals, in 1935, was its president until 1967 and then concentrated on oil exploration in Texas and Oklahoma, died Friday at his retirement home in Carmel, Calif. He was 83 years old. The institute sells analyses of legislation and regulatory activity that affects businesses. It advised companies on ways to cope with and profit from government mobilization for World War II. It now publishes guides to technicalities in the tax laws which are unfamiliar to the average taxpayer but are read avidly by accountants and lawyers, and publishes economic analyses used by industry marketing experts. Partner in Law Press

title: Shoney's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 6
description: The company said it has made $165 million of principal payments against the $585 million of bank borrowing used to finance its recent recapitalization. This included $41.2 million of scheduled payments and $123.8 million of prepayments. Principal payments made during the third quarter totaled $10 million.

title: Teltronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Can Summer Survive Labor Day?
description: Labor Day is a duplicitous holiday. Poised between the lazy pleasures of summer and the prospect of life at full throttle, it carries a bittersweet message: Play today, for one must slave tomorrow.

title: Ferrofluidics reports earnings for Year to June 30
OPEC Output Is Called High
description: The daily output of crude oil by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries rose above its self-imposed ceiling in August to the highest level this year, reports from industry and shipping sources show.

title: John Wiley & Sons reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company attributed the revenue increases in its latest first quarter largely to the Alan R. Liss Life-Sciences Publishing division, acquired on June 1; to improvement at Wilson Learning, the company's training group; and to increases in publishing revenues, offset by the loss of revenues from Milady Publishing Co., sold in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1989. The primary reasons for the decline in earnings were the impact in the publishing group of the financing cost relating to the Liss acquisition and a higher effective tax rate. In addition, the company said it incurred scheduled increases in marketing, operating and administrative expenses.

title: Ivy Ozer Is Married
description: Ivy Melissa Ozer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ozer of Kings Point, L.I., and Craig Paul Zuckerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zuckerman of North Bellmore, L.I., were married yesterday at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi Harvey Goldscheider performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Ephraim Biran. Ms. Ozer, 25 years old, who will keep her name, is a graduate of the Boston University School of Nursing and the Brooklyn Law School. She is to join the New York law firm of Squadron Ellenoff Plesent & Lehrer as an associate in October. Mr. Zuckerman, 29, graduated from the Rochester Institute of Technology. He is a freelance medical illustrator in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Moscow Is Discussing Bloomingdale's Shops
description: Marvin S. Traub, the chairman of Bloomingdale's, said yesterday that the retailing chain had had ''serious discussions'' with Soviet officials about opening two shops in Moscow. He said he was confident that a deal could be completed soon.

title: Major Realty reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The 6-month results take into account a restatement for the company's first quarter ended March 31 to $4,985,423, or 68 cents a share, from the previously reported loss of $133,390.

title: Myanmar's Unlost Cause
description: With dictatorships collapsing elsewhere, there's no reason to give up on last year's aborted democracy movement in Myanmar, then called Burma. But Myanmar's plight seems to have got lost in Washington.

title: Seven Oaks International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Head of Lamonts Sees Compliment in Aris Bid
description: Leonard Snyder, the chairman and chief executive who is rapidly expanding the retail stores of Lamonts Apparel Inc. in Western states, says he considers it a personal compliment that the Aris Corporation pointed to his strong management team as a principal reason for wanting to buy the chain, which is based in Bellevue, Wash.

title: Julie McMahan Becomes a Bride
description: Julie Anna McMahan, the daughter of Dr. William McMahan of Park City, Utah, and State Representative Paula Julander of Salt Lake City, and James Peter Shipman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Shipman of Rye, N.Y., were married in Durham, N.C., yesterday at the Duke Chapel at Duke University. The Rev. Joseph Bishop, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A table yesterday listing the endorsements of the six candidates for Mayor of New York City incorrectly described an endorsement for City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. The endorsement came from the Rachel Carson Environmental Democratic Club.

title: Genovese Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 18
description: The company said year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend declared in March.

title: I.R.S. Delays Benefits Rule
description: The Internal Revenue Service has delayed for two months a tax rule intended to encourage companies to provide health and life insurance benefits equally to all their workers.

title: It's No Holiday for Four In the Democratic Race
description: September 4, 1989, Monday, Late Edition - Final

title: Ames Dept Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: Lechters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Decor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: The latest quarter and year included an after-tax charge of $5,850,000 related to a store closing and corporate restructuring.

title: Student Gathering in Virginia Turns Violent; 4 Hurt
description: An annual gathering of thousands of college students erupted early today in a five-hour melee of rock throwing and looting that did not end until the local authorities called in the state troopers and the Virginia National Guard.

title: Steel Prices Are Lowest In 2 Years
description: Reflecting softer demand from automobile producers and appliance makers, steel prices have declined to their lowest point in nearly two years. And industry analysts said prices would remain weak or decline further the rest of this year.

title: Private Funeral For Giamatti
description: Funeral services for A. Bartlett Giamatti, who died last Friday, will be private, according to an announcement issued yesterday by the baseball commissioner's office.

title: Papers Slug It Out in Battle for 'Doonesbury'
description: THE recent effort by The Dallas Morning News to strip its archrival, The Dallas Times Herald, of syndicated treasures like ''Doonesbury,'' ''Dear Abby'' and Erma Bombeck has ignited yet another battle in one of the nation's most bruising newspaper wars.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Founder to Nominate New Chief for Coastal
description: LEAD: After 35 years as chief executive of the Coastal Corporation, the energy company he founded in 1955, Oscar S. Wyatt Jr. has decided to hand over the title to his second in command, James R. Paul.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on the Media Business page last Monday, about a contest to find a $25,000 golden horse, referred incorrectly to the person who retrieved the horse and to those who knew where it was. It was recovered solely by the contest referee, an executive of D. L. Blair. The hiding place was known only to the Blair executive and the contest's two creators, not to the sponsor, Intervision Inc.

title: Genesee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Devils Opening Camp Today
description: The Devils, who have added two Soviet players and a Finn to their Swedish contingent, will be the first of the New York area's three National Hockey League teams to open training camp.

title: Noah Vanquishes Mancini and Will Face Becker
description: Yannick Noah has always entertained tennis fans with his flamboyant style of play. His physical ability on sky-high overheads, diving volleys and thunderous serves has always made him stand out on the court.

title: Sci-Fi Fans Meet to Ponder Genre's Present
description: Cyberpunk and cute aliens are out, if the science-fiction writers, readers, editors, illustrators and fans who gathered here over the weekend have anything to say about it.

title: Hatred and Social Isolation May Spur Acts of Racial Violence, Experts Say
description: A volatile mixture of deep-seated racial animosities, starkly segregated environments and fear of economic change may have fostered the murder of a 16-year-old black youth in Bensonhurst last month, say social scientists who have studied race relations in large cities like New York.

title: 4 Who Burned Church Give Their Apologies
description: Four white people who burned a black church returned to the renovated building Saturday to give their court-ordered apologies to the congregation.

title: Ivy's Recruiting Is Suffering
description: The Ivy League championship could be resolved in the revived Thanksgiving Day game between Cornell and Pennsylvania; the Colonial League will have the player of the year in Frank Baur, the Lafayette quarterback, and the up-and-coming Yankee Conference expects a five-team race for its title.

title: Few Gains for Qaddafi In Drive to End Isolation
description: With fireworks in the night and the spectacle of the visiting Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, riding an Arabian horse in a beachfront race, the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, today wound up a celebration of 20 years of what the official press agency called ''the greatest revolution ever waged.''

title: U.S. Praises Choice of Nicaragua Opposition
description: American officials and other experts on Central America today welcomed the selection of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro as the opposition candidate for President of Nicaragua, saying she was the strongest possible choice and would unify the opposition.

title: Review/Dance; Troupe From Milwaukee Offers 'Romantic Options'
description: The first third of ''Romantic Options,'' a dance by Debra Loewen and Mark Anderson, was generic modern - a neo-Brownian loop here, a post-Tharpian wheel there, performed by a group of alarmingly healthy and well-adjusted-looking dancers from a place that wasn't New York City. Then came two oddly pungent trios. And the piece, performed by Ms. Loewen's Milwaukee-based Wild Space Dance Company at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, took off.

title: House of Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Cybermedic reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and the share earnings for the 9 months was less than one cent a share.

title: Replacement for Ruiz Picked in Bronx Race
description: A Democrat who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge four years ago has been selected to replace former State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr. as a candidate in a special election in the 32d District, which lies in the South Bronx.

title: VARIETY IS NEW SPICE IN MARATHON TRAINING
description: A new approach to the marathon that calls for greater recovery between long training runs and intermittent walking during the race is being advocated by the running authority who helped popularize high-mileage training two decades ago.

title: Gesco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $988,000, or 31 cents a share. c-After an extraordinary loss of $430,700. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: S.E.C. Move On 'Baskets'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday that it would ask the full United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit to review a recent decision by a panel of the court that ordered a halt to trading on two stock exchanges of hybrid financial instruments known as stock baskets.

title: Review/Pop; Dance Bands Convene In Queens for Salsa Festival
description: A handful of the world's best dance bands convened in the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium on Saturday night as part of the New York Salsa Festival '89. Greeted by a wildly enthusiastic audience, the show overflowed with cultural pride.

title: Beth Joan Feller And David Printz, Students, Married
description: Beth Joan Feller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin R. Feller of Dix Hills, L.I., and David Joel Printz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Printz of Del Mar, Calif., were married yesterday at the Dix Hills Jewish Center. Rabbi Nathaniel Steinberg performed the ceremony.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Policy
description: It started in 1898 when the Republic was scratching for revenue to fight the Spanish-American War. Congress levied a ''temporary'' tax of 1 cent on each telephone call valued at 15 cents or more.

title: Hawkins Chemcial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1989.

title: 2 in Bronx Accused of Impersonating Police
description: Two auxiliary police officers were arrested yesterday in the Bronx and charged with impersonating New York City police officers by frisking people who jumped subway turnstiles, the police said.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS PUT RISING FAITH IN NEGOTIATIONS
description: South Africa heads into its national elections on Wednesday with a growing conviction that the nation's political future, and its salvation, lie through negotiation, not confrontation.

title: Holiday Today
description: Because of the Labor Day Parade in Manhattan, Fifth Avenue between 44th and 72d Streets will be closed from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Because of the West Indian Day Parade in Brooklyn, Eastern Parkway between Utica and Washington Avenues will be closed from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Here are Labor Day holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit trains and buses on holiday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on holiday schedule.

title: What's a Fast-Growing Sport With a Designer Label? Golf.
description: Once more, the men in the White House are golfers. Some things, it seems, never change. But look again. ''Golf is the fastest-growing sport in America,'' said Kit Bradshaw, director of publicity for the National Golf Foundation in Jupiter, Fla. ''Its popularity and growth is cutting across different classes, races and sexes.''

title: U.S. Job Death Rate Still Relatively High
description: More workers are killed on the job in the United States than in most other major industrialized countries, according to a report that says the deaths cost the nation's economy at least $15 billion each year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about Voyager 2 misstated the luminosity of the Sun as it would appear from Neptune. The Sun would appear several million times brighter than Jupiter does, as seen from Earth (although the Sun would look only slightly larger than Jupiter); the apparent difference in brightness would not be slight.

title: Nominee for S.E.C. Chairmanship Faces Heavy Sessions With Senators
description: While it might seem logical that a major Government post be given to the most knowledgeable expert in the field, Presidents seldom feel bound by that reasoning.

title: Name as Mask: The Theory And Practice of Pseudonyms
description: Robert Ludlum's Watergate-inspired novel ''Trevayne'' - which was No. 1 yesterday on the New York Times list of paperback fiction best sellers - was Jonathan Ryder's ''Trevayne'' when it was first published in hard cover in 1973.

title: Must U.S. Free Trade Include Jobs Export?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen Farraye Marries
description: Ellen Mary Farraye, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Farraye of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Robert Bonaventura, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent E. Bonaventura of Garden City, L.I. The bride's uncle, the Rev. John Lange, and the Rev. Bernard Camire performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York. Mrs. Bonaventura is a litigation associate with the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. The bridegroom is an associate with the New York investment banking firm of Wasserstein Perella & Company.

title: Cuban Jetliner With 124 Aboard Crashes
description: A Cuban jetliner with 124 people aboard exploded and crashed this evening shortly after takeoff from Havana's Jose Marti airport, the Spanish news agency EFE reported.

title: MOST JOBHOLDERS CONTENT, POLL SAYS
description: Most full-time workers in the United States say they are satisfied with their jobs at least to some degree, but workers born since World War II, who entered the work force since 1960, are much less satisfied than older workers, a Gallup Poll says.

title: Lin Loses Plea On McCaw Bid
description: The Federal Communications Commission has refused to block McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.'s $5.5 billion hostile takeover offer for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Standard Brands Paint reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,145,000, or 20 cents a share, from effect on prior years, to Jan. 31, 1988, of adopting FASB 96 on accounting for income taxes.

title: Bielecki's Streak Is Snapped As Braves Set Back Cubs, 8-5
description: Jeff Blauser had three singles and three runs batted in as the Atlanta Braves ended Mike Bielecki's six-game winning streak with an 8-5 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Pitching Is the Key In Stretch Drive
description: With four weeks left to play, what wins pennant races with four teams scrambling down the home stretch?

title: Western Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said lower earnings in the latest second quarter and 6 months were virtually all attributable to the anticipated and previously announced decline in sales of its pictionary board game.

title: Two Sides in Warsaw Seem Near Cabinet Pact
description: Solidarity and the Communist Party appear to be nearing agreement on a new Cabinet whose makeup would satisfy both Communist demands for additional power and Solidarity's requirement that the party come to terms with a reduced role.

title: U.S. Would Bypass Factions In Arming Afghan Guerrillas
description: Administration officials said today that they hoped to arrange for the direct delivery of American weapons to Afghan guerrilla commanders inside Afghanistan, bypassing leaders of rebel factions based in Pakistan. The Pakistani intelligence directorate would continue to handle the deliveries.

title: Corrections
description: A map in some copies on Aug. 24 with the text of secret protocols to the 1939 Soviet-German nonaggression treaty showed the 1945 status of eastern Germany incorrectly. The German Democratic Republic was not officially proclaimed until 1949. The map also depicted postwar Lithuania incorrectly; it extends farther east to include Vilnius, the capital.

title: Evert Returns To Form
description: They walked onto the Stadium Court like twins, each with her sun-burnished hair pulled into a girlish ponytail caught up by a purple bow, each with a tentative smile in the other's direction. But the resemblance ended there.

title: Morris Injury May Be Serious
description: A week before the Giants open their season, they learned that Joe Morris, their career leader in rushing, might have broken his right foot and might be sidelined for weeks, months or even the season.

title: Iacocca Thinks of Cutting His Role at Chrysler
description: Lee A. Iacocca, who guided the nation's third-largest auto maker from near ruin to prosperity, said he has all but decided to leave the chief executive's post at the Chrysler Corporation at the end of 1991, when his four-year contract expires.

title: Laura E. Carsky, Dietitian, Marries
description: Laura Elizabeth Carsky, a daughter of Katherine S. Carsky of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late James B. Carsky, and Herald Franklin Stout 3d, the son of Lieut. Col. Herald Franklin Stout 2d, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Stout of Edinburgh, Va., were married at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville. Msgr. James M. Connolly performed the ceremony.

title: Donna Hall Wed To Michael Curry
description: Donna Lynn Hall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Russell Hall of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Michael Peter Curry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Curry Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. Msgr. Oscar Ferland performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Barrington. He was assisted by Auxiliary Bishop William J. McCormack of the Archdiose of New York, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Msgr. Florence D. Cohalan, the bridegroom's great-uncle.

title: Hudson's Bay Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary credit of $27,000,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Soviet Student Pursues College Degree in U.S.
description: An 18-year-old Soviet woman who will start classes at Emory University this week is apparently the first Soviet citizen to seek a degree from an American college.

title: Nancy Northup Weds Daniel Bergner
description: Nancy Jean Northup, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Samuel Northup of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Daniel Martin Bergner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Bergner of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. John Buehrens, a Unitarian minister, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: Laurie Adams Weds
description: Laurie Anne Adams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Y. Adams of Tallahassee, Fla., was married yesterday to Thomas Amory Host, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stig Host of Old Greenwich, Conn. A Congregational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Norman S. Ream on the lawn of the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo. Mrs. Host is a geologist working with Advanced Sciences Inc. in Denver. Mr. Host is the president of Peak Properties and Development Corporation, a real-estate development concern in Boulder, Colo.

title: Bid for UAL Seen Passing U.S. Scrutiny
description: Although the Government has indicated that it is prepared to take a harder line against leveraged buyouts of airlines, it is unlikely to reject outright a $6.75 billion bid for the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, analysts said over the weekend.

Circus Circus Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $9,235,000, or 28 cents a share, from a cumulative effect, to Feb. 1, 1988, of reduction of deferred tax liability due to a change in accounting principle.

description: To the Editor:

On a Stoop in Brooklyn, Life Was Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Trinidad Defeats Guatemala by 2-1
description: Kerry Jameson scored with two minutes left today to lead Trinidad and Tobago past Guatemala, 2-1, and into a 4-point lead over the United States in World Cup qualifying.

title:
Sports World Specials: BASEBALL;
Mixed Emotions
description: LEAD: For the six Cuban-born players on the University of Miami baseball team, a trip to the Soviet Union promises to be an emotional experience.

title: Avinda Video reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CPI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 22
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,246,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $324,000 for the quarter and $708,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect pending unit sale.

title: Fleetwood Enterprises reports earnings for 13wks to July 30
3 Cardinals Defend Convent Pact Against Attack by Polish Primate
description: Strongly disagreeing with Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, three of the four Cardinals who signed an accord with Jewish representatives to move a convent away from the Auschwitz death camp said today that the agreement must be upheld.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections.

title: Myth of Methanol
description: To the Editor:

title: Developing Nations Benefit As Service Exports Grow
description: Tens of millions of television viewers in more than 100 countries have followed the adventures of a sultry 19th-century Brazilian slave named Isaura who endures all sorts of adversity after falling in love with her master's son but eventually triumphs.

title: Reviews/Music; Violating the Pop Structure
description: Form dictated emotion at the drummer Bobby Previte's show at the Central Park Band Shell on Friday night. Mr. Previte, leading a band that included Marty Ehrlich on saxophone, Ray Anderson on trombone, Jerome Harris on bass and guitar, Stewart Cutler on guitar and Zeena Parkins on keyboards, has no fears about avoiding the grinding repetition of pop structure: a piece of his might open with a 15-second jolt of texture, then move into new territories, one after another, and never look back, leaving the air filled with surprise and question marks.

title: Local Business Weeklies Seek a New Direction
description: Two years ago, Michael K. Russell, then the chairman of American City Business Journals Inc., told employees of The St. Louis Business Journal that he would never sell his controlling interest in the company for less than $80 a share.

title: Tell Teheran: No Hostages, No Money
description: LEAD: The Government's attitude toward money and hostages is curious. It says that the United States won't pay ransom, yet it has paid and is ready to pay again hundreds of millions of dollars to Iran without demanding progress on the hostage front.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Taking Measure; Everything to Know on Odometer Readings
description: The Government has clarified what it takes to comply with the Truth in Mileage Act. And what it took was 30 columns of single-spaced fine print in the Federal Register.

title: The Post-Industrial Era Is Over
description: The sun is about to set on the post-industrial era.

title: The 1969 Cubs Still Haunt Highpockets
description: It was some time in late June and the Cubs were tripping all over themselves, and over the foul lines, too. They had been in first place for much of the season and suddenly they had dropped to second. People in Chicago were asking, ''What's wrong with the Cubs?'' One observer said: ''It's the Cubs' annual June swoon. The reason people are confused is that it usually happens early in June. The swoon just came a little late this year.''

title: Hong Kong Journal; Frantic for Deliverance From China's Clutches
description: When several local legislators recently suggested using Hong Kong's hefty budget surplus to buy an uninhabited island somewhere and resettle the colony's 5.7 million people there, other lawmakers agreed the idea was worth pursuing.

title: Panda Cub Dies of Infection
description: The tiny cub born Friday to the National Zoo's pair of giant pandas died of an infection early today, leaving officials clinging only to the tenuous hope that the aging animals might mate again.

title: Proposal on Hunt Tax Debt
description: The Internal Revenue Service has proposed settling the bill for Nelson Bunker Hunt and Carolyn Hunt's back taxes for about $200 million - less than one-third of the $700 million the Government originally sought.

title: Laura M. Rubenstein, a Lawyer, Weds
description: Laura Meryl Rubenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry G. Rubenstein of Gladwyne, Pa., and New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Nir Barzilai, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Barzilai of Haifa, Israel. Rabbi Henry Cohen performed the ceremony at Beth David Reform Congregation in Gladwyne.

title: Dr. Shayevitz, a Veterinarian, Is Married
description: Dr. Jessie Rebecca Shayevitz, the daughter of Dr. Myra Shayevitz and Dr. Berton Shayevitz of Holyoke, Mass., was married in Northampton, Mass., last evening to Dr. Robert Morton Kellman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Kellman of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Daniel Jezer performed the ceremony at the Helen Hills Chapel at Smith College.

title: OUTDOORS: TIME FOR BLUEFISH AND STRIPED BASS
description: From Cape Cod to New Jersey, the prime surf casting months for big bluefish and striped bass are September and October.

title: Ramya Thambuswamy Has Wedding
description: Ramya Thambuswamy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ayyaswamy Thambuswamy of Perrysburg, Ohio, and John Schaller Hopley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hopley of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in Perrysburg. Madhao Kharche, a Hindu priest, performed a Hindu ceremony, which was followed by a Presbyterian ceremony performed by the Rev. Ronald Martell.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Norman Wins: Greg Norman lost a four-stroke lead, then recovered with three birdies on the final seven holes yesterday for a three-shot victory in the Greater Milwaukee Open. Norman was at one over for the day before his late surge carried him to a final-round two-under-par 70 and a 72-hole score of 269 at the Tuckaway Country Club in Franklin, Wis. Andy Bean, with a final-round 66, finished in second place. Wayne Levi, who had three birdies and an eagle on the front nine to pull even with Norman, faltered with three bogeys on the back nine and finished with a 71 for a 274. (AP) McBee Surprises: Rives McBee shot a 69 in the final round and became only the third qualifier in the history of the Senior PGA Tour to win a tournament as he captured the Senior Golf Classic in Lexington, Ky. McBee, of Dallas, finished the 54-hole event at Marriott's Griffin Gate Resort golf course at eight-under 202. The victory was worth $45,000. Harold Henning, who began the day one stroke back at 134, shot an even-par 70 to finish in second two strokes back.(AP) Ritzman Is Leader: Alice Ritzman birdied the final two holes yesterday to finish off a six-under-par 66 and take a two-shot lead after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. Rail Classic in Springfield, Ill. Ritzman's 36-hole score of 135 put her ahead of Cathy Gerring and Betsy King, this year's leading money-winner. Gerring had 69 yesterday and King shot a 66.(AP) Auto Racing Earnhardt Is First: Dale Earnhardt wasn't going for a bonus yesterday, but he drove as if he were, setting a record pace to win the Southern 500 Nascar stock car race at Darlington (S.C.) Raceway. Darrell Waltrip, who did have a chance for the Winston Million, didn't come close to earning the bonus that goes to any driver who wins three of the sport's four major races. Waltrip finished 22d, eight laps back. Earnhardt led eight times for a total of 153 laps in the 367-lap event and averaged a record 135.462 miles an hour, breaking the race record of 134.033 m.p.h. set in 1983 by Cale Yarborough.(AP) Fabi Is Winner: Teo Fabi of Italy raced past Al Unser Jr. 26 laps from the finish, then used a perfect fuel strategy to run away to the Porsche team's first Indy-car victory in the Red Roof Inns 200 yesterday in Lexington, Ohio.(AP) Wrestling Soviet Team Prevails: Soviet wrestlers topped the medal rankings yesterday at the world freestyle championships after winning 4 of 10 titles at the two-day competition in Martigny, Switzerland. Second behind the Soviet team, which also earned two silver and two bronze medals, was the United States team with two championships and four silver medals. In yesterday's concluding matches, the 1988 Olympic gold medalist, John Smith of Stillwater, Okla., defended his world title in the 62-kilo (136.5 pounds) category with an easy 6-0 decision over Gary Bohay of Canada. (AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-6

title: Health Plan Tax Loophole
description: A new Federal health-care plan for the elderly contains a loophole that encourages tax-exempt investments and could cost the Treasury significant revenue losses, a Government investigator said last week.

title: Critic's Notebook; Is She a Rising Star? Or a Flash in the Pan?
description: Careful readers of the English magazine Opera, those who bother to devour all the fine print down to the ''fringe'' and school performances section of local British esoterica in the back, may have perked up a bit on page 623 of a recent issue.

title: Meg Newhouse, Executive, Wed
description: Meg Lynne Newhouse, the daughter of Florence Newhouse of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., and Irving Newhouse of New York, and Elliot Roy Sealove, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Sealove of Manhasset, L.I., were married yesterday at their home in Hampton Bays, L.I. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated.

title: Lisa Distelheim, a Reporter, Is Married
description: Lisa Beth Distelheim, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Distelheim of Highland Park, Ill., and William Francis Barron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Barron of Greenwich, Conn., were married last night at the Ritz-Carlton in Chicago. Rabbi Harold Kudan officiated.

title: INSIDE
description: Flood Scatters Asbestos A water main break flooded 8 blocks of midtown Manhattan with water and mud tainted with asbestos, closing the area to residents. Page 29. Cabinet Stakes in Poland Solidarity and the Polish Communists appear to be near an agreement on a Cabinet that would satisfy the union's requirement that the party come to terms with a reduced role. Page 2. Brooklyn's Volatile Mix Racial animosities, isolation and the fear of economic change may have led to the killing of a black youth in a white neighborhood. Page 31. Student Violence in Virginia An annual gathering of thousands of college students in Virginia Beach erupted in a five-hour melee of rock throwing and looting. More than 100 stores were damaged. Page 7.

title: Steel City Still Needs Help Despite Big Steel's Comeback
description: Plumes of smoke and steam billow again from the stacks of the USX Corporation's Gary Works, signaling the dramatic revival of big steel along the southern shore of Lake Michigan.

title: Hollywood Still Feels Writers' Walkout
description: A year has passed since Hollywood returned to work after its longest strike ever, and the industry has been assessing the damage ever since.

title: Some Luster Is Lost For Spanish Tourism
description: The thousands of vacationers lured this summer to the island of Mallorca by rock-bottom hotel prices have benefited from the slump in Spain's leading industry, tourism.

title: Israeli Aircraft Raid A Target in Lebanon
description: Israeli Air Force planes bombed a guerrilla base in southern Lebanon early today, a military spokesman here said.

title: The Issues Waiting for the Returning Congress
description: TAXES AND SPENDING

title: Twins' Big Hitters Stop Blue Jays, 9-4
description: Rick Aguilera won his first decision as a starter since Oct. 3, 1987, and the left fielder Dan Gladden hit a homer and threw two runners out at the plate as the Minnesota Twins stopped the Toronto Blue Jays, 9-4, today. The Jays' winning streak ended at five games.

title: Sports World Specials: SOCCER; Putting Information At Fans' Fingertips
description: The oldest soccer publication in the United States, Soccer America, has come up with a simple idea to provide a service to soccer aficionados: a yellow pages in booklet form.

title: AIDS Camp Frees Children of Awful Secret
description: Under a canopy of pine trees and a flawless blue sky, nine children with AIDS and their families spent the last week fishing and berry-picking, molding clay pots and singing campfire songs, making friends and breaking the bonds of secrecy that surround their disease.

title: The Enemies Within Poverty Law
description: So long as President Bush delays naming directors for the national Legal Services Corporation, he must share in the blame for one of Ronald Reagan's most prolonged abuses.

title: WATERY TREADMILL: SWIMMING LAPS IN A MACHINE
description: An engineer from New York has developed a new lap pool for swimmers, which works as a runner's treadmill does. The swimmer strokes in place, moving against an even current. Water in the pool moves as a river does, constantly circulating at a rate of 8,000 gallons a minute, according to James Murdock, the inventor of the Endless Pool. The rate of flow can be adjusted by turning a valve at one end of the 12-foot swim lane.

title: Bell, W & Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
As School Begins, Educators Are Facing Tough Lessons
description: As millions of summer-sated children in the New York metropolitan region get ready to tackle the 3 R's, school officials are tackling a tough course in demographics: how to cope with the baby-boom generation's own baby boom, which has led to overcrowded elementary schools, while high school classes have shrunk dramatically.

title: For Hispanic Paper, a Rising Market
description: El Diario/La Prensa, the Spanish-language daily newspaper in New York City, is the latest media organization to realign its ownership and management in an effort to capture the attention of a booming Hispanic market.

title:
BUNTING;
IS IT A LOST ART?
description: LEAD: The images that linger from last year's pivotal fourth game of the National League Championship Series between the Dodgers and the Mets are of Hollywood home runs. A two-run shot by Mike Scioscia brought the Dodgers back from the cutting-room floor to tie the game in the ninth. A home run by Kirk Gibson knocked the Mets' lights out in the 12th.

title: Philadelphia Journal; From Sidewalk Artistry To a Hotel on Easy St.
description: The Rittenhouse, a new hotel and condominium building here, is something of a private art gallery for Joe Barker, a street artist who sets up his easel every day in the center of the city.

title: Aides See Koch and Dinkins Neck and Neck in the Stretch
description: As they prepare to unleash a final avalanche of leaflets, letters, telephoned appeals and televised commercials, advisers to all four Democratic mayoral candidates agree that the primary appears to have evolved into a showdown between Mayor Edward I. Koch and Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

title: Gwendolyn Levine Is Wed
description: Gwendolyn Tracy Levine, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm Levine of Old Westbury, L.I., and Michael Craig Levy, a son of Milton Levy of New York and Corinne Levy of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Reuven Grodner performed the ceremony. The bride, 21 years old, is a graduate of Syracuse University. She is a manager in the housewares department of Macy's in New York. The bridegroom, 22, also graduated from Syracuse and is the director of customer services for Nation-Wide Plastics Company in Woodside, Queens.

title: Zenith Expects Loss in Quarter
description: The Zenith ELectronics Corporation said Friday that it expects to report a loss in the third quarter and that it is now less confident that it will report a profit for the 1989 year.

title: Claire Luce, 85, Dies; Was Versatile Actress
description: Claire Luce, a 1920's Ziegfeld star who left the musical stage for the classical theater, died Thursday at her Gramercy Park home in Manhattan after a lengthy illness. She was 85 years old.

title: Trade Talks Aim at Economic Habits
description: The United States has in recent years let the dollar collapse in value while its trade negotiators have denounced, cajoled and pleaded to get Japan to import more American products. But despite some progress, the trade deficit with Japan remains about what it was in 1985.

title: August's Congressional Recess Brought Lawmakers Little Rest Back Home
description: Congress returns to the capital after an August recess that was more restive than restful, as four weeks back home only underscored the hard political choices facing lawmakers.

title: Sports World Specials: BASEBALL; The Latest in Bats
description: As the pennant races heat up in the major leagues, the wooden-vs.-aluminum-bat controversy continues to simmer, stoked by stories that appeared this summer in Sports Illustrated and USA Today.

title: Reviews/Music; Alternate Cast In 'Desert Song' By City Opera
description: The New York City Opera's current run of ''The Desert Song'' is offering alternate casts. Saturday afternoon's featured Michele McBride as Margot and Richard White as Pierre, with Louis Otey playing Paul Fontaine.

title: Power Shoe-Lacing: More Than Meets the Eyelet
description: You may have noticed that athletic shoes often have extra holes around the lacing area. Usually there's a single extra hole on each side, but in the new models there may be as many as four or more extra holes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Steel prices have fallen to their lowest point in nearly two years, reflecting softer demand from automobile producers and appliance makers. Analysts said prices would remain weak or decline further the rest of this year. At the same time, the operating rates for the nation's steel mills have tumbled, to 76 percent at the end of August, from 89.5 percent in the comparable period last year and a high of 93.9 percent at the end of March. [ Page 33. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Trade talks are set to open in Tokyo today in a new phase of the U.S.-Japan effort to curb the American trade deficit. The talks are aimed at identifying and perhaps altering ''structural impediments'' to trade, which have to do with how each country manages its economy, organizes its businesses and sets basic priorities for its people. The negotiations are expected to last a year, and the going looks like it could be rough. [ 33. ] Developing countries are finding gold in the export of services. The trend is likely to have significiant implications for the world trading system. The third world's increasing stake in other nonmanufacturing activities that economists generally lump together as services is giving impetus to world trade liberalization, many trade officials believe. [ 33. ] Mallorca's rock-bottom hotel prices have benefited thousands of vacationers lured there this summer during the slump in Spain's leading industry, tourism. Amid fears that rooms would remain empty, the hotels started a price war. [ 37. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The sale of El Diario/La Prensa makes it the latest media organization to realign its ownership and management to capture the attention of a booming Hispanic market. What is noteworthy about the sale of El Diario, the Spanish-language daily newspaper in New York City, is that it reflects a striking change in the makeup and distribution of New York's - and America's - Spanish-reading population since 1980. [ 33. ] American City Business Journals Inc. has scaled back considerably from its peak of two years ago as it tries to recover from its rapid expansion. The company has a new chairman and controlling shareholder. His predecessor told employees two years ago that he would never sell his interest for less than $80 a share. In June, though, he settled for $22.75. [ 38. ] Was the Hollywood writers strike worth it? A year after the five-month walkout, a CBS official says the networks permanently lost 2 percent of their viewers, and a guild leader acknowledges that the strike sharply reduced the work for writers. [ 38. ] Yet another battle has flared in the Dallas newspaper war as a result of the attempt by The Dallas Morning News to strip its archrival, The Dallas Times Herald, of such syndicated treasures as ''Doonesbury,'' ''Dear Abby'' and ''Erma Bombeck.'' Press. [ 38. ] COMPANIES Security Pacific is forging close ties with Mitsui Bank, the banking arm of the Japanese financial and industrial giant, hoping that the relationship will bring new Japanese banking customers to Security Pacific in the United States. Greater possibilities are envisioned, including teaming up with Mitsui, or another Japanese company, on deals in the Pacific Rim or in Europe. [ 33. ] The U.S. will study carefully the $6.75 billion bid for UAL. Although the Government has indicated that it is prepared to take a harder line against leveraged buyouts of airlines, it is unlikely to reject the labor-management offer outright, analysts said. The bid, which offers $300 a share to shareholders, was presented to the UAL board on Friday after the stock exchange closed. [ 33. ] Lee A. Iacocca said he has all but decided to leave the chief executive's post at Chrysler at the end of 1991, when his four-year contract expires. [ 35. ] Bloomingdale's has had talks with Soviet officials about opening two shops in Moscow, said its chairman, who is confident that a deal could be completed soon. [ 34. ] TODAY'S COLUMN The I.R.S. has taken action against owners of small businesses who pay themselves what it views as too much or too little. But there are acceptable practices that owners can use to keep from running afoul of the I.R.S. Tax Watch. [ 34. ]

title: Alternative Fuels Are a Step to Cleaner Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Win Again As Dent Wises Up
description: Bucky Dent is growing smarter by the day. He is clearly more talented and more effective now than he was a week ago. Better prepared? Without question.

title: Barry Hyams, 78, Producer and Publicist
description: Barry Hyams, a former Broadway producer and publicist in New York and San Francisco, died Friday after suffering a heart attack at his San Francisco home. He was 78 years old.

title: Fly Now, Pay Never
description: Leona Helmsley's conviction for tax evasion evoked much schadenfreude, pleasure at her misfortune. People remembered what her former housekeeper testified she had said: ''We don't pay taxes. Little people pay taxes.''

title: Jackson Urges Voters' Support For Dinkins Bid
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson preached redemption and praised David N. Dinkins before an overflow congregation at a church in a black neighborhood in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: New World to Conquer for Chilean TV Star
description: For a time, Mario Kreutzberger, the television showman, spent two nights of every week on an airplane, struggling to sleep as the 4,500 miles between Santiago and Miami glided by.

title: Peete Is Sidelined For Lions' Opener
description: The rookie Detroit Lions quarterback, Rodney Peete, will sit out three to five weeks of the regular season after spraining his knee Saturday in an exhibition game against the Los Angeles Rams, the team announced today.

title: Cimco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter results were significantly below expectations due to greatly reduced customer requirements and higher than anticipated expenses associated with the start-up of a number of new product lines.

title: Socanav Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Steinlen Takes the Million
description: Steinlen, who proved himself the best grass horse in New York with two impressive victories at Saratoga last month, suggested he might be the best in the country when he scored a half-length victory over Lady in Silver today in the $1 million Arlington Million at Arlington International Race Course.

title: A.&S. Makes a Big Bet In Manhattan Retailing
description: Across the street from Greeley Square, where men and women living out of shopping bags sometimes doze on park benches in the middle of the afternoon, a sleeping giant is awakening.

title: Cuomo Calls For 'New Era Of Harmony'
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday dropped another cryptic hint in New York City's mayoral race when he said he supported the candidate ''who can best bring this city together,'' a remark quickly taken by supporters of David N. Dinkins to mean a tilt toward the Manhattan Borough President.
