description: Francis Bouygues said today that he had resigned as chairman of Bouygues S.A., the French concern that calls itself the world's largest construction company, in favor of his 36-year-old son, Martin. The 66-year-old Mr. Bouygues said he would remain a board member but would no longer be active in the day-to-day activities of the company. Speculation over Mr. Bouygues's resignation begain last year when he was rumored to be in poor health.

title: Economic Scene; Imported TV Sets Face Test in Japan
description: IN what might seem like carrying coals to Newcastle, the Philips Consumer Electronics Company this month will begin exporting color television sets from its Greeneville, Tenn., factory to Japan.

title: Lessons
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti used to argue that two of his great loves, baseball and literature, were spiritual cousins.

title: A Winged Insecticide Beats Mosquito Hordes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about A. Bartlett Giamatti referred incorrectly in some copies to a book he wrote. It is ''The Earthly Paradise and the Renaissance Epic.''

title: In Hungary, Communists Are Cheerful
description: Hungary's Communists are following with understandable concern the troubles of the Polish Communist Party, which recently lost its hold on the Government after four decades of absolute control. But the Hungarians say they are not having nightmares about meeting the same fate.

title: President Of Arby's Dismissed
description: After days of heated dispute, Victor Posner, the Miami financier who controls Arby's restaurants, dismissed the company's president and chief executive yesterday after the executive, Leonard H. Roberts, resigned from the DWG Corporation, which owns Arby's.

title: DE KLERK STIRRING WASHINGTON HOPES
description: American officials say they have high hopes, but no firm expectations, that the Acting President of South Africa, F. W. de Klerk, will be more willing than his predecessors to negotiate with blacks on steps to end apartheid.

title: Why Right-Hand Rule for Mazes Works
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13, B7 Salvadoran rebels will enter talks aimed at ending a decade of civil war, the rebels said. Page A1

title: Group Is Pursuing American Western
description: A group led by the senior management of the American Western Corporation said it is trying to raise enough money to acquire all common shares of the Sioux Falls, S.D., maker of plastic bags. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the management group, led by John L. Mulligan, American Western's chairman, did not disclose a price that it would be willing to pay for American Western's shares.

title: When Ordering, Watch Your Language
description: SCENE I. June 1975. The setting is the lunch counter at Bailey's in the Back Bay section of Boston. The 21-year old woman is not carrying a suitcase, but only because her luggage was lost between Columbus, Ohio, and Logan International Airport. She has just moved to Boston. ''May I have a cup of coffee, please,'' she said. ''Regular?'' asked the woman behind the counter, and the expatriate Midwesterner swooned. How many gourmet coffees must drip through Bunn-o-matics in Boston! In Ohio, coffee was coffee.

title: Random Drug Tests for Police
description: The New York City Police Department will begin random drug testing of all officers, from patrolmen to the Commissioner. Page B1.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: HERE we are, back from our vacations and with lots to do and a few entertaining obligations left over from spring. The microwave oven can help solve the problem by turning out pates in dazzlingly short times and with no sloppy, dangerous hot-water baths. Put out two pates to make a cocktail party with some breads, mustards and cornichons, or use one as a lead-in to dinner.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a camp for children with AIDS referred incorrectly to the site in California. Last summer the program was in Sonoma County, near the coast. This summer the program used a site 120 miles to the northeast, near the Tahoe National Forest.

title: MCA Music Group Names New Chairman
description: Al Teller has been named chairman of the MCA Music Entertainment Group, which includes MCA Records, MCA Distributing, MCA Music Publishing, the Universal Amphitheater and several other operations that are part of MCA Inc., a diversified entertainment conglomerate. He replaces Irving Azoff, who has headed the company's music operations since 1988.

title: Corrections
description: The Sky Watch chart on Sunday misstated the distance traveled by light in a minute. It is 11.16 million miles.

title: Outlays for Next Fiscal Year Would Rise by $716 Million
description: President Bush's drug control proposals would cost only $716 million more in the next fiscal year than drug programs already in that year's budget.

title: Chicago
description: IN its lavish food and elegant interior, Mareva's restaurant on Milwaukee Avenue evokes the all-but-vanished aristocratic culture of prewar Poland. Lately, underneath the lively Slavic melodies from the grand piano and wandering violinist, there can also be sensed the excitement of new possibilities for the old country in the intense conversations of Polish-speaking patrons.

title: Net Rises 15% at Heinz
description: The H. J. Heinz Company, a leading maker of processed foods, said today that its net income rose 15 percent in the quarter that ended on Aug. 2. The company reported profits of $126.5 million, or 95 cents a share, up from $110 million, or 84 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 5.8 percent, to $1.45 billion from $1.37 billion. The company said its Heinz ketchup, Ore-Ida frozen potatoes and Star-Kist tuna brands all showed strong volume increases.

title:
'Days of Rage' - Journalism or Propaganda?;
It's a Fair, Honest Film
description: LEAD: I am amazed and saddened at the controversy over my documentary on the Palestinian uprising, ''Days of Rage:

title: Political Analysts' Leader
description: Judith N. Shklar, the John Cowles Professor of Government at Harvard University, took office Saturday as the 85th president of the American Political Science Association. Dr. Shklar, a political theorist, is the first woman to head the 10,500-member organization, which has been meeting here.

title: INSIDE
description: Dollar Rises Sharply The surge prompted selling of the currency by the Federal Reserve to try to keep it from moving up. The dollar will now buy almost 2 West German marks. Page D1. A Conversation on Race For two Brooklyn clergymen concerned about improving race relations, a recent conversation revealed vast differences on the causes of racial conflict. Page B1. Beirut Embassy Evacuated The U.S. Ambassador and his staff have been evacuated because of poor relations with Christian leaders, official sources said. Page A8. Ben Johnson Loses Records Track's international governing body voted to strip the Canadian runner of his world records because of his admitted use of steroids. Page D21.

title: Plea by Demjanjuk's Lawyer
description: The Israeli lawyer for John Demjanjuk, a convicted Nazi war criminal, said today that new evidence had been found in a garbage can at the United States Justice Department, and he asked for a delay of at least 18 months in the case. The lawyer, Yoram Sheftel, accused department employees of concealing the evidence, which he said includes testimony contradicting court rulings that Mr. Demjanjuk was responsible for the death of hundreds of thousands of Jews in gas chambers during World War II.

title: Rule That Will Strip Johnson of His World Records Is Approved
description: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter, was effectively stripped of his world records in the 100-meter dash and the indoor 60-meter event yesterday when the International Amateur Athletic Federation passed a rule that nullifies any mark held by someone who admits to having used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Populist Regains His Power In Belize General Elections
description: The populist leader George Price, who led Belize to independence from Britain eight years ago, has regained power in general elections, according to results announced today.

title: Metal Detectors Deemed Success and Will Expand in Schools
description: The use of metal detectors in five public high schools in New York City reduced weapons possessions and other threatening incidents in the last school year, the Schools Chancellor, Bernard Mecklowitz, said yesterday.

title: Suez of Paris Buys Insurer For $4 Billion
description: Ending the largest takeover battle in French history, Compagnie Financiere de Suez, the Paris-based banking group, today sweetened its bid to $4 billion and won control of Groupe Victoire, the nation's second-largest insurer.

title: Dollar Rise Causes Fed To Step In
description: The dollar surged yesterday, prompting a round of concerted dollar selling by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan, the West German Bundesbank and eight other European central banks.

title: Drug Maker Rejects Pleas
description: The Burroughs Wellcome Company yesterday rejected demands by AIDS advocacy groups that it reduce the price of the AIDS drug AZT, which costs patients up to $8,000 a year.

title: 4 to 6 Communist Seats Seen in New Polish Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has completed his Cabinet selections, and they include at least four and perhaps as many as six Communists, officials said today.

title: Bar Panel Says Courts and Jails Mishandle Prisoners With AIDS
description: The handling of AIDS cases by the criminal justice system in New York State has sometimes deprived defendants of their legal rights and endangered their lives with inferior prison health care, a new report by the City Bar Association charges.

title: Dow Off 7.41, but Airline Issues Are Active
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday, the first day of trading following the long Labor Day weekend, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 7.41 points, to 2,744.68.

title: Capital
description: Presidents sometimes say the most surprising things.

title: Hugh P. Fox, Engineer, 84
description: Hugh P. Fox, an architectural engineer and former commissioner of the Board of Standards and Appeals for New York City, died of heart disease yesterday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 84 years old and lived in Rossmoor, N.J.

title: Help for Workers in a Complex World
description: Because millions of American workers cannot read, write or reason well enough to do their jobs, demand is growing for programs to teach adults literacy and technical skills.

title: Decision at UAL May Take Weeks
description: The bidding war for United Airlines is apparently far from over. People close to the situation said yesterday that the board of the UAL Corporation, United's parent company, might take at least several weeks to approve a bid.

title: West German Economy Continues to Strengthen
description: West Germany's economy turned in the strongest performance in 13 years in the first half, as the gross national product expanded by 4.6 percent from the level a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: In First for TV, a Network Asks Its Rival for a Show
description: The NBC television network has asked a production company owned and operated by the ABC television network to create and produce a prime-time drama series. If it works out, it would be the first time one network has produced a television show to run on another network.

title: Evert Bows Out as Garrison Prevails, 7-6, 6-2
description: Chris Evert's retirement descended on her yesterday afternoon with the gentle thud of one of Zina Garrison's deceptive and destructive drop shots.

title: The Nature of Racism: 2 Clergymen Disagree
description: Since the killing of a 16-year-old black, Yusuf K. Hawkins, by a gang of whites in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, there have been expressions of outrage, grief and remorse.

title: Occidental Petroleum To Lay Off 900 at Unit
description: In a move that analysts said reflected the limited growth potential of oil and gas exploration in the United States, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it would lay off 900 people in a restructuring of domestic operations intended to save nearly $100 million annually.

title: Japan Holds 5 in Bid to Sell Uranium to U.S.
description: Five Japanese have been arrested for trying to sell almost nine pounds of refined uranium to the United States Embassy for $83 million, the police here said today.

title: A Timeless Resort Celebrates Its Menu
description: LEAD: AT once elevated and enclosed by the Allegheny Mountains of western Virginia, the Homestead, a year-round resort hotel, has successfully banished the hurly-burly of modern living that lies beyond its dining areas, 15,000 acres of woods, golf courses, trails, spas and tennis courts.

title: After Trek From Brazil Crash, Survivor Says 46 of 54 Live
description: Two days after a Brazilian jetliner vanished over the Amazon, a survivor reached a remote ranch today and reported that 46 of the 54 people aboard survived a crash landing in the jungle.

title: Little Compton, R.I.
description: IN a town where the motto is ''Let's Keep Little Compton Little,'' the bakery Olga's Cup and Saucer has been a surprisingly busy success.

title: Official Injustice on AIDS
description: Last year, New York State's Office of Court Administration issued guidelines for the handling of defendants and prisoners with AIDS. It was a sorry display of ignorance. Among other things, the guidelines authorized use of surgical gloves, masks and plastic shields when dealing with AIDS victims.

title: Geren Gets All Caught Up In the New Yankee Spirit
description: On the charter flight that took the Yankees from the height of a winning streak to the uncertainty of the road, Bob Geren remembered he had been talking with his teammates about the team's sudden surge. The next thing he knew, he had agreed to let them shave his head.

title: Peru to Get Aid From U.S. Bank
description: The American Express Bank Ltd. reached an agreement with the Government of Peru and the International Foundation for Education and Self-Help to donate $5 million of its loans to the country to provide local currency financing of self-help programs, the company announced yesterday. The deal, which will reduce

title: U.S. Charges Bank Fraud
description: The former president of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, Patrick G. King, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Dallas on 13 counts of bank conspiracy, false entry and misapplication of funds, the Justice Department said.

title: El Paso Utility In Note Pricing
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company yesterday priced $300 million in notes with a maturity date of Sept. 1, 1990, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Royal M. Howard, Ophthalmologist, 67
description: Royal M. Howard, former chief of ophthalmology at Staten Island and Seaview Hospitals, died of coronary artery disease on Sunday at Staten Island Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: Computer Sciences Gets Subcontract
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation said it had received a 13-year subcontract worth $134 million to help to modernize the nation's air traffic control system. The main contractor on the $3.6 billion Federal Aviation Administration program is the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Private Library Struggles to Find New Purpose
description: The New York Mercantile Library Association, at 169 years of age one of the city's most illustrious literary adornments, no longer operates as a circulating library and is exploring new arrangements to maintain its reputation as a literary center. The library is known for its storehouse of books and the roster of eminent writers, including Emerson, Twain and Thackeray, who crossed its threshold to lecture on their craft, The Merc, as the library at 17 East 47th Street is known, stopped its services as a circulating library in mid-August, although its members still have the use of the gracious second-floor reading room, adorned with busts of eminent literary figures and illuminated by 14 chandeliers. The members can draw from a stock of 300,000 books and periodicals, including an especially large collection of mysteries.

title: Griffey Homers as Reds Beat Giants
description: Ken Griffey hit a three-run homer to cap a five-run third inning, and the Cincinnati Reds held on to stop San Francisco's winning streak at five games with a 6-5 victory tonight over the Giants.

title: Review/Film; Decency Battles Tyranny In 'Spices,' From India
description: ''Spices,'' opening today at the Cinema Third Avenue, is a socially alert, cinematically primitive Indian melodrama about feminism.

title: Soviet Plan To Cut Deficit
description: The Soviet Union plans to sell off unprofitable companies and issue bonds to help cut a $200 billion budget deficit.

title: The Pop Life
description: Jackson Raps Rap

title: National Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Assets for the latest period ended July 31 were $33,246,000,000 versus $30,666,000,000 for the year-ago period. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Jets' Offense Is Wary Of Patriots' Backups
description: The Patriots and the Jets got bad news this week: three of New England's best players, all defenders, are out for the year after being injured in the final exhibition game.

title: Casey's General Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * '21' Club, the Manhattan restaurant, to David L. Rawle Associates, Charleston, S.C., with an undisclosed budget.

title: Sanderson Farms reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,250,000, or 13 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Esterline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $376,000, or 4 cents a share. c-Included tax benefits of $236,000, or 3 cents a share, and $951,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S. Duo Gains In World Rowing
description: In the second day of qualifying heats for the world rowing championships on Lake Bled, Kris Karlson teamed up today with Cary Beth Sands to win their heat of the double sculls. They advanced directly to the final Sunday.

title: Mitchell Energy & Developent reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an after-tax provision for litigation of $13,596,000 and a gain from an accounting change of $20,594,000. c-Included an after-tax provision for litigation of $13,596,000.

title: SALVADOR REBELS AGREE TO TALKS WITH NEW REGIME
description: Leaders of El Salvador's leftist guerrillas said today that they had agreed to talks with the country's new rightist Government aimed at ending a decade of civil war.

title: No Change in Basics
description: President Bush's strategy for fighting drugs calls essentially for the Government to do more of what it has been doing with only marginal success for years: build more prisons, make more arrests, pay for more treatment centers and intensify efforts to break up drug-trafficking organizations.

title: Books of The Times; Tales of Suspense From the Psychiatric Couch
description: Love's Executioner And Other Tales of Psychotherapy By Irvin D. Yalom, M.D. Basic Books. 270 pages. $19.95.

title: Entertainment Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains from extinguishment of debt of $860,932, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,505,682, or 12 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary gains from extinguishment of debt of $254,292, or 2 cents a share, and $756,217, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The latest quarter and 6 months results included an unusual expense of $1,039,847, representing the writedown of the balance of the company's book value for its Crazy Eddie common stock.

title: Adtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said the decrease in the net income for the year and the loss in the fourth qurater can be primarily attributable to the increase in the estimated costs of approximately $800,000 of the Crescent City, Calif. projects during the fourth quarter of 1989. The company also said the fourth quarter results do not include an additional $56,000 related to income taxes which was previously reported in the first quarter of 1989 as $42,000 which should have been $98,000.

title: How to Get Drug Strategy Report
description: ''The National Drug Control Strategy,'' the report that President Bush sent to Congress today, can be ordered by mail or telephone or bought at Government bookstores.

title: You'll Never Get Rich Trading Sleep for Cash
description: To the Editor:

title: Cummins Engine
description: The Cummins Engine Company completed the sale of certain assets in its finance unit to a Citicorp subsidiary for $45 million and said it would use the proceeds to pay off some of its short-term debt. Cummins said last February that it would sell the unit as part of a restructuring plan to make it more competitive globally. Last month, the founding family of the engine company bought Hanson U.S.A.'s 8.8 percent stake in Cummins for $72 million.

title: Not-So-Vegetarian Soup
description: To The Living Section:

title: Blank Check for the Disabled?
description: With surprisingly narrow public scrutiny, Congress is moving swiftly to extend broad civil rights protection to the nation's 40 million disabled citizens. The sentiment is laudable: to bring the disabled closer to the mainstream of American society. But the legislation is vague; not even its defenders are able to calculate its benfits and costs. Those costs could be monumental. The proposal thus requires patient, unemotional examination.

title: Drexel Guilty Plea Expected In Fraud Case on Monday
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. will enter its guilty plea on Monday to six felony counts of mail and securities fraud, people in the United States Attorney's office and at the investment house said yesterday.

title: A Question Of Good Taste
description: The idea of legalizing drugs is distasteful for several reasons.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Baby Whale Holding Its Own
description: A baby sperm whale washed up on a beach here over the weekend and has been taken to a marine park, where experts are trying to save its life. The 900-pound whale is ''not getting any worse but not getting any better,'' Cheryl Snyder, senior trainer at Sea-Arama Marineworld, said today. ''He's holding his own.''

title: Georgia Gulf Gets Simmons Threat
description: The Dallas corporate raider Harold C. Simmons threatened to start a fight for control of the board of the Georgia Gulf Corporation if the board acted to thwart his $1.38 billion offer for the company. Mr. Simmons had earlier said he wanted a friendly transaction with Georgia Gulf.

title: A System to Speed Airline Travel
description: Six years ago, Mark Teflian may have been one of the few people who could have conceived of the sprawling system of interwoven computers that controls virtually every aspect of the United Airlines terminal here at O'Hare International Airport.

title: Sunrise Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $10,784,000 and $10,851,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Warners Promotes Top Three Executives
description: Warner Brothers has announced the promotion and re-alignment of its top three production executives.

title: Queens Leaders Are Indicating A Shift to Koch
description: With a week to go before the mayoral primary on Sept. 12, Queens Democratic leaders have signaled their intention to drop their support for Richard Ravitch and endorse Mayor Edward I. Koch's bid for a fourth term.

title: Wang Adds 4 New PC's
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., seeking to restore customer confidence and increase sales after a devastating loss and management shakeup, announced a new line of four I.B.M.-compatible personal computers today.

title: Bakker Suffered Only Stress, His Wife Says
description: The evangelist Jim Bakker, facing a hearing on whether his fraud and conspiracy trial will continue, was suffering from stress and not mental illness when he collapsed last week, his wife said today.

title: NHD Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
A Slice of New York (On Rye) in Texas
description: A recent conversation between a customer and waiter, conducted in a Texas drawl, went something like this:

title: Jersey Bell and Union Agree
description: New Jersey Bell reached a tentative agreement with its remaining striking union late yesterday and said its 15,000 workers, who have been on strike for a month, could be back on the job by Friday.

title: Bridge
description: There have been numerous cases of bridge players winning chess or backgammon tournaments, or making a small profit playing blackjack in casinos. But these are all intellectual recreations with a mathematical component. A different cross-game activity occurred in July.

title: Now Beijing Blames a Single Villain for All Its Ills
description: As China fills out its official version of the crushed democracy movement, a single villain has emerged who is held responsible for the student turmoil and virtually all of the country's economic woes: Zhao Ziyang, the ousted chief of the Communist Party.

title: Good Wines, Good Prices
description: TUSCANY has always been a source of some of the world's best wine bargains. This is still true, but times change: now the best Italian wines rank with the best of France and California and, not surprisingly, their prices reflect that. Here are some particularly good values.

title: Rivals' Contest Aids Buffalo's Mayor
description: Mayor James D. Griffin is a balding, bellicose man who calls his detractors ''goofs'' and ''liars.'' And like Edward I. Koch, his sometimes caustic counterpart at the other end of New York State, he has been in City Hall ever since winning a long-shot campaign in 1977.

title: Colombia's Leaders Take Drug Fight Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. to Pay For 'Live From Lincoln Center'
description: General Motors is to succeed Exxon as the sponsor of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' television series beginning in January, George Weissman, the center's chairman, said yesterday.

title: Diana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 22
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter included a gain of $14,661,000 from the disposition of subsidiaries.

title: Fabricland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $420,000, or 16 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Drug Suspect Shot by Officer
description: A drug suspect was shot and seriously wounded by an undercover police officer during a buy-and-bust drug operation yesterday in the Bronx, the police said. The suspect, who was not immediately identified, was listed in serious condition at Jacobi Hospital, suffering from a chest wound. The police said the undercover officer, who was dressed in street clothes, fired his weapon when the suspect apparently tried to rob him. The incident occurred in an apartment at 1105 Elder Avenue in the Soundview section at 2:22 P.M. during an operation by the police Tactical Narcotics Team.

title: Grand Met Sale Of Mecca Unit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that it had signed an agreement to sell its interests in the William Hill and Mecca betting shops to Brent Walker P.L.C. for $:685 million, or about $1.06 billion.

title: Weaver to Manage
description: Earl Weaver, who led the Baltimore Orioles to four American League pennants, has decided to return to managing, with the Gold Coast Suns of the Senior Professional Baseball Association.

title: McDonald's Test Of Fried Chicken
description: The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest restaurant chain, is testing bone-in fried chicken at a handful of outlets in Dallas and Houston, a spokeswoman said. The fast-food chain currently sells chicken filet sandwiches and bite-sized Chicken McNuggets. The spokeswoman declined to give details on the test.

title: Record Summer for Movies
description: The blockbuster action film ''Batman'' and the comedies ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' and ''Parenthood'' helped Hollywood rack up a record summer box office of $2.05 billion, according to figures released Tuesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It might not be the way I want people to remember me, but at least I'll be remembered.'' - Zina Garrison, after defeating Chris Evert. [ D23:6. ]

title: Ciudad Bolivia Journal; Forsaken Land Awaits a New Breed of Farmers
description: Out on the flat plains of western Venezuela, where cows outnumber people, a seed has been sown to bring Latin Americans back to the land.

title: Stronger Data Show Fiber Reduces Colon Cancer
description: Adding fiber to the diet can apparently shrink precancerous polyps in the lower intestine, reducing the risk of cancer of the colon and rectum, researchers have found.

title: L.J. Simone Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
The Bagel's New York Accent Is Fading
description: THE clash between old and new, tradition and progress, father and son that befell Bell Bagels in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn started when J. J. Bell wanted to experiment with an oven that both steams and bakes bagels, eliminating the step of boiling them before baking. His father, Marty Bell, himself the son of a bagel baker from Poland, was opposed.

title: Colombia's Leaders Take Drug Fight Seriously; Rivals the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Critical of I.M.F. Austerity Plan
description: Austerity measures imposed on the poorest countries by the International Monetary Fund as a condition for new loans, have produced no results, according to a United Nations report.

title: O.M.B.: A Dangerous Superagency
description: LEAD: A major battle - perhaps war - is brewing in Congress over the Office of Management and Budget, which has become a dangerous antidemocratic superagency.

title: A Prescription Form To Deter Forgeries
description: rrUsing technology tricks borrowed from the banking industry, a medical publisher is providing doctors with tamper-resistant prescription forms intended to deter narcotics traffickers.

title: STUDY DISCOUNTS PILL-CANCER LINK
description: A 10-year study of 118,273 women has found that middle-aged women who waited to take birth-control pills until their mid-20's face no unusual risk of breast cancer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Careercom Corp., King of Prussia, Pa., an operator of business schools and tractor-trailer companies, accepted an offer from Home Group Investment Corp., a merchant banking unit of Ambase Corp., to merge the company with Apple Acquisition Corp., a newly formed entity, for $11.50 a share.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Seeks Acquisition Of Landor
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM is negotiating to acquire Landor Associates, a large independent international corporate identity consultant with headquarters in San Francisco.

title: Suffering A Fool Ungladly
description: The court jester at the Royal Britain Exhibition here made unkind jokes about the royal family, and the museum's managers, not amused, told him to stop or else. He was suspended today. The marketing director for the exhibition, Kim Keble-White, said James Lovell, a 24-year-old actor who had been appearing as the fully costumed court jester, could have his job back if he cut the offending material from his act.

title: For Bergman, a New Twist on an Old Love
description: When Ingmar Bergman completed his Oscar-winning film ''Fanny and Alexander'' in 1984, he declared it the last of his some 50 movies. But he seems a most reluctant retiree at times. ''I dream about doing a film about once a week,'' he conceded.

title: Fish Nets Trap Dolphins In the Mediterranean, Too
description: Ignoring pleas from scientists and government officials, Mediterranean fishermen are joining Pacific nations in the large-scale killing of whales, dolphins and turtles through the use of huge drift nets in commercial fishing.

title: Brown Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,000,000, or 17 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,663,000 and $4,052,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Review/Television; The Palestinian View, Between Bookends
description: So the weeks of anger have finally arrived at ''Days of Rage.'' After being denounced as pro-Palestinian propaganda by the management of Channel 31, which squarely refused to show it, Jo Franklin-Trout's 90-minute documentary found its way to Channel 13, which added an hour of background reports and discussion as well as the information that PBS has been unable to pin down assertions that the Arab American Cultural Foundation, which receives financial support from sources in Kuwait, provided some of the money for the program. The result can be seen tonight at 9, under the title of ''Intifada: The Palestinians and Israel.''

title: Robert A. Greenberg, 59, English Professor
description: Robert A. Greenberg, professor of English at Queens College, who specialized in Victorian literature, died of leukemia Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: Everest & Jennings Internaional reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $874,000 and $970,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $319,000 for the quarter and $207,000 for the 6 months.

title: Japan Urges U.S. to Save
description: In talks today seeking solutions to the trade imbalance between Japan and the United States, Japanese representatives asked the Americans to save more, cut their budget deficit and adopt longer-term business thinking.

title: Unidentified Suitor Rejected by Syncor
description: The Syncor International Corporation rejected a merger proposal it said it received last week from an unidentified company, adding that it is not for sale. The rejected bid was apparently made at about the same time as a bid by the Van Kampen Merritt unit of the Xerox Corporation, which notified Syncor last week of an offer of $7.57 a share.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Cholesterolphobics

description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: He has talked of perhaps going elsewhere next season. New York, he has said, can be a cold, intimidating and lonely place. Last night, however, just might have given Juan Samuel reason to pause.

title: Promoting Texas: Ribs to Chili
description: ''Come to a country where the menus are in English and the food has an accent,'' an advertisement says. ''Visit a country where the natives are friendly and the language barrier is easily overcome,'' says another. Both trumpet, ''Texas: It's Like a Whole Other Country.''

title: About New York; Doctor's Orders: Take Eye Exam And Support Arts
description: We've finally secured an appointment with Dr. Eugene Weise, an ophthalmologist whose office is at 115 East 61st Street. We're invited to perch in a high-backed white metal swivel chair. The lights dim. We prepare to squint at an eye chart.

title: A Fragile Air Freight Strategy
description: The Federal Express Corporation is learning to greet customers in many different languages around the world, but some replies have been unfriendly.

title: United Gaming Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from an accounting adjustment of $565,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: H.U.D. Plans to Tighten the Rules On a Program That Lost Millions
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has decided to revamp a multi-billion-dollar mortgage insurance program that has cost the Government hundreds of million of dollars because of fraud and mismanagement, H.U.D. officials said today.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

description: Companies

title: Real Estate; Office Space In Orange County Rises
description: THE shortage of affordable housing, the high commercial rents and traffic congestion in such suburban office strongholds as Westchester County, Fairfield County and Bergen County have prompted some users of office space to venture farther north into the Hudson Valley region. A handful of developers has kept up with the demand for space in Orange County.

title: Agnes C. Maginnes
description: Agnes C. Maginnes, who was active in charitable work in Westchester County, died of cancer of the colon yesterday at the home of her daughter, Nancy Kissinger, in Kent, Conn. She was 94 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Ruling Due Sunday
description: The disputed 1-0 victory by Brazil over Chile in the World Cup qualifying match in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday is still causing a furor, but the Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's world governing body, said yesterday it would issue a ruling on the match next Sunday from its headquarters in Zurich.

title: A DEMOCRAT LIKELY AS ARMS DELEGATE
description: A conservative Democrat who has long been a confidant of Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, has been tentatively selected as the new American negotiator in talks to reduce conventional armed forces in Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carlisle Cos., Cincinnati, an industrial-products manufacturer, named Dennis J. Hall executive vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Jerome H. Eichert, who retired.

title: Prague to Make Changes, but Not Dramatic Ones
description: In a time of dramatic change in much of Eastern Europe, ''no dramatic change in the situation in Czechoslovakia can be expected,'' the Government spokesman insists.

title: Kidder Fills Equity Post
description: Thomas S. Shattan, who arranged private equity financings for emerging growth companies at Goldman, Sachs & Company, has been hired by Kidder, Peabody & Company to build a new department there to do the same.

title: 2d Officer's Wife Is Slain in Colombia
description: Gunmen shot and killed an army colonel's wife in Bogota today. Officials said the killing and one a day earlier were indications that the country's drug cartels might be stepping up their fight against a nationwide drug crackdown by attacking the relatives of members of the security forces.

title: Text of President's Speech on National Drug Control Strategy
description: Following is the prepared text of President Bush's speech here tonight setting out his plans for a national drug control strategy:

title: A PULLOUT BY U.S. REPORTED IN BEIRUT
description: The United States Ambassador and his staff were evacuated from Beirut this morning because of deteriorating relations with the Christian army commander, official sources here said.

title: Accounting Talks Go On
description: Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse announced yesterday that their exploratory merger discussions were continuing, as the two former competitors seek to tackle the 1990's jointly.

title: After Serving Man, a Humane Home
description: Paul moved into a retirement village here recently. It was not exactly his decision, but he likes it well enough.

title: Seabrook Plan Backed
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has approved emergency response plans for Massachusetts communities near New Hampshire's Seabrook nuclear plant, it was learned today, clearing another obstacle to commercial operation of the plant.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Aug. 18 and Sept. 3 about plans for peace talks between the Ethiopian Government and Eritrean rebels, under the sponsorship of former President Jimmy Carter, described the history of Eritrea incorrectly. Before its colonization by Italy in 1890, it was part of Ethiopia, not an independent nation.

title: KEY RATES
Alamo for State Senate
description: Who's favored to win next week's special election in the South Bronx - an election to fill the unexpired term of State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr.? Until last week, the answer was Mr. Ruiz himself - despite his Federal felony conviction and subsequent ouster from the Senate.

description: A former district office manager for Representative Newt Gingrich said today that she had to argue with Mr. Gingrich and his aides to prevent them from using the Congressional office and staff workers for political campaigning.

title: New Pests Threaten California Crops
description: Record numbers of exotic insects are invading Los Angeles County and threatening California's $16 billion-a-year farm economy.

title: Market Place; Stock Strategist Turns Cautious
description: THE Labor Day weekend has often been a turning point for investors, with September proving to be a weak month for stock prices. True to form, one of Wall Street's most influential investment strategists turned cautious over the holiday weekend and yesterday advised his institutional clients to sell 10 percent of the stocks in their portfolios.

title: General Re Sets Debenture Offering
description: The General Re Corporation, a reinsurance holding company, is offering $150 million in debentures due in 2009 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Communist Leader in Lithuania Warns on Provoking Soviet Action
description: The leader of the Lithuanian Communist Party said today that it was important for the Baltic republics not to push so hard in their drive for independence that they would provoke Moscow to use military force.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: When it came time to select a non-playing captain for a world championship team, the American Contract Bridge League used to select someone whose political connections vastly exceeded his playing expertise.

title: Fed Dollar Sales Set 3-Month Record
description: In its largest intervention ever in a three-month period, the Federal Reserve sold $11.9 billion worth of dollars, including $2 billion in two days, in its effort to curb the rise of the dollar in May, June and July.

title: Campbell Reports Loss
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it had lost $194.7 million in the quarter ended July 31, because of a worldwide restructuring.

title: Fall Classes for the Practical or Artistic
description: CLASSES and workshops for adults and children in the coming months will offer lessons in home decoration, blueprints for garden planning and harvesting and instruction in creating functional, folk and fine-art objects, among other subjects. Here is a preview of some of them.

description: Two Soviet astronauts orbited the Earth today and prepared to climb aboard the space station Mir after a four-month break in the Soviet manned space program forced by failures and disputes over costs.

description: ICM Artists and the Howard Gilman Foundation, which jointly sponsored the continuation of an American tour by the Donetsk Ballet in February after the Soviet dancers were stranded in Baltimore, are being sued by Heart of Art, the original producer of the tour.

description: ROWING U.S. Crews Gain: Five of the eight United States crews racing in the repechage, or second chance heats, advanced yesterday to the semifinals of the world championships on Bled Lake in Yugoslavia.

title: Angotti Repurchases Stake Held by Boase

description: b-Net income

title: Arby's New President
description: Arby's Inc. said today that Irving Riese had been named president of the roast-beef-sandwich chain. He succeeds Leonard H. Roberts, who was dismissed by the company Tuesday. Arby's is a subsidiary of the DWG Corporation, which is controlled by Victor Posner. Arby's said Mr. Riese is a principal in the Riese Organization, which controls more than 500 restaurant and real estate operations in 33 states.

title: Campaign Trail; Nadler Says 'This Is Not My Year' and Abandons Race
description: The lopsided four-way Democratic race for New York City Comptroller became a slightly less lopsided three-way contest yesterday when Assemblyman Jerrold L. Nadler, stuck at the bottom of the pack, dropped out and threw his support to a fellow Assemblyman, Alan G. Hevesi.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Western Corp., Sioux Falls, S.D., a maker of plastic bags, is discussing a $64.4 million leveraged buyout with a management group.

title: PRETORIA'S RULERS LOSE MANY SEATS BUT RETAIN POWER
description: The National Party, which has dominated South Africa's politics for 41 years, suffered substantial losses to conservative and liberal challengers in voting for the white House of Parliament on Wednesday, but maintained power by a slender margin.

title: Softkey Software reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Exxon Slips Away
description: The not so funny story is that it takes 10 Exxon executives to change a light bulb: one to change it and nine to do the public relations.

title: Illegal Sales to Contras By Salvador Reported
description: Officials of the Salvadoran Air Force illegally sold more than 61,000 gallons of aircraft fuel paid for with United States Government funds to the Nicaraguan guerrillas in 1986 and 1988, a Congressional agency said in a report issued today.

title: Court Overturns Ban on Logging
description: A Federal appeals court today lifted an injunction that blocked the cutting of centuries-old trees on Federal land in Oregon, but it kept alive a lawsuit by environmentalists to protect the northern spotted owl.

title: Home Improvement
description: GLAZED ceramic tile is pretty, durable and moisture resistant. To keep it sparkling, regular cleaning is necessary. And if tiles are damaged or the filler between them - known as grout - begins to deteriorate, prompt, skillful repair is essential.

title: Revised Data on Output Up a Bit in 2d Quarter
description: American workers posted a modest productivity improvement in the second quarter, with significant gains by factory workers leading the way.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Acquired Ron Tingley, catcher, from the Cleveland Indians for a player to be named. CLEVELAND (AL) - Called up Jeff Kaiser and Rudy Seanez, pitchers; Mark Higgins and Denny Gonzalez, infielders; and Beau Allred, outfielder, from Colorado Springs of the Pacific Coast League. Called up Tom Magrann, catcher, from Canton-Akron of the Eastern League. MINNESOTA (AL) - Acquired Greg Johnson, pitcher, from the Houston Astros completing a trade for Mark Davidson, outfielder. OAKLAND (AL) - Recalled Scott Hemond, third baseman, and Dann Howitt, first baseman-outfielder, from Huntsville of the Southern League.

title: 50 at Private Service As Giamatti Is Buried
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of major league baseball and a former president of Yale University, was buried today after a private graveside service at the Grove Street Cemetery.

title: Accounts
description: * Pharmavite Corp., to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, for its Nature Made Vitamins.

description: The morning after President Bush told the nation that he did not want his drug strategy to set off a ''partisan bidding war,'' skirmishes broke out today between Republicans and Democrats over how to finance the program.

title: Currents; The Face Isn't Familiar
description: RUSSIANS tell time on watches that look considerably different from those made in the United States. Now, eight different styles of Russian watches are being imported by the Time Exchange in Manhattan.

description: Annual Symposium, New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx; 212-220-8720.

description: b-Included a loss equaled to 3 cents a share from Telecredit's Light Signatures Inc. unit.

description: The board of trustees of the University of Alabama yesterday tentatively priced $67.7 million in University of Alabama at Birmingham hospital revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

description: To The Home Section:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an increase in blood imports to the United States misstated the type of blood -called the universal donor - that can be transfused to a patient with little risk of reaction. It is O negative, not O positive.

title: Lufthansa Plans To Issue Shares
description: Lufthansa, West Germany's national airline, today announced plans to raise $478 million through issuing new shares at a discount to prepare for an expected increase in air travel in the 1990's.

title: Powell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $623,000 and $1,260,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a loss of $45,000 for the quarter and a gain of $66,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Michael Rice Is Dead; Ex-TV Executive, 47
description: Michael Rice, a former general manager of WGBH in Boston, a leading public broadcasting station, died of AIDS yesterday at his home in Truro, Mass. He was 47 years old. Mr. Rice was a senior fellow at the Aspen Institute at the time of his death. He worked both in radio and television at WGBH from 1965 to 1978.

title: Dresdner Bank
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., West Germany's second-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that it planned to raise 1.2 billion marks (about $606.9 million) by offering 4 million new shares at 300 marks ($151.74) each. The stock would be offered to shareholders of record at the end of October or early November, at the rate of a new share for every eight held. In London, Dresdner's shares traded at 346/347 marks (about $175.01/$175.51) yesterday, after closing at 354 ($179.05) in Frankfurt.

title: Vehicle Sales Jumped By 22% in Late August
description: Responding to aggressive discounting of vehicles left at the end of the model year, American automobile buyers lifted the sales of domestically built cars by more than 22 percent in late August.

title: Baltic Political Humor: A Mask for Apprehension
description: The talk in the Lithuanian capital this week is of Russian troops, and the jokes are of Baltic nationalists who finally achieve solidarity - in prison trains headed for Siberia.

title: Baldwin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 31, for distribution on Sept. 15.

title: Review/Pop; Neil Young's New Subjects: Drugs, Venality, Betrayal
description: Loss of innocence can hurt, but few songwriters have taken it harder than Neil Young. His songs contrast an Edenic rural past with a brutal, corrupt present. Drugs, venality and betrayal reign in the new songs he brought to the Palladium on Tuesday - probably a preview of his album, ''Freedom,'' due for release Oct. 3 -and he offered little hope beyond the stubborn refusal to give up.

title: Drug Kingpin Is Found Guilty of Cocaine Smuggling in Los Angeles
description: A leading narcotics trafficker, whose capture and extradition to the United States sparked anti-American riots in Honduras that left five people dead last year, was found guilty today of cocaine smuggling.
