description: Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the Home State Savings Bank in Cincinnati, whose collapse in 1985 touched off a crisis among Ohio savingsgsnd l aoaininititiois, ,as filed a plan in Federal bankruptcy court in Jacksonville, Fla., to pay $16 million to his creditors.

title: Richard E. Coffey, Promotion Director, 69
description: Richard E. Coffey, advertising promotion director for the magazines of Time Inc. before his retirement in 1971, died of asthma last Thursday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 69 years old and had lived in Scarsdale, N.Y., for many years.

title: Internal Audits of Insurer Subpoenaed
description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce today subpoenaed all internal audits of the Travelers Insurance Company covering its role in servicing New Jersey's deficit-ridden Joint Underwriting Association, which insures half of the state's motorists.

title: British Hearing On B.A.T. Offer
description: Britain's Panel on Takeovers and Mergers said it would hold a hearing next week to decide whether Hoylake Investments Ltd. could extend its $21.4 billion hostile bid for B.A.T. Industries beyond the normal 60-day deadline. Sir James Goldsmith, who leads Hoylake, said last week that it would be difficult for the offer to succeed without an extension from the panel, which monitors takeover developments.

title: Talking Deals; Job Contracts After Takeovers
description: EXECUTIVES often gossip among themselves about the huge employment contracts -known as ''golden parachutes'' - that other executives get. Corporations, nevertheless, seldom challenge anyone trying to collect.

title: So Many Salvias, and So Little Room
description: INCREASINGLY of late, I have been of the opinion that my garden is sadly deficient in salvias. I hasten to add that I do not mean the torrid red annual bedding plants that look so loathsome all summer, especially when they consort with orange marigolds, a combination that occurs more often than it should.

title: Fatal Blast Aboard Battleship Iowa Was Probably Intentional, Investigation Finds
description: Naval investigators have concluded that the explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa in April was probably intentional, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Lomas Expects to Avoid Chapter 11
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation, which defaulted on $145 million in bank notes last Friday, said today that it expected to complete an agreement soon with creditors to refinance $1.45 billion in senior debt and avoid a voluntary bankruptcy filing.

title: Enough Burnt Sienna to Circle the Globe
description: ONCE there was a little boy who crayoned tick-tack-toe grids on the gray wool living-room rug: yard after yard of little squares, little O's and little X's. When his mother walked in, she realized just how much could be done with only one crayon.

title: Stake in Midway Raised by Ampco
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based rolled-metal concern, has raised its stake in Midway Airlines Inc. to 9.6 percent from 6.6 percent, the company reported in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Ampco-Pittsburgh said earlier that it might seek control of the Chicago-based airline.

title: Steinbrenner Reaches Accord With Winfield
description: George Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield, whose running feud over contributions to the Dave Winfield Foundation has been distracting Yankee fans for the better part of a decade, announced yesterday that the Yankee owner and the ailing slugger had settled their latest dispute, in Steinbrenner's favor.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BDO Seidman, an accounting and consulting firm, named Thomas G. Spence, Michael E. Cuncannan and Jack R. Suzar regional managing directors.

title: Bringing Old Cherry Wood Back to Life
description: LEAD: In the past, some unkind things were said about the most common of the furniture fruitwoods: American wild or black cherry. Sometimes it is referred to as mahogany's country cousin because it was often chosen by people who either could not afford mahogany or who were more at home with a native or local hardwood.

title: Q&A
description: Condensation in a Window Q. Eight years ago we had metal storm windows installed. Two years ago we started to notice moisture forming on the inside of the inner windows during cold weather: the moisture drips down onto the sill and mildew forms. The wood around the windows is in good condition, but the caulking on the outside of the inner windows is not. Could this be causing the moisture problem? A. I do not think so. Condensation is due to warm, moist air (the indoor air) coming in contact with a much colder surface (the window glass).

title: Takeover Rumor Propels Goodyear
description: Shares of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company jumped 7.7 percent in active trading yesterday on rumors that the world's largest tire producer was the target of a takeover by Pirelli S.p.A., the giant Italian tire maker. Both companies denied any knowledge of an acquisition. On the New York Stock Exchange, Goodyear's stock rose $4.125 to close at $57.625, as almost 1.4 million shares were traded.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday listing Ben Johnson's world sprint records gave an incorrect year in some editions for Carl Lewis's 9.92-second 100-meter dash. It was Sept. 24, 1988, not 1987.

title: Senate Leader Blames Bush for Top Vacancies
description: Stung by charges that the Senate has been dragging its feet in approving Presidential nominations, Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, produced figures today to back his contention that the main cause of the delays was the Bush Administration itself.

title: Jhirmack to Backer
description: The Playtex Family Products Corporation awarded its second advertising account of the week yesterday, giving its Jhirmack shampoo brand to Backer Spielvogel Bates. The account, which bills $10 million, had been at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss since 1980. On Tuesday Playtex assigned advertising for a line of hair care products to Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss.

title: White Is Right
description: To The Home Section:

title: LDI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,450,000, or 30 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago periods' results restated for a pooling of interests in January 1989.

title: Cubs' Lead Sliced to 1/2 As Phillies Rout Them
description: Bruce Ruffin scattered eight hits for his first complete game since May 8, 1988, and Darren Daulton and Dickie Thon each drove in three runs as the Philadelphia Phillies, in last place in the National League East, beat the first-place Chicago Cubs tonight, 9-1.

title: The Cost of Reagan
description: Self-indulgence is good for us:

title: Currents; Making a Statement, Page After Page
description: BOOKS designed by artists defy convention. The covers may be marble or other stone, and the pages may be shaped like stars or letters of the alphabet. Sometimes, there are no words at all. These handmade, one-of-a-kind books are the sole focus of the Ted Cronin Gallery, which opens tomorrow in Manhattan.

title: People
description: * John Blauner has been named executive creative director of the integrated communications division of FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: The Telltale Yawn Of Red Ransom
description: Tommy Kelly remembers the exact moment he realized that the fifth race at Saratoga on Aug. 2 was going to be the start of something big.

title: Politics
description: In the 1988 Presidential race, Southern Democrats had a great idea. They called it Super Tuesday, the day when all Southern states would vote as one for a Presidential nominee.

title: Jim Wright Joins Insurer
description: The former House Speaker, Jim Wright, has joined the American Income Life Insurance Company in Waco, Tex., as a part-time management consultant, the company's chairman, Bernard Rapoport, said today. Mr. Wright will help American Income motivate its employees. He will not engage in Congressional lobbying, the company said. American Income sells life, accident and health insurance primarily through unions. An investment fund controlled by Golder, Thoma & Cresser in Chicago acquired 75 percent of the company in a $229 million leveraged buyout in May. Mr. Rapoport owns the remainder of the company.

title: Lawyer Says Reagan Told Aide to Give False Data
description: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter said today that President Ronald Reagan directed Mr. Poindexter, his national security adviser, to give responses to Congressional inquiries in the Iran-contra affair that their client told the President he knew to be false.

title: Beirut Christian General Calls Exit by U.S. Envoy a Sellout
description: The Christian army commander today denounced the American decision to withdraw its diplomats from Lebanon, asserting that it left the Bush Administration without any influence here and amounted to a sellout to Syria.

title: Doubts Are Raised On Coolidge Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Wolfpack Report Is Public
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's preliminary report on possible rules violations in the North Carolina State basketball program contains serious accusations but does not support contentions of drug abuse or grade changing, the school's chancellor said today.

title: First Chicago Sale
description: The First Chicago Corporation said it would sell its First Chicago Investment Advisors subsidiary to a management group. The deal, worth $102 million, calls for First Chicago to receive $70 million in cash, a $15 million subordinated note and a 10 percent ownership stake in the new company. First Chicago said it expected to realize a pretax gain of $60 million to $65 million on the transaction.

title: Defense Lawyer Picked As Successor to Giuliani
description: President Bush yesterday nominated Otto G. Obermaier, a defense lawyer, as the permanent successor to Rudolph W. Giuliani in the highly visible post of United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: City Opera Musicians Set Strike Vote for Tuesday
description: The union representing the orchestra of the New York City Opera has tendered a seven-day strike notice to the company. On Tuesday night the union musicians will vote either to accept management's offer or to walk out the following day. For that evening, the City Opera's schedule lists a performance of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' at Lincoln Center.

title: Mixed Verdict On Laundering
description: A Federal jury today acquitted a Yugoslav diplomat and a bank chairman of conspiring to launder nearly $3.5 million. But a Texas businessman was convicted in the case.

title: New U.A.W. Division
description: The United Automobile Workers union announced the creation on Tuesday of a new department to deal with auto makers other than the Big Three. The department, called the Transnational and Joint Ventures Department, will be directed by the U.A.W.'s president, Owen Bieber. It will coordinate the union's activities at American auto plants owned by overseas-based companies and joint ventures. Honda, Mazda, Nissan and Toyota, all based in Japan, now operate auto plants in the United States.

title: Currents; Primitive Process Of Fire
description: IN ''Primitive Fire,'' 21 potters have used ancient techniques of firing clay to create pots, vessels and vases, which are to be shown, beginning Saturday, at the Clay Pot gallery in Brooklyn.

title: Heldor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Cordero Apologizes For Berating a Steward
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the Hall of Fame jockey who sharply criticized the Saratoga stewards after being fined $1,000 for a display of temper Aug. 26, called a news conference yesterday to apologize.

title: In a Course for Grandparents, Communication Is the Rule
description: IN one of the first efforts in the nation to improve relations between grandparents, parents and grandchildren, researchers at Arizona State University have just completed a yearlong educational program of classes, discussion groups and a survey intended to increase communication and understanding between the generations.

title: Lester C. Hopton, 87; Headed Ingersoll-Rand
description: Lester C. Hopton, a former president of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, manufacturers of heavy machinery and industrial equipment, died Monday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Catholic Church's Tax Exemption Is Upheld
description: The Federal Appeals Court in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a nine-year-old lawsuit in which abortion-rights advocates sought to challenge the Roman Catholic Church's Federal tax exemption.

title: Snags Seen in Europe Unity
description: The failure of European governments to act quickly is undermining the creation of a European Community with no trade barriers by 1992, a report by the European Commission said today.

title: Enterprise Oil Accord
description: Enterprise Oil P.L.C. said today that it had reached an agreement with British Gas P.L.C. and the Amerada Hess Corporaiton of the United States under which each of the three companies is permitted to buy parts of Texas Eastern North Sea Inc., the North Sea oil assets of the Texas Eastern Corporation.

title: Fidelity National Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Currents; What Came Naturally
description: LAST year, when Judith Farr, a landscape architect in Harrison, N.Y., started designing furniture, she did what came naturally. She made chairs with backs shaped like flowers.

title: Efforts to Teach Importance of Clear Writing Are Spreading
description: After 15 years, the instructors in the Bay Area Writing Project, which recently completed its summer session, have reason to believe that the rest of the country is catching up to their concern for the importance of teaching writing.

title: Groundwater Technology reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Student Rights Inquiry Opens in Resort Melee
description: The Justice Department today opened a criminal inquiry into charges that law- enforcement officers committed civil rights violations while quelling a weekend disturbance by a crowd of mostly black college students at Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Canucks Sign Krutov
description: With the signing of the Soviet star Vladimir Krutov, the Vancouver Canucks now have two-thirds of the KLM line of the Central Red Army team. Krutov, 29 years old, signed a three-year deal with the Canucks yesterday and the deal was announced at the Canadian Embassy in Moscow. He will join Igor Larionov, who agreed to terms with Vancouver earlier this summer. Sergei Makarov, the third member of the line, will play with the Stanley Cup champions, the Calgary Flames. (AP)

title: Dealership Study by Mazda
description: Following the lead of other Japanese automobile makers, the Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it had created a group to study establishing a separate network of dealers in the United States to sell only luxury cars.

title: Annette C. Murphy, Community Leader, 71
description: Annette C. Murphy, a community leader in Manhattan who led the drive to convert an abandoned asphalt plant on the Upper East Side into a community center, died Monday at New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Colombians Hail Bush Drug Plan, But Say the U.S. Aid Is Too Little
description: Reacting to President Bush's new drug control strategy, Colombians said today that they were delighted that for the first time an American leader had stressed domestic consumption and not only foreign production and shipping.

title: Short of the Mark; Bush Talked, Studied and Rehearsed, But Didn't Dazzle in His Drug Address
description: The White House had hoped that President Bush's speech Tuesday night would be one of those defining moments that occur in every successful Presidency, a kind of domestic policy version of the highly acclaimed addresses he made in May in Belgium and West Germany.

title: Bensonhurst Youth Is Indicted as Gunman
description: The white 18-year-old accused as the gunman in the killing of a black youth in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on two counts of second-degree murder.

title: 5 Die in Spanish Train Crash
description: A train carrying 120 passengers and traveling nearly 90 miles an hour rammed into a stationary freight train 70 miles northwest of Madrid today, and at least 5 people were killed and 54 injured, officials said. A spokesman for the Governor of Alava province said the dead were the passenger train's engineer and four women. The accident was the deadliest in Spain since March 1988, when 8 people died and 25 were injured in the crash of two passenger trains in a station in Valladolid.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Hong Kong investor Lo Yuk-sui offered today to lend $75 million to the Hooker Corporation, an Australian concern whose United States holdings, which include the Bonwit Teller and B. Altman department stores, are operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Close to Home
description: SUNDAY is a peculiar day. The hours yawn, the streets are quiet, the newspapers pile up and swallow the furniture.

title: Elderly Poor Face Higher Costs for Medical Coverage, Study Says
description: Nearly 60 percent of older Americans would pay more for insurance for catastrophic medical costs under a plan approved in July by the House Ways and Means Committee, a study released today by an advocacy group said.

title: Hip, Hot and Hyper: Soviet TV Cuts Loose
description: Imagine the gods of television had made Geraldo Rivera a Russian.

title: Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Mississippi Schools Facing Move to Stem Resegregation Tide
description: Like tidal ebb and flow, desegregation followed by resegregation has been a seemingly inexorable pattern in some Mississippi school districts.

title: Personal Health
description: If you were a physician, what would you make of a patient who comes in depressed and anxious, complaining that she hurts all over? She says she wakes up every morning stiff and tired, is able to do only half her work, and often has bellyaches, headaches, back aches, neck aches, numbness and abnormally cold hands and feet.

title: School Guide Says AIDS Should Not Bar Students
description: Students and teachers infected with the AIDS virus should be free to attend class without fear that their disease will be made public, according to a new guide for the nation's schools.

title: Review/Jazz; David Ware on Saxophone With Free Improvisation
description: The saxophonist David Ware opened his set at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night with a solo that contrasted blunt, drawn-out melodies with inkblots of sound, flurries that ran off into split tones and more. His saxophone sound quivered with intensity; Mr. Ware is one of the most powerful saxophonists playing, and the sounds from his tenor vibrated across the room.

title: A Chic Crowd Of New Rich For Ethiopia
description: At a soft-drink bar not far from the airport here, stylishly attired teen-agers in stone- washed jeans, glittery T-shirts and spiked heels socialize under a portrait of the singer Michael Jackson.

title: Campaign Matters; Koch, of Course, Might Label This Mayoral Matters
description: A few days after Mayor Edward I. Koch formally declared his candidacy, 5,000 posters disclosing details about the city's $5.2 billion housing program went up in the subways. Naturally, the posters mentioned the Mayor's name. They even bore his picture.

title: Our TV Signals Are Escaping Into Space; Wells and Welles
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Trump Project: A TV Game Show
description: Having bestowed his name on an airline, a casino, a yacht and a tower, Donald Trump now plans to extend it into new territory: Trump, the television game show.

title: Reward for 2 Suspects
description: The Government offered $250,000 tonight for information leading to the arrest of two of Colombia's main drug traffickers.

title: Teen-Age Hero in Amazon Jet Rescue
description: Survivors of a jetliner crash in the Amazon attributed their rescue today to an unemployed 19-year-old passenger who proved to be schooled in the ways of the rain forest.

title: Yields Post Slight Drop
description: Yields on money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down slightly for the week that ended yesterday.

title: The President Whispers 'Charge!'
description: ''Those who judge our strategy only by its price tag simply don't understand the problem,'' President Bush said in his first big televised speech, committing his Administration to an expanded war on drugs. But in fact, the price tag is all-important. Laudably, Mr. Bush offers an intelligent strategy in place of the simplistic oratory of his predecessor. Lamentably, having pointed in the right direction, Mr. Bush offers a program that would bring progress measured in inches.

title: S.E.C. Files Fraud Case On Retailer
description: Eddie Antar, the reclusive entrepreneur who at Crazy Eddie Inc. brought widespread discounting to retail electronics, was accused yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission of securities fraud and illegal insider trading.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 30 about Lane Kirkland's views on the state of the labor movement misattributed some comments. It was Mr. Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. - not John C. Truesdale, executive secretary of the National Labor Relations Board - who said he saw no difference between the labor policies of American-owned and foreign-owned companies. It was also Mr. Kirkland who discussed the recent election failure by the United Automobile Workers at the Nissan factory in Smyrna, Tenn.; he said pro-union votes by 700 employees represented something of a victory.

title: Pepsico Executive Is to Fill Top Post at Haagen-Dazs
description: Haagen-Dazs, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., announced yesterday that it had named Ove Sorensen, a Pepsico Inc. executive, as its new president and chief executive.

title: Gish Biomedical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits from the utilization of net operating loss carryforward of $193,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $383,000, or 22 cents a share, for the year.

title: Kansas City Journal; Council Vote to Decide Conventional Center Plan
description: The Kansas City Council will try Thursday to set off a chain of events that a lot of people here say will put new life into a city that is already awakening from a long slumber.

title: 15 Killed as Oil Tanker Hits Trawler in Baltic
description: All 15 crew members of a Soviet fishing trawler were killed when an oil tanker trying to avoid another boat veered into the trawler, sinking it in the Baltic, officials said.

title: Inauspicious Beginning for Rutgers
description: Although the season has just begun, Rutgers is already at another of those crossroads that so frequent the Scarlet Knights' football campaigns.

title: Pepper Successor Takes Oath
description: Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Florida Republican, was sworn in today and became the first Cuban-American member of Congress. A native of Havana, Ms. Ros-Lehtinen won a special election on Aug. 29 to succeed Claude Pepper, a Democrat who had represented the Miami Congressional district for 26 years until his death on May 30. Ms. Ros-Lehtinen's victory cuts the Democratic margin in the House to 79, with Democrats holding 255 seats and Republicans 176. There are four vacancies.

title: And Now the Question, Who Is a German?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bolt Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $577,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Included a charge of $11,511,000 from a writedown of assets.

title: Christian Lebanon Wants Syrian Army to Go; Beirut Was Syrian
description: To the Editor:

title: Chevrolet Rebates
description: Chevrolet announced rebates on two of its 1990 cars, two weeks after formally introducing them. The auto maker, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, put a $750 cash rebate on all models of its 1990 Lumina sedan, a car introduced earlier in the year to replace the Chevrolet Celebrity. It also offered an $800 rebate to buyers of the Geo Prism and Chevrolet Nova.

title: USE OF FUNGICIDES LIMITED BY MAKERS
description: The manufacturers of an important class of chemicals that kill fungal diseases in plants suspended their use on roughly 50 food crops today, including apples, melons, celery and carrots.

title: Review/Art; A Genius Blossoms Extravagantly in 1524
description: Age brings wisdom, people say. But the best thing that ever happened to the city of Mantua was when the top man in town, who was then aged 24, persuaded a 25-year-old artist called Giulio Romano to leave Rome and, to all intents and purposes, take over the city of Mantua.

title: Sanders, a Yankee Hit, Intercepted by Falcons
description: After he struck out in the sixth inning tonight, Deion Sanders walked slowly back to the dugout, grabbed his bat and glove and shook hands with Bucky Dent, the Yankee manager. When he disappeared through the door that leads to the visiting clubhouse at the Kingdome, it signaled the end to Sanders's first season in the big leagues.

title: The Limits of Audits; Counting Alone Cannot Detect Fraud If Management Is Juggling Numbers
description: The allegations of fraud filed yesterday against Crazy Eddie Antar show just how easy it can be to inflate profits, fooling investors and Wall Street analysts. What appears to have been an effort to make already-impressive results for 1985 a little prettier seems to have descended by 1987 into a complicated scheme to hide huge losses.

title: Peter Van Schaik, Aerospace Engineer, 60
description: Peter Van Schaik, an engineer who developed the backpack maneuvering unit that astronauts use in space, died here on Monday of undisclosed causes. He was 60 years old.

title: SOVIETS AND CHINA MAY SEE SOFTENING FROM U.S. ON GATT
description: A diplomatic cable made public today disclosed that the Bush Administration might soften its opposition to membership for the Soviet Union and China in the organization that manages the world trading system.

title: 2 Hypermarts To Wal-Mart
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has agreed to take full ownership of two large Dallas-area Hypermart stores for an undisclosed amount, its partner in the venture, the Cullum Companies, said today.

title: Citing an Illness, A Judge Annuls Bing's Marriage
description: The stormy marriage of Sir Rudolf Bing, the former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, and Carroll Douglass was annulled yesterday by a state judge.

title: Laurentian Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: AIRLINER AND JET IN NEAR COLLISION
description: A misunderstanding between an air traffic controller and the pilots of a Trans World Airlines jetliner nearly led to a midair collision near Chicago on Tuesday afternoon, Federal investigators said yesterday.

title: Everex Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
7 Employers Join to Provide Child Care at Home in a Crisis
description: In an ambitious experiment in child-care assistance, seven large New York employers have joined to place child-care workers in the homes of employees whose usual arrangements have been disrupted.

title: Sears and K Mart Go Head to Head
description: A half-mile apart on Richmond Avenue on Staten Island, a K Mart store and a Sears store are battling for the budget-minded shopper. It is a competition taking place in hundreds of cities nationwide as the nation's two biggest retailers, once very different in size and focus, have converged in many ways in the last year.

title: Deadline Nears for Toon Decision
description: The heart of the Jets' offense, Al Toon, wore a sling instead of his usual cryptic smile today. Worse for his teammates, he may still be sporting it on Sunday, when the season opens against the New England Patriots.

title: Intelligent Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months included results for Entre Computer Centers Inc., which was acquired in December 1988.

title: Approval Seen for Daimler On Messerschmitt Merger
description: West Germany's Economics Minister, Helmut Haussmann, will approve Daimler-Benz A.G.'s controversial takeover of Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., overriding objections from antitrust authorities to create a gigantic aerospace and armaments group, Government sources said today.

title: Small Spaces Packed with Big Ideas
description: LEAD: STREAMLINED furniture and white walls are usually prescribed as space-expanding devices for the small, architecturally bland apartments that are a reality of urban living.

title: KEY RATES
Mayoral Pick Creates Fight Within Paper
description: The Daily News has endorsed Richard Ravitch for the Democratic mayoral nomination after a weeklong dispute in which the publisher was dissuaded from his first choice, Mayor Edward I. Koch, by strong opposition from top editorial staff members. They wanted the newspaper to endorse Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

title: Stop Changing the Schools and Start Changing the Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch Leader Heading for Third Victory
description: Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers's centrist party appeared headed for victory tonight in general elections, making a third consecutive term likely for the Dutch leader.

title: COLOMBIA DEPORTS DRUG TRADE FIGURE
description: A suspected financial expert for the Medellin cocaine cartel was flown out of Colombia tonight bound for the United States, the Justice Department announced.

title: Italian Bank's Unauthorized Credits to Iraq
description: The chairman of Italy's largest state-owned bank came under strong pressure to resign today following disclosure that the bank's branch in Atlanta issued more than $1 billion in unauthorized export credits to Iraq.

title: Another Blast Spews Asbestos On the West Side
description: An asbestos-lined steam pipe burst in the street with a loud boom on Manhattan's Upper West Side last night, sending a geyser of steam into the air that an official said contained asbestos.

title: Penn Traffic Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 6-month periods included the results of P&C Food Markets Inc., as well as the results of Big Bear Inc. since April 1. The figures excluded the results of Grand Union.

title: Pan Am to Add Florida Flights
description: The Pan Am Corporation said it would increase its service to Florida by nearly 50 percent next month. The expansion, announced as Miami-based Eastern Airlines, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, entered the seventh month of reduced service because of a strike, will increase the average number of daily Pan Am flights to Florida to 70 from 48.

title: Our TV Signals Are Escaping Into Space
description: To the Editor:

title: American Realty Trust Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an $86,000 gain on sale of properties for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included a $234,000 gain on sale of properties for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: The God That Failed Fidel
description: While the breezes of freedom surge through much of the Communist world, Fidel Castro is resolutely turning Cuba into a fortress of reaction. The latest sinister turn was the arrest of three Cuban human rights monitors, Elizardo Sanchez Santa Cruz, Hiram Abi Cobas and Hubert Jerez Marino. Each was a leader of an unofficial group seeking some leeway for peaceful dissent; each was seized at 5 A.M. With their arrest, 23 human rights activists are now in Cuban jails.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: In the latest third quarter, the bank made provisions for credit losses of $92,000,000, bringing the total for the nine months to $171,000,000. This compares with $113,652,000 of provisions in the year-ago third quarter and $309,201,000 for the year-ago nine months. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Whitney Sponsors an Ad Against Helms Amendment
description: In an unusual political action for an art institution, the Whitney Museum of American Art has placed a full-page ''open letter'' in today's New York Times and Washington Post protesting the proposed Helms amendment to restrict Federal grants for art that is deemed ''obscene and indecent.''

title: On Battleground of the Street, Few See a Victory Over Drugs
description: Still perspiring from their foot chase of a crack dealer, Officers Charles Fernandez and Adam L. Burden caught their breath while listening to President Bush's drug speech over the radio in their darkened car. ''Another Band-Aid approach,'' Officer Fernandez said.

title: Presidential Tastes and a Bernstein Song Cycle
description: Late in the evening of April 5, 1960, Leonard Bernstein found himself in the East Room of the White House face to face with President Dwight D. Eisenhower, awkward silence all around. He also found the title for a work that he didn't get around to composing until last year, a piece that will have its American premiere tonight at Merkin Concert Hall. He loves to tell the story.

title: Why Seoul Says Don't Fix What Isn't Broken
description: LEAD: When President Roh Tae Woo, cautioning against troop-reduction sentiment in the U.S. Congress, recently said, ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it,'' he was warning against the poor timing of the proposal and against several key misperceptions on which the argument for withdrawal is based.

title: Warner Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $500,000, or 8 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Ways to Hide Valuables Of Any Size
description: THE door is locked - naturally. To enter, you must be buzzed in. Security is this company's specialty. ''Our business is safes of every kind you can imagine, including vaults,'' said Richard Krasilovsky, president of the 85-year-old Empire Safe Company in Manhattan.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Inch Up
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in light trading yesterday, with most of the trading by professionals.

title: New York Health Chief Proposes Medical Insurance for All in State
description: The Cuomo administration's chief health official has proposed establishing an insurance system that would guarantee basic health care to every resident of New York State.

title: HUNGARIAN PARTY IN MONEY SCANDAL
description: Looking ahead to the creation of a fully functioning multiparty system, the ruling Communist Party has quietly moved to transfer the use of vast assets, including resort hotels and other real estate, schools, a computer network and garages and repair shops, to a commercial company that it formed without public announcement last month.

title: Whodunit? Paul Stuart, In Full Color
description: It seems that here now in this Autumn so fine, In One Thousand Nine Hundred Eighty-Nine, A murder's been committed A deed none's admitted A deliciously dastardly crime.

title: Holiday for Nixon Is Proposed
description: The Town Council of Yorba Linda, the birthplace of Richard M. Nixon, wants to declare the former President's birthday a city holiday. Mr. Nixon was forced to resign in 1974 by the Watergate scandal. He was born in Yorba Linda on Jan. 9, 19l3. The Council voted 5 to 0 Tuesday night to instruct its staff to draft a resolution declaring Jan. 9 a holiday for city employees. ''President Nixon is definitely in fashion again,'' Mayor Henry Wedaa said. The Council is expected to pass the holiday resolution at its next meeting, scheduled for Sept. 19.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Becker Defeats Noah In 3 Sets
description: His name had been made on grass stages in Britain. But when Boris Becker's show was moved here late in each of the last several summers, playing before an audience eager to see a proven hit in London, something about his performances was lost in the translation.

title: Judge Rules Quadriplegic Can Be Allowed to End Life
description: A Georgia Superior Court judge ruled today that a quadriplegic who says he no longer gets any enjoyment from life has the right to turn off his own ventilator so he can die. The judge also allowed medical personnel to administer a sedative to assist the process.

title: Loews Names President With a 41-Year Career
description: Jerome Esbin, who has been in the movie industry since 1948, has been named president of the Loews Theater Management Corporation.

title: Li Peng, in Interview, Rules Out General Amnesty
description: Prime Minister Li Peng has declared in an interview that decision-makers in China felt nearly impotent and were forced to act as ''a clandestine government'' before moving to put down the student-led rebellion that began in Tiananmen Square in the spring.

title: Americans at Lebanon Embassy Pull Out Amid Christian Threats
description: The United States evacuated its embassy in Beirut today after the Lebanese Christian army commander reportedly threatened to take Americans hostage and settle Lebanon's problems with ''Christian terrorism.''

title: Topics of The Times; Opening Up New York
description: Eighth Avenue in Manhattan from 44th to 51st Street has been an odd sight the last few days. Sidewalk grates and subway entrances are shrouded in plastic. Workmen equipped with respirators, having swept and scrubbed the streets, have now moved underground in their effort to rid the area of 50 pounds of asbestos, scattered when a main burst and stripped the insulation from two underground steam pipes. But the oddest sight is at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 51st Street, where the city appears to be undergoing surgery.

title: U.S. Blocking Release Of Figure in Drug Case
description: Immigration officials blocked the court-ordered release on Tuesday of a former Mexican President's relative who is in Federal custody for questioning in the 1985 slaying of a Federal drug agent.

title: Film Directors In South Korea Protest Arrests Over Snakes
description: About 20 South Korean movie directors stopped filming today and began a hunger strike to protest the arrest of two colleagues accused of having nonpoisonous snakes released in theaters showing American films.

title: Rozier Ends Holdout
description: Mike Rozier, the Houston Oilers' running back, a holdout since the start of training camp, agreed to a one-year contract and reported to workouts yesterday in Houston.

title: Heinz, H J Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
HURRICANE VEERS AWAY FROM U.S.
description: Hurricane Gabrielle veered northward in the Atlantic today, taking its 130 mile-an-hour winds away from the United States mainland but threatening to sideswipe Bermuda.

title: Indiana Man Is Guilty of Planting 13 Bombs
description: A Federal jury has convicted a 42-year-old factory worker of participating in a failed conspiracy to blow up the southern Indiana town of Salem with 13 bombs that were planted in the community last year.

title: B.I.  Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Doubts Greet Drug Plan in New York
description: A day after President Bush unveiled his strategy for escalating the nation's war against illegal drugs, officials and drug experts in New York were skeptical about how successful it would be.

title: MB Group Buying U.S. Check Maker
description: MB Group P.L.C. of Reading, England, agreed to buy the ABS Holdings Corporation, parent of the American Bank Stationery Company, for $300 milllion in cash.

title: Sabatini and Graf Win In Open Quarterfinals
description: Like two women sharing a punching bag, Gabriela Sabatini and Arantxa Sanchez Vicario grunted and groaned and punched tennis balls at each other for more than two hours yesterday afternoon, all for the eerie privilege of meeting Steffi Graf in the semifinals of the United States Open.

title: MCI Gets Another Merrill Contract
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said it had awarded the MCI Communications Corporation a five-year, $50 million contract to manage the financial services firm's worldwide telecommunications network. In June, Merrill Lynch awarded MCI a $150 million contract to provide voice and data communications for the network.

title: Bank of Montreal reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest third quarter's decline in net income was due in part to increased provisions for loans to lesser developed countries. In addition, net from the year-ago third quarter was inflated by non-recurring interest income. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Hynes Receives Cuomo Support For Prosecutor
description: In a rare departure from his policy of not endorsing candidates in primary contests, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday announced his support of Charles J. Hynes, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn district attorney.

title: Candidates Try to Woo the Undecided
description: All but ignored by their more successful rivals, the two lagging Democratic candidates for mayor - Harrison J. Goldin and Richard Ravitch -are preparing last-minute television commercials that they say may help shape the outcome of the election.

title: Oregon Inaugurates Football Betting
description: Oregon, which advertises itself with the slogan, ''Things look different here,'' today became the only state to set up shop as an official bookmaker for professional football games.

title: Parent & Child
description: FIVE-YEAR-OLD Katie Sullivan has recently expressed a strong interest in spending more time by herself. ''When she's in a snit she closes her door and tells us: 'Don't come into my room. I want to be alone,' '' said her father, William A. Sullivan, a fund-raising executive in Minneapolis.

title: Budding Museum at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
description: The most famous address, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, evokes images of domesticity and statehood: of Abigail Adams drying her wash in the East Room, of Franklin Delano Roosevelt broadcasting his fireside chats in the Diplomatic Reception Room.

title: Asbestos in the Home
description: To The Home Section:

title: Camden Forces Its Suburbs To Ask, What If a City Dies?
description: This once-powerful industrial city on the Delaware River has been so battered, drained and gutted that there is little left today except neighborhoods of the extraordinarily poor and their government.

title: Ronald Syme, 86, Classics Scholar And Historian at Oxford, Is Dead
description: Sir Ronald Syme, an Oxford historian and eminent scholar of classical Rome, died Monday, the university said Tuesday. He was 86 years old.

title: Topics of The Times; Beauty Is the Beast
description: The Philadelphia Zoo once had a beautiful Bengal tiger that people traveled miles to see. But after a year, the tiger had to move on to a new home in Buffalo. The zoo knew that its attendance would drop after the loss of its main attraction. America's first zoo had no other guaranteed ticket-sellers, like the cuddly koalas of the San Diego Zoo.

title: FHP International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fraud Cited In Penny Stocks
description: Traders of penny stocks are losing an estimated $2 billion a year through widespread fraud in the market of the low-priced securities, a report issued today by a group of state securities regulators said.

title: Dinkins Stresses His Appeal for Harmony
description: Wherever he goes in these last days of the primary campaign - Chinatown, Harlem or the Bronx - David N. Dinkins has been incorporating the lessons of Yusuf K. Hawkins's death, often departing from his set speech to talk about the need to bind the wounds left by the killing of the black teen-ager by a gang of white youths from Bensonhurst.

title: Fannie Mae Sets Offering Of $1.1 Billion in Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $1.1 billion in debt securities consisting of $600 million in debentures due in 1996 and $500 million in indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1999 through various securities dealers.

title: Tolerance to Drug Patches Found in Some Users
description: Nitroglycerin patches, used to control chest pain associated with heart disease, rapidly become ineffective if they are worn 24 hours a day, as they commonly are, new studies show.

title: Campbell Soup Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary credit of $32,500,000, or 25 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. The company said the latest quarter and year net reflects a pretax restructuring charge of $343 million.

title: 103 Ethiopia Soldiers Slain, Rebels in the North Report
description: Rebels in northern Ethiopia said today that they captured a strategic garrison town last week, killing 103 Government soldiers and capturing 26 in three days of heavy fighting.

title: Paris Parley Is to Study Drug Profit Laundering
description: France announced today that experts from the Group of Seven industrial democracies will meet here next week to seek ways to stop the laundering of drug trafficking profits, a trade said to be worth as much as oil to the world banking system.

title: Giants Realigning for Life Without Morris
description: With their season opener Monday night, the Giants started preparing today without Joe Morris, their injured running back.

title: INSIDE
description: Evangelist's Trial Resumes After psychiatric evaluation found he had suffered a ''panic attack,'' not mental illness, Jim Bakker was ruled competent to stand trial. Page A18. Trouble for Crazy Eddie The S.E.C. accused Eddie Antar, founder of the electronics chain, of insider trading and fraud. Page D1. Dispute at Daily News Richard Ravitch was endorsed for mayor after a dispute between the publisher and senior editors. Page B1.

title: Discussions On UAL Offer
description: Stephen M. Wolf, the head of the UAL Corporation, met yesterday with Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner to discuss details of a takeover bid by a group that includes UAL's management, its pilots' union and British Airways. A spokesman for the Transportation Department said the Secretary would not have any comment. The group has offered to buy

title: Border Agent Is Slain in Fresno
description: An undercover United States Border Patrol agent was shot to death and his partner seriously wounded today while they posed as employers offering cash for illegal aliens, investigators said.

title: 14 Packed Into a Car Survive 70-Foot Fall
description: Fourteen people packed into a sedan, none wearing seat belts, survived a 70-foot plunge into a quarry after the car was forced off the road by a swerving vehicle.

title: 'Uncle Buck,' at $7.8 Million, Is No. 1 at the Box Office
description: ''Uncle Buck,'' starring John Candy as an obnoxious man taking care of his two nieces and a nephew, was the hottest movie ticket during the holiday weekend, taking in $7.8 million to capture the No. 1 spot at the box office for the third straight week.

title: Libyans Are Reported to Find A German Technician's Body
description: A West German aeronautical engineer building an in-flight refueling capacity for the Libyan Air Force was found dead in a Tripoli beachfront hotel this year, Western diplomats here say.

title: Dow Drops 24.89 Points on Rate Concerns
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday amid investor fears of rising interest rates and speculation that foreign central banks might slow the dollar's rise, analysts said.

title: Clash at South Korean Rallies
description: Students and workers clashed with the police in five towns today during demonstrations demanding the resignation of President Roh Tae Woo and the withdrawal of United States troops from South Korea. The police fired tear gas to break up the rallies, held in Masan, Seoul, Pusan, Suwon and Taegu.

title: Refugees and Hungary: No Easy Road
description: By punching a hole through the border between East and West and inadvertently inviting a flood of East German refugees, Hungary has found itself torn between old loyalties to the East and new aspirations in the West. With thousands of East

title: Johnson to Keep Medals
description: Although Ben Johnson has been effectively stripped of two of his world records and titles because of steroid use, he can keep his two bronze medals from the 1984 Olympics, the head of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday. Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said accomplishments at the Games were outside the scope of the decision made by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, track's governing body, this week to erase Johnson's world records in the 100-meter and indoor 60-meter events.

title: Silence! Athletes At Work
description: Yowls of anguish filled the Flushing night as Mets fans booed Gary Carter and probably the manager who sent the poor chap up there to make the next to last out of yet another dismal loss last night.

title: Clifford E. Vargas, Circus Founder, 64
description: Clifford E. Vargas, the founder of the Circus Vargas, died of heart disease on Monday at his home in Hollywood Hills. He was 64 years old. The grandson of Portuguese circus owners, Mr. Vargas founded Circus Vargas 20 years ago with three trucks and eight animals. In the early years, he was ticket taker, ringmaster and truck driver. The circus grew to include 150 animals and up to 300 employees, and is billed as the largest traveling tented circus in the world.

title: Cards Get the Pitching With Unheralded Cast
description: The Mets had Dwight Gooden, David Cone, Bob Ojeda, Ron Darling and Sid Fernandez, and after they lost Gooden to the disabled list, they added Frank Viola.

title: Sharpton Will March, Despite Claims It Might Hurt Dinkins
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that he plans to lead a march through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn on Saturday, despite arguments that a demonstration could detract from David N. Dinkins's campaign in Tuesday's mayoral primary.

title: Menopause Linked to Cholesterol Changes
description: Women's blood cholesterol levels worsen abruptly after menopause, and this may help explain their increasing risk of heart attacks, a new study indicates.

title: Hundreds Reported to Have Died in Iraqi Explosion
description: Hundreds of people may have been killed in an explosion at an Iraqi military installation last month, Egyptian military officials and diplomats in Baghdad said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL A diplomatic cable revealed that the U.S. may soften its opposition to membership for the Soviet Union and China in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which manages the world trading system. Such a move could offer both Moscow and Beijing a framework for normalizing trade relations with other countries. The disclosure was a surprise because the U.S. had suspended talks on Chinese membership in GATT after the violent crackdown on demonstrators in Beijing in June. [ Page A1. ] The chairman of Italy's largest state-owned bank came under pressure to resign after a disclosure that the bank's Atlanta branch issued more than $1 billion in unauthorized credits to Iraq. [ D1. ] Daimler-Benz's takeover of Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm will be approved by West Germany's Economics Minister, overriding objections from antitrust authorities, sources said. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Crazy Eddie's founder was accused of securities fraud and illegal insider trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In its complaint, the commission said the company's executives conspired to overstate profits. [ D1. ] The allegations of fraud against Eddie Antar show just how easy it can be to inflate profits, misleading investors and Wall Street analysts. [ D6. ] A Hong Kong investor offered to lend $75 million to Hooker Corporation, whose U.S. holdings are operating under Chapter 11. [ D5. ] Lomas Financial expects to complete an agreement soon with creditors to refinance $1.45 billion in senior debt. [ D15. ] A judge approved settlements to allow $750 million to be distributed to Washington Public Power Supply System bondholders. [ D5. ] Seven companies will provide at-home emergency chld care service to more than 13,000 employees. [ A1. ] ECONOMY Domestic auto sales rose more than 22 percent in late August. On a seasonally adjusted basis, sales at the end of last month were running at a 7.9 million pace, well above the yearly trend. [ D2. ] American workers posted a modest productivity improvement in the second quarter, with significant gains by factory workers leading the way. [ D14. ] MARKETS The Federal Reserve sold $11.9 billion worth of dollars, including $2 billion in two days, in its effort to curb the rise of the dollar in May, June and July. It was the Fed's largest intervention ever in a three-month period [ D1. ] The dollar drifted lower amid concerns of higher interest rates overseas. [ D19. ] Stock prices fell broadly on investor fears of rising interest rates and speculation that foreign central banks might slow the dollar's rise, analysts said. The Dow fell 24.89, to 2,719.79. [ D10. ] Treasury note and bond prices inched higher in light trading. [ D18. ] . Yields on money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/ Donoghue's fell for the week. [ D8. ] Copper futures prices tumbled, the third straight day of losses on New York's Commodity Exchange. [ D19. ] Traders of penny stocks are losing an estimated $2 billion a year through widespread fraud in the market for low-priced securities, a report by state securities regulators said. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS An Ohio lawsuit has strong ramifications for executives hoping to protect themselves against dismissal or loss of status after hostile takeovers or even friendly mergers. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The theory among some market strategists is that optimism blossoms as the prices of stocks and bonds begin to peak. Market Place. [ D10. ] Whodunit? If you solve a contest by Paul Stuart, the apparel store, you could win a prize. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everything has flown over the wall that could. What is left are all those with broken wings.

title: Frankfurt Gets Masters
description: The Association of Tennis Professionals Tour Championship, played in New York since 1977 as the Masters, will be held in Frankfurt, West Germany, beginning in 1990 under terms of a three-year agreement announced yesterday in New York.

title: MMR Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $3,360,000 for the quarter and $4,073,000 for the year, both due to antitrust litigation costs. c-Net income The company said the year's loss also included a $3.6 million pretax loss in connection with the settlement of claims with respect to the construction of a governmental facility, and an $8 million pretax writeoff reflecting the company's decision to terminate its participation in a joint venture.

title: JUDGE SAYS BAKKER CAN STAND TRIAL
description: A Federal judge ruled today that Jim Bakker was competent to stand trial after a psychiatrist testified that ''a panic attack'' and not any permanently debilitating mental disorder or psychosis gripped the former television evangelist last week.

title: Georges Simenon Dies at 86; Creator of Inspector Maigret
description: Georges Simenon, the masterly Belgian novelist whose Inspector Maigret mysteries and many other highly regarded works made him one of the most widely published authors of the century, died in his sleep Monday night at his home in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 86 years old and had been in declining health for several years.

title: Winning Pianists in Concert
description: Performances by winners of this year's Gina Bachauer International Piano Competition will open the new season of free concerts by students at the Juilliard School. The competition winners - Samuel Chang, Edith Chen and Dan-Wen Wei - will appear next Wednesday at 9 P.M. at Paul Hall, Broadway and West 66th Street, on the first floor of the school. The concert will also be broadcast live on WQXR AM (1560) and FM (96.3). Information: 874-7515.

title: National Vision Services reports earnings for Year to May 31
A Dream of a Day Lily
description: To The Home Section:

title: Norbert Freinkel, 63, An Expert on Diabetes
description: Dr. Norbert Freinkel, an educator and an international expert on endocrinology and diabetes, died of a heart attack on Tuesday while attending a concert on a visit to Leningrad. He was 63 years old and lived in Evanston, Ill.

title: South Africa's National Party: Vehicle for Afrikaner Power
description: The National Party of South Africa, which lost ground in elections today, has been the main vehicle for Afrikaner nationalism for more than 50 years and the dominant political force in the country since it came to power in 1948, steadfastly fighting to expand the political and economic power of the descendants of the Dutch and Huguenot settlers who came to the country in the 17th century.

title: New Delhi Journal; The Sikh's Hour of Horror, Relived After 5 Years
description: Seventy-year-old Sudini Kaur lives in a ghetto of heartbroken women, haunted by horrifying, sickening images of the night of carnage five years ago that took her son, three grandsons and her zest for life.

title: McKesson Chief Quits After a Disagreement
description: The McKesson Corporation, a distributor of drugstore products, said yesterday that Thomas W. Field Jr. had resigned as chairman, president and chief executive because of differences with McKesson's board over management philosophy and the future direction of the company.

title: A Small Lobby's Large Voice
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association has seven professional staff members, a small budget and no office in Washington. Its vice president in charge of Government affairs had never set foot in the nation's capital, even as a tourist, until he took the job.

title: Currents; Donating Material And Time
description: THE Manhattan Center for Living will offer a wide range of free services to people with terminal illnesses: shiatsu massages, art workshops and counseling, among others. The nonprofit organization, a companion to the two-year-old Los Angeles Center for Living, is to open Monday in Greenwich Village.

title: Books of The Times; The Bork Nomination, and Why It Failed
description: Battle for Justice How the Bork Nomination Shook America By Ethan Bronner Illustrated. 399 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.50.

title: Rediscovering the Charms of Cast-Iron Fireplaces
description: In the mid-19th-century, as the Industrial Revolution roared along in Britain, uncounted millions of cast-iron fireplace mantels in myriad styles rolled off production lines. There were floral designs, geometric patterns and classical Greek columns. There were evocations of Georgian formality and, with the arrival of the 20th century, Art Nouveau and Art Deco.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about the first shots of World War II described residents who ''waved as German troops entered'' the Baltic city now known as Gdansk.

title: Kerkhoff Industries reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,791,000 from utilization of operating loss carryforwards. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Market Place; A Healthy Fear Of Overconfidence
description: IN 1987, Edward S. Hyman, vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence/Morgan Grenfell Inc., predicted that the end of the 1980's stock market boom would be evident when investors began to rationalize their speculations with pronouncements about peace with the Soviet Union and an era of uninterrupted economic growth.

title: Christian Lebanon Wants Syrian Army to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Government-Issue Gambling
description: The Pentagon, at the urging of the House Armed Services subcommittee on readiness, is surveying the possibility of a Government-sponsored lottery for military personnel overseas. Like desperate state politicians who resort to lotteries when they don't dare raise taxes, the subcommittee got the idea that a lottery might help pay for recreational and family programs that are starved for funds. These programs are normally supported by PX profits, particularly from liquor sales, but business isn't as good as it used to be.

title: Burke, Devils' Goalie, Gives Team a Scare
description: Sean Burke, the Devils' regular goalie, hurt his right knee in a pickup game in Toronto Monday and will miss a week to 10 days of training camp.

title: 2 Brothers on Outing Found Slain in a Park
description: Two brothers, 10 and 11 years old, who had told their father they were going to pick up golf balls for pocket change, were found stabbed to death in a park here Monday night.

title: Settlement On Default Is Approved
description: Six years after the nation's largest municipal bond default, a Federal judge has approved settlements to allow $750 million to be distributed to holders of Washington Public Power Supply System bonds.

title: Cardinals Cash In on Mets' Mistakes
description: The Mets have reached the point in their season when they can no longer afford to make mistakes in clutch situations. But those mistakes were exactly what they made last night at Shea Stadium. And it led to a 3-2 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals, a team that knows how to capitalize.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: INSIDE
description: Finding on Battleship Blast Concluding that the Iowa explosion was ''most probably'' sabotage, the Navy also found serious mismanagement of the ship. Page A11. Computer Research Plan Bush's science adviser will present to Congress a plan to aid development of far faster supercomputers and to link U.S. research centers. Page D1. Corporate Conscience Environmental and religious groups joined with big investors to set a code of conduct to judge how environmentally responsible a company is. D1. Soviet Generals Mobbed I n a further sign of eroding Soviet control, three generals were held hostage for five hours by a crowd of angry Azerbaijanis. Page A3. Agassi Eliminates Connors It took five sets, but Andre Agassi, 19 years old, beat Jimmy Connors, 37, in the U.S. Open quarterfinals for the second straight year. Page A19.

title: An Array of Series Offering Movies and Vintage Video
description: All sorts of activities have arrived in a rush to sweep us toward autumn, and this weekend movies and vintage video are the thing. Several series get under way to introduce audiences to new work from the Far East, old work about the Far West, a German emigre's view of South America and a collection of experimental films that look inward to see outward. Parabola Film Festival

title: Guilty Plea In Stock Case Is Expected
description: A Federal investigation into the practice of stock lending has advanced following an agreement by a former executive with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to plead guilty to securities and tax charges and cooperate with the inquiry, people close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Hooker Corp. Plan Typical Of Hong Kong Financier
description: Lo Yuksui, the Hong Kong entrepreneur who has offered to make a $75 million loan to the ailing Hooker Corporation of Australia, has built a hotel and real estate empire through what his company literature describes as ''successful corporate rescues and reorganizations.''

title: Warning From I.A.A.F.
description: Track's governing body, meeting in Barcelona, Spain, warned yesterday that it might suspend athletes who renege on their commitments.

title: Brought to You by . . .
description: After a year of controversy, public television stations gave the film ''Days of Rage: The Young Palestinians'' an airing on Wednesday evening. The main, early argument had been whether the 90-minute pro-Palestinian documentary was too blatantly biased for treatment as broadcast journalism. The Public Broadcasting Service tried to meet those objections by wrapping the film in an additional hour of disclaimer and panel discussion.

title: Guilty Pleas in Futures Case
description: Two more futures traders pleaded guilty today to violating Federal commodity laws while trading in the Chicago Board of Trade's soybean pit, admitting they pocketed about $250 each at the expense of customers.

title: Science Academy Recommends Resumption of Natural Farming
description: The National Academy of Sciences has found that farmers who apply little or no chemicals to crops can be as productive as those who use pesticides and synthetic fertilizers, and today it recommended changing Federal subsidy programs that encourage overuse of agricultural chemicals.

title: Olds Offers Full Credit To Unhappy Buyers
description: The General Motors Corporation, moving to halt the customer defections that have plagued it since the early 1980's, is trying a new marketing ploy. Challenging an industrywide taboo, it will permit dissatisfied buyers of new Oldsmobiles to return the cars for full credit.

title: Group Sets Corporate Code On Environmental Conduct
description: The pension funds of New York City and California and other investors joined with environmental groups and religious organizations yesterday to introduce a code of conduct to judge which corporations are environmentally responsible. Those involved control more than $100 billion in investments, The 10-point code has been named the Valdez Principles, recalling the disastrous oil spill by the Exxon Valdez oil tanker off the Alaska coast. It calls on companies to address the effect of both products and production processes on employees, communities and the environment. It also includes requirements that companies appoint environmental experts to their boards and conduct and publicize an annual audit of their compliance with the code.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Quaker Sued On Cereal Ads
description: The Quaker Oats Company was sued yesterday by the Attorney General of Texas for purportedly making false advertising claims for its cereals. The Attorney General, Jim

title: Tesoro Studying Offer from Harken
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it will consider the Harken Energy Corporation's $11.75-a-share merger offer at its scheduled board meeting later this month. Tesoro, which is based in San Antonio, said its board discussed the unsolicited offer Wednesday and requested management to provide information on Harken's operations and performance projections and on industry trends. Tesoro said its board would make a decision on the Harken offer after considering the data, which is to be presented at its quar-terly meeting.

title: Meggett Sparking Giants' Offense
description: When the Giants opened training camp in July, Dave Meggett seemed almost mismatched.

title: Council Passes Law Restricting Carriage Horses
description: A law to bar horse-drawn carriages from most of midtown Manhattan was passed yesterday by the City Council, despite the bitter objections of carriage operators.

title: Review/Photography; The Otherworldly Abstractions of Aaron Siskind
description: Although it slipped into the Museum of Modern Art this summer with little fanfare, the exhibition ''Siskind From the Collection'' is a small gem that should not be missed by anyone who cares about photography's relation to modern art. Consisting of 31 black-and-white images dating from 1932 to 1988, the show pays tribute to the long career of Aaron Siskind, one of the most idiosyncratic and underappreciated figures in 20th-century photography.

title: Festivals and Fairs
description: Tomorrow WASHINGTON SQUARE OUTDOOR ART EXHIBITION, University Place, from 13th Street to Waverly Place; Washington Square East to Third Street; La Guardia Place from the park, south to Houston Street and Fifth Avenue from Eighth to 10th Streets. Works by more than 300 artists and artisans. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon to sundown. Information: 982-6255. EL BARRIO PRIDE STREET FAIR, Third Avenue, between 112th to 115th Streets. Food, entertainment. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M., rain or shine. Information: 996-2288. UPPER BROADWAY FALL FESTIVAL, Broadway, from 96th to 106th Streets; sponsored by the Bloomingdale Coalition, a group of block associations, and the Broadway Merchants Association. Entertainment, ethnic food. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date, Sunday. Information: 764-6330. GATEWAY COMMUNITY SIDEWALK SALE, 46th Street, between Queens Boulevard and Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens; sponsored by Gateway Community Restoration. Vendors, rides, entertainment. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date, Sept. 16. Information: (718) 937-5000. Sunday CLINTON STREET IMMIGRANTS' FAIR, Clinton Street, between East Houston and Delancey Streets; sponsored by Pueblo Nuevo, a housing and development organization. Latin bands, food, crafts. Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Rain date, Sept. 17. Information: 673-3940. PARK SLOPE ARTS AND CRAFTS FAIR, Seventh Avenue, between Union and Third Streets, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Show with 50 to 75 artists and artisans; sponsored by the Park Slope Chamber of Commerce. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: (718) 789-1659. STREET FAIR, Manhattan Avenue, between Greenpoint and Nassau Avenues, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Clothing, rides, food, entertainment. Rain date, Sept. 17. Information: (718) 383-4980.

title: Australian 'Rescue' Move
description: A brewing industry rival of the Australian businessman Alan Bond disclosed today that he was putting together a rescue package for the owner of the G. Heileman Brewing Company in Wisconsin and the Pittsburgh Brewing Company.

title: Salvador Rebels Plan To Cut Level of Combat
description: Leaders of El Salvador's leftist rebels announced today that they would reduce military activity in order to bring about ''as soon as possible a definitive process of negotiation'' to end the country's decade-long civil war.

title: BENNETT CONCEDES STATES WOULD PAY MUCH OF DRUG COST
description: President Bush's drug policy director acknowledged today that state and local governments would have to spend billions of dollars to meet the goals of Mr. Bush's national drug strategy, perhaps $5 billion to $10 billion next year for new prisons alone.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Browning-Ferris Industries, Houston, a waste-disposal company, named Bruce E. Ranck executive vice president of North American solid waste.

title: Holyfield Fight Set
description: Evander Holyfield, considered the main challenger to Mike Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, will fight Alex Stewart on Nov. 4, officials at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City said yesterday. Holyfield is 22-0 with 18 knockouts. Stewart (24-0) has knocked out every opponent he has faced.(AP)

title: Angel Estrada, 31, Designer, Dies; Created Sculptured Evening Wear
description: Angel Estrada, a fashion designer who gave downtown chic a touch of old-world glamour, died of respiratory failure arising from AIDS yesterday at his Manhattan town house. He was 31 years old.

title: Joseph Kaskell, 97; Lawyer Helped Bonn
description: Joseph Kaskell, an international lawyer who was active in the effort to rebuild Germany after World War II, died Tuesday at his summer home in Madison, N.H. He was 97 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Futures Regulator Is Criticized by G.A.O.
description: The investigative arm of Congress said today that there are shortcomings in the way the agency that regulates futures trading polices abuses at the country's exchanges.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ON THE FERRY

title: Cavaliers Announce Signing of Morton
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers signed their first-round draft pick, John Morton, yesterday and though no terms were announced, the Cavaliers were already relishing the versatility of the former Seton Hall guard.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Appointed Frank Howard minor-league hitting director. Announced that John Smoltz, pitcher, would miss the rest of the season. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Recalled Dorn Taylor, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. Purchased the contract of Stan Belinda, pitcher, from Buffalo. BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed John Morton, guard. WASHINGTON (NBA) - Signed Leonard Harris, forward. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Greg Paterra, running back; Kevin Simien, wide receiver, and Tony Bowick and Benji Roland, nose tackles, and placed them on the developmental roster. DENVER (AFC) - Signed Pat Hegarty, quarterback, and Jeff Mickel and Ron Sancho, offensive linemen, and placed them on the developmental roster. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Barry Sanders, running back, to a five-year contract. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Signed Qayne Johnson, quarterback; Ben Jefferson, offensive tackle; Joe Henderson and Ronnie Williams, running backs; Cornell Holloway, defensive back, and Dan Murray, linebacker, and placed them on the developmental roster. MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Cliff Stoudt, quarterback. Placed Scott Schwedes, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Signed Glenn Holt, wide receiver, and David Griggs, cornerback, and placed them on the developmental roster. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Re-signed Rick Strom, quarterback; Mark Stock and Eric Wilkerson, wide receivers; Carlton Haselrig, nose tackle; Tracy Simien, linebacker, and Lester Brinkley, defensive end, and placed them on the developmental roster. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Signed Stacey Searels, guard, and Elliot Smith, cornerback, and placed them on the developmental roster. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Signed Antonio Goss, linebacker, and placed him on the developmental roster. SEATTLE (AFC) - Released Bruce Scholtz, linebacker; Ken Clarke, nose tackle, and Mark Traynowicz, guard. HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Traded Chris McRae, left wing, and future considerations to the Detroit Red Wings for Kris King, left wing. Named Christer Rockstrom, Paul Crowley and Herb Hammond scouts. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Signed Tony Hrkac, center, and Todd Ewen, right wing, to multiyear contracts.

title: Review/Theater; Kabuki's Whirl of Illusions and Disguises
description: Two men claim to be the same warrior. One is not only an impostor, but also a fox. Both fox and man clamber over railings and pop in and out of windows with astonishing ease. And the roles of the fox, the fox disguised as the warrior and the real warrior are played by the same nimble actor - Ichikawa Ennosuke 3d, whose company, Ennosuke's Kabuki, opened Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House in a remarkable display of virtuosity.

title: Legal Services: Political Test Looms for Bush
description: The Legal Services Corporation, the Federal agency that provides most of the funds for legal service offices for the poor, has become an ideological battleground ever since Ronald Reagan tried to eliminate it and failed.

title: Buick Introduces Reatta Convertible
description: Buick has introduced its Reatta convertible after solving engineering problems. Buick's general manager, Ed Mertz, said the General Motors Corporation division might make as many Reatta convertibles as hard-top versions of the car, which has two seats.

title: Dataproducts Plans Significant Overhaul
description: Reacting to a takeover bid, the Dataproducts Corporation said today that it planned a significant revamping in which it would sell a subsidiary and its corporate headquarters, offer a special dividend of about $3 a share and take a $45 million write-off.

title: Colombian Justice Minister Ends Her Trip to Washington
description: Justice Minister Monica de Greiff of Colombia, a target of death threats from drug cartel leaders, left Washington today, ending a 13-day visit, a Colombian Embassy spokesman said.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the El Barrio Street Fair, Third Avenue between 112th and 115th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: GW Utilities reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $4,000,000, or 10 cents a share, for the latest year and $248,000,000, or $6.32 a share, for the year-earlier period. The company said the special gain in 1988 was from the sale of the company's 49-percent interest in Hiram Walker-Gooderham & Worts Ltd. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. Stifel Financial Qtr to July 28 1989 1988 Revenue 22,008,000 16,484,000 Net inc 389,000 b341,000 Share earns .11 - Yr rev 79,823,000 69,325,000 Net inc 635,000 b1,638,000 Share earns .18 - b-Net loss Texscan Corp Qtr to July 29 1989 1988 Sales 11,150,000 12,224,000 Net inc 141,000 b394,000 Share earns .01 - Shares outst 11,231,211 10,640,309 b-Net loss Toro Co(A) Qtr to July 31 1989 1988 Sales 137,455,000 118,487,000 Net inc 2,264,000 1,975,000 Share earns .21 .17 Yr sales 643,566,000 609,205,000 Net inc 22,096,000 20,048,000 Share earns 2.10 1.84 Trimel Corp Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Revenue 523,000 1,600,000 Net inc b3,148,000 91,000 Share earns 1.13 .04 6mo rev 2,100,000 3,300,000 Net inc b3,282,000 230,000 Share earns 1.18 .10 b-Included extraordinary credits of $3,111,000, or $1.12 a share, for the quarter and $3,110,000, or $1.12 a share, for the 6 months. The company said the gain in the latest quarter and 6 months is from the sale of its print publishing division. Figures are in Canadian funds.
