title: Toon's Injury Places Shuler in the Spotlight
description: Mickey Shuler looms larger than usual in the Jets' plans for their season opener Sunday after the team today downgraded Al Toon's playing status to doubtful. That means the club is giving Toon, the Pro Bowl wide receiver, only a 25 percent chance of returning from a shoulder injury for the game against the New England Patriots at Giants Stadium.

title: KIN OF ECHEVERRIA IS INDICTED BY U.S.
description: The brother-in-law of Mexico's former president has been indicted on perjury charges, nearly a month after he was taken into custody for questioning as a material witness in the slaying of a Federal drug agent.

title: Beijing Journal; At Tiananmen Exhibit, Fables From the Party
description: In their drive to explain why China was forced to put down what it officially describes as an anti-Government riot in June, Beijing officials decided recently that the people should see and touch ''the weapons of counterrevolution.''

title: Arthur Rubine Is Dead; Movie Press Agent, 53
description: Arthur Rubine, a motion picture press agent who specialized in independently produced films, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: Lendl's Open So Far Is on Cruise Control
description: Except for a scare from Andrei Chesnokov, Ivan Lendl has breezed through his first five matches at the United States Open. Lendl, the top-seeded player, has been cruising on the court in the same relaxed fashion he drives his sports car to the National Tennis Center in Queens, from his home in Greenwich, Conn. He has been in complete control.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about campaigning for mayor in the New York City Democratic primary erroneously reported an endorsement for David N. Dinkins. The Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association is nonpartisan and never endorses political candiates.

title: Robert V. Engle, Graphics Director, 65
description: Robert V. Engle, graphics director for the state's Urban Development Corporation and the Department of Economic Development, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and its headline on Thursday about a pretrial hearing for John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, incorrectly characterized a statement by his lawyer regarding former President Ronald Reagan. The lawyer, Frederick Robinson, asserted that President Reagan had approved a letter to Congress sent by Mr. Poindexter. He did not say that Mr. Reagan and Mr. Poindexter knew this document to be false.

title: Senate Panel Agrees on Cuts To Reduce Medicare Surtax
description: The Senate Finance Committee agreed informally today on several reductions in benefits under the new Medicare plan to protect older Americans from financial catastrophe because of the expenses of extended illness.

title: Victor Simonte Jr., Executive, 56
description: Victor Simonte Jr., president and chief executive of Bowne & Company, a large printer of financial papers and one of the oldest companies in the United States, died yesterday at his home in Brookville, L.I., after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

title: 4th Suspect Faces Murder Charge In Death of Youth in Bensonhurst
description: A fourth young white suspect was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges of murder and manslaughter in the killing of a black youth in Bensonhurst two weeks ago.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: DOW ENDS UP SLIGHTLY AFTER EARLY LOSSES
description: Stock prices made slight advances yesterday, driven by takeover rumors and some positive economic data.

title: PRETORIA OFFICER TELLS OF ABUSES
description: A South African police lieutenant has sacrificed a rising career by coming forward with an account of riot policemen running amok in a mixed-race township outside Cape Town on Tuesday, the day before the whites-only parliamentary elections.

title: Shrimpers Grudgingly Obey Turtle Protection Rule
description: Some Gulf Coast shrimpers grudgingly complied with a rule reinstated today requiring their nets to have escape doors for turtles, but others remained defiant.

title: Briton in Lebanon Reported Dead
description: The wife of a Briton held hostage in Lebanon said today that she had been told that her husband had died in captivity.

title: Patents; Guidelines Issued On Software Patents
description: Attorneys specializing in patents on computer software take note: The Patent and Trademark Office has published a review of legal guidelines on patenting mathematical algorithms.

title: 2 Are Attacked in Bensonhurst
description: Two Hispanic men were attacked by three white youths on a street corner in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn Thursday night, in what the police are investigating as a ''bias incident.''

title: Former Mayor of Danbury Is Indicted in Racketeering
description: A former Mayor of Danbury was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that he led a racketeering enterprise from the Mayor's office in the mid-1980's, using extortion to profit from the real estate and construction boom then sweeping western Connecticut.

title: Chicago to Hold Night Trials As Drug Suspects Crowd Jail
description: Some Cook County courtrooms will be opened for night trials to ease jail crowding and a backlog of felony cases.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is difficult to characterize last term's decisions as the product of anything other than a deliberate retrenching of the civil rights agenda.'' - Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court. [ 6:3. ]

title: U.S. WILL ABANDON URANIUM FACTORY
description: The Energy Department is abandoning a three-year-old $176 million plant that makes fuel for nuclear-propelled submarines and surface ships for the Navy.

title: Late Rally Pushes Bonds Higher
description: A late rally sent prices of Treasury securities soaring yesterday. Dealers attributed the rally to an unexpected drop in comsumer credit spending in July, which was reported by the Government shortly after 2 P.M. Until then, dealers said, prices were slightly higher in lackluster trading.

title: A MONEY MANAGER IS IN THE MONEY
description: In 1987, when the Aid Association for Lutherans, a 92-year-old fraternal organization, began searching for a professional money manager to invest $384 million in savings, representatives of the big names in money management rushed to its doorstep.

title: RESUTLS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Couple Achieve a First: David and Sandra Farmer-Patrick each won gold medals yesterday in the 400-meter hurdles at the World Cup meet in Barcelona, Spain, becoming the first married couple to win the same track event at a major international meet. David won the men's race in 48.74 seconds. Sandra won the women's in 53.84. AUTO RACING Pole Position for Elliott: The defending Winston Cup champion, Bill Elliott, took the top qualifying spot yesterday for the Miller 400 Nascar race tomorrow. The pole came after he turned a fast lap of 121.136 miles an hour in his Ford Thunderbird at Richmond International Raceway. GOLF Clearwater Ahead: Keith Clearwater had a one-stroke lead yesterday after the second round at the B. C. Open in Endicott, N.Y. Clearwater, of Orem, Utah, shot a three-under-par 68 at the En-Joie Golf Club for a 36-hole total of nine-under 133. (AP) Canadian Leads: Dawn Coe of Canada shot a four-under-par 68 to take a one-stroke lead yesterday as lesser-known players dominated the sun-baked first round of the Cellular One-Ping championship in Portland, Ore. The defending champion, Betsy King, was at 72. (AP) 7 Share Lead: Gary Player and six other players shot five-under-par 67's yesterday to tie for the lead after the first round of the GTE North Classic in Indianapolis. Sharing the lead were Dale Douglass, Gene Littler, Jim Dent, Walt Zembriski, Mike Hill and Billy Casper.(AP) YACHTING New Zealand Still in Front: The New Zealand yacht Steinlager 2 maintained its lead yesterday in the seventh day of the Whitbread Round-the-World Race, holding a 46-mile lead over the Swiss boat Merit. The yachts leading the race reported back to England that they had passed Madeira, an island off the coast of Morocco.(AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL Brigham Young Loses: Brigham Young, playing at home, scored 41 points against Washington State on Thursday night but still lost. With Washington State riding an offense that Coach Mike Price called the best in the country, the visiting Cougars outlasted the home Cougars, 46-41. Brad Gossen passed for 317 yards and two scores for Washington State and Steve Broussard caught a 66-yard scoring pass and ran for three other touchdowns.(AP)

title: West Virginia Senate Head Is Fourth Leader to Resign
description: The State Senate President, Larry Tucker, resigned today after it was disclosed in Federal District Court that he had pleaded guilty to extortion. He is the fourth West Virginia state official to leave office in disgrace this summer.

title: How Much to Fence In the Fed
description: The chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, Lee Hamilton, wants to tighten regulation of the Federal Reserve system. The legislation he has co-sponsored sounds innocent enough. It would strip away some of the secrecy the Fed now enjoys and make it more accountable to elected politicians.

title: Speedy Cray May Slow Its Pace
description: Cray Research Inc., the leading American maker of the fastest kind of computer, faces a growing challenge from rival machines that are less powerful but also far less costly.

title: Davis to See UAL Books
description: The UAL Corporation agreed yesterday to let Marvin Davis, the California billionaire, look at its confidential financial records, a spokesman for Mr. Davis said. The move would fulfill one of

title: Israeli Defense Chief Briefs Washington on Middle East
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel briefed senior Bush Administration officials today on the situation in Lebanon and developments in the Middle East peace process.

title: Edwin A. Burtt, Professor And Author, Dies at 96
description: Edwin A. Burtt, an author and professor emeritus of philosophy at Cornell University, died Wednesday at his home in Ithica, N.Y. He was 96 years old.

title: An Alternative to the P.L.O. - Fundamentalists
description: LEAD: As the episode of Israel's abduction of Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a Lebanese Shiite clergyman, fades from the headlines, the influence of Islamic fundamentalism in the occupied territories deserves the attention of Israeli and American policy makers. Surprisingly, these fundamentalists may hold the key to a Middle

title: Courage in Colombia
description: While some Colombians win international notoriety as drug barons, others labor heroically to defend their country's institutions. Without their efforts, the current U.S.-assisted drive to put the Medellin cocaine cartel out of business could have no real hope of success.

title: Unseen, Unsung, But Not Unloved
description: Rugby in the United States is the martyred sport. Although 150,000 play it, few watch it. Money is short and arguments long. It is rarely on television and seldom in the sports pages. More than 300 colleges have teams, but on a club basis without varsity coaching or financing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Marshall Says Court's Rulings Imperil Rights
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall told a group of Federal judges here today that recent Supreme Court decisions had ''put at risk not only the civil rights of minorities but the civil rights of all citizens.''

title: Mattlyn Gavers, 75; Ex-Choreographer And Ballet Teacher
description: Mattlyn Gavers, a former ballet mistress of the Metropolitan Opera and a professor of ballet at the University of Utah, died of emphysema on Aug. 19 in Salt Lake City. She was 75 years old.

title: Yeltsin, Soviet Opposition Figure, Is Due Today for U.S. Tour
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the swashbuckling Soviet populist whose mass appeal made him the symbol of growing political pluralism in Moscow, arrives in New York on his first American visit Saturday to offer Americans an insight into Soviet politics and to take a crash course in American capitalism.

title: To Dent's Surprise, Yanks Extend His Contract
description: Ten days after he suggested that Bucky Dent might have been summoned to manage the Yankees too soon, George Steinbrenner changed course, announcing today that he would extend Dent's contract through the 1990 season.

title: Association Takes No Position on Bones
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; From Bernstein, Songs About Words
description: Leonard Bernstein's new ''Arias and Barcarolles'' dances the delicate dance between words and music and does it with considerable skill. There are eight numbers using two singers, two pianists and one piano, and at every moment the composer asks the songwriter's two recurring questions: what do words say about music? what does music say about words?

title: Patricia Sparlow Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Luzerne, Pa., Patricia Ann Sparlow, a 29-year-old vice president at Ketchum Public Relations in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Curtis Morrow, a 32-year-old freelance art director in New York. The Rev. Paul Gerosky officiated.

title: Deborah Baber,Actress, Is Wed
description: Deborah Elwynne Baber, an actress and a playwright, and Richard R. Valcourt, the senior editor of The International Journal of Intelligence and Counterintelligence, were married yesterday by Rabbi David M. Posner at Temple Emanu-el in New York.

title: Bridge; Once a major-suit fit has been found, it's rarely right to abandon it.
description: Just as a sailing-ship captain is unlikely to abandon a favorable current in search of a better one, a bidding captain rarely has second thoughts: once a major-suit fit has been found it is hardly ever right to tack away to a minor-suit or no-trump.

title: East Germans in Budapest May Soon Get to Go West
description: The future of the East Germans stranded in Hungary appeared to be nearing resolution today as Bonn and Budapest indicated that the 6,000 people would be on their way to West Germany within days.

title: Yankee Investigation
description: An investigation by major league baseball into possible scouting improprieties involving the Yankees is centering on a former assistant to Syd Thrift, the team's former senior vice president.

title: Plane Crash Off Danish Coast Kills 55
description: A charter plane carrying Norwegian shipping company officials to a ship-christening in West Germany crashed in the sea north of here today. Rescue officials said all 55 people aboard were killed.

title: 2 New Fronts in Charles's Architecture War
description: Contemporary British architecture has been debated fiercely here since May 30, 1984. That night Prince Charles attended the 150th anniversary dinner of the Royal Institute of British Architects and stunned its members by accusing them of having ''consistently ignored the feelings and wishes of the mass of ordinary people.''

title: Posner Rules Out Sale of Arby's
description: Victor Posner, the chairman of the DWG Corporation, the parent of Arby's Inc., tried to calm fears over the dsimissal of Arby's president by telling employees and franchisees in a letter that his commitment to the fast-food chain was resolute. Leonard H. Roberts, Arby's president and chief executive, was dismissed on Tuesday after he wrote a letter criticizing Mr. Posner. Irving Riese was named the president the next day.

title: Bishop, Joseph Nkoane, 60, Dies
description: Joseph Simeon Nkoane, the Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg East in South Africa and an ardent opponent of apartheid, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in KwaThema, a black township. He was 60 years old and had been ill for several years.

title: Bill for the Disabled Only Rights Civil Wrongs
description: To the Editor:

title: Bit by Bit, Life Gets Better for Libyans
description: When people explain how change has come to Libya, the talk sometimes turns to ice cream.

title: U.S. Opens Talks With Exiled Afghan King
description: The United States has sent emissaries to talk to the exiled King of Afghanistan, Mohammed Zahir Shah, to see if he might play a role in ending the civil war in his homeland, Administration officials said today.

title: Italian Bank Gets New Head After Scandal Over Credits
description: The Italian Government named a socialist businessman and financier today to head the country's largest bank after its longtime chairman was forced to resign in a scandal over $2.6 billion in unauthorized export credits to Iraq.

title: Coe Still Running, But He May Retire
description: He has been running for gold for years and now he wants to run for office, so Sebastian Coe said yesterday in Barcelona, Spain, that he would announce his decision on retirement next Thursday at a news conference in London. Coe, who is running the 1,500 meters for Britain in the World Cup meet that began yesterday, is trying to gain a seat in Britain's ruling Conservative Party and is planning a long-term political career. ''Win or lose,'' Coe said, ''I've already made up my mind.''

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Modifying Portfolios
description: With almost three-quarters of the year gone, now is a good time to plan or to take another look at personal investment portfolios. In the first quarter of this year, stocks were the overwhelming favorites as interest rates edged up, spurred by fears of inflation. Since then, interest rates have come down, but not far enough to erase the threat of inflation totally. As a result, debt securities have increased in value. Portfolios tend to vary according to personal preferences and needs, with stocks used to increase personal wealth and debt securities to generate future income. These are some model portfolios being suggested to clients by a few brokerage houses: $ Brokerage Stocks Debt Cash House Securities Dean Witter Reynolds 75% 25% 0% Gruntal & Company 55 30 15 Merrill Lynch 45 55 0 Paine Webber 40 40 20

title: Clarification by Cuomo
description: A comment made by Governor Mario M. Cuomo at a news conference yesterday raised the possibility that the baseball owners are seeking a new commissioner, but Cuomo subsequently rejected that likelihood and emphasized that he himself was not interested in the job.

title: Reagan Undergoes Brain Surgery To Remove Fluid Linked to Fall
description: Former President Ronald Reagan underwent surgery yesterday to remove fluid from his brain that his doctors attributed to a fall from a horse two months ago, a spokesman for Mr. Reagan said.

title: Stricken Juror Is Dismissed From Child Molestation Case
description: Only 12 jurors remain to deliberate the McMartin child molestation trial after a juror was hospitalized with a rare blood ailment, the judge who is hearing the case said Thursday.

title: Giuliani Tries to Offer a Softer Image
description: Rudolph William Giuliani listened intently and asked gentle questions as a young man told him this week how, given the alternative of a long prison term for selling cocaine, he had entered a residential drug treatment program.

title: William N. Healey, Banker, 58
description: William N. Healey, a senior vice president and chief lending officer of the Ensign Bank, died of a brain tumor yesterday at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 58 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Store With an Enduring Mystique
description: Bloomingdale's, one of the world's best-known retailers, has built an enduring mystique over the years. The Manhattan store is ''New York City's greatest export, better known between Tokyo and Moscow than any Broadway show, and equal to the Statue of Liberty,'' in the words of Alan Millstein, an analyst who follows the retailing industry.

title: Travels in Search of Graham Greene
description: Speaking of Joseph Conrad, Graham Greene once said: ''That blasted Pole makes me green with envy because he writes literature when he's trying to write journalism and I write journalism when I'm trying to write literature.''

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Aug. 30 about 12 Colombian drug-trafficking suspects being sought for extradition to the United States included an erroneous description of a suspect's legal status, as supplied by the Drug Enforcement Administration. The suspect, Jaime Raul Orjuela Caballero, was the subject of a criminal complaint filed by the Federal drug agency in 1985 in Brooklyn. He is not under Federal indictment.

title: INSIDE
description: Nuclear Plant to Be Closed The Government said a new plant that makes fuel for nuclear ships is no longer needed, but a Senate aide cited faulty construction. Page 6. The Good Life in Moscow A renovated hotel in Moscow has all the trappings of a stately capitalist pleasure dome, including the Soviet Union's first casino. Page 4. A Graf-Navratilova Final The United States Open women's champions in 1987 and 1988, Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf, will meet in the final today. Page 43. Hope for East Germans The 6,000 East Germans stranded in Hungary likely will soon be allowed to go to West Germany. Page 3.

title: The L.I. Philharmonic Names Music Director
description: The Long Island Philharmonic has appointed Marin Alsop as music director for a two-year period beginning with the 1990-91 season. She will serve as music director-designate this season, and will make her conducting debut with the ensemble in February. Ms. Alsop succeeds Christopher Keene, the orchestra's first music director, who resigned in March after being named general director of the New York City Opera.

title: Smear Time
description: The end of a campaign brings out the worst in politicians. This year's New York City primary campaign has been much better than others, especially among the Democratic mayoral candidates. Recognizing that divisive campaigning could only hurt in the wake of the Bensonhurst tragedy, they have so far behaved with admirable restraint. David Dinkins even asked supporters to withdraw literature that offended Mayor Koch. Would that candidates in some other contests had followed their example.

title: Bill for the Disabled Only Rights Civil Wrongs; More Than Is Needed
description: To the Editor While no one can object to a bill that bars bias against the disabled (front page, Aug. 14), the scope and implications of at least some of its provisions should be clarified. Otherwise, the danger of a backlash against the disabled is a real possibility.

title: Fall in Consumer Debt Is First in 2 1/2 Years
description: Consumers repaid more debt than they took out during July, as installment debt outstanding fell for the first time in two and a half years, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: Revisiting Promises Koch Made in '85
description: While opponents speak in hopeful generalities, an incumbent mayor campaigning for re-election can - and Edward I. Koch does - hold forth the prospect of specific new housing and workplaces, pinpointing their locations and describing them appreciatively, almost as if they had already been built.

title: Burglar Taped Asking for Ride
description: A burglary suspect was arrested, the police said, after he accidentally taped a telephone call in which he asked his father to give him a ride home from a house he had burglarized. Paul Caliguiri, 24 years old, of Pittsburgh, was charged on Tuesday with burglary, theft and receiving stolen property.

title: Radio Executives Put Hate Mongers on Air
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.A. GUNMAN KILLS WIFE OF A BRITON
description: The German wife of a British soldier based in West Germany was shot to death by an Irish Republican Army gunman on Thursday night, the authorities said today.

title: A Survival Curriculum for Inner-City Kids
description: Young black New Yorkers are raised in a racially polarized society. The murder in Bensonhurst of Yusuf Hawkins is not an isolated incident. The number of racially motivated crimes has escalated since Howard Beach, as the city's mayoral candidates ought to know. And these crimes are only the most obvious form of racism.

title: Noise Rule Eased
description: In what appears to be a move to quiet the clamor over the new rule limiting crowd noise, National Football League referees are being instructed to penalize a team for excessive crowd noise only in extreme situations, the Indianapolis Colts' general manager, Jim Irsay, said yesterday.

title: Winthrop Hoyt, Executive, 88
description: Winthrop Hoyt, a retired New York advertising executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manchester Center, Vt. He was 88 years old.

title: INFLUX OF COCAINE IN U.S. HAS SLOWED, DRUG OFFICIALS SAY
description: Large air shipments of cocaine from Colombia to staging areas near the United States have slowed to a crawl since the Colombian Government began its crackdown on the nation's drug industry, officials of the Customs Service and other Federal agencies said today.

title: Learning To Focus
description: With today's films and cameras, taking pictures can be child's play. That literally is the premise of ''My First Camera Book'' (Workman Publishing, $8.95). Written by Anne Kostick and illustrated by Tedd Arnold to appeal to the single-digit set, the 64-page paperback comes complete with something new to children's book publishing: a working camera.

title: Party, Described as Cult, Seeks Role in Primary
description: The New Alliance Party, a small left-wing organization whose 1988 Presidential candidate was on the ballot in all 50 states, is presenting itself this year as the alternative to the regular Democrats running for City Council president, comptroller and several other posts in the New York City Democratic primary Tuesday.

title: Ruling Could Alter Use Of Newspapers' Sources
description: A Minnesota Court of Appeals ruling Tuesday that a reporter's promise of anonymity to a news source is an enforceable contract could reduce the use of unnamed sources by news organizations, according to some leading journalists and First Amendment experts.

title: The President With the Biggest War on Drugs
description: PRESIDENT VIRGILIO BARCO VARGAS, who has vowed to crush the drug lords who have turned his country into a killing ground, seems an unlikely field commander. Uninspiring at the microphone and uncomfortable with the grand gestures of leadership, Mr. Barco might be better cast as a university researcher.

title: Now Call Home And have a Chat With Your VCR
description: ''Machines are only human,'' observed Karel Capek, a Czechoslovak playwright writing in 1920 about what he called ''robots.'' At that time, it was only science fiction. Since then, the word has sneaked into dozens of languages, and the formerly imaginary robots have assumed reality.

title: Style Makers; Emily Gwathmey and John Margolies: Postcard Collectors
description: She is the author of ''Wholly Cow!,'' a book that celebrates the lure of the bovine. He is a photographer, writer and lecturer with a special interest in popular culture.

title: What Does One Do When the Skunks Move In?
description: IT was really time to tackle our little cellar - a small room, one step down, with a dirt floor. As I approached I thought I saw a flicker or two - but no - my eyes were playing tricks - or so I thought until I saw the elegant tail unfurl (Walt Disney style). At this point I turned tail and made for the door - bumping my head as I made my exit yelling ''A skunk! A skunk!''

title: Putting the Baby Sitter on the Books
description: Baby sitters, housekeepers and other household help are employees and thus subject to the same mare's nest of tax rules as other workers. Because they work in homes, though, the routine payroll responsibilities sometimes are ignored.

title: Patricia Buckman Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia Ann Buckman, the manager of research for Lifetime Television in New York, and Geoffrey Sumner Richards, a vice president in the treasury department at Salomon Brothers in New York, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Elizabeth in Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J. Msgr. David J. Casazza officiated.

title: Vegetarian Nostalgia With Music to Match
description: Like something out of a late-1960's theme park, Wetlands Preserve (161 Hudson Street, at Laight Street, 966-4225) turns a sparkling clean TriBeCa bar into a nexus of psychedelic nostalgia and current activism. One large nook holds bulletin boards full of leaflets (''Planet Care,'' ''All-Species Rights''), petitions to be signed and the whimsically painted shell of a VW microbus selling T-shirts, bumper stickers and underground comics. Bands, including many that either have 1960's pedigrees - the revived Big Brother and the Holding Company, perhaps - or that look back to 1950's and 1960's models, perform nightly on the small stage. Sunday afternoons at 5, the club sponsors ''Eco-Saloon'' for activists, and it also holds frequent benefits for groups like Greenpeace. A kitchen serves vegetarian, mostly organic, snacks - and in the lounge are black-lit, psychedelic posters.

title: After 9-Victory Streak, Yankees Drop the Ball
description: The sun above Mel Hall in the sixth inning today had produced another warm California afternoon. But when Hall looked into it and tried to catch a pop fly with a runner on base, it became an overpowering glare.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NO NAME ON THE BULLET. By Don Graham. (Viking, $19.95.) Some biographers have the ability to introduce a historical figure and make him compelling to new generations. In this study of Audie Murphy, America's most decorated soldier of World War II, Don Graham fails to do that but may satisfy those who remember the Murphy legend and want to know more.

title: Titleholder Keeps Single Sculls Gold
description: Kris Karlson, the defending champion in women's lightweight single sculls, achieved the only gold medal for the United States today on the first day of finals at the world rowing championships. That was the first medal awarded and by the time the day's races were over, the East Germans had won 5 of the 11 events.

title: Kathy Dick Is Married
description: Kathleen Marie Dick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Dick Jr. of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens, to John Bundy Ashwell Nye, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Nye Jr., of Lexington, Mass. The ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church was performed by the Rev. Bryan Hehir. Mrs. Nye, 25 years old, is known as Kathy. She is the general manager of the Lone Star Roadhouse in New York. Mr. Nye, 25, is a loan portfolio manager with Sotheby's Financial Services in New York.

title: West Virginia Rallies To Beat Maryland
description: Major Harris and Garrett Ford ran for second-half touchdowns today as West Virginia capitalized on a pair of turnovers to beat Maryland, 14-10.

title: Q and A
description: Succession Rights Question: For more than 36 years my husband and I have been tenants in a rent-controlled apartment. I conduct my business in this apartment; it was arranged through the original lease. Our daughter used to live with us and was a partner in the business. But a few years ago she moved to her own apartment. Six months ago, after I was struck by a car, she moved back, giving up her apartment. She is helping me with my rehabilitation and the business. Should my husband and I decide to move to a life-care community, would our daughter have the right to remain? . . . R. S., Manhattan Answer: According to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, as long as your daughter has no other residence, there should be no question on her right to stay.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Somers
description: LEAD: EDWARD BUROUGHS, the new director of planning in this northeastern Westchester County town of 32.5 square miles of hills, lakes and reservoirs, told a visitor to his office recently that he did not see a permanent need for his position. ''There aren't a lot of large tracts of 50 acres or more left,'' he said.

title: Rebuilt Giants Use Familiar Parts
description: Last Wednesday, in a telephone conference call, a football writer from Washington asked Phil Simms what he thought about the Redskins' ''rebuilt offense.'' ''What rebuilding?'' the Giants' quarterback replied.

title:
ART;
10 Artists Whose Works Make the Case for Tradition
description: LEAD: WITH Patricia Murphy Whitman's initials pushed together - PMW - the name of her gallery in Stamford resembles a cattle brand. It is fitting for Patsy Whitman, as she is known, comes from Dallas, although she has been in these parts for 28 years. This means she understands the tastes of a suburban New York audience and clientele, and the knowledge is reflected in her current group show, ''Summer Too,'' which features 10 artists from Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and New York

title: In the fall, Hollywood's high-powered stars come out
description: HOLLYWOOD reserves its most serious films for fall and winter, when the darker, chillier atmosphere encourages moviegoers to hunker down in theaters for something more solid than the action films and cartoon characters that dash across the screen in summer. But Hollywood's version of fall will never be, in Melville's phrase, ''a damp, drizzly November in my soul.'' This season's follow-up to a summer of splashy special effects and sequels is the presence of high-powered, high-priced stars in numbers that recall Hollywood's golden studio days, when box-office names turned out one film after another.

title: A Designer Returns To Praise
description: His fans did not seem to notice that George Stavropoulos had not had a formal fashion show for a year and a half. ''I always look to him for my chiffons,'' said Janice Levin, while Yveta Graff said, ''He always makes things for me and we never skipped a season.''

title: J. A. Griswold 2dAnd Miss Seiner Wed in Brooklyn
description: Zdenka Seiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Z. Dennis Seiner of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and John Augustus Griswold 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wool Griswold of Hamilton, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. C. Hall Powers performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

title: Peanut-Butter Diplomacy
description: In the article ''Recycling Is An Old Idea That's Come Around'' (Opinion Page, Aug. 20), the advent of peanut butter in plastic jars is decried.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: TRAVELS, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $4.95.) To work his way through medical school, Michael Crichton wrote five pseudonymous thrillers, finally putting his name to ''The Andromeda Strain,'' which made so much money that he didn't have to practice medicine. Becoming disillusioned with his riches, he set off on a spiritual journey, seeking the kind of ''energy'' that doesn't come from batteries. Last year our reviewer, Patricia Bosworth, said she was ''ultimately swept away, not just by his richly informed mind, but his driving curiosity. . . . Michael Crichton may be overly detached, but he seems bound and determined to explore every single mystery in the universe.'' THE TEMPLE, by Stephen Spender. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Sixty years ago, when 19-year-old Stephen Spender wrote this novel about the adventures of three homosexual Oxford poets in pre-Nazi Germany (modeled on Mr. Spender, W. H. Auden and Christopher Isherwood), it was rejected by his publisher as libelous and obscene. After the long-forgotten manuscript was unearthed in 1985 in the rare-books section of a University of Texas library, Mr. Spender rewrote it. Last year our reviewer, Martin Green, said the story has ''a modern flavor, even today. Its refusal to sound like conventional fiction, or to let us comfortably identify with the hero, is disconcerting in the manner of modern experimental novels.'' THE MATHEMATICAL TOURIST: Snapshots of Modern Mathematics, by Ivars Peterson. (Freeman, $10.95.) While physicists look to quarks as the building blocks of the universe, mathematicians seek reality's fundamentals in fractals, prime numbers, strange attractors, cellular automata and other abstractions. In The Book Review in 1988, Jim Holt wrote that Ivars Peterson's ''tour of mathematics moves along with an exhilarating tension-release rhythm: each of the many sections starts out easy, builds in complexity and detail, and then, just as it threatens to overwhelm the reader, gives way to a new topic.'' In ARCHIMEDES' REVENGE: The Joys and Perils of Mathematics (Fawcett Crest, $4.95), Paul Hoffman, a k a Dr. Crypton, writes about computer chess, thinking machines, impenetrable codes and other areas where mathematics intersects with modern life. In this ''breezy and lighthearted account . . . Mr. Hoffman approaches mathematics as a storyteller, and a good one,'' Mr. Holt said. In another new release, Theoni Pappas demystifies mathematics in a collection of miniature essays called THE JOY OF MATHEMATICS (Wide World/Tetra, $10.95). THE SHOWA ANTHOLOGY: Modern Japanese Short Stories, 1929-1984. Edited by Van C. Gessel and Tomone Matsumoto. (Kodansha, $14.95.) In one of these short stories, a Japanese boy finally masters the skill of bicycle riding the night Gen. Curtis LeMay's B-29 raid destroys Tokyo. Last year our reviewer, Hiroaki Sato, said these stories show the ''remarkable range of literary sensibility and expression'' produced in the last 60 years of Japanese literature. THE DREAMING BRAIN, by J. Allan Hobson. (Basic Books, $10.95.) A professor of psychiatry argues that dreams are tales told by the brain to make sense of the random neural firings that come with sleep. ''The evidence he cites in support of the theory is compelling,'' Gina Kolata said in The Book Review last year. ''He can even induce dreams by injecting the controlling neurons with a key chemical, acetylcholine.'' THE WOMAN WHO WAS NOT ALL THERE, by Paula Sharp. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Left behind by her friends and children, Marjorie LeBlanc, a single mother in North Carolina, is shocked by sudden illness into remaking her life. In this first novel, Paula Sharp's writing is ''taut and precise,'' Diana Blackwell said here earlier this year. ''Occasionally it even achieves a certain sturdy beauty.'' ONE OF THE GUYS, by Harry Stein. (Pocket Books, $7.95.) Harry Stein, who used to write the Ethics column for Esquire magazine, joins the chorus of authors bemoaning the tribulations of growing up male in America. Such books ''tend to be studiously sociological, ponderously psychological, hortatory, lamentatory, or all of the above,'' Anthony Astrachan said here last year. But this one, saved by the grace of humor, is ''full of pleasures and rewards.'' PRISONER'S DILEMMA, by Richard Powers. (Collier/Macmillan, $9.95.) Suffering from radiation damage, real or imagined, a father tries to lose himself in a fictional world called Hobstown. ''Despite its uneven prose,'' Ursula Hegi said here in 1988, '' 'Prisoner's Dilemma' gives an absorbing view of history, 'that most abstract, detached, impersonal, and curatorial of disciplines.' '' OXFORD BLOOD, by Antonia Fraser. (Bantam, $3.95.) While at Oxford to shoot a series on the life styles of rich and famous undergraduates, the television newswoman Jemima Shore uncovers a murder plot. In 1985 our reviewer, Beverly Lyon Clark, said Antonia Fraser's ''sentences are well-crafted and [ her ] frequent literary allusions tempt the reader to become a literary sleuth, even to deconstruct the novel.'' Bantam has also reprinted JEMIMA SHORE'S FIRST CASE: And Other Stories ($3.95), a collection of 13 mysteries, including one Jemima solves as a 15-year-old student at a Catholic boarding school. THE CONSOLATION OF NATURE: And Other Stories, by Valerie Martin. (Vintage, $6.95.) Last year our reviewer, Charles Johnson, said some of these stories ''occasionally generate suspense and capture the terror of nature and the nearly paralyzing humiliation of love's rejection.'' The title piece ''lays emotion bare as deftly as a surgeon.''

title: Pepe Sutton, Broadcasting Executive, And Karen Bunche Pierce Are Married
description: Karen Bunche Pierce, a daughter of Burton A. Pierce of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Jane Bunche Pierce, was married in New York yesterday to Pierre Monte Sutton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy E. Sutton of New York and Goshen, N.Y. Justice George Donald Covington of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at Tavern on the Green.

title: The Postman's Palace
description: WHAT DO POSTMEN DREAM about? It is no doubt unfair to judge by a single example, but it's quite an example. Created over the course of 33 years, from 1879 to 1912, by the hand of an obsessive French postman named Ferdinand Cheval (right, in 1905), ''Le Palais Ideal'' is the surreal, ornate reconstruction of what must have been a very beau reve. According to an autobiography Cheval left behind, it was in a dream that he first conceived the palace that would consume the latter part of his life. He died in 1914, at the age of 88.

title: Landfill Concerns Spark Interest in Cloth Diapers
description: LEAD: SO many parents are switching to cloth diapers that even diaper services not yet in business are reporting a surge in interest.

title: Demanding exhibitions that capture decisive moments in modern art
description: THIS SEASON IS distinguished by a kind of museum show that is very welcome at a time when more and more members of the art community know how to generalize and theorize about painting and fewer and fewer know how to look at it.

title: Stacy H. Director Weds
description: Stacy H. Director, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Director of White Plains, was married in New York last evening at the Pierre to David Werner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Werner, also of White Plains. Rabbis Maurice Davis and Mark Winer officiated. Mrs. Werner, 22 years old, is an administrative assistant at DIR Broadcasting in New York. Her husband, 28, is a sales executive for Dorby Frocks in New York.

title: Cure the Industry With More Creativity
description: The annual estimates of advertising in the United States have been presented for a number of years in rather a misleading way. In addition to main media figures, the estimates cover other less relevant categories of expenditure.

title: The Dating Game in Middle Age
description: SEVERAL years ago, I, a middle-aged widow, decided to look for a mate, excluding the single bars, however. I joined a church group of older singles.

title: Donna Lee Shira, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Donna Lee Shira, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Dee Shira 2d of Fairport and Hammondsport, N.Y., and Roy Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Smith of Rochester, were married yesterday at the First Methodist Church in Fairport. The Rev. Margaret Scott performed the ceremony.

title: A Cat's Urban Jungle
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Leschey Is Wed to Eliot C. Heher
description: Dr. Katrinka H. Leschey, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Leschey Jr. of Cape Elizabeth, Me., and Eliot C. Heher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Heher Jr. of Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday at the Spurwink Church in Cape Elizabeth. The Rev. Edward A. Thomson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Health, Maine
description: How to Stay Healthy Abroad Devised and edited by Richard Dawood, M.D. 506 pages. Penguin Books. Paper, $8.95. Travel With Health II By Herbert L. DuPont, M.D. and Margaret W. DuPont. 46 pages. Texas InfoGroup, P. O. Box 161196, Austin, Tex. 78716. Paper, $2.95. The Pocket Doctor By Stephen Bezruchka, M.D. 96 pages. The Mountaineers. Paper, $2.95. The International Health Guide for Senior Citizen Travelers By W. Robert Lange, M.D. 70 pages. Pilot Industries. Paper, $4.95.

title: Glass Wildflowers Bloom in Morristown
description: PAUL STANKARD'S miniature glass wildflowers glow in the spotlighted gallery of the Morris Museum like luminous blossoms in the dappled sunlight of a dense forest. Each stamen, petal, leaf and root is clearly visible, precise and pristine.

title: CIRME
description: A sensitive young man named Philip doesn't quite know what to make of an exotic young woman named Senta when he meets her in Ruth Rendell's psychological suspense thriller THE BRIDESMAID (Mysterious Press, $17.95). With her long silver hair and silent-movie vamp manner, Senta seems to Philip ''like a goddess of mystery and the arcane.'' Stifling his repugnance for the way she lives (on filthy sheets, in a dank and moldy basement room), he becomes her lover. Only when Senta makes a dramatic declaration of love - ''I shall prove I love you by killing someone for you, and you must kill someone for me'' - does Philip begin to question his goddess's mental stability.

title: A Retirement Opens a Race In New Haven
description: When Mayor Biagio DiLieto, the former Police Chief who has led New Haven's powerful Democratic machine for the last decade, announced last March that he would not seek a sixth term, the spotlight turned to State Senator John C. Daniels.

title: Susan Craig Wed To Thomas Stires
description: Susan Joy Craig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Eugene Craig of Short Hills, N.J., and Thomas Homer Stires, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer Stires of New York and Bay Head, N.J., were married yesterday at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills by the Rev. Virginia Scott.

title: Recent Sales
description: Freehold $121,900 253 Tulip Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old condominium town house; c/a, w/w carpeting; monthly maintenance $123, taxes $2,118. Maplewood $155,000 199 Parker Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $3,022. Marlboro $275,000 8 Kennedy Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, deck, c/a, den; taxes $6,000. Orange $116,000 633 Walsh Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 44-year-old Cape Cod; family room, deck, fireplace; taxes $2,498. Rutherford $207,000 71 Crane Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, enclosed porch, full basement; taxes $4,290. Short Hills $182,500 62 White Oak Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 44-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $2,747. OTHER AREAS West Hempstead, L.I. $285,000 224 Westminster Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; fireplace, den, partly finished basement; taxes $5,600. Ossining, N.Y. $299,500 47 Justamere Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, screened porch, 1-car garage, 0.54 acre; taxes $5,800. Milford, Conn. $165,000 40 Dogwood Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; secluded location, 95-ft.-by-53-ft. lot; taxes $1,836.

title: Missy Casscells Weds Frank Hamby
description: Margaret Sybil Casscells, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Ward Casscells of Montchanin, Del., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Frank Stephen Hamby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Hamby of Potomac, Md. The Rev. W. Ramsey Richardson performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Artists Aid a Stage Group
description: THE saving of an endangered theater season has resulted in an alliance between two art forms - for the moment.

title: FLOOR WARS
description: I find it surprising that Cathleen Schine sees evidence of the decline of Western civilization in the current state of toy soldiering. The realistic figures she admires may on rare occasions open the world of history and geopolitics to individual children; more commonly, they give children lessons in who their contemporary enemies are and how they ought to deal with them. Ms. Schine may imagine that these lessons would provide a true understanding of good and evil, but surely a glance at our current global position indicates how inadequate those categories are.

title: Tina Stacy Is Married
description: Tina Stacy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Stacy of Dallas, and Peter Hawkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hawkins of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Asheville, N.C., were married yesterday at the Point, a former Rockefeller family camp on Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y. A village justice of Saranac Lake, Debra Charland, officiated. Mrs. Hawkins is a sales executive for World Color Press, a magazine printer in New York. Mr. Hawkins is a cinematographer in New York.

title: ROOTED IN ABRUZZI
description: ITALIAN DAYS By Barbara Grizzuti Harrison. Illustrated. 479 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.95.

title: Newport Regatta Gaining in Status
description: Women who reach the upper echelon of sailing have largely been restricted to Olympic competition. But an international regatta for women that began five years ago in Newport, R.I., is gaining a substantial reputation, filling a void in yacht racing for women.

title: A World of Illicit Wealth
description: A Federal affidavit has provided a startling glimpse into the violence and enormous wealth surrounding the Medellin drug ring. Page 20.

title: At 70, the Bears Have Shed Their Nasty, Monster Image
description: As the National Football League opens its 70th season today, so do the Chicago Bears, who meet the Cincinnati Bengals at Soldier Field. The Bears were 1 of 12 N.F.L. charter teams that met on Nov. 17, 1920 at Ralph Hay's Hupmobile showroom in Canton, Ohio, and plunked down $100 for membership in the new league.

title: Auto Repair Costs And the Law
description: The article ''Fixing Customers' Cars and Attitudes'' (New Jersey Q & A, Aug. 6) should have also made readers aware of existing law.

title: A Game Plan For Rose
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHO TO BLAME, WHO TO FORGIVE
description: LEAD: WEARING AN INDIANA JONES FEDORA AND sunglasses, Russell Banks maneuvers his mint-green Mercedes-Benz 300 D through the streets of Princeton, N.J., and into the driveway of the apartment complex he lives in. The serene and redundant townhouses close in around us like a compound, and Banks remarks with some amusement that he rarely sees any of his neighbors.

title: Kristi White Wed in Texas
description: Kristi Gail White and Wallace Legette Hall, 27-year-old graduates of the University of Texas, were married yesterday at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Fort Worth by the Rev. William D. Nix. Mrs. Hall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry B. White of Fort Worth, is a vice president for institutional sales at Solomon Brothers in New York. Her father is the president and chief executive officer of White Brothers Inc., a real-estate development company in Forth Worth. Mr. Hall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Legette Hall of Dallas, is an executive vice president in New York for Weber, Hall, Sale & Associates, a Dallas-based stockbrokerage house of which his father is a founding partner and the president.

title: Diplomatese
description: DIPLOMATS, LIKE all practitioners of a specialized craft, have their own parlance, and in diplomacy, as elsewhere, things are not always what they seem.

title: CONSUMER RATES
The Two Jacks
description: JAKE GITTES IS BACK - 11 YEARS OLDER and with a permanent scar on the left side of his nose as a memento of the knife that slit his nostril in ''Chinatown.'' The cynical private detective has fought in World War II and joined a country club, and he's even learned to forgive himself, a little, for what happened on the streets of Chinatown.

title:
DINING OUT;
Imaginative Fare at a Gem in Summit
description: LEAD: ONE of the drawbacks of being a restaurant critic is that when one occasionally discovers a gem, one must love it and too soon leave it. A storefront restaurant called Union Place, in the Union County city of Summit, was such a find for me.

title: Central Banks Act Against Rising Dollar
description: The dollar surged, bringing intervention by the central banks of several nations, including the United States. They succeeded in halting the advance, but that still left the dollar just below the two-mark level against the West German currency and around 148 against the yen. In both cases that is considerably above what is widely assumed to be the upper limits favored by the United States and its economic partners - 1.90 marks and 140 yen. At the start of 1989, the dollar was at 1.77 marks and 125 yen. The Federal Reserve said last week that it sold a record amount of dollars, $11.9 billion, in the May-July period in an effort to halt the dollar's rise. *

title: As Reliance on National Guard Grows, So Do Questions About Readiness
description: At a time when the Army is relying more than ever on the National Guard to help maintain national security, increasing concern has focused on the readiness of the Guard to meet the challenge.

title: HOW USEFUL ARE PRODUCT REVIEWS?
description: EXECUTIVES who want to buy computers for their companies, or at least contribute to the discussion of which machines to buy, often do not have the time or patience to evaluate the 104 different models powered by the Itel 80386 microprocessor. Or perhaps an executive is charged with deciding which data base program to buy but doesn't know which way to turn.

title: Peppers, in All Kinds of Colors
description: ASSORTED peppers are abundant in the market. Not only are sweet red peppers coming from local farms, but yellow, orange and brown ones, as well as the usual green, are available. Adding to the variety are fresh hot green and red chilies.

title: Schools and Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: For 'Miss Pat,' TV With Live Children
description: ALTHOUGH Pat Swartz often hears singing behind the soup and soda displays in her local supermarket, she pretends not to notice. ''They are our songs so I know they are singing to me,'' the children's television hostess and nursery-school teacher said, ''but these are adults, and sometimes they don't want to admit they watch our show.''

title: Last Hurrah for Summer Vegetables
description: Farmers' markets are brimming with warm, sweet tomatoes in red, orange and yellow, striped with green or white, shaped like tiny pears or medium-size pears, not much larger than currants and as big as baseballs. Buyers should get their fill of tomatoes in the next month or so. After that, they will not be worth more than a passing glance until next summer.

title: 28 Arrested in Massage Parlor Raid on L.I.
description: Raids on eight massage parlors led to the arrests of 28 women who allegedly took part in a Korean prostitution ring, the Suffolk County Police said today.

title: A Showcase of Victorian Eccentricity
description: LEAD: CALKE ABBEY, an 80-room mansion in Derbyshire, England, which opened to the public in the early spring, has been called ''The place where time stood still.'' And what a place it was when its clock stopped ticking.

title: Desmond Hogan's Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: Unusual Bulbs to Decorate Spring
description: With the bulb planting season fast approaching, some of the lesser-known kinds should be considered for next spring's displays. An alert has gone out to gardeners to avoid buying and planting many of the diminutive species bulbs because they are collected from the wild. The selections here, are to the best of my knowledge, nursery propagated.

title: Invasion of the Lawn Monsters
description: AS a mother of two young children, my personal space is almost always up for grabs. Sociologists talk about an invisible bubble that surrounds each one of us and keeps others at a comfortable distance. Well, my bubble popped about three and a half years ago when I crossed the line from personhood to parenthood!

title: In Honor Of Black Women
description: The International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, drew a crowd of more than 1,000 people to a party for the New York opening of ''I Dream a World: Portraits of Black Women Who Changed America.'' The show, which will run through Oct. 29, is a collection of 75 photographs of women whose personal visions inspired them and helped shape American history.

title: Ambitious productions, rarely heard early works and modernist departures
description: THE 1989-90 SEASON finds classical music in transition, as a remarkable number of institutions, including the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, experience instability at the top, while others, such as the New York City Opera, face the season with new leaders.

title: 'It Begins With a Belief in People'
description: Max DePree is chairman of Herman Miller Inc., a furniture maker in Zeeland, Mich., known for its innovative designs and participative management system. Herman Miller, which had $793 million in sales in the fiscal year 1989, was the first to introduce the ''open office'' concept. It has been called one of the most admired companies by Fortune magazine.

title: INSIDE
description: Hungarian Buffer Zone Hungary has proposed a security arrangement with Austria and Yugoslavia that would include arms reductions along their borders. It is the first such proposal by a Warsaw Pact country. Page 19. Reagan in 'Rapid Recovery' A day after surgery to drain fluid that had formed on his brain, the former President ate a full breakfast, read several newspapers and was visited by his wife, Nancy, a spokesman said.

title: Opposition Leader From Soviet Union Begins Visit to U.S.
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the Soviet populist opposition leader, arrived in the United States yesterday and said he had come to learn more about ''the American experience in democracy.''

title: Budget Office's Economic Data Is Criticized by Agency of Congress
description: A nonpartisan Congressional agency says the White House's budget office has failed to tailor the Government's data-gathering efforts to assess complex changes in the economy.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Beach Videos

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: LINDA R. BERMAN;
Help for Gamblers and Their Families
description: LEAD: CHARGES that Pete Rose gambled - and may have placed bets on baseball games - has focused attention on compulsive gambling. Is it an illness? Can a gambler be helped?

title: RICH MAKES HIS PITCH
description: Although Bob Rich has yet to be awarded a major-league franchise for his team, the Buffalo Bisons, he is already making a major-league mistake. The correct plural form of bison is simply bison.

title: Story Time by the Radio With Uncle Orson
description: All the recent reminiscence of Orson Welles's 1938 production of ''War of the Worlds'' neglects the fact that Welles was more than a radio one-shot. Indeed, he had a rich radio career, especially in his 20's, initially as an actor, then as a director and producer, all of it informed by a distinctive brilliance. The first virtue of ''The Theater of the Imagination: Radio Stories by Orson Welles and the Mercury Theater'' (Voyager; six audio cassettes or one laser disk, $39.95) is to remind us of this oeuvre.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, an article today on page 48 of The New Season, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstates the role of Tom Wopat in the CBS series ''Peaceable Kingdom.'' He plays Lindsay Wagner's brother.
