Carle Place, L.I. $155,000 287 Jerome Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,500.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: Anthony Walton should cut us all, especially himself, some slack. Dr. King's dream and the ''great American dream'' are, indeed, dreams and, sadly, they are mutually exclusive. Their component parts (hope vs. status quo, spiritual vs. material) are antithetical.

title: Student From Latvia Anticipates 'Freedom'
description: When Natalya Tsarkova registers for classes at Harvard College tomorrow, she will be the first student from the Soviet Union to enroll in a degree program at an Ivy League school. She will have missed by only a few days being the first at any American college.

title: 'Madama Butterfly' To Open Saturday
description: BUSINESS has been booming since the Connecticut Grand and Stamford State Opera Companies became a single organization that puts on subscription series in Bridgeport and in Stamford.

title: Just Next Door to the Polo Club, Island Homes With Riding Trails
description: FOR those who prefer their horse near home and hearth, equestrian residential communities have become the latest option in a state that offers planned communities for everyone from baby-boom tennis players to golf-playing retirees.

title: POSTINGS: Trump Tower Tax Tiff; Who Pays?
description: New York City's tax collectors and the partnership that built Trump Tower - the 59-story building at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street - are battling over who pays taxes on the tower's commercial space. The partnership is seeking to force owners of 283 luxury condos above the commercial space to bear a higher share of the building's real estate taxes than they now do. The city's Finance Department is resisting and urging the condo owners to join its suit.

title: Anne Patterson Becomes a Bride
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., Anne Christine Patterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Patterson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Thayer Wilmerding, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Wilmerding of Rosemont, Pa. The Rev. George Zabriskie 2d performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Jack Smith.

title:
IN THE NATION: BOSTON;
A Trade-Union Bank Finances 110 Condo Units for the 'Southies'
description: LEAD: IN an effort to make housing affordable for first- time buyers and people wishing to stay in neighborhoods where they were raised, a bank established with money from the pension and annuity funds of the Massachusetts State Carpenters Union is financing the construction of a 110-unit condominium development here.

title: Lendl Gains Meeting With Becker in Final
description: Ivan Lendl does not have Andre Agassi's flamboyance or his following. But without much extravagance in his game or any more than a rare cheer in his ears, Lendl gets along just fine. Certainly he gets to the United States Open final with regularity.

title: Punishing Pregnant Addicts: Debate, Dismay, No Solution
description: IN July, a Florida woman was convicted of child abuse for using cocaine while pregnant.

title: Miami Overwhelms Wisconsin by 51-3
description: Craig Erickson shook off a sluggish start to throw four touchdown passes, including two to Wesley Carroll, as Miami routed Wisconsin, 51-3, today in Dennis Erickson's debut as the Hurricanes' coach.

title: Two Directors Reshape Classics From the 20's; 'The Threepenny Opera'
description: DASHED OFF BY BERTOLT BRECHT and Kurt Weill in 1928 in order to open a a young impresario's first season, ''The Threepenny Opera'' is a sublime example of theatrical triumph achieved through catastrophe and chaos. A script hurriedly cobbled together from a new German translation of John Gay's 18th-century satire ''The Beggar's Opera'' - along with Brecht's rewrites, Weill's music and a few borrowings from Francois Villon and Rudyard Kipling - was treated to a rehearsal period that would make the toughest and most sanguine of theatrical managers fall sweating and weeping to the office carpet. Appendicitis for one actress and sudden widowhood for another, performers' objections, both artistic and moral, a dress rehearsal that was three quarters of an hour too long, songs cut, songs added - it was the artistic process at its most vibrant and exciting. That Kurt Weill's bride, the fabulous Lotte Lenya, was accidentally left off the program was an incidental misfortune. And ''Mack the Knife'' - the mysterious and dangerous ballad that Bobby Darin made a Top-10 triumph - was a last-minute entry. Naturally the show became the hit of the year, indeed of the decade, in Weimar Germany.

title: Beethoven Featured In Several Concerts
description: BEETHOVEN has the inside track this week in the county, with a piano concerto and symphony listed by both the Philharmonia Virtuosi and the Westchester Symphony Orchestra.

title: On Campus, How Free Should Free Speech Be?
description: JUSTICE HOLMES once said that ''every idea is an incitement.'' The phrase has been used ever since by legal experts who argue that just about any speech should be protected by the First Amendment no matter how much it offends certain listeners. This very notion, however, has come under attack as universities consider whether they should draw the line at racial slurs, ethnic insults or other speech that is clearly meant to cause mental harm.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: LONG ISLAND;
In Suffolk's Preservation Efforts, The Cluster Compromises Help
description: LEAD: A SCENIC 115-acre tract bordering the Forge River in Center Moriches, where fields that once were farms are ringed by thick woods and salt marsh, is the kind of land that preservationists dream of keeping forever wild - and developers dream of turning into houses.

title: Nicki Mittman Is Married
description: Nicki Lyn Mittman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Mittman of West New York, N.J., and Livingston Manor, N.Y., was married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., to Ira Robert Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris L. Cohen of Floral Park, L.I. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans performed the ceremony. Mrs. Cohen is a geriatric counselor for the Department of Social Services, Human Resources Administration, in New York. The bridegroom is an associate with the law firm of Lysaght, Lysaght & Kramer in Lake Success, L.I.

title: Review/Concert; The Eclectix Impetus: New Music in Old Mode
description: Eclectix, a group that presents new music by composers of a decidedly conservative stripe, opened its fifth season with a program of songs, flute works and light jazz on Friday evening at CAMI Hall.

title: MERLIN WITH A LEICA
description: Since the 1930's, the French photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson has traveled the world with his signature Leica, to paint with light his searing vision of humanity. He is the master of what he refers to as ''the decisive moment'' - an amalgam of time, place and circumstance - and there is perhaps no aspect of his art more revealing than his portraiture. HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON: Photoportraits (Thames and Hudson, $50) offers 255 examples of his work at its most affecting. In all of Mr. Cartier-Bresson's work there is an edgy grace that embraces contradiction. As viewers turn the pages, they are faced with a panorama of the past: Renoir and Matisse, Chanel and Piaf; the poet Robert Lowell, half-reclining on a couch, looking nearly as childlike as a young girl in the background; the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, his head bowed and turned away from the light; the activist Malcolm X at a restaurant table, returning the camera's frank appraisal with one of his own. Equally moving are the nameless people caught at a moment in time: a family man in Champagne; a Mississippi woman clutching bolls of just-picked cotton; a lone, dirty child beneath the tracks of Chicago's elevated train. The volume opens with an ambitious preface by a friend of the photographer, Andre Pieyre de Mandiargues (ably translated from the French by Paula Clifford). But it hardly seems necessary to introduce the work contained in ''Photoportraits.'' If, as Mr. de Mandiargues writes, ''photography is the offspring of the noble art of alchemy,'' then Henri Cartier-Bresson is our modern link to Merlin himself.

title: Review/Rock; Jerry Garcia of the Dead, Quite Alive
description: Jerry Garcia's show at Brendan Byrne Arena on Thursday night started in the second set, when Mr. Garcia, after a short break, came out and sang ''How Sweet It Is to Be Loved by You.'' From then on, the show, which had taken its time and become a bit sleepy, jolted itself into a modest bit of excitement.

title: Does the Demon Barber Have a Human Face?
description: ''When the York Theater Company asked me to direct 'Sweeney Todd,' '' says Susan H. Schulman, ''the first thing I did was laugh.''

title: Insure Deposits, Not Fear
description: Depositor discipline: That's what Henry Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking Committee, and other influential public officials wish to create. They propose lowering the $100,000 limit on federally insured bank deposits.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: Glimpsing Into World of Drug Money
description: Near the end of an affidavit submitted by Government attorneys to oppose any release on bail for Eduardo Martinez Romero, accused of being a Colombian drug financier, is a tale astonishing even by the standards surrounding the Medellin cartel.

title: Style Makers; Allen Fannin: Contract Weaver
description: Allen Fannin, who grew up in Brooklyn and says he went to ''the school of hard knocks,'' has found a niche. He provides apparel and home-furnishings designers with fabrics in small quantities - as little as 100 yards - that the big American mills won't even consider making.

title: RICH MAKES HIS PITCH
description: I enjoyed Irvin Muchnick's article ''Rich Makes His Pitch'' (July 30). I was fortunate to attend a Buffalo Bisons baseball game on July 4 and was impressed by the family atmosphere (though I concede that I am biased, because my fiancee had a message flashed on the scoreboard in my honor).

title: The Voices in a Teacher's Head
description: WHEN I chose the profession, I had aspirations of making a difference, of helping people and changing their lives. I saw no other job as being more important or worthwhile. Yet I've met so many people who have tried to deter me, who have tried to persuade me to change my course.

title: Banks Cast A Hard Eye On Buyouts
description: For the last several years, banks have been eager lenders to leveraged buyouts. But in July, signs of change came when the Bank of Boston withdrew a promised $80 million financing for a management buyout of Dairy Mart Convenience Stores and some $75 million for a leveraged buyout at Recognition Equipment Inc. If that wasn't enough, the bank also threatened to pull financing on the Prime Computer Inc. buyout.

title: Nettles a Legend
description: Since the new Senior Professional Baseball Association held its first draft of former major leaguers last month, the eight Florida-based teams, which are to begin play Nov. 1, have been busy negotiating with their prospects.

title: Lucy James Weds David Ordoobadi
description: Lucy Wilson James, the daughter of Edward T. James of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Janet W. James, was married yesterday to David John Ordoobadi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abbas Ordoobadi of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. James H. Clark officiated at Grace Episcopal Church in Amherst, Mass.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FINANCIAL PRINTING;
Casualties and Hard Times Follow the Crash
description: LEAD: The financial printing industry was deeply humbled by the stock market crash of October 1987. After sailing through 1986 and most of 1987 banking record profits and building capacity, the industry was forced to slash prices and lay off platoons of employees when business fizzled and competition flared after the crash.

title: Who Will Subscribe to the Valdez Principles?
description: Environmentalists and socially minded investment fund managers did not have to look far for a model when they began secret meetings last winter aimed at finding ways to pressure businesses to be more aggressive about protecting the environment.

title: In Dallas, Race Is at the Heart Of City Politics
description: A STREAM of black politicians took the stand in a Federal courtroom here last week as testimony began in a suit claiming that the system of electing the city government discriminates against black and Hispanic voters.

title: At 'Barndominiums,' Home Is Where the Horse Is
description: FOR those who cannot bear to live without their horses, developers are creating housing that caters to the needs of both owner and steed. Designed to appeal to Connecticut's many horse owners, and newcomers who love horses, these new projects combine building lots or houses with barns, stalls and trails, a mixture that has led one developer to coin the term ''barndominium.''

title: LeMond's Finances
description: There's nothing like a second world championship to improve an athlete's finances. That seems to be the case, anyway, with Greg LeMond, the cyclist who has reportedly been getting by on just $500,000 a year as a member of the Belgian-based ADR team in Europe and with the Coors Light team in the United States.

title: Cookbook Formula To Teacher Education
description: I am very appreciative of Joseph A. Ricciotti's article, ''Repressing the Teacher' (Opinion page, Aug. 13). He hit upon some very important questions and issues in teacher education and mirrored many of the same frustrations I am having with state educationists.

title: Pretoria Consulate Attacked
description: Masked attackers stormed a South African Consulate in Copenhagen, throwing acid and setting small fires, newspaper reports in the Danish capital said today. In the incident, which occurred late Friday, 20 to 30 people arrived in a truck and smashed the doors of the building with battering rams and crowbars. No one was arrested. The police said the attackers were members of a squatter movement called BZ, which has been in many confrontations with the authorities in recent years.

title: Review/Dance; Immigrants' Impressions Re-enacted
description: The Synergic Theater, a multimedia group, was at its best at the Pace Downtown Theater on Thursday night when dance, speech, stage settings and lighting effects were so blended that one art became inseparable from another.

title: Ducks, Decoys and Stamps On Display at Stamford Museum
description: LEAD: WATERFOWL, from Muscovy ducks to Canada geese, roam the grounds of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, making an apt introduction to the current exhibition. ''The Duck Stamp Program,'' on view through Oct. 8, brings home the theme of conservation, focusing on the Federal duck stamp program.

title: Works of 39 Artists on View At 74th Hudson River Open
description: THE Hudson River Open is not a golf tournament but a juried art exhibition sponsored by the Hudson River Contemporary Artists, formerly the Yonkers Art Association. For most of its 74-year career, the show has been staged at the Hudson River Museum, first in the Trevor Mansion, which is now called the Glenview Mansion, and, from 1969 on, in the museum's modern extension.

title: Accenting Scents, Caramoor to Open Garden for the Blind
description: LEAD: CARAMOOR is inviting garden lovers to lavish fresh attention on its 100-acre estate here - a backdrop for four decades of summer music festivals.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'STRIKER UP'

title: Suspect Dies in Police Custody; Bronx Witnesses Charge Brutality
description: An unarmed mugging suspect died in police custody in the Bronx early yesterday shortly after violently resisting arrest, the police said.

title: THE RING CYCLE
description: What a joy it was to read Renee Bacher's article, ''The Ring Cycle'' (Hers, Aug. 13).

title: Primary Results Linked To Property-Tax Rise
description: LEAD: MAKING property-tax increases their top issues in the primary election on Tuesday, three challengers to incumbent members of the Suffolk County Legislature will test the depth of voter antipathy toward elected officials serving in a year of sharply higher local taxes.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: PRESNT AT THE SUPPRESSION
description: TIANANMEN DIARY Thirteen Days in June. By Harrison E. Salisbury. 176 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Those who count on using the difficulties of this transitional period for evil purposes and who are trying to undermine the influence of the party should know that this will not work.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 17:1. ]

title: Bereavement Fares: A Look at Airline Policies
description: IF you must travel to the funeral of a close family member, you are probably not prepared to do a lot of comparison shopping for air fares. However, some airlines provide price breaks to people on this sad mission, and it is worthwhile to pick a flight on one of them. Some United States airlines offer what is called bereavement fares; the majority do not.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: LEON DENMARK;
Widening the Role of Symphony Hall
description: LEAD: THE new executive director of Newark Symphony Hall, Leon Denmark, is a well-known arts administrator. With plans for a new cultural center in Newark, Symphony Hall's place in the cultural life of the city is considered to be at a critical juncture. The challenges for Mr. Denmark will involve establishing a strong program and base of financial support.

title: Personal Bankruptcy Filings Rise on L.I.
description: LEAD: The voice in the comercial is soft, soothing and reassuring, telling its audience that money problems are not the end of the world. They can be solved easily, with just one word: bankkruptcy. If once upon a time, many people thought the word itself was loathsome, those days seem long gone.

title: New Orleans's Street of Antiques
description: THE seven blocks of Royal Street between Iberville and Dumaine in the French Quarter of New Orleans, chockablock with street performers and family dynasties of shopkeepers, probably concentrates more quality antique jewelry and furnishings than any comparably sized area in the United States.

title: Anthems and Troubadours That Stirred Crowds to Protest
description: On May Day 1934, in concert with laborers from around the country and the world, hundreds of workers and their supporters demonstrated in Union Square in New York. Their marching song was a tune just published in the left-wing weekly New Masses, ''Into the Streets May First'' - by Aaron Copland.

title: Brooklyn Lyric Opera
description: The Brooklyn Lyric Opera will perform Rossini's ''Barber of Seville'' at Hirsch Hall, Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue, in Manhattan, at 3 P.M. today. The performance, which will be in English, is to be conducted by Sue Peters Albert. Tickets are $10. Information: 837-1176.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE DEMISE OF NUCLEAR ENERGY? Lessons for Democratic Control of Technology. By Joseph G. Morone and Edward J. Woodhouse. (Yale University, Cloth, $22.50; Paper, $6.95.) This sensible little book offers a penetrating and balanced assessment of a hefty subject: how a useful form of energy turned out to be unacceptable to the American public. The answer proposed by the authors of ''The Demise of Nuclear Energy?'' is that the commercial nuclear power program in the United States was flawed from the outset. Virtually every important decision about the design and regulation of nuclear reactors was made in private by small groups of engineers, businessmen and Government officials. Instead of developing safe reactors designed to be as economical as possible, the industry's early leaders developed economical reactors and then tried to build in safety. Lastly, the Government and the industry misled the public about the cost and the danger of nuclear power. Thus, support eroded swiftly after serious nuclear accidents near Detroit, in Alabama and at Three Mile Island convinced the public that the technology behaved in unexpected ways. Joseph G. Morone and Edward J. Woodhouse, who both teach at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, write that the short, expensive and mostly unhappy story of the United States commercial nuclear power industry could have been different if the industry's leaders had grasped the central requirement in a democracy for developing a technology as powerful and potentially hazardous as theirs was: share everything, the good and the bad, with the public. Had vital issues become public in the 1950's, the authors argue, important mistakes might not have been made. Mr. Morone and Mr. Woodhouse assert that lessons learned from the disappointing experience with nuclear power should not be lost on leaders of other technical industries of the late 20th century, among them biotechnology, chemical engineering and transportation.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: NEW JERSEY;
In Montclair and New Brunswick, A Few Drops for the Rental Trickle
description: LEAD: A SMALL rental-housing project opened for occupancy in Montclair on Sept. 1, and ground was broken last June for a larger one in New Brunswick - two of just a handful of rental buildings to be constructed in New Jersey over the last decade.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FRANNIE'S FRUITS By Leslie Kimmelman. Illustrated by Petra Mathers. 32 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Recent Sales
description: Carle Place $155,000 287 Jerome Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,500. Central Islip $119,273 Booth Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 0.5-acre; taxes $700 (under Economic Development Zone tax abatement). Hicksville $165,000 9 Robert Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, den, finished basement; taxes $2,600. Kings Park $150,000 18 Dawson Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Mineola $250,000 16 Pembrook Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old brick Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. West Hempstead $285,000 224 Westminster Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; fireplace, den, partly finished basement; taxes $5,600. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. $155,000 199 Parker Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $3,022. Ossining, N.Y. $299,500 47 Justamere Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, screened porch, 1-car garage, 0.54 acre; taxes $5,800. Milford, Conn. $165,000 40 Dogwood Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; secluded location, 95- by 53-foot lot; taxes $1,836.

title: 'Education Is a People-Intensive Business'
description: THOMAS A. AQUILA has been a member of the State Board of Governors for Higher Education since 1983 and this year he became its chairman. The board oversees a $433 million budget and it licenses and approves all academic programs at the public and private colleges and universities in the state. It also administers student financial aid programs.

title: SPIRE THRILLER
description: LEAD: THE PILLARS OF THE EARTH By Ken Follet. 973 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: A Soft Market Is Chilling Apartment Construction
description: SOMETIMES when he answers his phone, Robert Ginsberg gets the feeling that home buyers in New York City today are a band of marauders driven by a thirst for rock-bottom bargains.

title: BABES IN MAKEUP LAND
description: Can it be true that ''Children 11 to 17 spend $63 a week on pleasure,'' as stated by a Revlon executive in your article? I don't know any such children, and I hope I never will. DULCIANNE VYE Durham, Conn.

title: Looking at an Unkept Promise
description: ALJIRA'S ''Promise of Progress: Present Conditions'' is the third sociopolitical show to be staged by this Newark gallery since it moved to 2 Washington Place. It was organized by Carl Hazlewood, the gallery's artistic director, and its six participants, a press release says, ''have shed the disengaged 'cool' of much mainstream art.''

title: BABES IN MAKEUP LAND
description: It seems to me the concern here is not about a child's need (''. . . to give them a brand for themselves, not their moms' ''). It's about manufacturers getting some of the $63 a week that the children spend on ''pleasures'' into their own pockets. S. L. NEWMAN Somerville, N.J.

title: Inspections Focus on Illegal Rentals
description: LEAD: FIRE DEPARTMENT officials here are involved in an effort to eliminate severe and illegal overcrowding in some of the city's one- and two-family houses and apartments. Fires in which residents were living in crowded conditions have caused four deaths and at least 11 injuries in the last few years.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VICTORIAN FAIR

title:
GARDENING;
Dahlias Provide a Bright End to the Season
description: LEAD: OF all fall flowers, dahlias are exceeded only by chrysanthemums in popularity. At a time when most annuals have faded or gone to seed, dahlias will have just reached the zenith of their display.

title: Hospitals Lose Power As Balloon Hits Wires
description: A balloon knocked out power to two of Rhode Island's largest hospitals today, forcing surgeons to operate by flashlight and nurses to help intensive-care patients breathe by hand.

title: South Africa's Vote for Faster Slow Change
description: SINCE his election as National Party leader last February, F. W. de Klerk has been asking South Africans to share his vision of an evolution away from apartheid. Last week he got that support from a majority of white voters in turbulent parliamentary elections.

title: What Do You Expect for $2.25 Million?
description: ''LET ME TELL YOU ABOUT TONI,'' SAYS STEPHEN SHAPIRO, AS HE kills the engine of his black BMW 750iL with the dark glass, the black leather seats and, of course, the phone. ''Toni's been married and divorced three times. To the same man. So every time there's a change in status, she calls me. She needs a new house.''

title: Arthur Rubine Is Dead; Movie Press Agent, 53
description: Arthur Rubine, a motion picture press agent who specialized in independently produced films, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: Charles J. Kaiser Weds Miss Geer
description: Kristen Anders Geer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl B. Geer Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Woodstock, Conn., and Charles John Kaiser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Kaiser of Hales Corners, Wis., were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Woodstock. The Rev. James Harrison officiated.

title: THE GUIDE
description: HASTINGS BASEBALL

title: More Than the Movies, A Community Event
description: LEAD: TWELVE years ago, what is now known as the Westchester Community College Film Series in Valhalla was a fledgling event held not at the college at all but at the Chappaqua High School. Now the series, which begins Friday evening and runs through Nov. 10, is ''an institution,'' said Dr. William V. Costanzo, the Westchester Community College English professor who selected this year's movies.

title:
TRAVEL BOOKSHELF;
Health, Maine
description: LEAD: Maine: An Explorer's Guide. Fourth edition. By Christina Tree and Mimi Steadman. 391 pages. Countryman Press. Paper, $14.95.

title: REVENGE BEFORE LOVE
description: LEONARDO'S JUDAS By Leo Perutz. Translated by Eric Mosbacher. 154 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $16.95.

title: Sally Taylor Marries
description: Sally Christine Taylor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Stewart Taylor of Short Hills, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., was married to John Soule Truesdale, a son of Loring Reed of Dover, Mass., and Yarmouth, Me., and the late Robert Truesdale. The Rev. Douglas Tompkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket. Mrs. Truesdale, an agent at 58 Charles Associates, a real-estate company in Boston, graduated from Boston College. Mr. Truesdale is the president of the Truesdale Company, a chemical distributor in Boston. He is a graduate of the Middlesex School and Harvard College and received an M.B.A. degree from Boston University.

title: Modesty Sought From Trump
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. Sees No Early Accord With Iran on Hostages
description: The Bush Administration has concluded that despite hints that Iran would like a deal for the release of American hostages, Teheran's new leadership has not decided to act, and Government officials say it could be a long time before it does.

title: Paul McCartney, Meet Midnight Oil and the Lion of Zimbabwe
description: WITH MAJOR STARS like the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney, Bob Dylan, the Grateful Dead and Elton John all scheduled for concert dates in New York this fall, the coming season in pop music is more heavily stocked than usual with rock legends.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: Of course, it's a tragic fact that being black in this country makes one's life that much harder; exactly how much, however, is ultimately up to the individual. Unavoidably, we are judged by our physical appearance. Not only our complexion, but our carriage, style of speech and the anger (or lack thereof) in our eyes all contribute to how we are perceived. If I choose to wear neo-Nazi skinhead regalia and hostility like a flag, I should naturally expect to have plenty of trouble negotiating safe passage through large swaths of New York City. STEVEN BAUMHOLTZ Boston

title: Headliners; The Lawyer . . .
description: After seven years as a full-time lawyer for the homeless in New York City, Robert M. Hayes is cutting back to semi-pro bono. Mr. Hayes, who left the firm of Sullivan & Cromwell in 1982 to head the Coalition for the Homeless, said last week that he would join the New York branch of O'Melveny & Myers of Los Angeles next month, devoting a quarter of his time there to pro bono work. Not that he is tired of public service, he said. It's just that since the decision he won 10 years ago establishing the right of homeless men to shelter, he has become something of an icon of homeless advocacy with little time for the nuts and bolts of law. ''I felt I was too young to be a symbol, that I should have a few more years of substance,'' said the 36-year-old lawyer.

title: U.S. Investigating Theft and Sale Of Computer Gear
description: The United States Attorney's office here is investigating students and former students at the State University of New York at Buffalo in the theft of more than $100,000 worth of university computer equipment.

title: Brother and Sister Team Up on Books
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH fierce competitors during childhood, Ross and Kathryn Petras have put sibling rivalry aside to work toward a career together as writers. Their new paperback, ''The Only Job Hunting Guide You'll Ever Need,'' published last April by Poseidon Press, a division of Simon & Schuster ($8.95), is in its second printing.

title: The True Sport of Kings
description: To the Editor:

title: Noisy's the Word
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Solving the Problem Of 'Drug Babies'
description: Olga Gurny's article ''From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help'' (Opinion page, Aug. 6) is an excellent review of the tragic problem of drug-addicted babies. However, there are several points that need further clarification.

title: Elizabeth Stockbridge Winans Is Wed To Michael Carothers, Bond Salesman
description: Elizabeth Stockbridge Winans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Winans of Dover, Mass., and Harwichport, Mass., and Michael Hadley Carothers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Carothers 3d, also of Dover, were married yesterday at the Dover Church in Dover The Rev. Thomas Niblock, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: From Italy's Jewry Come 2,000 Years of Treasures
description: At the end of Primo Levi's novel ''If Not Now, When?'' a group of Eastern European Jews arrives by train in Milan and discovers to their surprise that there are Jews in Italy. ''Italian Jews are as odd as the Catholics,'' Levi's narrator thinks to himself. ''They don't speak Yiddish; in fact, they don't even know what Yiddish is. They only speak Italian; or rather, the Jews of Rome speak Roman, the Jews of Venice speak Venetian, and so on. They dress like everybody else, they have the same face as everybody else.''

title: Nan Molofsky Is Married
description: Nan Molofsky, a daughter of Iris Molofsky of Malverne, L.I., and the late Emanuel Molofsky, was married last evening at the Loft in New York to Arthur Nathan Skelskie, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Skelskie of Roswell, Ga. Rabbi H. Bruce Ehrmann officiated. Mrs. Skelskie is an associate at the New York law firm of Corbin Silverman & Sanseverino. She graduated from Cornell University and received a J.D. degree from New York University. Mr. Skelskie, an associate at the New York law firm of Stadtmauer & Bailkin, graduated from Brown University and the New York University School of Law.

title: Working to Bolster Residential Sales
description: HOW fares the residential real-estate market? One indication, a cartoon circulating among realtors, shows a sketch of an elderly couple standing in front of a house. The caption reads, ''At long last, we finally own our first home.''

title: Chinese Tale of Betrayal, With a Twist
description: One of the most searing images of the crackdown on the democracy movement in China was the scene of a young woman being praised on national television for turning in her younger brother to the police for his role as a student leader.

title: Michael J. White, Lawyer, Marries Dana Harrington
description: Dana Maddock Harrington, a daughter of Mrs. Stuart Faulkner Harrington of Bay Head, N.J., and the late Mr. Harrington, and Michael James White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis White of Ridgefield, Conn., were married yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head. The Rev. Edward B. Gammons Jr. performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. William Maguire.

title: Maria Neu Marries William Rorer 4th
description: Maria del Pilar Neu, a daughter of Dr. Harold Neu and Dr. Carmen Ortiz-Neu of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Herbert Rorer 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rorer 3d of Lumberville, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Smyth at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: 'The Dybbuk' Rises From the Ruins
description: On Friday, a bit of film history, painstakingly reassembled and refurbished, will be repeated: the showing in a commercial movie theater of the Yiddish classic ''The Dybbuk.'' It is a triumph of persistence that has assembled this 1937 film from pieces as mauled and scattered about the globe as the people for whom it was made to be seen.

title: A Love Story Preserved In Needlepoint
description: LEAD: IT was a classic love story: English aristocrat marries American socialite, but with a twist.

title: Can This Be Love?
description: 'She-Devil'

title: Ms. Postlethwaite Becomes a Bride
description: Andrea Jane Postlethwaite, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Postlethwaite of Washington, was married yesterday to Mark Joseph Riedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Joseph Riedy of Canton, Mich. The Rev. George Reid performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Barnseville, Md.

title: BABES IN MAKEUP LAND
description: I did come of age in the 1960's (''Babes in Makeup Land,'' by Linda Wells, Aug. 13). And you're right - I hardly ever wear makeup. Yet my two daughters, ages 3 and 4 1/2, can't wait to wear the stuff.

title: Miss Brio Winner Of Maskette Stakes
description: The 4-year-old gray filly is not what she used to be.

title: Works From The Wilder Side
description: THE STAGES ARE SMALL AND DARK AND without a front curtain or even wings, carved out of schools and church halls, gymnasiums and living and factory lofts. The performances often start late. The seats are jammed together. But out of these shabby, unsettled confines the imagination seems to take flight with special freedom.

title: Indulging a Passion for Mussels
description: THESE days the roads from the North Sea are punctuated with truckloads of mussels on their way to sate one of Belgium's grandest passions. In a small country that prefers compromise to last stands, mussels brook no argument.

title: Struggling for Profits in Electronics
description: The last several years have been miserable ones for specialty retailers of consumer electronics. After riding the boom in V.C.R. sales through the first half of the 1980's, most electronics chains are now being battered by flattened sales, brutal price wars and ill-conceived expansions.

title: EVERYTHING ABOUT BIRTIN' BABIES
description: MOTHERWIT An Alabama Midwife's Story. By Onnie Lee Logan as told to Katherine Clark. 177 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: First the Heart, Then the Face
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A DREAM OF OLD LEAVES. By Bret Lott. (Viking, $16.95.) The everyday epiphanies of marriage and family life are the subjects of the novelist Bret Lott's first collection of stories. Probing beneath the smooth surface of suburban domesticity, Mr. Lott's spare, emotionally restrained fictions bring to mind a minimalist John

title: CASES OF CHRONIC FATIGUE
description: At Harvard Medical School, we have been studying Chronic Fatigue Syndrome for several years (Body and Mind: ''Ill, or Just the Blahs?'' by Bruce H. Dobkin, July 16). This is, as Dr. Dobkin indicates, a mysterious illness. When a doctor cannot figure out what is producing a patient's symptoms, often he may react by thinking the illness must not exist or that it must be ''psychological.'' As doctors, we must avoid that trap.

title: Zeffirelli Pursues His Grand Design
description: The Viennese musicologist Hans Keller once made a list of fraudulent professions in which he included viola player, psychoanalyst and opera director. Looking over the sets for the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''La Traviata,'' I ask the opera's director, Franco Zeffirelli, what he thinks of Keller's list.

title: THE CASE FOR THE AMPERSAND
description: AN ESSAY ON TYPOGRAPHY By Eric Gill. Illustrated. 133 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95.

title: A Residential Flying Community With Streets Called Taxiways
description: GOLFERS and boaters long have known the advantages of living along the fairway or at a marina. Now pilots are carving out their own niche in the residential real estate market. The latest in this area is Meadow Creek, a 212-acre airport community under construction near Monee 35 miles southwest of the Loop, where pilots will be able to taxi their private planes up to their front doors.

title: Jon Amiel Tracks Life in the Dreamy Lane
description: ''Making a film,'' said the British director Jon Amiel, ''is like going through all the pain and anguish and tenderness that having a baby involves, then sticking it in a basket and floating it down the river. You have no idea whether it's going to be picked up by Pharaoh's daughter or eaten by the sharks.''

title: On Ballot, a Charter Is Distilled to 276 Words
description: With the New York City mayoral primary just two days away, most voters have not focused on the proposed changes in the City Charter that are to be voted on in the general election Nov. 7. But the ballot language for those proposals has now been set, reducing dozens of major recommendations to two questions totaling 276 words.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The fiberglass insulation on my attic floor has a foil vapor barrier on the bottom. There is no insulation over the soffits or eaves, but these soffits are warping because of moisture. The eaves are three feet wide all around the house and there are just two louvered vents, one on each side of the house. I also installed one louver near the roof peak. Is there anything I can do to prevent the warping of the soffits?

title: Style Makers; John Reuter: Polaroid Master
description: Some of the most intriguing photographs of the 1980's have been made with a huge, ungainly camera that spits out 20-by-24-inch color Polaroid prints.

title: Developer's Monorail Plan Scrutinized
description: WHEN Gov. Thomas H. Kean proposed a multibillion-dollar transportation system for the Hudson River waterfront in June, state officials acknowledged that the announcement followed months of lobbying by the Hartz Mountain Development Corporation to promote a monorail that would link its projects in the Meadowlands and the waterfront.

title: REBELS SINCE 1969, STILL GOING STRONG
description: RED REVOLUTION Inside the Philippine Guerrilla Movement. By Gregg R. Jones. Illustrated. 360 pp. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press. Cloth, $26.95. Paper, $16.95.

title: Assessments
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Clouds of Smoke From Trucks
description: Not too long ago we were hearing reports about high rates of poor maintenance on commercial vehicles, especially on their brakes. Now we're told by the trucking industry that emissions inspections are best done on the honor system because ''the majority of truck owners want to maintain vehicles at a high level because it's smart business.'' (''State Urged to Test Diesel Trucks for Emissions,'' Aug. 6.) Pass a few dump or garbage trucks and you'll see the results of self-inspection: thick clouds of smoke that we've now confirmed contain concentrated carcinogenic particles and deadly gases.

title: Triplet Speaker Systems State Their Attractions
description: Loudspeakers usually come in pairs and are normally delivered as identical twins. Lately, however, there has been a surprising incidence of triplets.

title: Deborah Frankel Has a Wedding
description: Deborah Anne Frankel, a director of the seminar division of Institutional Investor, a monthly financial publication in New York, and William Woodward Bancroft Jr., an investment manager with Alex Brown & Sons in New York, were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church. The Rev. Susan Harriss officiated. Mrs. Bancroft, the daughter of Deltra Locke Frankel of Garden City, L.I., and the late Dr. Emanuel Frankel, graduated from Finch College. Her father was a podiatric surgeon and a violin maker.

title: Center Helps Families Care for the Elderly Ill
description: LEAD: THE prognosis is not promising for most patients at the Dorothy Adler Center for Geriatric Assessment at Yale-New Haven Hospital. At least three-quarters have Alzheimer's disease, and the rest suffer from a range of debilitating symptoms attributed to old age. But a program that focuses on life styles as well as medical problems has helped many patients feel better soon after their first consultation at the clinic.

title: The New Romantics Paint the Past
description: The younger generation of romantic landscape painters seem to be spending less and less time confronting nature in the raw. While struggling to produce a nonabstract painting vocabulary that works for today, they scramble ever more eagerly for motifs from the art of the past and assiduously incorporate - not without irony - sentiments and images borrowed from earlier eras.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RESCUE. By Stephen O'Connor. (Harmony, $17.95.) In ''The Afterlife of Lytton Swain,'' one of several striking stories in this first collection by Stephen O'Connor, the Rev. Lytton Swain gradually adapts to a nether world where he can order a cup of coffee in a diner, casually pocket a severed finger found on the ground, and exchange pleasantries with Mr.

title: Washington Tops Texas A&M by 19-6
description: Washington unveiled its new one-back, short-passing offense today, and with Cary Conklin doing the passing and Greg Lewis doing most of the running, the Huskies upset Texas A&M, 19-6.

title: Miss Uroff Wed To Z. M. C. Colt
description: Elizabeth Uroff, a daughter of Margaret McKenzie Dickie of Athens, Ga., and Benjamin Uroff of Champaign, Ill., was married yesterday to Zenas Marshall Crane Colt, a son of Zenas Crane Colt of Wakefield, R.I., and the late Cynthia Means Colt. The Rev. James Yeary officiated at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Athens.

title: Marjorie Wallace Becomes a Bride
description: Marjorie Cook Wallace, a credit analyst in the private banking and securities division of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Peter Edward Gibson, a senior associate at Orion Consultants, a financial management consulting concern, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Miller Chapel at the Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary. The Rev. Edwin C. Bockstiegel, a Presbyterian minister and the father of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Greed Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Couple Imports Polish Culture
description: A SOUTHINGTON couple, Jan and Zofia Sklepinski, are so sure the popularization of Polish culture will spread to the United States that they are betting on it - to the sum of about $500,000.

title: Jackson Stumps With Dinkins At Queens Rally
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson campaigned yesterday for David N. Dinkins as the mayoral candidate of ''hope and healing'' for New York City.

title: Baiting Brokers
description: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I just plain and simple can't find anything I want to buy, and experience teaches that's an important warning flag.'' Barton Biggs chief investment strategist, Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Elegant East Side Chinese or Theatrical SoHo
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Auntie Yuan ** (Sept. 1, 1989), 1191A First Avenue, near 65th Street (744-4040) - This elegantly modern Chinese restaurant has a strong core menu of regional dishes with a few nods to Western tastes.

title: KOCH AND DINKINS SPRINT TO FINISH
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan, the two acknowledged front-runners for New York City's Democratic mayoral nomination, stumped the city yesterday in a final frenzy of rallies and walking tours in which they largely played to their separate constituencies while they preached racial harmony.

title: Installing Electrical Boxes
description: WHENEVER household wiring is connected to a switch, receptacle, light fixture or other outlet, the splices that form the connection are enclosed in a firmly mounted metal or plastic box called an electrical box or switch box.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Naturalness of Nature

title: Cubs Beat Cards, 3-2, in 10th for 1 1/2-Game Lead
description: Luis Salazar, who singled home the tying run in the eighth inning, doubled home the winning run in the 10th as the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2, today and held onto first place in the National League East. The victory gave the Cubs a one-and-a-half-game lead over St. Louis.

title: FLOOR WARS
description: Not to worry. The spirit of toy soldiering is alive and well - in the form of elaborate chess sets (Civil War soldiers, Roman gladiators, etc.) Hats off to Malcolm Forbes, a happy man indeed, with his motorcycles and toy soldiers. BYRON WHITEHALL New York, N.Y.

title: HE SAW HIS CHANCE AND HE TOOK IT
description: EXIT THE RAINMAKER By Jonathan Coleman. 401 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Ensemble Experiments
description: The Cucaracha Theater, situated in a 10,000-square-foot warehouse in TriBeCa (429 Greenwich Street, 966-8596), has become a center for some of the most interesting experimental theater work in New York. Since it was founded four years ago by Richard Caliban, a playwright and director, and David Simonds, an actor, Cucaracha, whose sprawling ensemble pieces have an intense, homemade quality, has presented some 40 works, featuring a total of more than 100 actors. The plays that have attracted the most attention have been ''Famine Plays'' by Mr. Caliban and ''Hunger'' by Peter Mattei. The company's season opens this Thursday with a four-week run of a new play, ''Indiana Dog,'' written by Jeffrey Klayman and directed by Mervyn Willis. A comedy featuring 25 actors, it is described by Mr. Caliban as a '' 'Peer Gynt'-style epic.'' This winter, the company will present a festival of one-act plays. - STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: Hiker's Paradise Of Alpine Plants And Animals
description: IN northern Italy, within sight of Mont Blanc, is the country's largest natural reserve, the Gran Paradiso National Park. The park is named for one of the mountains within its confines, the highest entirely on Italian soil. And the name is particularly fitting. For the park is a paradise of unspoiled Alpine wilderness, filled with an incredible variety of plants, flowers and animals.

title: Rap by the Bay: Oakland Emerges As a Force in Pop
description: ''It's hard times city,'' Dwayne Wiggins said. ''You can't half-step here. Whatever you do, you have to be good at it.'' Mr. Wiggins is one of the three principals of Tony Toni Tone, an Oakland funk group whose debut album has emerged smartly on the national charts. He was speaking of this blue-collar city, which over the last five years has become a veritable mixing board for black American music, a studio whose sounds are thriving on at least three prominent fronts: funk, rhythm and blues, and music from the rap and hip-hop movements.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article in The Times Magazine today about the American Civil Liberties Union appears with a line omitted on page 74. The affected passage should read, ''There are also instances where civil liberty principles collide - where a news organization's right to report events concerning a criminal prosecution, for example, might conflict with an individual's right to a fair trial.''

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Some breathe in the scenery, others concentrate on the music filtered through their earphones, a few practice what might be called active meditation and a minimal number simply clear their minds and operate in a vacuum. But most joggers (well, who can prove it one way or another?) fantasize about the other joggers they encounter while running.

title:
ART;
In Pursuit of Individual Expression
description: LEAD: MANY people agree that the dominant trend in art today is actually the absence of a specific trend, or movement. More artists now pursue independent directions than at any previous point in the century.

title: Amei Wallach Marries
description: Amei Wallach, the chief art critic for New York Newsday, and William P. Edwards, the chief executive officer of the Museum Company, a chain of gift stores with headquarters in Little Falls, N.J., were married last evening in the Sagaponack, L.I., home of Robert Dash. Cantor David Benedict officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is the daughter of Gerda Wallach of Hartford and the late Dr. Gert Wallach. She graduated from Columbia University. Mr. Edwards, a graduate of Harvard University who received a master's degree in American studies from the University of Minnesota, is a son of Faire Edwards of Montpelier, Vt., and the late Magnus William Edwards. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of her husband.

title: Shagging's a Carolina Duty and Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: ALASKA OIL CLEANUP NEAR END, BUT BEACHES REMAIN FOULED
description: After spending $1 billion trying to clean up less oil than Americans consume in a day, the Exxon Corporation's army of 10,000 workers is disbanding, leaving miles of beaches still coated in thick black goo.

title: Teacher Standards Are a Needed Reform
description: The State Department of Education is implementing an innovative new program that is challenging the status quo regarding entry into the teaching profession. It is called the Beginning Educators' Support and Training program, or BEST, and it emanates from the Education Enhancement Act of 1986, the foundation of the state's reform of the teaching profession. The act established a balanced equation: increase teachers' salaries for increased teaching standards.

title: 2 Texas Statues Embody Century of Racial Views
description: Two statues that symbolize racial attitudes a century apart have become focal points for protests against racism and statements for civil rights at the University of Texas.

title: Sarah K. Brown Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Sarah Kenney Brown, a daughter of Mrs. Norman Farquhar of Washington and the late Philip Bransfield Brown, to Lawrence Peter O'Hagan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Richard O'Hagan of Toronto, took place yesterday at St. Mary's Chapel of the Washington Cathedral. The Rev. Sanford Garner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Harold Bradley, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Maigret and Simenon
description: Devotees of mystery fiction had a true friend in Georges Simenon, who died last week at the age of 86. He gave them Inspector Maigret, 84 times, and he gave them something else as well: Paris. Just as London belongs to Sherlock Holmes and Los Angeles to Philip Marlowe, so Paris belongs to Jules Amadee Francois Maigret, lover of good food, good wine and that very good woman, Madame Maigret.

title: Getting In To See the Doctor
description: Re: ''Please, May I see the Doctor?,'' Opinion Page, Aug. 13. Yes, you may see the doctor, but . . . . The doctor's receptionist is really not the one who initiates the battle; often it is the patient who creates the war zone and offers little in the way of compromise or in establishing a neutral zone.

title: Teen-age Fantasies, Literary Classics, War and Revolution
description: EVER IN SEARCH OF young viewers to deliver to their advertisers, the networks have always offered a few series that exploit the fantasies of teen-agers. This season brings us three new ones.

title: Eueka and Yuck! How the Gypsy Moth Met Its Match
description: THEODORE ANDREADIS leaned back in his chair, laced his fingers behind his head and thought a moment. ''What was it like around here the day we discovered the gypsy moth fungus?'' he said, beaming as he repeated his visitor's question. ''It was an exciting day. A very exciting day.''

title:
HERS;
Just Two Women
description: LEAD: WE HAD WAITED three years to celebrate Christmas together in my family's home in Pietermaritzburg. While the midday heat wilted the flowers outside, we ate the steaming, traditional Christmas dinner and toasted with chilled white wine to ''the next time,'' not knowing when that would be.

title: Kelly Smith Weds J. Steven Kraus
description: Mary Kelly Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Smith Jr. of Basking Ridge, N.J., and J. Steven Kraus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kraus of Garden City, L.I., were married yesterday at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Basking Ridge. Msgr. William Capik performed the ceremony.

title:
DEAL JOURNAL;
For Town, if All's the Same Then That's How It Should Be
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the chill winds of change are buffeting many cities and towns across the state, this seaside community is likely to be much the same when the 21st century rolls around as it has been for much of the 20th. The reason is simple: the residents like it that way.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SARAH LAWRENCE COLLEGE;
Optimism Is the Word, at Least for Now
description: LEAD: ALICE STONE ILCHMAN, the president of Sarah Lawrence College, loves September and the return to academia.

title: Hot Tickets; Nights to Remember
description: * ''Orpheus Descending.'' Vanessa Redgrave re-creates her celebrated London role, Sept. 24 at the Neil Simon.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: I am tired of these stories by and about ''poor Ivy League Negroes'' who suddenly discover racism, as though attending Yale, Harvard or Princeton should exempt them from what other African-Americans encounter every day of their lives (''Willie Horton and Me,'' Aug. 20). Anthony Walton should have learned at Harvard that, in this society, a Negro is a Negro is a Negro, and that there are no exceptions. Apparently, he didn't, and he should petition the university's curriculum committee to include that bit of wisdom and truth in Philosophy 101 for future students who might be seduced into forgetting that there is a real world outside those ivy-covered walls. LINDSAY PATTERSON New York, N.Y.

title: Amy Sklut Is Married
description: Amy Lynn Sklut, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Sklut of Wilmington, Del., and H. Ronald Cohen, a son of Mrs. S. John Silverberg of Greenville, Del., and the late Edward Cohen, were married yesterday at the Hotel DuPont in Wilmington. Rabbi Herbert Yoscowitz officiated. The bride, a graduate of Vassar College and the Dickinson School of Law, is a lawyer for Hercules Inc., a chemical company in Wilmington. Mr. Cohen, a graduate of the University of Delaware, is a mortgage banker at Loyola Federal Savings and Loan in Baltimore.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FINANCIAL PRINTING;
The High Price of Over Expanding During a Boom
description: LEAD: The stock market crash certainly weakened Pandick and pushed Sorg and Chas. P. Young closer to bankruptcy, but it was not the only factor in their downfall. Their high levels of debt and over-zealous expansion during the bull market were perhaps as much to blame. Hard-pressed to match the heavy price discounts offered since the crash by their stronger competitors, analysts say all four have lost market share.

title: Boston Weighs Drastic Changes In School Board
description: Boston's leaders and residents, almost unanimously dissatisfied with the public schools, are considering dramatic changes in who runs the 59,000-student system.

title: Mets Falter as Pirates Get 3 in 12th
description: After 12 innings of baseball that lasted 4 hours 7 minutes, the Mets departed from Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon disgusted at themselves and dejected about their situation.

title: Question Of the Week; What Is Giamatti's Legacy to Baseball?
description: Bart Giamatti is baseball's John F. Kennedy. His arrival on the scene brought a surge of glamour and excitement to major league baseball: At last, an interesting man (and fan) as commissioner. The Pete Rose case was his Cuban missile crisis, where Giamatti demonstrated that he was tough enough for the job. And then, suddenly, Giamatti died, before he could fulfill his great promise.

title: First-Time Buyers Face Some Agonizing Choices
description: WHEN it came time to buy their first home, Jeff and Kelly Bonser of suburban Los Angeles matched the experience of many young couples setting out to buy into the American dream. They paid more than they had expected to, and settled for less than they had hoped for.

title: New Italian Fare in Huntington
description: HUNTINGTON food lovers are not waiting until tulip time to try Il Tulipano, the town's newest Italian restaurant. Its spiffy new paint job and bright emerald awning are stopping traffic on Route 25A.

title: Trollope's Fecundity
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackie Mason Stirs Up a Chancy 'Chicken Soup'
description: In a mere 48 hours, Jackie Mason will stand before four cameras and a live audience to tape the fourth episode of his new ABC series ''Chicken Soup,'' but as of this late August morning, he has yet to memorize his part. Not that this concerns the comedian. Indeed, as he rehearses on CBS/MTM Studios' Stage 16, he is blithely doing what he has always done so well - working the room for laughs.

title: U.S. LISTS COUNTIES WITH MOST PEOPLE
description: Minnesota's Hennepin County, which includes Minneapolis, has more than a million residents, bringing the number of counties in the nation with a million or more residents to 29, five more than in 1980, the Census Bureau says.

title: Yale and New Haven Become Tennis Partners
description: In an unusual marriage of town and gown, New Haven, Yale University and state representatives have cooperated to bring a major tennis tournament to New Haven.

title: Week's Lessons Extend Beyond Football Practice
description: When a football game ends with a score of 27-0, the winners usually run back to the locker room cheering and the losers try to slink off the field. This was not the case after the Earlham College Quakers defeated the Doshisha University Hamburgers.

title: Drug Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: GAY VOTE PURSUED WITH EXTRA VIGOR
description: The votes of gay and lesbian New Yorkers are being courted as never before in the municipal primary campaign, gay rights advocates and political leaders say.

title: Headliners; . . . but Not the Judge
description: He's the Terminator, the bodybuilder turned actor, a symbol of the perfect male specimen. What better choice to judge the Miss America pageant? In fact, it was all set and Arnold Schwarzenegger was scheduled to go to Atlantic City next weekend for this year's contest. But the organizers of the pageant didn't reckon on the power of a potential conflict of interest. Mr. Schwarzenegger's wife, Maria Shriver, is a newscaster for NBC, and her program, ''Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow,'' is planning a report on the pageant. She thought that would be a conflict of interest, the pageant director, Leonard Horn, said, and she persuaded her husband to withdraw. Mr. Horn said it has left him with rather large shoes to fill. Still, he has other big-name judges, Donald Trump, Merv Griffin, Phylicia Rashad and Dr. Joyce Brothers among them.

title: In Arts and Antiques, a Year of Gems
description: Provocative works from most historical periods and much of the globe will be exhibited at museums and galleries from now through the end of the year. Of the four areas of antiques and the decorative arts that dominate - antiquities, Americana, Oriental porcelains and jewelry - the runaway favorite is jewelry, the subject of at least six shows.

title: Novelist's Father Also Named Henry
description: In her otherwise informative article, ''Legacy of Modern Times, an L.I. Utopia'' (July 30), your reporter says, ''William James Sr., the father of the novelist Henry James, wrote in The Tribune . . . '' In fact, the father of the novelist was also named Henry James (often called ''the elder'') and his father, grandfather to Henry the younger, was named William. The novelist's brother, the philosopher and psychologist, was named after him. R. B. WEBER Department of English

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MORNING BREEZE: A True Story of China's Cultural Revolution. By Fulang Lo. (China Books, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $9.95.) In short, telling strokes, akin to those in a Chinese painting, Fulang Lo sketches a personal history that captures both the exhilaration and the chaos that gripped everyday life during the Cultural Revolution.

title: Tim Robbins, Hanging Out With the Gang
description: At about 6 feet 4, walking with a loose, shambling gait, his face dimpled and wrinkle-free, Tim Robbins looks like the overgrown kid he portrayed in the 1988 movie ''Bull Durham'' - the baby-faced pitcher with unknown potential.

title: While History Is Conflict, the End Is Not Yet
description: To the Editor:

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FINANCIAL PRINTING;
Growing in a Downturn to Gain Market Share
description: LEAD: Intent on exploiting the vulnerabilities of their weaker rivals, Bowne, Donnelley and the Merrill Corporation have been expanding since the crash. Each has already expanded itsmarket share by at least a few points. Their secrets? They were on firm ground before the crash hit. ''Any idiot can get giddy in an upturn,'' said Mr.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about bigotry in pop music omits a section on page 33. A corrected copy of the passage may be found in the main news section, on page 69.

title: Finding Out The Realities of AIDS in Prison
description: WITH hundreds of prisoners already dead and thousands more infected, New York State has a bigger AIDS epidemic within its criminal justice system than most states have in their entire population. But critics say that instead of rising to the challenge, the system has too often failed its inmates with AIDS, abridging their legal rights and even shortening their lives by neglecting medical care.

title: Bennett's New Weapon Against Drugs: Tact
description: If the debut of the Bush Administration's drug strategy this week was not ''Batman through the transom,'' the phrase William J. Bennett uses for an imaginary quick fix to the drug problem, it was certainly Czar at full tilt.

title: DANCE: Season Preview; Historic revivals, elaborate premieres
description: DANCE IS LOOKING both backward and forward this season, with both premieres and revivals of important works.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: WESTCHESTER;
A 306-Home Project Where Prices Start at $700,000
description: LEAD: SOWN two years ago, the seeds of Park Lane Reserve, a $250 million complex of 306 expensive houses in the Town of Harrison, have not grown at the pace expected by the developer. Harrison Park Lane Associates had anticipated selling 20 to 25 homes a year at prices ranging from $700,000 to $1.1 million and to set its construction timetable accordingly.

title: How the Alphabet Is Shaping Up In a Computer Age
description: Of the changes being forced on the world of type by computer technology, Edward Benguiat says, ''I certainly hope that a genius will appear who can make something beautiful out of all this, but I don't see one around now.''

title: Indian Troops to Leave by Dec. 31, Sri Lanka Says
description: India will withdraw its peacekeeping troops from Sri Lanka on or before Dec. 31, a senior Sri Lankan Government official said today.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Catching Up With Morris County's Joneses
description: LEAD: FOR years, Rockaway Township watched as office parks spread like crabgrass through other parts of Morris County. Now it is about to get one of its own.

title: Prospects; Productivity's Problem
description: The Labor Department's second-quarter productivity figures showed a modest overall increase of 0.7 percent, with gains of 2.9 percent in manufacturing accounting for nearly all of the increase. Analysts are increasingly suspicious of the productivity numbers as indicators of economic health. Three economists and a former auto worker discuss them. Sam Nakagama Chairman and chief economist, Nakagama and Wallace Inc.

title: FLOOR WARS
description: Cathleen Schine left out a crucial consideration. The toy soldiers of World War II and Korean War vintage included medics, nurses, stretcher bearers and wounded figures with casts and bandages. They provided a hint of the gruesome realities of battle. But none of the G.I. Joe fantasy warriors look as if they are capable of being wounded. They seem to teach that technology can make us invulnerable and that war is clean, neat and antiseptic. MELVIN A. KULBICKI York, Pa.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: In Long Beach, Revaluation Brings Specter of Higher Taxes
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, Cathy Northrop, a Long Beach homeowner, received a card in the mail informing her that a data collector would soon be visiting her house for purposes of reassessment.

title: Improbable Plots In 2 Schisgal Plays
description: BOTH ''Closet Madness'' and ''The Rabbi and the Toyota Dealer'' are about men who want to change their lives.

title: Hungary Plans Arms Pullback Along 2 Borders
description: The Hungarian Communist Party, demonstrating anew Hungary's independent spirit, has proposed forming a 60-mile zone partly free of offensive weapons along its borders with Austria and Yugoslavia, both neutral countries.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The fiberglass insulation on my attic floor has a foil vapor barrier on the bottom. There is no insulation over the soffits or eaves, but these soffits are warping because of moisture. The eaves are three feet wide all around the house and there are just two louvered vents, one on each side of the house. I also installed one louver near the roof peak. Is there anything I can do to prevent the warping of the soffits?

title: CHESS
description: The ideal in chess training is to arrive at the first round of a competition with sufficient practice and leisurely - yet still intensive - theoretical preparation behind you. But nowadays it is difficult for top players to achieve the right formula.

title: Rule by Steam and Gunpowder
description: MACHINES AS THE MEASURE OF MEN Science, Technology, and Ideologies of Western Dominance. By Michael Adas. Illustrated. 430 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $29.95.

title: T-Shirts' New Mood Is Sarcastic
description: Read any good T-shirts lately? How about bad T-shirts, hostile T-shirts, cynical T-shirts, T-shirts with chips on their shoulders? ''Welcome to New York,'' says one. ''Now go home.'' Another shirt shows a cartoony snub-nosed revolver. ''New York,'' it reads. ''It Ain't Kansas.''

title: Seoul Is Opening Up, But Its Jails Are Still Full
description: EVEN before the end of the Seoul Olympics last year, which raised Koreans' hopes for progress and stability, leaders here fretted about a potential post-Games letdown. Today the euphoria of that time is long gone, and South Korea is struggling with the shadows of its authoritarian past and lurching fitfully in its transition to democracy after decades of military rule.

title: Yugoslavia's Lesson
description: Yugoslavia surged ahead of other Communist countries 40 years ago, leaving the Soviet bloc and launching a series of reforms. Now it is first again, but in a different way. It is proving demonstrably that half a reform is not half a loaf, it is no loaf.

title: Silence Urged For Hernandez
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For a Ballboy, A Love Match
description: AS Mats Wilander walked off stadium court at the United States Open last year, he threw me his wristband. I had just been a ballboy for his match against Mikael Pernfors.

title: Special Today: residential Property/Section 13
description: Special reports in this issue include: First-time home buyers face hard choices. Demographics hold key to appreciation of home values. Confronting suburban sprawl is the big issue of the 90's. A soft market is chilling apartment construction. Blue Cross plans a cradle-to-grave development.

title: Elisabeth Butler, Paralegal, Is Wed
description: Elisabeth Carol Butler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Copeland Butler of Sparta, N.J., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Spencer Keith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Keith of New York. The Rev. Wade A. Renn officiated at Grace Episcopal Church in Nutley, N.J.

title: Outdoors; Whale of Time Bluefishing With Family
description: It is my opinion, though there is no way to verify it, that the world takes the deepest breath it can just before Labor Day and that summer - true fishing doldrums summer - lasts only until the world exhales that breath, turning the first leaves of fall and signaling the start of the bluefish blitz up and down the East Coast.

title: Ms. Kuhns Weds Stephan A. Shea
description: Ann-Louise Kuhns and Stephan Anthony Shea, program analysts for the joint legislative budget committee of the California State Legislature in Sacramento, were married yesterday at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Valatie, N.Y. The Rev. John Caldaro officiated.

title: Just Whose Cassette Is This, Anyway?
description: Video advertisers, actual and potential, are ever awaiting the latest tabulations on how consumers are taking to commercials on cassettes of feature films. Recently they got some fresh figures from Nielsen Media Research, a division of the ratings organization.

title:
GARDENING;
Dahlias Provide a Bright End to the Season
description: LEAD: OF all fall flowers, dahlias are exceeded only by chrysanthemums in popularity. At a time when most annuals have faded or gone to seed, dahlias will have just reached the zenith of their display.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FINANCIAL PRINTING;
Rewer Perks as Price Cutting Picks Up
description: LEAD: For decades, the financial printing business has been ruled by an old-boy network. Investment bankers and lawyers who steered business to one printing house or another were once likely to receive tickets to sporting events, luxurious dinners with limousines, a yacht at their disposal and open invitations to summer homes.

title: PBS Storms the Barricades
description: IT HAS THE BEST OF DICKENS AND THE worst of Dickens; the most tautly written dialogue and the most slackly indulgent melodrama, the most inspired and vivid beginning and the most unsatisfying end (or, for some, vice versa). In the year of the bicentennial of the French Revolution, however, ''A Tale of Two Cities'' has proved impossible to ignore. Arthur Hopcraft's four-part dramatization, to be shown on PBS's ''Masterpiece Theater'' beginning Nov. 19, is just one of a number of versions this year on stage, radio and television - but in scope, historical engagement and its use of French and English casts for their respective parts, it is much the most ambitious.

title: Editors' Note
description: A fashion article on page 108 of The Times Magazine today discusses the prospects of young designers including Angel Estrada. On Thursday, after the magazine had gone to press, Mr. Estrada died of AIDS-related causes.

title: Special Today: The New SeasonMagazine, Part 2
description: This preview of coming events includes: Selective guides to theater, dance, film, art, classical music, pop, television and photography. Special reports on August Wilson's new play, Jack Nicholson's latest movie and John Dexter's production of ''The Threepenny Opera.'' Plus Al Hirschfeld's first color illustration for The Times.

title: Demographics Hold Key To Home Appreciation
description: AS vice president and chief housing analyst for the Chicago Title and Trust Company, John Pfister is among the legion of real estate professionals who consider home ownership one of the most solid long-term investments available to American families.

title: Maja Paumgarten Weds John Parker
description: Maria Elise Paumgarten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Paumgarten of Brooklyn Heights and Northeast Harbor, Me., and John Forbes Parker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin E. Parker of Mendham, N.J., and Mishaum Point, South Dartmouth, Mass., were married yesterday in St. Ignatius Church in Northeast Harbor. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Martel, assisted by the Rev. Frederick Buechner, a Presbyterian minister. Ms. Paumgarten, who will retain her name, is known as Maja. The bride, a 23-year-old artist, graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and the University of Pennsylvania. Her father is a senior vice president at Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation in New York and an adjunct professor at Columbia Business School. The bride is a descendant of Nicholas Biddle, the president of the second Bank of the United States.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: CONCORD, N.H.;
New Attractions For Shoppers
description: LEAD: A $39 MILLION regional shopping mall is part of nearly one million square feet of retail space under construction here, making Concord the state's most active retail center. An additional half-million square feet is planned.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: Plant, dig, divide and replant overgrown clumps of perennials; plant new ones. Feed the lawn and reseed bare patches. Take cuttings of border annuals to root and grow as winter house plants. It's Time

title: Headliners; . . . the Justice . . .
description: Supreme Court justices often dissent sharply from their colleagues when they're on the bench, but usually leave it at that. Not so Justice Thurgood Marshall. In a speech to Federal judges last week, Justice Marshall said that recent High Court decisions taking a more restrictive approach to the rights of racial minorities ''put at risk not only the civil rights of minorities but the civil rights of all citizens.'' Appointed in 1967 by Lyndon B. Johnson, Justice Marshall, 81 years old, is among the few remaining liberals on the Court. Saying the Court is now deliberately reversing 35 years of progress on civil rights, Justice Marshall said, ''We could sweep it under the rug and hide it, but I'm not going to do it.''

title:
MUSIC;
Soprano to Perform Polish Art Songs
description: LEAD: THE American soprano Juliana Gondek has been casually collecting Polish art songs for years. When she finally decided to put together two recitals of the music, it was not because she was hired to do the programs.

title: Black Voters Say It's Time for Dinkins
description: A few weeks ago, Thomas Key paid little attention to the mayoral primary. The 62-year-old retiree said he had planned to vote for David N. Dinkins but was not especially inspired by the prospect. Politicians, he said, are basically the same.

title: Free Improvisation Heads Once More Into the Breach
description: THE ADVENT OF THE NEW York Branch of free improvisation (in which musicians improvise with noise and music but without planned structure) in the mid- to late 1970's seemed at the time like a blessing. Mixing the free-improvisational ideas developed in jazz with ideas taken from European improvisers and classical musicians, it made for exciting, radical music.

title: Congress Gets Serious On the Capital Gains Tax
description: ONE of President Bush's favorite ideas, to cut the capital gains tax, has been transformed this summer from long shot to near certainty. But what form it will take is not at all certain as Congress sets out to decide how to restore a tax preference that was abolished in the tax overhaul legislation of 1986.

title: Oakland Outbid In Luring Raiders
description: Oakland officials said their offer to lure back the Raiders amounted to $54 million, not $32 million as previously reported, but conceded that Sacramento's proposal was far more lucrative.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SILK ROAD. By Jeanne Larsen. (Holt, $19.95.) The Silk Road was the route of silk manufacture and trade in the myth-laden Tang dynasty of eighth-century China. And ''Silk Road'' is an excellent title for this newly made myth, recounting as it does a slave girl's quest for identity throughout that same realm.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: PITTSFIELD, MASS.;
The Eagle Spreads Wings
description: LEAD: THE Miller family, which owns The Berkshire Eagle newspaper, is expanding into real estate, redeveloping the historic 11-acre Clock Tower mill complex as a business park.

title: Catharine Scholtz Is Wed in Darien
