description: The wedding of Catharine Ann Scholtz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Scholtz of Darien, Conn., and Naples, Fla., and Matthew Arnold Labine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. A. Clem Labine of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien. The Rev. Anne Kimball officiated.

title: THE DECLINE AND FALL OF A SURE THING
description: BATTLE FOR JUSTICE How the Bork Nomination Shook America. By Ethan Bronner. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: Yonkers Discord Touches Primary
description: A FORESHADOWING of the election struggle expected in Yonkers in November over the issue of a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan may emerge Tuesday - Primary Day - in the mayoralty race and in four of the six City Council districts.

title: Campione: Italy's Little Vegas
description: THE slot machines start clicking and ringing at 3:15 P.M. every day and the roulettes spin night after night until dawn in the ancient village, an Italian-Swiss Atlantic City of sorts, on the eastern shore of Lake Lugano. Determined nongamblers, too, are often captivated by Campione d'Italia, a splinter of Italy, the size of one-third of Central Park in New York, embedded in the south of Switzerland. One of Europe's few political enclaves, it is a geographical and administrative curiosity.

title: FICTION
description: BLESSINGS. By Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $19.95.) At the heart of Belva Plain's ploddingly earnest novel, ''Blessings,'' is Victoria Miller, nicknamed Jill, a vivacious, red-haired Barnard sophomore, the oldest child of a surgeon and a librarian, adopted at birth in 1969. Well loved, well raised, both independent and romantic, Jill is determined to find her birth parents. But although her intent is revealed early on, Jill herself doesn't appear until midway through a lugubriously overloaded plot. The ostensible heroine is Jill's birth mother, Jennie Rakowsky, a nice Jewish lawyer from Baltimore, engaged to Jay Wolfe, a handsome young widower with ''two small girls and an infant son, a rather grand Upper East Side apartment, and a partnership in one of New York's most prestigious law firms.'' Jay's gracious, wealthy parents have welcomed Jennie and blessed her with the family pearls. The senior Wolfes also ask Jennie to represent the rural community where they have had their country home for nearly half a century, which is threatened by wicked real-estate developers. Then ''happy, happy'' Jennie, the world veritably her oyster, answers the phone. It's ''Birth Search,'' a ''service for adoptees.'' In flashback we meet Jill's birth father and learn what happened when Jennie was a college freshman. On a cold winter night soon after the phone call, the doorbell rings and ''Jennie, the strong one, who so proudly coped with crises'' is struck speechless. A week of improbably operatic meetings and misunderstandings involving the whole cast follows. Jill is somehow plausible; the rest of the characters seem ordered from a catalogue.

title: University Falls To Invading Birds In Dirty Defeat
description: The grackle is one species of birds that University of Texas officials would love to endanger. After years of all-out war they are employing new tactics in their continuing battle against the pesky black-feathered enemies.

title: 121 New Condos
description: Yet another condominium apartment house is joining the march of new residential buildings up Broadway north of Lincoln Center, this one on Sherman Square, at the intersection of Broadway, Amsterdam Avenue and West 70th Street. Named the Coronado, the 21-story project, with an address of 155 West 70th Street, will have 121 apartments from studios to four-bedrooms, with a price range of about $175,000 to $1.5 million. Exact prices are to be determined before the apartments go on sale early next year after the building is finished.

title: Turning the Tables With a Phrase. Take That, Monsieur
description: France is anything but bland. It cannot be negotiated with bland language. Standard phrasebooks may tell you how to ask the location of the nearest railroad station, but they often fall short when you need to assert yourself in thorny situations. The following may be helpful TAXI DRIVER AVEC CUJO

title: Miss Raymond Becomes Bride
description: Barbara Morris Raymond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Whitridge Raymond of Riverside, Conn., and Davidson Durand Williams, a son of Mrs. G. R. D. Williams of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Williams, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside. The Rev. Dr. Phillip E. Perkins officiated.

title: Navy Launches a Submarine Amid Protest
description: The Navy launched its newest Trident submarine today, the $1.2 billion U.S.S. Pennsylvania, in a ceremony mocked by about 100 anti-nuclear demonstrators, six of whom were arrested when they steered their small rafts too close to the submarine.

title: Forest Fires Blackening Acres of 'Green Spain'
description: After one of the driest winters this century and a hot, parched summer, Spain is experiencing one of its worst seasons of forest fires, the National Institute for Nature Conservation says.

title: CALL IT EXILE, CALL IT IMMIGRATION
description: JASMINE By Bharati Mukherjee. 241 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $17.95.

title: Rutgers Suffers Second Tie
description: In the second game of a now tarnished season, Rutgers again let a victory become a tie. Today it came against Ball State, a competent Mid-American Conference team from Muncie, Ind., that earned a 31-31 deadlock when Kenny Stucker kicked a 51-yard field goal with one second left on the clock.

title: AUSTERITY AT ISSUE IN NORWAY'S VOTE
description: The Labor Government's austerity policies, an unemployment rate that is high by local standards and the long waits for non-emergency care in the socialized medical system are the top issues here as Norwegians prepare to vote in parliamentary elections on Sunday and Monday.

title: Suburbia Has Changed; So Have I
description: I HAVE been living in Suffolk County since 1966 and chose to live here for all the obvious reasons. I wanted the advantages of my own home in the country. After 26 years of the city it was time for my American Dream!

title: Shopping List For Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Steffi Wins Survival Contest at the Open
description: The marathon continued yesterday at the steamy outdoor dance hall in Flushing Meadows, with the player who had suffered from cramps outlasting the player who suffered from being 32.

title: Miss Chamberlin Wed in Princeton To T. H. French
description: Liane Helen Chamberlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., and Timothy Hutchins French, a son of Alden French Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., and the late Dorothy Fairbanks French, were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Robert Ferrick performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Civil Suits Under RICO Turn Loose a Monster
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOWMANSHIP
description: OVER THE LAST FEW YEARS, THE NUMBER OF ART and antiques shows held at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street, have increased so much it appears that from October through June there is a preview party nearly every other week. There are shows devoted solely to paintings, others that deal exclusively in drawings, some that exhibit only modern decorative arts, and one dealing exclusively in antiquarian books. Indeed, the age of specialization has hit the antiques business. But despite the plethora of shows, grumblings have persisted among experts that New York doesn't have a truly international show, one on a par with Paris's Biennale des Antiquaire or London's Grosvenor House; or one that is vetted by a panel of experts who authenticate every object, as they do for European shows.

title: Miss Shorey Marries Nicholas Herold
description: At the Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, Va., Katherine Knight Shorey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde E. Shorey of Washington, was married yesterday to Nicholas Henry Herold, a son of Mrs. James K. Herold of Washington and the late Mr. Herold. The Rev. Richard Peard officiated. Mrs. Herold, 30 years old, is a freelance graphic designer and consultant in Boston. She graduated from Earlham College and received a master's degree in graphic design from Boston University. Her father, a lawyer, retired as a vice president of the March of Dimes in White Plains. The bride's mother, Joan B. Shorey, who served as an aide to Richard L. Ottinger when he was a United States Representative, is a founder of two nonprofit groups in Washington: Concern Inc., an environmental group for women, and the Walkways Center, which promotes walking for fitness and health.

title: Correction: On Bigotry in Rap
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about bigotry in pop music omits a passage. The section, on page 33, should read:

title: Birth Control Making Inroads in Populous Kenya
description: Kenya's birth rate has dropped, the first sign that the rate of population growth, the highest in the world, may be slowing, a Government survey shows.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After having what he described as his ''most enjoyable'' season to date in the National Basketball Assocation, Manute Bol, the 7-foot-7-inch, Sudan-born center for the Golden State Warriors, is apparently preparing for his most lucrative one. The 26-year-old Bol, who led the N.B.A. last season with 345 blocked shots, sixth highest in N.B.A. history, signed a four-year contract with the club. Financial terms were not disclosed. . . . John Tomac, the world mountain-bicycling champion, has turned professional and joined the 7-Eleven road racing team. The 21-year-old Tomac, from Chatsworth, Calif., was the first American amateur to finish this year in the Tour de Trump, the most important road race in the United States, and in the Milk Race, Britain's leading road race. Last year, he won the United States Criterium championship.

title: A New Balance in a New Season
description: IF the past theater season signaled a boom of new plays, the one about to begin (with ''42d Street'' on Wednesday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn) promises a more sensible balance of premieres and revivals.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MY LIFE IN WRITING: Memoirs of a Maverick. By J. C. Furnas. (Morrow, $22.95.) These polished recollections concern the comfortable Middle Western childhood, unremarkable education at public school and Harvard University, and enviably successful career of a leading magazine journalist, ghostwriter, novelist and author of two highly regarded biographies (of Robert Louis Stevenson and Fanny Kemble) - among much else.

title: China's Riches Yield To Diplomacy's Skills
description: In early 1987, when Charles H. Moyer gave Chinese authorities his ''wish list'' of nearly 80 masterworks from Beijing's Forbidden City that he wanted for a major American exhibition of traditional Chinese painting, the Chinese responded with a counterproposal.

title: Talking Condo Funds; Managing Capital Reserves
description: THE roof shingles will deteriorate, the driveway will need a new surface and even the corridor carpeting will wear thin. But unlike a co-op corporation, which can easily borrow funds for capital outlays to repair such conditions, the condominium is not so fortunate; banks are still wary since the condominium association has no collateral to pledge. And a special assessment creates too much individual hardship and internal strife.

title: FREE-TRADE CUISINE
description: A RESTAURANT WRITER'S LIFE HAS BECOME exasperatingly complicated in recent years, what with all the cross-pollination of cuisines and internationalization of kitchen staffs. Dining out used to be fairly straightforward: you went to a French restaurant and ate French food; Italian restaurants served Italian food, and the Japanese respected their gastronomic borders, as did the Spanish, Mexicans and Greeks. American food was a little trickier, melting pot that we are, but our cooking was still regionally identifiable.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: IT was a front-page courtroom drama that pitted religion against modern secularism, that tested a community's right to keep out unpopular opinion and that brought a big-city lawyer to challenge small-town America.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about scuba diving referred incorrectly to some equipment. The regulator, tank-pressure gauge and timer can be attached to the inflatable vest known as a buoyancy compensator, but are sold separately.

title: Mother Teresa Develops Fever
description: Mother Teresa has developed a high fever and an irregular heartbeat, hospital officials said today. Doctors said they had decided to put in a temporary pacemaker to help the 79-year-old nun, who is known for her work with the destitute and dying. Mother Teresa suffered a heart attack on Friday.

title: Syracuse Misses a Kick
description: Bill Scharr, who holds the New York State high school record for touchdown passes, today showed he could be a winning starting quarterback for Syracuse.

title: Football's Muzzled Masses Unleash a Call of the Wild
description: Last March, in all their might assembled in Palm Desert, Calif., the National Football League owners made a momentous decision. They voted to impose penalties against home teams for crowd noise that continually disrupts the offenses of their opponents, and if they thought they heard noise, the indications are that they ain't heard nothin' yet. After all, you can't smoke in elevators, spit on the sidewalk or shoot off a machine gun in church. Now this.

title: There's a New Sound in Pop Music: Bigotry
description: Has hatred become hip? From isolated spots in pop culture, racial and sexual prejudice have slithered back into view. Andrew Dice Clay, a comedian whose Nassau Coliseum performance on Saturday sold out immediately, mixes dirty-word jokes with vicious put-downs of women, homosexuals, blacks and Japanese. During a sketch on ''The Tonight Show'' Aug. 11, Johnny Carson, as his yokel character Floyd R. Turbo, invoked ''baseball the way it was meant to be played, on real grass, with no designated hitter and all white guys''; the studio audience gasped, then tittered nervously.

title: No New Taxes, But Plenty Of New Plans
description: AS the Bush Presidency unfolds, it is becoming clear that the Administration's most ambitious goals, like the war on drugs that the President proclaimed last week, are hostage to his campaign promise not to raise taxes. Even many of the President's strongest supporters agree that the drug initiative and some other Presidential proposals are constrained by inadequate financing, and nobody has proposed a politically feasible way to squeeze the needed funds out of the Federal budget.

title: A Blessing By Sanders
description: The deal that made Barry Sanders the highest-paid rookie in the history of the National Football League also meant something of a bonanza for a church in Wichita, Kan.

title: DATA UPDATE
HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS
description: WHAT AM I DOING HERE By Bruce Chatwin. 367 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Jersey City Tower
description: Ground is to be broken in Jersey City Tuesday for Pavonia Tower, an eight-story office building half a block north of Journal Square, which is undergoing extensive real estate development. The 68,000-square-foot building will be divided, with retail space on its ground floor and 57,000 square feet of office space on the upper floors. The building, scheduled to be completed late next year for occupancy early in 1991, will carry the address 600 Pavonia Street. The $8.5 million project is next to the Journal Square station of the PATH line between New Jersey and New York.

title: How 'Produced by David Wolper' Made Its Mark
description: By JEREMY GERARD

title: No More Than 1 in 5 Athletes Graduating at Many Schools
description: At 35 of 97 American colleges and universities with major men's basketball programs, no more than one in five players ever graduates, a Federal study has found. The graduation rates for football players were only a little better.

title: Correction
description: Because of producers' changes, the selective guide to theater on page 60 gives outdated schedules for two Broadway openings. ''The Threepenny Opera'' is to open Nov. 5; ''The Secret Rapture,'' playing at the Public Theater through Sept. 27, is to transfer to the Barrymore on Oct. 10, with an official opening Oct. 26. (On page 19, a picture caption also gives the outdated schedule for ''The Secret Rapture.'')

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS PREDICT COALITION
description: Opposition leaders in Managua say they believe that the next Nicaraguan Government will be a coalition between themselves and the Sandinistas, regardless of who wins the presidential elections scheduled for Feb. 25.

title: 'America's Rome'
description: To the Editor:

title: Badges of the Stylish Landlubber
description: Not since the tall ships sailed into New York Harbor a few Fourths of July ago have so many insignias been seen in these parts. No, the New York Yacht Club has not opened its membership to the populace at large. It is just that a couple of well-known fashion houses, Chanel and Adolfo, have come out with blazers whose designers apparently believe that if one insignia looks good, then many insignias look better.

title: GORBACHEV SAYS INTERNAL ENEMIES ENDANGER CHANGE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that his program of change was endangered by internal enemies who have whipped up public alarm and disorder.

title: An American Tradition Gains a Japanese Hand
description: LEAD: AS a child in Japan, Yoshie Yamamichi learned to sew from her grandmother, a kimono maker. Today, Mrs. Yamamichi lives in Darien and she still sews, but now the form and design she uses to express her cultural inspiration is traditionally American: quilting.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: 'Annie' Redux

title: Amid Convent Dispute, Cardinal Cancels U.S. Trip
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish church leader who has incurred criticism for his remarks in the dispute over a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, has canceled a scheduled visit to several United States cities, the Polish press agency said today.

title: Warren S. Lockwood, Consultant, 81
description: Warren S. Lockwood, a foreign trade consultant, died of a stroke and heart attack Friday at the Chesterfield Nursing Home in Chester, Conn. He was 81 years old and lived in Essex, Conn.

title: A Computer Course That's User-Friendly
description: GOD provides, Virginia Bull believes. But He isn't averse to accepting help along the way. For many years Mrs. Bull of Central Islip supplied that help. Now she could use a little too. Not for herself, but for her school, and the Long Island women whose lives may change because of it.

title: Panel Is Set to Consider Curbs on Guns
description: LEAD: THE accidental shooting deaths of four children this summer - three at the hands of playmates - have sparked new interest for a review of the state's gun laws and for changes on gun use and access.

title: Dinkins and Koch Vie for Jews' Votes
description: David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President running in the Democratic primary for mayor, had just completed a swing through a Lower East Side knish shop, seeking votes among the Orthodox Jewish families gathered for an early Sunday lunch. But the handshaking made no impression on a young man in a yarmulke at the back of the room.

title: New Job for Aide Who Quit Bush Campaign
description: Frederick V. Malek, who resigned a high-level post in George Bush's Presidential campaign last year while denying charges of anti-Semitism, will soon be appointed by Mr. Bush to a White House post, Administration officials said today.

title: Henderson's Mind Open on Yanks
description: In the late afternoon of another summer day at home, Rickey Henderson is thinking about next season. He is stretching and talking and looking toward the outfield grass, and he is saying what seems to be unthinkable: that he would consider coming back to New York.

title: Convent Issue: Divisions Growing Within Divisions
description: Seldom in recent times have prominent Roman Catholic cardinals been in such public disagreement as they were last weekend after Jozef Cardinal Glemp proposed discarding a 1987 agreement to move a convent of Carmelite nuns from the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Blue Skies, No Garbage: A Welcome Summer at Beaches
description: LEAD: ABOARD a passenger jet de scending toward La Guardia Airport on a breezy day this summer, a woman from Tennessee stared disapprovingly at the whitecaps off Long Island's South Shore. ''Will you look at all that garbage,'' she said, shaking her head. Ever since the odyssey of the Islip garbage barge and last summer's widely reported incidents of medical waste and other debris floating off its ocean beaches, Long Island, formerly terra incognita in much of the country, has been winning an unwanted reputation for being awash in its own garbage.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Mailings: Vote on an amendment to a legislative expenses bill that would cut Senate mass mailing funds by $45 million and devote the money to drug programs. Approved 83 to 8, September 7. 2. Disabled Rights: Vote on passage of a bill that would prohibit discrimination against disabled Americans in employment and assure their access to public accommodations, transportation and communication services. Approved 76 to 8, September 7. $ 1 2 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Y Lieberman (D) N Y New Jersey Bradley (D) N Y Lautenberg (D) Y Y New York D'Amato (R) Y Y Moynihan (D) N Y KEY Y Yea; N Nay; (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present. There were no votes in the House.

title: Sanders Activated
description: Less than three days after he left the Yankee outfield, Deion Sanders was placed on the active roster yesterday by the Atlanta Falcons for today's National Football League opener with the Los Angeles Rams. The Falcons also activated the All-Pro guard Bill Fralic.

title: Club Owners Working on a Plan to Share Salary Expenses
description: The majority of major league club owners have resisted the practice of sharing their revenue with each other, but they will soon embark on a plan to share a major part of their expenses.

title: Content, Not Costumes, Is What Counts
description: Hooray for Mr. Wolfsohn (Why Can't Grown-ups Act Their Age, Aug. 6)! In just a few hundred words he managed to bridge the gap between parent and child and solve the problems of mid-life crisis by stripping the over-40 set of their T- and sweat shirts.

title: THE A.C.L.U.: IMPECCABLE JUDGMENTS OR TAINTED POLICIES?
description: THESE DAYS THEY ARE EVERYWHERE, IT seems. On network television and Cable News Network, the day after the Supreme Court's recent decision on abortion, attorneys with the American Civil Liberties Union were explaining their view of the ruling's implications for women, and especially poor women and women of color; at a press conference in Washington, announcing a lawsuit against Mayor Marion S. Barry, among others, for allegedly violating the rights of the District's 2,500 foster children by failing to provide adequate services; in Federal District Court in Michigan, defending a high school student who has been barred from carrying a beeper by school officials concerned about the mechanisms' increasing use as a tool of the drug trade; and in a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing room, opposing the use by civil plaintiffs of the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act against representatives of the pro-life organization Operation Rescue, who have been called racketeers by some pro-choice groups.

title: Elizabeth Knapp Is Married
description: Elizabeth Knapp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. P. Knapp of Bronxville, N.Y., and Nicholas Paul Hotchkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Hotchkin of Macclesfield, Cheshire, England, were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville. The Rev. Robert Sweeny officiated. Mrs. Hotchkin graduated cum laude from Harvard University. Her father, who retired as a managing director and a senior vice president at Chubb & Son in New York, is the executive director of the Excess Line Association of New York, an organization of licensed insurance brokers. The bridegroom, who graduated cum laude from Harvard, is a planner in the international service parts division at General Motors in Detroit. His father is an air-traffic controller in Manchester, England.

title: 2 in Ukrainian Party Seek Ouster of Leader
description: Two Ukrainian Communist Party leaders appeared before the founding meeting of a nationalist movement today to call for the removal of the republic's hard-line party chief.

title: A Lesson a Crybaby Carries Still
description: I SAW the children starting off for school the other day. It was the first day of the new school year. The older children were walking with each other, some hand in hand, arm and arm, skipping, running, jumping.

title: Art and Archeology Clash Over Ravine Near Cropsey Studio
description: IN the late 19th century Jasper Francis Cropsey painted the rural scenes outside his yellow Victorian cottage in Hastings-on-Hudson, and art historians tell us he was hurrying to capture a part of history that the Industrial Revolution was sweeping away.

title: Heredity Plays a Leading Role
description: IF your father was the winner of a singing contest in which ario Lanza was a loser, and your grandfather on your mother's side played the trumpet for Sarah Bernhardt, wouldn't that give you a head start in show business?

title: 1,500-Girl School
description: The way Rabbi Samuel Fogelman tells it, since 1942 his girls' school in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn ''has been wandering from one dilapidated building to another.'' But now the foundations are being dug for what the rabbi says ''will be the largest religious girls' school in the world,'' capable of holding 1,500 students aged, as he puts it, 3 to 71.

title: 'THE LITTLE FRIEND CALLED THE ARCHITECT'
description: WALLACE K. HARRISON, ARCHITECT By Victoria Newhouse. Illustrated. 332 pp. New York: Rizzoli. Cloth, $45. Paper, $29.95.

title: Hurricane Stalls at Sea, Sending Swells at Coast
description: Hurricane Gabrielle stalled in the Atlantic today, sending heavy swells along the Northeast coast but remaining far from land.

title: WORSHIPING AT THE SHRINE OF A SCOUNDREL
description: MEXICO DAYS By Robert Roper. 261 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Neighbors Sue Over Condos
description: THE Pettinaro Company, is moving ahead with its $20 million urban housing project here despite objections from neighbors. The company has completed construction of the first phase of 475 condominiums on the border of the Browntown and Hedgeville neighborhoods, west of the city's central business district.

title: It May Be Art, but Cuomo's Aides Don't Like It
description: The painting shows Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as a puppeteer, pulling the strings to decide where nuclear waste will be dumped.

title: Shagging's a Carolina Duty and Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Dies in Plant Collapse
description: The mezzanine platform of a fruit packing warehouse here collapsed Friday, killing a woman and injuring seven other people. The woman, Sharon Raschke, died as she was sorting fruit at the Hansen Fruit Company warehouse, the police said. Barb Dunn, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Labor and Industries, said the Hansen warehouse had been inspected by the state in June and no violations were found.

title: Carbide's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: My Life With Crack
description: LEAD: Crack has improved my life.

title: Penn State Upset by Virginia
description: Shawn Moore threw two first-half touchdown passes to Herman Moore today as Virginia upset Penn State, 14-6, sending the Nittany Lions to their sixth loss in seven games including last season.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FRIENDS OF PROMISE: Cyril Connolly and the World of Horizon. By Michael Shelden. (Harper & Row, $24.95.) Cyril Connolly is probably best known today for such witticisms as ''Whom the gods would destroy they first call promising'' and ''Imprisoned in every fat man a thin one is wildly signaling to be let out.

title: False Economy: Cutting School Costs
description: I read with great interest your article on the changing Long Island economy [ ''L.I. Growth Years Over, Looking Beyond Defense,'' Aug. 13 ] . All of us who have made our lives and careers here have much at stake. A significant increase in unemployment and the subsequent impact on property values would certainly affect us all. I was concerned, however, about the comments made by Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.

title: About Cars; A U.S. Partnership Is in Saab's Future
description: By all accounts, Saab is in a bit of trouble.

title: CHAOS, EXCITMENT AND RAW EMOTION
description: GLASNOST' IN ACTION Cultural Renaissance in Russia. By Alec Nove. 251 pp. Boston: Unwin Hyman. Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $13.95.

title: 1,400 Hairstons Honor Kinship Born of Slavery
description: The Hairstons held their annual family reunion here this weekend, not far from two of the plantations where their forebears toiled as slaves or ruled as masters.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NEW MILFORD;
Town Studies Its Contrasts To Find Out Where It's Going
description: LEAD: NEW MILFORD is a place of superlatives. With 64 square miles, it has the largest land mass of any municipality in Connecticut, and the town green, which spans several blocks, is considered the longest in the state. Yet for all its magnitude, there are some in this southern Litchfield County town who believe that New Milford remains a community still defining its boundaries.

title: Devils Take the Ice Fit and With Focus
description: With seven players of proven quality acquired during the off season, the guaranteed jobs so apparent at the Devils' training camp last year no longer exist.

title: Where the Sun Shines, There He Is
description: George Hamilton was not in ''The Sun Also Rises.'' He wasn't even in ''Duel in the Sun.'' He most certainly was not in ''Hideous Sun Demon.'' He is, however, in the sun whenever possible.

title: Commercial Property: Specialty Buildings; Putting Up a Shield Against the Market's Vagaries
description: IN an effort to break from the pack in Manhattan's sluggish office market, building owners are creating specialty centers for jewelry dealers, children's wear companies, missions to the United Nations, textile manufacturers and a host of other tenants.

title: Confronting Sprawl, The Big Issue of the 90's
description: AS employment centers continue an inexorable expansion into suburban areas and beyond, they are posing one of the great challenges to residential development in the 90's - how to manage growth patterns so that suburbia won't choke on itself.

title: Being Taxed Out of One's Town
description: Re: ''West Milford Journal: Angered by Tax Increases, Residents Seek an Investigation'' (Aug. 13):

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TOTAL IMMERSION. By Allegra Goodman. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) While the elements of Allegra Goodman's short stories are often intriguing - Orthodox Jews who live in Hawaii, Yemeni cabdrivers who are really poets, experts in international terrorism who attend summer programs at Oxford - the sum of these parts consistently fails to add up to a successful whole.

title: More Prisoners Serving Time Outside Jail
description: A STATE program that allows people convicted of nonviolent crimes to serve the bulk of their sentences outside prison has prompted three counties to create similar programs and three other counties to consider establishing them.

title: Ms. Gibbs Wed To C. P. Barton
description: The wedding of Jenny MacKinnon Gibbs and Christopher Paul Barton took place in New York yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations. Deacon Jack Haney performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Elizabeth B. Evans Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Elizabeth B. Evans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Evans 3d of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and James P. Haynie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Haynie of Des Moines, took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated.

title: A Broker Is Wed To Cynthia Scully
description: Cynthia Crowell Scully, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Scully of Rye, N.Y., and Todd Hodges Doolan, the son of Mrs. James A. Gobes of West Hartford, Conn., and Dwight M. Doolan of New York, were married yesterday in Rye.

title: Fire Kills Two on Resort Island in Michigan
description: A fire destroyed two buildings early today on this popular resort island in northern Lake Huron, killing two people, the authorities said.

title: What Rose Did
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Americana, Not Monet, at Auction
description: At the Saugerties Auction Center in Ulster County in upstate New York, the word ''sale'' hardly describes what happens approximately every other Sunday when well-worn but cared-for artifacts - antiques and collectibles - are put up for auction. It's choreography, perhaps, or rap music, but not simply commerce.

title: STAMPS
description: Collectors who wish to follow the Voyager 2 spacecraft beyond Neptune and out of our solar system will find a philatelic galaxy prepared for them by the astronomy study unit of the American Topical Association.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: If it's true that not only Anthony Walton, but also all his black Ivy League friends, are waiting to ''slay the white dragon,'' then this country's future is even bleaker than I previously had feared. His was one of the most chilling essays I've read, anywhere. ROBERT DAVIDSON New York, N.Y.

title: Death in Tiananmen
description: That month in Beijing six years ago was exhausting but exhilarating, too. As the first foreign theatrical director in the People's Republic of China, I was directing ''Death of a Salesman'' with Chinese actors in Beijing's People's Art Theater, the equivalent of the Moscow Art Theater. There was a lot of skepticism surrounding the project, with many Chinese and foreigners doubting that the Chinese audience would understand the very American play.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A 200-year-old token issued by an Albany, N.Y. church has been discovered in the estate of a Vermont man who collected odd coins he found at his Laundromat. Resting in the hodgepodge of Indian Head cents and foreign coins, the Albany church token is one of only five known examples and will be auctioned in New York City this week by Bowers & Merena Inc.

title: IDOLATRY IN MIAMI
description: THE SHAWL By Cynthia Ozick. 70 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Notes From Between The Sheets?
description: The speculation in this space recently about Schubert's underground sexual life, as explored in documentary detail by the musicologist Maynard Solomon, brought two typical, if opposed, reactions from readers.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Fall Fashion Follies
description: LEAD: IT'S September and, by now, most of us are wearing the hot new fall styles, which look absolutely stunning on Cher and three female basketball players from Detroit.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The fiberglass insulation on my attic floor has a foil vapor barrier on the bottom. There is no insulation over the soffits or eaves, but these soffits are warping because of moisture. The eaves are three feet wide all around the house and there are just two louvered vents, one on each side of the house. I also installed one louver near the roof peak. Is there anything I can do to prevent the warping of the soffits?

title: UPWARD BOUND
description: SOMETIMES TALENT SEEMS TO BE THE LEAST of it. For a young designer or team of them to stay the course today, a strong sense of style, determination - even luck - are fine, but it takes much more. Such is the state of the marketplace that practical things - hefty financing, good management and steady store support - are usually the elements that spell lasting success. It is, however, heartening to see a number of new labels popping up in the stores, as well as many of those launched in the last few years, that are managing to hang in.

title: Party Season Need Not Be So Humdrum
description: FALL'S arrival heralds more than the return to school or the end of casual summer days. It also signals the start of the school-year season for children's birthday parties. For those parents who prefer not to play host to a child's friends and classmates at home, there are a number of places around the county that will act as substitutes.

title: Question Of the Week; What Is Giamatti's Legacy to Baseball?
description: The fan-turned-commissioner legacy is au naturel integrity. Allow the grounds-keeper to tend dirt and grass. Make the pitcher take his cut with a wooden bat. Schedule a few more games in daylight. Preserve the traditions and save an endangered species: the baseball fan. NEIL HANLON Cos Cob, Conn.

title:
Focus: Belmont, N.C.;
Old Mill Town Revived, With a New Twist
description: LEAD: RUSSELL AND DEBORAH WRIGHT, both workers at R. L. Stowe Mills in this textile town just south of Charlotte, live in a frame house built about 70 years ago by a man who made his fortune in spinning mills.

title: Jets Look Beyond Summer Woes
description: Don't judge the Jets until after the summer. For it could take until early October before their season takes shape.

title: THE RING CYCLE
description: The engagement ring I received from my husband almost 14 years ago was bigger than some and smaller than other rings my friends received from their fiances. But to me, it was and still is the most beautiful of all, because it was purchased by him, for me, as a surprise. He took the time and effort pick it out, and he paid for it himself, not a mean feat for a fourth-year medical student. The ring was not paid for by his family or bought with money borrowed by mortgaging his car. It represented a mature assessment of what he could afford then and reflects values that have stood up well to the test of time. DEBRA R. ROSENBAUM Summit, N.J.

title: Air Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Glasses Are in Demand, Even by 20/20 Children
description: It's time for school eye exams. And these days, eye-wear sellers report, glasses are more a status symbol than a stigma.

title: Q and A
description: Japanese Gardens

title: From Caesar To MacArthur, On the Hudson
description: IT would be a hard heart indeed that did not beat a little faster at the sight of the Army's Corps of Cadets, 4,361 strong, in their dress uniforms, marching in precision on the plain at the core of the United States Military Academy at West Point. It is a site that reverberates in American history. In 1778, during the Revolutionary War, Col. Thaddeus Kosciuszko supervised construction of fortifications on the strategic bluff overlooking the Hudson River. A year later Baron Frederick von Steuben began to train infantrymen of the Continental Army there. Shortly after, its commander, Gen. Benedict Arnold, the hero of the battles of Quebec and Saratoga, turned traitor and tried to betray West Point to the British.

title: Chrissy and Jimmy
description: They were teen-age sweethearts, with two-fisted backhands, who pretty much defined the game of tennis for two decades. And now, as this year's U.S. Open draws to a close, one has left center court for good and the other may soon be gone.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LOVE, PAIN, AND THE WHOLE DAMN THING. By Doris Dorrie. Translated by John E. Woods. (Knopf, $16.95.) For those whose real emotions brew dangerously below the surface of a banal life, Doris Dorrie's stories may read like a manual for deliverance. Most famous for her film ''Men . . .,'' the German writer and director shows a sharp talent for constructing the kind of lean, puzzle-like dilemmas that are the germs of good tales.

title: Ms. Oser Weds David A. Miller
description: Andrea Oser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Oser of St. George, S.I., was married yesterday to David Alan Miller, a son of Rachel Galperin and Gerald L. Miller, both of Los Angeles. The bridegroom's father, the cantor of Temple Judea in Tarzana, Calif., and a cousin of the bride, Judge Norma Shapiro of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, jointly performed the ceremony at the historical James House in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Wagner's Passing Paces 28-13 Victory
description: Ray Benvenuti, a sophomore making his debut as the starting quarterback for Wagner College, combined with Abe Higgins for three touchdown passes as the Seahawks defeated Delaware Valley, 28-13, yesterday afternoon in the season's opener for both teams at Grymes Hill on Staten Island.

title: Radium Cleanup in Queens Nears End
description: Late on the night of Aug. 28, a flatbed truck pulled away from a fenced-off cinderblock building in Woodside, Queens, and headed west, bound for the Nevada desert.

title: While History Is Conflict, the End Is Not Yet; Chaos Advances
description: To the Editor:

title: HIS IRISH IS UP
description: HARP By John Gregory Dunne. 235 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: For Blue Cross, a Cradle-to-Grave Development
description: ONE of this state's largest and most comprehensive residential communities - a $150 million project with 1,675 rental and condominum units proposed by Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Connecticut that is designed to accommodate every stage of life from the cradle to the grave - is now moving through approval stages in the Town of Hamden.

title: Fine-Tuning 'The Piano Lesson'
description: AUGUST WILSON AND LLOYD RICH-ards have been collaborating as playwright and director since 1982, when Mr. Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' was given a staged reading at the National Playwrights Conference at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. Mr. Richards, who is artistic director of the O'Neill conference as well as dean of the Yale School of Drama, subsequently staged the play at the Yale Repertory Theater and on Broadway. Mr. Wilson's next two plays, ''Fences'' (1987) and ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' (1988) followed even longer tryout routes, which included stops at several regional theaters. Each of Mr. Wilson's three plays won a New York Drama Critics Circle Award; ''Fences'' also won Tony Awards for best play and best director and the 1987 Pulitzer Prize for drama.

title: Old Newspapers Hit a Logjam
description: Hour after hour, around the clock, bundles of old newspapers rumble along a conveyor until they drop into a large vat at the Garden State Paper Company's recycling mill here along the Passaic River. In a few hours they will emerge as rolls of blank newsprint, ready to be used again.

title: Schools to Spend Millions to Comply With Asbestos Law
description: A RECENT Federal law requiring schools to protect students and school employees from asbestos has forced educators in the county to take a new look at the cancer-causing material that remains in many school buildings.

title: 13 Hurt in Dallas Gas Blast
description: Thirteen people were injured, two of them critically, by an explosion caused by a break or a leak in a natural-gas line in an apartment complex here Friday night.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Albuquerque
description: Situated a mile above sea level, Albuquerque is flanked on the east by the Sandia Mountains, which rise to 10,360 feet. To the west, open, arid mesas merge with a wide blue sky. The Rio Grande snakes through the city, its valley so thick with trees that it is called the Bosque, the Spanish word for forest.

title: Dawn C. Byrnes Married
description: Dawn Carol Byrnes and Kenneth Carey Clisham were married yesterday in the O'Bryne Chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., by the Rev. Michael O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest. Mrs. Clisham, the 25-year-old daughter of Carol Byrnes of Hampton Bays, L.I., and John F. Byrnes of East Hampton, L.I., is a bond analyst for the mortgage research department at Salomon Brothers in New York. Mr. Clisham, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Clisham of Naugatuck, Conn. He is a vice president in the bond trading division of Merrill Lynch Mortgage Capital in New York.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: A SELECTIVE GUIDE
description: September Deliberate Investigations. Four artists who use photographs as the basis for quasi-scientific installations - Dede Bazyk, David Bunn, Uta Barth and Connie Hatch - are each given a room in which their work can breathe. Sept. 7-Nov. 12, Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 5905 Wilshire Boulevard, 213 857-6111. Brian Lanker: I Dream a World, Portraits of Black Women Who Changed America. Mr. Lanker's photographs show the continuing power of straightforward, black-and-white portraiture. Sept 8.-Oct. 29, International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, 860-1777. On the Art of Fixing a Shadow: 150 Years of Photography. The closest thing to a definitive observance of the sesquicentennial of the medium opens in its second venue. Sept. 16-Nov. 26, Art Institute of Chicago, Michigan Avenue at Adams Street, 312 443-3600. (Last stop is the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Dec. 21-Feb.25, 213 857-6111.) The New Vision: Photography Between the World Wars. Some 125 classic and little-known photographs display the bracing optimism of full-blown Modernism. Alfred Stieglitz, Alexander Rodchenko, Walker Evans, Man Ray and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy are featured in the museum's first showing of its Ford Motor Company Collection. Sept. 22-Dec. 31, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, 879-5500. Experimental Photography: The Machine Age. Images from between the world wars from the Getty Museum's collection make this a West Coast version of the Metropolitan's ''New Vision'' (above). Sept. 26-Dec. 10, J. Paul Getty Museum, Malibu, Calif., 213 458-2003. October Berenice Abbott: A Modern Vision. Portraits of Paris literati, images of New York City buildings and scientific photographs are all part of this 140-print retrospective spanning five decades of work by the 90-year-old photographer. Oct. 7-Dec. 30, New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, 869-8089. Jean Cocteau: The Mirror and the Mask. A medley of portraits of the French Surrealist includes studies by Richard Avedon, Man Ray, Cecil Beaton and, yes, Berenice Abbott. Oct. 12-Dec. 2, Lieberman & Saul Gallery, 155 Spring Street, at West Broadway, 431-0747. Helen Levitt: Works in Color. A choice survey of color images taken on the streets of New York over the last 20 years - long before color pictures were considered ''serious'' photography. Oct. 25-Dec. 2, Laurence Miller Gallery, 138 Spring Street, 226-1220. November Magnum Founders: Robert Capa, Henri Cartier-Bresson, David (Chim) Seymour and George Rodger, 1931-1988. This is a companion show to the Magnum survey (below), sticking to the original big guns. Nov. 3-Jan. 7, International Center of Photography, 860-1777. In Our Time: The World As Seen by Magnum Photographers. A survey, long in coming, of photojournalism's finest hours, featuring work by Henri Cartier-Bresson, Bruce Davidson, Marc Riboud and dozens of others - more than 300 prints in all. Nov. 10-Feb. 4, I.C.P. Midtown (the new annex of the International Center of Photography), 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street, 768-4688. Image World: Art and Media Culture. An exhibition of more than 100 works, all showing the impact of photographic imagery, that represents the Whitney Museum's jump into photographic waters. Co-curators Lisa Phillips, Marvin Heiferman and John Hanhardt have selected paintings, sculptures, films, videotapes - even photographs. Nov. 9-Feb. 18, Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, 570-3600. Laurie Simmons. The artist who made toy figures into eloquent images of childhood experience turns her attention to ventriloquists' dummies, with psychologically eerie results. Nov. 18-Dec. 23, Metro Pictures, 150 Greene Street, 925-8335. December Ellen Garvens-Holly Roberts. Two quirky and imaginative artists who can't seem to leave photographs alone exhibit their sculptural (Ms. Garvens) and painterly (Ms. Roberts) work. Dec. 7-Jan. 6, Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery, 568 Broadway, 226-2251. Bernd and Hilla Becher. This German couple's fascination with industrial structures has led to grids of photographs that speak of uniformity and variation. The power of their pictures is as remarkable as their obsession. Opens Dec. 14 and continues for a year, Dia Art Foundation, 548 West 22d Street, 431-9232. Experimental Photography: The New Subjectivity. The Getty Museum surveys the postwar era, from the 1940's to the 60's, in the last installment of its five-part series in honor of photography's 150th anniversary. Dec. 19-March 4, J. Paul Getty Museum, 213 458-2003. Early 1990 Forced Out. A group exhibition, assembled by Carole Kismaric and Edward Leffingwell, documents the plight of political refugees. From the book of the same name. Jan. 14-March 11, P.S. 1 Museum, 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City, 718 784-2084. Photography Until Now. MOMA's retelling of photography history since Beaumont Newhall's landmark show (1937), and possibly the director of photography John Szarkowski's last comprehensive consideration of the medium's claims as an art form. Some 250 images are used to demonstrate how craft and form have interacted. Feb.18-May 29, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, 708-9480. Josef Sudek: A Life's Work. The master of Czechoslovak photography turned whatever his lens touched into poetic gold. Some 180 prints reveal the depth of his achievement. March 3-May 6, Philadelphia Museum of Art, Parkway at 26th Street, 215 763-8100. Irving Penn: Master Images. A 120-print retrospective selected from an archive the well-known fashion photographer donated to the Smithsonian in 1988. March 30-Aug. 19, National Museum of American Art, Eighth and G Streets, N.W., Washington, 202 357-2700.

title: Spare the Rod And Spoil Nothing
description: As a very young child I enjoyed fishing, as does Rosanne Kalick (''Another World at End of the Fishing Line,'' Opinion Page, Aug. 20), seduced by the slow ripples of water radiating from my legs and the flashing, rainbow-colored fish. But when I grew old enough to realize that it was wrong (and certainly no pleasure) to inflict unnecessary suffering on another, luring a fish to embed itself on my hook and pulling it from the water it needs to breathe became not magical but sickening.

title: Dinkins Offers a Better New York Than Koch Has Given Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Aoun of Lebanon: Is He a National Savior or, as Foes Say, a 'Mad General'?
description: Nearly a year after Gen. Michel Aoun was selected to be what he says is Prime Minister of all Lebanon, he has cut such a controversial image that many people in his country and abroad are still trying to decide whether he is the savior he casts himself as or simply an ambitious adventurer.

title: How Public Financing Has Changed New York City's Way of Campaigning
description: NEW YORK CITY's new campaign finance law, the second-largest public financing program in the country after the one for Presidential elections, is ending its first test with Tuesday's primaries. The verdict of candidates and other politicians is that it has drastically changed the face of city politics.

title: On the Ubiquity Of Gambling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IT'S NOT OVER TILL ITS OVER, AND IT'S NOT OVER
description: A CRITICAL DICTIONARY OF THE FRENCH REVOLUTION Edited by Francois Furet and Mona Ozouf. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Illustrated. 1,064 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press.

title: Echoing Past Glories
description: It might seem odd to call Town Hall (123 West 43d Street, 840-2824) new; it's been a midtown Manhattan fixture since 1921, and from the 1920's through the 1950's was one of the city's premiere forums for classical music. With the advent of Lincoln Center in the 1960's and the increasing clutter of Times Square, however, it fell into the doldrums. There are signs now that it is rousing itself from that lethargy. The place could still be better maintained, and more money would permit more self-produced concerts, instead of an endless round of rentals. But this remains about the best midsized concert hall in town, with wonderful sight lines and honest acoustics. And this season's programming ventures - which include the pianist Ursula Oppens (Nov. 20), the ensemble Vocalworks (Dec. 11) and the Manhattan String Quartet's series (starting Sept. 25) presenting the complete string quartets of Shostakovich - look promising.

title: Graf Struggles Early, but Captures Open
description: All year long, Steffi Graf had been in a struggle with herself to prevent 1989 from becoming anticlimactic to 1988, the season she attained a Golden Grand Slam of tennis by capturing all four Grand Slam titles and, in something of a command performance for her native West Germany, an Olympic gold medal.

title: Anita Shreve's Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Directors Reshape Classics From the 20's; 'Grand Hotel'
description: THE ROOMS AT THE HOTEL DIPLOMAT ON West 43d Street in Manhattan go for $45 a night. In the lobby, the paint is peeling from the walls and ceiling. There are holes in the sofas, the cashiers and the clerks are imprisoned behind glass and a sign informs new guests that the maximum stay is 28 days.

title: Correction
description: A review in the Arts and Leisure section last week of Brahms recordings by Stanislaw Skrowaczewski and the Halle Orchestra omitted information about the company releasing them in the United States. The recordings are available in this country through MCA Classics; the release numbers are MCAD 25188 (Symphony No. 1, ''Academic Festival Overture''; all three formats), 25160 (Symphony No. 2, ''Tragic Overture''; all three formats), 25857 (Symphony No. 3, ''Haydn Variations''; CD, cassette) and 25230 (Symphony No. 4, three Hungarian Dances; CD, cassette).

title: On Broadway and Off, what promises to be the liveliest season in years
description: DUSTIN HOFFMAN AS Shylock, Sting as Mack the Knife, Vanessa Redgrave in a play by Tennessee Williams, Maggie Smith in ''Lettice & Lovage,'' a musical (''Grand Hotel'') directed by Tommy Tune and Jerry Zaks's Lincoln Center revival of ''Guys and Dolls'' - this promises to be the liveliest season in years. Add to these shows the Steppenwolf Theater production of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and new plays by August Wilson, Athol Fugard, David Hare, Tom Stoppard, Steve Tesich, Israel Horovitz and Harold Pinter and the anticipation heightens.

title: Sports of The Times; Now the Mets Wait for Doctor K to Pitch Again
description: Instead of getting the job done, the Mets seem to be standing around like poor little rich boys waiting for their three rich uncles in Chicago, St. Louis and Montreal to die so they could claim what they consider to be their rightful inheritance, first place in the National League East. And now they're waiting again, this time for Dwight Gooden to pitch again.

title: Balancing Push-Ups With Pushing Bills
description: LEAD: IN a cafeteria in the Legislative Office Building just west of the Capitol in Hartford, a Temptations tape thumped its way through ''Ain't Too Proud to Beg.'' On the speckled gray carpet, 14 state employees stretched, writhed and kicked. The 12 women and two men are among 35 state workers who take an aerobics class in the state-owned building after work.

title: ALGERIA PRESIDENT DISMISSES PREMIER
description: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria dismissed his Prime Minister tonight over the slow pace of political and economic change, but the official, Kasdi Merbah, refused to leave his post.

title: Fortune's Smile Glimmers on Herald Sq.
description: FROM the windows of J.J. Hat Center, his hat store just south of Herald Square, Jack Lambert has spent 15 years watching one of the nation's busiest shopping districts move from one crisis to the next. ''Things have gotten worse and worse,'' he said. There was the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the flight of middle-class shoppers from the city to suburban homes and shopping malls, and a spate of department store closings in the neighborhood. Although Macy's survived and has prospered as the Herald Square landmark, Ohrbach's, Korvettes and Gimbels had closed by 1984.

title: Antwerp's Sculpture Garden
description: NEXT to an 11-foot-high hedge, Rodin's ''Balzac'' stands, hunched in his bulky mantle, vertically striped with green tarnish. From the shrubbery, Balzac glares at a sprawled and tumbling Maillol nude (called ''The River'') who seems to be reaching toward another Maillol who is seated, head tilted down, in absent-minded reverie. In an adjacent copse, perhaps the ''King and Queen,'' by Henry Moore, bother very little about their sovereignty, since they are installed on 30 acres with more than 300 other statues at Middelheim Open-Air Museum of Sculpture in Antwerp, Belgium.

title: FLOOR WARS
description: I have been retained by my 4 1/2-year-old-son, Wilson, to defend his favorite toys (''Floor Wars,'' Aug. 13).

title: Around Gorbachev, Centrifugal Forces
description: AN analyst diagnosing the collective emotional health of the Soviet Union in these days of ethnic discord and economic distress need look no farther than a television set, where the political commentators are being reinforced by hypnotists and faith healers.

title: Polish Church Leader Cancels Visit to U.S.
description: The Polish press agency announced that Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Archbishop of Warsaw, has canceled a tour of American cities that was to begin on Sept. 22. The Cardinal, who has angered Jews with his statements on the convent at the Auschwitz death camp, reportedly canceled the tour ''due to circumstances unfavorable for pastoral purposes.'' Article, page 18.

title:
IN THE NATION: LOS ANGELEs;
19 Families Join in 'House-Raisings' In the Gritty Wilmington District
description: LEAD: TAKING a cue from the community barn raisings of the Amish and other farmers, 19 families in the Wilimington neighborhood of Los Angeles, a 10-square-mile industrial district just north of Long Beach, have pooled their money to build their houses. Most of the families, three of whom are building for investment alone, are also participating in the construction now under way on their

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; A Building Boom Near New Haven's Green
description: THE construction crane, a bird with a ubiquitous presence in Stamford and Hartford, seems to be migrating into New Haven, judging from the half-dozen long steel necks hovering downtown.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Town Houses for Former Hospital Grounds
description: LEAD: A 600-UNIT town house project on a 60-acre site that was once part of the Central Islip State Hospital grounds is the first new development to get under way under a master plan for 800 acres of former hospital property. The first families are expected to start moving into the development, called Park

title: Midge Alter Marries Mark Caparosa
description: Marjorie Beth Alter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Alter of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and West Tisbury, Mass., was married yesterday to Mark Alan Caparosa, a son of Dr. Ralph J. Caparosa of Mount Lebanon, Pa., and Patricia E. Caparosa of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Edward Schecter performed the ceremony in the Tower Suite of the Time & Life Building in New York.

title:
DINING OUT;
Lusty Italian Portions Offered in Yonkers
description: LEAD: IT is always a treat to return to an old favorite, and our recent visits to Valentino's found the restaurant as wonderful as ever, if not better. Great food in lusty portions, enthusiastic clientele, warm welcome from the jolly owner Valentino Roina, caring and helpful service from a professional staff - all continue to contribute to the joyous, familial, guiltless, pleasure-loving atmosphere that remains

title:
GARDENING;
Dahlias Provide a Bright End to the Season
description: LEAD: OF all fall flowers, dahlias are exceeded only by chrysanthemums in popularity. At a time when most annuals have faded or gone to seed, dahlias will have just reached the zenith of their display.

title: Alexandra Danilova: She Continues To Be Champagne
description: Alexandra Danilova is an indisputable legend in a time when legends in ballet are few. Recently named to receive a Kennedy Center Honor this winter, she soon will be presented with the Handel Medallion from the City of New York. In a career in dance that has spanned more than seven decades, from her days as a student at the fabled Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg (now the Kirov in Leningrad) to her teaching at the School of American Ballet in Manhattan, Madame Danilova, as she is referred to by many, has become an exotic institution in American dance and a link between very different eras.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Atlantic Trains Join France's T.G.V. System

title: Coe Loses in His Last (Maybe) Race
description: One champion arrived and another departed today at the World Cup track and field meet, where Ana Quirot of Cuba reached the previously unattainable and Sebastian Coe of Britain succumbed to the inevitable.

title: Under the Rainbow, Above Times Square
description: When it opened last January on the 65th floor of the RCA Building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, Rainbow & Stars (632-5100), adjacent to the Rainbow Room, became the crown jewel of New York City's cabarets. An intimate supper club that seats around 100 at tables arranged in a semicircle facing windows that overlook Central Park, Rainbow & Stars exudes a pleasing mixture of grandeur and comfort, and its food is the best (and the most expensive) to be found in any New York cabaret. Booked for the fall and early winter are Steven Davis (Sept. 19-Oct. 7), Jerry Herman (Oct. 10-28), Lisa Kirk (Oct. 31-Nov. 18), Debbie Shapiro (Nov. 21-Dec. 9) and Lorna Luft (Dec. 12-30).

title: Belgium's Medieval Treasure
description: BRUGES is a city for those infatuated by the lost past, because it is not lost there. Brussels, Belgium's hustling capital, the seat of NATO and of the E.E.C.'s bureaucrats, is the gateway to Europe, as its airport proclaims. But some 30 miles to the northwest lies a small city that was, centuries ago, an artistic and commercial hub of the whole European continent. The Bruges Bourse controlled the rates of exchange thoughout Europe.

title: Ducks and Stamps in Museum Show
description: LEAD: WATERFOWL, from Muscovy ducks to Canada geese, roam the grounds of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, making an apt introduction to the current exhibition. ''The Duck Stamp Program,'' on view through Oct. 8, brings home the theme of conservation, focusing on the Federal duck-stamp program.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Dream a Little Dream 1989. Vestron Home Video. $89.98. Laser disk, $39.95. Closed captioned. 1 hour 44 minutes. PG-13. Sprinting through back yards, Bobby (Corey Feldman) and Lainie (Meredith Salenger) collide with each other and while out cold on the ground somehow assume the spirit and persona of two neighbors, one a mystically inclined older fellow played by Jason Robards and the other his wife, portrayed by Piper Laurie. Not illogically, a romance is kindled between the pair. ''Beneath the folderol about dreams and incarnations is a routine high-school flick, with good guys, bad boys and sexy girls. . . . There's a moral, too, but don't worry about it.'' (Walter Goodman) Chances Are 1989. RCA/Columbia Home Video. $89.95. 1:48. LD. $39.95. CC. PG. Louie (Christopher McDonald), the husband of Corrine (Cybill Shepherd), gets hit by a car and goes to heaven only to return as a Yale student named Alex (Robert Downey Jr.). Corrine spends the next 23 years pining for Louie, whose best friend, Philip (Ryan O'Neal) spends the same 23 years mooning over Corrine, while Miranda, Corrine and Louie's daughter (Mary Stuart Masterson), grows up and goes to Yale, where she falls in love with Alex. ''Romantic comedies, of which this is nominally one, are better off making their characters appear glamorous and attractive than making them look like ineffectual, long-suffering nincompoops, which is the case here.'' (Janet Maslin) Cousins 1989. Paramount. No suggested retail price. 1:40. CC. PG-13. Larry Kozinski (Ted Danson) and Maria Hardy (Isabella Rossellini), who are married to Tish (Sean Young) and Tom (William Petersen), respectively, meet at the marriage of Larry's uncle to Maria's mother and find themselves unexpectedly drawn together. An American remake of Jean-Charles Tacchella's romantic comedy ''Cousin, Cousine,'' this version is a ''coarse, raucous, furiously misguided effort'' that is ''ponderous and dull.'' (Maslin) The Land Before Time 1988. MCA. $24.95. LD, $49.98. CC. 1:09. G. Five baby dinosaurs join forces to find the fabled Great Valley and encounter earthquakes, volcanoes and a tyrannosaurus en route. ''Where animated cuteness is concerned, these dinosaurs stand just this side of baby Dumbo, or perhaps Lady and the Tramp's first litter.'' (Maslin) The January Man 1989. CBS/Fox. $89.98. LD, $39.98. 1:37. CC. R. The rather incomprehensible plot of this comedy-melodrama involves a search for a serial killer by an ex-police detective turned fire fighter (Kevin Kline) and his ex-girlfriend (Susan Sarandon), who is married to the city's police commissioner (Harvey Keitel), the fireman's brother. ''Pat O'Connor, the director, has imposed no visible order on this minor chaos, nor has he been kind to Mr. Kline. He allows this very gifted comic actor to work so hard trying to be funny that one alternately sweats and cringes while watching him.'' (Vincent Canby) Under the Sun of Satan 1987. Connoisseur. $79.95. LD, $49.95. 1:38. French with English subtitles. No rating. Winner of the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival, this film from the French director Maurice Pialat ''grapples simply and powerfully with the unknown.'' A country priest, Donissan (Gerard Depardieu), who gravely doubts his own ability becomes the center of a struggle between good and evil. Mouchette (Sandrine Bonnaire) is the woman who shapes his fate when she commits a murder. ''Though it deals with theology and rises to a stunning test of faith, it has a thoroughly secular style'' - one of the many things that make the film fascinating. (Maslin) Greetings 1968. Vidmark. $79.95. 1:28. R. Robert De Niro plays one of three hippie pals from the late 60's in this early example of Brian De Palma's writing and direction, made some two decades before the director's recent ''Casualties of War.'' It's a modest comic-strip romp that takes satirical thrusts at everything from Lyndon Johnson and the draft to sex. ''Some of it is amusing, as when one of the lads is coached in the technique of draft-dodging,'' and much of it is strained. But there's no doubt that Mr. De Palma ''is determined and camera-minded.'' (Howard Thompson)

title: 300 Demonstrators Are Met With Silence in Bensonhurst
description: Nearly 300 chanting black demonstrators protesting the killing of a black youth staged two peaceful marches through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday, and were met with calm, even respectful silence, by residents in the embattled white neighborhood.

title: District Attorney Rivals Pick Up Pace
description: Like a pot of water left on a burner, the contest for the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn District Attorney has suddenly boiled over. The closing days of the primary campaign have seen not only an increase in the political tempo but also the emergence of a sharper, angrier tone as three candidates -Charles J. Hynes, Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman and Norman Rosen -vie for a nomination that is virtually tantamount to election in the heavily Democratic borough.

title: Days Are Numbered
description: As the prospective new owner of the British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League, Murray Pezim is convinced that the C.F.L.'s days are numbered. Pezim, who announced in Vancouver on Thursday that he had formed a company, Prime Sports Inc., to buy the financially strapped franchise, said on Friday that he believes the league will eventually be displaced by expansion of the National Football League into Canada.

title: Middle Eastern Dishes at Affordable Prices
description: WHEN Sesame Seed opened its doors in an 1890's frame building in Danbury 12 years ago, it captured attention with its Middle Eastern and vegetarian menu and affordable prices. But its casual spirit suggested a short life span. That pessimism was misplaced, for Sesame Seed has not only survived, it has also prospered.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: Perhaps Mr. Walton should have chosen, as an example, someone other than Willie Horton. Willie Horton raped a woman, which is the supreme oppression of another group of people who have been fighting right alongside of and as hard as black Americans to remove prejudice. SUSAN K. EVERSHED New York, N.Y.

title: On the Runway Pondering Security
description: ON Wednesday evening, May 17, the headlines came home to me: The plane we were sitting in at Kennedy Airport in New York City, ready to take off for Europe, was the object of an anonymous telephone threat.

title: The Phony War
description: A President who was serious in declaring a new war on drugs would do at least these things:

title: Details, Old or New, From Yesterday
description: FLUTED pilasters, carved rosettes, bolection molding and other 18th-century architectural details are the 20th-century specialties of a millwork shop in South Windsor.

title: CAMERA
description: I'm old enough to remember when Nikon replaced the original Nikon F camera with the Nikon F2. Pros screamed, yelled and vowed never to change their equipment. Needless to say, within a couple of years every photographer who could afford one was toting an F2.

title: A Year of Firsts and Foremosts
description: WHEN IT COMES TO THE FULFILL-ment of a season's promise, our major museums have a good record.

title: For Tiny Library Users, All Noise Is Forgiven
description: LEAD: SOME of the youngest library users in the county have yet to take their first step or say their first word. Babies as young as 6 months old may take part in special library programs, and the only question is who enjoys the programs more, the babies, their parents and baby sitters or the librarians?

title: Survey of Homeless: Mental Ills and Addiction
description: More than 80 percent of the homeless people contacted in a survey in Baltimore were mentally ill and most of them suffered from drug or alcohol abuse and many other ailments, the study shows.

title: NEW FACES
description: Constance Hauman

title:
INVESTING;
Reducing the Volatility of Your Portfolio
description: LEAD: For investors who sell stocks short, this has been a trying year. With the Dow Jones industrial average surging to a record high this summer and the Standard & Poor's 500 index rising 27 percent so far this year, short sellers, who make money when stock prices decline, have been struggling to break even.

title: Freshmen Choose Dormitory Floors By Subject Matter
description: Pick an area of interest - any one of eight interests - and there will be a dormitory floor to suit you at Tulane University this year, where seven floors in freshman dormitories across campus and an entire three-story dormitory, Paterson, group students by their subject of choice.

title: Why a Good Carpenter Seems So Hard to Find
description: ACCORDING to a neighbor of mine, the reason it's so difficult to find a decent carpenter these days is because it's nearly impossible to buy anything made of real wood anymore. Take the neighbor's new house, for example.

title: 25 YEARS LATER
description: SILVER WEDDING By Maeve Binchy. 306 pp. New York: Delacorte Press.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: Hopefully, essays such as Anthony Walton's, and films like Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' will make 1989 the year black and white Americans realize that the priorities of those represented by the civil rights movement of the 1960's have matured and changed quite dramatically.

title: A KILLING IN MAINE
description: LAST YEAR, OUTSIDE Bangor, Me., on a November afternoon that could not have been more beautiful, Karen Ann Wood was shot in her own backyard by Donald Rogerson, a deer hunter. The 37-year-old mother of twin baby girls died minutes later. The incident aroused a furor in a state where the traditions of the great outdoors are more and more at odds with the realities of suburban sprawl. It grew even more bitter when a Bangor grand jury refused to indict the hunter, a homegrown son of Maine, on manslaughter charges, fueling an ''us-versus-them'' quarrel between natives and newer arrivals from ''away,'' as the rest of the world is called. Karen Ann Wood was from away. Wood and her husband, Kevin, had come to the Bangor area with their infant twin girls in July 1988 from Davenport, Iowa, where he had been in graduate school. The Woods had both grown up in the small, upstate city of Binghamton, N.Y., met in high school and married a few years later. They had postponed having children until Kevin Wood was settled in his profession as a child psychologist. The move to Maine also represented the fulfillment of a long-postponed desire: to resettle in the East.

title: Question Of the Week; What Is Giamatti's Legacy to Baseball?
description: Dr. Giamatti was baseball's finest spiritual leader. In banning Pete Rose he affirmed baseball's highest moral ground. Yet he also offered Rose a chance to seek redemption.

title: Relief For Families of Disabled
description: PARENTS with retarded children, the spouses of people who have multiple sclerosis, adult children of parents with Alzheimer's disease and others who care for permanently disabled relatives often share a common struggle: the need for a break. Hundreds of people in such situations can now take breaks more often, because of a state program that partially pays for someone else to take over temporarily, or respite care.

title: Melissa Callan Marries
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, Melissa Andrea Callan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Callan of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Craig Michael Donaldson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Donaldson Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The interfaith ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel Matarazzo, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. James Corgee, a Lutheran minister. Mrs. Donaldson, 24 years old, is a vice president of White Brothers, the printing division of Christies' Fine Art Auctioneers in New York. She graduated from Wheaton College. Mr. Donaldson, also 24, is to join the New York investment and real-estate firm of Jones Lang Wootton USA this month. He is a graduate of Babson College.

title: Question Of the Week; What Is Giamatti's Legacy to Baseball?
description: In this age of free-agency million-dollar contracts, player strikes and cable TV negotiations, Giamatti sought to reaffirm the notion that baseball was supposed to be fun: clean, wholesome, but sacred fun. His passion for the game, its history, its integrity and its lore, broke through all of the peripheral nonsense that has inflicted itself upon professional sports in recent years, and served to remind us that this was, after all, a game, a friend, a companion to accompany us from childhood through our adult years, and to be passed on to our children. MARK LUTIN Port Washington, L.I.

title: BRIDGE
description: If one had to select, in bridge terms, the strongest geographical cluster of countries the obvious choice would be Scandinavia. In the 1987 European Championships, crowded with teams of world class, the Scandinavians placed first, third, equal fourth and sixth in a field of 23 teams.

title: Bicoastal Momentum
description: In both New York and Los Angeles this season, there's a whole lot of moving going on where art galleries are concerned, including a couple of expansions to bicoastal status. SoHo, the Manhattan art neighborhood where more is never too much, is acquiring another gallery building, a five-story, 65,000-square-foot former bakery at 130 Prince Street (at Wooster Street) that has been under renovation for over a year. The structure, unusual in the area for its 1930's industrial design and its open, column-free spaces, almost became the Edward R. Broida Museum a few years ago, before the California collector changed his mind and returned to the West Coast. During the fall season, it will become home to as many as 10 new or relocated galleries. On Oct. 7, L.A. Louver, a 13-year-old Los Angeles gallery, will inaugurate an East Coast branch there, called Louver Gallery, New York, with an exhibition of work by Edward and Nancy Kienholz. The Christine Burgin Gallery, formerly of Lafayette Street, will follow suit later in the month, with an exhibition of new works by Fariba Hajamadi. Luhring Augustine plans to relocate from East 57th Street, opening in late November with work by the West German artist Hubert Kiecol. Other galleries that have signed leases for space in the building include the Andrea Rosen Gallery and Petersburg Press. Tony Shafrazi, whose Mercer Street gallery helped legitimize Graffiti Art in the early 1980's, is planning to turn the building's top floor and penthouse into a 15,000-square-foot gallery that would be one of SoHo's largest.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Estes Leads B.C. Open: Bob Estes used five birdies on the frontside at the En-Joie Golf Club to overtake the frontrunner, Keith Clearwater, and claim the third-round lead yesterday at the $500,000 B.C. Open in Endicott, N.Y. Estes had a five-under-par 66 for a 54-hole total of 13-under-par 200 and a one-stroke lead over Dave Eichelberger.

title: Of Two Minds on the Baltics
description: What are Americans to make of the nationalist pressures bubbling up in Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and across the Soviet Union? So long as independence for ''captive nations'' was inconceivable, it was easy for Americans to espouse. Now that a new kind of government in Moscow is offering the Baltics economic, linguistic and even political autonomy, America's goal is much harder to determine.

title: Ms. McFadden Has a Wedding
description: Cynthia Graham McFadden, a television producer and journalist, and Michael John Davies, the editor, publisher and chief executive officer of The Hartford Courant, were married yesterday in Old Saybrook, Conn. The Rev. James Kidd, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's by-the-Sea.

title: SWX AND DEATH IN CENTRAL PARK
description: WASTED The Preppie Murder. By Linda Wolfe. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
