title: WAR: IT'S HARD TO GET IT RIGHT
description: LEAD: The first postulate of the theorem of war is death. The problem set by the theorem for a writer about World War II - in particular for a war correspondent, writing soon after an action on the basis of raw experience - was how to arrive at the ''truth'' about warfare.

title: An Old Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Prehistoric Metropolis in Illinois
description: MONKS MOUND is a hundred feet high and a thousand years old, a big pile of dirt standing improbably amid a morass of freeways in East St. Louis, Ill. It is the largest prehistoric structure north of Mexico, what you might call North America's first imposing piece of architecture. This flat-topped pyramid, constructed in phases between A.D. 900 and 1200, served as a platform for an imperial temple that faced a central plaza flanked by 20 or so other earthen structures. Monks Mound was the dominant edifice in a city that anthropologists call Cahokia.

title: Beth H. Shuster, Reporter, Is Wed To TV Executive
description: Beth Hope Shuster, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Shuster of Los Angeles, and Michael Healy, a son of Mrs. Edward G. Healy of Buffalo and the late Dr. Healy, were married yesterday in Los Angeles. Judge Andrew Weisz, retired presiding judge of the Municipal Court in Beverly Hills, Calif., officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Capital Punishment Is Popular, But So Are Its Alternatives
description: THE State of Virginia electrocuted Alton Waye 10 days ago for fatally beating, raping, biting and repeatedly stabbing Lavergne Marshall, an elderly widow. The Supreme Court had rejected a last-minute appeal. Opponents and proponents of the death penalty marched. And, it seemed, the American criminal justice system, virtually alone among Western democracies in sanctioning executions, was operating normally.

title: Jennifer Ogden Has a Wedding
description: Jennifer Anne Ogden and Peter Thomas Zidlicky, 1987 graduates of Brown University, were married yesterday at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Joseph W. Hughes officiated.

title: San Francisco Opera Debut Is Disrupted by AIDS Group
description: About 50 AIDS activists disrupted opening night of the San Francisco Opera on Friday, chanting, ''You have the power to stop AIDS now.''

title: Text of the 1987 Agreement On the Convent at Auschwitz
description: Roman Catholic officials, including Franciszek Cardinal Macharski of Cracow and three other European cardinals, met with Jewish representatives in Geneva in February 1987 to discuss Jewish objections to the presence of a Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp in Poland. Following is the text of a declaration adopted at the meeting, as translated from the French.

title: Tigers' Lusader Ties Mark of 3 Errors in Inning
description: Scott Lusader, the Detroit right fielder, tied a major league record by committing three errors in Chicago's seven-run first inning and the White Sox snapped the Tigers' seven-game winning streak today, 13-3.

title: THE VCR AS BABYSITTER
description: An Alternative To the Sandbox

title:
INVESTING;
Koger's Reliable Returns
description: LEAD: With interest rates dropping from their levels earlier in the year, money markets have lost some of their luster and investors are scrambling to find more attractive yields.

title: Where Addiction Is the Subject Matter
description: IT carries titles like ''Fat Is a Family Affair,'' ''Is It Love or Is It Addiction?'' and ''If Only I Could Quit.'' And in less than a year, the Meridian Shoppe in Stamford, a bookstore that specializes in literature on addiction and recovery, has already turned a profit, its organizers say.

title: While History Is Conflict, the End Is Not Yet; Only the Beginning
description: To the Editor:

title: Measles for '89 Already at 9-Year High in U.S.
description: More cases of measles have been reported in the United States this year than in any year since 1980, as a decline in the disease has abruptly ended.

title: Flight and Futility Are Rountine in the Horn of Africa
description: THE Horn of Africa, which includes the waters of the Nile and the fertile lands of southern Ethiopia, is rich in the basic requirements for agriculture. Without war, it could easily be self-sufficient in food. But the last two decades have proved a time of hunger and dislocation on an enormous scale throughout the region. In an attempt to resolve one cause of that misery - the civil war between Eritrean rebels and the Ethiopian Government - preliminary peace talks began in Atlanta last week under the auspices of former President Jimmy Carter.

title: A Play in the Garden
description: The Mettawee River Theater Company will present ''Barnacle Bill the Husband,'' a musical theater work with choreography by Wendy Overly, in the Garden of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, at 7:30 tonight. The work's score includes chanteys, 20th-century music-hall songs and original music by Jody Kruskal. The text, which is about an encounter between Barnacle Bill, a mermaid and the ghost of Henry Hudson, was written by Dick Zigun. Admission is free. Information: 929-4777.

title:
GARDENING;
Dahlias Provide a Bright End to the Season
description: LEAD: OF all fall flowers, dahlias are exceeded only by chrysanthemums in popularity. At a time when most annuals have faded or gone to seed, dahlias will have just reached the zenith of their display.

title: For Starters, a New Jacket
description: Next to a winter coat, the most important part of a woman's fall wardrobe is a jacket. It can also be a major investment, but a worthwhile one because of its versatility and its ability to update last year's clothes.

title: The Idea Was Beaumarchais's
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Time Puts On A Happy Face
description: TELEVISION PROGRAMMERS ALL HAVE a certain predilection for sociology. They try to take the pulse of the nation, looking for a key that will translate into habit-forming television viewing. This year, it's the family. Nuclear and non-nuclear, blended and extended, families of one sort or another are the focus of most of the major networks' new shows. Nobody argues that it's a breakthrough concept. But the network programming departments seem to feel the time for breakthrough concepts is over anyway.

title: Leslie Vought Married to C. B. Kuenne
description: Leslie Vought, a daughter of Mrs. William O. Harbach of New York and Fairfield, Conn., and Peter Vought of Santa Fe, N.M., and Christopher Brian Kuenne, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Robert E. Kuenne of Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joanne Munroe, an Episcopal minister, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Douglas Lind, a Presbyterian minister and a nephew of the bride's stepfather.

title: TOXIC SITE CLEANUP REPORTED LAGGING
description: Only 34 of the 1,175 worst toxic waste dumps in the United States were cleaned in the first eight years of a program intended to solve the problem, and polluters paid less than a tenth of the cost, the Rand Corporation said in a report made public Friday.

title: Question Of the Week; What Is Giamatti's Legacy to Baseball?
description: I think Giamatti's greatest legacy to baseball is his love of the game. Yes, he was a dedicated and judicious administrator. But most of all - first of all - he was a fan, a passionate fan. He reminded us that in baseball, as in life, the important distinction is not whether one knows ancient languages, but whether one brings passion to the day and duties at hand. Giamatti unforgettably did. BROOKE BEDRICK New York

title: Reagan Is 'Recovering Rapidly' After Surgery for Fluid on Brain
description: Former President Ronald Reagan was reported today to be making a ''rapid recovery'' one day after minor surgery to drain fluid that formed on his brain, a spokesman for Mr. Reagan said.

title: Golfers Who Play in the Morning Get in Line the Night Before
description: LEAD: EVERY Friday and Saturday night, A. Cory Walling drives his 28-foot motor home to the Flanders Valley Golf Course in Morris County. Dr. Walling, a 75-year-old retired physician, will read and then drift off to the restful sleep he says he requires to play golf early the next morning. When he awakens at the crack of dawn, he will find 75 to 80 cars also waiting with him.

title: Salvador's Right Takes the Steps Its Center Couldn't
description: IN recent years, the campaign song of El Salvador's Nationalist Republican Alliance has promised that the country ''will be the tomb where the Reds will meet their end.'' But last week, barely three months after coming to power, President Alfredo Cristiani and his right-wing party, called Arena, were singing a different tune. Saying that it favors ''a permanent cessation of hostilities'' in the country's decade long civil war, the new Salvadoran Government agreed to begin a ''preliminary dialogue'' with the country's leftist insurgents.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The fiberglass insulation on my attic floor has a foil vapor barrier on the bottom. There is no insulation over the soffits or eaves, but these soffits are warping because of moisture. The eaves are three feet wide all around the house and there are just two louvered vents, one on each side of the house. I also installed one louver near the roof peak. Is there anything I can do to prevent the warping of the soffits?

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, misstated his age. He is 46.

title: U.S. Seeking $3 Million More for Sandinistas' Foes
description: Bush Administration officials said today that they wanted at least $3 million donated to opposition candidates in Nicaragua through the National Endowment for Democracy, but some officers of the endowment contend that the contributions would be illegal.

title: Classics Thrive on Screen Tests
description: You've watched the video, now see the movie.

title: Five Sites Chosen as a Possible Waste Dump
description: Five sites - two in Cortland County and three in Allegany County - have been selected as possible locations for a low-level radioactive waste dump that New York State must open by 1993 under a Federal mandate, state officials said today.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: EX-LOVER. By Eleanor Bergstein. (Random House, $17.95.) The working title for this novel by the author of ''Advancing Paul Newman'' might have been ''I Nearly Lost It at the Movies.'' After the deaths of several relatives and friends, the playwright Jessie Gerard accepts a magazine assignment to observe the filming of a movie about the libidinous daughter of a Holocaust survivor.

title: S.I. Newhouse and Conde Nast; Taking Off The White Gloves
description: LAST MARCH, TINA BROWN, EDITOR OF VANITY FAIR, JETTED OFF TO LOS ANGELES with a band of her star writers to throw a party at the Museum of Contemporary Art. The excuse was the recently opened Man Ray exhibition, but for Hollywood the bash served as a kind of finale to Academy Awards week. It was a hot ticket, a swank event jammed with the local swells: stars like Kim Basinger, artists like David Hockney, power brokers like Jeff Berg, International Creative Management's chief, and Don Simpson, co-producer of ''Top Gun.''

title: Rock of Many Ages
description: AS THE 1980'S WANE, POPULAR MUSIC is torn between nostalgia and future shock. The past seems to hold memories of indelible music and a vast, unified audience; those memories spur everything from lucrative rock reunion tours to carefully researched jazz repertory concerts to new but revivalist jazz and rock. By contrast, the present and near future seem to promise innumerable unconnected categories and micro-categories, all spinning off in different directions, a fragmentation that informs patchwork postmodern styles from rap to avant-garde jazz.

title: Nancy Mairs's Quest
description: To the Editor:

title: Lights! Cameras! On Your Toes!
description: Dance videos have come a long way. One pioneer is Merce Cunningham, who has maintained an imaginative commitment to video over 12 years. His newest video, CHANGING STEPS (1989, Cunningham Dance Foundation, $69), is both beautiful and provocative. It is not a documentary of the 1973 dance. But Mr. Cunningham and Elliot Caplan, the company's video maker and a former painter, have created a version that is remarkably faithful in spirit to the original and to Mr. Cunningham's philosophy of dance.

title: Melodic Dissonance on the Lower East Side
description: Down a short set of stairs at 165 Ludlow Street, between East Houston and Stanton Streets, you find yourself in the dining room of the Ludlow Street Cafe (353-0536). Under a pressed tin ceiling, serving from an Ecuadorian, vaguely health-food menu, it's the sort of place where a person wouldn't be embarrassed to whip out a book and read. The bar is where people hang out, listening to country bands and jazz bands, mostly still-unknowns, with a sprinkling of more famous rock bands like Beat Rodeo and the Shams. The atmosphere is part relaxed Austin, Tex., part Lower East Side arriviste, with patrons trying to live, second-hand, stories about Manhattan Bohemia. Outside on Ludlow Street, cultures clash as Nissans blaring salsa - the real music of the community -drive by and the middle-class patrons of the cafe stand around awkwardly.

title: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions; An Italianate Co-op and a Second Empire Facade
description: This is another in a series of columns answering questions about New York's changing streetscapes. 148 West 16th St. Rowhouse Q. I have not been able to pinpoint the date of construction of my eight-unit tenant-sponsored co-op. Can you help me? . . . Pam Udis-Kessler, Manhattan. A. Your building was one of six high-stoop rowhouses built in 1858 at 114-154 West 16th Street by Nathaniel West, a coal merchant who lived on Henry Street. Only 144-148 now survive, but they share typical detailing of the Italianate style: rusticated brownstone basements, plain brick facades, projecting brownstone window lintels and bracketed cornices. The floral pattern in the cornice panel is an unusual detail and the iron balcony on 144 is an elegant touch - 146 and 148 originally had identical balconies.

title: CONFORTED BY SLAUGHTER AND BY PRAYER
description: STONEWALL JACKSON Portrait of a Soldier. By John Bowers. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Hiker Is Found 15 Days After Breaking Leg
description: A hiker who had broken his leg and was stranded for 15 days in Yosemite National Park was airlifted to safety on Friday.

title: Party Season Comes Home to Roost
description: The party circuit shifted last week from summer resorts to the city. On Tuesday the Asia Society celebrated at a preview of the Indian film ''Spices,'' which is the first in a monthlong series of films starring the late Smita Patil. Guests included Robert B. Oxnam, president of the society, Ismail Merchant, chairman of the Patil Film Festival, and Bianca Jagger. Ms. Jagger is the chairwoman of a dinner on Oct. 18 that will open a second festival of Asian films, which will be shown through Oct. 28 at the society, Park Avenue and 70th Street.

title: EXPOSING THE F.D.A.
description: Mylan Laboratories Inc., a Pittsburgh-based generic drug company, knew it was taking enormous risks when it hired private detectives in 1987 to snoop around the Food and Drug Administration, which it suspected had been stalling its applications to make new generic drugs.

title: The State I Love And Love to Hate
description: I FIRST came to this state as the 3-year-old captive of Italian and Irish parents, who foresaw a crumbling South Bronx. We moved into a white box house in a spanking new suburb where the most exotic creatures were Japanese beetles.

title: 'Narrow Margin' Finds Its Route
description: Gene Hackman sat hunched inside a white ski jacket to ward off the chill of a northern summer night and pondered the question of why he was making a movie that was set almost entirely on a train in the Canadian Rockies. ''Maybe because it's old-fashioned,'' he said.

title: U.S. Unease on Gorbachev: How Exposed Is He?
description: In the last few months, a feeling has spread through the upper reaches of the Bush Administration that the policies of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have an increasingly poor chance of success over the long term.

title: MEMIORS OF AN EX-BOMBSHELL
description: SHELLEY II The Middle of My Century. By Shelley Winters. Illustrated. 494 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Jefferson Gets Jump on Season
description: Although school doesn't open officially until tomorrow in New York City and the first full schedule of Public Schools Athletic League football games won't begin until next weekend, Thomas Jefferson of Brooklyn is getting a jump on the season today.

title: Arkansas Spa Pushes Quest For Retirees
description: Hot Springs has an army of people who love to boast about mineral springs, pure air and cheap living in the Ouachita Mountains.

title: Medicaid Rationing Will Cost More in the End; Rescind the Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Conducting Playoffs of Their Own
description: Time is the first opponent that looms for Roger Neilson, the new coach of the Rangers, in his attempt to learn about his players.

title: Exxon Must Finish Cleanup Or Pay, E.P.A. Director Says
description: Exxon will have to finish the cleanup of the Valdez tanker oil spill in Alaska next spring or pay the government to do the job, William P. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today.

title: Mayoral Primary Ending With a Call for Harmony
description: After months of 18-hour days spent making speeches, shaking hands and scratching for contributions, the candidates for mayor of New York marched through steaming heat yesterday into the final hours of the primary campaign.

title: 8 Said to Die in Mozambique
description: Rightist Mozambican rebels have killed at least eight civilians and set fire to hundreds of houses in a raid on a village in southern Mozambique, the Portuguese news agency Lusa said today. It quoted a local military informant as saying that the rebel group, the Mozambique National Resistance, had also destroyed a clinic and three stores in the attack on Muianga, in southern Gaza province, on Friday.

title: New Jersey Bridal For Wendy Miller
description: Wendy Lynn Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Miller of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday to Philip Rosenbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosenbach of Watchung, N.J. Rabbi Stanley Asekoff performed the cermony at the Chanticler Chateau, a restaurant in Warren, N.J.

title: Andrea Raisfeld Weds Photographer
description: Andrea Jane Raisfeld, a daughter of Marcine Hiltzik of Jericho, L.I., and the late Harold Hiltzik, and William Charles Abranowicz 3d, a son of Margret Lohli of Fords, N.J., and the late William Abranowicz 2d, were married yesterday in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Schachter, the bride's aunt and uncle.

title: Scope Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,933. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $237,352, or 15 cents a share, and $473,594, or 29 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Washington Talk; Reaction to China Reopens Old Battle
description: China has disappeared for the moment from the headlines and the newscasts, to be replaced by Poland and South Africa and Colombia, but the constriction of freedom in China continues, by all accounts, and so does the argument here about how the United States should respond.

title: Selection of Garcia Trial Jury to Begin
description: On the day he was indicted on bribery and extortion charges in November 1988, Representative Robert Garcia said the charges were preposterous. He pledged to ''fight this case with all of my God-given strength.''

description: b-Net income The bank said the loss was primarily the result of increased loan loss provisions and writedowns of $3.4 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Andrew Rosenthal Weds Shari Levine
description: Shari Levine, the daughter of Arline Levine of Long Branch, N.J., and Gerald B. Levine of Rumson, N.J., and Andrew Rosenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Rosenthal of Arlington, Va., were married yesterday at their home in Millbrook, N.Y. Cantor Kerry Ben-David officiated.

title: Sports Psychology Becoming the Locker Room's Latest Rage
description: SPORTS psychology is the current pop approach to improved sports performance, the talk of top athletes' locker rooms. Coaches, athletes and sports psychologists are convinced that the difference between winning and losing for top-level athletes is largely a mental difference.

title: Remember Those Old-Time Beer Jingles?
description: To the Editor Your Aug. 16 article on the new dry beers included a passing reference to Rheingold Beer that should have stirred the memory of any New Yorker over the age of 45. My beer is Rheingold, the dry beer. Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer. It's not bitter, not sweet; it's the dry flavored treat. Won't you try extra dry Rheingold beer?

title: Farms, Food and Chemicals: Seeds of a Revolt
description: Although the transition to natural cultivation has begun in several regions, the National Academy of Sciences' proposal to shift most of American agriculture from a heavy dependence on synthetic chemicals would take decades and require profound changes in attitudes and public policy,farmers and agricultural experts say.

title: Elections Board Gearing Up to Avoid Voting Problems
description: Anticipating charges of electoral irregularities, fraud and vote-stealing, the city's Board of Elections is taking unusual steps to cut voting problems to a minimum tomorrow, during the most hotly contested mayoral primary election in many years.

title: Promotional News Videos Gain Support
description: WITH the aid of satellite technology, Capital Cities/ABC Inc. is set to lend its stamp of approval to one of the most debated features in television news: video news releases, promotional materials that often mimic the techniques and conventions of television news programs.

title: ENERGY DEPT. AIMS TO STOP SPENDING ON SPACE REACTOR
description: The Energy Department wants to stop spending money on the Government's main program to develop a nuclear reactor for use in outer space, Federal officials said last week.

title: Kansas City Papers Study Merger
description: The Kansas City Star Company is conducting a study to determine whether to merge its morning and afternoon newspapers.

title: Critic's Notebook; London Theater Museum: Fairly New but Deeply Troubled
description: ''To be or not to be'' may be the most hackneyed phrase in all Shakespeare, but it certainly sums up the present troubles of the London Theater Museum, which opened in Covent Garden in April 1987.

title: Yankees Returning To Losing Ways
description: The winning streak has turned into a losing streak. The Yankees, whose ride reached nine games and carried them from the East Coast to the West, crash-landed this weekend. But when they packed and left for another stop on their trip, they were not wondering why.

title: Child World reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said the increased losses in the latest second quarter were due to high interest charges and advertising costs as well as costs associated with stores opened less than one year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All my impressions of capitalism, of the United States, of Americans that have been pounded into me over the years, including by the Short History of the Communist Party - all of them have changed 180 degrees in the day and a half I have been here.'' -Boris N. Yeltsin. [ A1:5. ]

title: Turkish 'Dumping' Law
description: A law to block the ''dumping'' of unfairly subsidized imports will take effect Oct. 1, a Treasury official said Friday. He told reporters that fines would be imposed and other measures would be taken against companies responsible for such imports, which the Government says have risen sharply. It has been estimated that almost half of Turkey's $14 billion worth of annual imports may be unfairly subsidized. Most are from East Asia and Eastern Europe.

description: Debt

HUNGARY ALLOWS 7,000 EAST GERMANS TO EMIGRATE WEST
description: Hungary announced today that it is allowing thousands of East Germans who have refused to return home to leave for West Germany. It was another chapter, and a dramatic one, in a summerlong exodus through the new Hungarian gap in the Communist frontier.

title: Bears' Long Drive Tops Bengals, 17-14
description: It seemed only fitting here today at Soldier Field that a Chicago Bears fumble in the waning seconds would give the Cincinnati Bengals one more chance, one more shot at the Bears' biting defense, which kept bending but not folding.

title: Question Box
description: The E.R.A. Era Q. What is the major league pitching record for the most years with an earned run average lower than 2.00 and who holds it? A. When it came to milking victories without much support by being skimpy in allowing runs to score, especially the earned kind, Walter Johnson was the cream of the crop. Johnson, who holds major league career records for 1-0 decisions won (38) and lost (26), rang up 10 seasons with e.r.a.'s under 2.00 in his 21 years as the mainstay of the Washington Senators in 1907-27, and that's four more than any other pitcher. No slouch was he as a worker, either, for Johnson often pitched more than 300 innings a season. Here is a breakdown by year of Johnson's 10 seasons below 2.00, with innings pitched in parentheses: 1.64 in 1908 (257 innings); 1.35 in 1910 (373); 1.89 in 1911 (323); 1.39 in 1912 (368); 1.09 in 1913 (346); 1.72 in 1914 (371); 1.55 in 1915 (336); 1.89 in 1916 (371); 1.27 in 1918 (325); 1.49 in 1919 (290).

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,162,000 for the quarter and $15,370,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $1,094,000, or 37 cents a share. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,622,000 for the quarter and $4,363,000 for the 9 months.

Goldin of North Brunswick, N.J., were married yesterday at Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple in New Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Bennett F. Miller performed the ceremony.

description: One thing seems clear about the mayoral primary here on Tuesday: Mayor Coleman A. Young will advance to the general election in his bid for a record fifth term. What is not so clear in a field crowded with some of the city's biggest political names, including Representative John Conyers Jr., is who will face Mr. Young.

title: Micronetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Whatever the outcome of tomorrow's mayoral primary, it's safe to say that New York City will have a new comptroller, Manhattan a new borough president and Brooklyn a new district attorney.

description: The Southmark Corporation said Friday that Neal Batson, a partner in the Atlanta law firm Alston & Bird, had been appointed as examiner in the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. The appointment, which is subject to the bankruptcy court's approval, was made after a court directed that an examiner be appointed to investigate allegations of mismanagement and fraud in Southmark's operations. The examiner was also appointed to make recommendations on findings of the investigation.

description: A Cuban Air Force training plane crashed into the sea several miles northwest of Havana and seven men aboard are believed dead, the Juventud Rebelde youth newspaper reported today.

description: Facing labor opposition, Argentina's new Government is pushing ahead with efforts to reorganize the deficit-ridden state oil company and increase private participation in oil and gas exploration and production.

title: Elyse Leonard Is Married To R. Peter Evans on L.I.
description: At Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, L.I., Elyse Jill Leonard, a daughter of Stephen Mitchell Leonard of Albertson, L.I., and Eleanor Sage Leonard of New York, was married yesterday to R. Peter Evans, a son of Carol Evans of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated.

title: Evoking When Mambo Was King
description: As he dies slowly in a seedy New York hotel, Cesar Castillo, a onetime mambo musician and the central character of Oscar Hijuelos's new novel, ''The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' remembers the arc of his life.

title: Lewis H. Rohrbaugh, Administrator, 81
description: Dr. Lewis H. Rohrbaugh, an administrator of the Boston University Medical Center from 1962 to 1973, died yesterday at the Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Maine of complications from a hip fracture. He was 81 years old and lived in Rockport, Me.

title: Amy L. Schram Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Lynn Schram, a daughter of Mrs. Leonard H. Schram of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Mr. Schram, was married in New York yesterday to Howard Matson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Matson of Wayne, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Herman officated at the Terrace Restaurant atop Butler Hall at Columbia University.

title: Store Owner Shoots 3 Dead
description: A Brooklyn clothing store owner fatally shot three men in the head yesterday and later told investigators they had tried to rob him, the police said. Dexter Lockhart, the owner of the Final Phase Boutique at 3407 Church Avenue in the Flatbush section, told the police that three men had entered his store at 3:55 P.M. and threatened to rob him, Sgt. Maurice Howard, a police spokesman, said. The men, all in their 20s, have not been identified. During a scuffle in the back room, Mr. Lockhart, 24 years old, grabbed a .38-caliber pistol from one of the men, he said, and shot each once in the head. Detectives found that pistol, an unfired .45-caliber pistol and spent .45- caliber shells, Sergeant Howard said.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: TENNIS;
Life of the Touring Pro
description: LEAD: They traveled from city to city by car or by train, playing as often as seven days a week in high school gymnasiums and local arenas. Before the days of television exposure, corporate sponsors and open tennis, which legitimized the sport and its prize money in 1968, the life of a touring pro resembled that of a barnstorming tour.

title: Yeltsin, the Moscow Populist, Takes Manhattan (in Stride)
description: When he spotted the Statue of Liberty yesterday from the window of a circling helicopter, Boris N. Yeltsin smiled broadly and applauded. Then, in a spontaneous gesture of delight, he gave a lusty thumbs-up sign - as if he, the maverick prince of the Soviet Communist Party, and she, the symbol of American freedom, have a special thing going.

title: Pressure on World Bank to Save the World
description: As the World Bank considers how to use its considerable economic leverage to help reduce the threat of global warming, environmentalists and politicians are complaining that it is not exerting strong leadership.

title: Wagnerian Opening for a Tokyo Hall
description: It was one of the hottest tickets of this cultural season. For four nights, the last of them tonight, the Bayreuth Festival Opera offered its sumptuous production of Richard Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' in the opening of Tokyo's sleekest and newest cultural center to the cheers of audiences and the acclaim of Japan's critics.

description: All 1988 results restated to reflect compliance with SFAS 94.

description: Ashland Oil Inc. had agreed to pay $325 million to the National Iranian Oil Company to settle a 10-year dispute over crude oil purchases from Iran. National Iranian Oil had sought $768 million because an Ashland unit refused to pay for crude oil in 1979. A jury trial in the case was scheduled to begin Monday in United States District Court in Jackson.

description: The plan was to have no plan. And it worked, producing a 28-0 victory for the New Orleans Saints and ruining the National Football League coaching debut for Jimmy Johnson of the Dallas Cowboys.

description: Willi Schalk resigned on Friday as the president and chief operating officer of BBDO Worldwide. Mr. Schalk, 49 years old, said he would return to his native West Germany and pursue a career outside advertising.

description: Exercise machines that simulate walking up stairs have flooded the fitness market in the last two years. The newest generation of the step climber, one that uses air instead of hydraulics for resistance, will be available soon.

description: Shares in Air New Zealand went on sale Friday in the country's first important offering since the 1987 market crash.

description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who for years has confounded women's groups by resisting a clear pro-abortion rights stance, stated firmly Saturday night that abortion ''must be a matter of the woman's conscience.''

description: In New York City - where fads wax and wane, fun can be pricey and diseases are well-publicized - the ''talking date'' seems to be gaining currency.

title: INSIDE
description: Rumanian Ship Capsizes A Rumanian passenger ship carrying 179 people capsized and sank today after colliding with a Bulgarian tugboat on the Danube. Page A3. Gorbachev's Caldron After a summer of stress, Mikhail S. Gorbachev knows that the fall will test whether the Soviet people are ready for self-government. Page A10. Clot Is 2d Reagan Suffered In July, Ronald Reagan's doctors found a small blood clot in the former President's brain, and it healed without an operation. Page A14.

title: Professional Football's Most Frustrated Team
description: MIDWAY in the fourth quarter yesterday, the Jets appeared to have created the most stunning comeback victory from a halftime deficit in the history of this frustrated franchise. After trailing the New England Patriots, 21-0, in a first half in which they produced more boos than yards, the Jets had rallied for a 24-21 lead. But in the end, they lost their National Football League season opener, 27-24. Frustrated again. Except for their Super Bowl III season more than two decades ago, the Jets have always been more frustrated than fulfilled. Some franchises, like the New Orleans Saints and the Detroit Lions, have never been close to the Super Bowl. But the 1982 Jets were close until they got bogged down in the Miami mud. And in 1986, the Jets were rolling with a 10-1 record, the N.F.L.'s best, until injuries riddled the defensive unit and the rival Giants emerged as that season's Super Bowl champions.

title: Federal Reserve Doesn't Need Fixing
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Blocks Hoylake
description: A Federal judge in Tacoma, Wash., has rejected an attempt by Hoylake Investments Ltd. of Britain to prevent a review by the Washington State Insurance Commission that could block Hoylake's attempt to take over B.A.T. Industries in a $21.7 billion deal.

title: Giants, Redskins To Keep It Simple
description: The Giants and the Redskins will open their National Football League seasons Monday night with a head-on collision in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: Metro Tel Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings reflected payment of $25,200 in redeemable preferred stock dividends each year.

title: Niagara Mohawk Power reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Included write-off of $77,900,000 on disallowed Nine Mile Two costs in December 1987. The company said earnings for the year were lower due to the interim relief agreement on replacement power costs and increased expenses associated with the outage at the Nine Mile Unit One plant. The company also said earnings were lower because of the cost of programs not accounted for in electric and gas rate agreements with the New York State Public Service Commission and other state agencies.

title: Medicaid Rationing Will Cost More in the End; Rockefeller Warned
description: To the Editor:

title: Pierce Ordered Concessions on Project, Files Show
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr. ordered broad financial concessions for a luxury apartment complex in Chicago despite opposition from a senior Federal housing official who said he became so concerned about the $23 million deal that he refused to sign mortgage documents, Government files and interviews show.

title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody
description: The New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday that based on preliminary findings, a man who died in police custody on Saturday received no injuries that could have caused his death, but only minor cuts and bruises.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TV's Pace and the Ads Increase as Time Goes By
description: Next time Sam plays ''As Time Goes By'' during a television rerun of ''Casablanca,'' check his tempo. Thanks to the pervasive use of time-compression machines by broadcasters and programmers, Humphrey Bogart's time usually goes by in a New York minute rather than at the languid pace of a Moroccan night.

title: Florida Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank said a reduction in operating expense by $23.8 million contributed to the recent year's improvement.

title: Direct Mail: Political Arsenal's Precision Weapon
description: Keeping pace with the flood of television commercials in the final days before New York City's mayoral primary is a rain of campaign literature, as candidates fill mailboxes with pleas for money, appeals for support and attacks on their rivals.

title: Latin America Records Some Economic Gains
description: Despite a sharp contraction in economic growth last year, Latin American countries increased both exports and imports and managed for the first time since 1982 to reduce foreign debt, the Inter-American Development Bank said Friday.

title: Esprit Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $192,000 for both the quarter and year.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Outdoors: Hunting Those Little Imps Known as Woodcocks
description: LEAD: IF the woodcock is America's most peculiar gamebird, the fault lies with evolution. This cousin of sandpipers and plovers long ago abandoned the shoreline and has adapted splendidly to life in the upland coverts of the eastern half of the United States and Canada. Slightly larger than a bobwhite quail and considerably smaller than the ruffed grouse, it is a bird that inspires wonder and delight.

title: Treasury Schedule Is Light This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues for this week is confined to today's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Grand Jury Investigates Proxy Unit
description: A state grand jury in New York is conducting a criminal fraud investigation of the billing practices at the Carter Organization, one of three companies that dominate the business of proxy solicitation for takeover fights, people close to the inquiry said Friday.

title: Tektronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 19
description: b-Net income

title: Medicaid Rationing Will Cost More in the End
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil's Berth Is Official
description: Brazil officially reached the 1990 World Cup finals today when it was awarded a 2-0 victory in a qualifying game abandoned last Sunday in Rio de Janeiro by Chile, which said that its goalkeeper had been hit by a flare fired from the stands.

title: Linamar Machine reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $500,000, which is the net result of a tax credit and a loss from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: BT Telecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Kingdom Wins Hurdles
description: Roger Kingdom ran the fastest 110-meter hurdle race in history today at the World Cup meet here under the worst of conditions.

title: Still Nit-Picking Democracy
description: Running for public office shouldn't be a nightmare. But that's how Adele Cohen, a candidate for the New York City Council in tomorrow's Democratic primary, describes the bruising court fight that has marred her race against Sam Horowitz, a veteran Council member from Brooklyn.

title: Peters, J M Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Margaret B. Parkinson, Editor, 62
description: Margaret B. Parkinson, a book and magazine editor, died of pancreatic cancer Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 62 years old and had homes in Manhattan and East Quogue, L.I.

title: Britain Fails to Hinder European Money Plan
description: At a meeting of the European Community's finance ministers this weekend, British officials did their best to derail a movement to establish a European central bank and a single European currency.

title: Mother Teresa Said to Gain After Receiving a Pacemaker
description: Mother Teresa's condition improved today after the Nobel laureate received a pacemaker to steady her heartbeat and heavy doses of antibiotics to fight a fever, doctors said.

title: Moral of the U.S. Open: You Just Never Know
description: LET'S see if we've got this right. Howard Johnson was on third base but Martina struck out. Or was it, Kevin McReynolds was up a break and double-faulted twice?

title: Blue Jays Stretch Lead in The East
description: Now that he's on a winning team and his personal 14-game losing streak is history, Jim Acker can joke about it.

title: Skyline Chili reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 6
description: b-Net income The company said the latest third- quarter loss arose from a $600,000 restructuring charge related to the closing of six unprofitable restaurants.

title: Gander Mountain reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tent Cities Becoming the Front Lines
description: LEAD: Beneath freeway overpasses, in parking lots and in parks, people around the country are creating tent cities that are fast becoming the front lines in political battles over the homeless.

title: Dump Site Opponents Vow to Step Up Fight
description: Opponents of a proposed radioactive dump moved their battle over the weekend to Allegany and Cortland Counties, where a state commission has picked five sites for further study as a possible dump site.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Campeau's decision to sell Bloomingdale's was the culmination of miscalculations that began when the company took on too much debt to acquire Federated, analysts and deal makers say. Documents on file with the S.E.C. indicate that Campeau had agreed to guarantee by Friday that it could repay much of its short-term debt or give a stake to three lenders. [ Page D1. ] A grand jury is conducting a criminal fraud inquiry of the Carter Organization, which solicits proxies for takeover fights, people close to the investigation said. Prosecutors are said to believe that clients were billed for expenses that were never incurred. [ D1. ] The misconduct of two generic drug makers appears to have been more serious and widespread than had been thought, two members of Congress said. [ A17. ] Dress-shirt makers are scrambling to invent a better button, to replace those that crumble after professional laundering. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY The Energy Department wants to stop spending on a program to develop a nuclear reactor for outer space, officials say. [ A1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT European finance ministers have made progress toward economic and monetary union, despite British efforts to derail plans for a European central bank and a single currency. Representatives of the 12 European Community nations met in France. [ D2. ] Argentina's Government is advancing efforts to reorganize the state oil company and increase the private sector's role in the oil and gas business. But moves to sell pieces of the state company may lead to conflict with the oil workers union. [ D6. ] Latin American countries increased exports and imports last year, and managed to reduce foreign debt, according to a report by the Inter-American Development Bank. [ D6. ] West Germany's chemical industry may be near the end of a six-year boom as it confronts an uncertain global economy, currency swings and new health-care regulations. [ D6. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Rupert Murdoch says Sky Television is an answer to the ills of British TV. But early projections for his satellite service have been scaled back and Sky's growth prospects are uncertain. [ D1. ] Time-compression machines are frequently used by broadcasters to make room for more commercials by accelerating the speed of programs. The machines are also used to create an artificial level of enthusiasm on game shows and in commercials. [ D10. ] A campaign to promote ''designated drivers'' who would abstain from alcohol may have had considerable impact. But the sweeping nature of the campaign raises questions about how easily such underlying messages could be abused. Television. [ D11. ] Trans Continental will transmit video news releases to television newsrooms. Some TV executives fear that the promotional materials, which often mimic the conventions of news programs, may damage their credibility. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D12. ] Book publishers are rushing to retell the Leona Helmsley story, despite detailed news coverage of her tax-evasion trial. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Tight monetary policies in industrial nations are likely to produce a slowdown in growth next year while increasing the possibility of a global recession, analysts say. The inversion of the ''yield curve,'' in which yields on short-term debt exceeds that of long-term bonds, has often signaled downturns. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] The man nominated to be the next U.S. Attorney in Manhattan, Otto G. Obermaier, has been a white-collar criminal defense lawyer. But some lawyers expect him to be no less aggressive than his predecessors. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Government rules on eliminating storage tank leaks may create a fast-growing business, some analysts say. Several existing companies stand to benefit. Market Place. [ D8. ]

description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. and Private Employee Turnover Similar
description: The number of Federal workers who leave their jobs is comparable to that in private companies, a Government report shows, but some agencies say that those who leave are some of the best workers.

title: U.S. Prison Population Sets Record for a Year, in Six Months
description: The nation's prison population increased by a record 46,004 inmates in the first six months of this year to a total of 673,565 men and women, the Bureau of Justice Statistics said today.

title: Lectec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lee Hermann Marries
description: Lee Hermann and Eric Holtermann were married yesterday at the Bird and Bottle Inn in Garrison, N.Y., by the Rev. Leonard Rust, a Presbyterian minister. The 27-year-old bride, the daughter of Barbara T. Hermann of Dix Hills, L.I., and Robert L. Hermann of New York, is the assistant managing editor of Metropolitan Home magazine in New York. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Holtermann, 32, is the son of Magdalena Holtermann of Kinnelon, N.J., and the late Walter O. Holtermann. A graduate of the College of Architecture at the University of North Carolina, he an associate at Platt & Byard Architects in New York.

title: War On the 'War'
description: Political oppositions are in business to oppose; the television medium feels a need to provide ''balance''; commentators in print satisfy their following by the wit and acerbity of their denunciation; and plenty of people resent anything that comes from a central authority.

title: Lag Expected For German Chemicals
description: Facing an uncertain global economy, currency swings and new health-care regulations, West Germany's chemical industry, the fourth largest in the world, may be nearing the end of its six-year boom.

title: Knepper Tops His Former Teammates
description: Bob Knepper held his former teammates to five hits over six innings and Pat Sheridan hit a three-run double in the first inning today, leading the San Francisco Giants over the Houston Astros, 5-3.

title: Books of The Times; Writing on Writing, by One Who Should Know
description: Harp By John Gregory Dunne 235 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Market Place; Cleanup of Tanks Promises Profits
description: NEW Government regulations aimed at eliminating gasoline and chemical leaks from underground storage tanks should create a fast-growing business over the next several years, analysts say.

title: Weisfield's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: In the Sports Pages
description: It should come as no surprise to anyone who followed the extensive coverage of the Pete Rose gambling scandal and his eventual banishment from baseball that there is now statistical evidence that news about sports, or at least baseball, is hard to find in the sports pages of the nation's newspapers.

title: Housing Plan Is Central Issue In Yonkers Primary Contests
description: Local officials who favor compliance with a court-ordered housing desegregation plan have long felt that a majority in this city of 190,000 agreed that continued opposition to the plan was pointless.

title: Shaer Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Corrections
description: The cover of the Television section yesterday carried an incomplete listing for the ABC comedy series ''Chicken Soup,'' starring Lynn Redgrave and Jackie Mason. Channel 7, in New York City, has moved the show to 8:30 P.M. tomorrow to accommodate its coverage of the mayoral primary. Other stations will broadcast the show at the original time, 9:30 P.M.

title: Acura Prices Raised
description: The Acura division of the Honda Motor Company said Friday that prices for its 1990 Legend automobiles will be increased an average of five-tenths of a percent, or $143 a car, over comparable 1989 models. Prices for the Legend sedan will range from $22,600 to $30,410, it said, and prices for the coupe will be between $24,760 and $31,490. In May, the company announced prices for its redesigned 1990 Integra cars ranging from $11,950 to $16,675.

description: Listed below are the candidates in the contested races in tomorrow's primary elections in New York City. Incumbents are marked with an asterisk. At the right is a typical ballot for the Democratic primary as it will appear in voting booths in the 67th Assembly District, on Manhattan's West Side. title: Scheib (Earl) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Brady, W H reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credit of $4,625,000, or 62 cents a share, which represented a gain from insurance proceeds and a gain of $1,233,000, or 17 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment. The company said the latest quarter and year included a nonrecurring charge of $4,467,000 for writedown in the carrying value of certain assets.

title: COLOMBIANS FEAR FOR THE ECONOMY
description: As Colombia's stepped-up campaign against drug trafficking goes into its fourth week, many Colombians are divided over the wisdom of trying to abruptly shut down the country's most lucrative industry.

title: Bridge
description: As the World Team Championships began here today, players complained of travel problems caused by a strike of domestic airline pilots. A worse problem, still unsolved, concerns a member of the United States team. Peter Pender of San Francisco, who won the world title in Sao Paulo, Brazil, in 1985, has been refused a visa by the Australian authorities on medical grounds. He is a carrier of the AIDS virus, although he is not suffering from the disease.

title: Liat Cohen Weds Dr. Brent Lasker
description: At Congregation Orach Chaim in New York, Liat Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Cohen of Beersheba, Israel, was married yesterday to Dr. Brent Lasker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Lasker of Hazel Crest, Ill. Dr. Manfred Fulda, a rabbi, officiated.

title: Becker Foils Lendl to Win First U.S. Open Title; 3-Time Champion Is Beaten in 4 Sets
description: Across the net, Boris Becker smiled a cursory smile and twice in succession served the kind of serve that invites no reply. Ivan Lendl, put in his place in the very stadium he had come to regard as his place, made none.

title: Inter-Arab Violence Growing in Occupied Areas
description: Six Palestinians were killed in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip today, five shot by Israelis and one killed at the hands of fellow Arabs. The body of an Israeli man who was apparently killed by a Palestinian was found today in Tel Aviv.

title: Gulfstream Gets Contract
description: Gulfstream Aerospace Technologies announced Friday that it had signed an $85 million contract to manufacture wings for a new 29-seat British Aerospace aircraft.

title: Biomagnetic Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chyron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle increasing net income by $515,000, or 5 cents a share. The company said the latest year loss was after an income tax benefit of $2,185,000, or 20 cents a share, and the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle reducing net income by $350,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Pamela Tizer Marries
description: Pamela Susan Tizer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Tizer of Rydal, Pa., was married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan to David Alan Finkelstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Finkelstein of Toronto. Rabbi Simeon J. Maslin and Cantor Richard Botton officiated. The bride graduated from Tulane University and received an M.B.A. from George Washington University. Mr. Finklestein, a graduate of the University of Toronto who received an M.B.A. from York University, is the general manager of Light Line, a lighting company in Toronto.

title: In Switch, Algerian Premier Agrees to Give Up Job
description: Prime Minister Kasdi Merbah of Algeria agreed to give up his job today after refusing to step down when he was dismissed on Saturday by President Chadli Benjedid.

title: '92 Scares European Border Towns
description: In this never-never-land setting of soaring mountains and burbling streams, Modane's 7,000 people have a fairy-tale wish: that 1992 never come.

title: Five Reasons to Transform 42d Street
description: A giant cylindrical sign, 27 stories high, gyrates on one corner. The Great White Way dazzles with the brilliance of 20,000 new bulbs. Late-night strollers wander through concourses of shops and food stands.

title: Scramble Is On to Develop The Unbreakable Button
description: In a business that usually fusses over fit, color and style, the $2.5 billion men's dress-shirt industry is scrambling to invent a better button.

title: Fast Start For Sanders
description: Deion Sanders, making his National Football League debut today only three days after signing a $4.5 million contract, returned a first-quarter punt 68 yards for a touchdown although the Atlanta Falcons lost to the Los Angeles Rams, 31-21.

title: Signtech reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: After Day of Protest, Work Resumes on Mill
description: A paper mill expansion, brought to a halt by a violent protest over the hiring of nonunion workers, resumed today as about 370 nonunion workers returned to the site in five buses escorted by police cars, On Saturday, union supporters stormed a housing camp for nonunion workers at the Boise Cascade paper mill in this town of 6,500 residents on the Canadian border, setting trailers on fire and overturning vehicles at the site of the $533 million expansion.

title: Awaiting the Great Boredom
description: The great ideological struggles are over . . . Western liberal democracy has proved to be the best way to run a society, and is now without serious rivals . . . The West has not merely won the cold war: its success has put an end to history.

title: India's Bleakest Corner Is Where All Hope Ends
description: In an era when it is common to talk of Asian economic miracles and a Pacific century, the Indian state of Rajasthan is a reminder that there are, in reality, two Asias. There are the economic tigers and would-be tigers from Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Thailand, but also the struggling, crowded, volatile nations of South Asia, especially India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, where survival is difficult.

title: Dover Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Intelogic Trace Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary credit from purchase of debentures of $2,481,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: Metro Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $483,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: Cincinnati Limits Hours Street Musicians Can Play
description: The City Council has passed a regulation limiting the hours that street musicians can play here to 90 minutes at midday. It is an action that Victor Buttrom and Dishon Woody take personally, largely because they say they are the only musicians who regularly play on the city's streets.

title: ECC International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the year included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $2,100,000, or 37 cents a share.

title: Eliot Was a Good Poet With Bad Attitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 East Germans can leave Hungary for West Germany, Budapest said. The announcement was a final chapter in a summerlong exodus through the new Hungarian gap in the Communist frontier. Page A1

title: The Helmsley Trial Has Just Begun for Book Publishers
description: Book publishers are losing little time in retelling the story of Leona Helmsley, the self-proclaimed hotel queen, even though her trial and tribulations have unfolded in generous (and ungenerous) detail in the press and on television.

title: Judges Anguish Over Medical Issues
description: Saying they increasingly face anguishing decisions about medical cases, judges debated this weekend whether the courtroom is the place to resolve them.

title: Rumanian Boat Sinks in Danube
description: A Rumanian ship carrying 179 people collided with a Bulgarian tugboat and sank in the Danube today, leaving 151 people missing, Rumania's official Agerpres press agency reported.

title: 2 DRUG COMPANIES FACE ACCUSATIONS
description: Two members of Congress contended today that the misconduct of two generic-drug manufacturers of generic drugs that have pleaded guilty to bribing Food and Drug Administration officials appears to have been more serious and widespread than the companies led investigators to believe.

title: Canadex Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sharman Propp Marries on L.I.
description: Sharman Toby Propp and Richard Leslie Gans, lawyers for the city of New York, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman and Cantor Benjamin Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: Soviets to Buy Butter
description: The Soviet Union last week agreed to buy more than 110 million pounds of surplus American butter for a subsidized price of $80.9 million. The butter was priced at slightly more than 73 cents a pound, while the United States now pays about $1.21 a pound to buy butter under domestic price support programs. The butter is to be delivered from December through March of next year.

title: Business and the Law; Wall St. Ponders Prosecutor Shift
description: AT first glance, Wall Street corruption could not be further removed from this small island in Lake George nestled in the Adirondack Mountains. Yet the issue has been very real here, where in the last four days, prosecutors and other lawyers from Manhattan have been attending an annual conference held by Federal judges from New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: Prague Journal; Shirley Temple Black Unpacks a Bag of Memories
description: Shirley Temple Black is the last person you would think to find in Prague these days. But she has just become the American Ambassador to Czechoslovakia.

title: Bengals' Krumrie Is Back
description: Tim Krumrie's belief that he could recover from his Super Bowl XXIII leg injury and once again toil along the line of scrimmage for the Bengals became reality here today as the Chicago Bears defeated Cincinnati, 17-14.

title: A City Gets Excited As the Primary Nears
description: James Sessioms Jr., a 44-year-old former Marine with a quiet nature and a booming voice, wearing a pair of jeans and an old sweatshirt yesterday, prepared to wax his car: a sky-blue stretch limousine. Both the man and his Lincoln have an appointment tomorrow.

title: Newbridge Networks Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 5
description: The company was not public in the year-ago first quarter. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: San Francisco Journal; A Bridge Of Fame Is Losing Its Glow
description: Natives and tourists alike are growing increasingly curious about patches of gray on the Golden Gate Bridge, a landmark beloved for its signature orange finish.

title: Capital Reserve Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Cimarron Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jane Austen's Family Squabbles Over a House
description: ''One half of the world cannot understand the pleasures of the other,'' Jane Austen wrote 175 years ago, in the village where she spent her last years. Today her brother's descendants are living those words, squabbling over a house she loved.

title: United Tote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $207,862, or 9 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Murdoch Gambles on Satellite TV
description: In a rare public speech, Rupert Murdoch rose to the podium at the Edinburgh cultural festival two weeks ago to deliver a spirited defense of Sky Television, his biggest media gamble ever.

title: Saatchi Rumors Swirl After Stake Is Sold
description: The acquisition last week of a large stake in Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. by Southeastern Asset Management Inc., a Memphis-based investment management company, has touched off rumors in the British investment community that Saatchi may be on the block.

title: The Navy Scapegoats a Dead Seaman
description: LEAD: Accused rapists, killers and drug dealers enjoy the presumption of innocence until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. But a young naval petty officer last week was branded a mass murderer on the basis of evidence that was only ''relevant, material and not overly redundant.''

title: Geraldine Parker Weds
description: Geraldine Parker, an operatic soprano, and Dr. Richard A. Eisenberg, a physician in Melville, L.I., were married yesterday at the Hemisphere Club in New York. Rabbi Moshe Pomeranz and Cantor Paul Zim officiated. The bride, who has appeared with the Seattle Opera and Israel National Opera, is a daughter of Lucille Parker of Bloomfield, N.J., and the late Anthony Parker. Dr. Eisenberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Eisenberg of New Britain, Conn., graduated from Deerfield Academy, Wesleyan University and the University of Connecticut School of Medicine.

title: Walter James Dunfey Dies at 57; Hotel Executive Active in Politics
description: Walter James Dunfey, a former hotel chain co-owner who was politically active in New England and a financial supporter of Democractic Party causes, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital of complications from a brain aneurysm. He was 57 years old. Mr. Dunfey, who lived in Rye, N.H., was a co-founder and the director of Dunfey Hotels, which he helped build into an international hotel company. He sold it in 1974 and it is now known as Omni Hotels.

title: Mass for Slain Colombians
description: Their ranks thinned by fears of reprisal, the Colombian-Americans in Washington attended a Mass today in memory of the Colombians killed in the drug-related violence that has spread as Bogota challenges the country's drug cartels.

title: Tadeusz Sendzimir, 95; Created Metals Process
description: Tadeusz Sendzimir, the developer of a widely used process of galvanizing steel and other metals and the chairman of T. Sendzimir Inc., a manufacturing concern that operates in 34 countries, died Sept. 1 at the Jupiter (Fla.) hospital. He was 95 years old and had homes in Jupiter and in Bethlehem, Conn.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bearings Inc., Cleveland, a distributor of bearings, named Robert C. Stinson vice president and general counsel and Richard C. Shaw director of corporate communications.

title: Review/Music; Re-Creating Part of a Beethoven Oboe Work From Sketches
description: It is fascinating to know that Beethoven wrote an oboe concerto in his youth, frustrating to learn that someone (a publisher, probably) lost it, tantalizing to realize that some identifiable sketches for it exist.

title: Microbilt Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Anne E. Brodsky Marries in Newport
description: Anne Elizabeth Brodsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Brodsky of Newport and Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew L. Sternlicht, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Sternlicht of Stamford, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Leslie Getterman officiated at the bride's parents' home in Newport.

title: Becker Foils Lendl to Win First U.S. Open Title; 21-Year-Old Shows His Toughness
description: Until the 3 hours 51 minutes had ended, until Boris Becker had finally overcome the soreness he felt all over, the mastery of Ivan Lendl at the United States Open and his own past disappointments at Flushing Meadows, until the moment his racquet was hoisted 20 rows up in Louis Armstrong Stadium, it had been so easy to forget that he is 21 years old. ''Me, too,'' Becker said yesterday. ''I forget.'' He is young enough to possess the tools that once turned the idea of tournament championships into demands, and old enough to comprehend how difficult that task can be. Becker won his first Grand Slam event west of the All England Club, defeating Lendl, 7-6, 1-6, 6-3, 7-6.

title: Earlier Blood Clot on Brain Disclosed by Reagan Doctor
description: The blood clot that was removed from former President Ronald Reagan's brain on Friday was the second that he suffered since his horseback accident two months ago, Mr. Reagan's neurosurgeon said today.

title: Interphase Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Growth Index Off in Canada
description: Canada's leading economic indicator fell for the first time in five years in June, providing new evidence the economy is losing strength, a federal agency said Friday.

title: International Verifact reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said it had a one-time charge in the latest quarter from the retirement in May of a company founder. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Midwest Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Domco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cubs Top Cardinals In a Big Showdown
description: Shortly before the first-place Chicago Cubs took their positions here Friday for the opening game of their weekend series against the second-place St. Louis Cardinals, a bank of threatening storm clouds settled in over Wrigley Field. The sense of impending doom created by the clouds seemed only fitting.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Current Account 2d Qtr. Wednesday Auto Sales Early Sept. Thursday Retail Sales Aug. Friday Producer Price Index Aug Merchandise Trade July Inventories-Sales July Industrial Production Aug. Capacity Utilization Aug.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Prague's political and economic policies misidentified the Czechoslovak who will be at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington for three months. He is Karel Dyba of the Forecasting Institute of the Academy of Sciences, not the dissident Jiri Dienstbier.

title: Vornado Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Rypien of Redskins Is Set to Start Again
description: Mark Rypien might have been the Redskins' starting quarterback this season even if Doug Williams had been healthy. When Williams underwent back surgery last month and was lost for the season, Rypien got the job, and he will start Monday night against the Giants.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Double Sculls Victory Gives Karlson 2d Gold
description: Kris Karlson of the United States, who Saturday won the women's lightweight single sculls, teamed up with Carey Beth Sands today to win the women's lightweight double sculls.

title: Despite Skew Rates, Few Fear Recession
description: In the opinion of some analysts, tight monetary policies in the United States and other major industrial nations are at best likely to produce a slowdown in growth next year while increasing the possibility of a global recession.

title: Chaus (Bernard) Inc(N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net loss

title: Bush to Let U.S. Anti-Drug Troops Move Outside Latin Base Camps
description: President Bush has signed a directive that authorizes United States military advisers in Latin America to move outside base camps to ''secure'' areas to train local forces, opening the way for a potentially expanded role for American troops in the anti-drug effort, Administration officials said today.

title: Mortgage Rates Fall
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.17 percent last week, down from a rate of 10.22 percent a week earlier, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.71 percent last week, down from 8.74 percent the previous week, Freddie Mac said.

title: Caltech Captures Realization Stakes
description: Caltech, a Florida shipper who was running for a claiming tag earlier this summer, outdueled Valid Ordinate early and held off Pach to Batan late to win the $123,800 Lawrence Realization Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Courier Dispatch Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988, it elected to change its method of accounting for income taxes effective July 1, 1987. Accordingly, the amounts presented above for the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988 have been restated from amounts previously reported to give effect to the change although earnings as reported for the entire year were not affected. The effect of the change was to increase the net earnings and earnings per share for the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988 by $143,000 and 5 cents a share, respectively.

title: The Lure of the Lore
description: Not many people remember the movie, ''The Ball Game,'' produced by Thomas Edison in 1898. Nor are they aware that there have been six movies entitled ''Casey at the Bat'' or that the first baseball game ever televised was between Columbia and Princeton at Baker Field on May 17, 1939, with the sports broadcaster Bill Stern at the microphone.

title: Mallon Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Comparable year-ago results were not available because the company, which is a combination of publicly held Mallon Minerals and 19 limited partnerships, began operations in December 1988.

title: Gorbachev's Caldron Simmers On
description: A month of Crimean vacation has removed the pallor and strain from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's face, but he does not sound like a man happy to be back at work.

title: Horizon Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income c-Included extraordinary credits of $30,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $393,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year, and the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $133,000.

title: Son Is Now 'Emperor Of Concrete' in France
description: Martin Bouygues, the youngest son of France's ''Emperor of Concrete,'' has been handed control of Bouygues S.A., the empire built by his father, Francis. The younger Mr. Bouygues, who is 37 years old, likes to point out that he was born in the year the company was founded. He inherits a corporation that boasts that it has changed the face of the earth.

title: Crested Corp reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $201,000 from tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Smith Labs Names Chief In Bid to Press Merger
description: LEAD: Smith Laboratories Inc. has named Timothy J. Wollaeger president and chief executive and charged him with bringing about a proposed merger between the company and the International Power Machines Corporation that has been challenged by a dissident group of Smith shareholders.

title: Semicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $119,000 on purchase of debentures. c-Net loss

title: Review/Music; Rock, Blues and Jazz Blend At the Knitting Factory
description: The young guitarist Jean-Paul Bourelly brought an old-fashioned guitar power trio (with occasional help from a background vocalist, Dmania Kyles) to the Knitting Factory on Saturday night. All the traditional elements were there: hair-raising rock power, guitar virtuosity, a thundering, barely contained, improvising rhythm section. But the show was in no way traditional. Mr. Bourelly has managed the trick of blending rock and blues ideas with a jazz harmonic and instrumental sensibility, a blend that allowed him to snarl away on guitar, then suddenly drop drastically different musical colors and textures into his solos.

title: Africa Nations Plan Airline
description: A new airline is being created by Tanzania, Zambia and Uganda with plans to fly to Europe soon, a Tanzanian official said Friday.

title: Maurice J. Saklad, Prosthodontist, 74
description: Dr. Maurice J. Saklad, a longtime clinical professor at New York University's College of Dentistry and a university trustee for whom a dental center building was named, died of a heart attack Saturday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif., where he had lived since he retired five years ago. He was 74 years old.

title: Meryl Lashinsky, Lawyer, Marries
description: Meryl Ann Lashinsky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Lashinsky of Hollis, Queens, and Tel Aviv, was married yesterday in New York to Dr. Alexander Eugene Weingarten, a son of Dr. Ruth Weingarten of Laurelton, Queens, and the late Dr. Morris Weingarten. Rabbi Raphael Butler officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Size of Turnout to Be Vital In New York City Primary; Black Vote Is Pivotal in Mayoral Race
description: While the candidates for mayor of New York City sweated through street fairs, rallies and church services yesterday, their supporters were mobilizing for the campaign that really counts: making sure the right people vote.

title: Amy Ackerman Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Amy Susan Ackerman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman B. Ackerman of New York, and Robert Arthur Wexler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Wexler of Encino, Calif., took place last evening. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Steven Jacobs at the Alta Mira Hotel in Sausalito, Calif.

title: Reservation Gambling Protest
description: The antigambling faction on the St. Regis Indian Reservation is asking nonresidents to stay out of the reservation's internal affairs by not investing in or patronizing casinos. About 30 people demonstrated Saturday in Massena in a quiet protest against gambling on the reservation, the state police said. Dave Cole of Determined Residents United for Mohawk Sovereignty, or Drums, said the protest was aimed at Massena residents who have invested in casinos on the reservation. ''Basically, we're just asking them to stay out of the internal affairs of the reservation,'' he said. The gambling issue erupted after state and Federal authorities raided the reservation casinos July 20.

title: Browns Trounce Steelers By 51-0
description: David Grayson scored on a 28-yard fumble return and 14-yard interception return as the revamped defense of the new Cleveland coach, Bud Carson, scored three touchdowns today in a 51-0 rout of Pittsburgh.

title: Review/Television; Jasper Johns: The Mystery of Simplicity
description: Jasper Johns is not the most promising subject for a television biography. With his paintings and prints fetching record prices at auctions these days, the artist has automatically been thrust into the highest celebrity circles of this celebrity-obsessed age. Yet he remains a carefully private man, never revealing too much about himself and talking about his work in terms drenched in ambiguity. Like his paintings, Johns seems quite obvious at first glance but then turns out to be complicated, if not mystifying.

title: Jets Waste Comeback in Loss to Patriots
description: The Jets nearly overcame the New England Patriots and the flip-flopping fans at Giants Stadium today, coming back from a 21-0 halftime deficit only to lose by 27-24.

title: Crown Books Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Layoffs at Jeep Plant
description: About 300 Jeep workers will be temporarily laid off here when the Chrysler Corporation suspends production of the Grand Wagoneer's 1990 model for two weeks in September and two weeks in October because of slow sales. The sales of the 1989 Grand Wagoneer are off 15 percent from a year ago, and Jeep dealers still have a three-month supply of the vehicle in stock, said a Chrysler spokesman. As of Aug. 30, sales totaled 11,387, compared with 13,442 for the corresponding period last year.

title: Pope and Gorbachev to Meet
description: The Soviet Ambassador to Rome said today that a long-awaited meeting between Pope John Paul II and Mikhail S. Gorbachev would take place during the Soviet President's planned visit here in November.

title: Denmark to Salvage Plane
description: Aviation authorities prepared an underwater salvage operation today to hoist a Norwegian charter plane that crashed off Denmark's west coast, killing all 55 people aboard. Experts said metal fatigue in the aircraft was a likely cause of the crash.

title: Defiance Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $310,000 for the quarter and $1,498,000 for the year.

title: Is Bush Repeating Rockefeller's Folly?
description: If Miguel Ruiz were alive today, he might tell George Bush a thing or two about getting tough on casual drug users, one objective of the President's new drug plan.

title: Margaret Boyle, Reporter, 75
description: Margaret Sidney Eaton Boyle, a retired reporter for The Reporter Dispatch in White Plains, died of heart failure Friday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. She was 75 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y.

title: RESULTS PLUS
