description: Charles J. Hynes, a veteran prosecutor in his first campaign for elective office, won the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn district attorney yesterday. The nomination is virtually tantamout to election in the heavily Democratic borough.

title: Market Place; Electric Utilities Face Competition
description: FOR years electric utilities have produced energy with little fear of much changing except how much the regulators allowed them to earn, and investors have counted mainly on a steady dividend. But the industry is rapidly changing. Analysts see investment opportunities among the bigger, more competitive utilities, but they caution that many of the smaller ones will not survive.

title: Real Estate; Empire State Building Is Still Vital
description: THE Merry-Go-Round, a 37-state chain of 611 specialty clothing stores, has selected the Empire State Building as the site for its flagship store. The move is in keeping with recent shifts in the area around Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, where higher-priced stores have displaced many of the curio stands, fashion discounters and cut-rate electronics shops that had crept into the midtown neighborhood.

title: Mattingly Drives In 4, Yanks Are Driven Out
description: The California Angels, still in a pennant race, survived a ninth-inning pitching lapse and beat the Yankees tonight, 7-6, when Wally Joyner lined a single to center that drove in Claudell Washington from second base in the bottom of the ninth.

title: Holtzman, Hynes and Messinger Shake the Old Order
description: Like a forest fire clearing the land for new growth, yesterday's Democratic primary swept away one crop of New York City political leaders while preparing the ground for a new one.

title: Executive Gives Prep School $1 Million
description: Boston Latin School, the oldest public college preparatory school in the country, has received a gift of $1 million from a New York business executive.

title: Lois/GGK Wins Time Magazine
description: TIME magazine selected Lois/ GGK yesterday as the agency of record for both its trade and consumer advertising efforts, capping a day of important advertising announcements from the magazine division of Time Warner Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Lloyd Bentsen proposed restoring I.R.A.'s on a widely available, tax-deductible basis as an alternative to President Bush's plan to lower the capital gains tax rate. The move by the Senate Finance Committee chairman represents an attempt by Democrats to capture some political advantage on the tax issue. It came as the House Ways and Means Committee struggled toward a compromise on alternatives to a cut in the capital gains tax rate. [ Page A1. ] The service and investment sector of the economy showed a $200 million deficit in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said. It was the first such deficit in 30 years. [ D1. ] The union that represents most airline pilots has been drained by the six-month strike at Eastern and has begun polling its members on whether to continue financial support for the walkout. [ D1. ] Japan's trade surplus plunged 31 percent, helped by a surge in oil imports, strong domestic demand and a strong dollar. [ D22. ] COMPANIES Maneuvering to end the bankruptcy of Public Service of New Hampshire took an unanticipated turn as New England Electric made a takeover offer that would impose rate increases lower than those in a rate schedule that had previously been agreed upon. [ D1. ] Dow Chemical and United Technologies will form a venture to build plastics, or composite parts, for the aerospace, automotive and military contracting industries. [ D1. ] CBS's ''48 Hours'' is a valuable property, not because it is a hit in the ratings, but because it costs so little to produce. [ D1. ] Fuji Bank agreed to buy all of Kleinwort Benson's stock, the first such purchase since the Fed agreed to allow Japanese firms to continue to act as primary dealers. [ D1. ] Intel introduced a computer microprocessor that employs a breakthrough technology enabling it to perform two tasks at once. [ D5. ] Wang brought out a line of minicomputers that it says is three times more powerful than its current systems. [ D5. ] Eli Lilly is recalling batches of all drugs made in an Indianapolis plant after the F.D.A. found manufacturing problems. [ D4. ] Procter & Gamble said it would receive $125 million for violations of its patent on crisp and chewy cookies. [ D4. ] TECHNOLOGY Strict environmental rules are making landfills increasingly complex and expensive. But opportunities are opening up for companies that can meet the new standards. [ D6. ] A Dallas company has developed an electronic operator system that uses voice synthesis and recognition technology. [ D6. ] MARKETS Stock prices edged up broadly on higher volume. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.85 points, to 2,707.26. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury issues were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading. Short- and intermediate-term issues again outperformed longer-dated securities. [ D14. ] Yields for C.D.'s and money market accounts continued to show small declines in the last week. [ D6. ] The dollar was narrowly mixed as traders awaited new economic reports. Gold prices were also mixed. [ D15. ] Coffee prices plunged on indications that the U.S. will not support a return to international export quotas. [ D15. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Reagan Administration's dollar policy nearly resulted in disaster in the early 1980's, two Government specialists say in a new book. They argue that Congress and private interests should be drawn into currency debates. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The utility industry is changing, and competition may make it difficult for small companies to survive. Market Place. [ D8. ] Time magazine picked Lois/GGK to handle its trade and consumer advertising efforts. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D7. ]

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Savings Bank, Stockton, Calif., named Patricia A. Joyce senior vice president and director of corporate planning.

title: Jalalabad Shows Its Recovery As Siege by Rebels Dwindles
description: Lieut.Gen. Manokai Mangal wears no ribbons on his crisp battle fatigues, but his stature needs no underlining among supporters of the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul.

title: Another Blunder in Nicaragua?
description: The United States is about to take another misstep in Nicaragua, and this one could jeopardize Washington's ability to nurture emerging democracies elsewhere in the world.

title: Tandy Buying Swedish Units
description: The Tandy Corporation said that it had reached an understanding with Datatronic A.B. of Sweden to acquire its Victor and Micronic subsidiaries for an undisclosed amount in cash.

title: Bill Moyers Shares Poetry's Joys
description: As a journalist whose beat is ideas, Bill Moyers has chosen what he calls an inevitable topic - poetry - for his latest public-television project, a six-part weekly series called ''Moyers: The Power of the Word,'' beginning at 9 P.M. Friday on Channel 13.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Dismissed Doc Edwards, manager. Named John Hart interim manager. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed a three-year contract with Charleston, W. Va. of the South Atlantic League. FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Agreed to terms with Johnny Hector, running back. Placed Wesley Walker, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Waived Carl Howard, cornerback, and Randy Tanner, wide receiver, from the developmental roster. Signed Brian Washington, safety. Re-signed Ken Rose and Adam Bob, linebackers. Placed Bob on the developmental roster. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Signed Eddie Brown, wide receiver. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Placed John Dorsey, linebacker. Placed Cedric Gordon, wide receiver, on the developmental roster. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Waived Phillip Brown, linebacker, from injured reserve. PHOENIX (NFC) - Placed Tootie Robbins, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. Signed Shawn Knight, defensive end. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Re-signed Darryl Usher, wide receiver. Waived Leonard Coleman, defensive back. HOCKEY DETROIT (NHL) - Signed Lee Norwood, defenseman, to a multiyear contract.

title: Giants and Redskins Keep the Fans in Mind
description: The Giants had just upset the Redskins, 27-24, Monday night in their National Football League season opener. While the players were still celebrating Raul Allegre's 52-yard game-winning field goal with no time left, Coach Bill Parcells tried to put the victory in perspective.

title: Alphonse Persico, 61, Is Dead; Leader of Colombo Crime Family
description: Alphonse (Allie Boy) Persico, an organized-crime leader who was serving a 25-year Federal sentence, died of cancer of the larynx yesterday at the medical center for Federal prisoners in Springfield, Mo. He was 61 years old.

title: De Klerk Appeals to Marchers
description: On the eve of a major anti-apartheid demonstration planned here, South Africa's Acting President, F. W. de Klerk, appealed to its organizers today to comply with the law, which requires them to get permission first from the Government.

title: Left-Handers Get Higher Than Righties
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Sterling Dies at 82; Author of 8 Books
description: Philip Sterling, a writer and public relations representative, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Wellfleet, Mass. He was 82 years old.

title: Poles Approve Solidarity-Led Cabinet
description: The Polish Parliament today confirmed the first Cabinet not controlled by Communists since the 1940's.

title: Now if Only It Would Pay for the Call
description: A Dallas-based company has developed an electronic operator system that allows people to make collect calls and calls billed to a third party from pay telephones without a human operator. The company, Intellicall Inc., which makes pay phones for private ownership, says its computerized operator system will reduce the need for human operators and save consumers 5 percent to 7 percent on operator-assisted calls made from pay phones.

title: Book Notes
description: Tenpins at Ticknor

title: Giants Had Various Vantage Points, but All Agree: What a Kick!
description: Raul Allegre, who kicked it, knew it would be good if it went far enough. Jeff Hostetler, who held the ball, knew it would be good just from the sound of it. Lawrence Taylor, who was blocking, knew it would be good the moment he watched the ball sail. Mark Bavaro and Steve DeOssie, who were on the sideline, could not even watch it.

title: Dow Chemical Sets Venture With United Technologies
description: The Dow Chemical Company and the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to build plastics, or composite parts, for the aerospace, automotive and military contracting industries.

title: Family-Friendly Employers
description: Last week, seven large New York employers combined to offer emergency child care, at home, for more than 13,000 employees. The program, the first of its kind in the country, is a one-year experiment. But its existence shows how much the workplace is changing to accommodate working parents.

title: Washington Public Power Lifts Offering to $721 Million
description: After initially planning to sell $450 million in refunding revenue bonds for two nuclear reactors that have never been used, the Washington Public Power Supply System tentatively priced a larger $721 million bond issue yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Giuliani Swamps Lauder In G.O.P. Mayoral Primary
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney in Manhattan, decisively won the Republican nomination for mayor yesterday, setting the stage for the first significant attempt to drive the Democratic Party out of City Hall since the 1960's.

title: Jury Finds Gioiosa Guilty
description: A Federal jury today convicted Thomas Gioiosa of participating in a cocaine ring and conspiring to hide Pete Rose's race-track winnings from the Internal Revenue Service. The United States District Court verdict bolsters the Government's case against Rose, who is being investigated by a Federal grand jury in Cincinnati looking into his tax claims.

title: Film Based on the von Bulow Case
description: On a bed in a mansion swarming with cameras and spotlights sits Jeremy Irons as Claus von Bulow, in ascot and stocking feet. He reads as Glenn Close, playing his wife, Sunny, lies beside him, pale and rigid. The director, Barbet Schroeder, shouts, ''Action,'' and Ms. Close lets out a rattling sound deep in her throat.

title: As the Film Credits Roll, So Do the Lies
description: Hundreds of times in my life I have lied to friends, even fairly close friends. I have made a habit of it, in fact, a more or less determined habit. Lie is perhaps too strong a word, but I sure have dissembled, verbally wiggled and soft-pedaled the truth. My voice still elevates a little when I do it, but I have quelled the blushes.

title: 'Help Wanted' Signs Sprout in West as East Germans Continue to Arrive
description: As East Germans continued to stream into this border town, the local paper published a special supplement listing more than 4,000 jobs, many including the offer of an apartment or room.

title: Sri Lankan Woman Slain
description: The sister-in-law of former President J. R. Jayewardene was killed today by two gunmen at a traffic intersection in downtown Colombo, the police said. Though no one claimed responsibility for the killing, the police said they believe the gunmen were members of the People's Liberation Front, a Sinhalese group trying to overthrow the Government.

title: Council Will Recommend Vincent as Commissioner
description: Baseball's executive council voted today to recommend to the owners that Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr. serve as commissioner for the four and a half years of the unexpired term of the late A. Bartlett Giamatti.

title: DRINKING PERSISTS IN VALDEZ CREWS
description: Nearly six months after excessive drinking of alcohol was linked to the nation's worst oil spill, supertanker crew members in the Port of Valdez are still trying to board their vessels while drunk.

title: Judge Issues Literal Gag Order
description: A judge ordered a teen-ager's mouth taped shut for a court session because the youth swore at him in an earlier appearance. The 14-year-old was brought into Juvenile Court before Judge Robert M. Foster on Monday with his hands cuffed, his ankles shackled and a strip of tape over his mouth. He was sentenced to training school for assaulting three workers in one of his 13 earlier sentences to the juvenile detention center.

title: Home Loan Banks' $885 Million Issue
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday priced $885 million in bonds with maturities of one and three years through various securities dealers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD 2 World Bests by Italians: Stefano Lambruschini and Ileana Salvador of Italy had world bests and the hurdler Roger Kingdom earned one of three victories by Americans at the City of Verona meet in Italy yesterday. Lambruschini won the 2,000-meter steeplechase in 5 minutes 18.36 seconds, more than 6 seconds ahead of William Van Dick of Belgium. Salvador walked 2 miles in 13:23.04, surpassing the previous world best of 13:47.8 by another Italian, Giuliana Salce, set in 1987. Neither mark will count as a world record because each was achieved over distances not recognized by the sport's international governing body. Kingdom, the world record-holder, won the 110-meter hurdles in 13.245 seconds, beating his fellow Americans Reinaldo Nehemiah and Eric Cannon. (AP)

title: California County's Bonds for Hospital
description: To finance a new hospital for Riverside County, Calif., the Riverside County Asset Leasing Corporation is tentatively offering about $195 million in lease revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.45 percent for an issue due in 2014. The offering is through the First Boston Corporation.

title: Text of House's Measure to Protect the Flag
description: Following is the text of the bill approved by the House of Representatives today to outlaw the burning or mutilation of the American flag: A BILL

title: On Sake Bottles, More Labels Say 'Made in U.S.A.'
description: AS steam hissed overhead, Teisuke Kainuma looked down into an enormous vat of gleaming finely milled rice.

title: For Black Voters, an Evening of Inspiration and Giddy Celebration
description: Shortly after 9 o'clock last night, the street outside of David N. Dinkins's campaign office in Harlem erupted into cheers, horn-honking and dancing as television stations projected that Mr. Dinkins would win the Democratic mayoral primary.

title: Putting the AIDS Message Where the Trouble Is
description: The scene is intended to be both familiar and ambiguous: An unmarried black couple, somewhere in their late 30's, have just arrived at the man's apartment after a romantic evening. He goes into the kitchen to fix a drink, while the woman nervously reaches into her purse and pulls out a condom packet.

title: U.S. Trade In Services At a Deficit
description: The service and investment sector of the United States economy, where international surpluses have long been relied upon to offset deficits in merchandise trade, is now itself showing red ink.

title: Dissident Priest Urges Boycott of Newspaper
description: A dissident Roman Catholic priest is calling on his followers at a church he organized to boycott The Washington Post and its advertisers in retaliation for articles reporting that he once had a homosexual relationship with an altar boy.

title: Need Should Determine Student Financial Aid; Assistance Is the Norm
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffee Prices Fall on News Of U.S. Stance on Quotas
description: Coffee futures prices plunged yesterday on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on indications the United States will not support a return to international export quotas that would raise coffee prices.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Talks With Bidder
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said it was talking with the DD Acquisition Corporation about providing the hostile bidder with confidential data and arranging a meeting. The disclosure came a day after the Randolph, Mass., doughnut chain rejected DD Acquisition's sweetened $45-a-share takeover offer as inadequate. DD Acquisition, whose bid is worth about $315 million, is a joint venture of the Kingsbridge Capital Corporation, which is a subsidiary of the Unicorp Canada Corporation of Toronto, and Cara Operations Ltd.

title: Rain Forest Defender's Life Story Sold for Film
description: Movie rights to the story of the life and death of the Brazilian defender of the Amazon rain forest Francisco (Chico) Mendes have been sold by his family to Peter Guber and Jon Peters, producers of the summer blockbuster ''Batman'' and of ''Rain Man,'' which won the Academy Award as best picture of 1988.

title: Review/Television; It's Vulnerability That Makes the Man
description: For the better part of a decade, Jack Scalia has been a television star waiting to happen. He may finally have found the right vehicle in ''Wolf,'' the new CBS series being introduced tonight as a two-hour ''World Premiere Movie.'' The show's regular time will be Tuesdays at 9 P.M.

title: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: A Sense of Quiet Strength; Dinkins Triumph Is Built on Dissatisfaction With Koch and on an Unthreatening Image
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch was decisively transformed yesterday from a campaign underdog into a lame duck, but the metamorphosis began some months ago.

title: Helms Amendment Is Facing A Major Test in Congress
description: After months of debate over how the National Endowment for the Arts should be permitted to spend taxpayers' money on culture in America, the legislative battle will be renewed today in the House of Representatives. Both sides in the dispute are convinced the stakes are high, involving issues of artistic freedom and censorship, the proper role of government in the arts and the right, if any, of taxpayers not to have to pay for art they abhor.

title: New Line of Wang Minicomputers
description: In an effort to retain its waning customer base, Wang Laboratories Inc. introduced a new line of minicomputers yesterday, the VS 8000 series, that the company said was three times more powerful than its current VS 7000 systems.

title: Home Rule Giving Way to Joint Plans
description: For three years, 20 Bergen County fire departments have been saving money on new equipment by joining a common purchasing plan. Last fall, officials from 50 of the county's 70 towns met in Ridgefield Park to discuss rising garbage costs.

title: All but 1 of Council Incumbents in Race Are Renominated
description: The new City Council that will take office in January is likely to receive extraordinary new powers, and Council members, mindful of their reputation for somnolence, have already begun planning for the transition.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: House Passes Rewritten Law Barring Flag Burning
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today to outlaw flag burning in the aftermath of the Supreme Court's decision that such acts are protected under the First Amendment.

title: Corrections
description: A report in ''At the Nation's Table'' in The Living Section last Wednesday about the restaurant Postrio in San Francisco misidentified the executive chefs. They are David and Anne Gingrass.

title: New Twist In Bidding For Utility
description: The maneuvering to end the 20-month bankruptcy of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire took an unanticipated and complex twist yesterday, as the bidding for the beleaguered electric system moved in opposite directions.

title: Intel Chip Does 2 Jobs At Once
description: The Intel Corporation introduced a computer microprocessor today that employs a breakthrough technology enabling it to perform two tasks at once.

title: New Jersey, in 5 Years, Solves Teacher Shortage
description: Four years ago, facing teacher shortages and a declining quality of instructors, New Jersey education officials started an experimental program to hire recent college graduates and mid-career professionals who have skills but who have not gone through teacher certification procedures.

title: INSIDE
description: A New Trade Deficit The service and investment sector of the economy, which has shown a surplus for about 30 years, posted a deficit in the second quarter. Page D10. Bush Meets Yeltsin Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was received by President Bush in a brief visit to the White House. Page A6. Handling 'Me Me' Guests The national preoccupation with dietary restrictions is turning the American dinner party into an a la carte event. Page C1. Protecting the Flag In an effort to stall the drive for a constitutional amendment, the House voted overwhelmingly to outlaw flag burning. Page A26.

title: Bravery and Service Medals For Young in '88 Announced
description: A girl who saved a tourist from drowning in Hawaii and a California youth who disarmed a fellow student holding 70 people hostage will receive the 1988 Young American Medals for Bravery, the Justice Department has announced.

title: Phil Simms's New Arsenal Of Weapons
description: Raul Allegre's 52-yard field goal as time expired had produced a 27-24 victory over the Redskins, what Lawrence Taylor described as the Giants' ''biggest win'' since their Super Bowl XXI triumph. But now, in the midnight celebration in Washington, Coach Bill Parcells was assessing how Phil Simms, starting from the Giants' 29-yard-line with only 44 seconds remaining, had directed the drive that put the ball just inside their place-kicker's range.

title: Menus That Work for All Guests
description: SEVERAL caterers were recently presented with this typical but hypothetical request: ''I am entertaining 20 people whom I do not know well. Price is no object. Can you design a menu that is impressive but will not pose a problem for people on restricted diets?''

title: Dutch Premier Fails to Form A Center-Right Government
description: Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers's initial efforts to form a center-right government were dashed today when a small centrist party snubbed his offer to join a three-party coalition.

title: New Unit at Hearst
description: Seeking greater publishing opportunities abroad, the Hearst Corporation said last week that it would create a new operating unit, Hearst Magazines International. The unit will concentrate on building markets for Hearst publications in Europe, Latin America and Asia and will be headed by George J. Green, an executive vice president of the magazine division.

title: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed
description: The prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in continued sluggish trading yesterday. For the second straight session, short- to intermediate-term issues outperformed longer-dated securities.

title: Incumbent Democrat Wins Mayoral Primary in Yonkers
description: Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko of Yonkers won his Democratic primary today, moving into a general election that is expected to revolve around whether the city should comply with a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.

title: Dinkins and Friends Exult in Victory
description: Not long after the image of Mayor Edward I. Koch faded from a giant television screen above the Hotel Penta Grand Ballroom just after midnight, David N. Dinkins mounted the stage to the cheers of several thousand supporters to claim victory in the Democratic mayoral primary.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE FOR THE PREPARATION OF THE INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DONORS TO CAMBODIA HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE PROGRAM - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Cubs Extend Streak On Bielecki's Shutout
description: Mike Bielecki pitched a two-hitter and Vance Law scored from third base on a passed ball to snap a scoreless tie in the fifth inning tonight as the first-place Chicago Cubs beat the Montreal Expos, 2-0.

title: GTE Unit Prices Mortgage Bonds
description: The General Telephone Company of the South, a unit of the GTE Corporation, yesterday priced $100 million in 9 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2029 through competitive bidding.

title: No Timeout for Knicks' Coach
description: From the day Stu Jackson became the Knicks' head coach in July, his thoughts have been directed toward next season.

title: A Crowd on Defense As Devils Get Ready
description: The Devils' two Soviet defensemen will not play in the team's first exhibition game Saturday, but are expected to make their debut next week in Madison Square Garden.

title: Lawmakers Urge Congress to Review Navy's Inquiry on Battleship
description: Two lawmakers said today that they wanted Congress to review the Navy's investigation of the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa and the serious mismanagement of the ship that investigators said they uncovered in the four-month inquiry.

title: Dow Advances by 2.85 as Volume Rises
description: Stock prices edged up on a broad front yesterday as volume rose moderately.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Executive Named At Nationwide Health
description: LEAD: R. Bruce Andrews, an investor and former chief financial officer of American Medical International Inc., has been named president and chief executive of Nationwide Health Properties Inc., a California-based real estate investment trust that owns 100 health care facilities worth about $300 million.

title: Court Victory For Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that an appeals court had reversed a decision that required the company to pay more than $412 million to the Coastal Corporation, a Houston-based gas and oil company. Occidental said the United

title: About Education
description: ''I didn't take it as a job but as a mission.'' ''It'' was the presidency of Brown Unversity. The speaker, Vartan Gregorian.

title: Making the Town Dump Sanitary
description: Giant earth-moving machines growl across a hillside, gouging a huge gash in the ground. Along the bottom of the hole, other equipment is spreading and compacting a thick layer of clay. Later, layers of plastic sheeting will be added and a network of pipes installed, all to insure that no water seeps into the local water table.

title: Learning Conditions in U.S. Get C-Plus on 'Report Card'
description: American students have little incentive to achieve good grades, the head of the nation's largest school administrators' group says.

title: Give the Poor Better Choices Than Drug Dealing and Addiction; Dangers of Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Voting Machines: If We Find 'Em, We'll Fix 'Em
description: It takes 22,000 people to run an election in New York City, which is like bringing in the entire populations of Garden City, L.I., or Emporia, Kan., and having them make sure that everyone who goes into the voting booths comes out. New York City did not do that. But it did bring in John Miers, who is 1/10,337th of the population of De Ridder, La.

title: Spitz to Try Again
description: Mark Spitz, who won a record seven gold medals in the 1972 Olympic Games, says he will attempt to qualify for the 1992 Games at Barcelona, Spain, in the 100-meter butterfly, according to an article in USA Today yesterday. Spitz, who would be 42 years old by the next Olympics, was quoted as having said he was training for the United States Olympic Trials, which will be held in two and a half years. U.S. Swimming Inc. officials have confirmed that Spitz was reinstated as an eligible competitor by FINA, the governing body for world aquatic sports. In recent years, Spitz has been involved in real estate and the manufacturing of children's clothing. (AP)

title: S.E.C. Exempts Bond Offering
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has exempted from its registration requirements a $30 billion bond offering planned for next month by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created by Congress last month to resolve the problems of insolvent savings institutions.

title: Becker Insures Himself
description: A spokesman for Lloyds of London who requested anonymity said yesterday in London that Boris Becker, the West German player who added the United States Open men's singles title to his Wimbledon crown last weekend, had taken out a $10 million policy against being kidnapped. The spokesman said Becker was paying $160,000 a year for the policy. (AP)

title: Start Deferred Could Be Start Denied
description: The Bush Administration seems to be deliberately going nowhere in strategic arms talks with the Soviets even while actively pursuing an East-West agreement to reduce conventional forces in Europe. Its eagerness for conventional cuts is laudable, but not its inclination to slow Start.

title: Mets Now At Brink of 'Wait Till Next Year'
description: The Mets had the best of both worlds tonight: Dwight Gooden in the bullpen and ready to pitch for the first time in two and a half months, and Frank Viola on the mound pitching one-run ball into the ninth inning against the last-place Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Food Notes
description: A Day for Nibbling

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: EAST BERLIN TELLS BUDAPEST TO HALT AID TO EMIGRATION
description: East Germany demanded today that Hungary stop allowing East Germans to flee to the West, and a visiting Soviet Politburo member accused West Germany of encouraging the departure of about 10,000 East Germans in the past two days.

title: No Quid Pro Sweat
description: I saw in the paper that most college basketball and football players don't graduate. I was shocked. So shocked that I went personally to Buck Backbreaker, athletic director of my alma mater, dear old Alma Mater U. There were tears in my eyes when I intercepted him outside his office. ''Say it ain't so, Buck,'' I said. ''You're wasting my time,'' he said after feeling my biceps and giving me a brutal punch in the stomach to see if my abdominals were like iron.

title: Red Sox Lose Burks
description: The Boston Red Sox, who have slipped out of the American League Eastern Division race, have lost their regular center fielder, Ellis Burks, for the rest of the season. Burks separated his right shoulder in a collision with the Boston left fielder, Mike Greenwell, last week in Oakland, Calif. Burks was sidelined from June 14 until Aug. 1 after injuring his left shoulder while diving for a ball. Burks was hitting .303 with 12 homers, 61 runs batted in and 21 stolen bases.(AP)

title: Thomas Cox Allen, Pilot, 82
description: Thomas Cox Allen, one of the first black pilots to fly across the United States, died at Presbyterian Hospital on Monday after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Oklahoma City.

title: A Food Historian Works To Give the Dutch Their Due
description: AS autumn approaches in the northern reaches of the Hudson Valley, leaf-seekers are likely to find reminders of the original Dutch settlers all over - in the nearby cities of Amsterdam and Rotterdam, in local roads with names like Ten Broeck Street and in the city's basketball team, the Patroons, named for the region's early Dutch landowners.

title: Consumer Data for College Athletes
description: The proposed Student-Athlete Right to Know Act sounds unassailable. It would require every college or university that accepts Federal money to disclose the graduation rates of its athletic scholarship recipients. Yet this measure - no more than a consumer information statute - was stymied in Congress last year. It warrants passage this year.

title: Give the Poor Better Choices Than Drug Dealing and Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Charles E. Goshen, Psychiatrist, 72
description: Charles Ernest Goshen, psychiatrist and professor emeritus of Vanderbilt University, in Nashville, died of a heart attack Aug. 29 at his home in Glenwood, Md. He was 72 years old.

title: PANEL ANNOUNCES INQUIRY ON FRANK
description: The House ethics committee voted today to open a preliminary investigation into the conduct of Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat who has acknowledged employing a male prostitute as a personal assistant.

title: Democratic Reply on Drugs: Commit Another $2.2 Billion
description: In the first major Congressional response to President Bush's drug strategy, Senate Democrats today proposed trimming other Government programs to come up with $2.2 billion more for anti-drug efforts than the President has already proposed.

title: Bulls Land Armstrong
description: B. J. Armstrong, a 6-foot-2-inch guard from the University of Iowa who was the second pick of the Chicago Bulls in the N.B.A. college draft this year, signed a contract yesterday. No terms were disclosed. . . . In another signing, Tom Hammonds, the former Georgia Tech forward who was the first pick of the Washington Bullets in the draft, received a multiyear contract with the team after entertaining an offer from a team in Salonika, Greece. (AP)

title: BUILDERS PROPOSE HOMELESS PROJECT
description: A construction industry group has proposed building a $6.9 million complex of apartments to house the homeless on surplus Federal land, but opponents of the idea say the complex would be little more than a concentration camp.

title: Saks Kicks Off Fall Season From a New Venue
description: THE multifaceted celebration called SFA/USA with which Saks Fifth Avenue traditionally opens the fall fashion season took place in Lincoln Center last night.

title: Lucille Roberts Legerdemain
description: The Lucille Roberts Health Spas account is rapidly becoming the ad industry's equivalent of ''Now you see it, now you don't.''

title: Yugoslav Communists Anticipate Competition
description: The Yugoslav Communist Party has suggested that the nation's Constitution should no longer enshrine the party's leading role in society.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Western Corp., Sioux Falls, S.D., which makes plastic bags, agreed to be acquired by Carlisle Plastics Inc., Boston, for $13 a share, or about $73 million.

title: Another Contender For Top Job at Grace
description: When W. R. Grace & Company named three vice chairmen three years ago, establishing a group of candidates to succeed J. Peter Grace, no one knew how long Mr. Grace would remain chairman.

title: Review/Music; Catskill Chamber Players In Works of Many Roots
description: The Catskill Chamber Players, an ensemble from the Catskill Conservatory in Oneonta, N.Y., devoted a Sunday afternoon concert at Weill Recital Hall to music by Frank Bennett. Mr. Bennett, now on the faculty of the University of California at Los Angeles, was associated with the Catskill Conservatory for more than a decade.

title: Rejection of a Bid Appears to Assure Closing of Reactor
description: The demise of the Rancho Seco nuclear reactor in California was apparently assured on Monday night when the board of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, the agency that owns it, voted unanimously to reject the only bid to take it over and resume nuclear operations.

title: A Revamping Likely at B.P.
description: The British Petroleum Company is expected to announce a restructuring of its exploration and production operations that could involve the sale of $1 billion or more worth of assets.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There's nothing like a tough primary to toughen you up.

title: Mountain Lion Kills Boy
description: A 5-year-old boy last seen riding his tricycle near his home was killed by a mountain lion that was later tracked down and killed, the authorities said Monday. The body of the boy, Jake Gardipe, was found Sunday night just 30 yards from his home two miles north of this tiny community in mountainous western Montana.

title: Human Activity Is Found to Harm Wildlife Areas
description: The wildlife on Federal preserves is being harmed by human activities ranging from water-skiing to military dogfight practice, Congressional investigators reported today.

title: Smiling Soviet Visitor Meets Bush And Proves Deft in Capital's Ways
description: The White House doors opened, somewhat gingerly, for Boris N. Yeltsin today, as President Bush briefly greeted the Soviet politician and reiterated his support for perestroika.

title: Smithsonian to Give Up Indian Remains
description: The Smithsonian Institution agreed today to return the skeletal remains of thousands of American Indians to their tribes for reburial in their homelands, resolving a dispute that pitted the research needs of scientists against the anguish of Indians who say their ancestors have been desecrated.

title: Edwards Dropped As Manager of Indians
description: With his team 14 1/2 games out of first place in the American League Eastern Division after losing 24 of its last 35 games, Doc Edwards was dismissed yesterday as manager of the Cleveland Indians after a little more than two years on the job. Edwards, 52 years old, had replaced Pat Corrales. Last year, in his first full season, the Indians went 78-84, an improvement of 17 victories. This year, the Indians were only a game and a half out of first with a 54-54 record on Aug. 4, but then they went into a tailspin. Edwards's record as Indians manager was 173-207. Edwards will be replaced on an interim basis by John Hart, a special assignment scout who was third-base coach last season at Baltimore before being brought to Cleveland. (AP)

title: John S. Chapman Jr., a Lawyer, Dies at 91
description: John S. Chapman Jr., a lawyer for 69 years in Manhattan, died of cardiopulmunary arrest Monday at his home in Tuckahoe, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

title: For a Sad Koch They Play 'New York'
description: With a brave wave and a sad smile, Mayor Edward I Koch declared last night that ''there is a life after the mayoralty.''

title: What Went Wrong in New York's Services for Children at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Walker, 81, an Orchestrator Of Broadway Musical Comedies
description: Don Walker, a musician who did the orchestration for dozens of Broadway shows, died yesterday at Mercer Medical Center in Trenton after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in New Hope, Pa.

title: WPP Hollywood Deal
description: WPP Group P.L.C. turned its sights on Hollywood yesterday, announcing it would acquire Seiniger Advertising, a motion picture advertising agency in Los Angeles. WPP, the British owner of Ogilvy & Mather and J. Walter Thompson, said it would pay up to $30 million for Seiniger. WPP already has a presence in the movie advertising market through a subsidiary, JWT Entertainment Group.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Democratic primary for District Attorney in Brooklyn misidentified the publisher of The Amsterdam News.

title: In Phone Strike, Coping Is Very Big on Campus
description: For students at New York University, the talk this week is not so much about science requirements or Friday night dates as about who knows the closest working pay telephone and what is the best way to get a phone installed.

title: Too Much Opinion, at the Expense of Fact
description: If Walter Lippmann were alive, he probably would wonder how the media had come to find themselves in league with government, helping shape public attitudes rather than questioning, examining and describing the real world to the fullest extent possible.

title: Why Dokes Lost His Chance to Fight Tyson
description: As Mike Tyson's next opponent, Razor Ruddock has a million-dollar payday awaiting him, and Michael Dokes does not.

title: Books of The Times; On a Cross-Country Drive With a Blind Elderly Driver
description: The Widows' Adventures By Charles Dickinson William Morrow. 381 pages. $18.95.

title: Robert Charles Wallis, Epidemiologist, 68
description: Robert Charles Wallis, an epidemiologist and professor at the Yale University School of Medicine, died last Wednesday at Yale-New Haven Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived in North Haven, Conn.

title: Buddhist-Muslim Feud Divides an Indian Territory
description: A mass campaign of civil disobedience in the once-peaceable mountain valleys of Ladakh has brought India's traditionally nonviolent Buddhist minority to the edge of revolt.

title: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Show Drop
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to show small declines for the week that ended yesterday.

title: U.S. Inspection Leads to Lilly Recall
description: Eli Lilly & Company said today that it was recalling 18 lots of 10 drugs from wholesalers and stopping distribution of all products from an Indianapolis plant because of manufacturing problems found in a Federal inspection.

title: People
description: * Karen Ritchie has been named senior vice president and director of media services at McCann-Erickson/ Detroit.

title: Once More (Sigh), The Plum Torte
description: FOR the last six years the plum torte column, written in response to repeated demands for the recipe, has heralded the end of summer.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Eating Well
description: THOUGH it's hard to recall now, eggs once had high status. They were thought of as a wholesome, natural and nutritious food. But no more.

title: William Johnston, 67; Ran Shipping Bureau
description: William N. Johnston, a marine engineer and business executive, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: CNN Plans Newscast
description: The Cable News Network said yesterday that it would begin a one-hour evening newscast to compete directly with the network newscasts beginning next month.

title: Mona Ewell, Intelligence Analyst, 36
description: Mona Ewell, an intelligence analyst at the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, died of leukemia Sunday at Fairfax Hospital in Fairfax, Va. She was 36 years old and lived in Sterling, Va.

title: Hewlett Introduces New Laser Printer
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced its lowest-priced laser printer yet, the HP Laserjet IIP, which will list for $1,495. With discounts, the new machine could sell for as low as $1,000. Hewlett will continue to make the Laserjet Series II, which is priced at $2,695 but is commonly available for $1,700 to $1,800.

title: U.S. Seizes Danish Ship And a Ton of Cocaine
description: Federal officials said today that they had confiscated more than a ton of Colombian cocaine, a Danish freighter and several boats in the biggest narcotics seizure since President Bush announced his anti-drug strategy a week ago.

title: Japan Inflation Is Lowest
description: Japan had the lowest inflation rate among industrialized countries last year - 1 percent - while Peru had the worst with 1,722 percent, a United Nations agency said today. The Netherlands, with 1.2 percent, was second to Japan, followed by West Germany, with 1.6 percent.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Narrows by 31%
description: A surge in oil imports, robust domestic demand and a strong dollar helped narrow Japan's trade surplus by 31 percent in August, and economists here say the trend should continue for the rest of 1989.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about the fatal shooting of a man accused in a Federal racketeering case was published in error. It showed the scene of the murder of Duane Lewis, an 18-year-old student killed in Brooklyn, and not the scene of the murder of Fred E. Weiss on Staten Island.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT may be coincidental, but the season for wine making is also the season for wine buying. All the wine, at least in the Northern Hemisphere, will have been made in the next month or so; similarly, some 75 percent of all wine purchases for the year will be made between now and New Year's Eve, the busiest social season of the year.

title: Need Should Determine Student Financial Aid; Vets Benefits Ending
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts of Koch Concession And Dinkins Victory Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Edward I. Koch's concession speech and Borough President David N. Dinkins's victory speech as recorded by The New York Times. Dinkins

title: 2 Drug War Suspects Are Freed in Colombia
description: A judge has released two suspected cocaine traffickers for lack of evidence, officials said today.

title: Philip L. Boyd, Politician, 88
description: Philip L. Boyd, the first Mayor of Palm Springs, died at Eisenhower Mecical Center in Rancho Mirage Saturday after suffering a fall. He was 88 years old.

title: David Dinkins, With a Roar
description: What a stunning victory - more decisive than anyone anticipated. David Dinkins toppled Ed Koch, the man who has held the title so long that ''Mayor'' and ''Koch'' blurred into one word, the politician who dared try for an unprecedented fourth term. Mr. Dinkins stopped him - by offering New Yorkers everything the Mayor is not.

title: A Chemical-Free Cornucopia
description: TOWARD the middle of August, Ken Ryan's panel truck finally died. Until the moment of its demise, the mottled green truck, a 1970 Chevrolet, had performed faithfully. Every Tuesday and Friday since early summer, it had made a 100-mile round trip with Mr. Ryan at the wheel, carrying vibrantly fresh, often exotic, produce from his four-acre farm here to chefs at a dozen of Boston's most celebrated restaurants.

title: Zsa Zsa Gabor's Trial Is On, Amid a Flurry of Attention
description: When Zsa Zsa Gabor arrived in court Monday for the opening of her trial on charges of slapping a police officer, she was accompanied by her hairdresser, her daughter and her eighth husband, and was greeted by about 100 reporters. Today, as jury selection continued, the audience was far smaller, only about 20 people.

title: Police Acted Properly in Shooting at Roadblock, Agency Concludes
description: The State's Attorney's Office has ruled that New Canaan police officers acted properly two months ago when they fired 12 shots into a car, wounding its three occupants, after it tried to run a roadblock.

title: REVIVAL IS URGED FOR WIDER I.R.A.'s
description: Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today proposed a restoration of widely available, tax-deductible individual retirement accounts as an alternative to President Bush's plan to lower the tax rate on capital gains.

title: Vitro Is Refusing To Hold Bid Price
description: Vitro S.A. has refused to agree not to lower its offer for the Anchor Glass Container Corporation. Anchor Glass had said it would allow the Mexican concern to review its confidential financial information if Vitro agreed not to reduce its bid of $20 a share, or $280 million.

title: Jets' Walker to Miss At Least Six Games
description: Wesley Walker, the Jets' dangerous but injury-prone wide receiver, will miss at least the next six games after being placed on the injured-reserve list yesterday.

title: Give the Poor Better Choices Than Drug Dealing and Addiction; Remember Prohibition
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington at Work; Emotions in Check, Intellect Not, Sununu Wins Reluctant Respect in Capital
description: Talk to people who talk all the time to John H. Sununu and the word they use most often to describe him is ''focused.''

title: Economic Scene; Talk Is Cheap, Dollars Dear
description: IF President Bush decided to order tail lights for the Stealth bomber or buy a scrimshaw collection for the National Gallery, he would first have to convince Congress. But there is no such restraint on the unelected Government officials who spent $12 billion this summer to hold down the exchange value of the dollar - and kept it secret until last week.

title: Bridge
description: France and Brazil edged ahead of their rivals today in the qualifying stage of the world team championships, with Australia and Taiwan in pursuit. The Brazilians won an important match tonight by beating the Australians 20-10.

title: 60-minute Gourmet
description: LOIN of pork is a particularly versatile asset in the arsenal of a time-pressed home cook. When trimmed of fat and cut into serving portions, pork loin can be used in countless recipes that require little fussing.

title: Go After Companies That Abuse Pension Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Rheometrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included foreign currency losses of $474,000 and $358,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included foreign currency gains of $7,000 and $148,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share-earning computation does not reflect the assumed exercise of stock options, since the effect of such inclusion would be immaterial. The per share amounts have been computed giving retroactive effect to the 10-percent common stock dividend declared Feb. 17, 1989.

title: HEALTH: Ophthalmology; Smoking of Cigarettes Is Linked for First Time To a Form of Cataracts
description: For the first time, researchers have found evidence linking cigarette smoking and the formation of cataracts.

title: Mecklowitz Seeks to Stay Chancellor
description: Schools Chancellor Bernard Mecklowitz, who earlier said he did not want to be considered for the job beyond December, when his contract ends, said yesterday that he has changed his mind and become a candidate.

title: Stuarts Dept Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Laura Ashley Expanding Into Department Stores
description: OVER the last five years, a staggering number of Laura Ashley stores, featuring the late designer's sweet version of the English country style, have opened in large cities around the world. In fact, there are now 500 shops, from Los Angeles to Tokyo.

title: Kirstein, 82, To Retire As Director Of City Ballet
description: Lincoln Kirstein announced yesterday that he would retire on Nov. 1 as the New York City Ballet's general director and as the president of the School of American Ballet.

title: Fed Further Widens Rights Of Banks to Sell Securities
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday opened the door to further expansion of banking companies into the corporate securities market by allowing them to sell and trade securities backed by loans of their affiliated banks.

title: Ingram Named to Post
description: Cecil W. (Hootie) Ingram, an all-Southeastern Conference football and basketball star at the University of Alabama in 1952-54, was named athletic director at his alma mater. Ingram, who for the last nine years was the director of athletics at Florida State University, called his selection ''a dream come true.''

title: U.S. Expects Chemical-Arms Accord
description: Administration officials say they expect to sign an agreement on chemical weapons verification during a meeting next week between the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.

title: Unexpected Fat in Fast-Food Menus
description: Would you believe that a fast-food chicken sandwich has as much fat as a pint and a half of ice cream, or that half a dozen chicken nuggets are fattier than a hamburger?

title: Just a Comfy Country Couple and Their Objets d' Art
description: HE'S a photographer, art collector, artist and writer. She's a physical-fitness expert. They drive a red Isuzu Trooper and have been vegetarians for 12 years. This summer Michael and Deborah McKenzie moved into their new country house.

title: China's Repression: 'Purified' Journalism
description: LEAD: Who or what was behind the democracy movement that rocked Communist China this spring? Party officials blame ''rumor-mongers'' among others. Advocates of free expression in China have been demoted, fired or sent to jail. The recent dismissal of Wang Meng, the Culture Minister, is indicative of the repression.

title: Jones Spacelink Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The results for all periods represented consolidated results for Jones Spacelink and its Jones Intercable Inc. and Jones Group Ltd. subsidiaries.

title: From Bulbous to Saucerlike, Innovative Shapes in Basketry
description: ''THE Tactile Vessel: New Basket Forms,'' which opened Aug. 29 at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan, stretches all notions of the medium. The 32 baskets on view are fashioned from an astonishing variety of materials, employing innovative techniques beyond traditional coiling, twining and interlacing.

title: Destruction of Our Schools and Fear in the Streets Are Connected
description: To the Editor:

title: Sensor Control Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $66,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: This Time, the Other Stottlemyre Might Provide Playoff Tickets
description: The balance of playoff power in the Stottlemyre household may be on the verge of changing.

title: Dukakis Offers Plan to Fight Discrimination in Mortgages
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis announced a plan today to make sure there is no discrimination in mortgage lending, including expanded enforcement and new legislation to give regulators more powers.

title: New Hazard Is Seen at Colorado Weapons Plant
description: Colorado's effort to protect drinking water supplies around the highly contaminated Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant has raised a new safety problem: what to do with tainted water that is filling a storage pond now that the state has barred releases from it.

title: Dow Loses 27.74 Points to Close at 2,679.52
description: Stocks dropped sharply yesterday, as weaker bond and dollar prices prompted a late round of program trading.

title: Lorenz Graham, 87, Children's-Book Writer
description: Lorenz Graham, a prize-winning author of children's books, died of cancer Monday in the Hospice of the East San Gabriel Valley in West Covina, Calif. He was 87 years old and lived in Claremont, Calif.

title: Go After Companies That Abuse Pension Funds; Look to Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: Help Nicaragua's Democrats, Openly
description: Early next year, Nicaraguans will at last be able to register a meaningful choice about their political future in free, internationally observed elections. A coalition of democratic parties is now preparing to challenge the Sandinista regime in accordance with the Central American peace agreement.

title: Pittsburgh Prices Unlimited Bonds
description: The City of Pittsburgh priced $60 million in improvement unlimited tax bonds yesterday through competitive bidding.

title: SENATE WEIGHS BAN ON FLIGHT SMOKING
description: Temporarily frustrated by the parliamentary maneuvers of tobacco-state lawmakers, who are outnumbered but determined, the Senate today debated but did not vote on a measure that would permanently ban smoking on all domestic airline flights.

title: Foster Child Declared Brain Dead; Police Investigate Possible Abuse
description: A 2-year-old girl in foster care who was brought into a Queens hospital Monday evening with bruises and abrasions on her head and face has been declared brain dead, the police said yesterday.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A DAY after I moved into a new neighborhood, a preschooler who lives down the block came over to say hello. Within seconds he was telling me about his new baby sister, Katy. I asked the boy how old he was.

title: Seamus Twomey, 70, a Leader of Provisional I.R.A.
description: Seamus Twomey, a leader of the Irish Republican Army, died Tuesday in a Dublin hospital. He was 70 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: Hampton on Hampton: A Dislike of Pretension
description: LEAD: PEOPLE who know Mark Hampton primarily for his blend of pomp and coziness will soon get to meet a parade of hitherto-undreamed-of Hamptons. Next Thursday marks the publication of the designer's first book, ''Mark Hampton on Decorating'' (Random House, $24.95).

title: Neuharth on Neuharth: Plotter, and Proud of It
description: In the course of a lengthy career at the Gannett Company, Allen H. Neuharth schemed to remove his mentor, eavesdropped on a rival, manipulated his colleagues and board, and fumbled a merger with CBS because, as he puts it, his ego outran his brain.

title: Citicorp Auction Rates Down Again
description: For the second consecutive week, interest rates fell at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Aileen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: Proler International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Per-share amounts for the year-ago periods are adjusted to reflect a 3-for- 1 stock split.

title: A Panel Backs Punishment Therapy
description: A Federal panel of experts on treatments for retarded or disturbed people who repeatedly injure themselves said yesterday that punishments like electric shock or pinches were acceptable therapy to discourage the destructive behavior.

title: Dart Group Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $223,000 from the repurchase of debt. c-After an extraordinary loss of $108,000 from the repurchase of debt and a tax loss carryforward of $2,826,000, or $1.54 a share. The results included Jumbo Food Stores Inc. consolidated since date of acquisition June 30, 1988.

title: The Vote for Mayor and Comptroller, District by District
description: (NOTE: This table may be divided, and additional information on a particular entry may appear on more than one screen.)

title: Bush Agrees to Compromise On Financing of Drug Plan
description: The Bush Administration agreed today to small across-the-board cuts in Federal programs to raise money for fighting drugs, rather than deeper cuts in just a handful of specific programs.

title: 2 NOMINEES CLASH IN RACE FOR MAYOR WITH HARSH WORDS
description: David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani began the battle yesterday for the middle ground of undecided and independent voters, exchanging harsh attacks only hours after winning the Democratic and Republican primaries for mayor.

title: Randolph Guthrie, 83, Lawyer and Executive
description: Randolph H. Guthrie, a lawyer, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 83 years old and was a longtime resident of New York City.

title: Joyner's Single in 10th Gives Angels a Lift
description: Wally Joyner, who won a game for the California Angels in the ninth inning Tuesday night, won another tonight when he singled through the right side of the infield to beat the Yankees, 4-3, in the 10th inning.

title: Campaign Trail; A New Hurrah in the Democratic Party Girds for Battle to Take City Hall
description: As David N. Dinkins mounted the stage in the Penta Hotel's grand ballroom on primary election night, an exultant smile creasing his face, he was surrounded by the labor leaders, liberals and black politicians who over the last decade have come to constitute a muncipal government in exile in New York City.

title: From an Armful of Twigs, A Choice of Furnishings
description: ONE answer to the rising cost of furniture is to make it yourself, a task that is often easier said than done. Yet Abby Ruoff, a furniture designer, says even a novice can fashion a lamp table or settee out of twigs.

title: Campbell Soup Co Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4.1 million for the quarter and year related to the planned closure of its soup production facility in Portage La Prairie, Man., in January 1991. c-After an extraordinary credit of $3.5 million, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Iona Appliances reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the latest year's loss was partly due to about $830,000 of non-recurring expenses related to its new carpet dry cleaning machine, inventory provisions and other expenses. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Smithsonian Institution's agreement to return skeletons of American Indians to their tribes repeated an earlier error regarding the American Anthropological Association. The association, which has no such bones in its possession, has never taken a position on the issue but has designated a commission, including two anthropologists who are American Indians, to recommend a policy for adoption at its annual meeting in November 1990.

title: Westerbeke Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: A Personal Shopper, for Any Quest
description: DO you need a dinner setting for 12? A wardrobe for your first job? A wok for the kitchen? Susan Guth and Nancy Missett will buy them for you.

title: 2 Ex-Transit Officers Sentenced To 2-Year Terms for False Arrests
description: Two former New York City transit police officers convicted in March of making false sex-abuse arrests were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of two years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom's Dutch Unit
description: The Omnicom Group said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Boulet Dru DuPuy Petit, a French agency, for B.D.D.P. to acquire a majority interest in Omnicom's Dutch subsidiary, ARA. The terms of the deal, under which Omnicom will maintain a 15 percent interest in ARA, were not disclosed. Omnicom said it had sold the stake to focus on its two worldwide agency networks, DDB Needham and BBDO. In June, Omnicom defeated B.D.D.P. in a battle to acquire Boase Massimi Pollitt Partners, a British agency.

title: Calendar: The History of Parks
description: In the Parks, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6871.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 1 about Lech Walesa's comments on Solidarity's ninth anniversary referred incorrectly to Jan Nowak, a wartime resistance hero. He chronicled his wartime experiences under the nom de guerre Jan Nowak (the name by which he is now known), not Jan Karski. Mr. Karski is another writer who documented the Polish resistance.

title: Bond Sells Off His Lonrho Stake
description: The Australian business executive Alan Bond sold his 20.4 percent stake in the British trading conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. to financial institutions at a price of $:2.80 ($4.34) each. The Bond holding totaled 114.3 million shares; Lonrho has about 560 million shares outstanding.

title: Thor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. and India Sign Tax Pact
description: After 30 years of negotiations, India and the United States signed an agreement yesterday to avoid double taxation, and American officials said today that the accord could set a precedent for tax relations between the United States and other developing nations.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: The New York Primary; For Koch, Sigh of Relief; For Aides, Tight Smiles
description: For a last hurrah, it sounded distinctly like a sigh of relief.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SEALING a house against drafts is important year round, but it is especially crucial in cool or cold weather.

description: To the Editor:

title: Riley's Datashare Internaional reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Birthday Party at Bemelmans for Madeline, at 50
description: Madeline is 50 now, though she looks as small as ever in her portrait on the wall of the Bemelmans Bar at the Carlyle Hotel. Indeed, this elegant Manhattan establishment isn't exactly ''an old house in Paris, covered with vines,'' where ''lived 12 little girls in two straight lines.'' Those words are familiar to millions of little girls, past and present, who have read ''Madeline,'' Ludwig Bemelmans's children's classic.

title: INSIDE
description: Veto on Fighter Sustained Senators failed by one vote to override a veto of limits on U.S.-Japan production of the FSX. Page D1. Arrest in Brooklyn Slaying The police charged a man with the murder of Maria Hernandez, who fought against drug dealers. Page B1. Strike at City Opera The City Opera's orchestra, in a contract dispute, walked out on opening night of the fall season. Page C19. New Baseball Chief Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr., a former movie studio executive who served as A. Bartlett Giamatti's deputy, was elected by the major league owners as the eighth commissioner of baseball. Page D25.

title: Senate Sustains Bush Veto Of Limits on Japan Jet Deal
description: The Senate failed today by one vote to override President Bush's veto of Congressional restrictions on the joint American-Japanese production of an advanced jet fighter.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, excerpts from Mayor Edward I. Koch's concession speech in some copies yesterday carried an incomplete reference to the winner of the New York City Democratic primary. Mr. Koch said: ''I just called David

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about President Bush's broadcast on drugs to schoolchildren misidentified the school shown. It was the Signal Hill School in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Jewelmasters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income and the 6 months included an accounting adjustment gain of $106,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Chrysler in Europe
description: The Chrysler Corporation, the No. 3 United States car maker, expects to ship about 50,000 vehicles to Europe this year and could double the figure within two years, its chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said. Chrysler sold 31,000 vehicles in Europe last year, its first full year of sales, and revenues from Europe have already passed $1 billion, he told reporters attending the Frankfurt Auto Show. Mr. Iacocca spoke at the European introduction of the Chrysler Saratoga, a five-seat, four-speed sedan with either a 3-liter V-6 or a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine.

title: Cash-Flow Problems For Campeau
description: The gravity of the Campeau Corporation's financial problems became clearer yesterday as the Canadian company reported that for the rest of the year its two American retail subsidiaries would face problems with cash flow and debt repayment.

title: 'Junk Bond' Market Rattled by News
description: Worries about the liquidity crisis facing the Campeau Corporation, sent ''junk bond'' prices down in an already battered market yesterday.

title: Thousands of Marchers Conduct Multiracial Protest in Cape Town
description: A multiracial crowd of thousands of South Africans surged through this city today in a march permitted by the Government. It was the biggest public display of opposition to apartheid that the nation has witnessed since emergency rule was imposed more than three years ago.

title: Panel Votes Today on Gains Tax
description: Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today exhausted his options for compromise on capital gains taxes and scheduled a vote for Thursday on a cut in the tax rate. The cut is backed by the Bush Administration and supported by a majority of committee members.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * David Perry has been named executive vice president, director of broadcast production, and Gene Johnson has been promoted to senior vice president of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

title: Excerpts of the Victory Speeches of Dinkins and Giuliani
description: Following are excerpts from the victory speeches of David N. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee for mayor of New York City, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican nominee, as recorded Tuesday night by The New York Times. Dinkins

title: Day Wins 8 of 9
description: Pat Day rode eight winners in nine mounts at Arlington International Racecourse outside Chicago yesterday, the best percentage day ever for a rider in that many races at a North American track. Three riders have had eight winners on a single program - David Gall in 1978, and R. D. Williams and Chris Loseth in 1984, but they each had 10 mounts.(AP)

title: Ogivar Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hear the One About Admen Telling Jokes?
description: MIKE BERMAN, a copywriter at Geer, Dubois, furrowed his brow in deep thought before explaining why he had entered the ''Funniest Person in Advertising'' contest. ''There are three rites of passage for the Jewish male,'' he said. ''Circumcision, bar mitzvah and stand-up.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE FOR THE PREPARATION OF THE INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY - 3 P.M.

title: Colombia Debates Role Of U.S. Armed Forces
description: As Colombia continues its war on cocaine traffickers, a debate broke out here today over an age-old specter in Latin America: North American troops on South American soil.

title: Sanderson Helps Cubs Sweep Expos, 3-1
description: Scott Sanderson, making his first start since Aug. 18, allowed no runs in five and one-third innings tonight, and the streaking Chicago Cubs completed a three-game sweep with a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Keetmanshoop Journal; Politicians' Clever Foes: Namibian Sheep Farmers
description: Like other Namibians of color, the Rev. Willem Simon, a Roman Catholic priest in this desert town, anticipates a heady new experience in November. ''I'll be 50 years old this year and this is the first time I'm going to be able to vote for the government of my choice,'' Father Simon said. ''I've never been able to vote.''

title: Edwards Goes to Japan
description: Teresa Edwards, who played on the United States women's basketball teams that won gold medals in the Olympic Games of 1984 and 1988, has signed a one-year, six-figure guaranteed contract with Mitsubishi Electric Sales America, to play with the Mitsubishi basketball team in Nagoya, Japan, next season.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago 6 months included non- recurring gain of $640,000, or 3 cents a share, for sale of Thriftway Inns property. Share earnings adjusted for 5 percent stock dividend paid in May.

description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Yields End Week Mixed
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as yields on taxable funds rose and yields on tax-exempt funds declined.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage firm, named R. Alan Kershaw vice president and treasurer.

title: Foreign Exchange Trading Is Near $500 Billion a Day
description: The world's foreign exchange market is growing rapidly, according to reports released by central banks yesterday. London is still the largest foreign exchange market in the world, but the United States and Japan are catching up.

title: JG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: Personal Health
description: As increasing numbers of Americans use their feet to improve their bodies, ankles are taking a beating. Especially at risk are people who run, walk, hike, play tennis or basketball, skate, cross-country ski or dance.

title: Joseph P. Carucci, 76, Stock Concern Founder
description: Joseph P. Carucci, a stockbroker, died of cardiac arrest Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Mayflower Co-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Latest quarter results included $2,000 of gains on investment securities, compared to $98,000 a year ago. The company said it transferred loans totaling $1,202,000 to non-accrual status in the latest quarter and charged $90,000 to first quarter earnings.

title: H. W. Stunkard, 100, a Biologist
description: Horace W. Stunkard, a parasitologist who was chairman of the Department of Biology at New York University for 29 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Falmouth (Mass.) Nursing Home. He was 100 years old.

title: Transnational Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $35,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $81,000, or 3 cents a share, and $165,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Gas Explosion in Kentucky Leaves 10 Coal Miners Dead
description: Methane gas exploded in a coal mine near here today, killing 10 miners in the nation's worst coal mine disaster in five years.

title: Barge Runs Aground; Gasoline Spills in East River
description: A gasoline barge carrying nearly 100,000 barrels of gasoline ran aground and began leaking last night in the East River, forcing the closing of the Queens span of the Triborough Bridge, the police said.

description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,361,000, or 48 cents a share, for the quarter and year, on the repurchase of a portion of the company's subordinated debentures. c-Net income
