Reubin Clein, 83, Dies; Published Miami Life
description: Reubin Clein, the scrappy publisher of the weekly tabloid Miami Life, died of pancreatic cancer on Saturday at Desert Springs Hospital in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 83 years old and lived in Las Vegas, where he had moved after his retirement in 1965.

title: Freddie Mac Sells Debentures
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday priced $750 million in one-year noncallable debentures due Sept. 21, 1990, through its member selling group of securities dealers.

title: The Candidates on the Issues
description: In separate interviews last month with The New York Times, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed their views on major issues facing New Yorkers. Here are excerpts from their responses:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Mr. Dinkins, Self-Defined
description: In one stroke, David Dinkins has become one of the leading black political figures in the country and in one revealing moment early Wednesday morning, he gave an eloquent idea of who he is.

title: Helene Curtis's Secrets: Innovation and Timing
description: With a flair for innovation, a large advertising budget and a good sense of timing, an old name in hair-care products is emerging as a leader in the brutally competitive field.

title: Review/Television; '48 Hours' Opens Season By Tackling Drug Problem
description: Three hours of addicts, drug busts, threatened neighborhoods, strained emergency rooms and desperate therapy efforts may not be anybody's idea of prime-time entertainment, but the nation seems agreed that they demand prime-time attention. CBS kicks off the new season of ''48 Hours'' at 8 P.M. tonight with a full evening of ''Return to Crack Street,'' which sends an imposing team of CBS correspondents, led by Dan Rather, out to report on what has happened since September 1986, when the weekly news program carried its first special on crack.

title: Stroh Stake Sought
description: A company controlled by a Milwaukee investor is interested in obtaining a share of the Stroh Brewery Company, the No. 3 brewer in the United States. The Christiana Companies in San Diego has had discussions with Stroh for about six weeks, said Sheldon B. Lubar, who heads Lubar & Company, a Milwaukee venture capital firm that owns a controlling stake in Christiana. Mr. Lubar, a former director of the Pabst Brewing Company, said Christiana considered Stroh ''a worthwhile opportunity.''

title: Curator for Mapplethorpe Show Resigns Corcoran Posts
description: Jane Livingston, the curator who arranged the ill-fated Robert Mapplethorpe retrospective at the Corcoran Gallery of Art, resigned this morning, the museum announced.

title: ERC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included provisions for income taxes of $126,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the 6 months, of which $116,000 and $181,000, respectively, represented non-cash charges reflecting the income tax benefit of the utilization of the company's net operating loss carryforward. The balance, $10,000 and $17,000, respectively, represented provisions for alternative minimum taxes. c-Net loss The year-ago quarter's share earnings were less than 1 cent a share.

title: Jail Deaths Spur Talk of Release
description: A Federal judge has taken under advisement a request to release up to 500 misdemeanor offenders from an overcrowded jail where a mysterious bacterial infection has killed two prisoners.

title: Steego Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $322,000. Year-ago period's net included a gain of $1,400,000 from the sale of property.

title: Paramount Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $77,800,000, or 65 cents a share, and $206,200,000, or $1.73 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $65,300,000, or 54 cents a share, and $167,400,000, or $1.39 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter and year results included an after-tax charge of $48.3 million for costs incurred in Paramount's bid to acquire Time Inc.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Warwick Takes A New Name
description: Celebrating its 50th birthday and its impending move to downtown Manhattan and what its president half-jokingly calls ''the cutting edge of creativity,'' Warwick Advertising announced yesterday that it was changing its name to Warwick Baker & Fiore.

title: The Monster That Haunts The Mets
description: In the closing days of 1984 and 1985, when it was clear the Mets were not going to win this time, the players took curtain calls for their adoring fans.

title: Holtz, With No. 1 Team, Worries About No. 2
description: Considering the normal sense of paranoia that seems to come with the job of coaching college football at the highest level, and the low public expectations that became a weekly feature of Notre Dame's perfect season in 1988, Lou Holtz's outlook going into the first serious threat to the Irish this season is a predictable one.

title: Books of The Times; The Question Is: Will the Ranch Be Saved?
description: Keep the Change By Thomas McGuane 230 pages. Houghton Mifflin/Seymour Lawrence. $18.95.

description: b-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $2,351,928, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,390,928, or 26 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: HOUSE SHUNS BILL ON 'OBSCENE' ART
description: The House today rejected a Senate effort to restrict Federal grants for art deemed ''obscene or indecent.''

title: Washington Talk; The Ideal Of Service By Youth Is Revived
description: After nearly a decade out of circulation, the notion that millions of American youth should be induced, and perhaps even required, to perform some form of public service is hard currency again.

title: The New York Primary; From Primary, Swelling Pride and Easing Tensions
description: Until yesterday morning, the class in participation in government at Martin Luther King High School had seemed to the students, all seniors and all black, something of an abstraction.

title: Arye Leon Dulzin Is Dead at 76; Israeli Official and Zionist Leader
description: Arye Leon Dulzin, a former Israeli Government official and former chairman of the World Zionist Organization and of Israel's Jewish Agency, died after a prolonged kidney illness yesterday in Tel Hashomer Hospital in Tel Aviv. He was 76 years old and had lived in Tel Aviv.

title: Safecard Services reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,950,000 from litigation settlement.

title: The Perils of Gender-Neutral Pronouns
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
SRI LANKA BEGINS TALKS ON STRIFE
description: In a climate of tension, exhaustion and fear, representatives of almost all Sri Lankan political parties and ethnic groups came together in a heavily guarded conference hall here today to begin a monthlong search for a political formula to stem the drift into anarchy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about festivities marking the 20th anniversary of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's rise to power incorrectly included one group as among those attending. The group, Women Against Military Madness, based in Minneapolis, says it did not send a delegation and was not officially represented.

title: Aluminum Unit In Sale to Noranda
description: National Intergroup Inc. said it would sell the rolling division of its National Aluminum Corporation subsidiary to Noranda USA Inc., a subsidiary of Noranda Inc. of Toronto, for $117.7 million. National Aluminum's unit employs about 500 workers in Caldwell, Ohio; Salisbury, N.C., and Newport, Ark. The sale is expected to result in a one-time after-tax gain of about $30 million in the third quarter.

title: Maloney Impressing Islanders
description: Don Maloney's allegiance has turned from Broadway Blue to Blue and Orange.

title: Digital Offers Severance Deal
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's second-largest computer company, has offered 40 to 104 weeks of pay to 700 employees if they voluntarily leave the company.

title: 10 Tibetans Sentenced in Rioting
description: Chinese courts have sentenced 10 Tibetans to prison terms ranging from three years to life on charges of rioting and spying during pro-independence unrest in March, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: A Portrait of the Primary Voters
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Exodus Galls East Berlin; Nation's Sovereignty Seems to Be Mocked
description: To the East German Government, the drain of its citizens to the West, by way of Hungary, has been both an economic loss and a source of acute embarrassment. But what seems to provoke the sharpest anger is the open challenge posed by the exodus to East Germany's shaky legitimacy.

title: Tons of Toys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Ford Says 2 New '90 Models Won't Be Ready Till Spring
description: The Ford Motor Company introduced its lineup of 1990 cars and trucks today and set optimistic sales goals. But Ford executives, speaking at a news briefing, conceded that the company's two completely new domestic vehicles for the coming year would not be ready until spring.

title: Getty Is Selling 15 Paintings
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum announced yesterday that it would sell 15 paintings by Gauguin, Degas, Monet, Bonnard and Utrillo at Sotheby's in London in November. Most of the paintings, which are expected to bring $13 million to $18 million, were acquired between 1956 and 1975 by Mr. Getty, who died in 1976.

title: Guerrillas Begin Salvador Talks By Offering a 3-Stage Peace Plan
description: Negotiations between the Government of El Salvador and the leftist guerrillas seeking its overthrow began here today, with the rebels presenting a peace proposal to bring the decade-long civil war to an end in three stages over the next five months.

title: Capitals Defeat Swedish Team
description: Steve Leach and Mike Ridley scored goals in the third period today to lead Washington to a 3-1 victory over Brynas of the Swedish Elite League. It was the Capital's last exhibition game before they begin a tour of the Soviet Union.

title: Bell to Head Young's Drive
description: Former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell will head Mayor Andrew Young's campaign for Governor next year, Mr. Young's office announced today. It said Mr. Bell had agreed to be campaign chairman and Hobby Stripling, former Mayor of Vienna, Ga., had been named campaign manager. Mr. Young is expected to announce his candidacy for Governor early next year, shortly after he leaves the Mayor's office.

title: Emigres' Stooped Ceiling; Soviets Ease Exits, but U.S. Curbs Entries And Would-Be Refugees Are Caught in Gap
description: The new refugee ceilings announced this week by President Bush are not high enough to accommodate the Soviet citizens who have already applied for admission to the United States as refugees, much less the thousands expected to apply in the coming year.

title: Vincent Succeeds Giamatti as Commissioner
description: Major league club owners, as expected, elected Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr. baseball's eighth commissioner today, a move that was filled with irony.

title: C. Edward Quinn, 63, A Professor of Biology
description: Brother C. Edward Quinn, a professor of biology at Manhattan College for 30 years, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Christian Brothers Center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 63 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; S.O.S. Pads Shift
description: Griffin Bacal yesterday lost a $3 million to $4 million advertising account with Miles Laboratories. Miles, a Chicago-based maker of household products, reassigned the account for S.O.S. soap pads to Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk, a small Chicago agency that handles other Miles household cleaners.

title: Dunkin' Donuts In Several Pacts
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said it had signed confidentiality agreements with several parties interested in pursuing the possible acquisition of the doughnut-store chain. The parties to be given confidential corporate data include the DD Acquisition Corporation, which has been conducting a hostile tender offer for Dunkin' Donuts. The company said the agreement with DD provided that subject to certain conditions, DD would keep its tender offer open at least through Nov. 1. The company also said it and DD had agreed to postpone the trial date on next Monday for pending Delaware litigation between them.

title: Wild Paving Roller Crushes Sleeping Man in New Jersey
description: A homeless man was reported in critical condition today after a paving roller ran over him while he was sleeping.

title: Huffman Koos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included income tax benefit of $339,000.

title: Avante-Garde Computing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included restructuring charges of $950,000.

title: Emons Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $92,324, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $641,798, or 12 cents a share, for the year. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $62,413, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $366,025, or 7 cents a share, for the year. Latest quarter revenue included revenues from two acquisitions and from liquidation of assets of ET Railcar Corp.

title: A Late-Comer Is Off To a Very Fast Start
description: It took Bud Carson 33 years to become a head coach in the National Football League, and just one game to learn to worry when you win by 51-0.

title: U.S. Widens Inquiry on College Price Fixing
description: A Justice Department inquiry into whether prestigious colleges and universities may have violated Federal antitrust laws in tuition and scholarship practices has been broadened to include six more schools, officials at the institutions said today.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: SCS-Compute Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $497,000.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Faces Suit on Ethics; No Crime Is Charged
description: The City Attorney of Los Angeles filed a civil suit today against Mayor Tom Bradley, charging that he failed to disclose six personal investments as required by California law. But the City Attorney, ending five months of inquiry into possible conflicts of interest by the Mayor, said there was not enough evidence to press criminal charges.

title: Chefs International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Lucy C. Ferguson, 89, Island Preservationist
description: Lucy Carnegie Ferguson, a member of the industrialist Carnegie family who worked most of her life to preserve Cumberland Island, died Monday night after a long illness. She was 89 years old.

title: Dip in Farm Workers Could Open Door for Aliens
description: Officials of the Departments of Agriculture and Labor have been meeting over the last few days to determine whether there is a shortage of seasonal workers on the nation's farms. Such a shortage could open the door for nonresident aliens to gain legal status.

title: Victorious Mayor of Yonkers Sees End to Housing Dispute
description: Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko, winner by a wide margin in Tuesday's Democratic primary, said today that he felt that the results of his race and those for the City Council were ''the beginning of the end'' of the city's desegregation stalemate.

title: Topps Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Temperance Union Still Going Strong
description: Inside the red-brick headquarters of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union here, a bell sounds every day at two minutes before noon. For those two minutes, members of the temperance union are supposed to pray for prohibition.

title: Teacher Union Faults History Books
description: The five most commonly used high school history textbooks barely touch on such major figures as Washington and Lincoln and they largely ignore the passion and political significance of religion and economics in American history, according to a new study by the American Federation of Teachers.

title: A Glittering Run Brings Instant Glory in Atlanta
description: Since he became the first man to hit a major league home run and score a National Football League touchdown in the same week, Deion Sanders has drawn an even larger crowd.

title: Talking Deals; Auditing Mergers Expected to Clear
description: ANTITRUST regulators at the Justice Department are investigating a flurry of mergers that would significantly consolidate the number of top accounting firms. ''We are looking at each of the mergers,'' Robert Bloch, an official in the agency's antitrust division, said yesterday.

title: Expanded Effort To Lure Raiders
description: Sacramento County joined the city today in backing plans to lure the Los Angeles Raiders with $50 million in public funds. The move led to a prediction from the Sacramento Sports Association head, Gregg Lukenbill, that the deal would be made in four to six weeks.

title: Rules Passed by Metro-North Could Help to Rout Homeless
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad adopted draft rule yesterday intended to regulate public conduct aboard trains and in passenger stations in New York State, including Grand Central Station.

title: Ferdinand F. E. Kopecky, Lawyer, 82
description: Ferdinand F. E. Kopecky, a retired patent lawyer, died of a heart attack on Aug. 29 at his home in the Bronx. He was 82 years old.

title: Deal in Advanced TV By Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had become the first company outside Japan to acquire the designs chip makers need to compete in the vast market in high-definition television that is expected to emerge by the mid-1990's.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adidas A.G., Munich, West Germany, a maker of sporting goods, said Peter V. Ueberroth, the former Major League Baseball commissioner, would take a stake in the company and its three U.S. subsidiaries. Under the agreement, Mr. Ueberroth has an option until 1992 to buy up to 25 percent of Adidas in newly issued shares and a stake below 50 percent in its U.S. units.

title: Bush Reconsiders Nominee To Oversee A-Plants' Safety
description: The Bush Administration is reconsidering a widely criticized nomination to an Energy Department position, Deputy Secretary Henson Moore said today.

title: Q&A
description: Loose Floor Tiles Q.Five years ago the old linoleum was removed from our kitchen floor. A layer of 3/8-inch plywood was put down with new 12-inch square vinyl tiles on top. There has been no water damage, yet the tiles are coming loose in various places, especially where four tiles come together. The contractor said there should be a little ''give,'' but a manufacturer's representative said the tiles should lie perfectly flat. Could the new subfloor be warping and pushing the tiles up, and can I reglue the loose tiles? A.The manufacturer is right: the tiles should not be lifting or moving. It is possible that improper nailing of the plywood subfloor could be allowing it to warp, and this could cause the tiles to loosen.

title: Completions Of Houses Up
description: Lower mortgage lending rates and rising construction fueled a 1.1 percent jump in completions of new homes in July after a steep drop of 6.1 drop in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Doubts About the Cholesterol Crusade
description: Does reducing cholesterol, by diet or with special drugs, lessen the risk of heart disease? Yes, says a broad consensus of experts represented by the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute and the American Heart Association. No, contends a vigorously iconoclastic article by Thomas J. Moore in the current Atlantic Monthly. It's probably safer to bet with the experts; still, the benefit of their confident prescriptions could well be less than the public expects.

title: 'Days of Rage' Dispute Revives Debate on Rules
description: For nearly a year before the broadcast last week of ''Days of Rage: The Young Palestinians,'' a pro-Palestinian documentary, public television officials and journalists expressed concern about the financing of the film. Now, however, Public Broadcasting Service executives, independent film makers and experts in public-television policy say the dispute over the film has revived a much broader debate about PBS's role as an alternative to commercial television.

title: Staodynamics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net loss

title: S.E.C. Losing a Member
description: Charles C. Cox, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1983, said Tuesday that he would leave the Federal regulatory agency at the end of the month to join a consulting firm. The resignation of Mr. Cox, 44 years old, a former chief economist of the agency, had been expected because his term technically had expired. He will join Lexecon Inc., a Chicago-based economic consulting concern, as a senior vice president in its securities and finance group.

title: Remic Securities From Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, yesterday priced its 101st real estate mortgage investment conduit securities deal since the company began issuing them in August 1987.

title: Sun City Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Giacomini to Open Chicago Opera Season
description: Giuseppe Giacomini will sing the role of Radames in the season's first two performances of ''Aida'' at the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the company has announced. Mr. Giacomini will replace Luciano Pavarotti tomorrow, which is opening night, and in Tuesday's performance. The Icelandic tenor Kristjan Johannsson, who was scheduled to sing two performances in the ''Aida'' series, will sing six: on Sept. 22, 25 and 28 and Oct. 2, 6 and 11.

title: A Pottery Style's Rebirth
description: ALONG with the growing interest in Arts and Crafts furniture has come new demand for ceramics in that style. Several sources are once again manufacturing Arts and Crafts tiles and pottery.

title: NEW ELECTION PLAN HAS MIDEAST ASTIR
description: Intrigued by President Hosni Mubarak's 10-point plan for holding Palestinian elections in the occupied territories, a large group of leading West Bank Palestinians left for Cairo this week to discuss the proposal with Egyptian officials.

title: Rochester Cable Outlet To Become TV Station
description: To compete with traditional broadcast television stations, Time Warner Inc. is transforming a channel on the cable system it owns in Rochester into an independent station, programmed with network reruns, sports and locally produced children's shows.

title: Go After Companies That Abuse Pension Funds; Short-Term Surtax
description: To the Editor:

title: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: For the Jews of Italy, a History of Harmony
description: At the entrance to the Jewish Museum's ''Gardens and Ghettos: The Art of Jewish Life in Italy'' is a plaster cast of a portion of the Arch of Titus, built in A.D. 81 in Rome to celebrate a victory over the Romans' most rebellious and disobedient province, Judea.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Promotion Continues Fluor Succession Plan
description: LEAD: The Fluor Corporation said yesterday that it had promoted Leslie G. McCraw, its president of less than two years, to chief executive of the international engineering and construction company, thereby completing another step in its plan of succession.

title: Rangers Hope for Big Lift From Little Center
description: ''I got drafted by one regime, signed by another regime, and now I'll get to play for another regime,'' said Corey Millen. ''I've found it pretty interesting.''

title: The Disappearance of Room 16
description: Sometimes a century-old story or legend rattles around in the back of your mind, raising gooseflesh when a new thought triggers its recollection.

title: Campaign Matters; 'Rumpled Genius' And Hard Work Spell Triumph
description: Bill Lynch stood in the sunshine at City Hall yesterday, letting reporters ask him how it felt to be a guru while supporters told him where they had met him. He answered the questions and shook the hands, but the wry, rumpled architect of David N. Dinkins's primary victory was really having none of it.

title: Arrow Automotive Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-Net income

title: President Plans Bill to Aid in Adoption
description: Seeking to deal with what he called ''one of America's most difficult and saddest problems,'' President Bush today announced legislative proposals to encourage the adoption of children who have disabilities, who are members of minorities or who are otherwise difficult to place.

title: A Boutique as Glamorous As the Clothes Inside It
description: TODAY'S fashion designers who have become retailers are as consumed with the look of their shops as with the clothes. This is especially noticeable these days in the flourishing Flatiron district of Manhattan, where shops like Emporio Armani, Paul Smith and Williwear have become neighbors.

title: A Store's Celebration Of France In Fantasy
description: IN this bicentennial year of the French Revolution, Bloomingdale's is celebrating with a storewide promotion, ''Vive la France.'' Variations on the Gallic theme have been carried out in seven new model rooms that will be on view today through Nov. 4 at the flagship store at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street in Manhattan.

title: Folk Art, Through New Eyes
description: FRANK MIELE, who runs Hirschl & Adler Folk, has always been fascinated with how colleagues who deal in contemporary art view folk art.

title: Ignorance, Ignorantly Judged
description: LEAD: The past few years have seen a dirge of statistics testifying to the depth of ignorance of Americans. There seems to be no end to what we do not know, be it history, geography, but especially science. Is that really the case?

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: FROM May until October I sleep badly. I like a cold room and piles of blankets, and carving a warm nest out of icy sheets. All I have enjoyed about this summer, most summers really, are the evening rains. Like winter winds they've made me glad to be indoors, safe and sound, at rest in what, haunted by the childhood phrase, I always call ''my own little bed.''

title: For First Time, Democrats Choose A Black for Mayor in New Haven
description: State Senator John C. Daniels, scoring well in all but a handful of New Haven's 30 wards, defeated his party's endorsed candidate to become the first black Democratic nominee for mayor in this overwhelmingly Democratic city.

title: National Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $44,100,000.

title: When Talk Is About, Not Across, Fences
description: ONE pretty morning it wasn't there; but by lunchtime there it was: a 6-foot-high wooden stockade, grim, gray and spiked, across 40 feet of front lawn smack in the middle of the block. On Mechanic Street that day, the emotional barometric pressure fell precipitously.

title: Fed Ex-Official Gets 6 Months
description: A former director of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, Robert A. Rough, was sentenced today to six months in prison for leaking secret interest rate data. United States District Judge

title: A Singular Observer Of Everyday Places
description: THIS is J. B. Jackson country: a trailer camp, a horse barn, a highway crew paving a road to nowhere at a pace between lethargy and stillness. The route, calculated to befuddle the urban brain and dismantle sedans, is nonetheless a document on the preachings of the man. It is, in the word that John Brinckerhoff Jackson has almost coined, the ''vernacular'' landscape - the human trail of everyday places and plain-folks architecture.

title: Newmark & Lewis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sands Regent reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Japanese Putting Off Sale Of Stock in Nippon Phone
description: Japan today delayed a planned sale of shares in the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the giant telecommunications company that was involved in a bribery scandal that rocked the Government earlier this year.

title: Chiron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a $581,000 charge for a delay in construction of New Pilot manufacturing facilities.

title: Indians Hold Protest in Brazil
description: More than 300 Indians held a war dance outside the Brazilian Congress today to protest the invasion of Yanomami Indian lands by thousands of gold prospectors. The Yanomami, who live in the rugged hills along Brazil's Amazon border with Venezuela, are the largest tribe of forest Indians left in the Americas. They say the 40,000 gold prospectors threaten their survival by polluting the rivers with mercury and bringing new diseases. There are about 9,000 Yanomami in Brazil and 11,000 in Venezuela.

title: Third President in Year Named By Auto Renter
description: Agency-Rent-A-Car Inc. elevated Terry W. Holt to president yesterday, following the resignation last month of Kenneth J. Lorek as president and chief financial officer.

title: Israelis Give Doomed Nazi A Longer Period to Appeal
description: The Israeli Supreme Court today put off an appeal by a convicted Nazi war criminal, enabling his attorney to verify what he contends is new evidence covered up by the United States.

title: McDonnell Order
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said Alaska Air Group Inc. had ordered six MD-80 twin-jet aircraft in a deal valued at about $180 million. McDonnell Douglas said its Douglas Aircraft Company unit would deliver the first of the short- to medium-range jets to Alaska Airlines in October 1993.

title: Hired Pathologist Disputes Report on Suspect
description: The family of a robbery suspect who died early Saturday in police custody in the Bronx has commissioned an independent autopsy that challenges the findings of the Chief Medical Examiner's office.

title: Josette Frank, 96, Dies; Children's Book Expert
description: Josette Frank, an authority on books for children and a consultant on children's programming for radio and television, died of pneumonia Saturday at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va., where she lived. She was 96 years old.

title: Car Sales Off 2.8% on Low Supplies
description: Sales of American-built cars dropped by 2.8 percent in early September as consumers found that some 1989 models were in short supply at dealers after two months of brisk sales that had surprised some analysts.

title: Man Charged in Death of Brooklyn Drug Fighter
description: A 26-year-old homeless man, described as a small-time heroin dealer, was charged with murder yesterday in the death of Maria Hernandez, a Brooklyn woman who, with her husband, had fought to rid her neighborhood of drug dealers, the police said.

title: Canadian Western Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The bank was formed in April 1988 through the merger of Bank of Alberta and Western & Pacific Bank of Canada and year-ago figures for the 9-month period were not available. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Isle of Peace Is Threatened In Salvador
description: When the army began rounding up people in her village suspected of collaborating with the Salvadoran rebels, Rosita Maria fled with her teen-age son to this demilitarized municipality, which has risen from the ashes of the single most devastating aerial attack of the country's decade-old war.

title: Nehemiah Triumphs
description: Four weeks after Renaldo Nehemiah's longtime world record for the 110-meter hurdles was lowered by Roger Kingdom, the old champion, defeated the new one yesterday at a meet in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain.

title: Sale Effort Is Ended By Circle K
description: The Circle K Corporation, the nation's second-largest operator of convenience stores, said yesterday that it was ending its efforts to sell the company and was suspending payment of its 7-cent quarterly dividend.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Aug. 19 about Bucky Dent, the Yankees' new manager, reported incorrectly that he had been adopted by the uncle and aunt who raised him after his parents' divorce. Although his name was changed from O'Dey to Dent, his mother's maiden name and his uncle's surname, there was no adoption.

title: Pall Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: Year-ago quarter and year results were restated to reflect the acquisition of RAI Research Corp. on Sept. 30, 1988, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Detroit Mayor Easily Wins Primary but Faces Runoff
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young, one of the first blacks to lead a major American city, won a big victory Tuesday over a dozen challengers, with Representative John Conyers Jr. coming in third in the city's nonpartisan primary.

title: A Dirtier Air Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Jefferson Smurfit In Merger Accord
description: SIBV/Holdings Inc. and the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation jointly announced yesterday that they had made a definitive agreement to merge. SIBV/Holdings will acquire all the outstanding shares of Jefferson Smurfit common stock for $41.75 a share in cash. SIBV/Holdings is a joint venture equally owned by Smurfit International B.V., a subsidiary of Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C., and the Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund II L.P.

title: Bloomingdale's Gives Party Honoring French Style and Ends Up Stealing Show
description: AFTER a week in the national financial spotlight, Bloomingdale's turned the kleig lights on its Lexington Avenue facade last night and rolled out the red carpet for 1,200 high-powered people. The occasion was a charity gala, and while the cash registers were closed, a few guests may have had serious shopping in mind now that the Campeau Corporation has put a $2 billion pricetag on the 17-store chain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have already won, Mr. de Klerk. If you know really what is good for you, join us in the struggle for this new South Africa.'' - Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu. [ A1:1. ]

title: Pilots' Offer for UAL Is Said to Be Ready
description: The $300-a-share offer for the UAL Corporation by the pilots' union and the company's top management is to be presented to a meeting of UAL's independent directors in Chicago today, people close to those making the bid said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: France and Brazil moved further ahead of their rivals in the qualifying stage of the world team championships here this afternoon. Both teams won their seventh-round matches while their closest challengers, Australia and Taiwan, played each other in a match that was almost a tie.

title: Wiener Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: Photo Engravers & Electroypers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Jury in Los Angeles Acquits Five in Protests of Abortions
description: The leader of the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue and four associates were acquitted today of trespassing charges for blocking entrances to clinics where they said abortions were performed.

title: Scribner's Site to Be a Bookstore Again: a Brentano's Branch
description: The street-level floor of the Scribner Building on Fifth Avenue near 48th Street, vacant since early this year, will become a bookstore again in October when a branch of the Brentano's chain moves into the space, executives of the company said yesterday.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds End Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in moderately active trading yesterday.

title: French Sign LeMond To $5.5 Million Contract
description: Greg LeMond announced yesterday that he would ride next year for the France-based Z team under a three-year contract worth a minimum of $5.5 million. The agreement more than doubled the previous top salary in bicycle racing.

title: Dinkins Starts With Numerical Advantage, But Uneasy Democrats Could Go to Giuliani
description: A proven political machine, a 5-to-1 Democratic edge in enrollment and a party that appears to be unusually united help make David N. Dinkins the heavy favorite in the November mayoral race against his Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani. But Mr. Dinkins may be vulnerable to defections from some Democrats who are concerned about crime and may be reluctant to vote for a black candidate.

title: Results in Tuesday's Primary Elections
description: Democrat MAYOR David N. Dinkins ... 537,887 Edward I. Koch* ... 445,941 Richard Ravitch ... 48,289 Harrison J. Goldin ... 28,792 CITY COUNCIL PRESIDENT Andrew J. title: Ennis Business Forms reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Evangelist May Shut Hospital
description: The evangelist Oral Roberts announced today that he will close his City of Faith Hospital and Medical School and sell his home to help make up for a $25 million deficit caused by a drop in donations.

title: Canal Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' revenue figures have been reclassified to conform with the current year's presentation. The latest periods' results were after provisions of preferred dividends of $342,000 for the quarter and $1,025,000 for the 9 months, compared with $324,000 and $966,000 for the same year-ago periods, respectively. The company was formerly the United Stockyards Corp.

title: Interpoint Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said its results included the operations of Micra Corp., which was acquired on July 5. The figures included Micra's 9 months' losses of $645,000 and acquisition expenses of $270,000.

title: Gooden Finally Returns And It's Like Old Times
description: In the debris of their disintegrating season, the Mets had a moment of reflected glory tonight: Dwight Gooden came out of the bullpen and pitched three scoreless innings against the Philadelphia Phillies in his first appearance since he tore a shoulder muscle 10 weeks ago.

title: Sale of Sears Tower Stalls
description: An official with Olympia & York Development Ltd., a Canadian real estate development concern, confirmed today that negotiations for the sale of the Sears Tower had broken down after Sears, Roebuck & Company and Olympia & York, the potential buyer, were unable to agree on who would pay a tax increase under a reappraisal that is expected to follow the sale of the world's tallest building.

title: Market Place; Cross & Trecker's Debt Difficulties
description: ON Tuesday, the Cross & Trecker Corporation, one of the country's largest makers of factory automation systems and machine tools, said it had received an extension of a default deadline of last Friday on a $2 million industrial revenue bond. Few analysts who follow the company were encouraged by the news. Cross & Trecker is in debt way over its head, they say, and some are wondering whether it will emerge intact.

title: Envoy Nominee Withdraws In H.U.D. Contracts Inquiry
description: White House officials said today that the Administration's nominee as Ambassador to Luxembourg had withdrawn from consideration for the post after Senate Democrats told the Administration that he would not be confirmed.

title: Murdoch Bidding for MGM/UA
description: Just two weeks before it was to be sold to the Qintex Group of Australia for $1 billion, the MGM/UA Communications Company today received a surprise $1.35 billion counteroffer from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

title: The Soviets Proudly Present Their Friendly K.G.B. Agent
description: The K.G.B. stepped up its charm offensive today with the premiere of a new film on the benign patriotism and just-folks life styles of the Soviet secret police.

title: Journalists in the Front Lines Of Colombia's Cocaine War
description: Every morning, Maria Jimena Duzan leaves her bomb-proofed apartment, greets her armed police guard and drives a randomly chosen route to work.

title: Soap Operas Get a Weekly
description: Murdoch Magazines will introduce a weekly color magazine about television soap operas in November, its second publication on the subject, according to an announcement from the organization. Murdoch, a division of News

title: European Jews at Odds on Catholic Relations
description: The president of the European Jewish Congress, taking issue with a French colleague's interpretation, declared today that the organization had not backed a suspension of formal contacts between Jewish groups and the Roman Catholic Church.

title: U.S. Rejects Increase in Aid for Poland
description: Despite appeals from Congress and officials in Poland, the Bush Administration has ruled out any major, immediate efforts to provide economic assistance to Poland, Administration officials said today.

title: City Opera Is Struck; Fall Season Halted
description: The New York City Opera orchestra, unhappy with the company's proposals on wages and guaranteed work, struck the opera last night before the beginning of the company's fall season, which was to have been a performance of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia.'' The strike imperils the rest of the City Opera's season, which is scheduled to run through Nov. 19.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 An apartheid protest in Cape Town, which was permitted by the Government, was the biggest public display of opposition in South Africa since a state of emergency was imposed 39 months ago. Page A1

title: General Host Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,424,000. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $1,650,000. d-Net income Income from continuing operations in 1989 included the elimination of $2,500,000 of income tax reserves which are no longer required. The company said the loss from discontinued operations in both 1989 periods reflected an after-tax loss of $3,424,000 from the agreement in principle to settle two additional lawsuits stemming from the American Salt litigation. The extraordinary loss in the 1988 periods reflected a provision for the settlement of a class action suit which resulted from the March 1987 discovery of a problem in the computerized accounts payable system at the company's Frank's Nursery Crafts Inc. subsidiary.

title: Kansas to Honor Sayers
description: The University of Kansas announced it would retire the No. 48 uniform worn by Gale Sayers when he played at Lawrence, Kan., from 1962 to 1964. The ceremony will take place at halftime of the Jayhawks' game against Oklahoma on Sept. 30.

title: Henry Forster, 100, Real-Estate Executive
description: Henry Forster, a real-estate executive with Brown, Harris, Stevens for nearly half a century, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 100 years old.

title: New York Mortgage Unit Sells $290 Million in Bonds
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which is known as Sonyma, is offering $290 million in negotiated taxable and tax-exempt homeowner mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Espey Mfg & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $102,774, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of accounting change for income taxes.

title: House Votes Futures Bill
description: The House today unanimously approved a bill intended to strengthen oversight of the nation's futures markets and improve their record keeping.

title: Continental Medical Sys reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an accounting adjustment loss of $580,000 for the quarter and year reflecting the cumulative effect of accounting change for periods prior to July 1, 1988. c-Net income The income before adjustments in both latest periods were after pre-tax loss of $8,006,000 on sale of certain nursing facilities and writedown of other long-term care assets.

title: Jewish Student Accused of Faking Anti-Semitism
description: The former president of the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York in Binghamton has been charged with painting anti-Semitic slurs near a Jewish sanctuary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is our conclusion that Mr. Henry Hughes died as a result of cocaine intoxication. Physical injuries neither caused nor contributed to his death.'' - Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, Chief Medical Examiner of New York. [ B4:3. ]

title: SENATE APPROVES A BAN ON SMOKING ON ALL U.S. FLIGHTS
description: The Senate voted today to ban smoking on all domestic airline flights, rolling over the objections of tobacco-state lawmakers and illustrating a sweeping change in society's attitudes toward smoking and health.

title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor
description: In a chic neighborhood in Bogota, young executives gather in private clubs, set in mansions and fashionable apartments to smoke a powerful and extremely addictive form of cocaine.

title: Valentina, a Designer of Clothes For Stars in the Theater, Dies at 90
description: Valentina Nicholaevna Sanina Schlee, the fashion designer known by her first name who made clothes for social and theater personalities in the 1920's through the 50's, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday at her Manhattan home. She was 90 years old.

title: 38 Die in Sri Lanka Amid New Peace Effort
description: A television announcer was among 38 people killed in Sri Lanka in political violence in the 24 hours that ended this morning, military officials said.

title: Government - A Good Patron But Bad Censor
description: LEAD: This week, the House of Representatives rejected an amendment, authored by Senator Jesse Helms and passed by the Senate, to the appropriations bill for the National Endowment for the Arts. The amendment, which prohibits the use of Federal funds to ''promote, disseminate or produce obscene or indecent materials'' or work that ''reviles a person, group or class of citizens on the basis of race, creed, sex, handicap, age or national origin,'' has been sent to a

title: Jackson Has Surgery
description: Rickey Jackson of the New Orleans Saints underwent three and a half hours of reconstructive surgery yesterday on the cheekbone the linebacker fractured in a car wreck, and a team spokesman said he was expected to be out at least four weeks. Jackson narrowly escaped death early Monday when he drove a Corvette under the back of a flatbed truck about three miles from his home north of New Orleans. Investigators said he was going over 100 m.p.h., but said there was no evidence Jackson had been drinking.(AP)

title: Topics of The Times; Zzzzzz's
description: That humankind was not meant to be awake at 3 o'clock in the afternoon is known to everyone who ever had to prop his eyelids open after lunch. Now sleep researchers say so, too, in a book titled ''Sleep and Alertness: Chronological, Behavioral and Medical Aspects of Napping.''

title: Georgia Gulf Board Is Studying a Sale
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation's board said it was exploring a sale, a move seen as a response to the Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons, who has threatened a takeover battle for the chemical company. Mr. Simmons, who last week said he was seeking shareholder consent to oust the board, said he would proceed with that strategy but at a slower pace while Georgia Gulf studied a possible merger, sale or recapitalization.

title: Navarez Wins Opener At Boxing's New Stage
description: By 7 o'clock, Steve Corwin, a dockworker from Ozone Park, Queens, was settled into his balcony seat as the tuxedoed ring announcer was saying, ''Welcome to the ancient Beacon Theater.''

title: Argentine Chief Faces Economic Test
description: The surge in inflation that overcame Argentina as it changed governments two months ago has run itself down in recent weeks, dropping to a relatively modest 37.9 percent for August. And the September rate is expected to be less than 10 percent.

title: Bush Doubles Food Aid to Poland After Being Pressed by Congress
description: In a reversal apparently prompted by pressure from Congress, President Bush announced today that the United States would double food aid for Poland to $100 million in the next fiscal year.

title: Seamus Twomey, 70, a Leader of Irish Guerrillas
description: Seamus Twomey, a leader of the Irish Republican Army, died Tuesday in a Dublin hospital. He was 70 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: John F. Morgan, Realty Broker, 94
description: John F. Morgan, a New York real-estate broker for many decades, died Tuesday at Rex Hospital in Raleigh, N.C. He was 94 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He had lived for many years in New Jersey.

title: More Jobs for Shevack
description: Partners & Shevack yesterday added textile and cosmetics advertising to its growing business, winning the accounts for Flame Glo cosmetics, which are made by Del Laboratories, Farmingdale, L.I., and Forstmann & Company, a wool manufacturer. The new accounts are worth a total of $5 million, most of it from Flame Glow, an agency spokesman said.

title: Article 672989 -- No Title
description: The Senate sent President Bush legislation today providing $225 million to start building a city-sized atom smasher in Texas that scientists hope will lead them to the universe's most basic materials. The money, for construction and research on the superconducting supercollider, is just the start of what is expected ultimately to be a Federal infusion of up to $5 billion for the project. The project could take up to seven years to build.

title: Shift at DM News
description: After 10 years of exploring the technological boundaries of the increasingly intricate direct-marketing industry, DM News is switching from biweekly to weekly frequency, Adrian Courtenay, its founder and publisher, said yesterday. The change for the magazine, which is published by the Mill Hollow Corporation and has an audited circulation of 35,000, will occur in January.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Alto Emeritus Lou Donaldson, Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets (982-3260). Lou Donaldson can rip silence; a slashing alto saxophonist, he's on some of the finest be-bop sessions from the 1950's. He's also someone whose series of organ records in the 60's has somewhat tarnished his credibility as a jazz musician. This is too bad, because he's one of the finest living be-bop alto saxophonists, and a tough wit, as well. Sets tonight through Sunday are at 9:30, 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. The cover is $10 and the minimum is $7. Subtle Storm

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Developer in New York Seeks to Acquire Lionel
description: LEAD: The New York real estate developer Robert I. Toussie describes his pursuit of the Lionel Corporation as a prudent process: the type of slow careful move that has served him well in the past.

title: U.S. Is Backing the Wrong Horse in Cambodia
description: To the Editor:

title: Commonwealth Games Will Be Coe's Finale
description: Sebastian Coe, the British middle-distance runner who set a dozen indoor and outdoor records between 1979 and 1983, said yesterday at a news conference in London that he would make the final appearance of his career in the Commonwealth Games from Jan. 24-Feb. 2 at Auckland, New Zealand.

title: Grey Will Promote New Eisenhower Coin
description: The United States Mint awarded Grey Advertising yesterday the $3 million account for a silver coin commemorating the 100th birthday of Dwight D. Eisenhower. Grey will do advertising, direct marketing, sales promotion and public relations for the coin, which goes on sale next January. Grey has handled four assignments for the Mint since 1985.

title: REAGAN TO LEAVE HOSPITAL TODAY
description: Former President Ronald Reagan is to leave for his Los Angeles home Friday from a hospital here where he underwent brain surgery last week, a spokesman for Mr. Reagan said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE FOR THE PREPARATION OF THE INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY - 3 P.M.

title: Canadian Police Seize 4 Latins and Arms
description: Authorities in this city on the Maine border arrested four people with Venezuelan passports and seized an arsenal of assault weapons, the police said today.

title: A Milestone for Labor But No Silver Lining
description: The pending takeover of the UAL Corporation by a group including its pilots' union and its management is a coup for the labor movement. But experts on employee-owned companies say that difficulties even more trying than winning control of the company may lie ahead.

title: Review/Film; Animated Shorts, Some Already Shown on TV
description: As anthologies of short animated films go, and more seem to be flooding in all the time, ''The Second Animation Celebration: The Movie'' is an ordinary affair. The 24 shorts include a few bright, witty narratives, along with many cutesy exercises and several computer-generated films that seem to exist to flaunt their technical expertise.

title: Debate Over Drug War Focuses on Financing It
description: The debate between the Bush Administration and Congress over drug policy involves not only how much money to spend and where to spend it but also how to raise the money without breaking the budget agreement reached last spring.

title: A Film Retrospective Looks At an Early Ingrid Bergman
description: ''People think my mother was discovered as an innocent kid from Sweden and made into a star by Hollywood,'' Isabella Rossellini said last week. ''But she was a very well-known star in Sweden before she ever went to Hollywood, and now Sweden is taking pride in that and the Swedish Film Institute is restoring and subtitling her films.''

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums FREE FESTIVAL, with magicians, storytellers and other entertainment, and refreshments, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the 91st Street Playground, Riverside Park. Rain date: Sept. 24. Information: 678-0189. ANNUAL QUEENS COUNTY FAIR, with music, dancing, tours of a restored 1770 farmhouse, cooking demonstrations, games and other entertainment, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Queens County Farm Museum, 73-50 Little Neck Parkway, Floral Park, Queens. Admission: children under 6 years old free; children 6 to 12, $1; others, $3. Information: (718) 347-FARM. ''NORTH, SOUTH, EAST AND JIM WEST,'' a program of four tales told by Mr. West, who will also use puppets, 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Admission: $4.50. Information: (914) 698-0098. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' a magic, music and comedy show for young children, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sundays, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180.

title: House Panel Assails U.S. Policy on Khmer Rouge
description: The Administration's policy of supporting a settlement in Cambodia that would bring the Khmer Rouge guerrillas into a transitional government came under stinging attack today in Congress.

title: Helping the Customer
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Sales Increased 0.7% in August
description: Retail sales rose a moderate seven-tenths of 1 percent in August because of strong automobile sales, but analysts foresee growing sluggishness in the remainder of the year.

title: Red Ransom Will Miss the Futurity
description: Red Ransom, the unbeaten 2-year-old who was scheduled to run in the Futurity Stakes at Belmont on Sunday, has been sidelined with a shin irritation just below the knee in his left foreleg. Mack Miller, his trainer, said it was possible that the colt might be back in time for the Cowdin Stakes Sept. 30, but that he might also be through for the season.

title: A Booth-by-Booth Guide to the Book Fair
description: This is a booth-by-booth browser's guide to activities at the New York Is Book Country fair. The major displays of each booth are listed. Author appearances are subject to change. 1. New York Botanical Garden: Ruth Rogers Clausen, co-author of ''Perennials for American Gardens.''

title: The Invasion of the Bibliophiles: A Guide for Fairgoers
description: Imagine the biggest book in the universe, one that extends for half a mile from cover to cover, with trillions of words and hundreds of thousands of characters. Then imagine that you have just six hours to make your way through it before it vanishes.

title: Abba Schwartz, Refugee Expert, Dies at Age 73
description: Abba P. Schwartz, a lawyer and former high-ranking State Department official, died of a heart attack Tuesday on a street in Brussels while going to the United States Embassy on business. He was 73 years old.

title: Cadillac Increases 1989 Sales Goals
description: The General Motors Corporation's Cadillac division expects to sell 267,000 units in its 1989 model year, 2,200 more than initially forcast, its vice president and general manager, John O. Grettenberger, said. Through August, Cadillac's 1989 calendar-year sales totaled 167,925 units, up about 3,700 units, or 2 percent more than in 1988, he said. Two weeks are left in the 1989 model year.

title: Books of The Times; George Bernard Shaw And the Urge to Dominate
description: Bernard Shaw Volume II: 1898-1918 The Pursuit of Power By Michael Holroyd 421 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: Bronx Suspect Died From Cocaine, Not Injuries, Autopsy Report Says
description: The death of a robbery suspect in the Bronx early Saturday resulted solely from cocaine intoxication, not from injuries suffered in a struggle with police officers, the Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday in his final autopsy report.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Back to Baltimore

title: B.P. to Sell $1.3 Billion In Property
description: In a $1.31 billion deal, the British Petroleum Company agreed today to sell an assortment of oil and gas properties in the North Sea and elsewhere to the Oryx Energy Company, based in Dallas.

title: Homosexuals Are Targets Of Courter In New Jersey
description: Homosexual rights have emerged as an issue in the race for governor of New Jersey, raised by the repeated calls of the Republican candidate, Representative Jim Courter, for limiting the rights of homosexuals to work as teachers, foster parents and camp counselors or in other jobs that put them in contact with children.

title: Ex-Ashland Chief Pleads Guilty
description: Orin E. Atkins, the former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges that he tried to sell company secrets to an Iranian oil concern for use in its lawsuit against Ashland.

title: Campeau's Mounting Debt Burden
description: Nov. 2, 1986: The Allied Stores Corporation, operator of Jordan Marsh and other top retail chains, agrees to be acquired for $3.6 billion by the Campeau Corporation, led by Robert Campeau, who made his fortune in Canada developing shopping malls. Jan. 24, 1988: Campeau begins a bid of $4.2 billion for Federated Department Stores, owner of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and other chains. Feb. 11, 1988: The Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation and Olympia & York Development Ltd., two real estate companies, provide $660 million to Campeau toward the Federated bid. Feb. 29, 1988: Macy's offers $6.6 billion in cash and stock for Federated. April 1, 1988: Federated accepts a sweetened Campeau cash offer of $6.6 billion. Oct. 28, 1988: The First Boston Corporation discloses that a $1.1 billion issue of high-yield 'junk bonds' for Federated is being retructured after failing to sell; offering is scaled back to $750 million. Jan. 27, 1989: Campeau fails to pay off $1.1 billion bridge loan to First Boston, Paine Webber and Dillonl, Read and arranges longer-term debt and possible equity stake for the investment banks. June 30, 1989: At Campeau annual meeting, Mr. Campeau indicates that Allied and Federated cash flow will be able to exceed interest costs. Sept. 8, 1989: In a surprise move, Campeau puts Bloomingdale's on the block and announces discussions for a $250 million injection from Olympia & York, under which Olympia & York could gain control of Campeau. Sept. 13, 1989: Campeau discloses that Federated and Allied will face cash-flow and debt-repayment problems as the Christmas retail season approaches.

title: Market Place; Value Questions In Warner Deal
description: WITH the ''junk bond'' market reeling, shareholders of Warner Communications Inc. are suffering.

title: Jury in Los Angeles Acquits Five in Protests of Abortions
description: Randall Terry, the leader of the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, has been acquitted of trespassing charges along with four associates with whom he blocked entrances to clinics where the defendants said abortions were performed.

title: Reviews/Art: Rarities to See From Other Lands; A Visual History Of Jewish Life In Italy
description: IT is not every day that a major exhibition can claim to tread wholly new ground. But that is what can be said of ''Gardens and Ghettos: The Art of Jewish Life in Italy'' that can be seen at the Jewish Museum starting on Sunday. The organizers say it is ''the first overall visual history of the Jews of Italy presented anywhere.'' Given the rarity of many of the works on view, and given also the discretion of many of their owners, we have no reason to quarrel with that estimate. Indeed, the only fault that I can find with the show is that, hard as I looked, I had trouble finding any gardens, though I was duly impressed by the noble portrayal of an onion in full flower that appears in a 16th-century herbal.

title: Gorbachev Is Said to Back Baltic Autonomy
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with Communist Party and Government leaders from the three Baltic republics, and expressed support for greater autonomy for the area, according to the Estonian party leader.

title: Beijing Ousts Governor Tied to Zhao
description: In a sign that Beijing is trying to crack down on freewheeling economic policies in the provinces, China today announced the dismissal of the Governor of the nation's most experimental economic region.

title: Experts Cite 3 Ways Cocaine Effects Can Lead to Death
description: Pathologists and experts in toxicology say that cocaine intoxication usually leads to death in at least one of three ways. They can all occur without outside stimuli.

title: Tampa Airport Tax-Exempt Issue
description: A $119.3 million bond issue for the Tampa International Airport is tentatively being offered, with a maximum yield of about 7.23 percent for a bond due in 2019.

title: S.E.C. Nominee Says 'Junk Bond' Market Seems Sound
description: President Bush's nominee to head the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' still seemed sound despite tremors touched off by the cash binds of some debt-laden issuers, most recently the Campeau Corporation.

title: Economic Scene; How Has Bush Done So Far?
description: THE Bush Administration this month released a report on its ''initiatives and accomplishments.'' So far, how does its record stack up?

title: Stock Prices Fall, Reacting to 'Junk Bonds'
description: Stock prices declined broadly yesterday in a carry-over of selling from Wednesday afternoon, as investors were rattled by the price plunge in the 'junk bond' market.

title: Melee Follows 5th Indictment In Racial Case
description: A melee erupted yesterday in front of a Brooklyn courthouse shortly after a hearing announcing the indictment of a fifth white man in what the police have called the racially motivated slaying of Yusuf K. Hawkins in the Bensonhurst section last month.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Randolph H. Guthrie, a Manhattan lawyer, misidentified a sister who survived him. She is Thomasia Phillips of Hilton Head, S.C.

title: Mosbacher in Japan: Little Progress Seen
description: Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher, ending a three-day trip to Japan today, made little apparent progress on trade questions. He left many Japanese and Americans here wondering about the Bush Administration's goals.

title: Italian Music, Free
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Cathedral Singers will present a free concert of Italian music at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, tonight at 8 o'clock. The program, which is to be conducted by Luciano Berio and Eduardo Muller, includes Mr. Berio's ''O King,'' Vivaldi's ''Dixit Dominus,'' Petrassi's ''Beatitudes'' and Respighi's ''Ancient Italian Dances'' Suite No. 3. The soloists are Fiamma Izzo D'Amico and Francesca Bachi, sopranos; Yun Deng, mezzo-soprano; Renato Capecchi, baritone, and Franco de Grandis, bass. The concert is being given in conjunction with the opening tonight at 6 of an exhibition of called ''Italian Artists Against Apartheid.''

title: Poles Are Reported Beaten By Rumanian Border Troops
description: The Foreign Ministry filed a protest today after 30 Polish tourists said Rumanian border soldiers dragged them off a train and beat them with rifle butts, the state press agency reported.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Milken Says Government Leaked Data on Inquiry
description: Lawyers for Michael R. Milken, the former head of the ''junk bond'' unit at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., have accused the Government in court papers of leaking information about the Federal investigation of the financier to several large newspapers.

title: Europe to Join Colombia's Drug Fight
description: Cocaine-consuming nations of Europe and Latin America are starting to join the United States in giving Colombia concrete help in its war on drug traffickers, diplomats and Government officials here say.

title: GATT Weighs China's Entry
description: The world trade body GATT decided today to resume consideration of China's request to join it.

title: Accounts
description: * Vintwood International, to Korey Kay & Partners, with a budget of $3 million to $5 million.

title: When the Police Guidelines Don't Help
description: The New York City Police Department has developed strict guidelines for handling people suffering from cocaine intoxication, but law-enforcement experts say officers often do not know when to use the guidelines.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY ARCTIC DRAMA

title: Review/Theater; New 'Sweeney' With a New Message
description: Of all the powerful moments in the American musical theater, there may be none more perverse than the Act I apex of ''Sweeney Todd.'' That moment has never seemed either more moving or more sick than as played by Bob Gunton, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street, in the revival of Stephen Sondheim's musical that has arrived at the Circle in the Square.

title: No Talks Scheduled In City Opera Strike
description: The New York City Opera and its orchestra players have not yet met to discuss the salary and scheduling issues that led to a walkout on Wednesday evening.

title: C. Lincoln Crane Jr., Marine Engineer, 58
description: C. Lincoln Crane Jr., a marine engineer and chief of stability and control for the Davidson Laboratory at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., died at Southern Ocean County (N.J.) Hospital on Sept. 10 after a swimming accident. He was 58 years old and lived in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Writing Coaches Helping to Stamp Out Legalese
description: ''Dear Miss Grammar: What's the difference between 'commence' and 'begin'?''

title: Washington at Work; Barney Frank's Public and Private Lives: Lonely Struggle for Coexistence
description: When he was first elected to the State Legislature from the Back Bay of Boston in 1973, Barney Frank's friends told him that if he was going to be a politician he would have to spruce up. His hair was a mess, his shoes were unpolished, and, to be blunt, he was fat.

title: 'Fishbait' Miller, 80, Former Doorkeeper Of the U.S. House
description: William M. (Fishbait) Miller, who served three decades as the doorkeeper of the House of Representatives, died Tuesday night at his home in Greensboro. He was 80 years old.

title: PANEL SET TO DROP MEDICARE BENEFIT
description: Considering changes to reduce the costs of insurance that protects the elderly from being catastrophically high medical expenses, the Senate Finance Committee agreed informally today to drop either increased protection against doctor bills or payments for prescription drugs.

title: No More Automatics For Kickers
description: Syracuse University students did not celebrate the school's extra-point streak by chalking up 1's in the Carrier Dome, the way Met fans hang S's and K's from the upper deck for strikeouts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES A $6.75 billion bid for United Airlines was approved by the board of UAL, the carrier's parent company. The $300-a-share offer came from a group that includes the airline's pilots, top executives and British Airways. If the deal is completed, UAL would be the nation's largest employee-owned company. [ Page A1. ] The employee-owners may find that running the company may turn out to be more difficult than winning the bidding. [ Page D5. ] Campeau and its creditors continued last-minute talks aimed at arranging a $250 million loan that would put more working capital into the Canadian company's U.S. retail operations. Campeau is facing a deadline of today to arrange new financing. [ D1. ] British Petroleum agreed to sell some oil and gas properties to Oryx Energy of Dallas for $1.31 billion. [ D1. ] The former chairman of Ashland Oil pleaded guilty to criminal charges that he tried to sell company secrets to an Iranian oil company for use in its lawsuit against Ashland. [ D1. ] G.M. will idle a plant in Atlanta, which has 2,200 workers. The plant makes Chevrolet Caprices and Buick Estate Wagons. [ D1. ] An investor group led by Harold S. Geneen has an agreement to buy Continental Information Systems of Syracuse. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY Legislation to cut the tax on capital gains was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee, handing President Bush an important political victory and setting the stage for a fight on the House floor later this month. The vote was 19 to 17. Six Democrats voted with all 13 of the panel's Republicans. [ A1. ] Representative Ed Jenkins, a Democrat and the author of the capital gains tax cut, outmaneuvered the committee's chairman. [ D2. ] Retail sales rose 0.7 percent in August because of strong automobile sales. [ D15. ] The ''junk bond'' market was called basically sound by the Adminstration's nominee to head the S.E.C. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Mitsubishi Bank will be listed on the Big Board, becoming the first Japanese financial institution to trade on the exchange. [ D1. ] Bad debts held by the I.M.F rose sharply in the last year, and now total 10 percent of its outstanding loans. [ D6. ] MARKETS A new high-yield bond issue sold well, despite the jitters in the overall ''junk bond'' market. Even before pricing, underwriters had commitments for all $300 million of the issue of the Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group of Tennesee. [ D12. ] Stock prices fell in a carry-over of selling from Wednesday, as investors were rattled by the price plunges in junk bonds. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 14.63, to 2,664.89. [ D6. ] Copper prices surged to a four-and-a-half-month high. [ D13. ] The dollar rebounded, finishing higher in the U.S. after falling overseas. The gold price in New York was $360.50, up 60 cents. [ D13. ] Michael Milken's lawyers accused the Government of illegally leaking information to newspapers. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS

title: U.S. Seeks Details On Northwest Deal
description: The Transportation Department said it still had questions about the $3.65 billion acquisition of Northwest Airlines in July by the Los Angeles investor Alfred Checchi. In late June, NWA Inc., Northwest's parent, agreed to the cash offer from a group led by Mr. Checchi, whose partners include KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Steuben Day Parade, Fifth Avenue between 61st and 86th Streets will be closed tomorrow from noon to 4 P.M.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Natural Gas Corp., Denver, a subsidiary of Arkansas Power & Light, appointed Donald H. Anderson president.

title: Jets Wonder if Absences Make the Players Grow Softer
description: Barely three weeks after the Jets signed three important veterans for a total of $2.5 million this season, the club will face the Cleveland Browns on Sunday with one missing, one returning from an injury and one out of shape.

title: Campeau Loan Talks Continue
description: Robert Campeau, chairman of the Campeau Corporation, and his closest advisers were locked into last-minute negotiations last night with their key lenders and partners in an effort to cement a $250 million loan that would infuse new working capital into the company's American retail subsidiaries.

title: MX Missile Destroyed Three Minutes Into Test
description: An MX missile pulled from a silo in Wyoming for a test was destroyed three minutes into flight today, the Air Force said.

title: Soviet-Refugee Plan Faulted; Critics Say Flow Will Dry Up
description: Republican and Democratic members of Congress and religious groups today harshly criticized a Bush Administration plan to establish new procedures for screening Soviet refugees in Moscow, saying it would choke the flow of Soviet Jews and Pentecostals to the United States.

title: Soviet Refugees, by Any Other Name
description: How can the Bush Administration turn so heartlessly against Soviet Jews yearning for freedom? ''Heartlessly'' does not, at first, seem too strong -not when Jewel Lafontant, the Administration's refugee coordinator, tells Congress, so what if the U.S. doesn't admit them; they can ''always go to Israel or return to Russia.''

title: Boy, 5, Used as Drug Runner
description: A 5-year-old boy was used as a drug runner by the cousin who was his baby sitter, the police said today. Three people, including the baby sitter, were arrested and charged with fifth-degree criminal possession of a controlled substance and endangering the welfare of a minor. The police said the boy's mother was unaware of what was happening to her son in his baby sitter's care.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about public reaction to the mayoral primary in New York City misstated David N. Dinkins's share of the white vote. Of all whites who voted in the Democratic primary, 29 percent voted for Mr. Dinkins, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV poll. Of all Dinkins voters, however, 34 percent were white, according to the poll.

title: Plan to Allow Building Near Swamp Is Denied
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection rejected plans today for a municipal sewage treatment plant that would not only clean waste water but also encourage development.

title: Reebok Planning Inflatable Footwear
description: Reebok International Ltd. said it was introducing sneakers that could be inflated with air and that would sell for $170 a pair. ''The wearer will be able to inflate the shoe using a pump on the tongue of the shoe, making it fit round the wearer's foot perfectly,'' the company said.

title: INSIDE
description: Flaw in Part Delays Rocket A defect in a $12 circuit board has forced the Pentagon to delay deployment of the newest missile for Air Force fighters. Page A19. Executive Pleads Guilty Orin Atkins, the former chairman of Ashland Oil, admitted to criminal charges that he tried to sell company secrets to Iran. Page D1. Daily News Editor Resigns F. Gilman Spencer resigned after five years in which he was often at odds with the tabloid's publisher. Page B3. 7 Die in Assault Rifle Attack A man went on shooting spree at a printing plant in Louisville, Ky., and then killed himself. Page A12. Met Opera Selects Chief Hugh Southern, the acting head of the National Endowment for the Arts, has been named general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. Page C29.

title: Palestinian Sought by U.S. Asking for Release by Greece
description: A Palestinian accused in the bombing of a Pan Am jet asked today to be released from prison while Greece decides on a United States extradition request, his lawyer said.

title: Review/Theater; Anthropomorphic Acrobats From Japan
description: Puppets served tea and performed acrobatic tricks Tuesday morning when the Japan Society offered ''Karakuri Ningyo: Ancient Festival Puppets,'' a presentation that was both unusual and delightful.

title: Mitsubishi Bank Listing On Big Board
description: Mitsubishi Bank Ltd., the world's fourth-largest bank, with some $350 billion in assets, next week will become the first Japanese financial institution to be listed for trading on the New York Stock Exchange. It will be the largest commercial bank and the largest foreign company ever listed on the Big Board.

title: N.Y.U. Offers a Boost Toward Public Service
description: One-third of the new graduates of New York University Law School have decided to donate part of their income to a fund to enhance salaries of law graduates who take public service jobs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11, D17

title: Bell Atlantic Planning Cuts
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, one of the nation's seven regional Bell telephone operating companies, said yesterday that it planned to reduce its work force by 1,000 to 1,200 managers by the end of the year to cut costs.

title: Auctions
description: Kaufmann Collection

title: We've Been Bowling Since Peter Minuit
description: To the Editor:

title: Boufford Quits Post as Chief Of Hospitals
description: Dr. Jo Ivey Boufford, who has headed New York City's municipal hospital system during a period of crisis, announced her resignation yesterday to take a fellowship in England.

title: Hungary's Motive: Earning Western Good Will
description: Initially embarrassed at serving as an escape hatch for East Germans fleeing to West Germany, Hungary now appears to believe that having allowed more than 13,000 citizens of an ally to flee to a country in the opposing alliance will do it more good in the West than harm in the East.

title: California Journal; No Escape In the Wild From Grip Of Society
description: The idea was to get away from the fetters of big-city life in Los Angeles, away from the congestion, crime and traffic tickets. But two backpackers far up in the Sierra Nevada, amid 20 million acres of Federal wilderness, got a ticket over the weekend for hiking on the wrong trail.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 40 cents. The change is prompted by rising production and distribution costs. The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

title: In Moyers's Poetry Series, The Stress Is on Listening
description: Television and poetry are not natural bedfellows. The ordinary currencies of talk shows, local news programs and sports coverage are misused words, stale images, sloppy syntax, loony locutions and sheer blather.
