description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, which operates the largest natural gas pipeline system in the United States, agreed to sell its Houston Center real estate development to the JMB Realty Corporation for $400 million. The company said proceeds from the sale, which should close in 90 days, would be used to pay off debt.

title: New York Telephone Proposes Increases
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday proposed rate increases for 1990 to offset what it says is a decrease in revenues because some customers no longer pay for the telephone wires inside their homes.

title: Saudi Export Gain
description: Saudi Arabia's petrochemical exports rose by 22 percent in the first half of 1989, to $1.38 billion, from $1.13 billion in the period a year earlier, an official statement said today.

title: 2 African Innovators Receive Annual Hunger-Project Prize
description: The President of Botswana and a grassroots organizer from Burkina Faso have received the Hunger Project's annual leadership prize.

title: A Congressman Confronts a Hostile Art World
description: Representative Dana T. Rohrabacher, a proponent of the Helms amendment to restrict art financing by the National Endowment for the Arts, came to New York Thursday night to confront a hostile art world -or at least, a hostile segment of it. The freshman Congressman from California drew some laughter but also hisses from the audience during a lively panel discussion sparked by the current controversy over endowment financing for works by two photographers, Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1989
description: Companies

title: Review/Film; Graduating to Adulthood Just Before the South Erupts
description: ''Heart of Dixie'' is a clear-eyed, funny and affecting movie about the emotional awakening of a pretty, white Alabama coed in 1957, on the eve of the great racial struggles that would mark the 1960's throughout the South.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18.

title: A New Day for United Employees
description: Rank-and-file employees of United Airlines greeted today's news that they may soon own part of the company with reactions ranging from ebullience to skepticism.

title: Damaso Perez Prado Dies at 72
description: Damaso Perez Prado, the band leader who helped start a North American mambo craze in the 1950's, died Thursday at his home in Mexico City after a stroke. He was 72 years old.

title: 13 Die in Hindu-Muslim Riot
description: The police opened fire on rioting Hindus and Muslims in Kota, a western Indian town, and at least 13 people were killed and more than 50 injured, news reports said today. In a separate incident, the police held Sikh extremists responsible today for an attack that killed 12 people in renewed violence in Punjab in northern India on Thursday night. The clashes in Kota came late Thursday during celebrations of a Hindu festival, the Press Trust of India said.

title: Motorcycle Makers Shift Tactics
description: Beset by declining numbers of young men and by soaring prices, motorcycle manufacturers in this country are trying some novel marketing tactics in an effort to halt a decade-long slide in sales.

title: Patents; Diet Pills Said to Curb Fat and Cholesterol
description: Jackie R. See and William E. Shell, two cardiologists who founded See/ Shell Biotechnology Inc. in Los Angeles, won a patent this week for what they call ''Fat Magnets'': diet pills that prevent the body from absorbing some of the fat and cholesterol in food.

title: East Berlin Cancels a Visit by West Germans
description: With delicate relations between the two Germanys strained by the migration of East Germans through Hungary, East Germany today canceled a planned visit by members of West Germany's main opposition party.

title: McEnroe Seeks Change
description: John McEnroe, who reached the semifinals at Wimbledon this year before losing in the second round at the United States Open, won $232,500 Thursday for a 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Stefan Edberg in a winner-take-all exhibition match at the London Arena. Fans paid between $15.50 and $38.75 to watch the first one-night exhibition in Britain in more than a year and a half.

title: BOGOTA ON ALERT AFTER EXPLOSIONS
description: Three bombs exploded in Bogota today and Colombia's drug traffickers threatened a weekend of terror, prompting the Government to order the nation's soldiers and police on full alert and send military patrols into the streets of the capital.

title: Health Magazine in Spinoff
description: In an unusual twist for a magazine spinoff, Hippocrates will put its name on a new publication for physicians while keeping the contents of the existing magazine under a new title, In Health.

title: Kroger to Sell 9 Food Units
description: The Kroger Company, the grocery store chain operator, said it expected to reap $260 million in after-tax proceeds from the sale of nine food processing plants and two more whose sales are under negotiation. Kroger is selling the plants as part of a $4.6 billion corporate restructuring begun last fall to stave off two unsuccessful takeover attempts. Cincinnati-based Kroger owns supermarkets, convenience stores and food processing plants in 32 states.

title: From Prose and Poetry Of Robert Penn Warren
description: I got to Mason City early in the afternoon and went to the Mason City Cafe, Home-Cooked Meals for Ladies and Gents, facing the square, and sampled the mashed potatoes and fried ham and greens with pot-likker with one hand while with the other I competed with seven or eight flies for the possession of a piece of custard pie.

title: A Channel Innovates and Moves Up
description: In the two and a half years since MCA Inc. took over New York's least-watched, lowest-rated commercial television station and shipped it across the Hudson to Secaucus, N.J., WWOR-TV, Channel 9, has climbed out of sixth place in the nation's largest television market by shaking up the schedule with innovative, sometimes disputatious programs, from Morton Downey Jr. to Arsenio Hall - along with ''Cosby Show'' reruns, the most expensive in the history of television syndication.

title: Your Money; Long-Term Plan Yields Stock Gain
description: If a small investor had spent the last 20 years doing just what Wall Street professionals often say the little guy does - buying high - that person could have more than quadrupled the money invested, a new study from T. Rowe Price shows.

title: Charles J. Wurmfeld, Engineer, Dies at 82
description: Charles J. Wurmfeld, an engineer and inventor, died Thursday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 20,000 Apartheid Foes Allowed To March Through Johannesburg
description: The South African Government allowed a mass demonstration against apartheid to proceed unimpeded again today, although such marches are illegal under the current state of emergency declaration.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about defects in a rocket arming switch misidentified two jet fighters. The F-15 is flown by the Air Force and the F-18 by the Navy.

title: Campeau Said To Lose Control Of Retail Giant
description: Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who amassed one of the world's biggest retail empires by borrowing heavily to buy such stores as Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, was forced yesterday to yield control to get yet another loan to keep the operation solvent, executives in Toronto and New York said.

title: Look Who's Arming the Drug Cartels
description: Earlier this year William Bennett, President Bush's director of drug policy, stirred controversy with calls for a ban on the military assault rifles readily available in gun shops across the country. Now officials in Colombia add powerful weight to the case for a ban.

title: Letter: On Space Exploration; The Case for Splitting NASA
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. VOICING FEARS THAT GORBACHEV WILL DIVIDE WEST
description: In advance of new high-level Soviet-American talks, top officials of the Bush Administration are expressing concern that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies could lead to the breakup of the Western alliance and the disintegration of the postwar European order.

title: Braniff's Loss At $20 Million
description: Braniff Inc. posted a $20 million loss for the three months ended July 31, mainly because of a reorganization to build an important hub at Kansas City International Airport, the company reported this week.

title: Dollar Finishes Day Lower After Sharp Morning Rise
description: The dollar went on a wild roller-coaster ride yesterday, reaching three-month highs in the morning because of a positve trade deficit report and then plunging in the afternoon on unfounded rumors, including one that President Bush had been shot. There was also a round of coordinated dollar selling by the United States and its allies.

title: Saturday New Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Breaking One of South Africa's Barriers
description: Vernon Grigg's application for a Supreme Court clerkship was heavy with conventional credentials. He is a student at Yale Law School. He had an honors degree from the University of Michigan and a year at the London School of Economics. He had also apprenticed at two top law firms, was a licensed glider pilot and had performed in a singing group called Up With People during halftime at Super Bowl XVI.

title: Jail Term for Ex-Officer of Unisys
description: A former executive of the Unisys Corporation, who was described as ''a major figure'' in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing fraud, was sentenced today to 32 months in prison for bribing a Government official with money from a secret $5 million fund.

title: Mr. Courter Embraces Prejudice
description: Even people uncomfortable with homosexuality ought to be uncomfortable with the way Jim Courter, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, discusses it in his campaign.

title: In Killer's Disorder, Cycles Of Elation and Depression
description: Joseph T. Wesbecker, who killed seven workers Thursday at a printing plant in Kentucky before killing himself, suffered from manic depression, relatives told the police.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 40 cents. The change is prompted by rising production and distribution costs. The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

title:
GARDENING;
The Return of the Seedless Watermelon
description: LEAD: SEEDLESS watermelons have been popular this year among commercial growers in the South. While relatively few seem to have shown up in produce markets in our region, they will certainly be here next season, and undoubtedly they will also appear in seed catalogues for those gardeners who grow their own.

title: RIO DE JANIERO
description: Correspondents on assignment around the world discuss the influence of local fashion on their own attire.

title: Refacing Coins to Rekindle Collectors' Interest
description: While investors have made coins more glamorous than they once were, only collectors, the industry says, can preserve their value over the long term by keeping demand high and coins out of circulation. But rising prices and the advent of slabs, which prevent coins' surfaces from being handled, have soured many collectors on coins. And the stale designs of the country's current coins haven't helped sustain their interest.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: INTERNMENT ART ''From Bleakness...'' is the title of an art exhibition and series of programs based on the experiences of Japanese-Americans sent to American internment camps during World War II.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LEAD: William H. Chace, president of Wesleyan University, nourishes his passion for the works of James Joyce by teaching a course on the author at Wesleyan. He will be the guest speaker at the next meeting of the James Joyce Society in South Windsor at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Danville, Vt.;
Town Resists Planning Law
description: LEAD: THIS dairy-farming town of 2,000 people has joined a handful of others in the Northeast Kingdom, a three-county region that is the state's most rural and independent, in refusing to plan under a new state law. The residents here voted, 2 to 1, last month to oppose using Act 200, a law that offers small planning grants in return for following state guidelines on such things as open space and commercial development.

title: Miss Macdonald Weds B. C. Twomey
description: Melinda Macdonald, a vice president in the investment banking division of Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, and Barry Cornelius Twomey, a vice president with AMEV Venture Management, a venture capital company in New York, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J. The Rev. James Steele officiated.

title: Proud Tina Keeps On Burnin'
description: Tina Turner's new album ''Foreign Affair'' (Capitol 91873; all three formats) adds some grit to the formulas that made Ms. Turner one of the most gratifying comeback stories of the 1980's.

title: Pamela Phillips, Lawyer, Is a Bride
description: Pamela Kim Phillips, the daughter of Nancy Phillips of Jacksonville, Fla., and John Phillips of Charleston, S.C., and R. Richard Zanghetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Zanghetti of Fishers Island, N.Y., were married yesterday at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church on Fishers Island. The Rev. Edward Wisneski officiated.

title: M.T.A. INSISTS GOLF WAS REALLY HOOKY
description: The Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will send evidence to the Bronx District Attorney this week showing that 19 Transit Authority workers regularly played golf on the authority's time, a spokesman for the Inspector General said yesterday.

title: Steven Mesh and Diana Juul: Lighting Designers
description: Steven Mesh and Diana Juul happily combine marriage and an architectural lighting design business in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Monique Richards Weds
description: Monique R. Richards, a daughter of Mrs. Joel H. Freis of Los Angeles, and David O. Zenker Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Zenker of Morristown, N.J., were married yesterday at the Lamington Presbyterian Church in Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. Dr. George Chorba, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Jay David Burke, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride, 26 years old, is a client-service representative at Sotheby's in New York. Her husband, 35, is a vice president of institutional sales at Oppenheimer & Company in New York.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a marble-topped coffee table that I recently tried to polish, using some old, dried-out marble polish. The surface now looks partly coated and streaked, and I have been unable to remove this with a new application of polish, even after considerable rubbing with a clean cloth. I also tried using warm water and soap. What I can use that will not damage the marble?

title: Tourist Grabs Mugger on IRT and Is Slashed
description: A 32-year-old Swiss tourist was stabbed in the face yesterday after he grabbed one of four men who had robbed him and three other tourists on a downtown No. 1 subway train, the transit police said.

title: A LIFE BEYOND THE PICTURE FRAME
description: LEAD: MOVING PICTURES By Anne Hollander. Illustrated. 512 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Review/Dance; 'The Disaster Series'
description: Quite a lot happened at the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Sept. 9. There were heartaches, lovers' quarrels, sudden deaths, car crashes, tornados, famines, avalanches and tidal waves - all because the Joe Goode Performance Group was on stage in ''The Disaster Series.''

title: NONFICTION
description: LEGENDS: Conversations With Baseball Greats. By Art Rust Jr. with Michael Marley. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) ''I have always been a sports fan, but baseball is my great love,'' writes Art Rust Jr., the host of a New York City radio sports talk show. The short narratives in ''Legends'' and his warm, passionate dialogue with past and current superstars - including Joe DiMaggio, Stan Musial, Mickey Mantle, Don Mattingly, Bob Feller and Rod Carew - amplify his claim. Mr. Rust's interviews (assembled with the assistance of Michael Marley, a sports columnist for The New York Post) are probing and illuminating. The players' tales of games, feats, teammates and opponents will fire up the memory of any baseball fan. However, the two most poignant voices in this book belong to Red Barber and Rachel Robinson. Mr. Barber provides anecdotes about the early radio and television broadcasts of baseball games. He also chronicles the efforts of Branch Rickey, general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, to integrate major-league baseball in 1947 and tells how he, a white Mississippian, learned to accept and admire Jackie Robinson, the future Hall of Famer who was the first black player in the big leagues. Rachel Robinson, Jackie's widow, gracefully tells of her husband's struggles on and off the field while playing for the Dodgers. Through these insightful interviews, particularly with the old-timers, Mr. Rust provides us with a view of big-league baseball in a gentler time - a time before Astroturf, domed stadiums, cable television contracts and players selling their autographs to fans. For providing us with this view, Mr. Rust deserves our thanks.

title: Jan DeGaetani, 56, Singer of Avant-Garde Works
description: Jan DeGaetani, an American mezzo-soprano who became a champion of avant-garde music, died of leukemia Friday night in Genesee Hospital in Rochester. She was 56 years old and a resident of Rochester.

title: Freshman-Year Surprises for Mom and Dad
description: ''THERE won't be any ninth graders on the bus,'' my son announced before the first day of school. ''Cool kids don't take the bus.''

title: The Demon Seesaw Actors Ride
description: His hands were trembling so much I thought he was going to break into a hundred pieces like a Tom and Jerry cartoon character. He had been sitting at a nearby table in an L.A. actors' hangout and as he got up to leave, he threw me a ''We've never met, but I know you'' wave. I waved back and asked him to join my table. He hesitated a beat, then came over.

title: Susan A. Johnston, Lawyer, Is Wed To William F. Lattimer in Maryland
description: At Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Bethesda, Md., Susan Alice Johnston, a daughter of Ernest S. Johnston Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Anne M. Johnston, was married yesterday to William Franklin Lattimer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston D. Lattimer of Danville, Calif. The Rev. Leonard Bachmann performed the ceremony.

title: Linda Cornelius Becomes a Bride
description: Linda Louise Cornelius, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Edward Cornelius Jr. of Buffalo, was married in New York yesterday to Andrew Arthur Neisser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Neisser of Newport Beach, Calif. Acting Justice Richard L. Price of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated at Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: It Will Be Hard to Make Money
description: The high-definition television picture could use some clarification with regard to its likely roll-out schedule and its prospects for strengthening American-owned consumer electronics manufacturers. My view is that HDTV will take longer to become widely available than most people think and that it will not alter the decline of the American consumer electronics industry. HDTV has, however, been helpful in focusing attention on the need for an American industrial policy. I am cautious about HDTV for three reasons: First, HDTV will take longer to become widely available than many people expect. A review of the pace of introduction of color TV as an enhancement of black-and-white TV, or of FM radio as an enhancement of AM radio, shows that these successful technologies took four to five years, from initial commercial availability to about 1 percent penetration. To reach over 50 percent of households, took another 10 years. Video cassette recorders, show a similar pattern.

title:
RECORDINGS;
A New Chance to Hear Forgotten German Operas
description: LEAD: While it was new, German opera during and after World War I made little international headway. Outside Central Europe, even Richard Strauss's works after ''Rosenkavalier'' found little resonance, let alone the work of lesser figures: verismo from Max von Schillings, febrile explorations of neurosis and exotic decadence by Franz Schreker, Alexander von Zemlinsky and Erich Wolfgang Korngold, the post-Wagnerianism of Hans Pfitzner, the neo-classicism of Ferruccio Busoni, the expressionism of Schoenberg and Berg, and later the leaner and jazzier idioms of Paul Hindemith, Ernst Krenek and Kurt

title: In a First for Nardin Gallery, Five Photographers Exhibit
description: CROSS RIVER

title: Sputtering Syracuse Wins
description: Army gave Syracuse a battle today. The Cadets held on to a 7-0 lead until late in the third period, but at the end, the Orange, stronger although hardly better, had prevailed and won by 10-7.

title: Ms. Albern Marries Dr. John Sheffield
description: Audrey Lee Albern, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Albern of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Dr. John Van Loon Sheffield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Sheffield of Webster Groves, Mo. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: Neil Young, Dinosaur Extraordinaire
description: Of all the dinosaur rockers lumbering across our musical landscape, Neil Young counts as the liveliest, the one least likely to be headed toward creative extinction. It's possible for any old rock act to reproduce ancient hits for decades, and even to crank out new songs that vaguely recall those hits. The Beach Boys have been doing that for more than 20 years, and the Rolling Stones - however frisky their self-imitations - are doing it now.

title: Baseball Tied to Gay Rights In a San Francisco Coalition
description: Aides and supporters of Mayor Art Agnos are dressing these days in a mismatched wardrobe of coalition: lavender shirts and ties with orange and black baseball jackets.

title: Deng Is Silent, And the Chinese Can't Tell Where The Power Is
description: IN the last few years, Deng Xiaoping has played the Great Balancer, steering China into new directions but almost always positioning himself in the center of competing factions. These days the balancing act is wobbly, creating new uncertainties about China's political and economic future.

title: Giants' Defense Set For Run and Shoot
description: It's wide open. It's alive. It's different. It's dangerous.

title: ICE BREAKS BEFORE IT MELTS

description: In a review of Haiti's political situation after one year of rule by Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, two United States-based human-rights groups have criticized the Haitian Government for failing to stop widespread political violence and for slow progress toward promised democratic elections.

title:
FOCUS: MOUNTAIN VIEW, CALIF.;
A Downtown Reverses Trend to Suburban Sprawl
description: LEAD: The skeletons of a new City Hall and an arts complex rising on the main street of this suburb of San Jose represent more than just a demonstration of civic pride.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: Cyprus canteen chits are one of the most multinational currencies ever printed. Issued by an American-supported agency and printed in Jerusalem, they were used in Cyprus in camps run by Britain and spent by Jewish refugees.

title: POSTINGS: Factory Renovation; Ping Pong Apartments
description: Blending a soupcon of whimsy with a touch of history and big hopes for profits, an architect-turned-developer who bought an abandoned commercial loft in the Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn has renamed it the Ping Pong Building and is cutting it into 33 cooperative apartments.

title: George Adams
description: George Adams, a saxophonist, leads a quartet tonight at the Village Vanguard, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: To win, the Mets must bench Darryl Strawberry, play Keith Hernandez and learn how to score runs from third base on outs. LARRY LEVINSON New York

title: Julie Beth Meer Marries
description: Julie Beth Meer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse R. Meer of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Robert Michael Harnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jason Harnick of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi William Kloner performed the ceremony at the Palm House in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Mrs. Harnick, 24 years old, is the assistant to the treasurer at the Museum of Broadcasting in New York. Mr. Harnick, 26, is an associate with the New York law firm of Kahn & Horwitz.

title: Rain and Fines, but Mostly Rain, Slow Burning of Amazon Forest in Brazil
description: Plumes of gray smoke are once again rising over the green sea of Amazonian rain forest surrounding this city. But preliminary survey figures from this year's dry season point to a new trend: a marked drop in burning.

title: Hungary's Defiance And Europe's Future: Journey Without Maps
description: IN May, when the Hungarians snipped the first strand of barbed wire along the Austrian border, they intended the act as a proud demonstration of their new Western posture. They also had no real need for the wire anymore. Several months earlier, the Government had lifted travel restrictions, opening a lively two-way traffic of Hungarian black marketeers and Austrian bargain-hunters.

title: A Suitable Home For Steamrollers
description: ARMED with oil cans and wrenches, several men approached a 1904 steam engine that once ran an entire woodworking factory. ''I hope this works,'' Robert Hungerford said. ''We put a lot of hours into this.''

title: Man Hurt in Fall Down Shaft
description: A 26-year-old Manhattan man fell two stories down an elevator shaft yesterday after the doors apparently malfunctioned and he stepped into the chasm without looking, the police said. The man, Yaron Kaplan, was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where he was in critical condition last night, a hospital spokeswoman said. The accident occurred about 10:45 A.M. as Mr. Kaplan, who works in retail sales, was waiting for a freight elevator on the fourth floor of 700 West End Avenue, where he lives. The elevator doors opened and Mr. Kaplan stepped into the shaft, plunging to the top of the elevator, which was on the first floor. Residents said they often use the freight elevator because it is faster than the one for passengers.

title: Badlands
description: To the Editor: In reading about the ''Good Old Days in the Badlands'' (Travel, July 30) I would like to contribute a few more details about the eccentric Marquis de Mores, the founder of Medora, N.D.

title: Time of Reckoning For 'Junk Bonds'
description: ''Junk bond'' prices plunged amid increasing worrries about the financial health of some large issuers of the high-yielding low-rated debt. The focus of attention last week was the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian real estate and retailing concern that took on heavy debt in an aggressive acquisition campaign. Facing a cash squeeze, Campeau said earlier this month that it wanted to sell Bloomingdale's, the glitzy stores that many considered its prize holding. Campeau was trying last week to arrange an emergency loan from Olympia & York, the Canadian real estate concern. The talks were expected to result in Olympia & York taking effective control of the company from its chairman, Robert Campeau. Last week the bonds of some Campeau units had one-day losses of as much as $200 for each $1,000 in face value. Losses elsewhere were not that drastic but they were widespread. *

title: DVORAK YES, BEETHOVEN NO
description: JANACEK'S UNCOLLECTED ESSAYS ON MUSIC By Leos Janacek. Edited and translated by Mirka Zemanova. Preface by John Tyrrell. 234 pp. New York: Marion Boyars Publishers.

description: Linda Helen Miles, a daughter of Mrs. David Adams 4th of Bethlehem, Pa., and the late Frederick W. Miles, was married yesterday to Louis Charles Murray Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray of Orlando, Fla., at the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd in Blooming Grove, Pa. The Rev. John Lipinski officiated.

title: Mr. D'Amato's Double Vision
description: Dear Senator D'Amato: Your distaste for the Andres Serrano photograph of a crucifix immersed in urine seemed clear when you ripped up the catalogue of a show that included the photo and threw the shreds on the Senate floor. But your correspondence with a constituent who disagrees with you raises a nagging question.

title: Plane Carrying 22 Is Missing Over the Jungles of Indonesia
description: A plane carrying 22 people disappeared over the jungles of the eastern Indonesian province of Irian Jaya, the official Antara news agency reported today.

title: Students Helping Students Cope
description: LEAD: ''COME on now, give me some synonyms for 'afraid,' '' said Janet Cervalli, a school psychologist, to 35 students spending a Saturday in the library of East Brunswick High School. ''Worried, anxious, freaked out, nervous,'' the students suggested. Ms. Cervalli nodded. It is important, she told the young people, that they not come on to their peers like a

title: Freedom of Speech, II
description: Wildflowers do not blossom in the carefully tended Rose Garden at the White House, or at the carefully scripted ceremonies there. But last week, Chantee Charles, a 13-year-old from Arlington, Va., used a Rose Garden ceremony honoring an anti-drug program to lecture against the death penalty as President Bush, who supports it, looked on a bit nonplused. Instead of reading her anti-drug pledge, Chantee said of the death penalty, ''All it does is take away someone else's life.'' Mr. Bush seemed to compliment her indirectly. ''It's not easy,'' he said, ''to get up in front of a big, scary audience like this and do such a good job, say what's on your heart, not worry if people agree with you or not.''

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: The Mets organization should stop reading their preseason notices, play like a hungry team, get consistent, go back to basics, practice trying, and maybe next year will be better. CAROL WELLMAN Wilton, Conn.

title: Cuomo Pushes Shoreham Deadline
description: LEAD: SETTING a deadline for a crucial step toward dismantling the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has urged the Long Island Power Authority to complete its purchase of the $5.5 billion plant by November.

title: Rutgers a Winner on a Kick
description: A blocked punt that led to a third field goal by Doug Giesler with nine seconds to play lifted Rutgers to a 9-7 victory over Boston College today at Giants Stadium.

title: 1,367-Pipe Organ Is Dedicated at Ossining Church
description: THE parish of St. Augustine was founded in Ossining in 1853, and remained at its original site for more than 125 years. Then the widening of Route 9 forced the parish to relocate about a mile north, where it took over the former Mary Immaculate School. Those makeshift quarters were adequate, though hardly inspirational, and for the next eight years the congregation worked to raise enough funds to build a new church.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Food Aid to Sudan Seen as Averting Famine
description: Enough food, medical and other relief supplies are now reaching the strife-torn southern half of the Sudan to prevent a recurrence of the widespread famine that devastated the area last year, a senior United Nations relief official says.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Lionel Cros: Fashion Designer
description: LEAD: One of the hottest new fashion designers in Paris never went to fashion school and never had a fashion show. Technically speaking, Lionel Cros (pronounced kro), 32 years old, has not even produced a commercial line of clothes.

title: Egypt Would Be Host to Israeli-Palestinian Talks
description: Egypt indicated readiness today to be host to negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis on a phased and comprehensive settlement of the political deadlock surrounding the 22-month Palestinian uprising in Israeli-occupied territories.

title:
WINE;
German Wines Ready to Challenge U.S. Fare
description: LEAD: OFF-DRY (slightly sweet) German white wines appear ideally positioned to challenge popular American top sellers, like white zinfandel, for consumer dollars in the 1990's.

description: IN a recent newspaper interview, one of New York's trend-spotters and consultants summed up a troublesome syndrome that has overtaken society in the disposable 80's.

title: Correction
description: In an article last Sunday about television programs produced by David L. Wolper, the candidate who ran against Barry Goldwater in the 1964 Presidential race was misidentified. He was Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: It seems that every third thriller these days has to do with flying, and here are two ambitious specimens of the genre by Dale Brown and Mark Berent. Both men were flying officers in the United States Air Force, so when they write about flying they are to be read with respect. Whatever their abilities as writers - and it should be said that each author can manage a word processor in a professional manner -they know everything about advanced fighter aircraft and the physical and emotional problems that go into flying them.

title: Catholics and Jews Exchange Hope and Misunderstanding
description: FOR a quarter century, Roman Catholic and Jewish representatives have examined their traditions and tried to root out sources of prejudice and misunderstanding. Yet today, relations between Catholic and Jewish leaders have fallen into exceptional disarray.

title: WHO'S AFRAID OF THE BERLIN WALL?
description: GERMANY, AMERICA, EUROPE Forty Years of German Foreign Policy. By Wolfram F. Hanrieder. 509 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95 THE TWO GERMAN STATES AND EUROPEAN SECURITY. Edited by F. Stephen Larrabee. 330 pp. New York: Institute for East-West Security Studies/St. Martin's Press. Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $15.95.

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: If they're still in it by this time (doubtful), the Mets will have to play with an intensity they haven't been able to muster all year. They'll also have to go with Magadan and Barry Lyons, and keep the once-great Hernandez and Carter out of the lineup, and harm's way.

title: Houston Journal; Grand Jury Disruption: 5 Lawyers And a Feud
description: A state district judge chose an unusual grand jury last month, and the legal system here has been tied up in knots ever since.

title: Carol Bergren Marries
description: The marriage of Carol Marie Bergren, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Bergren of Easton, Pa., to John D. Santoleri, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Santoleri of Havertown, Pa., took place yesterday at the College Hill Presbyterian Church in Easton. The Rev. Thomas Yorty, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Stephen F. X. Flynn, a Roman Catholic priest. Ms. Bergren, who will keep her name, is an assistant vice president of Boston Properties, a real-estate development firm in New York. Mr. Santoleri is an associate with E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company Inc., a New York venture capital concern.

title: Design Preview; Milano Nuovo
description: JUST AS FASHION MAVENS look to the seasonal Paris shows for new directions in clothes, every September the design world turns to the Salone del Mobile di Milano. Indeed, nearly 150,000 people - furniture dealers, store buyers, designers, architects and journalists - annually flock to Milan to see innovative objects and new talents. By far the world's most important furniture fair, this is where trends begin and stars are born.

title: There's Something Old, Something New, and a Lot of Both
description: The flood of classical recordings will continue this season, driven, as in recent seasons, by the compact-disk boom. Releases scheduled over the next months include newly unearthed rarities, warhorses, new artists, old artists, old labels rejuvenated and new labels, which are popping up constantly. A look at Musical America magazine's listing of forthcoming recordings turns up about 1,000 releases, and that is sure to be only part of what awaits the classical buyer.

title:
WORLDLY DRESSING IN 3 EASY LESSONS;
2. Finding Your Suit Style
description: LEAD: The differences between Japanese, American, Italian and English tailoring are partly a matter of silhouette. To find what shape suits you, follow the line of the shoulder.

title: Deborah J. Savin Marries
description: Deborah J. Savin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Savin of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Steven L. Scoggan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Scoggan of Boulder, Colo., by Cantor Robert Abelson at the Hotel Pierre. The couple own and operate ''Z'' Place, a private club in Park City, Utah. The bride's father is the chairman and the chief executive officer of IPCO Corporation, a White Plains manufacturer of health-care products. The bridegroom's father retired as a real-estate developer in Boulder. Mr. Scoggan's first marriage ended in divorce.

The surface now looks partly coated and streaked, and I have been unable to remove this with a new application of polish, even after considerable rubbing with a clean cloth. I also tried using warm water and soap. What I can use that will not damage the marble?

description: Mara Louise Mullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Rolf Mullen of South Egremont, Mass., and Brenton Robinson Grant 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant Jr. of Kennett Square, Pa., were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Great Barrington, Mass. The Rev. Donald T. Oakes, an Episcopal priest, officiated, assisted by the Rev. James Chace, a Congregational minister.

title: F. C. Trump 3d, Realty Manager, Weds Ms. Lorant
description: Lisa Beth Lorant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald J. Lorant of Princeton, N.J., was married last evening to Frederick Crist Trump 3d, the son of Linda Trump of Jamaica, Queens, and the late Mr. Trump Jr. Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the interfaith ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daphne Hawkes, a Presbyterian minister, at Temple Micah in Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: There's a Crime Wave, Or a Perception Wave, In the Soviet Union
description: CRIME and punishment has always been an exotic subject in this vast stew of a nation. Nowadays in the Soviet Union, one of the darker boons of a more open society is that mayhem buffs can flit from articles about the 14-year-old boy who strangled his mother, to the ''Wild East'' train robbers who specialize in halting freight runs of desperately needed food and furniture out in Siberia, to criminal shepherds in the vast southern steppes who enslave alcoholic vagabonds to watch their flocks.

title: Janet Jackson Adopts a New Attitude: Concern
description: Janet Jackson's older brother Michael staked out the world as his pop territory when his ''Thriller'' created a new order of magnitude for a best-selling recording. She got a taste of mass pop success with her 1986 album, ''Control,'' which sold five million copies in the United States. Its sequel, ''Janet Jackson's Rhythm Nation 1814'' (A&M SP 3920, LP, cassette and CD), unabashedly aims for the commercial stratosphere.

title: A Rush of Investors Cause Hobbyists to Flee
description: When George B. Berk opened a rare coin shop in Canton, Ohio, in 1979, the necessary skills for his job included a horse trader's bent for negotiating, an encyclopedic knowledge of coinage and an artist's eye for appraising a coin's quality and esthetic appeal.

title: Wildflowers Spruce Up the Highways
description: THOUGH only in the initial stages, we've already witnessed some promising results of the State Transportation Department's attempts to beautify the highway along Interstate 95.

title: Oracle's Envious Ascent
description: On-Line transaction processing systems have so far relied primarily on proprietary software. Buyers of a Tandem or Stratus computer for transaction processing need programs from the same company.

title: Athletes Make Leap to New Life
description: On Willie Davis Day in Green Bay, Wis., the guest of honor stood on Lambeau Field, where he had played for 12 years, and cried because he recognized that this would be the last time people would cheer for him as a football player.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: My father is the proud owner of a new auto-focusing, single-lens-reflex camera. It isn't his first SLR, but it's the first he has owned that does the focusing for him. And thereby hangs a tale.

title: 1. How to Wear a Navy Suit
description: A double-breasted navy suit can go almost anywhere with the right accessories. Pack four shirts and three ties, and get a world of wardrobe options.

title: Keep Moscow Out of GATT
description: LEAD: When Secretary of State James Baker meets Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Wyoming later this week, economic as well as political issues will be on the table. While seeking to use economic tools as part of a creative approach to the Soviet Union, U.S. officials should be careful not to undermine other efforts important to our national interest.

title: Slovenia Defies a Warning From Belgrade
description: The Yugoslav republic of Slovenia has ignored a federal warning by adopting amendments to its constitution that proclaim a right to secede from the country.

title: DATA BANK: Sept.17, 1989
1989 Murder Rate Nearly Identical to 1988's
description: Murders in New York City are occurring at a rate almost identical to that of last year, when a record 1,896 were reported, according to Police Department statistics.

title: Rain Brings Early Curtain on Yankee Victory
description: There was something merciful about the rain that fell last night at the Stadium.

title: Some Fear U.S. Rocket Industry Will Fizzle Out
description: The nation's fledgling private rocket industry could fail in the next few years unless extraordinary steps are taken to insure its survival, aerospace experts say.

title: L. A. Giroux Wed To Miss Halliday
description: Stephanie J. Halliday, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Halliday of Columbus, Ohio, was married last evening to Leigh A. Giroux, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Giroux of New York. The Rev. Thomas York performed the ceremony at the Broad Street Presbyterian Church in Columbus.

title: Vichy Aide Accused in Jewish Children's Deaths
description: An association of children of Jews deported during World War II has filed a complaint accusing Rene Bousquet, a former police chief in France's Vichy Government, of crimes against humanity.

title: Children's Parties: Costlier and Exotic
description: LEAD: IT is Star Date 1989 and a group of teen-agers gather before the console of the Starship Enterprise. Dials set to warp speed, they prepare to embark on an adventure like none they have had before.

title: Barbara Dugan Marries on L.I.
description: Barbara Mary Dugan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Dugan of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Peter Beuerlein, a son of Mrs. Robert Wylie of Whiting, N.J., and the late William Beuerlein. The Rev. Peter Kelley performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Old First Church in Huntington, L.I.

title:
ART;
An Expressionist's Way With Sail and Cycle
description: LEAD: AN Expressionist painter who earned a Bronze Star for the combat paintings he made during a tour of duty in Vietnam, Tony Antony, is nothing if not exuberant and passionate. He paints what touches him and in this category are motorcycles and sailboats. He also paints his wife, Monika, and the adventures of an otherwise unidentified woman named Gretchen.

title: A Golf Complex a Chip Shot From Boston
description: LEAD: A $250 MILLION golf community offering affluent people of working age primary homes in a leisure-living environment is rising on 350 secluded acres in this suburb just a half-hour's drive north of Boston. The 235 homes, with lots, start at $450,000, with many above $1 million.

title: Divvying Up Defendants So Judges Get a Fair Share
description: Watch out Judge Rothwax. Get busy Judge Leff. Here come Hugh Tingling and his court efficiency experts.

title: Force or Politics?
description: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians is off the front pages of our newspapers. The drama of the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza is reduced to a few paragraphs recording another 12-year-old shot dead by Israeli soldiers, another alleged ''collaborator'' killed by fellow-Palestinians.

title:
Interview: Bishop John R. McGann;
Guiding the Faithful In Turbulent Times
description: LEAD: IN 1957, the Diocese of Rockville Centre was established to oversee all Roman Catholic parishes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Previously, the Island's Catholic churches had been a part of the Brooklyn Diocese.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: It is impossible to overstate the importance of having enough breadth in your repertoire to be able to choose both kingside and queenside openings. Yet many players try to avoid all the work that entails by specializing in one or the other.

title: Japanese Variations On the Pancake Theme
description: IN Japan, American-style pancakes, with butter and syrup, are readily found in coffee shops, where they are called hotto keki, the Japanese pronunciation of hot cakes. Their indigenous cousins, however, are much more interesting, filled with sweetened, mashed beans (tai-yaki, dora-yaki and ningyo-yaki); chopped cabbage, seafood, meat, and even noodles (okonomi-yaki) and bits of cooked octopus (tako-yaki).

title: NONFICTION
description: BACK THERE WHERE THE PAST WAS: A Small-Town Boyhood. By Charles Champlin. (Syracuse University, $18.95.) Charles Champlin, who left his hometown of Hammondsport, N.Y., in 1942 at the age of 16, still considers himself on ''temporary assignment from Hammondsport to the larger world.'' In ''Back There Where the Past Was,'' compiled from columns he wrote for The Los Angeles Times, he enshrines the small-town American life of his boyhood. Mr. Champlin lovingly remembers the gas station that was his teen-age hangout, the bandstand where he played the cornet during Saturday night concerts, and the post office, the social focus of the town. He writes of growing up with doting grandmothers and great-aunts, of being one of the few kids with divorced parents and about his conflicts over sin (that is, sex) versus purity as a member of ''the next-to-last non-permissive generation.'' Yet lurking among the charming details of Mr. Champlin's childhood are stories of other lives, and I wanted to hear more. What did Hammondsport feel like to Black Eva, one of its few black citizens, who made her living cooking for white families, or to Gladys, the sole Jewish girl in Champlin's class, or Jack Van Loan, the ''myopic bachelor with a vast belly'' who spent his life clerking at the post office? Mr. Champlin muses in passing on the lives of these and others, but in the end his memoir becomes a nostalgic slide show of the past, a book that will appeal to those who grew up in similar small towns, but that may leave some readers suspicious that everything back then, back there, was too good to be true.

title: Police Check Whether Body Is That of a Missing Teacher
description: A woman's body was found yesterday in a car in Uniondale, L.I., and the Nassau County Police were investigating whether the body was that of a missing Brooklyn teacher.

title: Child Care: A Need That Keeps On Growing
description: AS the number of working mothers increases daily, so does the need for child care.

title: Reviews/Music; Fine Young Cannibals Pilfer the Past
description: Pop music continually recycles itself, building new hits around familiar hooks. The Fine Young Cannibals, the British band that opened a sold-out two-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday, do not bother to disguise their pilferage. They ransack Top 40 songs from the 1960's through the 1980's, with special (and obvious) attention to Motown songs. Before they played their biggest hit, ''She Drives Me Crazy,'' the band's lead singer, Roland Gift, led an a cappella version of the Temptations' ''My Girl,'' which supplies a chord progression for ''She Drives Me Crazy.'' (Half the song's chorus, meanwhile, derives from Cyndi Lauper's hit ''Girls Just Wanna Have Fun.'') The Fine Young Cannibals have a worthy pedigree. Their guitarist, Andy Cox, and bassist, David Steele, were members of the English Beat, a band that put an intelligent spin on pop, punk and Jamaican ska. But the Fine Young Cannibals have returned to ordinary pop topics and cliches, retaining only the mildest of ironies by setting morosely lovelorn lyrics to uptempo tunes.

title: A PRANKSTER PAYS THE PRICE
description: LEAD: On a whim, a retired British spy named Hilary Glasp, the protagonist of the title piece in the actor, director and author Peter Ustinov's book THE DISINFORMER: Two Novellas (Arcade/Little, Brown, $14.95), responds to a news report of a car bombing with a prank phone call attributing the crime to an invented Arab terrorist group.

title: Where Can a Black Win? The List Is Getting Longer
description: WASHINGTON

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 11 misidentified a new development on Nantucket, and its location. A reader has recently written to point out that it was the Cliffside Beach Club, overlooking Jetties Beach.

title: SOMETHING VENGEFUL AND ANCIENT
description: FIRST LIGHT By Peter Ackroyd. 328 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $19.95.

title: Body and Mind; DIFFERENT BUT DEADLY
description: FIVE YEARS AGO, AT the bedside of a patient in a cardiac intensive-care unit, a senior cardiologist remarked to me that he hoped I never needed to be on a balloon pump. Intra-aortic balloon pumps are ingenious sausage-shaped devices that sit deep in the aorta and temporarily assist the failing hearts of patients who are awaiting open-heart surgery. Ingenious though they may be, the cardiologist explained, they are one-size-fits-all - the size appropriate for an average man, which means that for smaller women, the pumps either can't be used at all or can lead to complications.

title: Redus's 3-Run Homer Helps Pirates Halt Mets
description: Gary Redus hit a three-run homer and Mike LaValliere and Jose Lind had consecutive run-scoring doubles to give Pittsburgh the lead in the fourth inning today as the Pirates beat Chicago, 8-6, to end the Cubs' winning streak at six games.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE INVENTORY MESS;
Caution: A Price Deflation Is Under Way
description: LEAD: Inventories are the pivot on which the business cycle swings. Economists trained to track just the gyrations of supply and demand are apt to miss the shifts from inventory accumulation to inventory liquidation, and back again. Successful business heads know better. They see inventories as completing the eternal triangle between supply and demand.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Columbus Avenue Festival, Columbus Avenue between 66th and 90th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. The avenue between 90th and 96th streets will be closed from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the Muscular Dystrophy Bed Race.

title: Couple Enter House Market, But With a Trade in Mind
description: FRANK FABIANO has spent nine years renovating a 50-year-old log cabin here on Lake Mohawk into a comfortable recreational environment for his wife, Cindy, and daughters, Stacy, 19 years old, and Jessica, 14.

title: Soviet Jews Finding Israel Short of Jobs and Housing
description: Tanya Rosenweig, a Jew from Leningrad, could hardly restrain her eagerness to become an Israeli.

title: 'SPEND IT ALL, SHOOT IT, PLAY IT, LOSE IT'
description: LEAD: THE WRITING LIFE By Annie Dillard. 111 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Parishioners Protest a Ban On Bare Legs
description: The signs on the doors of Sacred Heart Church issue a commandment to all who enter: Thou shalt not dress immodestly or casually.

title: Gunmen Kill 82 Sinhalese in Sri Lanka
description: Gunmen rampaged through three villages in central Sri Lanka, burning and shooting to death at least 82 unarmed Sinhalese civilians in repeated night raids, residents and military officials said today.

title: After Four Terms, Us Versus Them Still Plays in Detroit
description: AT a time when a new class of crossover black politicians is reaching out to whites, Coleman A. Young, the cantankerous, tart-tongued Mayor of Detroit, continues to confound the experts with his popularity.

title: Keeping the Pitch Where It Should Be
description: The Lubo Opera Company is to be commended for its efforts to standardize the pitch to which orchestras tune (''As Pitch in Opera Rises, So Does Debate,'' Aug. 13). The relentlessly upward wavering of the ''concert A'' is a deception that jades our perception of performance. It is as unworthy a practice as grade inflation is in the classroom or as anabolic steroids are on the playing field. It is why so many foreign recordings sound tense and, frankly, out of tune.

title: Rural North Fork Is Fading Quickly
description: LEAD: THE future has arrived on the Island's North Fork, and it is a new shopping plaza on the corner of Tuthills Lane and Route 25 in Aquebogue.

title: Budapest Says It Will Keep Frontier to the West Open
description: Hungary will keep its border to the West open indefinitely after the migration of East Germans this week, Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth said in a commentary written for a West German newspaper and made public today.

title: RJR's Brave New World
description: Last week was not a happy one in the ''junk bond'' market. As the Campeau Corporation's highly leveraged empire started to crumble, fears - some might even say panic - about the fate of other companies that had gone private through junk bond-financed leveraged buyouts swept Wall Street. Junk bond prices plummeted, dragging down even bonds that analysts had thought safe.

title: Compromises Made By Working Parents
description: I know I'm not the only self-employed parent who had a grim laugh at the Aug. 27 Page 1 photograph of mom, child and computer at home.

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: The Mets should:

title: U.S. Champion Wants More
description: Charles Marks, the first black to compete in the top ranks of offshore powerboat racing, has won the national title on accumulated points. He isn't required to compete Saturday in the final race of the circuit, but he has reason to be there, anyway.

title: Review/Theater; An Exploration of Cultural Confusion
description: Mixed media in the theater can be a mixed blessing. In ''Anulah, Let Them Eat Cake'' at the Theater for the New City, the music of Tonny Prabowo and Mickele Navazio is as light and loony as most of the dialogue, giving this little play the air of comic opera. But symbolic film and video sequences running throughout the performance mostly add further confusion to a mystifying story.

title: Gubernatorial Candidates Hone Images
description: AS the campaign for governor enters its final six-week run Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate, and Representative Jim Courter, the Republican challenger, are sharpening their efforts to form the images voters will take with them into the voting booth.

title: How Schools Can Win Votes At the Polls
description: I WAS distressed to read recently that the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education was planning to deal with the rejection of school budgets this year in about half of the state's public school districts by running workshops and conferences with such titles as ''Passing the Budget'' and ''Winning at the Polls.'' What the school boards association must learn is that you must first win the confidence of your constituency before you can win at the polls.

title: Dr. Lisa Wojan Becomes Bride
description: Dr. Lisa Denise Wojan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Alexander Wojan of Cornwall Bridge, Conn., was married in Amherst, Mass., yesterday to Dr. Joseph Edward Struckus, a son of Terri Priest of Worcester, Mass., and the late Edward Joseph Struckus. The Rev. Dr. Deene D. Clark, an Episcopal minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony in the Johnson Chapel of Amherst College.

title: Hurricane Imperils Eastern Caribbean; Warnings Are Issued
description: Residents of the eastern Caribbean boarded up homes and stockpiled supplies today as a hurricane churned toward the popular resort islands with winds of up to 140 miles per hour.

title: Hanna Hymans Becomes a Bride
description: Hanna Hymans, a daughter of Kathy Nakajima Hymans of New York and Osaka, Japan, and the late Murray Hymans, was married last evening to Greg Ostroff, a son of Mrs. Jack Ostroff of Cherry Hill, N.J., and the late Mr. Ostroff. Rabbi Henry Weiner officiated at Windows on the World in New York.

title: Allison D. Barrall Wed in Rhode I.
description: Allison Davies Barrall, a financial analyst for the SEI Corporation in San Francisco, and Scott Wyllis Christopher, an investment banker at Shearson Lehman Hutton there, were married yesterday at St. Matthews Episcopal Church in Jamestown, R.I. The Rev. Daniel Burke performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Herbert Barrall, an uncle of the bride.

title: A Conductor Must Help to Shape Public Taste
description: The only significant body of work that has been added to our orchestras' standard symphonic literature in the last 30 years is the music of Gustav Mahler - a telling example of how orchestral repertory has been shrinking. But even that acceptance was a long time in coming.

title: In From the Cold, but Cold
description: Though Soviet defectors have been an invaluable weapon for the C.I.A., they have often been cast aside once their usefulness is over. One became a dishwasher in a New York noodle shop, another a bellhop.

title: Florida State Finally Wins
description: Peter Tom Willis hit Terry Anthony with a 32-yard touchdown pass in the third quarter and ran 7 yards for a touchdown in the fourth period tonight to lead Florida State to a 31-21 victory over Louisiana State.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Kyoto
description: Kyoto these days lives in eager anticipation - and more than a little fear - of next year.

title: Carla Jean Edwards to Wed in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Edwards of Jersey City have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Carla Jean Edwards and Herve Gouraige, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franz Gouraige of Rowland Heights, Calif.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Sales Slump in Hamptons Starts to Turn
description: LEAD: EXCEPT for houses that sell for $1 million and up, the vacation-home market in the Hamptons has generally not done well this summer, although some brokers say they have been very busy. Now, with the approach of fall - traditionally a strong selling season - interest appears to be picking up for houses in all price ranges.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bridgton, Me.; Condos Rising On Site of Inn
description: A LAKESIDE condominium project is being developed on the site of a former inn in this little town in Maine's western mountains. The complex, Moose Pond Village, nestled behind birches and evergreens on nine acres on Moose Pond, will include 19 units of 2,700 square feet priced at $275,000.

title: ONE WOMAN AGAINST THE ODDS
description: AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN By Tracy Kidder. 340 pp. Boston: A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Turkey Louis Quinze

title: Building Housing to Keep Staff
description: IN an area burdened by high housing costs and labor shortages, Manhattanville College in Purchase is one of a growing group of employers nationwide taking matters into its own hands. With help from a Washington-based development consulting firm, the college is putting the finishing touches on plans for a $5 million town-house apartment complex that could accommodate as many as 48 members of the school's staff, plus their families.

title: Gender Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Savimbi Says He Is Halting Angolan Peace Talks
description: The Angolan guerrilla leader, Jonas Savimbi, said tonight that he was suspending negotiations to end his country's long civil war because the two sides remain too far apart to have meaningful talks.

title: Karen H. Greve Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Helene Greve, an assistant commissioner with the New York City Department of Investigation, and Dennis Edward Milton, the chief deputy county attorney in the Suffolk County Attorney's Office in Hauppauge, L.I., were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. James J. Fischer officiated.

title: LIFE IN A DOOMED HOUSE
description: QUEEN LEAR By Molly Keane. 233 pp. New York: Obelisk/E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Michael W. Dush Weds Miss Myers
description: Susan Deaver Myers was married to Michael William Dush yesterday by the Rev. Compton Allyn, an Episcopal priest, in the Chapel at Watch Hill, R.I. The bride is the daughter of Paul D. Myers of Watch Hill and Cincinnati and the late Mary Coombe Myers. Mr. Dush is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Dush of Misquamicut, R.I.

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: The Mets need to hire a motivational psychologist to light a spark, move Dave Magadan to the second slot in the order, and move Keith Miller to center. He can at least bunt and make contact. Samuel has not done the job at bat, nor in the field. Someone needs to persuade Straw to look the bat on to the ball; he is pulling his eyes away before he makes contact. Until Doc is ready, move Sid Fernandez into middle relief and let him blow them away like he did the Red Sox in '86. Give Carreon more playing time. WALTER MCCARTHY Massapequa, L.I.

title: Southwestern Food With a Twist
description: FORGET all the Tex-Mex restaurants with their tasteless refried beans, stale tortilla chips, canned salsa and cheese-over-everything combination platters and head for Arizona Flats in Bridgeport.

title: Social Events
description: African-American Auction

title: Deng Reappears, Saying China Will Seek Change
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, reappeared today after three months of seclusion to declare that China would continue its reform policies, but he suggested that the country would from here on pay more attention to ideology.

title: Italian Circus to Warm Up the Garde
description: FROM Itzhak Perlman to Nipsey Russell to the Peking Acrobats, the Garde Arts Center in New London is putting together its first subscription season.

title: Art of Bunting Is Sacrificed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the Selective Guide to Photography last Sunday in The New Season, part 2 of The Times Magazine, gave an incorrect location for the show by Ellen Garvens and Holly Roberts, opening in Manhattan on Dec. 7. It will be at the Jayne H. Baum Gallery, 588 Broadway (219-9854).

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a marble-topped coffee table that I recently tried to polish, using some old, dried-out marble polish. The surface now looks partly coated and streaked, and I have been unable to remove this with a new application of polish, even after considerable rubbing with a clean cloth. I also tried using warm water and soap. What I can use that will not damage the marble?

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Tasty Team for Fall
description: Apples go with pork as naturally as peas go with carrots. The combination is a sure sign of cooler weather; the recipe here is an updated version of an old familiar.

title: Pocono Cancels Race
description: As expected, officials of the Pocono International Raceway in Long Pond, Pa., have canceled next year's Indy-car 500-mile race, but the reason, according to Pocono's chief executive officer, has less to do with the unsafe condition of the 2.5-mile oval track than with the financial condition of the race.

title: The Riches of Brunei
description: IT isn't quite Wonderland, but Brunei has qualities that would delight Lewis Carroll. It also has Western-style comforts that can be welcome to a traveler ranging around Southeast Asia or the South Pacific who is tired of going native. There is an air of unreality about this tiny kingdom rooted like a molar on the north shore of the island of Borneo. It seems almost surreal if one goes directly to it from a poor, crowded place like Vietnam.

title: Yankee Fan Urges a Boycott
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Actress In Love With Risk
description: Karel Reisz has a favorite story about Vanessa Redgrave when she was on location for his 1969 film ''Isadora.'' The still photographer had asked her to run along a castle parapet above a sheer drop of hundreds of feet. It wasn't an important or urgent request; but no sooner was it made than she was up there in her Isadora Duncan costume, frolicking and defying fate. ''Why did you do that?'' asked the appalled director. ''Oh, I knew I wasn't going to fall off,'' replied the actress, ''and I wouldn't have cared if I had.''

title: Support For Spitz
description: LEAD: Some eyebrows were raised last week when it was reported that Mark Spitz, who won seven gold medals at the 1972 Olympics, would try to qualify in the 100-meter butterfly for the 1992 Games.

title: The Findings Clarified
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy's Treasures
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann was right in his article on ''Italy's Endangered Treasures'' (Travel, July 30). However, I am pleased to report that the first floor of the Borghese gallery was not closed on a recent weekend. Contrary to published listings and the firm belief of the clerk at our hotel, the lowest level of the Villa Borghese museum was open to the public on July 29 and, wonder of wonders, in the afternoon and at no charge. However, the second floor, containing the main display of paintings, is indeed closed. On the first floor, in addition to some wonderful Bernini sculptures, we enjoyed a lovely Canova portrait in marble of Napoleon's sister Paulina (who married Prince Camillo Borghese) posed topless on a chaise lounge. MEL MANDELL New York, NY

title: Beware Those Network Failures
description: The number of companies that have tied their personal computers into local area networks, or LAN's, is growing rapidly, and a new study has found that the networks function properly 94 percent of the time. But what about that other 6 percent - those times when the network fails? The study, released at the Networld trade show here last week, found that the LAN failures are a bigger problem than many people think. In fact, they can cost a large corporation an average of $3.48 million in losses each year.

title: Power Is Short-Circuiting Tennis's Appeal
description: A three-of-five-set men's singles match certainly gives you time to reflect upon trends in tennis today.

title: On Education, Washington Is Looking Hard for Bargains
description: THE House of Representatives voted last week to create federally financed scholarships in math and science and to establish tuition awards for students who would agree to teach in elementary or secondary schools. But the move was hardly noted, and perhaps that is not surprising.

title: A Boom Down Under
description: Visiting Australia and New Zealand for the first time this summer, I was impressed by not only mountains, fjords and sophisticated cities but by the number of flourishing dance groups, some of them unfamiliar to audiences above the equator.

title: WRECK SALVAGERS RAISING TREASURE
description: Salvagers who have begun raising gold bars and coins from a sunken 19th-century steamer say they expect to stay offshore until winter recovering as much as $1 billion from the ship, an expedition spokesman said.

title: Both Sides, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: New Barriers to Homeless at Station
description: Although the stately marble waiting room of Grand Central Terminal has been sealed off behind a plywood wall since early this month, the half-million people who dash through the station each day have hardly been inconvenienced.

title: Hitler's Berlin Is Seen Through Shirer's Dairies
description: When Jerry Rafshoon approached Ted Turner in the summer of 1988 about making a mini-series based on ''The Nightmare Years,'' William Shirer's memoir of his reporting from Germany during Hitler's rise, Mr. Turner asked skeptically, ''Is this another Nazi story?''

title: Who Pays for the Windfalls of Others?
description: THERE is something wild going on about money nowadays, which has me worried. I'm referring to the outlandish amounts paid to certain segments of our society.

title: TALKING: Title Transfer; Advantage Or Pitfall For Aged?
description: AMONG the tips that elderly parents often pass along to one another is the notion that major estate-planning advantages may be gleaned by transferring the title of their homes to their children.

description: Magazine Part 2

title: Gender Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: On Life's Beach, Sands of Time
description: IF you have spent summer days at the beach, as I have, you can look about you and see your life unfold from blanket to blanket.

title: Disarm, Don't Disengage
description: Military people all over are getting the jitters as East and West come to grips for the first time with the idea of really cutting armed forces. Norway is no exception, although there are political advantages.

title: Robin C. Comizio Becomes a Bride
description: Robin Carol Comizio, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Comizio of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Douglas Andrew Goodman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome David Goodman of Saddle River, N.J., were married yesterday at the Most Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Franklin Lakes. The Rev. Carl Hindrichson performed the ceremony.

title: Ismail Leads Notre Dame Past Michigan
description: They speak in the complex football language of the late 1980's at places like Notre Dame. They prepare for months for days such as this one, the first of several decisive meetings to determine the New Year's Day matchups and define the final outcome of the national college polls.

title: Amy Laurie Wed To Allen Kovac
description: Amy Rose Laurie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laurie of Westfield, N.J., and Claverack, N.Y., was married last evening at the Carlyle in New York to Allen Kovac, a son of Helga Kovac of Eugene, Ore., and the late Andrew Kovac. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Joel Gore.

title: 3. Simple Ways to Mix Color
description: Start with a clean, monochromatic look in earth tones. For a wedge of color, add a shirt in neon orange or blue.

title: Ms. Booker Weds Richard Snowdon
description: At St. Luke's United Methodist Church in St. Michaels, Md., Catharine Evans Booker, an independent estate trustee in Washington, was married yesterday to Richard Ward Snowdon 3d, a partner in the Washington law firm of Trainum, Snowdon, Holland, Hyland & Deane. The Rev. Raymond T. Hopkins 3d officiated.
