title: A Half-Century of Remodeling New York
description: NO New Yorker who has turned 50 - and there are others who would set the mark at 20 - has gained maturity in quite the same city that the native knew as a youngster. There has been no era in its history that some chronicler or another has not recalled, sometimes wistfully, sometimes exuberantly, a New York that was a gentler, somehow more intimately scaled city. Yet, particularly for those who come to settle in New York, the metropolis, with all its dangers, dirt and disruptiveness, is an unmatched exciting, vibrant center.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A Waterfront Community in Paulus Hook
description: LEAD: NOWHERE else along Jersey City's reviving waterfront does the Statue of Liberty loom so large, or the Manhattan skyline seem so clear as from the five vacant acres at the foot of Washington Street in the downtown Paulus Hook area.

title: NABOKOV'S LETTERS: 'LET ME EXPLAIN A FEW THINGS'
description: Vladimir Nabokov (1899-1977) belonged to a generation that still wrote letters, and he wrote them with tremendous zeal and artistry. Today his correspondence, stacked on shelves in cardboard filing boxes, covers an entire wall of the study in the suite of his wife, Vera Nabokov, at the Palace Hotel in Montreux, Switzerland. Later this month, some 400 of those letters will be published as ''Vladimir Nabokov: Selected Letters, 1940-1977,'' edited by Dmitri Nabokov and Matthew J. Bruccoli. Nabokov's correspondents were varied - friends, family, colleagues, editors and writers among them. And he addressed them variously with affection, irascibility, passion, outrage and - above all - honesty, sometimes to a fault, as the 18 letters selected and abridged here demonstrate. For instance, when his younger brother sends him a batch of poems for appraisal, he betrays a certain impatience, and questions the poet's motives. To his brother, Kirill Nabokov Circa 1930

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
A New-Old Victorian Blend in Dobbs Ferry
description: LEAD: A 125-YEAR-OLD, 9,000-square-foot Victorian mansion in Dobbs Ferry has been renovated and converted into three condominium apartments in a project that will include three new town houses designed to resemble the mansion.

title: The Trashing of New Jersey
description: JUDGING from the amount of litter that covers our highways and byways, streets, parks and public areas, New Jerseyans seem to be trashing their state with abandon.

title: Maine Lobsters
description: To the Editor: It is doubtful if Cynthia Hacinli caught ''a glimpse of trawlers, their nets full of hundreds of lobsters'' coming into Five Islands (''No-Frill Lobster on Maine's Coast,'' Travel, Aug. 13). It is illegal to catch lobsters in nets.

title: Ms. Adams Weds Michael S. Baldock
description: Jennifer Lynn Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Adams of Gwynedd Valley, Pa., and Bay Head, N.J., and Michael Shaun Baldock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lawrence Qualman of Coos Bay, Ore., were married yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head. The Rev. Edward B. Gammons Jr. officiated.

title: THE LANGUAGE OF FASHION
description: LEAD: AT A RECENT LONDON wedding, the English friends and family of the bride were dressed to the peak of their sartorial powers: fine black morning coats, buff-colored waistcoats fastidiously undone at the last button and silk top hats. Like their refined speech, their dress was redolent of the best and worst of English society - tradition and an unbridled sense of superiority.

title: Amy Grenen Wed to Donald Levantin
description: The marriage of Amy Sann Grenen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl M. Grenen of Radnor, Pa., to Donald Adam Levantin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen M. Levantin of Philadelphia, took place last evening at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia. Rabbi Elliot Holin and Rabbi Richard Steinbrink co-officiated.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Seoul at Night
description: EVENING is descending on Pagoda Park, a meditative oasis along one of Seoul's fiendishly thriving boulevards. The homespun-clad elders - men in stringy gray beards to match their Korean-white balloon pants and slippers, women with faces creased into a permanent cheery grimace - beckon me to join their circle. Even in summer, the capital of Asia's ''high blue'' kingdom imparts the sense of being a mountain citadel, a retreat to hole up in and erase the centuries of humiliation at the hands of stronger neighbors, to live hard and drink hard and gather warmth. The faces of the elders show long exposure to a wintry chill that's best kept at bay with hand-clapping and bursting into sorrowful song, the Korean habit of public balladeering complimented by habitual nibbles of kimchi and bracing swigs of soju, a turpentine-like substance that thins the impact of the peppered cabbage.

title: How Gypsy Moth Met Its Match
description: THEODORE ANDREADIS leaned back in his chair, laced his fingers behind his head and thought a moment. ''What was it like around here the day we discovered the gypsy moth fungus?'' he said, beaming as he repeated the question. ''It was an exciting day. A very exciting day.''

title: Kickback Accusations Have Gandhi on Defensive
description: Allegations that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi stifled efforts to reveal Indian recipients of bribes paid in an arms deal have put his Government on the defensive as a national election approaches.

title: On Language; The Legislative Mangle
description: LEGISLATIVE LAN-guage is governed by a law of etymology that is also the ancient code of the bureaucracy: It doesn't have to be right, it just has to be close enough for government work. If they understand what you mean, it doesn't matter what you say or how you say it. In most legislatures, punctilious attention to correct usage is considered elitist. The word government, for example, is normally pronounced ''gummint''; bureaucracy is ''bureaucacy''; fiscal comes out ''physical,'' and one moves not to suspend the rules, but to ''suppend.''

title: With Striking Fashions, Gigli Reaches New Heights
description: Romeo Gigli worked his fans into a frenzy at his first major New York show Thursday, re-creating the hysteria that greeted his first Paris show last March. The designer from Milan, Italy, has widened his circle: his earlier presentation was for retailers and the press; this one was for the women who would wear the clothes. The show was sponsored by Bergorf Goodman in the space at 745 Fifth Avenue and 57th Street that will be part of its men's store next year.

title: The Ear In the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: A Man Who Ran, The Story Behind It
description: LEAD: ONE sunny May morning in 1982, just days before the graduation ceremony he was to preside over at Charles County Community College in Maryland, Dr. Julian (Jay) Carsey disappeared.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
description: LEAD: I TRIED VERY HARD TO MAKE THE TRANSITION SMOOTH AND efficient. The objective I had in view, of course, was to avoid the confusion that occurs when one man comes in and another goes out. About a week after the Presidential election of 1952, I called Dwight Eisenhower and invited him to come over and sit with the Cabinet, and I had each member of the Cabinet report exactly what was going on and what had to be done.

title: Leslie Ann Davis Wed in Bronxville To W. R. Dahl Jr.
description: Leslie Ann Davis, an associate in structured finance at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York, and W. Robert Dahl Jr., a vice president in investment banking at the First Boston Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher Webber officiated.

title: In Yonkers, Voters Now Face a Clear-Cut Choice
description: MAYOR Nicholas C. Wasicsko's decisive victory in the Yonkers Democratic primary last week sets the stage for what has been anticipated as a general-election ''referendum'' on a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan, pitting the one-term Mayor, who favors compliance, against Henry Spallone, who opposes the plan.

title: FROM THE PARIS SEWERS TO VIETNAM'S STREETS
description: On his hands and knees, Cameron Mackintosh was scrounging around under the antique coffee table the other day in his Bedford Square office. The British musical theater producer - ''Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Les Miserables,'' ''Cats'' - was looking for some black-and-white glossies of his latest stage extravaganza, ''Miss Saigon.''

title: Sports of The Times; The New Commissioner Brings Up the Name Joe Page
description: The Joe DiMaggio of sports columnists, Mr. W. W. (Red) Smith, once tried to pull a swifty on a new baseball commissioner. Not only that, but he did it while the commissioner was buying.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, some copies of the Business section last Sunday omitted page 14, which included the continuation of an article about Mylan Laboratories Inc. Readers wishing copies may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell
description: An angry Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist says a new book about Robert H. Bork's ill-fated Supreme Court nomination incorrectly states that the Chief Justice broke a promise to keep Justice Lewis F. Powell's impending retirement a secret.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a marble-topped coffee table that I recently tried to polish, using some old, dried-out marble polish. The surface now looks partly coated and streaked, and I have been unable to remove this with a new application of polish, even after considerable rubbing with a clean cloth. I also tried using warm water and soap. What I can use that will not damage the marble?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The hot-money takeover game is over. The whole network is being disassembled.'' Michael Metz, chief investment strategist, Oppenheimer & Company, on the junk bond turmoil.

title: Transactions
description: Hockey

title: Palladio
description: To the Editor: I would like to add one bit of advice to Susan Lumsden's excellent article on Palladio's works in Vicenza (Aug. 13). There is a book, ''The Palladio Guide'' by Caroline Constant (Princeton Architectural Press), which takes Palladio fans to and through all the extant buildings he designed, both in Vicenza and elsewhere in the area around Venice. ROBERT WECHSLER Highland Park, N.J.

title: Beauty/Fashion; The Image Makers
description: MAKEOVERS ARE NO LONGER CASUAL ACTIVI-ties, a teen-age diversion on a slow Saturday night.

title: Nicaragua: Howard Fast's Version
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Grinnell; Campus Housing For Gay Students Being Considered
description: The president of Grinnell College said last week that the college was seriously considering including lesbian and gay couples in residences that would be established for married students.

title: FICTION
description: MURDER AT THE KENNEDY CENTER. By Margaret Truman. (Random House, $17.95.) Margaret Truman's ninth Washington-based whodunit is a bewildering clutch of characters, last-minute confessions, secret files, eavesdroppers and ethnic types who walk with, and without, limps. By the middle of the novel, we are as confused as the gracefully aging Mackensie Smith, a George Washington University law professor who reluctantly abandons his classroom to make sense of a scandal that begins when a lascivious female aide of Senator Ken Ewald is gunned down on the grounds of the Kennedy Center. Ewald, a philandering liberal Democrat from California and likely Presidential candidate, is discovered to be the owner of the weapon, and though there are no witnesses to the crime and no fingerprints are found, the police lock up the Senator's son, who was having an affair with the victim. Professor Smith, called in to defend the hapless lad, springs him easily but stays on to solve the murder. While calling on suspects and pursuing leads, Smith takes a suite at the Watergate Hotel. With his lawyer-turned-gallery-owner girlfriend, he eats in the right restaurants. They fly off to Manhattan to track down an unsavory blackmailer and then go on to San Francisco. In both locations, they also manage to stay in the right hotels and eat in the right restaurants. When the going gets rough, Smith hires a private investigator named Tony Buffolino, a hard-boiled photocopy of Peter Falk's Colombo, who provides comic relief and derring-do. Buffolino also ends up in the right hotels and restaurants, though he prefers room service. There is some muttering about the inadequacies of moral standards, and we are supposed to believe that Ken Ewald, for all his extramarital activity and derivative speeches, would make a better President than his conservative Democratic rival, a Georgian backed by a smarmy television evangelist - not to mention the smug Republican in the White House. At the climax a pointless assassination attempt is quashed, and the murderer confesses in a blurt of braggadocio, but what is most memorable are those room service entrees provided by the Watergate Hotel.

title: MEN OF THE WORLD
description: THEY live on planes, shop in airports, trade in foreign capitals, feel at home on seven continents. In the language of fashion, their vocabulary is concise: one suit, one suitcase, a 48-hour watch.

title: Cheer of Flying
description: WE were somewhere above Manitoba, my bride and I, when I lifted my plastic cup in praise of long airplane flights. ''That's just because of the free champagne,'' she answered. Much as I hate to replace emotion with reason, I had to admit that my judgment might have been swayed by the chilled bottle of Domaine Chandon before us, secreted out of the first-class cabin by a flight attendant determined to see our honeymoon begin happily besotted. But by the time, eight hours later, that we descended into Tokyo, having drained the drink and fallen asleep and awakened woozily sober, I was no less convinced of my case.

title: Late Summer Vegetables, Decorative and Abundant
description: LATE summer vegetables, which are still in abundance through early fall, make particularly decorative sauces for pasta. For a dish that is immediately satisfying, both to the eye and the palate, take some juicy sun-ripened tomatoes, chop them up and mix them with basil and a green olive oil and serve them on hot spaghetti. This simple dish, which needs no cooking, is redolent of the summer garden - and will all too soon be a memory when the last of the local tomatoes have been consumed and those pink rocks from Florida head our way.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: California; Fraternities Phase Out 'Little Sister' Groups
description: Fraternities across the nation are disbanding their ''Little Sister'' programs, under which women become associated with the men's groups, often paying small-scale dues. Little Sisters serve as hostesses for parties and help with service projects.

title:
NOTES FROM ABROAD;
BONN
description: LEAD: Correspondents on assignment around the world discuss the influence of local fashion on their own attire.

title: Live Music Dying Out in Casinos
description: AFTER a year without work, George Hernandez has given up trying to make a living in Atlantic City. He has sold his house, packed up his belongings and bought a one-way plane ticket to Los Angeles, where, at the ag of 58, he hopes to start a new life.

title: Betsy A. Burnham Marries
description: Betsy Alison Burnham, the daughter of Dr. Bernard A. Burnham and Mary C. Burnham, both of Watertown, Conn., was married last evening to Mark Andrew Stern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Stern of New York. Rabbi Stephen Pierce performed the ceremony at the Lake Waramaug Country Club in New Preston, Conn. Mrs. Stern, 27 years old, is the director of studio and corporate services for the Gap in New York. Mr. Stern, 26, is the director of development for the Trilogy Entertainment Group, a New York film production company.

title: Designers Vie to Honor Stalin Victims
description: What is the proper way to remember the victims of Stalin?

title: A Black Network Makes Its Move
description: Being the head of one of the smallest cable television networks does not keep Robert L. Johnson from thinking big.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; For Fun Over, On And Under The Earth
description: Weekend afternoons are calm in Kutztown, a country town set amid rolling cornfields and wheat fields about 25 miles west of Allentown in Pennsylvania Dutch country. The town, just inside the eastern boundary of Berks County, has retained the character of a quiet rural center since its founding in 1780.

title: Commitment to Drug Treatment Is the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT. By Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Flush from the runaway success of his previous book, ''All I Really Need To Know I Learned in Kindergarten,'' Robert Fulghum has come out with a second book of what are meant to be inspirational little homilies. Mr. Fulghum, a Unitarian minister in Seattle, specializes in taking ordinary stories from everyday life and using them to show that people are good, that life is sweet and that love endures. The stories in ''It Was on Fire When I Lay Down on It'' seem to have been designed to make the reader feel warm and fuzzy inside. They are like the children's story of Ferdinand the bull, where the moral is that it is better to sit still and smell the flowers. There is a market for this stuff, but how compelling is it to read an entire chapter in which Mr. Fulghum explains why he declines to say what it is he does and why he disdains business cards that categorize people? He concludes, ''I and you - we are infinite, rich, large, contradictory, living, breathing miracles - free human beings, children of God and the everlasting universe. That's what we do.'' Or how about a chapter on Mr. Fulghum's laws of life, laws that include ''Buy lemonade from any kid who is selling'' and ''Always take the scenic route'' and ''When the circus comes to town, be there''? I had trouble with this book for the same reason that I cannot watch an evening full of situation comedies on television. Others who have the same impatience with a prolonged immersion in popular culture should be forewarned.

title: Miss Curtis Weds Robert Goodman
description: Diane Hart Curtis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Peck Curtis Jr. of Rochester, and Robert Michael Goodman, a son of Donald Franklin Goodman of Stony Brook, L.I., and the late Marie Tscherne Goodman, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert M. Wainwright officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester.

title: Alfred Hurley Jr. Weds Denise E. Lee
description: Denise Elizabeth Lee, a daughter of Bernice A. Lee of Huntington, L.I., and Joseph O. Lee of Drums, Pa., and Alfred Francis Hurley Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hurley of Denton, Tex., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Gerard Reedy, the dean of Fordham College, performed the ceremony.

title: Violence Flares Again in Azerbaijan Republic
description: Three people were killed in a bus explosion in Azerbaijan today as the authorities reported a heightening of ethnic tensions and further disruption of vital services in the Soviet Transcaucasus.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE CULTURE WE DESERVE. By Jacques Barzun. Edited by Arthur Krystal. (Wesleyan University, $19.95.) Jacques Barzun, a distinguished cultural critic for more than 50 years, has collected in ''The Culture We Deserve'' a series of essays, all of which point toward the decadence and decline of our culture - in the university, in the arts, in language and in the political world at large.

title: Lisa McCowan Becomes a Bride
description: Grace Elizabeth McCowan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace D. McCowan of Richmond, and Thomas Coleman Foley, a son of Gifford P. Foley of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Catherine Coleman Foley, were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Chapel at the Kent (Conn.) School. The Rev. Richardson Schell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

description: A Problem With Asbestos

title:
GARDENING;
The Return of the Seedless Watermelon
description: LEAD: SEEDLESS watermelons have been popular this year among commercial growers in the South. While relatively few seem to have shown up in produce markets in our region, they will certainly be here next season, and undoubtedly they will also appear in seed catalogues for those gardeners who grow their own.

title: THE NATION: David N. Dinkins; An Even Temper In the Tempest of Mayoral Politics
description: IT took David N. Dinkins a long time to get to where he is today, replacing the once-indomitable Edward I. Koch at the top of New York City's Democratic ticket. Yet probably the most delicate step in Mr. Dinkins's slow, cautious career will be his next one: in seeking to become mayor, he must convince the voters that he can lead a changing city.

title: How a Book Became Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NARRATOR HAS ALZHEIMER'S
description: OUT OF MIND By J. Bernlef. Translated by Adrienne Dixon. 150 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $17.95.

title: Unesco Chief About to Face A Showdown
description: The man who hopes to coax America back into an international organization it left five years ago will soon face his moment of truth.

title: Creations From the Iberian Peninsula
description: THOSE on the cutting edge of culinary trends are calling Spanish food the latest fashionable cuisine. Hitching a ride on the current popularity wave of light Mediterranean dishes (largely from Italy), Spanish creations are coming into their own.

title: STREETSCAPES: 66 Third Avenue; A 'Costly Looking Barn' for the Charities Agency
description: AS long as anyone can remember, it has been an architectural conundrum, an oddly proportioned, one-story structure at the northwest corner of 11th Street and Third Avenue. ''I've always been curious about it,'' said Robert L. Bien, an architect who lives nearby. ''It's so ornate - but it was just a garage.''

title: Scant Help Is Seen in Bush Drug Plan
description: LEAD: AS President Bush plans his $7.9 billion drug-control strategy, there are an estimated 70,000 addicts in Connecticut ready to accept treatment but just 1,000 beds for them.

title: An Influx of Big Brokerages Stokes Price Volatility
description: Individual investors are not the only ones to stampede into coins. The healthy returns, the pervasiveness of standardized grading and the computerized trading exchange have also made coins attractive to big league investors.

title: 2 Shrimpers Die in Boat Crash
description: A Norwegian tanker and a shrimp boat collided in a heavy rainstorm Thursday in the Gulf of Mexico, killing two shrimpers. The 500-foot tanker Lavender collided with the 75-foot shrimp boat Cooter Glitter about 60 miles south of Sabine, said Don Merwin, duty officer at the Coast Guard station in Galveston. The shrimp boat, registered in Tampa, Fla., sank. One of the three shrimpers on the boat was rescued by the Lavender, the Coast Guard said, and the tanker later recovered the bodies of the two other crew members.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LOVER. By Harriet Zinnes. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) As its title implies, love is the primary subject of the first volume of short fiction by the poet and critic Harriet Zinnes. Seldom more than a few pages long, these 29 stories focus on the darker end of the emotional spectrum, delving into romantic obsession, jealousy, infidelity and assorted other violent passions.

title: In 'Black Rain,' East Meets West With a Bang! Bang!
description: After four grueling months that included location work in Japan and New York, the director Ridley Scott is completing ''Black Rain'' at Paramount Studios, on a hi-tech-with-Deco-accents hostess-bar set that is supposed to be in Osaka. Two scenes, filmed on successive days, seem to underscore the theme of the conflict-of-two-cultures thriller, which opens Friday at Loews Astor Plaza and 34th Street Showplace and casts Michael Douglas and Andy Garcia as New York cops pursuing a capo in the yakuza - or Japanese Mafia - in an uneasy collaboration with the Japanese police.

title: THE BUZZARDS ABOVE, THE CANE BELOW
description: BIG SUGAR Seasons in the Cane Fields of Florida. By Alec Wilkinson. 263 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. By Richard J. Margolis IN 1951, President Harry S. Truman's Commission on Migratory Labor examined farm worker conditions nationwide and concluded that what held the system together was human misfortune. ''We depend on misfortune to build up our force of migratory workers,'' declared the commission, ''and when the supply is low because there is not enough misfortune at home, we rely upon misfortune abroad to replenish the supply.''

title: Skipper's Sentencing in Spill Off Rhode Island Is Delayed
description: A Federal district judge has refused to sentence the captain and the owner of a tanker that spilled nearly 300,000 gallons of heating oil off Newport in spring until he knows more about their records and willingness to pay damages.

title: Margaret Garrett Weds
description: Margaret J. Garrett, a ballet dancer and actress, and Bruce Wolosoff, a concert pianist and composer, were married yesterday at the New York Academy of Art by Chief Judge Sol Wachtler of the New York State Court of Appeals. Ms. Garrett, 24 years old, will keep her name. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clarke W. Garrett of Carlisle, Pa. Her husband, 34, is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alvin B. Wolosoff of Kings Point, L.I.

title: Nassau or Suffolk? Taking Sides
description: EVER since our courting days, my husband and I have been feuding like the Hatfields and the McCoys over one particularly touchy topic: which county is superior, Nassau or Suffolk. I say Suffolk. He says Nassau.

title: A Doctor Who Aided Immigrant Workers
description: LEAD: AN exhibition on the life of Dr. Jacob Nemoitin, who practiced in Stamford for 56 years, helped its early immigrant population and became a local legend, will open on Tuesday at the Stamford Historical Society.

title: THE FACES BEHIND THE MASKS
description: IN THE SHADOW OF THE SACRED GROVE By Carol Spindel. 318 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: Hot Giants Tickets
description: When the Giants are playing at Giants Stadium, there is no such thing as a general admission ticket. The team has been so popular for so long that season tickets are handed down from generation to generation and the waiting list is measured in decades. ''We're sold out on a season basis,'' is the way Ed Croke, the team's spokesman put it the other day. ''All the seats belong to subscribers.''

title: Remember O'Malley?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At the Trial of Bakker, Sensation on the Wane
description: The sensationalism that marked the downfall of the television evangelist Jim Bakker has not been entirely absent from his fraud and conspiracy trial here.

title: Seidelman's Heroines Rebel in the Highest Style
description: First, the heroine of ''Cookie'' takes her best friend's last $10 and buys herself a pink plastic camera; then she jumps over a subway turnstile. But the misguided title character of Susan Seidelman's new film finds her true calling soon enough. She doesn't exactly straighten out; Cookie gets more crooked. Before long she is seen wrapped in a furry, cherry-red coat that's hot - in the criminal sense of the word - while reading a paperback copy of ''Mafia Princess.''

title: Convicted Officer Issues Warning on Corruption
description: A convicted ringleader of a gang of crooked New York City police officers has made a dramatic videotape aimed at warning officers of the the perils of police corruption.

title: NO MORE SCRAMBLING?
description: The Washington Redskins aren't buying it, but Randall Cunningham, quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles, says he's giving up scrambling.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Aug. 20 with an article about Kentucky mislabeled the state north of Louisville. It is Indiana.

title: Prague Tries To Cut Off All But Party Line
description: The dissident Jiri Dienstbier lost his telephone number, 220-110, on Aug. 10. The Czechoslovak authorities said they needed it ''for an important public purpose.''

title: Breathing New Life Into Old Houses
description: WILLIAM C. NORTON remembers the moment as if it were yesterday. It was 1965, and the 23-year-old Berlin resident, just out of the Army Reserve, was working as an automobile mechanic, and he was bored. As he drove home one evening, he switched on the Paul Harvey radio show.

title: 2d Suspect Named in Killing of Drug Fighter
description: A man described by the police as a middle-level heroin dealer has been identified as a second suspect in the slaying of Maria Hernandez, a Brooklyn woman who along with her husband fought to rid her block of drugs, the police said yesterday.

title: Eliot H. Harris Wed in Capital
description: Eliot Halsey Harris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Harris Jr. of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to William Christopher Edgar, a son of Katharine Edgar Cobey of Washington and Cushing, Me., and William H. Edgar of Paris. The Rev. Dr. Francis H. Wade officiated at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington, where the bride's parents were married in 1958.

title: JUGGING UP
description: REMEMBER JUG wines? Big, fat bottles, with screw-on caps? With a glass ring at the neck that you stuck your index finger in to get some leverage because they were so hard to pour? Wines with easy-to-remember names like California Burgundy and California Chablis? Whatever happened to them, anyway?

title: POSTINGS: 713-Acre Complex; Homes in the Adirondacks
description: Hoping to capture a market among New York City and Boston residents seeking second homes in the Adirondacks, as well as professionals working in Albany, Schenectedy and Troy, developers have completed the first phase of a complex of homes and recreational facilities in Queensbury, N.Y., just south of Lake George. The $330 million complex, Hiland Park, is to be developed over 10 years and resemble a small town.

title: OLD TROOPERS TO THE RESCUE
description: ARMY BLUE By Lucian K. Truscott 4th. 436 pp. New York: Crown Publishers.

title: Tentative Agreement on Rocky Flats Cleanup
description: Federal and state negotiators have reached a tentative agreement that would limit Federal officials' liability for their handling of hazardous waste at the Government's Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in Colorado, an official involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: New Jewish Group Formed for Interfaith Ties
description: Three major American Jewish organizations have formed a new group to represent them in international discussions with the Vatican and other Christian bodies. The action reflects divergent approaches by Jewish groups to interreligious dialogue and to issues like the dispute over a Roman Catholic convent at Auschwitz.

title:
Prospects;
A Brand New Deficit
description: LEAD: For the first time in decades, the balance of trade in the services and investment sector of the economy posted a deficit. In the second quarter, all of the components of the trade balance became negative because of that loss. The shift reflects growing foreign ownership of American assets and increased borrowing from overseas.

title: Westchester Puts Homeless In Troubled Midtown Hotel
description: Just as New York has begun moving its homeless out of sometimes-wretched Manhattan hotels, Westchester County has placed 34 homeless adults and children in the Bryant Hotel in midtown.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: WILLIAM G. JOHNSON;
Measuring the Voters' Temperament
description: LEAD: THIS is the season of the pollster. While ''mood-of-the- country'' polls are taken year round, September and October are when political polling is at its peak - when candidates want to know ''How am I doing?''

title:
MUSIC;
Celebration of Victorian Era in Song
description: LEAD: MANY American songs of the late 19th and early 20th centuries were about hopes and dreams, and about freedom.

title: Arbour Finds Bright Spot As Flyers Beat Islanders
description: The outcome was negative, but the signs were mostly positive as the Islanders opened their National Hockey League exhibition schedule today by losing, 3-2, to the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: Miss Jones Wed To Joseph Valis
description: Roselynd Kimberly Jones, a daughter of Mrs. R. Wood Jones of O'ermead Farm in West Chester, Pa., and Robert H. Jones, also of West Chester, was married yesterday at the Westtown (Pa.) Friends Meeting House to Joseph William Valis, a son of Mrs. Joseph Valis of Baltimore and the late Mr. Valis.

title: Growers Worry About Alar-Free Apples
description: LEAD: THE warm sunny days and cool nights marking the end of this summer are providing ideal ripening conditions for the approximately one million bushels of apples grown at the 136 commercial orchard in the state.

title: Reviews/Dance; Dance World's Bessies Honor Some Achievers
description: Dance Theater Workshop presented its sixth annual New York Dance and Performance Awards Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Familiarly known as the Bessies, the awards are named after Bessie Schonberg, chairman emeritus of the dance department of Sarah Lawrence College and a noted teacher of dance composition. They honor achievements in various aspects of dance and performance art.

title: GREENING THE WHITE HOUSE
description: If Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, had his way, President Bush would write off the environment on political grounds, foregoing clean-up programs because they are too costly to industry. And besides, ''nature lovers'' never have made good Republican constituents.

title: Deals on Wheels
description: ''I VISITED NICARAGUA IN 1980, at the suggestion of a friend who had seen a lot of people there in broken wheelchairs,'' Ralf Hotchkiss says, ''and I met some skilled mechanics who were new wheelchair riders. I was riding a homemade chair, and they said, 'We can do that. Maybe we can even make a better one. But we can use some technical assistance.' ''

title: Blacks Started Dinkin's Bid In a Symbolic River-Crossing
description: One day last November, four black Brooklyn politicians strode into the Manhattan office of Borough President David N. Dinkins. Over coffee, for the next 60 minutes, they urged the gray-haired official to run for mayor.

title: Geralyn Geany Becomes Bride
description: Geralyn Mary Geany, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Geany of Vero Beach, Fla., and Osterville, Mass., was married yesterday to Paul Michael Heffernan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Heffernan, of Worcester and Harwich, Mass. The Rev. Francis C. Mackin performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius of Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: FASHION: On the Street; In Jodhpurs, Standing Out From The Herd
description: Though horses are almost as rare in midtown Manhattan as free cabs, jodhpurs aren't. They can be seen on women striding down Madison or Fifth Avenues and looking jaunty, purposeful and comfortable.

title: POSTINGS: Atlantic City Convention; Art in Architecture
description: People who are thinking of building a home and are looking for examples of the latest work of architects and artists to help them find just the right design might meander down to Atlantic City on Thursday for the start of the 89th annual meeting of the New Jersey Society of Architects. More than 2,000 architects, designers and developers will offer more than 250 exhibits of their professional efforts at the Atlantic City Convention Center Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: When Neighbors Lend Their Hands
description: THOUSANDS who suffered from July's devastating tornadoes have begun the long process of rebuilding their homes, their businesses and their lives, with the help of millions in Federal funds.

title: The Wild Gray Yonder
description: Thanks to Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, a former two-pack-a-day man, millions of plane passengers may soon be breathing a lot easier. He led the fight in the Senate to ban smoking on domestic flights, and last week he won it.

title: Warning on Crises Facing Migrating Birds
description: EVERY autumn thousands of waterfowl flying from Canada to their winter grounds near the Gulf of Mexico stop to eat and rest in nutrient-rich wetlands in Kansas. But in recent years, some have dried up, and that concerns Alexander Gardner of New Canaan.

title: Freedom of Speech, I
description: Not long ago, a visiting Soviet politician who said things like Boris N. Yeltsin said last week would have to have been planning to stay here. During an eight-day visit, Mr. Yeltsin maintained a steady stream of the sort of criticism of Mikhail S. Gorbachev that got him booted out of the Politburo two years ago.

title: McCoy Tyner
description: McCoy Tyner, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight; there is a $15 cover tonight and tomorrow, $12 on Sunday, with a $6 minimum.

title: GIVING UP GUNS
description: I fully support Dennis Graham's decision not to own a gun (About Men: ''Giving Up Guns,'' Aug. 20). I also share his outrage regarding the schoolyard carnage in Stockton, Calif., and the continuing slaughter in our nation's capital.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Do College Football Polls Mean Anything?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Repairing a Dripping Faucet
description: AS a rule, fixing a dripping faucet is easy. This article describes repairing compression faucets (pictured), the most common kind.

title: Maryland Crabs
description: To the Editor: With regard to the ''sweet, succulent'' pieces of meat in the ''inner chambers'' of Maryland's crabs (Fare of the Country, July 16), I say, balderdash! - never have I encountered such a disgusting mess of maritime gore as at a crab feed aboard a Baltimore harbor cruise in June. The largest piece was the size of a pencil eraser, and it all had a faintly noxious aroma. A mere tourist from the provinces, you say? Perhaps, I'll take the chicken, thanks. STEVEN C. ANDERSON Boise, Idaho

title: Apple Growers Hurt by Loss of Alar
description: Standing beside his packing house, Ted Wright watched a forklift operator pick up a large box filled with McIntosh apples and load it into a trailer truck.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL 'Slavonic Opera Arias' Lucia Popp, soprano; Munich Radio Orchestra conducted by Stefan Soltesz. Angel CDC7 49319 2; CD only. This is a welcome exception to the usual run of opera star recitals. Here is important, rewarding repertory that, while it has by no means gone unappreciated, has not always attracted voices of Ms. Popp's caliber. Here is an artist especially equipped by linguistic background to do justice to Janacek, Smetana, Dvorak, Prokofiev and Tchaikovsky, but who has generally been heard in her Strauss-Mozart area of specialization. The results may not efface the memory of beloved recordings of the individual arias (Ms. Popp's voice, though still quite beautiful, is not in its first bloom, and she is a sensitive and idiomatic interpreter rather than a riveting one), but they do add up to a very attractive introduction, for the general opera lover, to this exciting material. And right from the beginning of Tatiana's Letter Scene there is one unmistakable quality that has been in woefully short supply on other recent aria albums: enthusiasm. - Will Crutchfield Vaughan Williams: Choral Works Christ Church (Oxford) Cathedral Choir, English String Orchestra conducted by Stephen Darlington. Nimbus 5166; CD only. The five works in this admirable program display varied facets of Vaughan Williams as a composer of religious music: extroversion in the motet ''O Clap Your Hands'' and the 1928 ''Te Deum,'' sing-along simplicity in ''The Old Hundredth Psalm Tune,'' arranged for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, and sensuous impressionism in ''Flos Campi'' for choir, viola and orchestra, based on selections from the Song of Songs. In all, playing and choral singing are splendid (Christ Church, Oxford, boasts one of the finest choirs in England), but ''An Oxford Elegy'' is marred somewhat by the dry speaking voice of the narrator, Jack May, whose aggressive declamation of Matthew Arnold's pastoral text is at odds with the ethereal lyricism of Vaughan Williams's musical setting. - Barrymore L. Scherer Cage: The String Quartets, Vol. 1 Arditti Quartet. Mode 17; CD only. The two works on this disk document part of a concert of John Cage's string quartet music the Arditti Quartet played at Wesleyan University last year. In both pieces the players sat far apart from each other, whether displaced on the stage for ''Music for Four'' (the work's premiere) or scattered in odd locations around the hall for 30 Pieces for String Quartet (1983), prompting one audience member to ask whether the players liked each other. Liking doesn't matter, though, with Mr. Cage's chance-derived music; only independence does. And the surprising result of music made from separated, unrelated contrapuntal voices is serenity. Mr. Cage's expertly made musical chaos happens to be just as good at producing beautiful patterns as the various forms of natural chaos are, especially when aided by an ensemble as good as this one. A second volume will include Mr. Cage's classic early quartet along with a new work the composer is writing for the ensemble. - Mark Swed Mozart: Serenade in B flat (K. 361) Orchestra of the 18th Century conducted by Frans Bruggen. Philips 422 338-2; CD and cassette. Mozart's sublime Serenade ''for 13 Winds'' (12, actually, and a string bass) has been a favorite of record companies in recent years and has already received fine treatment in period style. Still, no fancier of the sweet-and-sour sonorities of ''original'' instruments will want to miss this version. The Dutch band meets the lofty standard it has quickly established for itself, with chords superbly weighted and balanced, and Mr. Bruggen, a former wind virtuoso who is proving a formidable conductor, brings a particular virtue to this work: a sure instinct for pacing that allows the music to breathe and phrases to soar. No music ever written ''breathes'' more truly than does Mozart's third-movement Adagio, exquisitely languid and soulful in this performance. - James R. Oestreich Handel: Solo Cantatas Julianne Baird, soprano; John Ostendorf, bass-baritone; Aurora (period-instrument ensemble). Newport Classics NCD 60043; CD and cassette. We know by now what to expect of Julianne Baird: Limpid, fresh tone; unassertive but sparkling clarity of diction and spirited delivery; imaginative and virtuosic ornamentation, and brisk, neat rhythm. John Ostendorf, whose enterprise in record producing as well as his musicianly singing has made him a familiar presence on the Baroque music scene, has less charm of timbre, but he phrases with authority and moves his voice around the florid music with nimble athleticism. They do well, sometimes delightfully well, by the four tuneful cantatas (two for each singer) recorded here. The instrumental playing (which includes a traversal of a trio sonata, Op. 2, No. 8, spread out like a series of entr'actes among the cantatas) is good without being up to the highest current standards, but the singing is generally preferable to that of the British early-musickers who have recorded some of the same material. - W. C. Schubert: Octet The Nash Ensemble of London. Virgin Classics VC7 90731; CD and cassette. Beautiful ensemble playing, a classical sense of proportion and a striking affinity for just the right rhetorical gesture add up to a thoroughly engaging performance of this endearing masterpiece. As in this ensemble's splendid recording of Dvorak's ''Dumky'' Trio and Op. 81 Piano Quintet on the same label, the careful engineering yields both clarity and the desirable ambience of chamber music played at home. - B. L. S. POP/JAZZ Van Morrison: 'Avalon Sunset' Mercury 839262-1; all three formats. Either out of stinginess or because the way is so hard, this Irish singer has for years delivered only the outlines of a great Van Morrison album, making promises other singers could not keep and he himself seems unlikely to. On ''Avalon Sunset,'' he turns to inspiration from above, which means that he stays on his path, but also that his path is without interesting surprises. The songs are simple and in the end only perfunctory, but Mr. Morrison sings with passion and vigor, his voice twisting and swelling until it engulfs his subject matter. Against uninspired accompaniment, this is the foreground of a great Van Morrison album - a little closer than he's come in a while, but still tantalizingly not there. - John Leland D'Atra Hicks: 'D'Atra Hicks' Capitol 46990; all three formats. Half forgettable soporific ballads and half turbo-charged up-tempo material, this debut album marks the arrival of a 21-year-old singer of real promise, someone who can really scream. Her producers have allowed Ms. Hicks the room to sing, and each melody, however trite, gets the full treatment, with her dense voice swirling and Ping-Ponging all over the place. The tunes - and the lukewarm production - aren't always inspiring, but Ms. Hicks growls and shouts through the songs, giving the pleasure of a gospel-trained singer really emoting. - Peter Watrous Nanci Griffith: 'Storms' MCA 6319; all three formats. ''Folkabilly'' is the nickname that the twangy-voiced Texan singer and songwriter has given to a style that, in defying country and pop radio formats, has prevented her from becoming a star. ''Storms,'' her eighth album, moves toward a pop mode without adopting overly trendy musical trappings. As always with Ms. Griffith, the songwriting is the center of the album. By far the most powerful song, ''It's a Hard Life Wherever You Go'' is an aggrieved reflection on the rise of prejudice, with scenes set in Belfast and in a Chicago cafeteria inspiring a reverie of the 1960's and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King. ''If we poison our children with hatred,'' the singer warns, ''then the hard life is all they'll ever know.'' - Stephen Holden Sugarcubes: 'Here Today, Tomorrow, Next Week' Elektra 60860-4; all three formats. On the Icelandic group's second American album, innocent banalities - a missed bath, a synthetic fiber - trigger sudden outbursts of violence and collegiate irony. An unresolved mix of carnival frippery, psychedelia and incongruous horn outbursts, this album is a wrestling match: between Bjork Gudmundsdottir's dreaming, screaming waif and Einar Orn's truculent wise guy, between the folky underlying melodies and the noise billowing over them, between acerbity and camp. If ''Here Today'' is a bit disappointing after last year's eye-opening ''Life's Too Good,'' it's because Ms. Gudmundsdottir does not win the wrestle often enough, and camp prevails too often. - J. L. Frank Morgan: 'Reflections' Contemporary CD 14052-2; all three formats. While it's often said that Mr. Morgan is a briliant be-bop alto saxophonist, deep into the language of Charlie Parker, it's just as often overlooked that his style is changing a bit, growing more elliptical, even florid. This becomes especially evident when his work is contrasted to that of the other saxophonist on the date, Joe Henderson, who plays with a coarse bluntness; together they present a well-rounded whole. And as usual, Mr. Morgan elevates a kind tenderness and passion to an art. - P. W.

title: A Year of Years for the High Priest of Modernism
description: In April, it was the glass pyramid of the Louvre, a structure that has become the virtual symbol of the remaking of Paris. Then just a little more than a week ago in Dallas came the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center, the most expensive and elaborate concert hall in a generation, and later this year it will be the new 70-story skyscraper headquarters of the Bank of China, already a landmark on the skyline of Hong Kong - three buildings that have little in common except the fact that each has won headlines around the world, and each is a design of I.M. Pei.
