title: A Child's Game of Hide and Seek Induces Panic
description: IT happened suddenly. One minute my 2-year-old daughter was standing next to me at the children's counter in a large department store and the next minute she was gone. I had momentarily turned my head to tell my older daughter Jamie not to pull tags off the clothes and Jenny had vanished. I called her name. There was no answer. ''She's disappeared,'' my 4-year-old announced with the calm of a metropolitan newscaster. My head seemed to swivel perilously on my neck as I searched the large room quickly. I could see frilly dresses and racks of colorful cotton sweaters and miniature Izod shirts.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner; Gardens and Terraces Invite Diners Outdoors
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Arcobaleno

title: CARPETS AND COOKIES
description: It was awfully nice of Jack Rosenthal to take me back to my childhood in Boston by mentioning an old Boston radio jingle. (On Language: ''Diluting the Awe by Some,'' Aug. 20). However, the jingle was not an advertisement for an all-night drugstore, but, rather, for a carpet-cleaning company called Adams & Swett, which is still located in Boston. The lyrics were: ''How many cookies did Andrew eat? ANdrew 8-8000. How do you keep you carpets neat? Call ANdrew 8-8000.'' MICHAEL G. KALOYANIDES Bethany, Conn.

title: Legislatures Face a Barrage Of Measures Banning Guns
description: The killing of seven people in Louisville, Ky., by a deranged man firing an AK-47 semiautomatic rifle has spurred new momentum among state legislators around the country to ban such weapons, gun-control experts and advocates say.

title: No One Yet Has Immunity From Racial Conflict; Leadership Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Of all the national parks, it is the one closest to extinction. We ditched, diked and drained

title: It Still Ain't Over: A League For the Over-30 Ball Player
description: LEAD: WHEN Jim Tavegia was growing up on the outskirts of Chicago, his dream was to play third base for his favorite team, the Cubs, just like his idol, Ron Santo. Mr. Tavegia reached the collegiate level as a third baseman and catcher at Ottawa University in Ottawa, Kan. Now, he simply wants ''to still be playing baseball when I'm 50-something.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a judge's order to move welfare families out of the Allerton Hotel in Manhattan misstated the name of the judge in one reference. She was Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Jane A. Margolis Becomes a Bride
description: Jane Ann Margolis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Margolis of New York, was married there last evening to Aaron Leslie Saperstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Saperstein of Danbury, Conn. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Plaza, assisted by Rabbi Jerome R. Malino.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Maryland; Students Charge Rights Violation In Suit on Voting
description: Four University of Maryland students have gone to court on behalf of more than 300 students who, they maintain, were stripped of their right to vote in the city in the November election.

title: Where Is the Invective Of Yesteryear in Opera?
description: It is really too early to be concerned. After all, the season is not yet in gear. Still, connoisseurs of operatic controversy must have been a little disappointed at the lack of acrimony and passion that marked the recent disagreement between Luciano Pavarotti and Lyric Opera of Chicago. Has it come to this: constrained civility between famous singers and impresarios?

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Togetherness is having a pretty hard time these days. The ''me syndrome'' has reached the point where it is transcending generations. And the demand for space in relationships is increasingly vocalized. So what hope is there for the couple who not only live together but work together, in the same room or the same house? Almost none, one would think, which just goes to show how ornery life can be. But an unofficial, unscientific survey shows that couples who spend anywhere from more-time-than-average to all their time together are getting along just fine, thank you.

title: POCKETS FULL OF WONDER
description: LEAD: GROWING UP HAPPY Captain Kangaroo Tells Yesterday's Children How to Nurture Their Own. By Bob Keeshan. Illustrated. 230 pp. New York: Doubleday.

title: Come Up With an Agenda, Cuomo Tells Party
description: Add Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to the list of prominent Democrats searching for a message to carry the party through three more years of Republican Presidential rule.

title: Merchant Marine Wins
description: The Merchant Marine Academy turned four turnovers into four field goals by Rich Egal to gain a 12-10 Liberty Conference victory over C. W. Post in a steady rain yesterday at Kings Point, L.I.

title: Freedom of Love
description: Storybook romance? Well, they did meet at a bookstore and the Prince proposed a year later while walking her home from the university where she was studying. Last week, the ''love marriage'' - as opposed to an arranged marriage - between Prince Aya, the 23-year-old second son of the Emperor and Empress of Japan, and Kiko Kawashima, a commoner, also 23, was formally approved by the Imperial Household Council, a 10-member body headed by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. In a year dominated by political scandals, the prospect of a royal wedding has delighted Japan. The Prince is second in line of succession behind his older brother, Naruhito, who is 29 and not yet engaged. When she first met Prince Aya, Miss Kawashima said, ''I thought he was much more unpretentious than I expected.''

title: NONFICTION
description: THE CHASE. By Alejo Carpentier. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) We are, Alejo Carpentier once wrote, ''lost in a labyrinth of false notions.'' And picking through that labyrinth in search of occasional flecks of truth is what drives this brief novel. The Cuban writer, composer and diplomat, known for the architectural complexity of his plots, here adopts the equally dense structure of Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony to trace the intertwined days and nights of two young men who have come to Batista-era Havana to carve their destinies. One, a student and ticket seller at a concert hall where the symphony is being played, wants ''to understand great things.'' The other has stumbled into revolution and sees ''the best members of his generation . . . falling to the bullets of the repressive police.'' Betraying his comrades, betrayed by a prostitute, the rebel is on the run. As the chase winds through a closed-in byzantine landscape, he becomes increasingly incapable of escaping his past, even of confessing his sins, and when the music in the hall reaches its climax all the pieces in the lush, profound construction close in on him. Though not widely known here, Carpentier (who died in 1980) was one of the early giants of modern Latin American literature, a man whose writing helped shape and define the period of ''magic realism,'' a term that he coined. Without ''The Chase,'' which was first published in 1956, the work of Carpentier's more widely known successors would be vastly different. It is good that Alfred Mac Adam's fine translation has made this short masterpiece available in English at last.

title: GETTING TO THE HEART OF DIXIE
description: ENCYCLOPEDIA OF SOUTHERN CULTURE Edited by Charles Reagan Wilson and William Ferris. Associate editors, Ann J. Abadie and Mary L. Hart. Illustrated. 1,634 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press.

title: Lucy F. Davis Marries Jeffrey Haynes
description: Lucy Furman Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle Ragland Davis Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., and New York, and Jeffrey Norman Haynes, a son of Senator and Mrs. Joe Mann Haynes of Nashville, were married yesterday at Kirk in the Hills, a Presbyterian church in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Dr. James Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Photographs Aspire to Be More
description: ANIMAL and baby pictures may ''sell'' a newspaper, but they are seldom the stuff of its art columns. Even Andy Warhol, whose genius was for transforming the banal into art, ignored (or overlooked) them.

title:
DANCE;
Companies Find a Scarcity of Men
description: LEAD: WHEN the New Jersey Ballet Company opens the fall season on Saturday with a performance at Kean College, it will sport a couple of new male dancers on its already richly adorned roster. Their presence reflects one of the paradoxes afoot in the New Jersey dancescape, which, increasingly, looks to foreign-trained male dancers to meet the demand for high-caliber performers.

title: Colorado Big Plays Bury Illinois, 38-7
description: The tailback Eric Bieniemy ran for two touchdowns and threw a 48-yard pass on the halfback option for another today as Colorado powered past Illinois, 38-7.

title: For the Western Serial, Time to Saddle Up Again
description: The script for the opening scene in one of the initial episodes of ABC's new series ''The Young Riders'' calls for the Pony Express rider, a youthful Bullalo Bill Cody - played by Stephen Baldwin - to gallop up to the relay station in a cloud of dust. Somebody forgets to tell Mother Nature. The capricious old girl strips the bottom off a monster thunderhead that has been building all morning above ''Morganville,'' part of the western location set in the high Sonoran desert and mountain country 30 miles southeast of Tucson, and the grand champion of all gullywashers turns the last leg of Cody's ride with the ''mochilla,'' or mailbag, he must hand off to the next Express rider into a raging sluiceway.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: If all of space is too broad a subject for a hobbyist starting a topical collection, one natural sub-topic is manned space exploration.

title: Hand-Knitted at Home, in High Style
description: The popularity of hand-knitted oversize sweaters and classic tailored knit suits in this season's designer ready-to-wear collections has spurred an upswing in home knitting.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $178,000 15 Overlea Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; c/a, 1-car garage, w/w carpeting; taxes $3,283. Avon-by-the-Sea $240,000 504 Garfield Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old colonial; sun porch, fireplace, central vacuum; taxes $2,080. Jackson $140,000 11 Drexel Drive 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 20-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, c/a, front porch; taxes $2,600. Livingston $177,500 18 Congressional Parkway 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 44-year-old colonial; fenced yard, full basement, double driveway; taxes $2,551. Vernon $149,900 14 Butternut Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; 2-zone heat, landscaped yard, full basement; taxes $4,290. Wall $124,000 1502 Sunset Terrace 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old ranch; deck, eat-in-kitchen, 1-car garage, h/w floors; taxes $1,535. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. $825,000 308 Pondfield Road 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 76-year-old Dutch colonial; study, fireplace, sun room, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $10,980. Newington, Conn. $202,000 16 Cricket Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; new fitted carpeting, on cul-de-sac, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,128. Westbury, L.I. $165,000 35 Faith Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500.

title: Palaces of the Yi Kings
description: THE ghosts of the Yi dynasty, whose kings ruled Korea from 1392 to 1910, still haunt the palaces of Seoul,those oases of serenity amid the incessant motion and noise of this vibrant city. But the tranquil halls and exquisite gardens, a refuge from the Hyundai cars and the purple and white buses that rumble like elephants through the streets, mask a past rife with court intrigue, betrayal and war.

title: Survivors of Shooting and Gunman's Relatives Ponder Sad Riddles
description: The first funerals were held today for victims of the gunman who shot up a printing plant here, while his family and co-workers searched their memories for any clues that might somehow explain the rampage.

title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys
description: The first follow-up studies of babies born to mothers using crack show that in early childhood they have serious difficulty relating to their world, making friends, playing like normal children and feeling love for their mothers or primary caretakers.

title: Parties Evolve For Many Species
description: Snips and snails and puppy dog's tails, preening swans and diving sea lions showed up at parties last week. On Tuesday, the exhibition ''Strange Attractors: Signs of Chaos,'' opened at the New Museum in SoHo. While the guests dined, a vitrine of snails munched on two cabbages as part of one exhibit, ''Palimpsest.''

title: DINING OUT Song and Southwest Flavor in Pawlin
description: LEAD: IN its move from a 200-year-old building in Beekmanville last year, the Towne Crier Cafe lost some of the funky charm that we do not lament. While it may lack the dusty ghosts of the former quarters, the new site in Pawling has the capacity and the means to satisfy discriminating diners as well as fans of entertainers such as Janis Ian, Queen Ida, Herbie Mann, Maria Muldaur, the Rude Girls, Leon Redbone, Oscar Brand and the Persuasions.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Hudson Square; Offices in a Former Industrial Area
description: WHEN owners of the industrial buildings on the lower west side of Manhattan just north of the Holland Tunnel started carving office space out of former printing plants and warehouses a few years ago, the idea was to exploit the area's proximity to the financial district and offer an alternative to high rents there.

title: R. P. Kelling Jr. and Miss White Wed in Illinois
description: Paisley Addams White, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. White of Kenilworth, Ill., was married yesterday to Robert Paul Kelling Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelling of Haddonfield, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert W. Bowen, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the interdenominational Kenilworth Union Church.

title: Astoria
description: To the Editor:

title: Downtown Renewal In Port Chester: A New Optimism
description: LEAD: This attractive but somewhat dilapidated village has cried ''redevelopment'' for its downtown so often in the last 15 years, with no major change occurring, that many people have stopped listening.

title: SOVIET MINERS SEEK CONTROL OF UNION
description: Two months after they led the largest industrial walkout this country has seen since the 1920's, independent coal miners this week took the first steps in a campaign to seize control of the official coal workers union.

title: Japan on $100 a Day - or Less
description: WHEN you tell people you are going to Japan, they are likely to say they know someone who paid $6 for a cup of coffee there and wonder how you can subject yourself to such an economy. The language and culture are so forbidding, so strange - and those prices are somehow openly hostile. But if you go, you will discover that traveling on a budget in Japan is not only possible but also easy and surprisingly comfortable.

title: BARD-WATCHING
description: REINVENTING SHAKESPEARE A Cultural History, From the Restoration to the Present. By Gary Taylor. Illustrated. 461 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $29.95.

title: Language Schools Are Talking Business
description: AN executive at a Manhattan telecommunications company lives in Peekskill and travels back and forth to Japan on business three times a year. A young psychiatrist in Scarsdale is treating a number of Japanese patients. An accounting firm in Hartsdale has a growing list of clients in West Germany.

title: A Supermarket Of Jade: Both Cheap and Choice
description: UNDERNEATH the Gascoigne Road overpass in Kowloon, in the triangle formed by Kansu, Reclamation and Battery Streets, an unprepossessing piece of ground enclosed by a chain link fence acquires a luminescence each morning as tables are set up for the Hong Kong Jade Market. On one table is set water drops of emerald green translucence. Another displays a slippery, hard, white jade, looking and feeling like fresh fat, carved in the shape of a pea pod. On others: a simple ring, solid and heavy, of olive gray stone splotched with dark brown; crudely shaped and incised celadon beads; intricately cut peaches (a symbol of fecundity and female sexuality) of glistening caramel, tinged with green; a pristine bracelet of palest lavender.

title: Fall Lectures: Archeology to Velazquez
description: LEAD: ART and architecture, politics and philosophy, science and sociology - it is all there to explore in lectures offered countywide this fall. The selection of lectures here, while not all-inclusive, suggest the range of topics to be explored in the coming months. Unless a fee is specified, the lectures are free and open to the public.

title: Happy Hour Begins On the L.I.R.R. 5:47
description: SWAPPING their briefcases for fishing poles, about 35 commuters on the Long Island Rail Road's 5:47 P.M. train to Huntington embarked on an all-day fishing trip from Captree State Park earlier this summer.

title: Dr. Julie Fudge Weds
description: Dr. Julie L. Fudge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Smith Fudge of Horseheads, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard L. Barbano, a son of Anita C. Barbano of Brooklyn and the late Frank A. Barbano 2d. The Rev. Stephen Parr, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Lawrence Chapel in Odessa, N.Y. The bride, who will retain her name, is a first-year resident in psychiatry at the Payne Whitney Clinic of New York Hospital. The bridegroom is an intern in medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Kathleen E. Dougherty Has Wedding
description: Kathleen Elizabeth Dougherty, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James F. Dougherty of Sea Girt, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. James Aloysius Boozan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Boozan of Elizabeth, N.J., and Sea Girt. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Edward J. Dougherty, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: JOHN HIDDLESTONE;
'Opera Wasn't Written for Highbrows'
description: LEAD: THE new season of the Connecticut Grand Opera-Stamford State Opera began last night when the curtain rose on ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Palace Theater in Stamford. The production, which will also be offered on Sept. 23 at the Klein Memorial Auditorium in Bridgeport, is the first of four productions to be performed at the two theaters during 1989-90, the fourth season since the two companies joined forces in 1986.

title: Martha Monserrate, Consultant, Weds
description: Martha Lee Monserrate, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Patrick Monserrate of Binghamton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Herbert Hardinge McDade 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McDade Jr. of Scarborough, N.Y., and Denver. The Rev. William Bradley officiated at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Emergency Room Gridlock: On the Verge of Crisis
description: People seeking treatment in emergency rooms in many parts of the country are finding a medical gridlock that keeps patients waiting for hours, even days, for hospital beds, emergency room physicians say.

title: On the Plan to Revise Special Education
description: As a former member of the New Jersey Special Education Study Commission, which drafted the Plan to Revise Special Education in New Jersey, I would like to call attention to erroneous allegations in the article ''Plan to Revamp Special Education Draws Criticism'' (Aug. 6).

title: No One Yet Has Immunity From Racial Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: FLY BUYS
description: TWO YEARS ago, Clint Rodenberg made a discovery at Linate Airport in Milan that he still recalls with pleasure. There, in a men's shop, was a wide array of Hermes neckties selling for the equivalent of $48 apiece. That may not sound like a bargain, but to an aficionado of the silk ties, which then went for about $75 each at Hermes's New York boutique, it was a steal.

title: CONSUMER RATES
CAMPUS LIFE: Syracuse; Campus Rapes Lead to Formation Of a Task Force
description: Two rapes of undergraduate women at Syracuse University in the first week of school, as many as had been reported in the previous two years, have led to protests on campus and the formation of a task force to work on the problem. Students have held a demonstration, accused the administration of insensitivity to the victims and called for more and better protection.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Baylor; Suit Attacks a Ban On Single Students Who Are Pregnant
description: An unwritten policy barring pregnant unmarried students from classes is being challenged for the first time in the 144-year history of Baylor University.

title: Now It's Bob Horton's Turn at B.P.
description: Listen to Bob Horton talk and you might easily mistake him for a Wall Street trader or a corporate bust-up artist. His eyes light up as he confesses his love for ''active asset trading'' and ''swaps.'' There is joy in his voice as he discusses ''doing an arbitrage'' and ''making money by betting on the difference between your view and somebody else's.''

title:
GARDENING;
The Return of the Seedless Watermelon
description: LEAD: SEEDLESS watermelons have been popular this year among commercial growers in the South. While relatively few seem to have shown up in produce markets in our region, they will certainly be here next season, and undoubtedly they will also appear in seed catalogues for those gardeners who grow their own.

title: Colombian 'Day of Love' Broken By a Long Night of Drug Violence
description: Colombia marked its annual ''Day of Love and Friendship'' today after one of the most violent nights in the new drug war.

title: A College Takes Steps To Combat Racism on Campus
description: AS a teen-ager growing up in Hartford, Terrell E. Davis had the grades to get into Trinity College but almost did not apply. ''Trinity has had a reputation of being a white, elitist, racist institution,'' said Mr. Davis, who is now a student there and the vice president of the Pan-African Alliance, an organization representing black students at the Hartford college. ''And in college you've got enough to worry about without having to worry about that.''

title: Easy Goer Proves He's No. 1
description: If Easy Goer were only an ordinary horse, or even just a very good one, he would have probably lost the $809,000 Woodward Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. But the truly special ones find a way to win, and Easy Goer finally found one at the top of the stretch.

title: Marshals Shield Suspects and Judges Against Terror Attack in Drug Cases
description: In a vast walnut-paneled room barely two blocks from the Capitol, 24-year-old Rayful Edmond 3d is receiving the sort of Federal protection usually reserved for potentates: bulletproof shields, television surveillance, metal detectors, even hidden sharpshooters.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Utah;
description: The University of Utah has looked a gift horse in the mouth, and a large part of the university community believes it's the richer for it.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HEALTHY PLEASURES. By Robert Ornstein and David Sobel. (Addison-Wesley, $16.95.) I wish I could believe every word of Robert Ornstein and David Sobel's uplifting book, ''Healthy Pleasures.'' I do believe enough of them that I'm going to order a juicy steak for dinner tonight, buy a ticket to Michael Feinstein's next concert and maybe even invest in a home aquarium.

title: Miss Nougue-Sans, Corporate Lawyer, And Frederick J. Iseman Are Married
description: Marguerite Nougue-Sans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Nougue-Sans of Paris and Assat, France, was married last evening to Frederick J. Iseman, a son of Marjorie F. Iseman of New York and Joseph S. Iseman of Paris and Rye, N.Y. Judge John C. Carey of Westchester County Criminal Court performed the ceremony at the Knickerbocker Club in New York.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE sky was blue, the sun was shining, the air was crisp and cool. It was a day so perfect that even cliches couldn't mar its perfection; a morning made for early risings, and hot biscuits, and picnics and turning off onto roads you've never ridden before, just to ''see where they go.''

title: LONDON
description: Correspondents on assignment around the world discuss the influence of local fashion on their own attire.

title: American Indian Dancers Rekindle Their Heritage
description: Most Americans have grown up with the image of American Indian culture as a thing of war whoops and tom-tom beats. And that image has been perpetuated among young children, according to Arlie Neskahi, a Navaho drummer and singer, and Wade Baker, a Hidatsa-Cree dancer and singer. Both are members of the American Indian Dance Theater, which makes its New York City debut with a two-week engagement that begins on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater.

title: Pipe Organs
description: To the Editor: As a collector of organ recordings of instruments I have heard in Europe and America, Craig Whitney's article on ''Perusing Pipe Organs'' (Travel Section, Aug. 13) was particularly appealing to me. The more so since I have always read his foreign dispatches with great admiration.

title: For Mets and Expos, Big Question About the Big Deals
description: Look at it this way: by not winning the National League East championship and thus losing a chance to reach the World Series, the Mets will save $550,000.

title: Disturbing To Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pollution Poses Growing Threat To Everglades
description: The Everglades, 10,000 square miles of delicate marshland that is home to some of the country's rarest birds and other animals, are caught in a worsening environmental crisis, with thousands of acres already unable to sustain wildlife.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: When the bridge players of Australia undertook hosting of the 1989 world team championships now approaching their midpoint in Perth, they knew that the effort would be expensive. The financial burden became even greater when a major sponsor withdrew following the 1987 stock market crash and every tournament player in the country paid a contribution.

title: Voter Friendly
description: The countless voters who carried a red-white-and-blue booklet to the polls in last week's primary election in New York City attest to the popularity of the city's first official Voter Guide.

title: An Abstract Pioneer Gains Recognition
description: LEAD: AFTER more than six decades at his easel, John Opper, a pioneering American abstract artist, finally is receiving the recognition some critics have long said he has deserved.

title: Rightists Under Suspicion In New Guatemala Violence
description: The authorities arrested two men and began a search for a third, a right-wing former presidential candidate, in an investigation of a wave of violence in which at least 34 people have been killed and 7 students have disappeared.

title: All the Trimmings for a Stylish Fall
description: Handbags are getting pouchier. Belts are taking on all manner of ornamentation. Necklaces and earrings are longer. Scarves are bigger. Tassels and fringes are sprouting everywhere, and animal patterns are going wild. Welcome to the world of accessories for fall 1989.

title: Arab League Begins New Beirut Peace Effort
description: The Arab League began a new effort today to end the fighting in Lebanon with a peace plan welcomed by Syria but offering no public concession to the main demand of the country's Christian commander.

title: Noriega Critic Arrested
description: More than a dozen armed plainclothes officers broke into a law office on Friday and arrested Jaime Padilla Beliz, the owner of an opposition newspaper shut down two years ago, one of his associates said. The incident occured at the office of the firm Padilla y Asociados, where Mr. Padilla is a senior partner, said Venus Cardenas, a lawyer in the firm. Mr. Padilla's newspaper, El Siglo, was critical of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader, and was closed in July 1987.

title: With Asbestos, the Law Never Anticipated the Worst
description: NEW YORK CITY officials have long prided themselves on the city's asbestos regulations, acknowledged to be among the most stringent in the nation.

title: OUTER LIMITS
description: HIGH IN THE HIMALAYAS lives a shaggy little goat of international distinction: Its name is Kashmir, and without it, the world would be a coarser place.

title: Falsely Shouting Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; Amaryllis: Follow the Rules
description: Everything about amaryllis is superlative. The trumpet-shaped flowers are spectacular, anywhere from six to 10 inches across. Their petals can be seen in many colors ranging from red, pink and white to bicolors, especially red and white or pink and white. The bulbs are huge - as big as a man's fist.

title: The Law in Vermont
description: To the Editor:

title: Needless Cruelty to Animals
description: LEAD: Ask an experimenter about the animals in his laboratory. Nine times out of 10 he will tell you that they are well cared for and that he abides by the Animal Welfare Act passed by Congress in 1966.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Eaters With Consciences

title: LIFE IN REVERSE
description: AND AGAIN? By Sean O'Faolain. 287 pp. Birch Lane Press/ Carol Publishing Group, 120 Enterprise Avenue, Secaucus, N.J. 07094.

title: Robert Kessler: Music Producer
description: Flash back 25 years. Ten-year-old Robert Kessler, of Chevy Chase, Md., is listening to radio dramas. His favorite: ''Heartbeat Theater.''

title: Text by Goethe, Subtext by Freud
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Tufts; Students Protest Policy to Limit Speech Practices
description: Protesting a new university policy that they say limits freedom of speech in some campus areas, a group of Tufts students got up in the middle of the night last week to draw chalk lines dividing the campus into free speech zones and posted signs mocking the new rule.

title: K.G.B. DEFECTOR GUNDAREV IT'S COLD COMING OUT
description: AT DUSK ON AN evening in January 1986, two men from different worlds strolled together down the street of an Athens suburb. The taller of the two, a solidly built man with receding red hair and broad features, spoke good but heavily accented English. His name was Victor Gundarev. He was a full colonel in the K.G.B. His message was direct and electrifying: He wanted to defect to the West.

title: North Castle Library Names New Wing for Set Designer
description: LEAD: CHARLES ELSON of Armonk has designed sets and lighting for Broadway plays and major operas for most of his 80 years, but recently he moved into a new area: a library. Last week, the new wing of the North Castle Public Library was dedicated and named after Mr. Elson, in honor of his activities as a fund raiser and member of the board of trustees and his esthetic contributions.

title: FICTION
description: GREEN BANANAS. By Michael Drinkard. (Knopf, $17.95.) The question is: How will Sylvan, the hero of Michael Drinkard's spirited but callow first novel, get 29-year-old Phyllis pregnant? His way or hers? Sylvan, a college senior employed at Phyllis's day-care center, views her in a brazenly hormonal fashion. She lives with the widowed mother of one of her charges and appears to disdain men. But the clamor of her biological clock prompts a yearning for Sylvan, the ideal candidate to be the ''sperm daddy'' for the child she is determined to have by ''alternative'' insemination. This consistently benevolent, one-joke account of a Me generation that's evolved into a Me-and-Only-Me generation provides several comic obstacles to keep the course of true lust from running smooth. But while his wit is striking, Mr. Drinkard's green talent must ripen before he'll be able to produce a successful novel. At its most sage moments, ''Green Bananas'' uses sperm donation as a metaphor to reflect the sexual estrangement of our era, propagation stripped of any possible intimacy. Still, Mr. Drinkard's overall tone fails to sustain depth or develop characters beyond their surface. Bending truth for the sake of a laugh, using exposition to convey what would better unfold in dialogue and overdescribing the obvious, ''Green Bananas'' is the promising but unseasoned product of a talent that's clearly worth watching.

title: Putting an Oar In
description: In an effort to promote rowing in the United States, Oxford and Cambridge universities in England, which usually oppose each other on the Thames in London in March, brought their 160-year-old rivalry to the Chicago River yesterday for their first race in this country. Oxford won by less than half a length. ''We had a great race,'' said George Cheveley of Oxford. ''Only London counts, but all of them matter. We don't ever want to lose to Cambridge.''(AP)

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: The Met manager should:

title: Robina Ramsay Becomes a Bride
description: Robina Kate Evelyn Ramsay, the daughter of Donna Cook Hazen of Brooklyn and Robin Ramsay of Sydney, Australia, was married yesterday to Nathaniel Joseph Litwak, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Eugene Litwak of Scarsdale, N.Y., at the Esterwood Mansion at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Judge Louise Gruner-Gans of New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: Miss Yellin Weds Lucius T. Hill 3d
description: Wendy Lorraine Yellin, who is to join the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy next month as an associate, and Lucius Tuttle Hill 3d, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Bernard Bloomstone officiated at the Tumble Brook Country Club in Bloomfield, Conn.

title: Would-Be Geniuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; What Must Mets Do In Stretch Drive?
description: Get out their golf clubs. MICHAEL SMOLENS Great Neck, L.I.

title: Getting Close To Nature in Japan's Alps
description: THE usual tourist route in Japan is to go from crowd to crowd at museums, shrines, commercial centers and restaurants. Surely one essence of Japan lies in the nature of its humanity packed into tiny spaces, so much so that one can forget that about three-quarters of the country is hilly or mountainous terrain, much of it heavily forested, relatively unpopulated - and spectacularly beautiful.

title: U.S.-Soviet Issues Are Overshadowed
description: THERE is something accidentally symbolic about the fact that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will hold their ministerial meeting this week in a mountaintop lodge in Jackson Hole, Wyo. While this is not the first important diplomatic meeting to be held in an out-of-the-way place, this time the relative obscurity somehow befits the state of United States-Soviet relations.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Gregg Nomination: Vote to confirm Donald P. Gregg to be Ambassador to South Korea. Approved 66 to 33, Sept. 12. 2. FSX Fighter: Vote to override President Bush's veto of Congressional restrictions on the co-production of a jet fighter with Japan. Rejected, with 66 votes in favor and 34 opposed (67 votes in favor were needed to override), Sept. 13. 3. Smoking on Airlines: Vote to cut off debate on an amendment that would ban smoking on all domestic airline flights. Approved 77 to 21, Sept. 14. title: Miss Greene Wed To Robert R. Isen
description: At the Union League Club in New York, Patricia Greene and Robert Rand Isen were married last evening by Rabbi Richard Chapin. The bride is the daughter of Betsy S. Green of New York and Roy Greene of Atlanta. Her husband is the son of Reva Robinson of Valley Forge, Pa., and Harold Isen of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Rep. Frank Says He May Consider Retiring
description: Representative Barney Frank says he would consider retiring at the end of his term if the investigation of his relations with a male prostitute damages the causes he considers important.

title: Susan S. Foster Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Sheree Foster, a daughter of Gertrude Schotter of Green Pond, N.J., and the late Ralph Schotter, was married yesterday to Dr. Alvan Grayson Walker 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker Jr. of Melbourne, Fla. The Rev. John Allen, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, performed the ceremony in Flanders, N.J., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Smith Shelton, friends of the couple.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ELLEN KOTEEN;
AIDS and Its Toll on Women
description: LEAD: ELLEN KOTEEN, a social worker, doesn't remember exactly when she became an activist, but she believes she came by activism naturally, and points out that she attended high school and college in the 1960's - the time of rebellion and flower children.

title: Jays Beat Indians on an Error in 11th
description: Luis Aguayo, the Cleveland shortstop, bobbled Tony Fernandez's grounder with the bases loaded in the 11th inning today and allowed the winning run to score as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Indians, 3-2.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: TOMORROW'S TELEVISION;
The Profits Will Be in Niche Markets
description: LEAD: Whether American companies ought to participate in the new markets for advanced video technologies - of which high-definition television is the most obvious symbol - is a meaningless inquiry without answering a prior question: Can any American company make acceptable profits on HDTV or any other consumer electronics product?

title: Radical Assamese Separatists Gaining in India
description: Radical militants appear to be taking control of a separatist movement in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, nudging aside the separatist leaders who signed a truce with the state and national governments last month.

title: Lord Trafford, British Health Minister, 57
description: Lord Trafford, minister of state for health, died today of lung cancer, the Government announced. He was 57.

title: Rhona Chalson Has a Wedding
description: Rhona E. Chalson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Chalson of Forest Hills, Queens, was married in New York last evening to Richard A. Weiss, the son of Hans Weiss of New York and the late Mary Weiss. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Loft.

description: Kenya Cautions

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
