description: LEAD: POLISH DANCE AND MUSIC

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ST. VALENTINE'S NIGHT. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $18.95.) Andrew M. Greeley may be a great priest, a great sociologist, even a great fellow. But, to judge from his latest book, a great novelist he is not. In ''St. Valentine's Night,'' a respected investigative reporter named Neal Connor, on assignment in his hometown of Chicago, meets his first love, the recently widowed Megan Lane, at a class reunion.

title: As Trading and Con Games Increase, So Does 'Slabbing'
description: A small California company is transforming the rare coins trade. Formed three years ago, Professional Coin Grading Service Inc. in Newport Beach has developed a system for grading high-quality coins that has since become the industry standard. While other companies offer grading services, none have matched Professional Coin's acceptance among dealers. Analysts estimate that the company has graded as much as 40 percent of the $1 billion in coins traded annually.

title: Smooth Sailing Along the Banks Of Kensico Dam
description: FEW sights seem more suited to the reflecting pool at Kensico Dam Plaza than a white boat sailing serenely by. A model boat, that is, assembled from a kit with the meticulous care of a hobbyist.

title: THE PLAYWRIGHT AS TERRORIST
description: BERNARD SHAW Volume Two: 1898-1918. The Pursuit of Power. By Michael Holroyd. Illustrated. 421 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: New City
description: HARDLY new and never more than a hamlet, New City is an unlikely county seat. Its center is not on the Palisades Interstate Parkway, the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway or Route 9W, the three major highways that connect nearly every other hamlet, village and town in Rockland County with New York City and New Jersey. Its main business district is a three-mile stretch of Main Street and most stores are in converted 19th-century frame houses.

title: Price of Vaccines For Measles Criticized
description: As a mother and a registered nurse, I am outraged and dismayed that ''private doctors charge an average of $75 for the booster to reimmunize our teen-agers against measles and/or measles, mumps and rubella.'' (''Measles Directive Puzzling Parents,'' Aug. 13).

title: U.S. Trade Official 'More Positive' on Europe
description: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that she was ''in a more positive frame of mind'' about threats of restrictions on American imports than she was a week ago when she began a round of talks with European trade officials.

title: S. R. Cordill Wed To Ms. O'Connell
description: Carolyn Elizabeth O'Connell, an assistant vice president in the mutual funds and annuities department of Prudential Bache Securities in New York, and Stephen Richard Cordill, a first vice president and director of financial services for the same company, were married yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. Msgr. Harold Murray performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. William Devine and the Rev. Thomas Wedsworth, a Presbyterian minister. Mrs. Cordill, 31 years old, is a daughter of Mrs. Thomas R. O'Connell of Short Hills and the late Mr. O'Connell. She graduated from Denison University. Her mother, Christina O'Connell, teaches first-grade students at the Pingry School in Short Hills. Her father was chairman of Advanced Resource Technology, a computer software company in Reston, Va. Mrs. Cordill's grandfather the late Vincent J. Coyle built the Carlyle Hotel and the Beverly Hotel, both in New York.

title: Jeanne L. Clendenin, Legislative Aide, Is Wed to Daniel C. Sweeney, Lawyer
description: Jeanne Louise Clendenin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Clendenin of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Charles Sweeney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh O. Sweeney of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Horace Grinnell officiated at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Arlington, Va.

title: Dinosaur Display Can Be Scary
description: You recently had a number of articles devoted to the dinosaur exhibition at the Sands Point Preserve.

title: CATCHES OF THE DAY: SOME CURIOSITIES
description: There is nothing as elemental to the sport of angling as the fish hook. Whether the hooks are great, heavy-gauged models for billfish or tiny, fine-wired versions for trout, they excel at their express purpose: to connect fishermen with fish.

title: Indy Fisher, Surfing Champion, Weds
description: Melinda Grace Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Fisher of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Kimogenor Point, New Suffolk, L.I., and Tyler Stokes Callaway, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Trowbridge Callaway Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla., and Quogue, L.I., were married yesterday in Southold, L.I. The Rev. Roy Brewer officiated at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: INSIDE
description: Poland on Soviet Invasion

title: Colgate Holds Off Penn for an Upset
description: Dave Goodwin threw two touchdown passes and ran for another today as Colgate upset Pennsylvania, a defending Ivy League co-champion, by 21-14. The Red Raiders (2-1) opened up a 14-0 lead in the first quarter and held off two Penn rallies in the Quakers' season opener.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FIDDLING AROUND

title: State Grapples With Homelessness
description: LEAD: OVER the last year, the state Department of Human Services, using temporary rent subsidies, has succeeded in moving hundreds of homeless families out of welfare hotels and into apartments. But their places in the welfare hotels are being taken by new homeless families.

title: The Passive President
description: In conscience and self-interest, the West cannot let the democratic experiment in Poland fail. Then why has the Bush Administration decided against giving immediate, large-scale aid to Poland's collapsing economy?

title: This 'Treasure' Was Flawed
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I Love My Wife' At Cabaret in Bridgeport
description: SEXUAL permissiveness, with a bit of drug taking on the side, may have been a fashionable pastime of the 60's and 70's, but it is an acknowledged taboo of the 80's. Recording it for posterity requires the perspective of social satire or the purposefulness of a sociological statement. Otherwise, the subject is passe, if not objectionable.

title: HONG KONG
description: Correspondents on assignment around the world discuss the influence of local fashion on their own attire.

title: In the H.U.D. Investigation, Everyone Wants Pierce Now
description: SAMUEL R. PIERCE JR. has tried to portray himself as a ''hands off'' manager who was unaware of the influence-peddling during his tenure as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. And for a time he was viewed that way, while Federal investigators focused on a few senior agency officials, particularly Deborah Gore Dean, Mr. Pierce's former executive assistant.

title: UNNERVING ART
description: Twice in his article on Francis Bacon, described as ''perhaps the greatest living figure painter,'' Michael Kimmelman reports that Bacon ''details his fondness for men,'' apparently with some degree of pleasure and pride, yet no amplification of these observations made it into print, even in euphemistic form (''Unnerving Art,'' Aug. 20). Given the hot debate over the work of Robert Mapplethorpe, another gay artist who wasn't afraid to deal with his sexual preference in public, Francis Bacon's forthright homosexuality, described in his own words and on his own terms, would have been fascinating, as germane to his paintings as to today's censorial climate. ED SIKOV New York, N.Y.

title: About Men; No Longer My Brother's Keeper
description: I AM IN THE EMER-gency room of a Veterans Administration hospital in West Los Angeles, sweating. Across from me, a young bearded doctor is inserting an IV device into the forearm of a 40-year-old alcoholic whose profuse vomiting has left him dehydrated. As I watch this doctor puncture the patient's vein, I am aware of my own heartbeat - I am speeded up, on edge. Then it happens: the doctor withdraws the needle, and it pings onto the floor. I do not understand that it is no longer required; I think something has gone terribly wrong. I clamp my teeth to keep from saying, ''Danny, don't you think a real doctor should take over now?'' Danny, this cool young man with a stethoscope dropping from his neck and a beeper clipped to his belt, is a second-year resident in internal medicine at U.C.L.A. He is my little brother.

title: Penn State Routs Temple, 42-3
description: Blair Thomas rushed for 138 yards and two touchdowns and Tom Bill passed for 192 yards and two scores today as Penn State defeated Temple, 42-3.

title:
ART;
Mystery of Genesis In a Homage to Science
description: LEAD: AS advances in science and technology have outstripped even the wildest imaginings of visionary thinkers, art has adopted a more populist orientation. The language of contemporary art, filled with references to familiar images and everyday experience, seems to have little in common with the abstruse vocabulary of modern science.

title: Staten Island to Continue as Powerhouse
description: While the Island of Manhattan may have more size, wealth, population and prestige when it comes to high school football in New York City, it's Staten Island that has the power, and it looks as if it will be that way again this year.

title: A CRITIC AT THE TOP OF HIS VOICE
description: HARLAN ELLISON'S WATCHING By Harlan Ellison. 514 pp. Los Angeles: Underwood-Miller. $29.95.

title: Review/ Opera; Drama On and Off Stage For a Catalani Rarity
description: During the grand procession of the Festa del Volto Santo, or the Feast of the Moving Saint, on Wednesday evening -after which Lucca's opera season traditionally begins - the management of the Teatro del Giglio must have offered its own set of prayers.

title: HOW MEN SEE THE WORLD
description: As William E. Connor was preparing for a business meeting in Seoul, South Korea, he realized that he was missing something terribly important: his pants. Part of a dark suit, they had not come back from the dry cleaner. Connor, the representive director of William E. Connor Inc., a Tokyo-based trading and sourcing company, had no alternative but to borrow from a Korean colleague - a simple solution, except that his sartorial Samaritan was almost a foot shorter than he is.

title: Poles Denounce '39 Soviet Entry As Criminal Act
description: The Polish Communist Party newspaper accused the Soviet Union today of perpetrating large-scale crimes when it invaded Poland in concert with Hitler's army at the start of World War II.

title: Nepal, Nashville
description: To the Editor: Your section has sent us off well prepared to many exotic places. In fact, ''What's Doing in Katmandu'' (Travel, Jan. 15) arrived as we were ready to leave for the airport on a trip to Nepal, and it was very helpful.

title: Scotch's New International Status
description: To Alastair Robertson, manager of the Glenkinchie Distillery here, the pleasing perfume of Scotch whisky breathing in oak casks as it ages for 10 years is the sharp, sweet smell of success.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-29

title: Badlands
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest ''The Good Old Days in the Badlands''. Those interested in more information on the Marquis de Mores should look to the book ''The Marquis de Mores: Emperor of the Bad Lands.'' It was written by my late father, Donald Dresden, who was born in Larimore, N.D., in 1910. Published by the University of Oklahoma Press, it has been in and out of print over the past 20 years but fortunately can be found in most large public libraries. ANTHONY V. DRESDEN Washington

title: Ed Koch's New York
description: As he flew in from Washington one evening during his second term, a contented Edward Koch looked out at the glittering New York skyline and smiled. ''Mine, all mine,'' he said, figuratively, of course, but with unfeigned warmth.

title: Snapshots of Hope and Hopelessness
description: WHEN NEW YORK City Schools Chancellor Richard Green died abruptly of a heart attack last May, more than 5,000 mourners thronged the memorial service and lined the streets leading to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Clearly they were grieving not only for the man, who had only been in office 14 months and was not a native New Yorker, but for the city's public school system. It was as if the problems Green had faced were so massive, so overwhelming that they had literally killed him.

title: On the Plan to Revise Special Education
description: As teachers implementing the Plan to Revise Special Education in New Jersey, we wish to clarify some of the information in ''Plan to Revamp Special Education Draws Criticism.''

title: Clean Air Bill: The Question Is, Who Is Picking Up the Check?
description: Everyone wants clean air. But who should pay for it?

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Hurt In Attack Near Jordan
description: An assailant thought to be a Jordanian soldier opened fire on an Israeli Army patrol across the border this morning and slightly wounded two Israeli soldiers. Jordan said one of its soldiers was wounded by Israeli fire in the incident.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE BREAKTHROUGH: The Race for the Superconductor, by Robert M. Hazen. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A scientist gives an inside account of the race to discover and patent higher-temperature superconductors. ''The result is both dramatic and fair-minded,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ''Dr. Hazen writes with wonderful clarity about science, foreshortening the action where the going gets heavy and stretching it out when the story is accessible.'' BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) In another novel about a lower-middle-classJU family in Baltimore, Anne Tyler introduces Maggie Moran, a cheerful, meddling woman who marries off her son to a 17-year-old she shanghais from an abortion clinic. Last year our reviewer, Edward Hoagland, said Ms. Tyler shows that ''in this fractionated era she can write so well about blood links and family funerals, old friendships or the dogged pull of thwarted love, of blunted love affairs or marital mismatches that neither mend nor end. Her eye is kindly, wise and versatile (an eye that you would want on your jury if you ever had to stand trial).'' THE FACTS: A Novelist's Autobiography, by Philip Roth. (Penguin, $7.95.) Philip Roth comes clean with the true story of his heavily fictionalized life, including, for good measure, commentary by his character Nathan Zuckerman. ''All of this suggests that for Mr. Roth his life and his work, his 'facts' and his 'fiction,' are virtually identical,'' Justin Kaplan said here last year. ''The three component terms of his title - facts, novelist, autobiography - are charged particles whose shifting polarities, repulsions and attractions account for the book's hypomanic intensities as well as its occasional languors.'' Next month, Houghton Mifflin will publish a 30th-anniversary edition of Mr. Roth's first book, GOODBYE, COLUMBUS: And Five Short Stories ($7.95). Included is a new introduction by Mr. Roth, written in the third person, explaining how the book came to be. A DEADLY SILENCE. The Ordeal of Cheryl Pierson: A Case of Incest and Murder, by Dena Kleiman. (Signet/ New American Library, $4.95.) A New York Times reporter tells about the sexually abused Long Island teen-ager who paid a classmate $400 to kill her father. Last year our reviewer, Betty Rollin, said the book is written ''with care, intensity and a novelist's sense.'' FOUND IN THE STREET, by Patricia Highsmith. (Atlantic Monthly, $8.95.) A nice waitress who wants to be a model moves to Greenwich Village and becomes the obsessive interest of Ralph, a middle-aged night watchman; Natalia, an art gallery manager; Jack, Natalia's rich husband, and a number of other people. ''Often misrepresented as a genre writer of thrillers, Ms. Highsmith is a fine psychologist and ironist, and her newest novel is a powerfully disturbing, resonant creation,'' Richard Burgin said here last year. ON BENDED KNEE: The Press and the Reagan Presidency, by Mark Hertsgaard. (Schocken, $11.95.) Reporters were too ready to laugh at Ronald Reagan instead of seriously analyzing his shortcomings, Mark Hertsgaard contends. Last year our reviewer, Stephen E. Ambrose, said that the author gives the press a ''bum rap'' but that he ''has worked hard and produced a readable and often enlightening book.'' THE INDIA FAN, by Victoria Holt. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) The poor daughter of a rector becomes involved with the fabulously wealthy family next door. This novel ''could turn the most resolute boob tuber into a book lover,'' Sheila Paulos said here last year. ''With a cursed fan made of peacock feathers, a bogus count, an illegitimate child, a white slaver, servants both faithful and traitorous, not to mention a follower of an ancient murder cult, the plot is full of enthralling stuff.'' THE LETTERS OF JOHN CHEEVER, edited by Benjamin Cheever. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) When this selection of John Cheever's correspondence was published last year, The Times's John Gross said that the author's son Benjamin had produced ''a loving but far from idealized portrait: a hefty selection of letters, accompanied by an editorial commentary that deserves a place alongside Susan Cheever's admirable memoir of her father, 'Home Before Dark.' '' THE ORGAN BUILDER, by Robert Cohen. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A New York lawyer returns to New Mexico in search of his father, a Manhattan Project physicist who disappeared years ago. Last year our reviewer, Nina Sonenberg, called this ''an intimate, stunningly written portrait.'' Robert Cohen ''gives us romance and humor, real passion and pain and even some mystery, all narrated in a voice that, despite occasional excesses, often approaches sheer poetry.'' AMERICA INVULNERABLE: The Quest for Absolute Security From 1812 to Star Wars, by James Chace and Caleb Carr. (Summit, $12.95.) The Strategic Defense Initiative, the authors argue, is the outgrowth of an obsessive belief in unilateral defense that is rooted in the War of 1812, when the British burned the White House. Last year our reviewer, Gaddis Smith, disagreed with this thesis, but he said ''the two final chapters, on recent policies in this hemisphere and President Reagan's Star Wars enterprise, make this book worth reading.'' CABAL, by Clive Barker. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) The horrors in this novella and four stories ''demonstrate why the gleefully gory Mr. Barker is at the top of his genre,'' Howard Mittelmark said here last year. ''Filled with one ghastly, baroque effect after another, it's dazzling, captivating stuff, but finally it's all special effects.''

title: Toward the 18th Hole With Baby Boomers
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Leader Appoints New Cabinet
description: President F. W. de Klerk appointed a Cabinet today that reflected a desire for stability as well as his expressed intention to pursue negotiations with the country's black majority.

title: Telltale Tomato And the Turn Of Seasons
description: IT'S coming to an end. Yesterday was the turning point, evident in the different quality of the sunlight slanting over my shoulder as I weeded the now tall leafy tomato plants. Wait a minute! These plants were just seedlings, bravely waving their tiny leaves in a barren garden. Now they are heavy with fruit, vying for space among the bushy marigolds and encroaching green pepper plants.

title: GREAT LEADER TO DEAR LEADER
description: In attempting to describe a nation whose ''perception of the world is so different from ours . . . that reality and unreality seem to blend and blur,'' Nicholas D. Kristof seems to assume that his own sense of what is real is normal and that of the Koreans is in some essential way abnormal, or distorted (''Great Leader to Dear Leader,'' Aug. 20). How else to explain Mr. Kristof's curious statement that the North Koreans' faith in their leaders ''seems so excessive that it cannot possibly be genuine.'' Or his suggestion that ''quasi-religious feelings for a political leader seem incomprehensible to most Americans.'' I am not so certain.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Kingdom Wins Hurdles in Tokyo: Roger Kingdom, the two-time Olympic champion, won the men's 110-meter high hurdles in the Tokyo International Super meet yesterday, but failed to lower his world record. Kingdom led from the start in winning in 13.28 seconds. His world record of 12.92 was set at Zurich on Aug. 16. Another American, Tonie Campbell, finished second in 13.38. Randy Barnes, also from the United States, beat the world-record holder and Olympic gold medalist, Ulf Timmermann of East Germany, in the shot-put for the first time. Barnes did 69 feet 9 1/2 inches to Timmermann's 69-2 1/2. Other American winners were Larry Myricks in the long jump at 27-4 3/4; Mike Conley in the triple jump at 57-7 3/4; Evelyn Ashford in the 100-meter dash, clocking 11:21, and Sandra Farmer-Patrick in winning the women's 400 in 51.81. Rodion Gataullin of the Soviet Union took the pole vault at 19-8 1/4, not far off the world record of 19-10 3/4 held by another Soviet athlete, Sergei Bubka.(AP) Tennis Wightman Cup Triumph Completed: The doubles team of Lori McNeil and Patty Fendick completed a United States sweep of Wightman Cup matches yesterday as they defeated Jo Durie and Anne Hobbs of Britain, 6-3, 6-3, in Williamsburg, Va. After trailing by 3-2 in the second set, the Americans rallied and broke Hobbs's serve to go up 4-3. They broke Durie's serve to win the final game, which ended when McNeil hit a forehand winner down the line. It was McNeil's second victory of the afternoon after she beat Sara Gomer, 6-4, 6-2, in the day's first match, the fifth of the annual seven-match competition between the United States and Britain. In the second match yesterday, Mary Joe Fernandez beat Durie, 6-1, 7-5. The Americans had clinched the cup Friday when Fernandez beat Gomer, 6-1, 6-2, and then teamed with Betsy Nagelsen to defeat Gomer and Clare Wood.(AP) Fernandez-White Advance: The top-seeded team of Gigi Fernandez and Robin White beat their fellow Americans Cynthia and Cammy MacGregor, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims International in Tokyo. Elizabeth Smylie and Wendy Turnbull of Australia defeated Maya Kidowaki and Kimiko Date of Japan, 6-2, 6-2, in the other semifinal. The final will be today at Yoyogi National Stadium.(AP) Yachting Darien Man Wins Title: Jamie McCreary, a sailor from Darien, Conn., won the International One-Design world championship Friday at the end of a weeklong sailboat regatta on Long Island Sound. McCreary, 34 years old, was in second place as he started the last race of the five-race series. He and his crew of four managed to win the last race by putting four boats between themselves and their closest rival in overall points. The regatta, organized by the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., drew 16 of the 33-foot sloops to the starting line. Golf Two Tied in Boston Event: Brad Faxon, cheered on by hometown fans in a bid for his first PGA victory, caught Don Pooley and tied him for the lead after yesterday's third round of the Bank of Boston Classic at Sutton, Mass. Faxon shot a one-under par 70 for a 54-hole total of 10-under 203 at Pleasant Valley Country Club. Pooley, who took a two-stroke lead over Faxon with a course-record 131 in the first two rounds, slipped into a tie with a 72. Mark Calcavecchia, last year's winner, and Peter Jacobsen were tied at 204.(AP) Ferree Leads in Seniors: Jim Ferree birdied the 16th and 17th holes yesterday to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Crestar PGA Seniors Classic at Richmond. Ferree finished with a 66 and was at 11-under-par 133 after 36 holes, one shot ahead of Dick Rhyan, who bogeyed the 16th hole and finished with a 68. Chi Chi Rodriguez and Bob Charles both shot 69's and were tied at 135 with first-day leader, Jim Dent.(AP) Daniel Leads by 4: Beth Daniel shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to take a four-stroke lead after the third round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Safeco Classic at the 6,222-yard Meridian Valley Country Club in Kent, Wash. Daniel had a total of 13-under-par 203. Pat Bradley was at 207 after shooting a 70.(AP) Hockey Flames 5, Sokol Kiev 2: Sergei Priakin became the first former Soviet national team member to score for a National Hockey League team as the Calgary Flames defeated Kiev Sokol yesterday, giving N.H.L. teams a 3-0 record in their tour of the Soviet Union. The Flames also won Thursday in Leningrad against Voskresensk Khimik, and the Washington Capitals defeated Moscow Spartak, 8-7, Friday. Priakin, who opened the scoring early in the first period on a breakaway, signed with the Flames last March, the first player released by the Soviet Hockey Federation to play in the N.H.L.(AP)

title: A Tarrytown Couple's Home Is, Indeed, Their Castle
description: LEAD: ROSWITHA H. THOMAS has a deep belief in her man. Seven years after they were married in West Germany, her husband, Heribert W., wanted to come to America. She did not.

title:
IN SHORT: NO FICTION;
THE TRANSCENDENTAL TOURIST
description: LEAD: In the spring and summer of 1833, when he was 29, Ralph Waldo Emerson spent five months in Italy, working his way up from Sicily, visiting Naples, Rome, Florence and Venice. The abject poverty he encountered in Naples bothered him: ''Whilst you eat your dinner at a Trattoria, a beggar stands at the window, watching every mouthful.

title: Hawkins Matches Wits With Carson
description: Methodically and neatly, so different from the man he replaced, Ralph Hawkins has filed away his old game plans, dusted off the old sayings, and now must leave it up to the players.

title: Black Agony Pierces the Heart Of an Afrikaner
description: Midway through ''A Dry White Season,'' Euzhan Palcy's new film about South Africa, an Afrikaner teacher named Ben Du Toit ventures for the first time from his suburban Johannesburg home into the teeming black township of Soweto. With the company and protection of a black cabbie, Du Toit is bound for a funeral home, there to mourn over the body of an aquaintance, who died in security police detention.

title: Letting Feelings Bloom
description: THE days of summer gradually shorten and I look back and say, ''Where has the time gone?'' The feeling that keeps emerging is frustration. I don't seem to have done very much. Or have I?

title: Clocks and Jewels From the Golden Age of Cartier
description: Glorious glitter, classical styling and Oriental flourishes are the hallmarks of the House of Cartier's early-20th-century designs, as can be seen in an exhibition here at the Walters Art Gallery. The show of 70 precious objects - jewelry, clocks, handbags, picture frames, desk accessories and potted hard-stone flowers - is the first public presentation of one of the finest private collections of Cartier in the United States.

title: BOSTON BRAWLER
description: LEAD: STRAIGHT SHOOTING What's Wrong With America and How to Fix It. By John Silber. 336 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: A 'Film Cuckoo' Plays a Main Role in Its Study
description: LEAD: AT the Wesleyan Cinema Archives in Middletown, the complete working scripts - leatherbound - of ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' ''It Happened One Night,'' ''You Can't Take It With You'' and ''It's a Wonderful Life'' rest on one of the dozens of shelves devoted to the Frank Capra collection.

title: Nebraska Rolls Past Utah
description: Ken Clark ran for 130 yards and two touchdowns and the quarterback Gerry Gdowski had three scoring runs today to lead Nebraska past Utah, 42-30.

title: Expos Hammer The Mets
description: The Mets had a great chance to gain in the homestretch again tonight but squandered it when the Montreal Expos rose up from the misery of a five-game losing streak, chased Sid Fernandez inside three innings and hammered the Mets, 10-1.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BEVERLY HILLS. By Pat Booth. (Crown, $18.95.) The author of ''Palm Beach'' lays the plot of her latest potboiler flat out on page 2: Paula Hope, a young, beautiful, penniless girl with a flair for interior design, is looking for love, security, safety, excitement and revenge in glittery, glamorous Beverly Hills.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Vacation time is over for house plants; before moving them back indoors, turn pots on their sides and hose off the plants to remove spiders, mealybugs, yellowed leaves and dead twigs. If roots are pushing out the drain holes, plants have outgrown their pots. Repot them in clean pots that are at least one size larger than the ones in which they were growing. Water well to settle the roots. Christmas cactus and jade plants remain outdoors until the first frost to be sure that flower buds are set, then take them inside. Yard Waste

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Visiting Beijing: Fewer Tourists, Some Bargains

title: Second 'Wood Chipper Murder' Trial Begins
description: The long-awaited replay of last year's trial of an airline pilot charged with killing his wife and feeding parts of her body through a wood chipper has begun here in Superior Court.

title:
GARDENING;
The Return of the Seedless Watermelon
description: LEAD: SEEDLESS watermelons have been popular this year among commercial growers in the South. While relatively few seem to have shown up in produce markets in our region, they will certainly be here next season, and undoubtedly they will also appear in seed catalogues for those gardeners who grow their own.

title: No One Yet Has Immunity From Racial Conflict; Not Johannesburg
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: 555 Broadway; 3 Sisters Renovate
description: People grow and change and so do neighborhoods, and in NoHo the idea of new departures has been joined at 555 Broadway. There, an ornate, century-old mercantile building is starting a new life as an office center and the developers are three professional women who formed a real estate troika to do the project.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mad Monk's Banned Banner
description: Knowing that radio station WHTZ-FM had already stirred Yankee fans to bring signs and banners to Friday night's game, knowing that the American Civil Liberties Union had protested his security officer's strongarm tactics in banning signs critical of him two weeks ago, baseball's most tiresome proof of free speech, George Steinbrenner, upheld the Constitution with all the democracy he could muster. On only 24 hours' notice, the Yankees announced that fans could parade Friday night with signs and banners critical of the principal owner while he was about 2,000 miles downrange, at a United States Olympic Committee meeting in Colorado.

title: Food; Coming Home to Roast
description: SOMETIMES, I WOULD GLADLY GIVE UP dinner at a starred restaurant for real home-cooked food; at other times, I crave the excitement and sophistication of a great restaurant. Although a French saying asserts that ''On ne mange bien que chez soi'' - ''we eat well only at home'' - travel guides like the Michelin maintain that the greatest food in the world is found in the famed restaurants.

title: MOSCOW
description: Correspondents on assignment around the world discuss the influence of local fashion on their own attire.

title: Reviews/Music; Cosmopolitan Quality Of the Polish Art Song
description: For most listeners, the art song is primarily the province of Western European and, in this century, American composers. But the literature extends in other geographical directions, too. On Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, Juliana Gondek - an American soprano of Polish descent - offered the first of two concerts devoted to the Polish song literature.

title: How Inflation Looks In a Real Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable TV Provokes Dispute in Somers
description: JACOB L. TROBE is not a fanatic follower of sports, movies or ballet, but he wants to be able to flip his cable television dial and bring the Sports Channel, Home Box Office and the Arts and Entertainment Channel into his Somers home. His neighbors in town have that option, but Mr. Trobe, a 77-year-old cable television producer, does not.

title: Lyric Operetta Gaining an Audience
description: WITH the timing of a seasoned businessman, William Edgerton of Darien turned a hobby into an operetta company that has doubled its subscriptions in less than five seasons.

title: Oil Spill Shuts Part of Hudson
description: A 30-mile stretch of the Hudson River south of Albany was closed to water traffic yesterday after more than 1,000 gallons of oil spilled into the river, the Coast Guard said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Worcester, Mass.;
2d Key Building In Biotech Park
description: LEAD: THE second major office building in the new 75-acre Massachusetts Biotechnology Research Park is being fitted for tenants as this city tries to expand its science-industry employment.

title: End of a Yard Sale: Sore Feet, Rejected Dolls
description: I HELD a yard sale last week. I knew it would be a smashing success. I would dispose of memorabilia accumulated since college, the first years of marriage and my daughter's infancy and make room for the trappings of middle age and preadolescence. And, I would earn a lot of money.

title: India Tries to Quit Sri Lanka's Despair
description: AS Sri Lanka and India edge toward an agreement that will send 40,000 Indian peacekeeping troops home, people on both sides of the straits that separate the two countries are counting the political costs of New Delhi's ill-fated foray into a foreign war. The conflict the Indians came to end is not over. On the contrary, the seeds of even more bitter battles have been sown.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a state program that allows sentences mainly outside prison for people convicted of nonviolent crimes misidentified the program. It is the Intensive Supervision Program, not the Intermediate Sentencing Program.

title: Photocopying Centers: A New Slice of Life In the Wee Still Hours
description: The paper sign - soggy and forlorn - was taped to a lamppost at Eighth Street and Broadway. The photocopied message said:

title: Megan Crowley, Producer, Weds
description: Margaret Anne Crowley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Crowley of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Keith Alexander McAllister, the son of Joan S. McAllister of New York and the late John T. McAllister. The Rev. Joseph A. Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart.

title: Review/Music; 19th-Century Songfest Of Protest and Reform
description: Voices of Change, a series at Merkin Concert Hall devoted to political songs, got started Monday evening with a program that looked back to the 19th century. The concert opened with the Hutchinson Family Singers, a quintet from Minnesota that re-creates the repertory of the original Hutchinsons, who started performing as a group of siblings in 1840 and continued through three generations, until the death of their founder, John Hutchinson, in 1908.

title: Correction
description: A picture of two Bronte sisters on Aug. 20 was published in error. It showed Anne (at left) and Emily, not Charlotte and Emily.

title: Driving Down The Dollar
description: These days, it seems that nothing can stop the mighty dollar. A combination of relatively high interest rates, a desire by foreigners to invest in American assets and concerns over political instability elsewhere has turned the dollar into the darling of the currency markets. Last May, a dollar bought 130 yen; today it buys 144 yen. And a dollar is now worth 1.93 West German marks, up from 1.88 last spring.

title: Cheap Air Seats: Gone Today and Here Tomorrow
description: WHEN American Airlines flight 218 left Seattle for Chicago on Aug. 23, just past midnight, the 12 first-class seats were filled and so were all but one of the 130 coach seats.

title: Putting Together a Defensive Portfolio
description: Pity the small investor. As the stock market leaps to record highs and then pulls back, these investors are racked with a conflicting mixture of fear and greed. If they have been cringing on the sidelines since the October 1987 crash, is now the time to jump in again to snare some fast profits? If, on the other hand, they got into the market before the recent gains, is it time to cash in their winnings or should they dig in and not miss out on the chance for further gains?

title: Umpire Troubles In New League?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Two Who Made A Revolution
description: Next Sunday, an exhibition that we have long been waiting for and sometimes despaired of ever seeing will open to the public at the Museum of Modern Art. ''Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism'' deals at first hand and in detail (much of it quite new) with one of the most celebrated partnerships in the history of European art.

title: Giving the Voters A Say on Shoreham
description: The article ''L.I. Power Authority Weighs Alternate Plans for Shoreham,'' Sept. 3, did not consider the alternative plan suggested to President Bush, Governor Cuomo, and Energy Secretary Watkins by the Association for a Better Long Island. I would like to review that proposal.

title: A Full Crock of Foot-Stomping Charm
description: ''PUMP BOYS AND DINETTES,'' now at Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre, is a foot-stomping, hand-clapping, country-western pop musical. It starts off the theater's 15th anniversary season with a crock of good ole boy charm.

title:
The View From: The Office of Disaster and Emergency Services;
Getting Ready for Anything, Underground
description: LEAD: THE newly renovated quarters of the County Office of Disaster and Emergency Services has only one window, and it is not real. There are white curtains - pretty against the newly painted pale blue walls -a pane of glass and, a few inches behind the glass, a poster of a waterfall in a leafy glade. That's the best one can do two stories underground, in a subbasement that is relatively safe in the event of radioactive fallout or other deadly hazards.

title: Computer Stocks With Promise
description: While minicomputer and mainframe sales remain soft, as more and more tasks are shifted to personal computers, analysts say one segment of the market for large computers will continue to grow. Demand is strong for the high-performance machines that can handle a blizzard of transactions with very little risk of a crash.

title: Brazil Sure to Qualify In World Bridge Play
description: The qualifying stage of the world team championships drew to a close here tonight with the qualifiers in doubt in both series.

title: Center Opens to Assist The Hard of Hearing
description: LEAD: JUST about anyone who is hearing-impaired is familiar with hearing aids, but far fewer people know about assistive listening and alerting devices. So said Edith Shapiro, president of the county's chapter of the national organization called Self Help for Hard of Hearing People; and Ruth Rabiner, coordinator of a new center where these devices are demonstrated.

title: Bangkok Returns to Its River
description: LEAD: ''THE highways of Bangkok are not streets or roads but the river and the canals.''

title: TOKYO
description: Correspondents on assignment around the world discuss the influence of local fashion on their own attire.

title: DEATH ON THE MOUND
description: THE PITCH THAT KILLED By Mike Sowell. Illustrated. 330 pp. New York: Macmillan. $17.95.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: Anthony Walton's article ''Willie Horton and Me'' (Aug. 20) touched me on several levels. There is often isolation, in this between-and-betwixt world black professionals occupy.

title: No One Yet Has Immunity From Racial Conflict; We Are All Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET ARMS PLAN GAINING U.S. FAVOR
description: Administration officials said today that the United States had decided to accept a basic element of a Soviet plan for monitoring the size of underground nuclear blasts.

title: BIG BUCKS, TOUGH TACTICS
description: THIS MAY BE THE MOST TROUBLE ROGER KING HAS ever had getting a program on television. The burly 45-year-old chairman of King World Productions, the first syndicator in broadcast history to have three simultaneous top-rated hits - ''Wheel of Fortune,'' ''Jeopardy'' and ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' - is standing before a wall unit in his Manhattan office, fumbling with a video cassette player. Like a dumb pet, the machine refuses to perform now that company has arrived. Unfortunately, King's guest is Brooke Bailey Johnson, vice president of programming at the Arts and Entertainment Network, and he's trying to interest her in a pilot that has recently been test marketed. ''The show I'm about to show you is called 'Offshore TV,' '' he tells her. ''It did, like, a 25 share, 8 rating in Detroit at one in the morning,'' he says, futilely poking at buttons. His secretary answers a call for help. Plink. The tape begins to roll. So does Roger King. He has made thousands of pitches before, but few like this. ''Offshore TV,'' an offbeat half-hour of music and comedy set in a fictitious ''pirate'' television station, is a King World project from start to finish, marking the company's second foray into production. The first was ''Inside Edition,'' a television ''magazine'' that has garnered mixed ratings since its debut last January.

title: How the Disabled Sold Congress on a New Bill of Rights
description: WHEN Judith Heumann was 5 years old, her mother proudly pushed her wheelchair to the local public school, only to be told that the eager kindergartner could not be admitted because she was a fire hazard. When she was 21, she was denied an elementary school teaching credential because her lower limbs were paralyzed from polio. She has been asked to leave airplanes because she wanted to travel unattended and she was once forcibly removed from an auction house, because, the owner explained, she was ''disgusting to look at.''

title: Review/Dance; 2 Visiting Companies
description: Anne Bluethenthal and Dancers, a troupe from San Francisco, and the Van Pelt Dance Ensemble of Columbus, Ohio, shared a program Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Both groups had competent dancers, but too many of their offerings included dull choreographic ideas.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE ROAD TO JOY: The Letters of Thomas Merton to New and Old Friends. Edited by Robert E. Daggy. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.95.) Thomas Merton was, in his mind, at all times a monk. His other vocation, the writing of poetry and books, was secondary. He treated his writing, which was influential in the secular and spiritual worlds, as an ''addiction'' that sometimes needed curbing. In ''The Road to Joy'' - edited by Robert E. Daggy, director of the Thomas Merton Center at Bellarmine College - the reader has further access to the heart and mind of the author of ''The Seven Storey Mountain'' and other books. After becoming a Trappist monk, Merton achieved his cherished solitude and devoted his time to prayer and writing. In this collection, the second volume in a series that began with ''The Hidden Ground of Love'' in 1985, the letters date from 1931, 10 years before Merton joined the monastery of Our Lady of Gethsemani, to 1968, when he died. His letters portray Merton's enduring exuberance and optimism, as well as his keen intelligence and sharp-tongued humor. They mostly concern literary and religious matters, from overseeing his publications to discussing his spiritual enlightenment. Often, Merton offered priestly advice or expounded on social and political issues - the Vietnam War and racism, for example - despite his cloistered existence. His gift as a letter writer was the ability to maintain the balance between his two vocations, sometimes to the point where the boundary lines disappeared. In reading these letters, one wistfully longs for Merton's close company.

title: Reviews/Music; Mel Torme Improvisations In Easy-Listening Disguise
description: Jazz singers have often served as intermediaries, bringing jazz instrumentalist ideas to an audience that would not go near a jazz club. So it was at Michael's Pub on Wednesday night, when Mel Torme slyly included themes by Charlie Parker, Tiny Kahn and other jazz musicians in an arrangement that cloaked his rapturous, risky improvisations in the guise of entertainment.

title: Digital Speakers Thrive on a Diet of Laser Beams
description: Last Spring, reporting from the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, this column briefly mentioned Meridian's D600 digital loudspeaker as ''the best-sounding item in Chicago and probably anywhere else.'' Since then we have listened to it at greater length, hearing many different kinds of music in less distracting circumstances than those prevailing at a trade fair. Our opinion remains unchanged.

title: U.S. FOUND PAN AM LAX ON SECURITY SOON AFTER BLAST
description: Federal investigators found a number of security violations by Pan American World Airways in a special inspection conducted after the bombing of a Pan Am jet over Scotland, people familiar with the inquiry say.

title: World Cup Hunt Resumes for U.S.
description: The United States national soccer team continues its pursuit of a spot in the 1990 World Cup on Sunday against El Salvador.

title: Sara Fowler Is a Bride
description: Sara Fowler, an associate editor of Mad Magazine in New York, and Brian Friedman, an editor on the foreign desk of The Associated Press in New York, were married on Sept. 9 at the Garrettson Memorial United Methodist Church in Rhinebeck, N.Y. The Rev. Gregory Friedman, a Roman Catholic priest and a brother of the bridegroom, officiated; he was assisted by the Rev. Bruce Stollings, a Methodist minister. The bride, 31 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fowler of Memphis, Tex. She graduated from Southern Methodist University. The bridegroom, 33, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Friedman of Cincinnati. He graduated from Ohio University.

title: Short Shrift For U.S. Open
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: HOW PIZZA CAME TO QUEENS Written and illustrated by Dayal Kaur Khalsa. Unpaged. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $13.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Disposal of Toxic Ash Posing Problems
description: LEAD: IN the drive to build incinerators as an alternative to garbage dumping, Long Island officials are wrestling with the problem of what to do with the tons of toxic ash left after burning.

title: Rose Linked to a 2d Wager Scheme
description: Pete Rose, whose denial of owning a winning race-track ticket was disputed by witnesses and the defendant at the recent trial of Thomas Gioiosa in Cincinnati, has been linked to another winning Pik Six ticket that he allegedly had someone else cash for him.

title: On the Plan to Revise Special Education
description: I would like to offer my reactions on the Plan to Revise Special Education as a principal of a pilot high school. The Bergen County Vocational-Technical Schools district was one of 10 districts selected to pilot new special-education initiatives. Of the 650 students in the high school, probably 20 to 25 percent have a classification in the perceptually impaired and neurologically impaired range.

title: WHAT IF...?
description: The FANTASY IS AS OLD AS ''CINDERELLA'' and as new as ''Working Girl.'' A little makeup, a new hairstyle, some expensive clothes and a good pair of shoes magically transform a woman from scullery maid/secretary into princess/executive.

title:
FILM;
Blier Puts a Fresh Wrinkle in the Old Triangle
description: LEAD: It was a dare the French film director Bertrand Blier simply couldn't resist. After years of making raw and audacious black comedies dominated by men, Mr. Blier decided to make a film that would wade straight out into the roiling waters of the New-Age woman. In matters of love, his film would ask, just what do these women really want anyway?

title: Home Sellers Trimming Brokers' Fees
description: MICHELLE KANE is looking for a house with more room for her private psychotherapy practice, so her current home, a dramatic four-bedroom contemporary in Great Neck, L.I., is up for sale.

title: Sri Lanka Offers Rebel Front A Secure Role in Peace Talks
description: After the island's worst week of violence in months, the Government today offered Sinhalese rebels security and protection if they joined a peace conference. The rebel group, the People's Liberation Front, has usually spurned such invitations.

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $112,000, or 2 cents a share. c-After a loss of $157,000 for the quarter and income of $2,298,000, or 47 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The income from discontinued operations in the year-ago 9 months included a loss of $152,000 from the discontinued operations, which partially offset a $2,450,000 gain on the operations' disposal.

description: The Bush plan for dealing with drugs is good and should be tried.

title: Success Has No Kick for Champagne
description: It should be time for the Champagne industry to break out the bubbly, as grape growers cheer a vintage harvest and worldwide sales soar to record levels. Instead, the industry's unprecedented success is threatening to tear apart the closely knit Champagne region, an area of gentle slopes and generous vines 90 miles east of Paris.

description: The Smithsonian Institution's decision to return the skeletal remains of American Indians when it is requested by tribal descendants is seen by many museum directors and anthropologists as the turning point in a decade-old struggle between Indians and scientists.

description: Gordon F. Wolf, a top merger and acquisition executive, has left Citicorp to join the Golodetz Group, a privately held New York commodity trading firm that is expanding its leveraged buyout business.

Doctors said that the 79-year-old Roman Catholic nun had contracted a malaria parasite but that the parasite was not the cause of a recurring fever. A statement from the Woodlands Nursing Home, where she is recovering from a heart attack, said her condition did not change during the day.

description: Felicia Robin Miller, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Amos W. Miller of Lido Beach, L.I., and Dr. Benjamin Judah Leeman, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Albert J. Leeman of Riverdale, the Bronx, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Sholom in Long Beach, L.I. The bride's father and the bridegroom's father jointly performed the ceremony. Rabbi Miller is the spiritual leader of the congregation. The bride, 28 years old, is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and Boston University School of Law. She is a lawyer with the Department of Buildings of the City of New York. Her father is a former president of the Rabbinical Assembly of Nassau and Suffolk Counties of New York. Her mother, Hannah B. Miller, is a social studies teacher at Beach Channel High School in Rockaway Park, Queens.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Sales of United States savings bonds rose $622 million in August, pushing the value of savings bonds held by Americans past $115 billion for the first time, the Treasury Department reported Friday. The August sales were 2.5 percent higher than July's sales of $607 million and brought total purchases for the first 11 months of the 1989 fiscal year to $7.2 billion, up 7 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. Americans now hold $115.04 billion in savings bonds, the Treasury said.

Now, ESPN's 24-hour, year-round fare on cable television includes the National Football League and the N.C.A.A. basketball playoffs and will add Major League baseball starting next year.

title: Vaughn Communications reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Steel Imports Off in July
description: Steel imports fell 5.9 percent, to 1.46 million tons, in July from the previous month and represented 19.3 percent of the domestic supply, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported Friday. Steel imports for the first seven months of 1989 were 10.2 million tons, down 19.7 percent from the corresponding period last year. Imports represented 17.5 percent of domestic supply through July, the trade group reported. The percentage is below the Bush Administration's Voluntary Restraint Agreements target of 18.5 percent of imported steel in the domestic market.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Destiny in Lebanon
description: A vital but forgotten bit of history helps make sense out of the tragic chaos in Lebanon. The key year was 1920, when Lebanon's Maronite Christian community prevailed on France to draw boundaries that doubled the size of the Ottoman province of Gran Liban. This meant that predominantly Muslim areas, including the Bekaa Valley, were incorporated into what became the Republic of Lebanon, with a Western-style Constitution, in 1926.

title: Softech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
Maybe Not the Best, But Still Winners
description: Senor Pete and Dance Colony are probably not the best 2-year-old colt and filly in New York this year, but both proved to be clearly better than the fields they faced yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: One-Year Treasuries to Be Sold This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues for this week is confined to today's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills and Thursday's auction of a new one-year issue.

title: Review/Television; Mort Sahl, Daring From the Hungry I Until Today
description: ''Mort Sahl: The Loyal Opposition'' is the sort of show that Mort Sahl, the irreverent comedian, might have kidded on a good night. This earnest 90-minute contribution to the ''American Masters'' series, at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, takes Mr. Sahl at his own estimate, but without his redeeming humor.

title: Karen Strauss Weds Stephen Filler
description: Karen Randy Strauss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Strauss of North Woodmere, L.I., and Highland Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Stephen Charles Filler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Filler of Toronto. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere.

title: Very Big Spill, Too Little Will
description: Six months after one of its tankers piled into a reef and fouled an Alaskan bay with 11 million gallons of oil, Exxon has declared victory and is heading home. The company says it has already spent a billion dollars to clean the waters and shorelines of Alaska's Prince William Sound and, with bad weather looming, can do no more until spring. The state of Alaska says the job is far from finished, that Exxon is cynically counting on America to forget and that it won't return at all.

title: Beauticontrol Cosmetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
2 Die as Casino Train Runs Into Stalled Car
description: On the first day of N.J. Transit's commuter service to Atlantic City, a casino-bound train collided with a car in a suburb of Camden yesterday, killing the car's two occupants and injuring 10 people on the train.

title: New Jersey Symphony Rejects Contract
description: The musicians of the New Jersey Symphony voted Friday afternoon to reject the latest contract offered them by the orchestra's management. In a vote of 40 to 14, however, the players ratified an agreement to continue working under the terms of their old contract - which expired Friday - while the negotiations for a new one continue. No players voted to accept the contract, and it was not known whether any abstained. The orchestra's membership is 73, but several players were on leave of absence.

title: Question Box
description: Always on Base Q. Did any major leaguer ever have a season with at least 400 times at bat in which he reached base more than half the times he batted? A. You can count on one hand the number of players who have done it since 1900. On the other hand, only two players really matter - Babe Ruth and Ted Williams - because they dominated this particular aspect of batting, doing it seven of the nine times it was accomplished. In 1941, when he batted .406, Williams, baseball's last .400 hitter, put together a .551 on-base average, the best ever. It was so good that for the season, he finished 99 percentage points ahead of the American League's second-best performer in on-base average, Roy Cullenbine of the St. Louis Browns. Williams had 185 hits that season, including 33 doubles and 37 home runs, and walked 145 times. The Boston Red Sox outfielder also has the fourth-best on-base percentage in baseball history, .516, in 1954, and he didn't do badly in 1942 or 1947 either, when he barely failed to reach base half the time with .499 percentages.

title: Yeltsin Leaves for Moscow
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the Soviet politician, left the United States for Moscow today, moments after placing an order for $100,000 worth of disposable hypodermic needles to help the fight against AIDS in the Soviet Union. Earlier today, before winding up an eight-day tour of the country, Mr. Yeltsin told guests at his last official function here that his nation would one day be as democratic as the United States.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Review/Music; American Music of Protest, Politics and Persuasion
description: The Voices of Change series presented by the Hebrew Arts School at its Merkin Concert Hall offers an invigorating panoply of music, even if one might argue that its subtitle -American Music of Protest, Politics and Persuasion - is rather broad.

title: A.& S. a Hit, but Can It Keep the Shelves Full?
description: Shoppers thronged to the new Abraham & Straus department store in Manhattan over the weekend, and cash registers rang up sales of $1 million a day. But questions remained about the store's ability to maintain its inventory in the wake of a cash crisis at its Canadian parent company, the Campeau Corporation.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Paul Harvey Named Personality of Year
description: WLS-AM in Chicago was named ''Legendary Station'' and the ABC news commentator Paul Harvey won the personality-of-the-year award in the first Marconi Radio Awards.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about college admission test scores misidentified John Weiss, co-author of ''Standing Up to the SAT.'' He is the founder and a former executive director of Fairtest, a consumer-testing advocacy group. The executive director is Cinthia Schuman.

title: Literary Fare for Book-Hungry Throngs
description: Literature was the order of the day as readers, writers and publishers swarmed onto Fifth Avenue in midtown yesterday for the 11th annual New York Is Book Country festival. While 164 booksellers, publishers and other purveyors of the printed word enticed people with books, games, entertainment and literary celebrities, 11 noted writers discussed the ins and outs of authorship at several nearby gatherings.

title: Police Shoot Robbery Suspect
description: A police officer shot a robbery suspect in the arm last night in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, the police said. Two armed men were holding up the Pioneer Supermarket at 602 West 185th Street, and one pointed a gun at officers who had been called, a police spokesman said. The wounded man, who was not identified, was taken to the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The other suspect fled.

title: Dataphaz Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Science and Math Teaching Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Harald Thelander, Translator, 80
description: Harald Thelander, a former translator at the United Nations, died of cancer yesterday at Christ Hospital in Jersey City. He was 80 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: Driver Is Killed
description: Don Pratt was killed today when his modified stock car crashed into a wall at Pocono International Raceway in the 39th annual Nascar Race of Champions, race officials said.

title: Ukraine Catholics Hold Huge Mass to Press Soviets
description: Tens of thousands of Ukrainian Catholics joined today in their church's biggest service since World War II to demand that the Kremlin restore the church's legal status and end decades of repression.

title: Intolerance Will Be Topic For Students
description: Andrea Ambris, a 13-year-old student at Intermediate School 166 in the East New York section of Brooklyn, was worried about David N. Dinkins's safety.

title: New Bank to Emphasize Aid to Small Borrowers
description: When Lyndon B. Comstock was trying to raise money in the 1970's for a low- and middle-income housing cooperative in Berkeley, Calif., he was so disheartened by bankers' refusal to lend money that he resolved to start his own bank.

title: Hurricane Pummels Resort Islands of Caribbean
description: A hurricane with winds of up to 150 miles per hour churned over the small islands of the eastern Caribbean today, leaving at least nine people dead and thousands homeless, then roared into the Virgin Islands.

title: Hudson Spill Cleanup Could Take Two Weeks
description: It could take weeks to mop up a dense oil spill that closed the Hudson River for 11 hours Saturday, officials said.

title: In Women's Biathlon, Participation Is No. 1
description: THE Ultratech Orlon Women's Biathlon in Central Park on Saturday was for women only, but the race's homogeneity ended there. The run-bike-run event drew athletes of all ages, from 18 to over 60, and seemingly every level of intensity, ability and aspiration. The winner, Claudia Kretschman, was highly trained in the two-sport discipline, but an estimated one-third of the 210 participants were combining running and biking in competition for the first time.

title: International Barrier Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

description: Meridian Bancorp Inc. said it would raise its estimated $704 million bid for the First Pennsylvania Corporation to surpass an offer made by the Corestates Financial Corporation.

description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, the largest television production company in the world, has always been a minor merchant in the largest television market in the world, the United States.

title: Tremor in Southern Mexico
description: A tremor shook southern Mexico on Saturday, but no damage or injuries were reported, the National Seismological Service said. A tremor registering 5.2 on the Richter scale, a quake capable of considerable damage, occurred at 5:21 P.M. in the southern state of Oaxaca. It lasted 15 seconds and was felt in Mexico City, 310 miles away.

title: Mets Again Fail To Gain Ground
description: The Mets headed for Chicago tonight and they were straggling not swaggering, beaten not bold. And they were second, not first, and still five and a half games behind the Cubs with only 14 left to play.

description: * Aventek Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., an industrial products manufacturer, said Gary G. Harmon was resigning as chief financial officer and secretary to pursue other business opportunities.

description: A Federal judge refused Friday to dismiss a lawsuit seeking to prohibit the Government from destroying material generated on National Security Council computers in the Reagan Administration.

Schmitt of Novato, Calif., were married yesterday at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y. Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

description: The body of a Bensonhurst high school teacher who disappeared 12 days ago was found Saturday in a car in Uniondale, L.I.

description: Jim Wright, former Speaker of the House, was greeted as a beloved elder by about 3,000 Democrats who ate barbecue and danced the two-step last weekend at a fund-raising party on a ranch outside Austin.

description: After receding for much of the summer, worries about inflation could well re-emerge this fall, credit market analysts said.

description: Last week's primary election ended the first practical test of New York City's new public campaign financing system. The campaign exposed a number of flaws, but the system worked remarkably well to curb the influence of wealthy favor-seekers. The experience offers several live lessons for the country.

description: SUMMER does not officially end until later this week, but book publishers are already well into their most important season - fall.

description: Dan Marino, who had struggled against New England for most of his career, threw three first-half touchdown passes, and the Miami Dolphins capitalized on botched punt plays on the Patriots' first two possessions for a 24-10 victory today.

description: Virginia's two candidates for Governor, separated by only a few percentage points in public opinion polls, have turned to bruising attacks on one another as the campaign passes the halfway mark.

description: ''The trauma is that there is no prospect for hope. I stopped believing in miracles.'' -Saba Saba, who fled Beirut for Cyprus. [ A13:1. ]

HRE said this quarter's results included a final settlement with the State of Florida for the taking of a small parcel of land at the trust's shopping center in Clearwater, adding $1.2 million, or 20 cents a share, to net income. The trust also said net income was adversely affected this year by continuing legal and other costs related to Kimco's previously reported $27- a-share acquisition proposal, which lowered this quarter's earnings by almost 5 cents a share.

description: Government corruption was not invented in the state of West Virginia.

title: GATT Sees Trade Gains
description: The volume of world merchandise trade is expected to increase by about 7 percent in 1989, and growth will probably remain strong in the next few years, the international trade body GATT said Friday.

title: For Yale's Offense, The Wishbone Fits
description: In Ivy League football, a coach fits his system to whatever material comes through the admissions office, and Carm Cozza has fit the wishbone to the Yale team this year.

title: DENG IS REPORTED TO NAME HIS HEIR, THE PARTY CHIEF
description: Deng Xiaoping has proposed that the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, be his heir as China's paramount leader, according to a confidential report of two ''informal talks'' between Mr. Deng and other senior officials.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf McCallister Wins: Blaine McCallister broke out of a six-way tie with birdies on the last two holes yesterday for a one-stroke victory over Brad Faxon in the Bank of Boston Classic. He shot a five-under-par 66 for a 72-hole total of 271 at the Pleasant Valley Country Club in Sutton, Mass. (AP) Rodriguez Triumphs: Chi Chi Rodriguez rallied from a 14th-hole bogey with a birdie on 16 on the way to a four-under-par 68 and one-stroke victory yesterday over Jim Dent and Dick Rhyan in the Crestar PGA Seniors Classic. Rodriguez shot 203 on the 6,644-yard Hermitage Country Club course in Richmond. (AP) Daniel Nears $2 Million: Beth Daniel shot a final-round 70 yesterday to win the $300,000 Safeco Classic at Kent, Wash., by six strokes, her second straight L.P.G.A. victory and third in four outings. She is now $32,000 shy of the $2 million mark. Daniel finished 72 holes over the 6,222-yard Meridian Valley Country Club course in 273, 15 under par and well ahead of Cindy Rarick's second-place 279.(AP) Auto Racing Earnhardt Is First: Dale Earnhardt outdueled Mark Martin over the final 34 laps to win the Peak Performance 500 at Dover Downs International Speedway yesterday in Delaware. Martin, who still is trying to win his first Nascar Winston Cup race, kept the pressure on Earnhardt, the series point leader, all the way to the end, finishing just one-tenth of a second behind after the two bumped twice during the final 20-lap sprint to the checkered flag. Earnhardt averaged 122.942 m.p.h. in a race slowed by five caution flags. (AP) Hockey Moscow Dynamo Trounces Capitals: Aleksandr Semak scored a pair of goals as Moscow Dynamo defeated the Washington Capitals, 7-2, yesterday to become the first Soviet team to defeat a National Hockey League club in the Soviet Union. Dino Ciccarelli scored both Washington goals, but the Capitals were outskated and outplayed throughout the contest. (AP) Horse Show Patton Rides Winner: Beezie Patton of Casanovia, N.Y., rode Northern Magic over two faultless rounds and gained a victory in the $75,000 Cadillac American Gold Cup for horse show jumpers at the Devon, Pa., show grounds yesterday. Patton cleared nine obstacles in 37.86 seconds to gain the victory over Daydream, ridden by Margie Goldstein of Miami. Tennis Jaite Takes Final: Martin Jaite of Argentina won the Madrid Grand Prix tournament yesterday by defeating Jordi Arrese of Spain, 6-3, 6-2. It was Jaite's second Grand Prix title this year. (AP) Rinaldi Tops Shriver: Kathy Rinaldi broke Pam Shriver's serve eight times to win the All-American championships, 7-5, 7-5, at Amelia Island Plantation on Captiva Island, Fla., yesterday. (AP)

title: Barfield Near Contract as Season Wanes
description: The sun did not break through until the ninth inning, but by then it was already too late. Jesse Barfield had swung and missed at a third strike, then returned to the dugout and quietly watched the final moments of another meaningless game at the Stadium.

title: American League; Blue Jays Win, 2-1, On Hit by McGriff
description: Fred McGriff took advantage of an open left field, lofting a run-scoring single in the 10th inning as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Cleveland Indians, 2-1, today for a three-game sweep.

title: Moscow Journal; Where to Put Lenin, Not to Mention His Pedestal
description: For decades, Lenin's mysterious power in stone and bronze has gripped this nation -his sculpted glare beaming condor-like from every hamlet pedestal, his granite hand held in visionary gesture even as Communism's future clouded over.

title: Ms. Benou Weds Real-Estate Broker
description: Denise Rachele Benou, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Benou of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Todd Abram Stires, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Stires of Somerville and Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Timothy Mulder performed the ceremony at the Bedminster (N.J.) Reformed Church.

title:
THE RYDER CUP;
High Stakes in Golf: A Trophy and Pride
description: LEAD: THERE are many theories on exactly when the decline of American professional golf began. Some people think it was the day corporate sponsors made every pro a millionaire just for showing up. Others point to the time Arnold Palmer started wearing contact lenses and a hearing aid. But historians generally agree it occurred in the fall of 1985 somewhere in England on the last green of a four-ball match.

title: Opening Up at the Royal National
description: On Sept. 1, 1988, the day Richard Eyre took over as the artistic director of the Royal National Theater, he said that in his nightmares he thought of the National as ''the Chateau d'If on the South Bank'' of the Thames. The reference, of course, was to ''The Count of Monte Cristo,'' in which the count was imprisoned and tortured in the If dungeon.

title: Youth Is Shot to Death At L.I. Birthday Party
description: A 16-year-old high school student was fatally shot Saturday night by a retired New York City corrections officer when the youth refused to leave a birthday party here for the man's 13-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That was down from 10.17 percent last week. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders asked an average initial rate of 8.68 percent this week, down from 8.71 percent, Freddie Mac said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 17 about Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company referred incompletely to the firm's own investment in RJR Nabisco Inc. In addition to its $56 million share in the Kohlberg, Kravis investment pool that won control of RJR, Kohlberg, Kravis has invested $80 million in RJR directly. Its total investment therefore exceeds the $75 million fee that Kohlberg, Kravis earned in the takeover.

title: Brooklyn Catholics to Get a New Bishop
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, liberal and independent under the leadership of Bishop Francis J. Mugavero for the last 21 years, will soon be getting a new - and probably more conservative - bishop. Pope John Paul II is expected to name a replacement for the retiring Bishop Mugavero before the end of the year.

title: Win Ugly, Live Ugly
description: In sports, they call it ''winning ugly,'' a celebration of the sneak punch, the bent rule, the shredded spirit of the game that makes losers of us all. It's no different, only more dangerous, in the real game. In politics this season in New York City, nobody will win unless two basically decent men can control their teams' impulse to believe the prize more important than the struggle.
