description: Three New Jersey communities have taken steps to broaden communications between their police departments and their black and Hispanic residents after being rocked by racial violence and protests that came after fatal confrontations between the police and minority residents in the last 15 months.

title: Third World Shifts Focus of Chemical-Arms Talks
description: More than 60 nations will gather in Australia on Monday to discuss the problem of chemical weapons. But the conference is already headed in a different direction from that originally planned by the Bush Administration.

title: Diversified Foods reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Homeless at Melodrama Add a Dickensian Touch
description: When she bought her permit to stage a play in the 79th Street boat basin, Leslie Sara Carroll was assured by the Parks Department that the homeless who have been living there would be removed before she rang up whatever passed for a curtain - the stage being in the middle of a dry fountain.

title: U.S. Enters Fairchild Suit
description: The Justice Department has joined a lawsuit that contends Fairchild Industries defrauded the military by selling faulty jet equipment to the Air Force.

title: Lord Trafford, 57, Britain's Health Minister
description: Lord Trafford, Minister of State for Health, died on Saturday of lung cancer, the Government announced. He was 57 years old.

title: Teen-Age Childbearing Must Be Reduced
description: To the Editor:

title: Flexwatt Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ph.D. Is the Intellectual's Moment of Truth; No More Dissertations
description: To the Editor:

title: Xeta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's results included $802,000 gain from sale of Hobic-Plus Inc., a subsidiary.

title: Campeau Loan Pact Called Final
description: With many suppliers delaying, reducing or canceling shipments of merchandise to stores operated by its Federated and Allied groups, the Campeau Corporation has reportedly reached a final agreement with its lenders on a $250 million loan.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting today, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, is increased to 40 cents. The change is prompted by rising production and distribution costs. The newspaper's Sunday price is unchanged, as is its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

title: Political Memo; The Drug War Becomes a Budget War
description: President Bush's drug policy has become the latest battlefield in the budget wars between Congressional Democrats and the Administration, exposing the frustrations, suspicions and outright hostilities that now surround the Federal budget.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Inflation
description: LEAD: The National Basketball Association salary cap has zoomed to $9,802,000 this season, and now even a bench player can earn more than $2 million a year. Jon Koncak proved that recently.

title: Campaign Matters; Victory Recipe: Labor, Resolve And a Rainbow
description: Are New Yorkers better off now than when Edward I. Koch was first elected Mayor?

title: Campeau Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a pretax gain of $24 million on the sale of assets. c-After an after-tax gain of $84 million on the sale of assets. d-After a pretax gain of $99 million on the sale of assets. e-Net income and included an after- tax gain of $318 million on the sale of assets. Increased revenue and operating profits for the latest periods principally reflected Campeau's May 1988 acquisition of Federated Department Stores Inc. All figures are in U.S. currency.

title: Review/Television; 'The Famous Teddy Z,'' Mailroom to Press Agent
description: Having just spent time drifting in military service and resisting his Greek grandmother's entreaties to work in the family bakery, 23-year-old Teddy Zakalokis takes a job in the mailroom of Hollywood's Unlimited Talent Agency. Scrawny, earnest, boyish Teddy, a sort of Henry Aldrich for our times, is not terribly ambitious, but within days, he finds himself being made a press agent at a salary of $50,000. He is well on his way to becoming ''The Famous Teddy Z,'' which turns out to be the best of the new season's pilots.

title: RCM Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Proper English, Yes; But Educationists, No
description: LEAD: I grew up in a small farm town in Germany where all of us spoke an ungrammatical version of Plattdeutsch (low German). In our two-room schoolhouse, we were taught, with the discipline of a stick, to speak and write Hochdeutsch (or high German) - the German version of the ''Queen's English.''

title: For Sellers, Magazines Generate Big Profits
description: The giants who strode through the communications industry in the 1980's, buying every type of publication conceivable, created empires worth billions of dollars. In the process they sprinkled fortune through much of the kingdom, making many former subjects wealthy and often eager to re-enter the game with new publications.

title: Foreign Car Dealers' PAC Is Given a Clean Bill
description: The Justice Department has notified a political action committee representing American dealers of foreign cars that it has found no evidence that the group is a foreign agent.

title: Peru Oil Deal With Mobil
description: Peru's Government and the Mobil Oil Corporation signed a contract Friday to open for oil exploration much of Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, a region largely under control of leftist rebels and a focus of President Bush's anti-drug strategy.

title: Review/Theater; On the Parallel Pitfalls of Politics and Religion
description: If there are still any innocents who fantasize that movie actors make up their own dialogue, they will quickly be disabused of the notion at ''Carnage, a Comedy,'' the new play at the Public Theater. The co-author (with Adam Simon) and director of ''Carnage'' is the gifted actor Tim Robbins, who was in every way the winning pitcher in the jazzily written baseball movie ''Bull Durham.'' But the author of ''Bull Durham'' was Ron Shelton. Mr. Robbins's performance as a writer for the theater, let alone as a director, is far less persuasive. There may have been a more amateurish work than ''Carnage'' on a professional stage in New York this year, but somehow the gods spared me from seeing it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Graf Campaign For Swissair
description: A new advertising campaign for Swissair depicts neither Switzerland nor airplanes - all part of a strategy to emphasize that the airline flies to European destinations other than Zurich and Geneva.

title: Canadian Inquiry May Be a First Step
description: A Federal commission's exhaustive investigation into the seamy underside of international sports has given outsiders their first look into a world they had only known through rumor, gossip, innuendo and speculation.

title: Audio-Video Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $343,000, or 4 cents a share, due to an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Sandata Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
Smoothing the Sailing for the Disabled
description: LEARNING to sail a boat, and ultimately, racing one, is no longer just a fantasy for disabled people. A boat designed to accommodate almost any physical handicap has helped hundreds of aspiring sailors become yachtsmen.

title: Vocally, Poles Commemorate the Soviet Invasion
description: In religious observances, private visits to cemeteries and in official newspapers, Poland today marked the 50th anniversary of the day when Soviet troops seized eastern sections of Poland, two weeks after the Nazis had invaded from the west to begin World War II.

title: Ismail Stymies Michigan Drive
description: The defensive linemen and the linebackers in the Notre Dame defense, two questionable areas after the loss of three starters before the start of the season, were in the process of holding Michigan to its lowest total of rushing yardage since the 1987 Rose Bowl.

title: First Family Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ambrit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $299,000 from discontinued operations. The latest 6 months' earnings equaled less than 1 cent a share.

title: Thibaudeau Shines As Islanders Win
description: In defeating the Rangers, 5-2, in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum tonight, the Islanders got an impressive performance from a free agent with remarkable offensive attributes.

title: Ellen Lebetkin Wed to Michael Jahn
description: Ellen Lebetkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Lebetkin of Bay Terrace, Queens, and Michael Jahn, the son of Mrs. Joseph C. Jahn of Sayville, L.I., and the late Mr. Jahn, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Raymond Singer performed the ceremony.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Anti-Fashion Statement For Fashions
description: LIKE a roundhouse punch, the word ''Everlast'' has charged out of magazines of late, its enormous black letters as distinct from the elegant photographs of designer suits as Mike Tyson is from Tom Wolfe. With it, a company known better inside gyms than to the outside world served graphic notice on American men that it wants their business.

title: Cascade Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Amre Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After income of $203,000, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $155,000.

title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long
description: One month after the murder of a presidential candidate here unleashed Colombia's attack on cocaine cartels, President Virgilio Barco Vargas appears to be preparing for a long war against the major drug traffickers.

title: Oil Cleanup Brings Sad Prosperity to Village
description: Instead of hanging salmon to dry this month, as Aleut natives have done for centuries here on the toe of the Kenai Peninsula, John Kvasnikoff was putting up a $3,000 television satellite dish on the bluff next to his home above the sea.

title: Elizabeth Huber Weds
description: Elizabeth Alton Huber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clark Huber of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Jason Lee Port, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Port of Whitestone, Queens. Walter Lawton, leader emeritus of the Westchester Ethical Culture Society in White Plains, performed the ceremony at the Siwanoy Country Club in Bronxville. Mrs. Port is an assistant vice president at Sotheby's in New York. Dr. Port is a resident in radiology at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Cut Is Urged In Oil Award
description: A retired Federal judge has decreased the amount of damages recommended for French oyster growers who lost shellfish in the 1978 oil spill from the supertanker Amoco Cadiz, lawyers said last week.

title: Clabir Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss of $299,000 from discontinued operations. The net income in year-ago 6 months was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Books of The Times; A Portrait of Jerusalem, in Its Many Excesses
description: Jerusalem City of Mirrors By Amos Elon With maps. 286 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: Drug Witness Resurfaces in Spokane and in Trouble
description: A man whose battle with crack dealers on his Queens street made him a hero to some and led to the fatal shooting of Police Officer Edward Byrne, has blown his cover in the Federal Witness Protection Program after a dispute with the police in his new home, Spokane, Wash., the authorities said yesterday.

title: Witness Names Youth's Shooter In Bensonhurst
description: A defendant in the Bensonhurst slaying told the police that he heard a gunshot and saw another defendant, Joseph Fama, pointing a gun at a young black man and ''saw him shoot the gun three more times,'' according to the statement he gave detectives after the killing.

title: After the Hudson Spill: Bathing Fowl and Rocks
description: Cleanup of an oil spill in the Hudson River continued on two fronts today, as crews scoured the river's rocky shoreline and wildlife biologists at a nearby laboratory scrubbed oil from sick waterfowl.

title: Biogen Gets Funds For Protein Drug
description: Biogen Inc. said the New York Life Insurance Company would provide $20 million to expand the company's development of CD-4, a protein that may provide a potential treatment for AIDS. CD-4 is a protein found on the outer member of immune system cells attacked by the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The bioengineered protein acts as a decoy, attracting viruses and halting their invasion of the cells.

title: Public Service Enterprise reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
Bridge
description: A strong surge at the start of the Bermuda Bowl contest here today gave the United States a big lead against Australia. The margin after 16 deals was 74 international match points, but the host country fought back and cut the deficit to 54 imps at the end of the day.

title: Sceptre Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mets' Pennant Hopes Go From Faint to Worse
description: Whatever it was, the Chicago Cubs delivered it tonight: the haymaker, the knockout punch, the coup de grace. And they destroyed the Mets in what was left of their battle for first place.

title: Diodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Macmillan Deal With Merrill
description: Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Merrill Publishing for $260 million in cash. Merrill, based in Columbus, Ohio, publishes textbooks for the secondary, high school and college markets.

title: Torotel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago quarter results restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 96.

title: Addenda
description: * Playboy Enterprises has sold Boarts International Inc., a distributor of periodicals and paperback books, to Worldwide Media Service Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Dr. Lisa I. Aaron Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Lisa Iris Aaron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Aaron of New York, and Dr. Daniel Jaime Pilowsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Beny Pilowsky of Santiago, Chile, were married on Sunday at Alder Manor on the grounds of Elizabeth Seton College in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony. The bride, 34 years old, will retain her name. She is a resident in psychiatry at the New York University Medical Center. Her father is the chairman of the Sherry-Lehmann wine and spirits company in New York.

title: 7% Christies Stake Sold
description: Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian investor, has sold his 7 percent interest in Christies International P.L.C., the auction house, for a profit of more than $:10 million (about $15.7 million).

title: INSIDE
description: The Corcoran to Apologize The Corcoran Gallery of Art, after three months of protests and criticism, said it would apologize for canceling the Robert Mapplethorphe exhibition in June. Page C16. An About-Face in Drug War Redefining the Pentagon's role, Defense Secretary Cheney gave the military three weeks to find new ways to stop the drug flow. Page A19. Indian-Sri Lankan Accord In an accord that could end its costly involvement in Sri Lanka, India agreed to withdraw its 43,000 troops by December. Page A3. Dashed Hopes in Bulgaria Thousands of Muslims feel stranded in Bulgaria because Turkey closed its border, shutting off a mass migration they hoped to join. Page A12.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
A Diploma, a Tie and a Lie
description: LEAD: It was during a recent job interview that I discovered the relationship between the wearing of a necktie and the telling of lies.

title: Mexico Set To Sell Its Phone Unit
description: Mexican Government officials said today that the state intended to put its majority stake in Telefonos de Mexico, the country's troubled, unpopular and inefficient telecommunications monopoly, up for sale in the next few days.

title: Deferment for Divac
description: Vlade Divac, the center from Yugoslavia who was signed by the Los Angeles Lakers last month and is currently working out at the Lakers' training camp, was granted a one-year deferment from his military obligation to his native country yesterday. Tanjug, the Yugoslav news agency, said that Divac, who had been scheduled to begin his military service yesterday, may also be granted another year's deferment.(AP)

title: U.S. Agency Accused Of Favoring I.B.M.
description: Six computer companies accused a Federal agency yesterday of awarding more than $1 billion in data processing contracts to the International Business Machines Corporation without competition, saying that the practice may have cost the Government millions of dollars in excess procurement costs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WEIGHT LIFTING Record Lift: The lightweight lifter Israil Militosian of the Soviet Union set a world record of 352 pounds yesterday in the 148 1/2-pound division snatch competition at the world championships in Athens. The 21-year-old broke his own mark of 349 pounds on his second lift. Militosian failed in a bid to lift 357 1/2 pounds.(AP) TENNIS Tulasne Is Beaten: Thierry Tulasne of France, winner of the Count of Godo tournament in 1985, was ousted yesterday in the opening round of the tournament in Barcelona, Spain, by Agustin Moreno of Mexico, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4. Ivan Lendl, seeded No. 1, and the other top-seeded players begin play tomorrow.(AP) HOCKEY Calgary Edges Soviet Team: Doug Gilmour scored in overtime to give the Stanley Cup champion Calgary Flames a 3-2 victory over the Soviet Wings yesterday in an exhibition match in Moscow. After a scoreless first period, Yevgeny Shtepa of the Wings scored in the second period, but the Flames took a 2-1 lead before the period ended. The Wings tied the score at 2-2 in the third period, forcing the overtime.(AP)

title: John McShain, 90, Constructor Of Pentagon and Kennedy Center
description: John McShain, a contractor and developer who erected several important public buildings in Washington, including the Pentagon, the State Department Building and the Jefferson Memorial, died of a stroke on Sept. 9 in Killarney, Ireland. He was 90 years old.

title: Gooden Start Scratched
description: Dwight Gooden was scratched tonight as the probable starting pitcher for the Mets Tuesday against the first-place Chicago Cubs because of stiffness in his right shoulder. But both Gooden and Davey Johnson, manager of the Mets, said the stiffness was normal and not related to the torn muscle that disabled the 24-year-old ace for 10 weeks this summer.

title: Penril Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Latest quarter results included a loss of $240,000 from non-operating items, compared with $300,000 for year-ago period. Latest 12 months results included profit from non-operating items of $328,000 versus a loss from non-operating items of $39,000 for prior year. Non-operating items included early retirement of debt and discontinued operations.

title: Passport Travel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Judge to Admit Tax and Drug Charges
description: A State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, William T. Martin, will plead guilty tomorrow to Federal tax evasion and the use and possession of cocaine, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Renewed the contract of Tom Kelly, manager, through the 1991 season. BASKETBALL SEATTLE (NBA) - Signed Dana Barros, guard, to a four-year contract plus an option year. COLLEGES JACKSONVILLE - Named Gary Izzo athletic director. MANHATTAN - Named Tony Sterra men's assistant tennis coach. MERCY, N.Y. - Named Mike Young men's head basketball coach. TRENTON STATE - Named Joe Russo women's head soccer coach. FOOTBALL DALLAS (NFC) - Signed Ray Alexander, wide receiver, and Kevin Lilly, defensive lineman. Placed Cornell Burbage, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Released John Duff, tight end, off injured reserve and released Sean Smith, defensive tackle. SOCCER BALTIMORE (MISL) - Announced that the team had been purchased by Edwin Hale. Named Stan White general manager. CLEVELAND (MISL) - Signed Joe Koziol, midfielder.

title: Anti-Sandinista Candidate Seeks Aid Among Exiles in Miami
description: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the presidential candidate of the Nicaraguan opposition, has visited Miami for two days to explain her electoral strategy, seek financial support and try to unite Miami's large Nicaraguan exile population behind her candidacy.

title: Qantel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,217,000, or 13 cents a share, on the redemption of debentures.

title: Mood to Alter Medicare Sets Off Budget Alarm
description: Convinced that repeal of the Medicare program to cover the catastrophic cost of extended illness is more and more likely, Administration officials are said to be searching for ways to minimize the impact of a repeal on the budget for the next fiscal year.

title: Dallas Paper Is Rebuffed
description: A state judge in Texas has refused to grant The Dallas Times Herald a preliminary injunction that would prevent many of its most popular syndicated features and comic strips from switching to The Dallas Morning News, its archrival.

title: Corrections
description: A report in some editions of SportsMonday this week about the Islanders' exhibition game against the Rangers misidentified a player who had signed with the Islanders as a free agent. He is Don Maloney, not his brother Dave, who has retired.

title: Microbilt Accord Revised by Block
description: H & R Block & Company, the tax-preparation concern, said the terms of its agreement to acquire the Microbilt Corporation had been revised. The original offer was for $18 a share in Block stock.

title: Two New Exhibitions Show I.B.M. Artworks
description: Artworks from the I.B.M. collection are on display in one of two new exhibitions at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, at Madison Avenue and 56th Street. ''Fifty Years of Collecting: Art at I.B.M.'' includes more than 100 paintings, sculptures, photographs and works on paper by such artists as Childe Hassam, George Bellows, Edward Hopper, Oskar Kokoschka, Willem de Kooning, Emil Nolde and Jean Arp.

title: Hungary Restores Israeli Ties
description: Hungary became the first Communist nation to restore ties to Israel broken in 1967. It also moved closer to Washington on trade. Page A3.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Bush Administration seems almost nostalgic about the Cold War and the rigid superpower relationship that divided the world into two hostile and isolated camps.'' -Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell. [ A14:3. ]

title: Standard Microsystems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs
description: Something made Detective Pat DeGregorio do a double-take on the ride home that afternoon a year ago, an instinct, perhaps, after years of making undercover drug buys on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Organizations Helping a Relief Fund
description: Organizations involved in hurricane relief said yesterday that the greatest needs were money, nonperishable foods and building supplies.

title: Plan to Lower World Debt Criticized
description: An organization that represents most of the world's big commercial banks contended today that a new international strategy to cut global debt could misfire by shrinking the core of lenders to the third world.

title: Defense Chief Imposes a Deadline In Pentagon's War on Drug Flow
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, redefining the Pentagon's mission to make the anti-drug campaign a ''high priority,'' today gave military commanders three weeks to find new ways to stop the flow of narcotics, even if it means diverting troops from other activities.

title: Kings Road Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $365,211 on the restructuring of debt. c-Net loss

title: Mubarak and Rabin Meet in Cairo on Voting Plan
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak discussed starting peace talks in the region today in the first direct Egyptian-Israeli discussions on the Middle East stalemate.

title: Corestates and First Pennsylvania to Merge
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation and the First Pennsylvania Corporation agreed today to merge in a $730 million deal.

title: 72 Killed as Typhoon Hits Chinese Province
description: A storm has killed 72 people and left hundreds missing in Zhejiang province, Chinese national televison reported today.

title: Killearn Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Cali Cartel: Colombia's Smoother Drug Gang
description: When the Government began cracking down on drug traffickers nearly five weeks ago, the cartel in Medellin lashed back with a wave of bombings and shootings.

title: Skull of Slain Woman Found
description: The partial remains of a 26-year-old woman from Switzerland who was apparently slain after a lovers' quarrel were found yesterday in a plastic bucket in a parcel check area at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the police said. The former boyfriend of the woman, who the police said was a modern dancer, was arrested and charged in the slaying.

title: Giuliani Assails Dinkins, Citing A Goldin Audit
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday used a critical report by one Democrat, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, to question the administrative ability of another Democrat, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral nominee.

title: Polydex Pharmaceuticals Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The results are in U.S. funds.

title: Help Is Offered Across a Void of Silence
description: As a hurricane ripped across Puerto Rico and other Caribbean islands yesterday, people in the New York, Philadelphia and other mainland centers of Puerto Rican population organized relief efforts and relatives sought information they could not get.

title: Pier I Imports Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Lakeland Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Courter Strives To Revitalize His Campaign
description: Hit in the last week by a struggle over his campaign staff and doubts about his position on key issues, Representative Jim Courter, the Republican candidate for governor, moved today to regain control of his apparently flagging campaign.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the play ''Carnage, a Comedy'' referred incorrectly in some copies to the performer at the center.

title: 10 Are Killed in Beirut As Shells Hit Building
description: Ten people were killed and nine seriously hurt when an apartment block collapsed in the Muslim part of Beirut overnight after being hit by artillery fire during renewed heavy gun battles, police and hospital officials said today.

title: Judge Halts Random Drug Tests of All Police
description: A new Police Department policy making all uniformed officers subject to random drug testing that was to have gone into effect yesterday was blocked when a police union won a temporary restraining order.

title: Talking Business with Donohue of American Trucking; An Industry Plan To Curb Pollution
description: The nation's $224 billion trucking industry is emerging from a decade of rapid change that began with its deregulation in 1980. Truck companies can now change schedules and prices more easily. Although parts of the industry have consolidated under deregulation, new companies have entered other sectors, including the transport of large shipments over long distances.

title: Harry Tugend, Film Writer and Producer, 91
description: Harry Tugend, a screenwriter and film and television producer who helped establish the Screen Writers Guild, died of heart failure on Sept. 11 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 91 years old. Mr. Tugend's long, prolific career in the entertainment industry began around 1930, when he wrote sketches for ''Ziegfeld Follies'' and Fred Allen's radio show. He went to Hollywood with Allen to make ''Thanks a Million,'' and during the subsequent three decades, his 39 film credits included ''The Road to Bali,'' ''Birth of the Blues,'' ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' and ''Pocketful of Miracles.'' In 1933, with a group of other writers, Mr. Tugend founded the Screen Writers Guild, which became the Writers Guild of America in the 1950's. Mr. Tugend was an executive with Paramount Pictures during the 1940's, but left the studio to be a freelance writer and producer. He produced many television shows during the 1950's and 1960's, including ''The Ray Milland Show'' and ''The General Electric Theater,'' and wrote a play, ''The Wayward Stork,'' which was produced on Broadway in 1966. He is survived by a son, James, of Los Angeles, and two granddaughters.

title: Backman May Move On
description: Wally Backman, the former Met second baseman who was traded last December to the Minnesota Twins, is not likely to be with that team in 1990. Backman said yesterday in Minneapolis that he plans to test the free-agent market at the end of this season with the understanding that the Twins are unlikely to bid for him.

title: A Panel Recommends 3 Finalists In Search for Schools Chancellor
description: A search committee set up to find a new schools chancellor for New York City recommended three finalists for the post yesterday: the superintendents in Miami, Fairfax County, Va., and Portland, Ore.

title: Advance Is Seen In Treating Infections
description: A new treatment could save the lives of thousands of people who would otherwise die from bacterial infections they contract in hospitals, a biotechnology company reported today.

title: PPC Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: More Rigs Drill for Gas
description: Drilling for natural gas has surpassed oil exploration in the United States for the first time. Baker Hughes Inc. reported that 486 rigs had drilled for gas last week, while 468 had drilled for oil.

title: Chess
description: The richest tournament payoff in chess history, the World Cup Cycle, came to a close on Sept. 2 in Skelleftea, Sweden, when the world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, and his countryman and perpetual challenger, Anatoly Karpov, tied for first place in the sixth and final competition of the series.

title: Picking Winners For the 80's
description: It is too early to fill out this year's Eclipse Award ballot for thoroughbred racing's divisional champions since the season's decisive races have yet to be run. But it's not too soon to fill in most of an imaginary ballot that is 10 times more interesting: Who are the Horses of the Decade, the champions among champions of the 1980's?

title: Hungary's Heart, and America's
description: Four months ago Hungary ripped a hole in the barbed wire in its section of the Iron Curtain. Now, more dramatically, it gives East Germans safe passage to the West. For that, Hungary deserves America's salute - and more. Yesterday's announcement that the Bush Administration hopes to grant Hungary new trade status is a timely step in the right direction.

title: General Mills Posts Decline
description: First-quarter earnings at General Mills Inc. were only about half the level of a year ago although operating profits rose 18 percent, the food and restaurant giant said today.

title: Sonics Sign Barros To Long-Term Pact
description: Dana Barros, the Big East Conference scoring champion for the past two seasons at Boston College, has signed a long-term contract with the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: In Defense Of Ads That Win Awards
description: NOT for Allan Beaver the awards-bashing that has become fashionable among those who believe in a distinction between creative advertising and sales.

title: Financial Adviser Is Vindicated
description: Last week's agreement on an employee-led buyout of the UAL Corporation came as vindication for Eugene J. Keilin, the Lazard Freres investment banker who has advised the company's pilots for 29 months despite criticism that a deal was impossible and his firm's fees were unnecessary.

title: Science Accessories reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring pretax gain from litigation settlement of $925,001.

title: Macy Discloses Its Earnings
description: R. H. Macy & Company told its investors yesterday in a letter that its full-year earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation totaled $925 million, an 11 percent increase from $833.6 million the year before.

title: A Tough Choice Facing Peugeot
description: A 14-day-old strike at the Peugeot automobile group is threatening to slow the momentum of the company's recent turnaround.

title: Third Big Coup For an Executive
description: The agreement on Thursday for an employee-led buyout of United Airlines is the third major coup in less than four years for its chairman and president, Stephen M. Wolf.

title: Breathalyzer Test Allowed, But Evidence Issue Looms
description: A Criminal Court judge in Manhattan rejected a defense challenge to a Breathalyzer test yesterday, but a high-ranking prosecutor said drunken-driving cases that relied on the tests would still be difficult to prosecute.

title: Judy's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and the 6 months was after a credit of $600,000 for the cumulative effect of change in accounting methods.

title: 'Crystal Wind' And Torrents Lash San Juan
description: With swirling winds and crashing rain, Hurricane Hugo virtually cut off Puerto Rico from the rest of the world today.

title: Out of Disorder, a Deal: 5 Weeks of UAL Talks
description: When the management of UAL agreed five weeks ago to listen to a proposal to participate with United Airlines' pilots in a buyout, relations between the sides were at a low. After more than a year of negotiations, there was almost no progress on a new contract, and on-the-job slowdowns by the pilots had caused many summer delays on United flights.

title: A Milestone in Laser Printers
description: THE Hewlett-Packard Company, which dominates the laser printer market for personal computers, last week unveiled a new low-cost model that could become the first laser to flirt with a price tag under $1,000. Until recently the lowest discounted prices for laser printers were at least $1,500.

title: Bertram D. Tallamy, 87, Official For U.S. and New York Highways
description: Bertram Dalley Tallamy, an engineer who supervised billions of dollars in highway construction for the Federal Government and for New York State, died of kidney failure Thursday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 87 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Value Line Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a $7.5 million non-recurring after-tax charge resulting from the purchase, with one of its subsidiaries, of Integrated Resources Inc. c-Net income

title: Reeves Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $956,000, or 8 cents a share, and $2,286,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Bid Brings Goldsmith To America
description: Sir James Goldsmith, whose $21 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries has stirred controversy in Europe and the United States, has come to America to try to persuade members of Congress and state insurance regulators that his proposal posed no threat to the company's operations here.

title: A Bizarre Nostalgia for the Cold War
description: LEAD: Why are top Bush Administration officials expressing nostalgia for the cold war period just before the Soviet Foreign, Eduard Shevardnadze, arrives in the U.S. for important talks with President Bush and Secretary of State James Baker?

title: In a Suspicious Death, an Autopsy Alone May Be of Little Help
description: WHEN a medical examiner is trying to determine the cause of a death, a witness's description of the scene and circumstances surrounding the death can be as important as an autopsy. Without carefully reconstructing events, a pathologist has great difficulty deducing from an autopsy whether any cuts, bruises, broken bones or damaged organs contributed to the death.

title: Schwartz Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cabby Fatally Shot Near Park
description: A 56-year-old taxi driver was found shot to death behind the wheel of his cab early yesterday on West 84th Street near Central Park, the fourth medallion driver to have been killed at work this year, the police said. The victim was identified as Thomas F. Dooley of 318 West 51st Street. A Taxi and Limousine Commission official said he had driven a cab for 35 years. Mr. Dooley's wallet and cash were found undisturbed, and a pouch with change was on the car floor, Officer O'Donnell said. No weapon was recovered.

title: AIDS DRUG'S MAKER CUTS PRICE BY 20%
description: The Burroughs Wellcome Company cut the price of the AIDS drug AZT by 20 percent today after a month of mounting protests over its cost.

title: Dow Rises 12.92 for Second Straight Gain
description: The Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.92 points, to 2,687.50, yesterday, adding to the small rally of Friday.

title: Argentine to Pardon Ex-Officers
description: President Carlos Saul Menem says he intends to pardon about 20 retired generals and admirals facing charges of political killings and torture and nearly 100 younger officers who took part in military rebellions.

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
Lawsuits Snarl Study of Imperiled Alaskan Eagles
description: FOR the last three months a bald eagle with a full crown of snowy hair and a wingspan of five feet has been cowering inside a cage at the Arctic Animal Hospital here, sick from a small sample of the cargo of the Exxon Valdez. Intoxicated after eating oiled prey, the eagle was unable to fly correctly and crashed to the ground, breaking its wing.

title: Circuit City Choice Seen
description: After an exhaustive search that ended in a showdown between J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam, Circuit City Stores Inc. yesterday awarded its $25 million account to Thompson's New York office, a person familiar with the account said.

title: Skyline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Airsensors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the loss in the recent quarter resulted from non-recurring expenses of combining, restructuring and centralization of its Impco Carburetion acquisition.

title: Errant Rocket Spares U.S. Embassy in Colombia
description: Terrorists struck the United States Embassy here with a homemade rocket on Sunday night. Fired from a park 10 blocks away, the rocket bounced harmlessly against a wall and fell to the ground without exploding.

title: Secrets of the Concert Hall Yield to the Laws of Physics and the Computer
description: THE design of acoustically pleasing concert halls, long considered an obscure art mastered by only a few builders, has begun to yield its secrets to computer programs capable of shaping a hall's geometry even in the midst of a concert.

title: Harold's Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $119,000, or 4 cents a share, representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Unauthorized Gun Tests Aboard Iowa Not Tied to Blast, Navy Says
description: The investigation of the explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa disclosed that a naval team had been conducting unauthorized tests of the ship's 16-inch guns.

title: Investment Firm Raises Saatchi Stake
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. has disclosed that Southeastern Asset Management Inc., the conglomerate's largest shareholder, has raised its stake to 10.2 percent from 9.4 percent.

title: Mark's Work Wearhouse reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $289,000, or 3 cents a share, and $739,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Thanks, Boris, but No
description: Americans who meet Boris Yeltsin in Moscow sometimes tell him it is a pity he is not American himself. They say he is so charming, so open and candid that he would win an election back home.

title: Hugo Cuts Off Calls to Islands
description: Long-distance communications between the United States and several Caribbean islands were severed Sunday as Hurricane Hugo swept the area.

title: Stars to Re-enact News on Chung Program
description: In the first edition of the new Saturday night CBS News program, the anchor will be Connie Chung - and the star will be James Earl Jones.

title: Senate Leader Asserts U.S. Fails To Encourage Change in East Bloc
description: George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, accused the Bush Administration today of failing to encourage changes in the Eastern bloc and feeling ''almost nostalgic about the cold war.''

title: Light Reduction Doesn't Cut Infant Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: Skylink America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said revenues for the recent quarter reflected one month of operations contributed by the Thomson Consumer Electronics and Commercial Satellite Services contracts.

title: Market Place; Oryx Energy's Overseas Gamble
description: THE Oryx Energy Company's leap into the ranks of global energy producers offers a clear example of why many American oil companies are placing more of their bets on foreign oilfields.

title: Banner Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $4,573,000 for the quarter and income of $10,921,000, or 76 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included an extraordinary loss of $8,070,000 from writeoff of financing. c-Net loss d-Included income from discontinued operations of $233,000, or 2 cents a share, and $5,353,000, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said discontinued operations included discontinued operations and businesses held for sale. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 30.

title: Get the Pentagon Out of Biological Warfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Thrift, Bowden Cleared
description: Syd Thrift and his former assistant, Jim Bowden, have been cleared of any suggestion they stole Pittsburgh Pirate records when they left for the Yankees, the baseball commissioner's office said yesterday.

title: Blue Jays' Lead Is Cut To 2 Games
description: The Boston Red Sox, unable to defeat Toronto at home since 1987, beat the first-place Blue Jays tonight, 6-3.

title: Where's the Flag Fire?
description: Americans were angry over the Supreme Court's flag-burning decision in June, but their anger has cooled. Some members of Congress learned during their August recess that the public hates flag desecration - but also recognizes that tolerating dissent, even the hateful views of scoundrels, is what America is about.

title: NEW BID TO CURB MONEY LAUNDERING
description: A senior American Treasury official said today that the best way to make banking havens with strict secrecy laws part of the fight against the laundering of drug money was through cooperation, not confrontation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the United States' current account deficit referred incorrectly to the change for the second quarter.

title: London Journal; For Asia's Children, Hard Knocks in an Alien Land
description: When the schools of London opened this month amid a national teacher shortage, the worst crisis affected the poorest areas of East London, where the faces of the students are brown and Asian. Most are from families that have immigrated from Bangladesh.

title: Salvador Rebel's Peace Offer Brings Skepticism From U.S.
description: The United States is skeptical of a Salvadoran rebel leader's offer to stop fighting if the United States halts military aid to El Salvador's Government, the State Department said today.

title: Austrian-Israeli Rift Deepens
description: Austria will downgrade diplomatic relations with Israel because the Israelis refuse to send an Ambassador to Vienna as long as Kurt Waldheim is President, the Foreign Ministry said today. A ministry spokesman said Austria's Ambassador to Israel, Otto Pleinert, had been reassigned to Stockholm. No replacement will be named, and Mr. Pleinert will be succeeded by a charge d'affaires, he said. Mr. Waldheim's war record and his concealment of it have been widely condemned.

title: Finding Fingerprints
description: A scientist working with the Secret Service has devised a method of developing fingerprints that can find them on things like adhesive tape, where they have not been found before.

title: Q&A
description: Wave Heights Q. How are wave heights measured? A. In marine weather forecasts, wave heights are estimated, rather than measured, said Dennis Sigrist, a geophysicist with the National Weather Service.

title: Olga Erteszek, 73, Dies; Founder And Designer of a Lingerie Firm
description: Olga Erteszek, designer and founder of the Olga Company, which makes women's underwear and sleepwear, died of cancer Friday at her home in Brentwood, Calif. She was 73 years old.

title: Article 700489 -- No Title
description: The proposed $250 million loan to the Campeau Corporation from Olympia & York Developments Ltd. was held up yesterday by differences with the banks over the final terms sought by Olympia & York, executives close to the discussions said.

title: Smoking and Pets
description: While scientists have long known that passive smoking, inhaling smoke produced by a smoker, is hazardous to people,a new study indicates that it is hazardous to pets as well.

title: Knicks Tickets Go on Sale
description: Tickets for the Knicks' two home exhibition games and their first 19 games of the 1989-90 season, at an average price increase of about 25 percent, will go on sale at 10 A.M. today at the Madison Square Garden box office, TicketMaster outlets and by mail.

title: Prism Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $39,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Included extraordinary credits of $24,000, or 1 cent a share, and $96,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Cooper Cos reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $5,399,000 for the quarter and $7,305,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a loss from discontinued operations of $21,172,000. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $3,317,000 and $10,013,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $4,580,000.

title: Jetronic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $16,000 for the quarter and $28,000 for the 6 months. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $175,000 and $192,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Both year-ago periods restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Frances Denney Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bank of Tokyo Trust Appoints a Chairman
description: After a 10-year tour of duty in Tokyo and in Jakarta, Indonesia, Kenji Yoshizawa is returning to the United States, this time as chairman of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company in New York and the bank's resident senior managing director.

title: McCormick & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,662,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $83 million, or $3.76 a share, for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $879,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,644,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $6.4 million, or 27 cents a share.

title: Credo Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Echo of South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Why the Gypsy Moth Had Such a Bad Year
description: SCIENTISTS have identified the mysterious fungus that has kept leaf-eating gypsy moths in check across much of the Northeast this summer.

title: General Mills Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 27
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7.7 million. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $198.3 million and a loss of $70 million after-tax cumulative accounting change related to adoption in fiscal 1989 of accrual accounting for post-retirement health benefits. The company said prior year results have been restated to reflect discontinued Vromans frozen novelties operations separately.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Dai-Ichi Kangyo will buy control of a Manufacturers Hanover unit and a portion of the bank's stock for $1.4 billion, the largest investment yet by a Japanese bank in a U.S. financial company. The financing will help to strengthen the financial condition of Manufacturers, which said it would add $950 million to its reserves for losses on third-world loans. [ Page A1. ] First Pennsylvania agreed to a $730 million merger with Corestates Financial. [ D19. ] First Interstate of Wisconsin said it would merge with Norwest. [ D4. ] Burroughs Wellcome cut the price of the AIDS drug AZT by 20 percent. Protests had been mounting over the drug's cost. [ A1. ] A proposed $250 million loan to Campeau was held up by differences with banks over terms sought by Olympia & York. [ D1. ] Additional investors are expected to join a Citicorp unit's effort to acquire a division of Del Monte. [ D1. ] Birmingham Steel agreed to be acquired by Harbert for about $375.6 million. [ D4. ] A strike is threatening to slow Peugeot's momentum while the French auto maker is preparing to introduce a crucial model. [ D1. ] Imported cars again dominated the best- and worst-mileage categories in the E.P.A.'s annual survey. [ D15. ] Delta, Northwest and TWA are considering a merger of their computer reservation systems. [ D11. ] Six computer companies accused the National Intitutes of Health of awarding data processing contracts to I.B.M. without competition. [ D2. ] Apple and Microsoft are expected to cooperate on technology for the display and printing of typefaces. [ D2. ] Sir James Goldsmith has come to America to try to persuade legislators and regulators that his takeover bid for B.A.T. poses no threat to the company's U.S. operations. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY Companies are aggressively moving to control airline travel expenses, as fares used by business people have jumped. [ A1. ] U.S. and Japanese executives had unusually blunt exchanges over trade imbalances at a conference on manufacturing. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL The Mexican Government intends to sell its majority stake in Telmex, the unpopular and inefficient telephone monopoly. [ D1. ] President Bush said he would grant Hungary permanent most-favored-nation status, starting next month. [ A3. ] The Brady plan to cut global debt could misfire by further shrinking the core of future lenders to the third world, the Institute of International Finance, which represents banks, contends. [ D15. ] A U.S. Treasury official said cooperation might bring banking havens into the fight against laundering of drug money. [ A18. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.92 points, to 2,687.50, in relatively slow trading. [ D8. ] The dollar dropped in the aftermath of last week's panicky decline. Gold prices fell. [ D20. ] Prices of Treasury securities eased slightly in very sluggish trading. [ D19. ] Cocoa futures prices fell to new life-of-contract lows after the failure of a six-day meeting to guarantee prices. [ D20. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Problems of air quality and congestion can be addressed without harming the trucking industry, says Thomas J. Donohue, of the American Trucking Associations. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Oryx Energy's $1.31 billion deal with British Petroleum is an example of why American oil companies are placing more bets on foreign oilfields. Market Place. [ D8. ] Advertising ''is about doing great creative work,'' says Allan Beaver of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver. A retrospective of the agency's work shows that awards can be won for a variety of clients. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D23. ]

title: First Bank Weighs Cuts in Work Force
description: The First Bank System Inc. may cut its work force by up to 20 percent under a revamping that could cost nearly $40 million and reduce assets by $2 billion. Its chairman, DeWalt H. Ankeny Jr., said the possible restructuring was still being studied and had not been presented to the board.

title: Hughes Aircraft Unit to Cut Jobs
description: A unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company involved in radar technology said it had reorganized its operations and was eliminating 1,000 jobs. The cuts at the Hughes Radar Systems Group come in a revamping at Hughes, part of the General Motors Corporation. Hughes said in June that it would eliminate 6,000 jobs through layoffs and attrition to prepare for expected cutbacks in military spending.

title: Landlord Found Guilty in Deaths Of Two Tenants in Yonkers Fire
description: The landlord of a rooming house in Yonkers where eight residents perished in a fire this year was convicted today of criminally negligent homicide in the deaths of two occupants, whose attempts to flee were thwarted by a door locked by a key from the inside.

title: Hurricane Is Scrambling Travel and Cruise Plans
description: With a hurricane churning through the islands of the eastern Caribbean, tourism officials said yesterday that the industry was straining to assure the safety of the guests and cruise ship passengers and to offer alternative vacations.

title: Vernal B. Pemberton, Educator, 70
description: Vernal B. Pemberton, who helped create the first black history program in the New York City schools, died of cancer Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Careers; Fund-Raisers In Demand At Colleges
description: THE weekly Chronicle of Higher Education is filled with persuasive advertisements about jobs for development officials. In collegiate circles, development means fund raising.

title: Kentucky Youth Frees 11 Hostages and Surrenders
description: An armed 17-year-old student apparently acting out the plot to a novel entered a high school classroom and took 11 classmates hostage today. He released them all and after nearly nine hours surrendered.

title: Cilluffo Slate Wins Seats at Amdura
description: Cilluffo Associates L.P. has won its battle to replace the board of the Amdura Corporation, a Denver hardware distributor, after gaining the consent of shareholders representing about 3.6 million, or nearly 51 percent, of Amdura's shares, the companies said.

title: Giants' Dorsey Breaks a Foot and Will Be Out for the Season
description: The Giants' happiness over winning their first two games of the season was tempered today when they learned that Eric Dorsey, their starting left defensive end, has been lost for the season with a broken foot. He will probably be replaced by John Washington, like Dorsey a fourth-year pro who is especially strong against the run.

title: Surprise Resignation By Kellogg's President
description: In a move that surprised Wall Street, Horst W. Schroeder, until now considered a shoo-in to be the Kellogg Company's next chief executive, resigned his position as president and chief operating officer of the world's largest cereal company, effective immediately.

title: Use of a Special Prosecutor Is Proposed in H.U.D. Case
description: Members of Congress from both parties are calling for a special prosecutor to review allegations of impropriety involving former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and others who worked at senior levels of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Hungary Restores Ties With Israel
description: Hungary today became the first Communist country to restore full diplomatic relations with Israel after having broken them over the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.

title: Issue by Credit Unit Of Pitney Bowes
description: The Pitney Bowes Credit Corporation is offering $150 million in notes, due in 2009, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Birmingham Steel Sets Harbert Merger Deal
description: LEAD: The Birmingham Steel Corporation, a maker of steel products in Alabama, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Harbert Corporation, one of the nation's largest private companies.

title: Theater Secret: Keep It Small
description: Five years ago Thomas Viertel and Steven Baruch were partners in a real-estate business, and Richard Frankel was managing director of the Circle Repertory Company, a nonprofit theater group in Greenwich Village. Today the three men are among the most successful producers of Off Broadway theater in New York.

title: HURRICANE ROUTS THOUSANDS IN PATH ACROSS CARIBBEAN
description: A powerful hurricane struck Puerto Rico yesterday after cutting a path of destruction across a 350-mile chain of Caribbean tourist islands. The storm severed communications with the region and left at least eight people dead and tens of thousands homeless.

title: Fraud Inquiry By Ferranti
description: Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., the British military electronics company that is investigating serious financial losses in a United States subsidiary, said it might have been a victim of fraud.

title: Quadrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,234,000 and $2,663,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $779,000 and $1,327,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 6 months are restated to reflect discontinuation of computer systems segment.

title: National Health Enhancement Sytems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PARTY IN POLAND SEEKS NEW IMAGE
description: The Central Committee of Poland's Communist Party today took up the question of whether the party - euphemistically called the United Workers Party -should water down its name further in the hope of making it less objectionable to more Poles.

title: PATTERNS
description: What Crisis?

title: Dress Barn Inc reports earnings for 13wks to July 29
description: The latest quarter included a 13- week period, compared with 14 weeks for year-ago period.

title: U.N. to Open Session in an Optimistic Mood
description: The United Nations gathers here Tuesday for the opening of its 44th General Assembly as the organization's prestige and support from the Soviet Union are growing.

title: Saynor Varah reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $290,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Net loss The company said year-ago income figures have been restated and included a $676,000 gain on the sale of its western operations. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M., followed by consecutive meetings of main committees. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW OF TECHNICAL COOPERATION AMONG DEVELOPING COUNTRIES - 10 A.M.

title: 2 Positive Drug Tests Not Reported by U.S.
description: The chairman of the medical commission of the world governing body for track and field said today he was concerned that The Athletics Congress of the United States failed to report that two athletes had tested positive for drug use at the national indoor championships last February in New York. A spokesman for T.A.C., however, said the athletes had won appeals and the tests were, therefore, not positive.

title: Human Transplant of Altered Cells Is Success
description: Scientists at the National Cancer Institute said today that the first federally approved transplant of genetically altered cells into a human had been successful.

title: Bulgarian Turks Finding Disillusion With Exodus
description: His timing was terrible, Hassan Ahmedov said. He was bemoaning his own plight, but he could also have been describing the predicament facing tens of thousands of Bulgarian Muslims who want to leave the country and feel stranded.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: News Summary
description: International A3-18 U.S. foreign policy was criticized by George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, who said the Administration has not encouraged changes in the Eastern bloc and was ''almost nostalgic about the cold war.'' Page A1 Pravda's writes ugly profile of Yeltsin in the U.S. A14 Polish party seeks new image A14 India agreed to withdraw troops from Sri Lanka by December and end hostilities with the main ethnic Tamil insurgent group. A3 Turkey's move to close its border to more Bulgarian Turks in late August has created a class of people who are ready and able to leave Bulgaria, but have nowhere to go. A12 Hungary restored ties with Israel after having suspended them over the 1967 Mideast war. Hungary became the first Communist country to mend relations. A3 Direct Egyptian-Israeli discussions between President Mubarak and Defense Minister Rabin were held to find ways of unlocking the Middle East stalemate. A8 The United Nations convenes today to open its 44th General Assembly. The organization has seen its prestige grow and Moscow's support expand. But some question U.S. support. A7 A Nicaraguan presidential candidate for the opposition, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, arrived in Miami to explain her electoral strategy and seek financial support from exiles. A18 Colombia's other drug cartel, in the southern city of Cali, has become a target of its belligerent rivals in the north, the Medellin cartel. A18 Errant rocket spares American Embassy in Colombia A18 Bid to curb money laundering A18 National A19-23, B6-7 A hurricane struck Puerto Rico after cutting a path of destruction across a chain of Caribbean tourist islands. The storm severed communications and left thousands homeless. A1 Puerto Rico struggles A1 Hurricane Hugo could land in Carolinas or northeast B6 Storm scrambles travel plans B7 A Japanese bank is buying control of a unit of Manufacturers Hanover and part of the bank's stock in the largest investment yet by a Japanese bank in a U.S. financial company. A1 D1 The price of AZT was cut by 20 percent after a month of protest against the AIDS drug's maker, the Burroughs Wellcome Company. A1 G.O.P. senators proposed changes in President Bush's drug plan, suggesting that it be financed through across-the-board cuts in most programs and deeper cuts in a few areas. A19 Defense chief imposes deadline in Pentagon war on drug flow A19 Bush prods Congress on bills B7 Efforts to reduce travel expenses, like banning first-class flying, have been started by many businesses. They are increasingly concerned about the large bills created by high air fares for business people. A1 Five weeks of United talks: out of disorder, a deal D1 A jetliner crew was pessimistic about whether it could land United Flight 232 safely, cockpit voice recordings show. But crew members said shortly after the July 19 crash that they believed they would land safely. A20 The blast on the battleship Iowa was not related to unauthorized gunpowder testing, the Navy said. The issue was raised by a news report. A22 A special counsel to review charges of impropriety involving former Housing officials, including Samuel Pierce, is being called for by Democratic and G.O.P. lawmakers. A22 Philadelphia is to receive $7.5 million from the state to restore social services to 4,000 mentally retarded people who live at home, a court ruled. A23 Dioxin anguishes Georgetown, S.C. As the International Paper Company moves to reduce its emissions there, the town has been caught in anger and confusion. A20 Teen-ager frees hostages A20 Regional B1-5 A family's struggle with drugs is described in the story of Pat DeGregorio, a New York City narcotics detective who discovered his daughter was an addict and a dealer. A1 Three candidates for chancellor of the New York City school system have been recommended by a search committee set up by the Board of Education. One said he did not want the job. A1 Robert Garcia ''went bad'' because he and his wife ''were in desperate need of money,'' a prosecutor said in opening statements at the Representative's trial on extortion, bribery and conspiracy charges. B1 Bronx judge to pead guilty to tax and drug charges B1 Rural protests have been set off by New York State's plans for a nuclear dump. A Federal mandate requires the state to find a repository for low-level nuclear waste by 1993. B2 A challenge to a Breathalyzer test was rejected by a Criminal Court judge in Manhattan. But a high-ranking prosecutor said drunken-driving cases that relied on the tests would still be difficult to prosecute. B3 Co-defendant identifies Bensonhurst shooter B4

title: Nike Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Prime Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share data is not applicable; the company went public in November 1988.

title: A United Pilot Sticks to His Goal
description: Airline industry veterans often scoffed after Frederick C. Dubinsky made up his mind in January 1987 that the best way to insure the pilots' future at United Airlines was for them to own the carrier.

title: Pact Seen in Computer Type
description: Apple Computer Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation are expected to announce on Tuesday an agreement to cooperate on developing technology to allow type styles to be displayed on computer screens and printed by computers on paper.

title: Tab Products reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JAPANESE MAKING BIGGEST DEAL YET WITH A U.S. BANK
description: The world's biggest bank, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, announced plans yesterday to buy control of a unit of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and a portion of the bank's stock.

title: Critics Fault Secret Effort To Test AIDS Drug
description: A NEW YORK man participating in an unorthodox private study of an AIDS drug has died, and the circumstances surrounding his death are making AIDS patients and their advocates take a critical look at this method of testing drugs.

title: Nuclear Dump Plan Ignites Rural Protests
description: Federal Express made an unwelcome delivery the other day to Marilyn Ostrander's farm here in the lush green hills of Allegany County.

title: Philadelphia Ordered to Restore Funds for the Mentally Retarded
description: A Commonwealth Court judge here today ordered the state to provide Philadelphia with $7.5 million so it can restore social services to 4,000 mentally retarded people who live at home.

title: Peerless Mfg reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $15,229, or 2 cents a share, and $34,794, or 4 cents a share, for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: Filmstar Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The latest fiscal year was the company's first as an operating company.

title: CRASH TAPE SHOWS A PESSIMISTIC CREW
description: A transcript of cockpit voice recordings released today by investigators shows that the crew of United Flight 232 was pessimistic about whether it could safely land the crippled plane in Sioux City, Iowa, on July 19.

title: Denigrate, Debase of Revile
description: Representative Sidney Yates has any number of well-chosen words - ''incredible hodgepodge of administrative barriers,'' for instance, and ''the start of George Orwell's age'' - for the proposal by which Senator Jesse Helms would shackle the National Endowment for the Arts. Last week they fell on willing ears. The House rejected the punitive Helms amendment to the $10.9 billion appropriations bill. Would that the Senate had been as sensible; it passed the Helms amendment by voice vote six weeks ago.

title: Emmy Awards for 'Roe v. Wade' and 'Day One'
description: The television industry saluted the movies ''Roe v. Wade'' and ''Day One'' with Emmy Awards on Sunday evening.

title: Our Towns; To Drum Corps, A Drill Is Serious And Color-Blind
description: The Montrose Fire Department has no patience for people who take parades lightly. ''We march in black shoes - no frills,'' said Chief Richard Stickles. ''Black socks. Not brown. Hair cut above the collar. We march in a very close formation which always looks good. We're tight. After the parade, in the beer tent, a lot of firemen will take off their jackets. We don't.'' ''Even in the rain, we're into it,'' said Scott Cole, who was standing in the rain here Saturday at the Westchester County annual volunteer firefighter's parade. ''We don't take off our hats after the parade. Girlfriends don't wear our hats.''

title: Revitalized Broncos Stop Bills' Streak, 28-14
description: Denver's big-play defense, sparked by interceptions from Wymon Henderson and Tyrone Braxton, helped the Broncos build a 21-0 lead and they held on for a 28-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills tonight.

title: Lendl Gets Married
description: Ivan Lendl, runner-up to Boris Becker at the recent United States Open, was married to Samantha Frankel last Friday at their home in Greenwich, Conn. The couple honeymooned for the weekend at a Connecticut inn, then flew to Europe, where Lendl will play in a tournament in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Japanese See Gains in '90
description: The Japanese economy remains robust and the trend will continue into the first quarter of 1990, the Finance Ministry said today in a report.

title: Jay Jacobs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
People in China Scoff at Official Version of the Events of June; The Fallen Novelist
description: To the Editor:

title: Werner Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The Corcoran to Apologize for Canceling Show
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art said today that it had decided to issue a statement of regret and apology for its cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe exhibition in June.

title: Town Agonizes Over Dioxin Levels
description: The paper industry was surprised a few years ago when a study showed that paper mills were producing toxic dioxin and releasing it into nearby rivers.

title: Dressing Up, and Down, for Fall
description: Just four days before the official end of summer, Arnold Scaasi had the last word on fall fashion.

title: The 'People's Opera' vs. Parity for the Musicians
description: The current strike by the New York City Opera orchestra doesn't seem on the surface to make a whole lot of sense - for either side. The two parties appear to be within negotiating distance, and the six-day-old strike threatens the entire fall season, which is scheduled to end Nov. 19. Indeed, Martin J. Oppenheimer, vice chairman of the City Opera and its chief negotiator, said that if the strike began to approach the 54 days of the orchestra's 1983 strike, ''it will last a lot longer than that, because we'll cancel the entire season.''

title: Insufficiency Is the Only Scandal in Legal Services for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin in U.S.: Pravda's Ugly Profile
description: The visit to America of Boris N. Yeltsin, the critic of the Kremlin, was depicted at length today in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda as a vulgar spree by a hard-drinking demagogue.

title: Currents Will Dictate Course of Storm
description: Scientists watching the hurricane that swept Puerto Rico yesterday say its future course and possible impact on the East Coast depend on timing.

title: KEY RATES
Investors Seen Joining Del Monte Bid
description: In an attempt to overcome significant obstacles to the deal, additional investors are expected to join Citicorp Venture Capital's effort to acquire the canned food and processing division of Del Monte, people familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Rita Noel, Mezzo-Soprano
description: Rita Noel is a mezzo-soprano who was trained on the viola and continues to play it in public, an unusual combination that sets one wondering whether she performs the solo and obbligato parts of the Brahms viola songs simultaneously. She did not play the viola during her attractive song recital Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, but she did exhibit the musicianship and scrupulousness of intonation that one associates with singers who have mastered an orchestral instrument at a professional level.

title: Filming the Life of a String Quartet Is Like Filming a Marriage, Times 2
description: ''No matter how well people know one another, there is a certain distance that is naturally a part of life in any kind of relationship, whether a friendship or a marriage or a business.''

title: Jayark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Indian Army Agrees to Leave Sri Lanka
description: India agreed today to withdraw its 43,000 troops from Sri Lanka by December and end hostilities with the main ethnic Tamil insurgent group.

title: Bush, in a Visit to the West, Prods Congress About Key Bills
description: President Bush gave Congress a sharp elbow today, suggesting that it ''move fast'' on his legislation covering crime, drugs and the environment.

title: U.S. Contends The Garcias Needed Money
description: Representative Robert Garcia was a politician who ''went bad'' because he and his wife ''were in desperate need of money'' for a style of life they could not afford, a prosecutor said yesterday in opening statements at Mr. Garcia's extortion, bribery and conspiracy trial.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * B. Altman & Co., the department store chain, named Warren Wishart senior vice president and controller.

title: The Editorial Notebook; There She Is, Miss Different
description: My wife wondered: Should we tape that movie on public television and watch the Miss America pageant live, or vice versa? It was no contest. There are certain things one simply does at certain seasons. We could no more pass up Miss America in September than the World Series in October, the bowl games on New Year's or the Oscars in April. To watch such pop cultural events is to watch the culture change.

title: East Germans Said to Impound Passports
description: East German emigres say that Czechoslovak and East German authorities have begun seizing passports to stop them from reaching Hungary and emigrating to the West.

title: 3 Airlines Weigh Merging Ticket Systems
description: Delta, Northwest and Trans World Airlines are considering merging their computer reservation systems, executives at the three airlines said yesterday.

title: Playmaker and Goalie Raise American Hopes
description: The United States finally got to use its best playmaker and may have found its best goalkeeper Sunday in a World Cup qualifying game against El Salvador. Hugo Perez scored the goal, Tony Meola got the shutout, and with the 1-0 victory, the Americans took a giant stride toward joining soccer's elite in Italy next summer.

title: Premier Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Books of The Times; Third-World Refugees Rootless in the U.S.
description: Jasmine By Bharati Mukherjee 241 pages. Grove Weidenfeld. $17.95.

title: People in China Scoff at Official Version of the Events of June
description: To the Editor:

title: Get the Pentagon Out of Biological Warfare; Tested in Manchuria
description: To the Editor:

title: Clancy to Train Cooney
description: Gil Clancy, the color commentator for CBS Sports and the Madison Square Garden cable-television network, will be training Gerry Cooney for his Jan. 15 match against George Foreman in Atlantic City. Clancy came to terms yesterday with Tom Mara, the Long Island construction man who represents Cooney.

title: NCNB Stock Offer in Japan
description: The NCNB Corporation will be offering its common shares in the Japanese market for the second time in two years. The company plans to offer five million newly issued shares at $51 a share.

title: Faradyne Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
John Burr Williams, 88, Economist, Dies
description: John Burr Williams, an economist and investment manager, died of complications of a stroke on Friday at the Weston Manor Nursing Home in Weston, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beckman Instruments Inc., Fullerton, Calif., which makes analytical instruments, said it would phase out 150 jobs in its Bioanalytical Systems Group by the end of the year.

title: Library Acquires Stage Designer's Works
description: The New York Public Library has acquired an all-embracing collection of the work of Rouben Ter-Arutunian, whose critically acclaimed scenery, costumes and artwork have for a half-century been a hallmark of leading dance, theater, television and film productions.

title: Jet Quarterback Vows He Will Play Smarter
description: Ken O'Brien's world - the one he sees when he is upright - is easy to define.

title: Mozambique to Ban Flogging
description: Mozambique's Parliament voted today to abolish public flogging, which had drawn criticism from international human rights bodies. Flogging was introduced in 1983 as a punishment for security offenses, black marketeering, armed robbery and the rape of minors.

title: Jumping-Jacks Shoes reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rangers Lose Game and Millen
description: There were sections of ceiling missing in the hallways, scaffolding dominating one end of the building and a large, black, makeshift shroud hiding the other end.

title: Apple Computer Picks Key Officer
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that Ian W. Diery had been named senior vice president of the company and president of Apple Pacific, its sales and marketing organization for Pacific Rim countries. He succeeds Delbert W. Yocam, who announced last year that he would conclude his operational duties at Apple on Nov. 27. Mr. Diery will begin working at Apple on Oct. 16.

title: Gencorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $65,000,000, or $2.06 a share, and $208,000,000, or $6.58 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,000,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter, and $4 million, or 15 cents a share, for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $3 million, or 10 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Imports Lead Mileage Lists
description: Imported cars again dominated the best-mileage and worst-mileage lists in an annual survey by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: G.E.-Asahi Effort
description: Wear-resistant diamond coatings may be the first product of a venture involving a unit of the General Electric Company and the Asahi Diamond Industrial Company. G.E.'s Superabrasives unit, the world's largest producer of manufactured diamonds, has joined with Asahi to develop a process of making diamonds. The gems, frequently used for cutting tools, also have vast potential in the fields of semiconductors, heat-transfer material and optical products.
