title: T Cell Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Park Seeking to Oust 1,000 Mountain Goats To Save Rare Plants
description: LEAD: FEW scenes of the high country of the American West rival the sight of a shaggy, snow-white mountain goat standing at the edge of a precipice. So it could seem paradoxical that officials are attempting to get rid of almost all the 1,000 mountain goats in the rain-drenched Olympic National Park in Washington.

title: Take Off That Tie, Pal, You're in the Bleachers
description: Two innings into last Tuesday night's game here between the Chicago Cubs and the Montreal Expos, the Bleacher Preacher put down one of his many signs that exhort the hometown heroes and left his lucky seat to conduct some very important business.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Ease
description: Prices of Treasury securities eased slightly in very sluggish trading yesterday.

title: U.S. and Japan Executives Exchange Barbs on Trade
description: Tensions over the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan today produced some unusually blunt exchanges between chief executives gathered here for a conference on the outlook for manufacturing industries.

title: Numbers Into Pictures
description: THE electronic spreadsheet is an essential tool of business, but its results are not always easily grasped. It is much simpler to see the trend in monthly gizmo sales by looking at a bar chart than by studying columns of numbers.

title: Anatomical Atlas Caps a Half-Century of Medical Illustration
description: DR. FRANK H. NETTER, probably the world's best-known medical illustrator, has completed what he considers his crowning achievement: a comprehensive color atlas of the human anatomy that is the fruit of several decades of work and study.

title: Allegheny & Western Energy Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
Detroit Journal; In Joe Louis's Shadow, The Discipline to Win
description: In the dim lobby of the Wheeler Recreation Center, in the center of the Brewster housing project, there is a framed painting of Joe Louis, the longtime heavyweight champion, his fists up, his eyes fixed and hard, staring into the gloom.

title: Ron Whyte, 47, Dead; Playwright of Disabled
description: Ron Whyte, a playwright, editor and advocate for the disabled, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in New Haven on Wednesday. He was 47 years old.

title: First Interstate In Merger Deal
description: The First Interstate Corporation of Wisconsin said today that it would merge with the Norwest Corporation, one of the largest bank holding companies in the Midwest. Under the agreement, First

title: REVISED DRUG PLAN WEIGHED BY G.O.P.
description: Senate Republicans proposed modifications to President Bush's $7.9 billion drug-fighting package today, suggesting that it be financed by across-the-board cuts in most Federal programs and some deeper cuts in a few areas.

title: Business Seeks to Trim Rising Cost of Flying
description: The air fares used mainly by business travelers have jumped as much as 47 percent in the last year, but the Wall Street investment firm Bear, Stearns & Company has managed to limit the increase in its overall travel costs to 10 percent in that time.

title: Northwest Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: By Design; The Coat of the Moment
description: Shearlings are No. 1. Fake furs are big fashion, too. But if you want to look impossibly well turned out as well as warm, you'll go looking for a wool bathrobe of a coat right now before winter comes. Pull it on, wrap it around, sash the waist, snuggle the collar up around your ears, and let it drape down over your shoulders - that's 1990's style.

title: Oppenheimer Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Everett Puts New Life Into Rams' Offense
description: Last season, when Jim Everett passed for 3,964 yards and 31 touchdowns, the Los Angeles Rams saw the merits of the riveting, three-team trade that sent Eric Dickerson to the Indianapolis Colts on Halloween 1987. Last Sunday, against the Colts, Everett again showed why he is a better quarterback and why the Rams are a more explosive team without Dickerson.

title: For Chips That Overheat: A Tiny Radiator
description: The success of computer designers in cramming increasingly powerful chips into ever smaller spaces for the next generation of supercomputers is creating a difficult problem: overheating.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Tastes of France Past

title: Genia Nemenoff, 84, Partner in Piano Duo
description: Genia Nemenoff, a pianist who toured widely in the 1940's and 1950's as part of a duo with her husband, the pianist Pierre Luboshutz, died of heart failure on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: Container Center Helps Poor and Homeless to Help Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Griffin Proposal To Cost Investors
description: LESS than a year after raising $325 million in the ''junk bond'' market, Merv Griffin yesterday proposed a reorganization of Resorts International that will leave bondholders with substantial losses but holding a 25 percent equity stake in the troubled casino company.

title: Baker, Defending Policy, Details 'Creative' Response to Gorbachev
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d moved today to counter charges that the Bush Administration was unresponsive to opportunities presented by changes in the Soviet bloc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Artists Divided On Corcoran Apology
description: Artists remained divided today over whether a statement of regret by the Corcoran Gallery of Art for canceling an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe was acceptable.

title: The Case of the Reluctant Idler
description: I SUPPOSE I inherited my aversion to vacations from my father. His idea of foreign travel consisted of venturing from his office in suburban Los Angeles all the way downtown, which his job occasionally required him to do.

title: It's Still Too Cold
description: A gap is widening between U.S.

title: More Bad News for Bills
description: The bad news for the Buffalo Bills on Monday did not end with their 28-14 loss at home to the Denver Broncos. Yesterday, the Bills confirmed that their Pro Bowl linebacker, Shane Conlan, had suffered a serious knee injury that will sideline him for at least six weeks. Conlan, who was hit by the Denver tight end Clarence Kay early in the fourth quarter, wasn't available to talk about the injury. Coach Marv Levy described it as ''a second-degree srain of the medial ligament.'' (AP)

title: A Connecticut Farm Turned Crafts Cornucopia
description: ON a rare stretch of U.S. 1 that is still framed by apple and peach orchards, just a few miles from the urban clutter surrounding New Haven, an old farm in Branford has been transformed into a thriving crafts center. About 20 artists and artisans work at Branford Crafts Village at Bittersweet Farm, in unpretentious but attractive quarters that double as workshops and stores.

title: Pennsylvania Under Abortion Spotlight
description: As members of the General Assembly return to work this week, they are encountering a barrage of letters, demonstrations and lobbying about how they should vote on abortion issues.

title: Gorbachev: Beyond Our Help
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's troubles are mounting again, and Americans wonder whether and how to help him. This week's events frame the question nicely.

title: WHAT'S DOING AROUND: Lake Champlain
description: Perhaps it is childhood memories of stories about the pilgrims, but whatever the reason, Americans seem to have an atavistic yearning for New England each fall. Those craving frosty nights and crisp, clear days may chose to tour Lake Champlain, where they can admire the autumnal beauty of the Green Mountains of Vermont and the Adirondacks of New York State.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wells Is Losing Lauren And Procter & Gamble
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation yesterday dealt Wells, Rich, Greene a major setback, confirming industry rumors that they would shift their accounts from the agency.

title: Review/Music; Concert of Italian Works
description: The Cathedral Free Concert Society opened its eighth season of free performances at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine with a Saturday evening concert of Italian music. The performance, which featured the Brooklyn Philharmonic, the Cathedral Singers and vocal soloists, was co-sponsored by the Italian Government and was offered as an adjunct to the ''Italian Artists Against Apartheid'' exhibition at the cathedral, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, through Sept. 27.

title: Hefty New Primers For Cooke Lacking Practice and Time
description: COOKBOOK publishers this fall are rolling out weighty new editions intended for an audience of inexperienced but eager cooks. Their needs are seen as different from, and their tastes more wide ranging than, those of the generation that already wore out the basic cookbooks bought in the 60's, 70's and early 80's.

title: Small Storm Nearby May Sap Hugo
description: The hurricane heading toward the East Coast may be weakened by a smaller tropical storm that has developed in its wake, meteorologists said yesterday. Partly as a result, they said, the heavy rains accompanying the hurricane may prove a bigger threat to the United States mainland than the winds.

title: Smoothing Out the Bumps a Bit in Charter Flights
description: In his capacity as spokesman for the consumer affairs section of the Department of Transportation, Hoyte B. Decker Jr. does not have many occasions to laugh. But this time he did. Asked if he thought 1989 would go into the books as not having seen the stranding of mobs of people traveling overseas on air charters, he roared. ''Oh, no, you'll never get me to say that,'' he said. ''Sure as I do, I'll get a phone call with bad news. And you know that this is the time it happens, when people start to come home in the fall.''

title: Pierce Considers Citing the Fifth Amendment
description: A lawyer for Samuel R. Pierce Jr. raised the prospect today that the former Housing Secretary would consider citing his constitutional right against compelled self-incrimination if, as expected, he is forced to appear before a House panel on Tuesday.

title: Bentsen Ends Hearing Because Sullivan Is Missing
description: In an action some Republicans called politically motivated, Senator Lloyd Bentsen angrily ended the committee's deliberations about Medicare today because Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, was not present.

title: FRENCH DC-10 LOST OVER WEST AFRICA
description: A DC-10 jetliner bound for Paris from Congo with 170 people aboard disappeared today, probably over West Africa, the French airline UTA said.

title: States Using Stiff Methods To Collect Child Support
description: Using strengthened Federal and state laws, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York are tracking down parents who fail to pay court-ordered child support and collecting the money by seizing their wages, intercepting tax refunds or putting the delinquents in jail until they pay.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: LENTILS, ancient staples in Middle Eastern and Indian cooking, and widely used in Italian and French cuisine, have become commonplace in many fancy restaurants. But as a healthful food, lentils, like other legumes, have had to take a back seat to more popular foods like oat bran.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Blazing Trails
description: To the Editor: In ''Blazing Unfamiliar Trails'' you write, ''Ms. Wadsworth was too old for youth hostels . . . .'' I hope you meant that she preferred to camp out. The youth hostels in Europe are not restricted by age. In fact, there are often special accommodations for families.

title: 'Junk Bonds' Recapture Much Lost Ground
description: Trading in the ''junk bond'' market rebounded sharply yesterday, making up a third to a half of the ground lost last week, as buyers came looking for bargains.

title: Methanol Defended as Option
description: The Environmental Protection Agency responded today to oil and auto industry criticism of an important part of President Bush's clean air legislation by defending methanol as both an economically and environmentally sound fuel alternative to gasoline.

title: Canadian Inquiry Ends
description: After eight months of testimony from 120 witnesses, the Canadian Government's inquiry into the use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes ended today with a sober look to the future. The final witness, Lyle Makosky, the assistant Deputy Minister of Fitness and Amateur Sport, said that despite the heightened awareness around the world of drug use in sports and a variety of initiatives to address the problems, ''the international campaign has been largely on paper.''

title: Orioles Stay in Chase By Beating Tigers, 6-2
description: Craig Worthington and Tim Hulett broke out of slumps with home runs as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Detroit Tigers, 6-2, tonight for their third victory in four games and stay right behind Toronto.

title: France
description: To the Editor: One of the methods used by the Republicans to dispatch the objecting Vendeans (Travel, July 9) was the noyades, or wholesale drowning.

title: Salary Data Show 8 College Heads Top $200,000
description: The chief executives of eight leading private universities each earned more than $200,000 last year, according to Federal tax forms the institutions made available to the public for the first time.

title: Budget Roundup; Senate Votes to Increase Limit On Mortgages Insured by U.S.
description: The Senate approved a measure tonight to raise the ceiling on mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration, making them more available to home buyers in high-cost areas.

title: Review/Opera; Brecht-Weill 'Mahagonny,' Set in 20's Hollywood
description: The Los Angeles Music Center Opera, which in its first three seasons has brought home-grown, big-time opera to this city for the first time, has a penchant for splashy, flashy productions. The opening pair of fall operas consists of a ''Tosca'' with Maria Ewing, conducted by Placido Domingo, and a new staging of the Brecht-Weill ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny'' directed by Dr. Jonathan Miller, designed by Robert Israel and conducted by Kent Nagano.

title: Los Angeles Journal; In a Quest For Profit, Beethoven Is Ousted
description: The final anguished notes of the symphony still hung in the air as the announcer, Mary Fain, said, ''That was Tchaikovsky's 'Pathetique' Symphony, composed just a few months before his death, and played just a few hours before ours here at KFAC.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a Yale law student who works as a law clerk for a Supreme Court judge in South Africa misidentified the judge. He is Richard Goldstone.

title: Move by Simmons On Georgia Gulf
description: The Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons has raised his stake in the Georgia Gulf Corporation to 9.9 percent from 8.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he had bought 250,000 Georgia Gulf shares for prices ranging from $51.875 to $52.50 a share. Mr. Simmons had sold a portion of Georgia Gulf shares last week.

title: CONSUMER PRICES STEADY IN AUGUST
description: Consumer prices over all were unchanged in August, making it the first month in more than three years that the Consumer Price Index did not rise, the Labor Department reported today.

title: New MGM Grand Complex
description: MGM Grand Inc., which owns a luxury airline and the Desert Inn & Casino of Las Vegas, Nev., said today it plans to build an entertainment complex in Las Vegas. The $100 million complex will include a new MGM Grand hotel, a movie theme park and a studio tour.

title: Kemp Would Cut Officials' Power To Award Housing Funds at Will
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp will propose ending the awarding of funds based on personal discretion over need and merit. Mr. Kemp said he would also propose that consultants be required to register with his department and disclose their fees.

title: Review/Film; Sutherland Catches On To Apartheid Slowly
description: Being on the side of the angels isn't always an advantage. Moral certainty can reduce matters that are, quite literally, black and white to terms that are even more so. Thus far, virtually every cinematic attempt to convey the outrages of South African life under apartheid has been diminished by its own good intentions and by a grim sameness that eradicates any element of surprise. Watching stirrings of rebellion, brutal interrogations or mysterious disappearances at the hands of the police, audiences know all too well what to expect.

title: Blazing Trails
description: To the Editor: I was joyed yet saddened to read the article ''Blazing Unfamiliar Trails'' by Paul L. Montgomery (Travel, Aug. 13). Joyed to read about others who share my love for walking and saddened because of Esther Wadsworth's statement: ''I wouldn't recommend it for anybody alone. It's too lonely.''

title: Brazil Skips Loan Payment
description: Brazil, the third world's biggest debtor, skipped an important interest payment Monday, joining a growing list of Latin American countries in arrears on debt.

title: The Can't-Do Guy
description: President Bush says nothing can be done about these massacres.

title: James Sheils, 76, Dies; Headed Siboney Corp.
description: James H. Sheils, a former New York City Commissioner of Investigation and a retired president of the Siboney Corporation, died of complications from lymphoma Monday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Philadelphia
description: LEAD: AT most restaurants, food and politics are like oil and water. But at the White Dog Cafe, the two have coalesced in a fashion that reflects the philosophical leanings of the cafe's owner, Judy Wicks. Ms. Wicks, 42 years old, has embraced capitalism as a means to spread her views of freedom and brotherhood.

title: Portable and Desktop Units To Be Introduced by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce its long-awaited portable Macintosh computer Wednesday and a new high-end desktop machine known as the Macintosh IIci.

title: Campeau Wraps Up Loan Pact
description: Resolving a weeklong financial crisis, the Campeau Corporation said yesterday in Toronto that it had reached a definitive agreement for a $250 million loan that would help ease a cash shortage at its nine department store divisions in the United States.

title: 4 Executed in Burkina Faso As an Attempted Coup Fails
description: Four men were executed in Burkina Faso after security agents uncovered a plot to overthrow the head of state, Capt. Blaise Compaore, the sub-Saharan nation's official press agency said today. The Government spokesman, Clement Ouedraogo, reached by telex from here, said the coup leaders planned to seize the airport and if they had met resistance, and to shoot down Captain Compaore's plane.

title: Where Vermont and Quebec Meld
description: THINK of Derby Line, Vt., and Rock Island, Quebec, as an El Paso and Juarez of the north. Smaller and colder than the Texas-Mexico border towns, but both locked in a geographic embrace across an international divide. The invisible United States-Canadian border runs through the center of what appears to be a single town.

title: Forest Murder: Ours and Theirs; Brazil's Season of Shame
description: This is the time of year when Brazil's farmers torch the Amazon forest, the ancient home of 80,000 different species of plants and 30 million species of animals, many still unknown to science.

title: Our Sugar Protectionism Spurs Coca Growing; Look at the Causes
description: To the Editor:

title: Graduating Jocks - A Numbers Game
description: LEAD: Senator Bill Bradley would have us believe that legislation forcing colleges to reveal the graduation rates of their athletic scholarship holders would help cure the ills of college sports. Actually, such a law would probably make things worse.

title: Vatican Acts After Persuading Polish Primate to Ease Confrontational Stance
description: The Vatican statement supporting the removal of a Carmelite convent from the site of the Auschwitz death camp was apparently issued after quiet but firm efforts to nudge the Polish Roman Catholic leadership around Jozef Cardinal Glemp to take a more conciliatory stand on the issue.

title: Bush's Mother Hospitalized Suffering From Pneumonia
description: Dorothy Walker Bush, the President's 88-year-old mother, was admitted to Greenwich Hospital with pneumonia Monday.

title: Review/Dance; A Jammed Carnegie Shows That Tap's Time Has Come
description: Is tap dancing popular? Does the sun rise in the morning? A packed Carnegie Hall filled with aficionados applauded fine points and roared their approval Monday night as they confirmed the art form's rebirth.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions in some copies of Science Times yesterday, with an article about a private study of an AIDS drug, reversed the identities of two men. George Annas, a professor at Boston University School of Medicine, was at the right with beard and glasses; Martin Delaney, director of the study, was at the left.

title: Mets Fine And Bench Two Stars Who Left
description: The Mets finally won a game today but steepened their fall from grace when Darryl Strawberry and Kevin McReynolds were fined and benched for being in the locker room during the ninth inning Monday night, while their teammates were trying to rally against the first-place Chicago Cubs.

title: G.O.P. Senators Offer More Drug Spending
description: Senate Republicans offered today to add $800 million to President Bush's anti-drug proprosals to meet a political challenge from the Democrats, said lawmakers involved in the negotiations.

title: Ex-ZZZZ Best Official Fined
description: A former ZZZZ Best Company official was ordered to return profits he made by trading stock in the rug-shampooing company founded by Barry M. Minkow, who was convicted of defrauding investors. Jerry Polevoi, 41 years old, of

title: INSIDE
description: Unorthodox AIDS Study Asserts Some Promise Despite three deaths and other complications, a much-criticized study of an AIDS drug produced some encouraging results, its director said. But he warned patients not to take Compound Q yet. Page A21. Campeau Gets $250 Million Agreement was reached for a loan to help ease a cash crunch at Bloomingdale's and the eight other Campeau-owned department stores. Page D1. Japan to Reduce Drift Nets Tokyo said it would reduce by two-thirds the number of boats practicing drift-net fishing, which is likened to strip-mining. Page A3. DC-10 Missing in Africa A French-owned jetliner carrying 170 people disappeared after leaving Chad for Paris. Two other DC-10's have crashed this year. Page A5.

title: Jet on Injured Reserve
description: The Jets placed their strong safety, Rich Miano, on injured reserve and waived a running back, Nuu Faaola, yesterday. Miano, a fifth-year veteran, reinjured his left knee in the second quarter of the 38-24 loss Sunday at Cleveland. He was originally hurt in the Aug. 12 exhibition game at Green Bay. Faaola played mostly on the special teams in three years. He went into the season with 18 carries for 61 yards. The Jets also re-signed the cornerback Carl Howard, who was waived after the opener.(AP)

title: John G. Main, Executive, 60
description: John G. Main, managing partner of Management Practice Inc., a management-consulting business in Manhattan, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He was 60 years old.

title: Louisa Campbell, 81, American Art Expert
description: Louisa Dresser Campbell, former curator of collections at the Worcester (Mass.) Art Museum and a specialist in early American painting and American decorative arts, died of a systemic infection on Friday at the Medical Center of Central Massachusetts-Memorial in Worcester. She was 81 years old and lived in Worcester.

title: Wine-Making Family Expands L.I. Operation
description: September is a vintage month for members of the Simicich family of Mattituck, L.I. They harvested their pinot noir last week and have just sent their winery label to the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms for approval. Soon, they will bottle their very first wines, '88 chardonnay and '88 riesling.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Still a False Start
description: President Bush promised Monday to produce proposals for reducing strategic arms that will ''capture the imagination of the Soviet people.'' But in the next breath he said he felt in ''no rush on that subject.'' Not that anyone would accuse him of haste. In his eight months in office, there's been practically no movement in these almost eight-year-old negotiations with Moscow.

title: House Panel Backs Minimum Wage Plan
description: The Democratic-controlled House Labor and Education Comittee bowed today to President Bush's insistence that a proposed increase in the minimum wage be held to $4.25.

title: Dow Falls Slightly, but Many Issues Gain
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday on moderately higher volume.

title: Forest Murder: Ours and Theirs; Tongass Trees Aren't Cheeseburgers
description: When visiting U.S. senators urged President Jose Sarney of Brazil earlier this year to stop the burning of the Amazon's wondrous rain forest, he asked: ''But what about Tongass?''

title: Review/Music; Love Songs Of Mexico, Some Bawdy
description: ''Mexico Romantico,'' the program that Repertorio Espanol is presenting at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, is an enchanting revue built around 42 popular and traditional songs from Mexico, performed in Spanish by seven singers.

title: Steroid Testing In N.F.L. Upheld
description: A Federal judge refused today to stop the National Football League from testing for anabolic-steroid use and declined to reinstate 13 players suspended under the program.

title: About New York; Brother Fights Possible Parole In Fatal Beating
description: In New York, they say, people get away with murder.

title: Remote Splendors of the Highlands
description: NOWADAYS even the English enjoy visiting the Northwest Highlands of Scotland. It wasn't always so. For more than a thousand years, they ventured there only to chase Highlanders, just like the Romans before them, thinking, like them, that neither the place nor the people were quite civilized.

title: Frazier Wins Knicks Radio Job
description: Clyde and the Pearl, also known as Walt Frazier and Earl Monroe, spent their playing careers trying to upstage one another as opponents and as teammates. Recently, they each made a play for the spot in the Knicks' radio booth left vacant when Ernie Grunfeld moved to the bench as an assistant to Stu Jackson.

title: Q and A
description: Air Couriers

title: Text of Vatican Statement
description: Following is the text, translated from the French by The New York Times, of a Vatican statement today on the Jewish-Catholic dispute over a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The Vatican supported relocation of a Carmelite convent from the site of the Auschwitz death camp in Poland. It said it was willing to pay part of the cost of a new interfaith prayer center outside the camp. Page A1

title: Oil Services Export Aid
description: The United States Department of Energy will begin ''a major export initiative'' to help American oil-service companies gain business abroad, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Energy Secretary, said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's Department of Puerto Rican Community Affairs in the United States asked yesterday that donations to assist victims of Hurricane Hugo be sent to the American Red Cross or branch offices of three banks that are setting up special accounts for Puerto Rican disaster assistance. The banks are Banco Popular, Banco de Ponce and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: Pauley Discussing Her Role With 'Today'
description: After yet another major change at NBC's ''Today,'' the co-anchor Jane Pauley has scheduled a meeting with NBC executives to discuss her future with the program.

title: Teacher Corps of 70's Inspired Team Spirit; Take a Vow of Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Wary Southeast Watches the Skies
description: Coastal residents across the Southeast warily followed the path of Hurricane Hugo today as some experts raised concerns about what a combination of runaway coastal development and unprepared residents could mean if the storm slammed into the area.

title: Sooner to Go to Prison
description: The former University of Oklahoma quarterback Charles Thompson is scheduled to report today to the Federal prison at Big Spring, Tex., to begin serving a two-year term for a cocaine-related conviction. Thompson, who would have been a junior this season, faces a maximum of 27 months in prison and a minimum of 21 months. New Federal statutes dictate that he may not be paroled and that he undergo three years of drug testing or drug counseling upon his release. (AP)

title: Economic Scene; Fighting Cocaine, Coffee, Flowers
description: EVEN as President Bush cheers Colombia's brave effort to stamp out exports of cocaine, others in the Administration are making it more difficult for Colombians to profit from exports of coffee and cut flowers.

title: Quarterback Suspended
description: Penn State's starting quarterback, Tom Bill, has been suspended at least one game for violation of team policy, Coach Joe Paterno announced yesterday at his weekly news conference. Paterno said a sophomore, Tony Sacca, would replace Bill in the starting lineup Saturday against Boston College. The coach said the suspension was for an indefinite term and would be reviewed ''when reasonable and proper to do so.'' While Paterno refused to discuss the specifics, court records in State College, Pa., revealed that Bill was cited early Monday morning on campus for public drunkenness. The citation said the campus police found Bill at 2 A.M. sitting on a sidewalk in an intoxicated state.(AP)

title: A Natural Fat Substitute
description: To The Living Section:

title: Upjohn Says President Plans to Retire on Jan. 1
description: Lawrence C. Hoff, who joined the Upjohn Company in 1950 as a drug salesman calling on doctors, will retire as its president and chief operating officer on Jan. 1, the company said yesterday.

title: Our Sugar Protectionism Spurs Coca Growing; Colombian Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Goetz Freed From Jail Just After Midnight
description: Bernhard H. Goetz was released from jail early this morning after serving more than eight months of a one-year sentence for possessing an unlicensed handgun.

title: Gorbachev Warns Separatists
description: The Soviet President called for 'solving all problems by political methods,' but denounced secessionists as 'adventurists.' Page A8.

title: Cubs, Salazar: Right Player, Right Team
description: The Yankees used to do this kind of thing, the last-minute shopping expedition when company is coming.

title: Yankee Game Is Postponed
description: The daylong rain yesterday forced the Yankees and the Milwaukee Brewers to postpone their game last night at the Stadium and reschedule it as part of a twilight-night doubleheader today beginning at 4:30 P.M.

title: Japan to Limit Ships With Huge Nets
description: Under pressure from the Western allies and South Pacific nations, Japan said today that it would cut by two-thirds the number of fishing boats permitted to deploy giant drift nets that sweep up large amounts of ocean life, including sea birds, seals and dolphins.

title: Deals
description: Basketball

title: On the Trail of the Wild Porcini North Italy
description: YEARS later I can still remember my first taste of fresh porcini. My Tuscan host insisted on ordering the first of the fall season's wild mushrooms, and tucked in his napkin with a flourish. When the dish arrived, with its strong taste of musk and forest, it wasn't at all what I expected. Some six inches across, the mushroom cap had simply been broiled and was served up like a steak. Seasoned with Tuscany's deep green olive oil, and the requisite garlic and parsley, this was better than any steak. I was convinced.

title: William Eddy, 87, a Developer of TV, Dies
description: William Crawford Eddy, an engineer who developed television transmission and helped to establish Chicago's first television station, died at his home in Michigan City on Saturday after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Sept. 12 about machines that detect explosives in luggage referred incorrectly in some copies to the abilities of one device.

title: Miami Official to Be Named New York City Schools Chancellor
description: The New York City Board of Education decided yesterday to select the Superintendent of the Miami-Dade County school system, Joseph A. Fernandez, to be the city's next schools chancellor and is expected to approve the choice in a formal vote this morning, several members of the board said.

title: L.I. Merlot Wins State Contest
description: A 1987 merlot from Le Reve, a financially troubled Long Island winery, won the best-of-show honors Saturday in a tight contest sponsored by the New York Wine and Grape Foundation. But none of the competing wines were considered good enough to be awarded gold medals.

title: Books of The Times; When Winter Will Neither Chill Nor Charm
description: The End of Nature By Bill McKibben 226 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Task for Bacteria: Getting Rid of PCB's
description: Naturally occurring bacteria are increasingly being used to clean up chemical waste sites, particularly watery ones where methods developed for concentrated wastes would be costly to apply. But they have not been particularly effective on a group of chemicals known as polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, which were widely used and discarded in places like the Hudson River before their toxicity was discovered.

title: Interim Chief Named At Home Loan Banks
description: Mary K. Bush, a top official at the Federal National Mortgage Association, yesterday was named the interim managing director of the Federal Housing Finance Board, an agency created to oversee the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

title: Washington at Work; Spokeswoman on Foreign Affairs: A Behind-the-Scenes Player Is Up Front
description: Before Margaret Tutwiler took the job as State Department spokeswoman, she called many people she knew and some she did not know who had held the job in the past.

title: Koch Details His Final Year as Mayor
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch issued his annual Mayor's Management Report for the 12th and last time yesterday, praising his own stewardship of New York City while noting that the next Mayor faces ''enormous problems.''

title: U.S. Appeals Court Refuses To Re-examine Attica Case
description: Eighteen years after the bloody prison uprising at Attica, N.Y., the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has foreclosed a new examination of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's responsibility for the violence that ended in the deaths of 10 hostages and 29 prisoners.

title: Where Mallomars Don't Exist
description: EXPATRIATE New Yorkers out here engage in a ritual whenever they meet: they immediately pat each other on the back, extol the glories of warm weather and otherwise congratulate themselves on the joys of Pacific Coast living.

title: Writer Wins Plea on U.S. List of Excluded Aliens
description: Three years after the Government, without explanation, barred a Colombian journalist from entering the United States, a Federal district judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to make available to the woman's lawyers its secret list of all excluded aliens.

title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say
description: A 28-year-old East Village man charged with killing and dismembering his girlfriend is a marijuana dealer who created his own bizarre religion, practiced animal sacrifice and sometimes said he was God, acquaintances and the police said yesterday.

title: U.S. Official Questions Foreign Airline Deals
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that the Bush Administration had serious questions about the increasing number of foreign investments in United States airlines, even when the foreign partners buy stakes smaller than the 25 percent legal limit.

title: NBC Is First All Season
description: Even with ABC and CBS offering some of their new series last week, NBC managed (with a little help from Miss America and Sister Kate) to retain its hold on first place in prime time. It was the 65th consecutive first place for NBC, which became the first network ever to place first for all 52 weeks of a season.

title: Thornburgh Urged to Limit Iran-Contra Role
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra cases said today that the Attorney General should stay out of those cases unless he believes that national security considerations are sufficient to cancel a trial entirely.

title: How the Cup Was Won
description: Sept. 26, 1983 Dennis Conner, sailing for the New York Yacht Club, loses the America's Cup to Australia. Feb. 4, 1987 Conner, sailing for the San Diego Yacht Club, wins back the cup from Australia and begins making plans for a 1990 defense in 12-Meter sloop. July 17, 1987 Michael Fay of the Mercury Bay Boating Club of Auckland, New Zealand, challenges the San Diego Yacht Club to a race in 1988 with boats larger than a 12-Meter. After San Diego refuses his challenge, Fay asks the New York State Supreme Court, which oversees the cup's deed of gift, to force the San Diego club to race. Nov. 25, 1987 State Supreme Court Justice Carmen Ciparick orders the San Diego Yacht Club to accept Fay's unorthodox challenge. Sept. 9, 1988 Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes defeats Fay's New Zealand, 2-0, off San Diego. March 28, 1989 The New York State Supreme Court disqualifies San Diego Yacht Club's catamaran from cup races and orders the club to forfeit the America's Cup to the New Zealand club. Sept. 19, 1989 Appellate Division of State Supreme Court overturns the lower court and awards the cup to the San Diego club. Fay says he will appeal.

title: Teacher Corps of 70's Inspired Team Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Christian Chief Rejects Lebanese Peace Plan
description: An Arab League envoy's efforts to arrange a cease-fire stalled today as Christian leaders insisted on assurances for an early withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon.

title: Deng, Looking Fit, Sees a Japanese Politician
description: Appearing healthy and lucid, Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, today made his second public appearance in four days today and laughed at rumors that he had been ill.

title: Hazards Cited In Asbestos Job By Metro-North
description: For at least a year, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad routinely ordered its workers to remove asbestos from steam pipes, walls and wires under Grand Central Terminal ''without any protection from the serious health risks of inhaling the cancer-causing material,'' the New York State Attorney General charged yesterday.

title: Three Scottish Tables For Top-Notch Eating
description: BORN with the name of McIntire, growing up in a north-country family, I must have Scottish blood in my veins. It's a connection I'd resisted most of my life, disliking heather honey, Scotch terriers and anything with tartan wrapped round it. Then six years ago work forced me up to Scotland. Gorse shone yellow against blue sea and white sand. Everyone was relaxed. The roads were quiet. It seemed a gloriously foreign country. Now I return every year with a longing I can hardly credit.

title: Carolco Plans To Raise Stake
description: Carolco Pictures Inc. said today that it planned to buy additional shares of Live Entertainment Inc. in the open market.

title: Ethiopian Peace Talks Recess With Some Issues Unsettled
description: Negotiators for the Ethiopian Government and an Eritrean rebel group have recessed their talks for two months with some procedural issues unresolved.

title: Real Estate; Jamaica Mall Is Renovated After Setback
description: THE owners of the shopping mall in the former Gertz department store in Jamaica, Queens, who have seen a third of their retail tenants leave since the mall opened 18 months ago, are trying to infuse new life in the stalled center with a renovation and a new name.

title: MOVE BY VATICAN APPLAUDED IN U.S.
description: The Vatican's declaration backing relocation of a Roman Catholic convent from the site of the Auschwitz death camp removes a serious impediment to better Catholic-Jewish relations, leaders of the church and of Jewish organizations said yesterday.

title: Our Sugar Protectionism Spurs Coca Growing
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons
description: In a speech to the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Walter Lippmann once lamented what he called the ''enormous vacuum'' in American college curriculums.

title: Gorbachev Offers Fractious Nationalists Both Olive Branch and Stick
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today laid down a policy on growing nationalist agitation in the Soviet Union that invited conciliation but drew the line firmly against the separatist hopes of the nation's restive republics.

title: Angola Is Admitted to the World Bank and I.M.F.
description: Angola joined the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank today, despite objections by the United States, which earlier this summer cast the only vote against its membership.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Turnaround at Ally & Gargano
description: For 27 years, the advertising agency Ally & Gargano has battled on behalf of America's corporate underdogs, helping unknown companies like Federal Express and MCI Communications become household names. It now appears that the New York agency known among marketers for its pugnacious advertising is triumphing over its own demons.

title: Costs in New York Area Rose by 0.2% in August
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the regional bureau of the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: In Command At the U.N.
description: The United Nations opened its 44th General Assembly today by unanimously electing as its new President a former Nigerian major general who was a leader of one of Africa's most unusual military coups. The new Assembly

title: Many Oil Tankers Lack Radio Officer After U.S. Eases Rule
description: Oil companies have obtained waivers from the Federal Communications Commission to eliminate radio officers on many tankers, a move to reduce costs that critics contend will increase the chances of oil spills.

title: Vatican Strongly Urges Removal Of Convent at Site of Auschwitz
description: Intervening in a dispute between Roman Catholics and Jews, the Vatican expressed strong support today for the relocation of a Carmelite convent from the site of the Auschwitz death camp in Poland.

title: Private Study of AIDS Drug: Praise and Warning
description: A private study of a promising AIDS drug has produced encouraging results, its director said yesterday. But he warned people who have obtained the drug on the underground market not to take it until more studies are completed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 9 about a former mayor of Danbury, Conn., indicted on Federal racketeering charges misstated the number of terms he served. The former Mayor, James E. Dyer, served four two-year terms between 1979 and 1987.

title: Rosso Journal; Age-Old Hatred Burns as Hot as the Desert Sun
description: It was in the chilly hours before dawn when the soldiers arrived. They surrounded the camp, firing pistols in the air. Then, the man said, they herded several dozen of his family's cattle, kidnapped his mother and two sisters and shipped them in canoes across the Senegal River.

title: And for the Proficient Cook...
description: FOR experienced cooks, the fall season for cookbooks and books about food promises to be one of the most interesting and exciting in years. Among the early offerings for cooks and readers alike, look for the following:

title: Court Rules Mullin Must Pay $3.9 Million
description: Chris Mullin, the former St. John's University star who now plays for the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association, has been instructed by a Brooklyn Supreme Court jury to pay $3.9 million in damages to a pedestrian who was permanently injured in a 1985 accident after he was struck by an automobile driven by Mullin.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly GENERAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW OF TECHNICAL CO-OPERATION AMONG DEVELOPING COUNTRIES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Heirlooms Of The Garden
description: LEAD: SWEET tomatoes are abundant, shell beans plump, the new crop of winter squashes just coming in. Now is the climax of the vegetable gardener's year, but for those whose passion is heirloom vegetables, the year is also just beginning. Fall is the time to collect seeds from the best and the brightest for next year's crop.

title: 25 Films Chosen for the National Registry
description: In accordance with the National Film Preservation Act passed last year by Congress, the Library of Congress today issued a list of 25 American films that will be placed on the National Film Registry as ''culturally, historically or esthetically significant.''

title: 220 DC-10 Engines Are to Be Inspected For Possible Defects
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today ordered inspections of 220 jet engines like the one involved in the crash landing of a United Airlines DC-10 in Iowa that killed 112 people two months ago.

title: Haiti's Chief Cuts Sentence of Duvalier Aide
description: The life sentence of the chief of Francois Duvalier's secret police has been commuted to 30 years in prison, a state-run newspaper said today.

title: Strong Sales to China
description: China continues to be a substantial buyer of United States farm products this year, the Agriculture Department reports. The value of commodity sales to China are still expected to be around $1.5 billion in the fiscal year that runs through Sept. 30, up from $613 million in 1987-88, the department's Economic Research Service said Monday. Wheat and cotton have been the main United States items bought by China. After China's crackdown on student dissidents in June, there was widespread speculation that trade would decline.

title: Jackson Tells Bensonhurst School to Reaffirm Rights Effort
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told a crowd of cheering students at a high school in the Bensonhurst area yesterday that after the killing of a black teen-ager there last month, they had an important opportunity to reaffirm the victories of the civil rights movement.

title: McDonald's Hopes Pizza Will Be the Next McHit
description: After several years trying to develop a pizza-making operation fast and good enough to satisfy its customers, the McDonald's Corporation has begun to test-market a product.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Tina Turner - 50?

title: Results Plus
description: TRACK AND FIELD Berger Upsets Lewis: Andreas Berger of Austria upset Carl Lewis in the 100-meter sprint yesterday at an international meet in New Delhi. Berger was timed in 10.46 seconds to Lewis's 10.47 on a hot, humid evening at the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium.

title: Lawrence Marks, 64, Corporation Executive
description: Lawrence I. Marks, former chief financial officer of the Culbro Corporation, a manufacturer of tobacco, candy, health and beauty aids and other products, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Saturday at his summer home in New London, N.H. He was 64 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: OPPOSITION FORMS IN EAST GERMANY
description: The largest of several new groups formed to campaign for change in East Germany announced today that it had applied to field candidates in parliamentary elections next May as the first countrywide opposition organization.

title: HEADS FOR THE U.S.
description: The fiercest hurricane to rake the northeastern Caribbean in a decade sideswiped the Bahamas yesterday and began swirling toward the United States after damaging tens of thousands of homes and causing billions of dollars of damage.

title: U.S. Securities Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, despite economic reports that were better than expected, while the ''junk bond'' market staged a rally after losing ground last week.

title: 25 Cinematic Treasures
description: The Best Years of Our Lives (1946); director, William Wyler; starring Fredric March, Myrna Loy and Dana Andrews. American World War II veterans try to readjust to civilian life. Casablanca (1942); Michael Curtiz; Humphrey Bogart, Ingrid Bergman and Claude Rains. Everybody comes to Rick's. Citizen Kane (1941); Orson Welles; Orson Welles, Joseph Cotten and Everett Sloane. The rise and fall of a newspaper publisher who resembles William Randolph Hearst. The Crowd (1928); King Vidor; James Murray and Eleanor Boardman. A silent film about a down-and-out couple in the city. Dr. Strangelove (or, How I Leaned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb) (1964); Stanley Kubrick; Peter Sellers, George C. Scott and Sterling Hayden. A nuclear-era comedy about the Doomsday machine. The General (1927); directed by and starring Buster Keaton. Silent comedy about a stolen train and spies during the Civil War. Gone With the Wind (1939); Victor Fleming; Vivien Leigh, Clark Gable, Leslie Howard and Olivia de Havilland. Rhett Butler, Scarlett O'Hara and the burning of Atlanta. The Grapes of Wrath (1940); John Ford; Henry Fonda and Jane Darwell. John Steinbeck's dustbowl ballad. High Noon (1952); Fred Zinnemann; Gary Cooper, Grace Kelly. Sheriff searches for support among townspeople who foresake him when vengeful Frank Miller comes to town. Intolerance (1916); D. W. Griffith; Lillian Gish, Robert Harron and Mae Marsh. Epic silent melodrama of bigotry from Babylonian times to the present. The Learning Tree (1969); Gordon Parks; Kyle Johnson and Alex Clarke. Growing up black in Kansas. Color. The Maltese Falcon (1941); John Huston; Humphrey Bogart, Mary Astor, Sydney Greenstreet and Peter Lorre. Dashiell Hammett's detective drama about the stuff that dreams are made of. Mr. Smith Goes to Washington (1939); Frank Capra; James Stewart, Jean Arthur and Claude Rains. An idealistic young Senator finds corruption in Washington. Modern Times (1936); directed by and starring Charlie Chaplin, with Paulette Goddard. Silent comedy about the machine age. Nanook of the North (1921); Robert Flaherty's silent documentary about Eskimos. On the Waterfront (1954); Elia Kazan; Marlon Brando, Eva Marie Saint, Karl Malden, Lee J. Cobb and Rod Steiger. Organized crime on the New York docks and a misfit who could have been a contender. The Searchers (1956); John Ford; John Wayne, Jeffrey Hunter, Vera Miles and Natalie Wood. Old West tale of a search for a girl kidnapped by Indians. Color. Singin' in the Rain (1952); Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen; starring Gene Kelly, Debbie Reynolds, Donald O'Connor and Jean Hagen. Musical about Hollywood as the talkies arrive. Color. Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937). Walt Disney's first full-length animated feature. Color. Some Like It Hot (1959); Billy Wilder; Jack Lemmon, Marilyn Monroe and Tony Curtis. Two male witnesses to a mob massacre hide out in an all-girl band. Star Wars (1977); George Lucas; Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher. Luke Skywalker battles Darth Vader and the evil empire. Color. Sunrise (1927); F.W. Murnau; George O'Brien and Janet Gaynor. Silent film about a farmer planning to kill his wife for another woman. Sunset Boulevard (1950); Billy Wilder; Gloria Swanson, William Holden and Erich von Stroheim. Silent-film star Norma Desmond after the pictures got small. Vertigo (1958); Alfred Hitchcock; James Stewart and Kim Novak. Thriller about detective who falls for woman he stalks. Color. The Wizard of Oz (1939); Victor Fleming; Judy Garland, Ray Bolger, Bert Lahr and Jack Haley. I don't believe we're in Kansas anymore, Toto. Color.

title: Season Ends as a Profitable One for Many Baseball Farm Clubs
description: In a sport where buses are as much a staple as cramped clubhouses and $11 a day in meal money, not many Class A baseball teams fly to their games. But the Mets of Pittsfield, Mass., flew to a playoff game recently and by all accounts they deserved it.

title: Yields Down On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday.

title: Witness Calls Garcia's Wife Power Behind Congressman
description: Robert Garcia's wife, Jane Lee Garcia, was known in political and business circles as ''the real Congressman,'' a former executive of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday at the bribery trial of the seven-term Representative from the Bronx and his wife.

title: GPA Group to Buy 12 Airbus Planes
description: Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, said GPA Group Ltd., an Irish aircraft leasing company, would acquire 12 A321 airliners, with delivery set for 1996. It gave no financial details, but industry officials said the list price for an A321 was $45 million.

title: Bridge
description: After a battle down to the last few deals here tonight, the Dutch women's team qualified for the final of the Venice Trophy world championship contest. After trailing the West German team by 18 international match points going into the final session of 16 deals, the team gained 39 to win by 21. The turning point came when the star German pair had a disastrous misunderstanding, losing 1,700 by playing in four clubs doubled with a 2-1 trump fit, rejecting an 8-4 fit in hearts.

title: Relief Agencies Gear Up to Help Victims of Storm
description: As reports of devastation caused by Hurricane Hugo continued to pour in from Puerto Rico and other Caribbean islands, government and voluntary relief agencies geared up yesterday for a vast effort to assist the victims with medicine, food, shelter and money.

title: Joining the Wranglers at the Circle Z
description: IN the morning sun, the sandstone walls of the canyon glowed yellow, orange and a dozen shades of red. A gnarled mesquite or a cactus jutted out here and there from a crack in the rock wall. I felt at home in the saddle after a week of daily riding, and I scarcely glanced at my horse, Butterfly, a lively chestnut mare with flaxen mane and tail. The landscape on every side made me catch my breath. The sure-footed Butterfly followed a few feet behind Richard, one of the Circle Z wranglers who sat on his horse with the straight back and easy grace of generations of cowboys. Behind us were eight more guests from the Circle Z Ranch, about 60 miles south of Tucson, Ariz., making their way along the winding trail that led though the canyon.

title: New FICO Issue Of $665 Million
description: The Financing Corporation, an arm of the Federal Home Loan Bank system, yesterday priced through competitive bidding $665 million in 8.6 percent bonds due Sept. 26, 2019, through Salomon Brothers, which purchased the entire issue.

title: Storm Cut Across the Economic Lines
description: The two extremes of San Juan's social spectrum - the shantytowns of the poor and the oceanfront condominiums of the wealthy - appeared to suffer the most from the hurricane that swept across Puerto Rico on Monday.

title: WINE TALK
description: SOME people from the Robert Keenan Winery turned up in New York last week to plug their merlot wine. The California winery, on the slopes of Spring Mountain, overlooking the Napa Valley, makes three wines - chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon and merlot - and is especially proud of the third.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PESTO sauce, among the most glorious exports of Genoa, has myriad uses aside from mixing with pasta. I often use pesto, or some variation of it, as a sauce for grilled fish, cold meat or salads.

title: Citicorp Rates Dip at Auction
description: For the third consecutive week, interest rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Frank's Friends Dispute Suggestions of Demise
description: Friends and colleagues of Representative Barney Frank today disputed suggestions that his chances of political survival were rapidly dimming.

title: Ford Buys A Stake In Jaguar
description: Firing the first shot in what analysts expect to erupt into a bidding war for Jaguar P.L.C., the Ford Motor Company announced today that it had begun buying shares of the troubled British manufacturer of luxury cars.

title: Blockbuster Deal
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, which runs hundreds of video rental stores, said Cox Cable Communications had agreed to buy one million Blockbuster common shares at $15 each. It said Cox Cable had also signed a letter of intent to operate 100 Blockbuster video superstores.

title: Lawyer Denies Police Bensonhurst Account
description: The lawyer for a defendant in the killing of a black youth in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn denied yesterday that his client had told the police that he saw another defendant shoot at the teen-ager.

title: Judge Fines a Jersey Polluter $3.2 Million
description: A Federal judge today fined a chemical-storage company $3.2 million for systematically polluting coastal waters and harshly criticized the company and environmental officials for inaction.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Malta, the airline of the Republic of Malta, ordered three Boeing 737-500 jetliners for about $90 million.

title: August Home Construction Dropped 5%
description: Housing construction, depressed by a jump in mortgage rates, fell by 5 percent in August, the Government said today in a report many analysts viewed as only a temporary setback for the housing industry.

title: New Products From Next Inc.
description: Next Inc. stepped up its campaign to capture a chunk of the business market today, announcing two new products and promoting a deal with the International Business Machines Corporation. Steven Jobs, who founded

title: After the Maples, The Golden Tamarack
description: THERE'S a tree in Lyme, our New Hampshire village, that serves as an infallible guide. Set on the village common, it's the first large maple visitors see as they drive into town. In early September, somewhere between the first frost and the beginning of the foliage forecasts on the nightly news, a leaf toward the top will take on a barely detectable tinge of red. Immediately, as if by magic, a car with out-of-state plates will stop, and out will step an excited middle-aged couple carrying cameras - to we natives, ever sensitive to nature's portents, an even surer sign of autumn than that first crimson blush.

title: Ferranti Unit Under Inquiry
description: The Defense Department said today that it is investigating a Pennsylvania company bought two years ago by Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., a British electronics company. A Pentagon spokesman, Fred Hoffman, was asked about reports that the British military contractor had lost up to $235 million through questionable contracts it inherited in a takeover of the International Signal and Control Company, based in Lancaster, Pa., in 1987.

title: A Legacy Revealed In Food and Song
description: LEAD: Two little trees have been born on my ranch, Two little trees that look like twins, And from my house I see them all alone Because that is how God wanted for the two of them to be born. From the album ''Canciones de Mi Padre,'' by Linda Ronstadt.

title: Coats and No Coats
description: New York experiences many temperatures but only two seasons, Coats and No Coats, and they just changed. In spring and summer, commuters can go to work carrying nothing more than the paper and maybe an umbrella. The windswept rain yesterday demanded more than umbrellas.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from my second visit to the Grampian and other areas of Scotland in two years, I read the articles about Scotland (Travel, July 16) with particular interest.

title: Hanover's Debt Rating
description: Officials at debt-rating agencies said yesterday that they had not raised the investment ratings of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation despite the banking company's announcement Monday that it would sell control its business finance unit for $1.28 billion and raise $620 million through the sale of new stock.

title: Review/Theater; Identity Loss in 'Imperceptible Mutabilities'
description: Behind the imposing title ''Imperceptible Mutabilities in the Third Kingdom,'' there is the voice of a thoughtful young playwright, Suzan-Lori Parks. In a quartet of thematically related scenes (at BACA Downtown in Brooklyn), the author demonstrates a historical perspective and a theatrical versatility. The title of the piece is entirely applicable. In this study of the black experience from slavery to the present, the changes are almost invisible - like geological shifts in the earth.

title: Oompah Time in Hermann, Mo.
description: DISGUSTED with their life in Philadelphia and hoping to create a Teutonic empire in the wilderness, a band of hardy German-American settlers founded a new town, Hermann, in the rolling hills of central Missouri just before Christmas in 1837. The site they chose, on the banks of the Missouri River, must have reminded them of the Rhine.

title: College Housing Headache: Research Equipment
description: The increasing sophistication and cost of scientific and engineering research equipment is straining the ability of the nation's major colleges and universities to house and maintain the devices properly, officials in higher education and the Federal Government say.

title: New York Games May Join Grand Prix
description: The New York Games, an artistic if not financial success in its debut as an international track and field meet last July, would become affiliated with the worldwide Grand Prix circuit next summer if the International Amateur Athletic Federation approves a measure designed to restructure the circuit.

title: Book Notes
description: Harper the Winner

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Information Services Co., a unit of American Express Co., named Louise M. Parent general counsel.

title: Forestville, Calif.
description: WHEN you walk into Brother Juniper's Bakery in Forestville, Calif., it always smells a little bit like harvest time.

title: KEY RATES
Connaught's Stock
description: Connaught Biosciences Inc. rose again today on continued speculation that Institut Merieux S.A. of France would try to top a bid of $764 million (Canadian), or about $644 million (United States), from Ciba-Geigy Ltd. and the Chiron Corporation. Connaught shares rose 62.5 Canadian cents, to $32.375, on the Toronto Stock Exchange - $2.375 higher than the offer from Ciba and Chiron. Before the offer, Connaught had planned a stock swap with Merieux to create a new company that would be 51.4 percent owned by Merieux.

title: Bond to Sell Breweries In a $1.9 Billion Deal
description: The Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond announced today that he had reached a multibillion-dollar deal to sell half of his brewing operations to Lion Nathan Ltd., a New Zealand brewer and retailer.

title: Whose Millennium Is It Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Communists and Foes Back a Multiparty Hungary
description: The Communist Party and six opposition groups reached partial agreement Monday night on arrangements for Hungary's transition from a one-party state to a multiparty parliamentary system.

title: Vietnamese Leader, Assailing the West, Ignites Fear at Home
description: The Vietnamese leadership has intensified a crackdown in ideological and intellectual life, warning against Western subversion in the language of the cold war.

title: Namibian Election Rivals Say Swapo Tortured Its Prisoners
description: As it begins campaigning for elections here in November, the South-West Africa People's Organization has found itself combating politically damaging allegations about its treatment of dissidents in exile.

title: Abducted West Bank Mayor Rescued by an Angry Crowd
description: A mayor in the Israeli-occupied West Bank was abducted by Arabs suspected of collaborating with the Israeli authorities Monday night but freed after hundreds of residents attacked the house where he was held, witnesses said today.

title: Gertrude T. Friedberg, Playwright, 81
description: Gertrude Tonkonogy Friedberg, a playwright and an author, died of cancer on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: Experts Say Tyson Would Not Beat Louis
description: Site fees for Mike Tyson's title defenses have diminished by millions since the Las Vegas Hilton paid $7 million for his bout with Frank Bruno in February because of the scarcity of credible opposition for the heavyweight champion.

title: WASTE STUDY SET AT WEAPONS PLANT
description: The Department of Energy said today that it would begin studying how to dispose of toxic solvents stored at the Rocky Flats plant near Denver under an agreement with the Environmental Protection Agency and the State of Colorado.

title: Ryan Honored Again
description: Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers, who struck out his 5,000th major league batter on Aug. 22, has been named recipient of the American League's Joe Cronin Award for significant achievement in 1989. Ryan also won the first Cronin award in 1973 while pitching for the California Angels and becomes the first player to win it twice.(AP)

title: When Spain Ruled the Southwest
description: DRESSED as an 18th-century Spanish colonist, Della Roybal, a volunteer at the Old Cienega Village Museum south of Santa Fe, thrusts along-handled paddle into the horno, or beehive oven, and withdraws a paddleful of plump, perfectly browned miniature loaves. The aroma of freshly baked bread wafts around the adobe courtyard, and like a pied piper in black skirts and white lace, the baker collects a crowd on her way to the sale table. At $1 a loaf, it moves quickly.

title: Wisconsin-Palestinian Link Is Praised and Criticized
description: The student government at the University of Wisconsin here says it is forming one of the first student-to-student relationships between a Palestinian university and an American one.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: SCOTT CARSBERG, a 26-year-old from West Seattle, came home a few months ago. He had been cooking in Europe; now he cooks at Settebello in Seattle, as high a high-end Italian restaurant as the Pacific Northwest can boast.

title: Review/Film; Tomatoes Smash, Music Swells and Lovers Love
description: The opening sequence of ''Queen of Hearts'' revels in its own melodrama.

title: Kwang Lim Koh, 68, Envoy, Dies
description: Kwang Lim Koh, a scholar and diplomat who was professor of political science at Central Connecticut State University in New Britain for the last 23 years, died Sunday at his home in New Haven. He was 68 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The World Bank yesterday announced the pricing and terms of a $1.5 billion global bond issue. Not only is the sale the organization's largest, but analysts also said it would be the first offering structured for sale and trade simultaneously in the leading world markets.

title: SUNY and CUNY Plan No Increases in Tuition
description: With both Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature eager to avoid a replay of this spring's protests against proposed tuition increases, administrators at New York's public universities said today that they did not plan to seek any rise next year.

title: Mookie's No Longer a Spectator
description: The routines have regained a lovely and long-lost rhythm. Trips to the ball park are now unfailingly followed by trips to the plate. Mookie Wilson's name is now in the lineup and not just over his locker. And so all the small rituals -batting practice and the shagging of fly balls - have assumed a purpose beyond being a way to kill an early evening.

title: I.B.M. Data Will Speed Programs
description: Filling in one of the final pieces of its vision of computing in the 1990's, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a broad range of software-development tools designed to speed the process of writing and managing new programs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The people on the islands respect these storms. When they have warnings they take them seriously. People in the United States should do likewise.'' - Lee Grenci, Pennsylvania State University meteorologist. [ A1:6. ]

title: With Koch Out, Giuliani Tailors Appeal to the Right
description: Changing a strategy that was drawn up with Mayor Edward I. Koch in mind as the likely Democratic opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani and his advisers are now trying to appeal not so much to liberal Democrats as to conservative and independent ones.

title: On Appeal, San Diego Club Recovers the America's Cup
description: A New York appeals court ruled yesterday that the San Diego Yacht Club could keep the America's Cup, which it won a year ago on the water but then lost in court.

title: Vietnamese General Says Rebels Have 23,000 Troops in Cambodia
description: A week before Vietnamese forces are scheduled to pull out of Cambodia, a senior Vietnamese general said today that the guerrilla coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-backed Government in Phnom Penh has 37,000 soldiers, of whom 23,000 are currently inside the territory of Cambodia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Morgan Goes to B.S.B.
description: J.P. Morgan & Company yesterday assigned its advertising account, which had been at Doyle Graf Raj before that agency dissolved, to Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. And B.S.B. plans to work internationally for Morgan, which used Doyle almost entirely to advertise its private banking services to wealthy Americans. ''As financial markets become more global, the need for this type of representation becomes more apparent,'' said B.S.B.'s chairman, Carl Spielvogel. Della Femina, McNamee WCRS and TBWA Advertising were the two other finalists for the $10 million to $15 million account.

title: Campaign Trail; Giuliani Seeking D'Amato's Support
description: The D'Amato-Giuliani political minuet began yesterday and is likely to end later this week with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato pledging his support to Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose mayoral candidacy he tried to derail by backing Ronald S. Lauder in the Republican primary.

title: Urging Testy Drivers to Be Easy Riders
description: It is not much fun commuting on Connecticut highways, with their daily delays because of construction projects and jackknifed tractor-trailers. No wonder drivers get testy.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Air Strike In Australia Causes Delays

title: Corrections
description: An article and picture captions in Science Times yesterday about Alaskan eagles, and a related front-page caption, misidentified a biologist and her institution. She is Karolann Kemenosh-Longo of the Arctic Animal Hospital of Anchorage, of which the Bird Treatment and Learning Center is a part.

title: POWELL SEES RISKS IN WAR ON DRUGS
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, President Bush's nominee to be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that involving the armed forces in the war on drugs would be risky but would not lead to another Vietnam.

title: The Unavoidable 'German Question'
description: LEAD: For several decades it has been conventional wisdom that the ''German Question,'' if not dead, was likely to remain dormant for the foreseeable future.

title: Venus May Tell Us How to Escape Its Fate; The Next Giant Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Leslie Cole Is Dead at 94; Guided Growth of Reader's Digest
description: Albert Leslie Cole, the first general manager of Reader's Digest and the engineer of its expansion into international editions, books and records, died Tuesday after a brief illness at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 94 years old.

title: Parole Is Denied In Slaying of Actor
description: The State Parole Board denied parole yesterday to John Bonizio, who has served six years of a maximum 18-year prison sentence in the killing of an actor.

title: Brady Plan Is Forcing Bank Loss
description: The wrap-up last week of an accord to provide debt relief to Mexico is forcing a new round of losses at major American banks.

title: Senate Panel Votes More East Bloc Aid
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a nearly $1.2 billion, three-year aid package to Poland and Hungary today, adding to the chorus of criticism from Congressional Democrats that the Bush Administration has been too passive in reacting to the developments in Eastern Europe.

title: Pickens Raises Koito Stake
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas corporate raider, said today that he would raise his stake in the Koito Manufacturing Company and renewed his demand for a seat on the Japanese concern's board.

title: Man Found Guilty of 13 'Night Stalker' Murders
description: A man was convicted of 13 murders and 30 other felonies today by a jury that decided he was the Night Stalker whose attacks terrified Southern California in 1985.

title: Rebel Rockets and Explosion From Truck Kill 12 in Kabul
description: At least 12 people were killed and 17 wounded today when rockets launched by rebels rained on the capital and a military truck exploded.

title: Review/Dance; Poland's National Folk Troupe Rejoices in Song
description: When members of Slask stepped proudly forward in a polonaise as the curtain rose on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the performers' fervor was both unmistakable and admirable. Near the evening's conclusion, a sense of love of country and folk tradition was again communicated when the company offered a dignified cracovienne while the backdrop glowed with a slide projection representing the ancient towers of Cracow, the city after which that dance is named.

title: Personal Health
description: Last June, four years after she was first treated for cancer, my mother-in-law made out a ''living will,'' specifying her desire not to be given any means of life support should she become terminally ill or permanently unconscious.

title: A Soviet General's Second Thoughts
description: In 1968, Ivan D. Yershov was a young Soviet general serving as second-in-command of the Warsaw Pact forces that invaded Czechoslovakia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When we landed, we were pounced upon by about 15 tourists. They said, 'Please get food! Please get water! Please help us! They're looting. We've seen police looting. We've seen National Guard looting.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl will begin Thursday, with the United States opposing Brazil.

title: Nixon's Birthday a Holiday
description: This Orange County community where former President Richard M. Nixon was born has declared his birthday, Jan. 9, a holiday for its 100 municipal employees. ''We're not here to judge history - we're here to recognize it,'' Mayor Henry Wedaa said.

title: Tax Reform Reform
description: Tax reduction has worked. Despite liberal grumping throughout the 80's, the Kemp-Roth tax cut followed by the Packwood rate reform has produced higher tax revenues and a longer prosperity than most optimists envisioned.

title: CARIBBEAN TRAVEL BEGINS TO REBOUND
description: Air and sea travel slowly returned to normal yesterday in the Caribbean, as Hurricane Hugo continued moving away from the tropical resort islands and toward the United States.

title: The Promise of Chancellor Fernandez
description: The selection of Joseph Fernandez, Superintendent of Schools in Dade County, Florida, as New York City's new schools chancellor is an encouraging sign for the renewal of the city's troubled school system.

title: Tyson May Sell Holly Farms Units
description: Tyson Foods Inc. said it was considering the sale of two divisions of the Holly Farms Corporation, which it acquired from Conagra Inc. in July for $1.29 billion, to raise about $300 million to ease the debt load from the takeover.

title: Chicago Journal; For Fans of the Cubs, The Bubble Defies Fate
description: Only the true believers can see it. But it is there. It is as vivid as the texture of hope, as bright as the color of dreams. It wafted into town off Lake Michigan several weeks ago, blown by a magical breeze. And it has grown larger with the passing of each September afternoon.

title:
GARDENING;
After the Harvest, Joys of the Cleanup
description: LEAD: THE frost isn't exactly on the pumpkin - if it were, the pumpkin would rot - but we will be talking serious autumn before very long: the time to finish the harvest, plant the bulbs and, at long last, clean up the place before the snows start to fall.

title: 3 Die as Jetliner Plunges Into Bay Off La Guardia
description: A USAir jetliner taking off for Charlotte, N.C., from La Guardia Airport late last night skidded off the end of a rain-slicked runway and plunged into the bay near Rikers Island, killing 3 and injuring 51 of the 62 people aboard, police and fire officials said.

title: Bailout Urged For Hospitals With Losses
description: Foreshadowing what is likely to be a divisive debate in Albany next year, a representative of New York City's private hospitals called today for a $300 million bailout of many financially troubled hospitals.

title: Lionel Corp.
description: The board of the Lionel Corporation said it plans to review the $150 million takeover offer from Robert I. Toussie at its next meeting. The board's decision was contained in a letter last Friday to the New York real estate developer and disclosed today in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Toussie's offer for the New York-based toy retailer was scheduled to expire last Friday, but he said he would consider extending it.

title: Parent & Child
description: JOHN HORNICKEL looked up from his dinner plate one evening to see his 5-year-old daughter, Jane, staring intently at a small dark object darting along the edge of the table.

title: In a Houseboat, a City So Near Seems Far Away
description: LEAD: TEN minutes north of downtown, where Lake Union wedges a large thumb print of water into this city's densest neighborhoods, is a community that people here speak of almost poetically. To live on a houseboat is to come home to a floating world where blue heron and Canada geese are one's neighbors. It is to be in the city, but separated from it.

title: Fashion Industry Executives Find Situation Exasperating
