description: The Calendar of Events in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday gave an incorrect closing date for the exhibition ''Maurice Freedman: Paintings, 1929-1982'' at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. The show continues through Sunday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ambase Corp., a financial services company, named Christopher C. York vice president of planning and marketing.

title: Hjelm's (Jim) Private Collecion Ltd(O) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Murry Dickson, Pitcher, 73
description: Murry Dickson, a pitcher who compiled a 172-181 record and a 3.66 earned run average with 5 teams in 18 major league seasons, died from complications of emphysema today at Bethany Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived near Leavenworth, Kan.

title: Federal Express Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter's net included a gain of $18.1 million, or 34 cents a share, for the effect of a change in income tax accounting.

title: Boston Celtics LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Officials in New York Region Begin Preparing for the Storm
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, already soggy from torrential rains on Tuesday and Wednesday, will experience flooding if Hurricane Hugo follows its current track and passes over the Northeast Friday night.

title: Miguel Manteo, a Puppet Maker And Theater Patriarch, Dies at 80
description: Miguel (Papa Mike) Manteo, a puppeteer and the patriarch of the Manteo Familiy Sicilian Marionette Theater, died Sept. 13 in Clove Lakes Nursing Home on Staten Island. He was 80 years old.

title: Wise Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: Figures are in Canadian funds

title: Stewart's Leg Broken
description: Al Stewart, a scrappy 25-year-old left wing for the Devils, fractured his left leg in a training camp accident yesterday at South Mountain Arena in West Orange, N.J., and is lost to the team indefinitely. Stewart apparently caught a skate blade and twisted his leg as he fell backward to the ice.

title: Edwards (A.G.) Inc(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said share earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend payable on Oct. 2.

title: DeGaetani Memorial
description: A memorial service for the mezzo-soprano Jan DeGaetani will be held next Friday at noon at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street. Friends and colleagues will speak, and the Juilliard String Quartet will play. Miss DeGaetani died of leukemia on Sept. 15 at the age of 56.

title: 3 Airlines to Match American Fare Increase
description: Three major airlines moved yesterday to match American Airlines in raising fares typically used by business travelers, and other carriers were considering similar increases.

title: Congress Adds to Penalties of Resident Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese in Deal for 10% of Tiffany
description: Tiffany & Company, the jewelry maker whose fine products in robin's-egg-blue packages are status symbols around the world, said yesterday that Mitsukoshi Ltd., one of Japan's leading department stores, would buy about 10 percent of its shares.

title: American Greetings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FPS Computing reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Beijing Journal; Revel Planned Where Goddess of Democracy Fell
description: Near the spot in Tiananmen Square where the Goddess of Democracy held vigil over the democracy movement several months ago, the Government has put up what it regards as a more appropriate mascot of China: a giant statue showing a worker, a farmer, a soldier and an intellectual united in a heroic revolutionary pose.

title: United Bankers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bush Rejects Coffee Appeal
description: President Bush is refusing a request by President Virgilio Barco of Colombia to reinstate a one-year Colombian coffee export program that has been beneficial to Colombian farmers, the White House says.

title: Skipper's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Art; Wishing Cocteau a Happy 100th Birthday
description: Even at the Pierpont Morgan Library, which customarily has the touch of gold in these matters, Jean Cocteau (1889-1963) is not the easiest of subjects for a 100th birthday exhibition. Heaven knows, there is plenty of material. No one role was ever enough for Cocteau, who for 60 years was active in his native France as poet, playwright, novelist, magazine editor, aphorist, autobiographer, polemicist, draftsman, caricaturist, poetical movie maker and leader of taste.

title:
About Real Estate;
Condos Replace Pool Clubs in Canarsie
description: LEAD: Two large condominium projects in Canarsie, Brooklyn, are bringing new housing to an area that has not seen major residential development since the early 1960's.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BRONZE MENAGERIE

title: Devastated by Hurricane, Montserrat Starts to Rebuild
description: ''I always thought of wind as something you can hear and feel,'' Kenneth Allen said today as he looked from his doorstep at the remains of this devastated Caribbean island, hard hit by Hurricane Hugo. ''I never thought you could see wind.''

title: Glaxo Holdings Plc reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents one Glaxo ordinary share. Results are in U.S. dollars; the 1989 figures were converted at an exchange rate of $1.55 to the pound sterling, which was the rate prevailing at June 30, 1989 and the exchange rate used for conversion of the 1988 figures was $1.71 to the pound sterling, which was prevailing at June 30, 1988.

title: Indian 'Night Ragas'
description: Pandit Pran Nath, the Indian vocalist and composer, will present ''Night Ragas,'' the second part of his ''Raga Cycle,'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, tonight at 9 o'clock. The ensemble accompanying the singer includes La Monte Young and Marian Zazeela, who will sing and play tamburas, and Ray Spiegel, who will play the tabla. Tickets are $14. Information: 662-2133.

title: Darryl? Or Davey? Or Both?
description: In olden days, a gossip columnist named Walter Winchell had pet phrases for people who were not getting along: for professional feuds he wrote, ''Don't invite Martin Mogul and Stanley Star to the same party,'' and for personal estrangements he would write, ''I hear Liz and Dick are pffft,'' as in cat-fighting. Or Liz and Eddie. Whoever.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the 1988 loss was the result of a rate settlement of its New England Power Co. unit, resulting in an after-tax writedown of $179 milllion for the 12 months.

title: The News Is Gorby, Not Gobie
description: LEAD: When I arrived at my office last Tuesday, I had more than a dozen messages on my desk from television, newspaper and magazine reporters. Every call was about Barney Frank.

title: Stabilizing the Dollar; Coordination Process of Group of 7 Is Under Pressure as Allies Convene
description: Foreign exchange traders and economists will be looking for a new sign of commitment to a stable dollar policy when the United States and its economic allies meet tomorrow in Washington.

title: Where the Elk and the Diplomats Roam
description: In choosing Grand Teton National Park as a setting to talk about arms control with Soviet diplomats this weekend, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will be showing off one of the most dramatic places in the American West but also an area that is in conflict with itself.

title: Nichols (S.E.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,281,000, or 91 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,171,000, or $1.09 a share, for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $464,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $771,000, or 16 cents a share, for the 6 months. d-Net income

title: Full Force of Storm Hits South Carolina
description: Surging in power and speed, Hurricane Hugo hit Charleston, S.C., shortly before midnight last night, lashing the coastal city with 135-mile-an-hour winds, toppling trees, snapping power lines and cartwheeling telephone poles down streets.

title: Facts of Museum Life For Prospective Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Union Votes to Strike
description: Members of the state's largest health-care workers union voted overwhelmingly yesterday to strike at 56 hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City area on Oct. 4 unless a contract settlement is reached. Members of the union, Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees, which includes nurses aides, blood bank technologists, orderlies and X-ray technicians, have been working without a contract since June. The vote of 51,000 union members yesterday was 10 to 1 in favor of an unlimited strike next month. The workers want raises of 8.5 percent; the League of Voluntary Hospitals has offered 4.5 in the first two years and 4 percent in the third year.

title: Reform New York's Judicial Reform
description: For years, reformers in New York City have pointed to the screening panel used by Manhattan's Democratic Party as a model for choosing judges. But a furor over this year's choices spotlights the need for more extensive reform.

title: Books of The Times; An Era Revealed in a Perfect Butler's Imperfections
description: The Remains of the Day By Kazuo Ishiguro 245 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Giants vs. Cards: Who Is for Real?
description: The Giants, who have started the season with a 2-0 record, may be for real, though it is too early to tell. But is there any way the Phoenix Cardinals, 2-0 after two road games, can also be contenders?

title: Arafat Stops Short of Backing Egypt's Peace Plan
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, withheld a direct, public endorsement of Egypt's newest Middle East initiative today, but said he was ready for a discussion with Israel.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Peaceful Coexistence

title: Bridge
description: An exciting day of world team championship play here today ended with both titles in the balance.

title: INSIDE
description: Saudis Behead 16 Saudi Arabia beheaded 16 pro-Iranian Kuwaitis in Mecca in connection with bombings and other acts of terrorism during the Muslim pilgrimage in July. Page A8. Auschwitz Plan Advances Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, who renounced a pact to move a convent from the Auschwitz death camp, has endorsed the move. Page A3. Curb on Death Row Appeals A committee of Federal judges created at the behest of the Chief Justice urged strict limits on the many appeals now commonly filed by prisoners sentenced to death. Page B20. Bank Uses New Power The Bankers Trust Company will be the first to use the new power granted banks to manage the sale of an issue of corporate bonds. Page D1.

title: Brooklyn Neighborhood Not a Cradle of Racists; Scapegoat Community
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Rejects Nixon Effort to Stop Show
description: Lawyers for Richard M. Nixon have tried to keep ABC from broadcasting a drama based on Mr. Nixon's last months as President, but the network and the program's sponsor, A.T.&T., said today that the program would be broadcast as scheduled next month.

title: Angels Lose in 17th On Sacrifice by Jacoby
description: Brook Jacoby hit a sacrifice fly in the bottom of the 17th inning to score Tommy Hinzo, who was pinch-running, and give the Cleveland Indians a 5-4 victory over the Angels tonight.

title: Bronx Racial Attack Reported
description: A black teen-ager shot and seriously wounded a white 19-year-old early yesterday in the Bronx in what the police said was apparently a racially motivated attack. They said it was prompted by an argument in which the wounded man's white friend had been told, ''You don't belong here.''

title: IBC Publications Adds Donoghue
description: IBC USA Publications Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the Donoghue Organization Inc., which publishes Donoghue's Moneyletter, a mutual fund newsletter, and Donoghue's Mutual Fund Almanac, a directory of mutual funds. Terms of the deal were not announced.

title: Review/Jazz; Elmer Gill With Drums And Bass
description: Though New York is home for the world's best jazz musicians, club bookings here often rely on the same group of players, over and over again. The arrival of the pianist Elmer Gill, who last played New York in the early 1950's as a member of the Lionel Hampton orchestra, underscores the fact that out there fine musicians lurk.

title: What's Ahead
description: Cautioning that predicting the course of a hurricane is chancy at best, meteorologists yesterday gave this estimate of the likely path and impact of Hurricane Hugo. They said the storm was likely to lose intensity once it moved inland.

title: Dining Out Guide: Off Museum Mile
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Azzurro ** (Sept. 26, 1986), 1625 Second Avenue, at 84th Street (517-7068) - Azzurro is a family-run Sicilian restaurant that offers some very good pastas and regional seafood. Among appetizers to consider are charred fresh endive tied with strands of scallion and homemade mozzarella in a wrapping of prosciutto. Pastas, the highlight of the menu, include bucatini with sardines, wild fennel and pine nuts. Two recommended entrees are tuna Sicilian style and charcoal-grilled baby lamb chops. Appetizers are $6 to $8.50, pastas $11 to $13.50, entrees $14 to $21. Hours: 5:30 to 10 P.M. Sunday to Thursday, until midnight Friday and Saturday. Erminia * (Jan. 30, 1987), 250 East 83d Street (517-3410) - Wood-fire grilling is the specialty at Erminia, a snug and romantic Italian restaurant with rustic decor. Two suggested appetizers are the crisply sauteed baby artichokes and fresh mozzarella with roasted red peppers and basil. The wood-fire grill turns out entrees of chicken, lamb, whole lobster, veal chop and skewers of meat and fish. Appetizers are $8.50 to $11.95, entrees $15.95 to $32. Open from 5 to 11 P.M. daily. Le Refuge ** (April 7, 1989), 166 East 82d Street (861-4505) - This intimate country French restaurant has three smartly decorated dining areas. Vegetable terrine set on a refreshing red pepper-tomato coulis and gratineed oysters are appealing starters. Good entrees are lamb chops with dauphine potatoes; salmon in red wine butter , and swordfish in an aromatic Provencal sauce. At lunch, appetizers are $4 to $7.50, entrees $8.50 to $15.50; at dinner, appetizers are $5.50 to $9.50, entrees $16.50 to $23.50. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Saturday, until 4 P.M. Sunday; dinner: 5:30 to 11 P.M. Monday to Saturday, until 9:30 P.M. Sunday. Parioli, Romanissimo ** (April 15, 1988), 24 East 81st Street (288-2391) - Here is a luxurious town-house setting for expensive and generally pleasing Italian cuisine. The stately dining area is set in the former parlor, an ornately plastered, high-ceilinged room. For starters and pasta dishes, the recommended choices are homemade ravioli filled with wild mushrooms, stuffed baby artichokes, and wild-mushroom risotto. The entrees include grilled Dover sole and and garlic-crusted rack of lamb. Appetizers are $12 to $14.50, pastas $18 to $26, entrees $28 to $38. Dinner: 6 to 11 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday. Closed Sunday and Monday. Terrace at the Stanhope Diner's Journal (July 21, 1989), the Stanhope Hotel, 995 Fifth Avenue, at 81st Street (288-5800) - While weather permits, this cafe serves lunch and cocktails alfresco - overlooking Fifth Avenue and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The lunch menu consists of salads, sandwiches, some entree specials and desserts; a half-dozen good wines are available by the glass. Dishes include a colorful salad of warm chicken, goat cheese, and mango and cold poached salmon fillet garnished with capers, onions, and creme fraiche. Lunch dishes are $12 to $18, desserts $6.50 to $8. Hours: Lunch noon to 4 P.M. and cocktails from 4 to 8 P.M. daily.

title: Review/Theater; Four One-Acts by Young Playwrights
description: The four writers in this season's Young Playwrights Festival are among the most talented to emerge in the eight years of the annual series. Their short plays opened last night at Playwrights Horizons (three by other playwrights will be given staged readings in October). As was also true last year, there are definite signs that the young playwrights - they have to be under the age of 19 when they submit their work to the Dramatists Guild competition - are exploring ideas that move far beyond the problems of adolescence.

title: Japan's Boom Continues, And It's Creating Problems
description: Japan's economy is continuing to expand at a robust rate, according to Government figures released today, adding to a growing labor shortage and increasing inflationary pressures.

title: Review/Music; A Benefit Of Wagner Begins A Season
description: Isolde's ''Liebestod,'' the half-crazed outpouring of emotion with which Wagner ended his ''Tristan und Isolde,'' has been a successful staple of Jessye Norman's repertory for many years. Although she has never sung the complete role on any stage, she has handled this fearsome 10-minute challenge with increasing vocal authority and dramatic insight. Still, it is unlikely that Miss Norman has ever given a more entrancing account of the ''Love Death'' than she did on Wednesday evening at the New York Philharmonic's opening night concert, a benefit for the orchestra's pension fund. It was a promising way to begin a season.

title: Dow Jones Bids for Rest Of Telerate
description: Dow Jones & Company moved unexpectedly yesterday to make complete its ownership of Telerate Inc., the rapidly expanding financial information service, with a $576 million offer for the portion of Telerate in public hands. Dow Jones already holds 67 percent of the company.

title: Brooklyn Neighborhood Not a Cradle of Racists
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Antic Duo in Atlantic City: Magic a la Penn and Teller
description: Anatomy of a magic trick: the Amazing Bouncing Bagel Effect is achieved through the use of a table top, which is ordinary in all respects but which happens to be upside down. That way the magicians, who are upside-down themselves, can drop bagels or playing cards or other objects onto the table and make these things appear, to the eye of a similarly inverted television camera, to bounce or fly.

title: Paychex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Mercedes Mile foot race, Fifth Avenue between 62d and 86th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 1 P.M. to 2 P.M. Because of the West End

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 466 money market mutual funds increased by $1.3 billion, to $348.98 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased by $645.4 million, to $84.21 billion. The assets of the 230 general-purpose funds were up by $1.13 billion, to $113.21 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $815.8 million, to $151.56 billion, the institute said.

title: Bank Set To Manage Bond Sale
description: Making quick use of new powers granted by the Federal Reserve Board, the Bankers Trust Company announced plans yesterday to handle the sale of a new issue of ''junk bonds,'' thus becoming the first banking company to manage a public sale of corporate bonds.

title: GPA Group Ltd. Establishes $1.25 Billion Credit Facility
description: One of the largest credit facilities ever raised in the aviation industry has been established by GPA Group Ltd., Shannon, Ireland, an airplane leasing company.

title: Lebanese Legislator Killed by 3 Gunmen On a Street in Beirut
description: A Sunni Muslim member of the Lebanese Parliament was assassinated in West Beirut today, the second prominent Sunni to be killed in four months in the part of the city policed by Syrian soldiers.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Sept. 11 referred incorrectly to the Spinnaker Capital Corporation in Boston. It is a private investment corporation.

title: I. M. Bomba, 90, Dies; A Schieffelin Executive
description: I. M. Bomba, director and consultant to Schieffelin & Company, importers of wine and spirits, died Monday at Moses Ludington Hospital in Ticonderoga, N.Y. He was 90 years old and had suffered a stroke 10 days earlier.

title: Wausau Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Troops Find Looting and Devastation on St. Croix
description: Twelve hundred United States Army troops landed on St. Croix today to restore order to an island devastated by a hurricane, then torn by looting and violence.

title: F.B.I. to Abide by Ruling In Hispanic Agents' Suit
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it would not appeal a sweeping court order intended to eliminate discrimination against Hispanic agents.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Fela at the Ritz

title: Review/Film; Former Teen-Agers Look Back on 50's Fooleries
description: ''Heavy Petting'' is a brief, cheery compendium of teen-age enthusiasms, filtered through the memories of an interesting array of former teen-agers. Though its interviewees range from David Byrne to William Burroughs, the film's heart is firmly planted in the 1950's, when adolescent longings were so fervently at war with social mores.

title: Jack Smith, Film Maker, 57
description: Jack Smith, an independent film maker and theater artist, died of AIDS on Monday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chief Executive Quits At First Bank System
description: The First Bank System, Minnesota's largest banking company, yesterday announced the resignation of DeWalt H. Ankeny Jr. as chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Treasury Issues Decline Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped further in moderately active trading yesterday as concerns about upcoming auctions of new issues prompted traders to sell securities.

title: Questions About Aouita
description: The men's Mercedes Mile down Fifth Avenue tomorrow was hitting a snag yesterday. One of the two dream runners in the 19-man field, Said Aouita of Morocco, holder of the world record at 1,500 meters, was proving to be something of a reluctant competitor for the other one, Abdi Bile of Somalia, the world champion at the distance.

title: Pop/Jazz; Blending Ethnic Music In a Series At Town Hall
description: ''Fusion'' once referred to a heady mixture of the spirit of jazz and the energy of rock. Now it usually describes a kind of slick, predictable pseudo-jazz.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's Department of Puerto Rican Community Affairs in the United States has asked that donations to assist victims of Hurricane Hugo be sent to the American Red Cross or branch offices of three banks that are setting up special accounts for Puerto Rican disaster assistance. The banks are Banco Popular, Banco de Ponce and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Announced that Greg Walker, first baseman, is out for the season. BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed Charley Brown, forward. NETS (NBA) - Signed Purvis Short, forward, to a one-year contract. ORLANDO (NBA) - Signed Nick Anderson, forward, to a four-year contract. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Waived Chris Burkett, wide receiver.

title: Central Illinois Public Service reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
National Service Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums OPEN HOUSE, for children up to age 12 and their parents, from noon to 4 P.M. tomorrow, at the Rhinelander Center Visual and Performing Arts Program, with activities that include puppetry, painting, sculpture, music, rock-theater workshops, clowns and refreshments at the newly renovated building, 350 East 88th Street. Free. Information: 876-0500. CRAFTS FAIR, a festival with craftspeople from around the Northeast, street performers, music and refreshments, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Sunday, at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Admission: $1. Information: (914) 698-0098. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic show with audience participation, with Brian McGovern and Imam, 2 P.M. Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Information: 924-1472. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' a magic, music and comedy show for young children, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sundays, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''FOSSILMANIA,'' participants learn how fossils tell stories of the past, and how to make a fossil for the future, with Prof. G. Ology, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Dairy in Central Park, near 64th Street, north of the Wollman Rink. Reservations required: 397-3165. ''AMAZIN' MARIONETTES,'' a performance by the Leela Puppet Theater, 2 and 3 P.M. Sunday, in Central Park at the Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, at 79th Street. Reservations and information: 772-0210. ''CINDERELLA,'' a show by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the West 72d Street Studios, 131 West 72d Street. Tickets: $4. Reservations required: 874-3297. ''ELSIE PIDDOCK SKIPS IN HER SLEEP,'' a story told by Diane Wolkstein with music by Shirley Keller, a guitarist, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen Statue in Central Park, Fifth Avenue at 72d Street. Free. ''THE WORLD OF TOMORROW,'' an 83-minute documentary reviewing the 1939 World's Fair, and ''A View From the People Wall,'' a 1966 film on the exhibition at the I.B.M. Pavilion at the 1964 World's Fair, 2 P.M tomorrow, at the Queens Museum, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Flushing. Free with admission to the museum by contribution. Information: (718) 592-2405. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828.

title: KEY RATES
Fort Tryon Park Joins the Medieval World
description: Not so long ago or so far away, on a wooded bluff in the small island fief of Manhattan, there appeared troubadours and jesters, knights on horseback and even a dragon. There were colorful pageants and dances, and a marketplace full of exotic foods and wares, not to mention tens of thousands of 20th-century time-travelers.

title: Murdoch to Sell TV Station To Owners of Boston Celtics
description: Under regulatory pressure, Rupert Murdoch has agreed to sell his television station in Boston to the Boston Celtics L.P. While some other teams in the National Basketball Association are owned by media companies, this is the first time a team has bought a television station.

title: United's Income Expected To Cover Cost of Buyout
description: The pilots' union and management group that made a $300-a-share tender offer for the UAL Corporation predicted yesterday that the $7.2 billion in debt needed to finance the takeover of the company's airline could be paid off in eight years from operating income.

title: Jet vs. Dolphins: Anything Goes
description: Giants Stadium, the Orange Bowl, Joe Robbie Stadium - it doesn't matter where they play, the Jets and Dolphins produce a typographical-error explosion of scoring.

title: Dinkins Sharpens His Sword To Win a Wider Constituency
description: David N. Dinkins, who campaigned for the Democratic mayoral nomination as ''a liberal and proud of it'' and shunned the word ''tough,'' is now courting a broader constituency by proclaiming himself a ''mainstream Democrat'' and challenging Rudolph W. Giuliani, his Republican opponent, for the title of New York City's ''toughest'' crime fighter.

title: U.S. REVISES PLAN TO AID OPPOSITION IN NICARAGUA VOTE
description: The Bush Administration submitted a new proposal today to help opposition groups in the Nicaraguan elections scheduled for February, revising a plan that Congress rebuffed amid questions about its legality.

title: Pravda Eats Those Words About Yeltsin
description: Pravda, the Communist Party's once officially unimpeachable organ, had another free-press innovation forced upon it today: the apology, or ''grovel,'' as it is more vividly termed by Western practitioners.

title: Reynolds to Curtail Cigarette Shipments
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said today that it would reduce United States cigarette shipments for the rest of the year and eliminate its sales incentives.

title: Mets Reduced To Being Spoilers
description: The Mets slipped spectacularly into the role of spoiler tonight when they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-1, behind a dazzling performance by Sid Fernandez, who allowed only 2 hits, struck out 13 batters and personally outhit the Cardinals by delivering two singles and the first home run of his career.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Senate Puts Limit on Child Custody Jailings
description: The Senate voted today to limit the length of jailings in child custody cases in the District of Columbia. The measure was intended to free a mother who has been in jail more than two years in a custody dispute.

title: New Yorker Named As Chief of Research On Rwanda Gorillas
description: Diane Doran, a researcher at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, has been chosen from 15 applicants to be the next director of the Karisoke Research Center, the gorilla research station in Rwanda that was formerly headed by Dian Fossey.

title: PBS Corporate Support
description: Corporations donated a record $70 million for national public television programs in the 1989 fiscal year, with 20 corporations giving more than $1 million each, the Public Broadcasting Service said Wednesday. The $70 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30 was 6.9 percent more than in the previous year, PBS said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * M. T. Rainey has been named chief executive of the London office of Chiat/Day/Mojo.

title: Reeves Exercises Total Control
description: As vice president and head coach of the Denver Broncos, Dan Reeves carries an awfully big stick. It's his show, his party.

title: For the Record
description: Law in the Fast Lane

title: Tennessee Judge Awards Custody of 7 Frozen Embryos to Woman
description: A Tennessee state court yesterday granted temporary custody of seven frozen embryos to the woman who produced the eggs. The court rejected the efforts of her estranged husband, whose sperm fertilized the eggs, to prevent them from being implanted in her womb.

title: G.N.P. Growth in 2d Quarter Revised to 2.5% From 2.7%
description: The nation's economy grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the April-June quarter, slightly lower than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Ohio Steer Owner Gives Up Ribbon and Cash
description: Because she broke a rule by dyeing hairs on her steer, the 18-year-old owner of the grand champion at the Ohio State Fair has agreed to relinquish the blue ribbon and the $28,000 she earned when the steer was sold at auction.

title: Sanford Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Best Products Co reports earnings for 13wks to July 29
description: Best Products was acquired in a leveraged transaction in November 1988 by Adler & Shaykin, a private New York investment firm. The company said post-acquisition results reflect incremental depreciation and amortization relating to purchase accounting adjustments as well as the interest on the acquisition-related debt.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Cowgirl Hall of Fame

title: Publishers Oppose Laws on Recycled Paper
description: The nation's newspaper publishers say they support the increased use of recycled paper for printing newspapers but oppose legislation requiring its use. Such legislation has been passed or offered in 14 states so far.

title: Clorox Sells Paints To PPG Industries
description: The Clorox Company said it had agreed to sell its Olympic and Lucite brand paint businesses to PPG Industries for $130 million in cash. PPG, based in Pittsburgh, markets paints under the Pittsburgh Paints brand name in North America and the PPG Corona name in Europe.

title: American General Selling 2 Divisions
description: The American General Corporation, a Houston-based insurance and financial services company, said it had a definitive agreement to sell its Dallas-based group-life and health insurance companies to American Insurance Companies of Indianapolis for $195 million. American General would receive $175 million in cash and a $10 million note, which is contingent on the companies' performance.

title: Navy vs. Irish Set for Jersey
description: The Naval Academy today chose Giants Stadium over London, Dublin and Cleveland as the site for its 1990 football game with Notre Dame.

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Top Draft Choice Scores But Islanders Are Losers
description: The Islanders' first-round draft choice scored his first goal for the team as it lost, 4-2, tonight to the Philadelphia Flyers in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HARNESS RACING Goalie Jeff Wins: Goalie Jeff, winner of the third division, never trailed in the raceoff and won the Little Brown Jug yesterday at the Delaware County Fairgrounds in Delaware, Ohio. Goalie Jeff, driven by Michel Lachance, drew the first post position in the raceoff and won in 1:54 1/5 over the mile course. Barefoot Hanover, winner of the second division, finished second. Tyler's Best, winner of the first division, finished third. Goalie Jeff's victory marked the second successive Jug triumph for his trainer, Tom Artandi, and Lachance. Both were affiliated with the 1988 winner, B. J. Scoot. Goalie Jeff paid $2.80 for $2 to win, $2.20 to place and $2.10 to show. The victory was his 12th in 24 starts this year.(AP) GOLF Baum Wins the Met: Mel Baum was the only player to shoot under par yesterday as he won the Izod Metropolitan P.G.A. championship at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Baum, an assistant at Bonnie Briar Country Club in Larchmont, carded a four-under-par 66 at the 6,631-yard layout for a three-day total of 208 and the first prize of $5,500. Bobby Heins, the head pro at Old Oaks; Darrell Kestner, the assistant at Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, and Jack Druga, the head pro at the Creek Club in Locust Valley, L.I., tied for second at 211 and earned $3,200 each.(AP) Three Share Lead: Steve Pate, Billy Andrade and Rick Fehr shot six-under-par 64 yesterday to share the lead after one round of the Southern Open at the hilly par-70, 6,791-yard Green Island Country Club course in Columbus, Ga. They held a one-shot lead over Kenny Knox and Ray Barr Jr. At 66 were Tim Simpson, Corey Pavin, Billy Tuten, a tour rookie; Hugh Royer 3d of Columbus, who got a sponsor's exemption to enter, Ted Schulz, Bill Britton, Bill Kratzert and Andrew Magee.(AP) HOCKEY Capitals Win in Leningrad: Geoff Courtnall scored three goals to rally the Washington Capitals to a 5-4 victory over a Soviet army team in Leningrad last night, ending the first visit by National Hockey League teams to the Soviet Union. Washington and the Calgary Flames won six of eight games in the visit. The Capitals fell behind, 3-0, in the first period and trailed, 4-1, midway through the second period. But they scored two goals late in the second period and scored twice in the final period for the victory, their third in four games on the Soviet tour. The army team they beat is based in Leningrad.(AP) WEIGHT LIFTING Russian Wins Another: Anatoly Khrapaty of the Soviet Union won his fifth consecutive world title yesterday, capturing the medium-heavyweight competition at the world championships in Athens. Khrapaty lifted a total of 913 pounds as the Russians took the top two medals in the 198-pound class. Sergei Syrtsov finished second with 896 1/2 pounds. Ivan Tchakarov of Bulgaria lifted 880 pounds and took third place. The Soviet Union has won titles in four of seven weight classes.(AP)

title: New Unit Head Named At American Express
description: The American Express Company yesterday announced the formation of the new Consumer Financial Services Group, which will deal with international consumer businesses, and named Steven D. Goldstein as president.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kent Cigarettes Leaves BBDO
description: After suffering a chronic decline in market share for its Kent cigarette brand, Lorillard Inc. yesterday dismissed BBDO Worldwide as the agency for Kent advertising. A spokeswoman for Lorillard said the company had ''mutual differences in creative approach'' with the agency.

title: Nets Sign Short To One-Year Contract
description: Purvis Short, who has averaged 18 points a game in an 11-year National Basketball Association career, will be throwing up his familiar high-arching rainbow jumpers for the the Nets this season. Looking for more scoring and ''someone who has been there before,'' the Nets signed the 6-foot-7-inch Short, an unrestricted free agent, to a one-year contract yesterday. Short played the last two seasons for the Houston Rockets, the first one under Bill Fitch, the Nets' new coach.

title: Man and 2 Women Are Found Slain In Harlem Rooms
description: The bodies of a man and two women, one who appeared to be in her 60's and the other in her 70's, were found in a Harlem apartment yesterday. The police said that all had been stabbed to death and that the man's throat had been slashed.

title: Rockwell Sues U.S. Over Waste at Nuclear Plant
description: Saying it is trapped between the conflicting demands of different Government agencies, the Rockwell International Corporation sued the Federal Government today over the company's role as manager of the Energy Department's Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant.

title: Carolina Hotels Awash in Evacuees
description: They began streaming away from the coast early in the day, and by nightfall here, inland hotels throughout the Carolinas were awash in residents fleeing Hurricane Hugo.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Pilots in Jet Crash at La Guardia Are Sought by U.S. Investigators
description: Federal investigators tried unsuccessfully yesterday to locate the pilot and co-pilot of the USAir jetliner that crashed into the East River Wednesday night to learn why the flight was aborted in its 140-mile-an-hour rush down a runway at La Guardia Airport.

title: Kaiser Health Group Offering
description: Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, is offering $150 million in notes due 2001 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Koch Warns of Layoffs Over Coliseum Suit
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch warned last night that New York City faces ''massive'' layoffs of city workers and will have to drop plans to hire additional police officers if opponents of the Columbus Center project pursue a lawsuit to block construction and deprive the city of $247 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fluor Daniel, Irvine, Calif., an engineering company, said it had been awarded a $125 million contract with Fort Howard Corp., Green Bay, Wis., to build a tissue-making machine for its Savannah River mill.

title: Review/Film Festival; Love Out of Sync in 'Too Beautiful for You'
description: Bernard (Gerard Depardieu), a prosperous garage owner and automobile salesman, is in a Continental fix. He is married to the beautiful, model-chic Florence (Carole Bouquet) when he develops an inexplicable passion for the sweet, plain, somewhat overweight Colette (Josiane Balasko), a temporary secretary not in the bloom of youth.

title: Shevardnadze Gives Bush Arms Offer as Summit Pans Are Worked Out
description: The United States and the Soviet Union edged toward setting a date for a summit meeting today as Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union presented President Bush with new proposals on arms control.

title: Orioles: Young Team Heading For an Old-Style Photo Finish
description: It is still a stretch of the imagination to consider the crazy thing that has happened in baseball. The season has turned to September, leaves have begun to change their color, cooling breezes are sweeping across the city at night, and yet they are still up there, defying the laws of gravity almost magically, pressing forward as the days pass, offering a pennant race when they should be nowhere near first place.

title: Our Towns; In a Small Town, One Pharmacist Versus a Chain
description: Neil Norwood has always tried to give his small-town pharmacy a personal touch. He keeps one bottle of Odol imported mouthwash on the shelf for Mrs. Bogyo. ''Mrs. Bogyo's happy when she comes in and sees it,'' Mr. Norwood said. ''The fire chief comes in for Ionil medicated shampoo in the 32-ounce size. Pat Warner just bought her Norell cologne, so I don't have any, but I've reordered and her Norell will be there next time she's in.''

title: Neiman-Marcus Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After a charge of $10,542,000 resulting from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. There was a loss per share for the 1988 year resulting from preferred dividend payment.

title: Marshall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Continuum Concert
description: Continuum, an ensemble that specializes in 20th-century music, is to perform works by Henry Cowell, Luigi Dallapiccola, Roberto Sierra, John Anthony Lennon, Francis Schwartz and Manuel de Falla at Armor Hall, Wave Hill, 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $13 in advance; $14 at the door. Information: 549-3200.

title: Monsanto Wins Mobil Damages
description: A Federal jury has awarded the Monsanto Company more than $21 million for a breach of contract by the Mobil Oil Corporation. Monsanto contended that Mobil had violated a five-year agreement to buy phosphorus and other products, including detergents and lubrication additives, for Mobil plants in Ohio and South Carolina.

title: Blount Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $7,003,000, or 59 cents a share, for the quarter and $10,190,000, or 85 cents a share, for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a loss of $10,834,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Opto Mechanik Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Sprinter's Drug Allegations Draw Denials
description: An American sprinter who says he received performance-enhancing drugs from two of the nation's leading track coaches and supplied drugs to Florence Griffith Joyner, one of the nation's most acclaimed track champions, drew a series of vehement denials yesterday, one of them delivered to his video face on national television.

title: 780 White South Africans Vow to Resist Draft
description: In the largest concerted campaign so far to resist conscription, more than 780 whites of military age pledged today to refuse to serve in South Africa's armed forces.

title: Fernandez Wants to Empower Local Schools to Make Decisions
description: Joseph A. Fernandez, who will soon take control of New York City's public schools, said yesterday that he would like to replace the 21-year-old decentralized school administration with the system he has started to put into place in Miami, where important decisions are made at the school level.

title: Documentaries Are Hot At the '89 Film Festival
description: HAS the power of the documentary film to bear witness to reality endured in an era saturated by the instantaneous images of television news? Has the documentary been rendered irrelevant - or worse, boring - by the competitive video verite of the Cable News Network and its 24-hour-a-day bulletins in millions of homes? Such concerns, debated by film makers, critics and assorted videologues, are answered definitively by the New York Film Festival in its 27th series, which opens tonight.

title: Morgan's Reserve Up $2 Billion
description: J. P. Morgan & Company announced yesterday that it had added $2 billion to its reserve against third world loans. The step is expected to create a $1.8 billion loss in the third quarter, as well as a loss for the year. Morgan's move is likely to intensify the pressure on other banks to increase their reserves as well.

title: Open Mind and Bayakoa in Early Showdown
description: The showdown everyone thought would have to wait until the Breeders' Cup Distaff on Nov. 4 is now scheduled to come off at Belmont Park this Sunday: Open Mind will face Bayakoa in the Ruffian Handicap and the winner will be hailed as the best filly in the country.

title: Brooklyn Neighborhood Not a Cradle of Racists; Yet Change Comes
description: To the Editor:

title: Auctions
description: A 30-Tear Collection

title: 3Com Posts A Profit, After All
description: Last month, when the 3Com Corporation told analysts it could not rule out the possibility of a quarterly loss, the widespread perception was that the company had finally hit the wall.

title: Market Place; Why Is Buffett Raising Money?
description: IF Warren E. Buffett is borrowing money, does that mean he thinks there are compelling investment opportunities awaiting?

title: Andrew F. Peck, Securities Executive, 63
description: Andrew F. Peck, a securities executive, died of cancer Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 63 and lived in Manhattan. At his death he was chairman of Andrew F. Peck Associates, a discount brokerage firm that he formed in 1979. He was previously executive vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Insurers Win Court Round
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit filed by 19 state attorneys general that had charged numerous insurance companies with engaging in anti-competitive behavior that made liability insurance expensive or impossible to get.

title: Bid for B.A.T. Clears Hurdle
description: The British Government gave conditional approval today to the hostile takeover bid by Sir James Goldsmith for B.A.T. Industries.

title: Vestaur Securities Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Net income represented net investment income. Net assets were $89,736,000, or $14.03 a share, on Aug. 31, 1989 and $86,712,000, or $13.56 a share, at Aug. 31, 1988.

title: TCBY Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
American to Add Miami Flights
description: Officials of American Airlines Inc., a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, announced plans to nearly double, to 70, the number of daily flights serving Miami by the end of the year. It said it expected the number of employees involved to double to more than 2,600 within the next several years.

title: The Apple Crop Is Ready, But the Supply Is Smaller
description: The apple harvest has begun in orchards close to metropolitan New York, with scores of farms in the Hudson Valley, Connecticut and New Jersey open for those who want to pick their own fruit.

title: The Mad Circle
description: Yesterday it was Colonel Higgins, hanged by the neck. The day before, Pan Am 103, blown into bits of metal and bone over Scotland. Today a French plane, exploded somewhere over Africa. Tomorrow will come, soon enough. Each time, the world - the part of it that cares - draws a breath of horror. Political leaders say that by God, terrorists must pay.

title: I.B.M. and Baxter in Venture To Sell Health-Care Systems
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Baxter Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that they were forming a partnership to sell computer software and services to hospitals and physicians.

title: Confronted With Cookie That Doesn't Crumble, Lawyers Find Patent Case a Hard Nut to Crack
description: Jerome G. Lee, a senior partner in the New York firm of Morgan & Finnegan, has been practicing patent law for 39 years. For 32 of them, he represented Procter & Gamble, and his cases have involved a laundry list of household names, like Tide, Pampers, Rely, Bounce, Bounty, Luvs, Coast and Crest.

title: Famous for (No, in) 15 Minutes
description: Just inside the living room window of the long, thin, white two-story home on a tree-lined street, two tiny glass hands are pressed together, fingertips facing up. The words printed at their base are pointed outward for the world to see: ''Prayer Changes Things.''

title: Sergeant Is Acquitted in Tompkins Sq. Case
description: The first police officer to be tried on brutality charges stemming from the melee in Tompkins Square Park last year was acquitted yesterday.

title: Henricus A. F. Heidweiller, Ex-Suriname Official, 60
description: Henricus A. F. Heidweiller, a former Foreign Minister of Suriname, died Tuesday at his home in Paramaribo, the South American's country's capital. He was 60 years old.

title: Qume reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included gains of $1,364,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,984,000, or 25 cents a share, for the 6 months, both on the sale of minority interest in unit.

title: Bernstein Orchestrated
description: Gerard Schwarz will conduct the New York Chamber Symphony, the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham and the baritone Kurt Ollmann in the world premiere of the orchestrated version of Leonard Bernstein's ''Arias and Barcarolles'' at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock. The orchestration is by the composer Bright Sheng, under Mr. Bernstein's supervision. The program also includes Beethoven's incidental music for Goethe's ''Egmont,'' with Erie Mills as the soprano soloist and Werner Klemperer narrating, and Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23 in A (K. 488), with Richard Goode as the soloist. The program is to be repeated on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $20 to $30. Information: 996-1100.

title: Saudi Arabia Beheads 16 Kuwaitis Linked to Pro-Iranian Terrorism
description: Saudi Arabia beheaded 16 Kuwaiti Shiites by sword in public today in the Islamic holy city of Mecca in connection with bombings and other terrorism during the annual Muslim pilgrimage in July.

title: Review/Pop; Argentine Baritone Makes a Debut
description: Hope, friendship, idealism and poetry animate the songs of Alberto Cortez, the Argentine pop singer who made his New York debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Cortez, who has lived in Spain since 1964, has a large, loyal audience that gave him a standing ovation when he walked on stage Wednesday. And with his expansive baritone voice and an actor's expressiveness - he could seem tragic, sly, nostalgic or whimsical from verse to verse - he had concertgoers hanging on every word and every note.

title: D'Amato, After Backing Lauder, Supports Giuliani for Mayor
description: Proving that strong feelings can have short lives in politics - at least publicly - Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he would support Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican nominee for mayor of New York City, ''without equivocation.''

title: DEFECTS TOP CAUSE OF INFANT DEATHS
description: Birth defects are the leading cause of death in infants, Federal researchers say, and their prevalance will make it difficult to meet national goals for reducing the infant mortality rate.

title: Familiar Partisan Banners Unfurl As Fight Over Taxes Takes Shape
description: The lines were drawn in the House today for a bruising fight over taxes, with Democratic leaders scrambling to sell their newly devised plan as a boon to the middle class and Republicans asserting that it was just another tax increase.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nothing really terrible happened except that the plane broke in half.'' - Joanna Trojer, a passenger on USAir Flight 5050. [ B4:1. ]

title: Norway Mistakenly Exports Barred Computers to Soviets
description: Norway broke Western export rules by mistakenly sending high-tech computers to the Soviet Union, believing it was flying supplies to a Red Cross hospital in Armenia, Norwegian customs oficials said today.

title: New Antiques Extravaganza With an International Flavor
description: GLORIOUS gilded eagles, decorating an assortment of wares from Italy, Russia, England, France and the United States, reflect the global character of the goods presented by 84 dealers at New York's newest bazaar for secondhand wares - the International Antique Dealers Show. The fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory is to open today in previews and tomorrow to the public for a five-day run.

title: 19 Texas Students Die When Bus Plunges Into Water
description: Nineteen high school students were killed and 64 were injured today when their bus plunged into a rain-filled 40-foot gravel pit after being struck by a delivery truck.

title: Texas Concern In Revamping
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had reorganized most of its computer products operations to put more emphasis on developing complex software and information management systems.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 7.1% Increase Projected In TV Advertising Sales
description: Emboldened by predictions of a robust economy, the Television Bureau of Advertising projected yesterday that revenue from television advertising would increase 7.1 percent in 1990. The bureau said the sharpest growth, an estimated 15 percent, would be in revenue from sales on syndicated programs.

title: Restaurants
description: The summer of '89 belonged to Pino Luongo. For the last three months, Le Madri, his Tuscan restaurant on West 18th Street, has been the coolest sanctuary of the bronzed and fashionable set, its weeknight West Hampton. On eastern Long Island, in Wainscott, he snagged road-weary weekenders at his stylish Sapore di Mare. Talk about strategic marketing.

title: On Stage
description: Keeping 'Roberts' in the Family

title: Sleep-Inducing Drug Studied
description: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating an unusually high number of reports of unwanted side effects to the drug Halcion, a widely prescribed sleep medication.

title: Bush, the U.N. and Too Many People
description: When President Bush addresses the General Assembly on Monday, he will not call the U.N. ''an unreal place . . . torn by tensions'' as he did during the 1988 campaign. Now he is likely to praise U.N. peacekeeping forces in regional trouble spots and call for stronger U.N. measures to protect the global environment.

title: At the Jet Crash: Fear, Futility and Bravery
description: A sudden braking that threw passengers forward in their seats. The shouted alarms of flight attendants -''Get your heads down! Brace yourselves! Cover your heads!'' A shower of debris and the dark waters of Rikers Island Channel filling the back of the USAir 737-400 jetliner.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: This Weekend Today TWELFTH CRAB AND BEER FEST, Our Lady of Pompeii Church, Bleecker and Carmine Streets; sponsored by Village Visiting Neighbors. Food and entertainment. Today, 6 to 9 P.M. $20 ($15 for the elderly). Information: 260-6200. CRAFTS AT LYNDHURST, Great Lawn of the Lyndhurst estate, Route 9, Tarrytown, N.Y.; sponsored by Gannett Westchester Rockland Newspapers. Artwork, shopping and live musical entertainment. Today, 1 to 5 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. $5 ($4 for the elderly, $2 for ages 6 to 16, free for those under 6). Information: (914) 631-0046. Tomorrow TRIBECA STREET FAIR, Greenwich Street, between Franklin and Chambers Streets; sponsored by Battery News, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Argo International and Citibank. Food, games and flea market. Tomorrow, noon to dusk. Rain date, Sunday. Information: 964-9491. FIRST STONEWALL FESTIVAL, Washington Place, from Washington Square East to Broadway; sponsored by the Stonewall Democratic Club. Food, crafts and antiques. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Rain date, Oct. 7. Information: 751-4932. THIRD ANNUAL BROADWAY FLEA MARKET, Shubert Alley, between 44th and 45th Streets, west of Broadway; sponsored by Broadway Cares, a support organization for those with AIDS. Theater memorabilia, costumes, books, records and food. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and 4:15 to 7 P.M. Rain date, Sunday. Information: 974-7500. FALL FLOWER MARKET, 128 West 58th Street, sponsored by the Horticultural Society. Large selection of house plants, spring bulbs, potpourri and garden books. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free. Information: 757-0915. 19th GRACIE SQUARE ART SHOW, East End Avenue, between 84th and 87th Streets; sponsored by the Carl Schurz Park Association. Oil paintings, watercolors, sculpture and photography. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon until dusk. Information: 459-4455. OKTOBERFEST, 84th Street, between First and York Avenues; sponsored by the East 84th Street Neighborhood Association. Bavarian band, German beer and wurst, homemade delicacies, crafts, books and antiques. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: 744-2130. FIFTH ANNUAL WEST SIDE ARTS, CRAFTS AND ANTIQUES FESTIVAL, West End Avenue, from 88th to 96th Streets; sponsored by the N.A.A.C.P. Mid-Manhattan Branch. Handcraft exhibits from third-world nations, including macrame, ceramics, jewelry, woodcarving. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date, Sunday. Information: 764-6330. Sunday ASIAN LABOR FESTIVAL, Columbus Park, Bayard and Mulberry Streets; sponsored by the New York City Central Labor Council, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and local trade unions. Music and dance. Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. Information: 685-9552. UNION SQUARE COMMUNITY COALITION CARNIVAL, Union Square Park, 17th Street between Park Avenue South and Broadway; sponsored by Union Square Community Coalition. Games, pony rides, food and music. Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. Information: 533-2838. ANNUAL STREET FAIR ON THIRD AVENUE, between 68th and 96th Streets; sponsored by Our Town and The New York Post; 1,000 vendors, food, entertainment and more. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date, Oct. 15. Information: 439-7900.

title: Judge Says Owens-Illinois Violated Laws in Acquisition
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. lost a round yesterday in its continuing feud with the Federal Trade Commission over its acquisition of Brockway Inc., a competing maker of glass containers, in April 1988.

title: Review/Cabaret; Julie Wilson Sings Porter, Sondheim And More
description: During her last six years on the cabaret stage after a lengthy show-business sabbatical, Julie Wilson has methodically worked her way through the songbooks of leading popular songwriters including Porter, Sondheim, Rodgers and Hart, Weill, and Schwartz. Now, for the first time since coming out of retirement, the singer, who is appearing at the Cafe Carlyle, 76th Street and Madison Avenue, through Oct. 28, and her accompanist William Roy are performing a smorgasbord of songs by Bart Howard, Johnny Mandel and Peter Allen, as well as a healthy sprinkling of Porter and Sondheim.

title: Wells Fargo Buys Central Pacific
description: Wells Fargo & Company agreed to purchase the Central Pacific Corporation of Bakersfield, Calif., and its American National Bank subsidiary for $160 million, or $28.50 a share. Shareholders of Central Pacific will have the option of receiving either cash or Wells Fargo common stock for their shares.

title: Politburo Shuffle? Muscovites Shrug
description: Out on the streets, where Kremlin-watching is no mere academic exercise, the morning-after view of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, master Politburo purger, was of a man whose political gifts still fail to ease the national torment of fading opportunity.

title: Richardson Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Investigators Reach Wreckage of French Jet
description: With all signs pointing toward sabotage, investigators converged on the wreckage of a French DC-10 jetliner in the North African desert today. A French magazine and French officials said pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon had warned France that it would suffer terrorist acts.

title: Review/Art; Richard Serra in Shows Of Drawing and Sculpture
description: Richard Serra's latest works are terrific. They are complex and resolved and they richly reward the patient observer. One of the saddest legacies of the debacle involving the removal this year of ''Tilted Arc'' from Federal Plaza in Manhattan is that many people who have never spent much time with Mr. Serra's sculptures, or who have seen them only through photographs, have no doubt formed opinions about the artist. These people could do nothing better than to visit the Pace Gallery, where three new sculptures are on view, and the Leo Castelli Gallery, where Mr. Serra's recent drawings have been hung.

title: Time to Talk About Afghanistan
description: Washington has kept faith with Afghanistan's mujahedeen guerrillas, and more. Direct Soviet military involvement justified U.S. support for the Islamic resistance forces. The presumption was that the aid would cease when Soviet forces withdrew. But though Soviet troops left in February, generous U.S. aid continued - as has Soviet support for the Kabul regime. Washington has consistently cold-shouldered proposals for a mutual arms cutoff and political compromise, counting instead on an early mujahedeen military victory.

title: Picasso and Braque, Brothers in Cubism
description: ''PICASSO AND BRAQUE: PIONEERING CUBISM,'' opening Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, is the show of the decade. It is remarkable on every level: in the quality and importance of the art, in the intelligence and originality of the installation, in the psychological and esthetic implications of its story.

title: Judicial Panel Urges Limit on Appeals by Death Row Inmates
description: A special committee of Federal judges, set up at the request of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to study the judicial system's handling of death penalty cases, today recommended strict new limits on the multiple appeals that are now commonly filed by death row inmates.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wells, Rich Account
description: Wells, Rich, Greene yesterday won the advertising account for the business credit services division of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. Kenneth Olshan, chairman of Wells, Rich, said the account would bill between $5 million and $10 million and represented the bulk of Dun & Bradstreet's advertising expenditures. Earlier this week, the agency suffered the loss of the Polo Ralph Lauren and Sure deodorant accounts.

title: Polish Primate Backs Convent Move
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has stated, in a letter made public today, that the disputed Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp should be moved to an interfaith center to be built nearby, as the Vatican urged two days ago.

title: Teachers Taking More Pride In Profession, Survey Finds
description: Teachers feel substantially better about their profession and about themselves than they did five years ago, a survey of 2,000 teachers of kindergarten through 12th grade reported yesterday. In fact, 92 percent of those surveyed said that the quality of education in their schools was good or excellent.

title: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said that the Chi-Vit and Bearings divisions, which were sold earlier this year, had contributed $18,900,000 to sales and $2,400,000 to operating income in the third quarter of 1988.

title: Langston Heads List Of Possible Free Agents
description: Mark Langston, whom the Montreal Expos have already offered $9 million for three years, and Mark Davis, who leads major league relief pitchers with 41 saves, head the list of 138 players who are marking time until they can become free agents at the end of the season.

title: Charles Blount Jr., 92, Dye Works Ex-Chief
description: Charles Blount Jr., the retired president of United Piece Dye Works Inc. in Manhattan, died Tuesday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 92 years old and had homes in Evanston and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Conagra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 21
description: The latest quarter's income included a $26.9 million after-tax gain from the settlement of litigation and a $24.8 million after-tax charge for realigning processed meats operations.

title: Chicago Merc to Allow Some Trading Off Floor
description: To accommodate the demands of large institutional traders, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that it would begin an experiment in which some trading of futures contracts would take place off the exchange floor, outside the confines of the exchange's cherished ''open outcry'' system.

title: Soviets, in Apparent Shift, Remove Barrier to Strategic Arms Treaty
description: In a possible shift that could remove a major obstacle to an accord on strategic nuclear weapons, the Soviet Union appears to have dropped its demand that an arms agreement be held in abeyance until a separate accord is reached on space weapons, a senior American official announced tonight.

title: Campeau's Foes in Toronto Gloat
description: There has been little sympathy for Robert Campeau this week on Bay Street, Toronto's clubby financial district.

title: Patents; A Chemical Treatment To Prevent Blindness
description: Dominic Man-Kit Lam, chairman of Houston Biotechnology Inc. of The Woodlands, Tex., has patented a chemical treatment to prevent blindness caused by degeneration of the optic nerve and retina.

title: U.S. RELIEF MOVES BEGIN IN CARIBBEAN
description: President Bush declared seven counties in South Carolina to be major disaster areas today, making them eligible for Federal assistance, while the Defense Department and other agencies began relief operations in the Caribbean islands hit by Hurricane Hugo earlier this week.

title: Same Old Same Old Deficit
description: The Federal budget taking shape for 1990 will scale new heights of hypocrisy. The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law requires deficit reduction each year and President Bush and Congress are doing their best to make it appear they've complied. In truth, they're still playing games.

title: Stocks Remain Sluggish; Dow Gains 1.33
description: Stocks edged up yesterday, adding 1.33 points on the Dow Jones industrial average to close at 2,681.61, finishing a lackluster week with an uninspiring gain of 7.03 points, as volume continued at a plodding pace.

title: For Storm Victims, a Day of Slow Agony After a Day of Fear
description: Yesterday was the uncertainty of anticipating what was coming. Today was the slow agony of finding out what came.

title: Rockwell Is Giving Up Rocky Flats Plant
description: The Department of Energy and the Rockwell International Corporation said late yesterday that the company will give up management of the department's Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in Colorado.

title: Swedish Bank Raided
description: The police this week raided the head office of Sweden's largest bank, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken, to seize material in a tax evasion inquiry against its chief executive. Neither the executive, Jacob Palmstierna, nor the prosecutor who is leading the inquiry, Bengt Stromberg, was available for comment. The penalty for tax evasion is up to six years in jail.

title: Campeau May Seek New Mortgages
description: The new committee charged with rebuilding the American retailing arm of the Campeau Corporation is expected to give high priority to arranging new mortgages for many of the 125 retail buildings that the company owns outright.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aris Corp., Phoenix, completed the acquisition of Lamonts Apparel Inc., Bellevue, Wash., a fashion retail chain, from Northern Pacific Corp. The purchase price was about $136.5 million.

title: Treasury Issues Are Little Changed
description: Treasury note and bond prices were essentially unchanged yesterday, while bill rates posted moderate gains. Dealers described trading as light and featureless in the absence of any significant news. The fixed-income market largely ignored Government reports of rises of four-tenths of 1 percent in personal income and nine-tenths of 1 percent in spending in August, which were in line with expectations.

title: The Good News About Asbestos
description: Water can kill - in quantities large enough to permit drowning. The same is true for asbestos. It can cause illness and death, but only after victims have been exposed to sufficient concentrations over a long time.

title: Buyer Is Sought By Anchor Glass
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation's directors have agreed to seek a buyer for the nation's second-largest glass maker in an attempt to thwart an unsolicited $280 million takeover bid from a Mexican company.

title: Bridge; Americans win in one world championship but are in trouble in another.
description: The bridge players representing the United States snatched a victory in one world championship event here tonight, but were in trouble in another.

title: UAL Deal To Enrich Executives
description: The chairman of the UAL Corporation stands to gain $76.7 million for his stake in the parent of United Airlines if a proposed buyout by pilots and management is completed, but he plans to work without pay for a year after employees take control, a company official said yesterday.

title: School Plan Draws Praise And Cautions
description: Joseph A. Fernandez's proposal to reshape the New York City school system so important decisions are made at the school level elicited praise from several quarters yesterday along with some cautions about the obstacles to its adoption.

title: U.S. Also an Offender in Setting Nets in the Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs
description: LEAD: The patriotic indignation against the use of illegal drugs and in favor of President Bush's resorting to extreme methods to combat drug traffic leaves the armchair detective puzzled.

title: Bhutto on Defensive Amid Tensions in Punjab
description: Nearly 10 months after coming to power, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government is on the defensive, losing popularity because of unfulfilled election promises but unable to risk bold legislation because of its small parliamentary majority.

title: Third World Debt Woes; Major U.S. Banks, After Absorbing Losses, Could Lose Their Appetite for New Loans
description: J. P. Morgan & Company's surprise decision Thursday to drastically increase its financial cushion against bad loans to third world countries raises new questions about how those countries will escape their severe economic problems.

title: Patents; New Biotech Rulings Stir Confusion
description: The Patent and Trademark Office has given two companies what appears to be strong patent protection for the same drug, setting the stage for another biotechnology dispute.

title: No U.N. Monitors for Cambodia
description: The Cambodian Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen has been rebuffed in an attempt to assemble an international force of military observers to monitor the Vietnamese troop withdrawal, diplomats here say. The Vietnamese pullout is scheduled to be completed next week.

title: Some Mets Annoyed Over Team Psychiatrist
description: In a season of controversy, the latest storm enveloping the Mets centers on the team psychiatrist, Dr. Alan Lans, whose role was publicly questioned by several Mets players during the tumultuous road trip that ended Thursday night in St. Louis.

title: Thomas F. Burke, 60, Electronics Executive
description: Thomas F. Burke, the chairman and chief executive of M/A-Com Inc. of Burlington, Mass., manufacturers of electronic equipment, was fatally injured Thursday in an automobile accident near Tewksbury, Mass. He was 60 years old and lived in North Andover, Mass.

title: Advertisers Drop Program About the Timber Industry
description: A television program about threats to timberlands in the Pacific Northwest has lost all its advertising, after pressure was put on the companies by a group representing the logging industry, the program's co-producer and the television network that is carrying the program said.

title: Leader of Christians In Lebanon Accepts Arab Plan for Truce
description: The military commander of the Lebanese Christians, Gen. Michel Aoun, today formally accepted an Arab League plan for a cease-fire in the civil war, setting the stage for discussions on national reconciliation.

title: East Berlin Officials Declare Pro-Democracy Group Illegal
description: The East German Government has declared a pro-democracy group illegal and accused the group's organizers of ''anti-state policies'' and attempts to deceive the public about its true aims.

title: Betsy B. Erskine Weds Executive
description: Betsy Bevan Erskine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McArdle Erskine of Hurst, Tex., and Leopoldo Cortes Toralballa, the son of Gloria Cortes Toralballa of Stamford, Conn., and the late Leopoldo Vasquez Toralballa, were married yesterday at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. E. Gaye McGuigan. The Rev. Jane Henderson, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: City Opera Strike Talks Produce No Progress
description: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its orchestra, which has been on strike since Sept. 13, met Thursday night. ''We clarified our positions but made no real progress,'' said Martin J. Oppenheimer, the City Opera vice chairman and its chief negotiator.

title: Expect a Rough Mayoral Campaign
description: New York City is enjoying, temporarily, an era of good feeling following David Dinkins's historic victory in the Democratic mayoral primary. The general election campaign, however, will be a very different from the primary fight.

title: Bielecki Helps the Cubs Win a Big Victory
description: The Chicago Cubs made a division championship a little more certain today by beating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-2, but the victory was tempered by the uncertain status of one of the team's pitching mainstays, Rick Sutcliffe.

title: U.S. Limits Aid to Buyers of Savings Units
description: The Bush Administration is limiting the protection it is willing to give to buyers of insolvent savings institutions, a marked shift from a much-criticized Government policy in the 1988 savings and loan bailouts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY SEPTEMBER 23, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Leonard E. Kust, 72, New York Tax Lawyer
description: Leonard E. Kust, a tax lawyer, died of spongiform encephalopathy, a neurological disorder, Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: Fixed Mortgage Cost Off
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.03 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporaiton. The average rate was 10.05 percent last week. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.70 percent this week, up from 8.68 percent the week before, Freddie Mac said.

title: Dinkins Outdoes Giuliani in Donations
description: David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral candidate in a predominantly Democratic city, raised twice as much in the latest two-week reporting period as his Republican-Liberal opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, according to financial reports filed yesterday with the Campaign Finance Board.

title: Gallo Curbing Skid Row Sales
description: The E.&J. Gallo Winery, the world's largest wine maker, said this week that it had stopped selling its high-alcohol Thunderbird and Night Train brands to retailers in skid rows throughout the country. The skid rows were not identified. Thunderbird and Night

title: Leon Culberson Outfielder, 71
description: Leon Culberson, an outfielder who played with the Boston Red Sox and the Washington Senators during a six-year major league career, died last Sunday. He was 71 years old. He broke into the majors with Boston in 1943 and was with the Sox for five years. His best season was in 1946, when he batted .313 as the Red Sox won the American League pennant. His career batting average was .266.

title: Your Money; Advisers Divided Over 'Junk Bonds'
description: Although investors in ''junk bond'' mutual funds have been collecting fat monthly income checks this year, on paper at least, they have large principal losses. The net asset value of their funds is down sharply this year.

title: F.D.A. Asks Stronger Label On Sleep Pill Under Scrutiny
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee today suggested stronger labeling for the sleep drug Halcion to explain more clearly what side effects some patients might expect. The panel also concluded that reports of adverse effects had been overstated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For these two pilots to have been sequestered for more than 36 hours after an accident that took two lives, and to do so without explanation, is highly questionable.'' - James B. Busey, the Federal Aviation Administrator. [ 26:1. ]

title: U.S. Also an Offender in Setting Nets in the Sea; First Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY AID EFFORTS FOR STORM VICTIMS
description: With the hurricane's path of destruction at an end, efforts in New York to help aid its victims show no signs of waning.

title: Pact for McCammon
description: Bob McCammon, who nearly guided the Canucks to a first-round upset of the Calgary Flames in the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, signed a new multiyear contract as coach in Vancouver yesterday. Details were not released.(AP)

title: FORMER H.U.D. HEAD BARS TV COVERAGE
description: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. did the unthinkable today in this publicity-conscious town: he pulled the plug on television coverage of his appearance on Capitol Hill.

title: Cairo Journal; Egypt's Pain: Wives Killing Husbands
description: When the newspapers here began chronicling a series of attacks in which women killed their husbands, the stories seized the headlines and stirred some debate about the future of a land where no transition seems easy.

title: Abrupt Oil-Price Shifts Seen As Unlikely Despite Swings
description: Prices of crude oil, which have edged higher in recent weeks after being remarkably stable through much of the year, may fluctuate as much as a dollar a barrel in the months ahead, but abrupt changes are not likely, many analysts believe.

title: Conservative Figures See 'Bright' Future
description: There was more than a trace of self-congratulation in the air today as Vice President Dan Quayle, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other like-minded political leaders assured each other that Communism and socialism were on the defensive everywhere.

title: Arts Nominee Speaks Out Against Helms Amendment
description: John E. Frohnmayer, who has been nominated by President Bush as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, spoke out today against the Helms Amendment, the proposed law that would forbid Federal support of obscene or indecent art.

title: Otto Obermaier Named To Replace Giuliani
