description: Otto G. Obermaier, a defense lawyer and former prosecutor, was confirmed yesterday by the United States Senate as Rudolph W. Giuliani's successor as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: Hundreds of Children With AIDS Are Unable to Obtain AZT
description: Hundreds of children with AIDS are suffering or dying prematurely because they are unable to obtain AZT, a drug that could prolong and improve the quality of their lives, Federal officials, researchers and advocates for AIDS patients say.

title: Books of The Times; 2 Strangers Telling Each Other Their War Stories
description: Dirty Work By Larry Brown 236 pages. Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill/Workman Publishing. $16.95.

title: MATHEW SESHI OGAWA, EXECUTIVE, 69
description: Mathew Seshi Ogawa, who was to assume the presidency of Lions Club International next year, died Thursday at University of California-Los Angeles Medical Center after cancer surgery. He was 69 years old and lived in Tokyo.

title: Dr. Allan M. Sachs, 68, Physicist
description: Dr. Allan M. Sachs, former chairman of Columbia University's physics department, died of a heart attack Wednesday while playing tennis at a tennis club in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 68 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Outside U.S. Embassy, Soviet Extortion
description: American officials trying to cope with increasing crowds of Soviet applicants for immigration say the people in long lines outside the United States Embassy are being victimized by an extortion racket involving Soviet police guards assigned to keep order.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Vatican statement on the Carmelite convent at Auschwitz misstated the current affiliations of Rabbi James Rudin of New York. He is national interreligious affairs director of the American Jewish Committee and chairman of the Jewish Council for International Interreligious Relations. He is former chairman (not the current one) of the International Jewish Committee for Interreligious Consultations.

title: Who's Behind the Coup Talk in Moscow?
description: LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev, in what perhaps was the gloomiest speech of his political life, a few weeks ago told the Soviet people, ''We can hear threats of approaching chaos and talk of a threatened coup, and even of civil war.''

title: KEY RATES
Louisville Sets Out To Gain Recognition
description: In four years, Coach Howard Schnellenberger transformed the University of Miami Hurricanes from mediocrity to a national collegiate championship team in 1983. He has been striving since 1985 to pull off a similar feat with Louisville, where for three seasons he has labored with teams that had records of 2-9, 3-8 and 3-7-1.

title: Reorganization For Steel Concern
description: The New York investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was in talks about a new plan to reorganize the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest steel producer. Wheeling-Pittsburgh has been in reorganization proceedings under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since 1985 and faces $1.2 billion in creditor claims.

title: Stamford Commuters Try To Leave the Driver's Seat
description: James Slattery drives 50 miles to work each day on some of the most crowded roads in the state. If all goes well, the trip takes an hour and a quarter. But if there is an accident or a storm, Mr. Slattery said: ''Forget it. You're dead.''

title: Campaign Trail; Unveiling Campaign TV Ads and Gaining New Endorsements
description: Is it a subtle attack on his Republican opponent? Or a gentle homily to Democratic values?

title: Cummins Stock Takes Tumble
description: The stock of Cummins Engine Company Inc. tumbled $5.125 today, to $57.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, and analysts attributed the drop to a negative earnings estimate issued late Thursday by the Columbus, Ind., manufacturer of diesel engines and automotive parts.

title: Senate Bargaining on Drug Funds Collapses
description: Negotiations between Democratic and Republican senators over the financing of an anti-drug package unexpectedly collapsed late this afternoon, with the two sides only $150 million apart on how much money to add to President Bush's $7.9 billion proposal for the new fiscal year.

title: Watchman Kemp, and His Watchers
description: Secretary Jack Kemp's outline of proposed reforms for the Department of Housing and Urban Development seems well conceived, as far as it goes. It deserves careful scrutiny by Congress. But one of the chief failures uncovered in the H.U.D. scandals was of Congressional oversight. Congress also needs to scrutinize itself.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's Department of Puerto Rican Community Affairs in the United States has asked that donations to assist victims of Hurricane Hugo be sent to the American Red Cross or branch offices of three banks that are setting up special accounts for Puerto Rican disaster assistance. The banks are Banco Popular, Banco de Ponce and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: 113th Texas Bank Fails
description: The number of bank failures in Texas this year, 113, equals the number recorded in all of last year. The latest bank to fail, Rose Capital Bank of Tyler, was closed Thursday by state regulators. Nationally, Rose Capital was the 160th failure this year. The bank, which had assets of $64.6 million and deposits of about $61.1 million, was purchased by the First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc. for $25,000. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will provide $16.8 million in assistance and retain assets with a book value of $18.2 million.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Sept. 15 about ''High Fidelity: The Adventures of the Guarneri String Quartet'' misattributed an earlier film, ''From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China.'' It was produced and directed by Murray Lerner. Alan Miller, producer and director of ''High Fidelity,'' served as artistic supervisor of the earlier film. (The error also appeared in an interview with Mr. Miller on Sept. 19.)

title: Suspect Jailed in the Death Of Noted Kidnapping Victim
description: A worker at a tomato packing house has been jailed in the hit-and-run death of Steven Stayner, whose kidnapping as a child almost two decades ago was the subject of the recent television movie ''I Know My First Name Is Steven.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Clampett Leads: Bobby Clampett, who is in danger of having to qualify for the PGA Tour next year, shot a six-under-par 64 yesterday to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Southern Open in Columbus, Ga. Clampett's 36-hole total of 131 over the par-70, 6,775-yard Green Island Country Club course was one stroke better than the scores of Rick Fehr, Steve Pate, Dave Rummells and Ted Schulz. Clampett, who had six birdies and 12 pars, is No. 148 on the money list with $62,688 and would have to go to qualifying school to get back on the tour next year if he does not finish in the top 125. (AP) BOXING Advances: Skipper Kelp of Colorado Springs moved easily into the quarterfinals of the world amateur championships last night in Moscow. Kelp scored his second victory in the 139-pound class when he won on a walkover over Dariusz Chernij of Poland, who was too sick to compete. (AP) WEIGHT LIFTING Bulgarian Wins in Upset: Petar Stefanov of Bulgaria scored an upset yesterday in Athens by winning the semi-heavweight division at the world weight-lifting championships with a total lift of 913 pounds. (AP)

title: Mihai Alimanestianu, Parking Engineer, 71
description: Mihai Alimanestianu, a civil and mechanical engineer who originated Speed-Park in Manhattan, one of the first completely automatic parking garages, died on Tuesday in the crash of a DC-10 jumbo jet in the Niger desert en route from Chad to France. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Medical Bill Workers Plead Guilty in Fraud
description: Two managers of a company that handled medical billing and collections for 10 private hospitals in New York City pleaded guilty Thursday to falsifying documents used to qualify hundreds of patients for Medicaid coverage, state officials said yesterday.

title: Jet Defenders Eager As They Await Marino
description: Who owns the football field?

title: Corrections
description: The Lottery Numbers chart yesterday listed the New Jersey Pick-It number incorrectly in some editions.

title: Aouita Pulls Out of Mile
description: The men's Mercedes Mile down Fifth Avenue this afternoon was virtually conceded to Abdi Bile of Somalia yesterday as his chief rival, Said Aouita of Morocco, officially withdrew, passing up a $25,000 appearance fee and a chance to cap an outstanding season.

title: G.M. Incentives
description: Some General Motors Corporation car and truck divisions announced today incentives ranging from $200 to $1,250 on a variety of 1990 vehicles. Incentives on two Chevrolet pickups and the Chevrolet Corsica came a week before the vehicles officially went on sale. Some incentives on the Chevrolet, Buick, Oldsmobile and GMC Truck products varied, depending on option packages purchased. Low-interest financing also was offered on some cars and trucks. Earlier this month, Chevrolet announced incentives on its Lumina sedan and the Geo Prizm, both new cars for the 1990 model year.

title: Article 927489 -- No Title
description: In a move that will considerably broaden its holdings in the health and beauty care field, the Procter & Gamble Company announced today that it had agreed to buy the Noxell Corporation, the maker of Cover Girl cosmetics and Noxzema skin cream, for securities worth $1.3 billion.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. This new Postal Service stamp, one of four celebrating dinosaurs, has created quite a stir among paleontologists. Why? 2. With one sentence on Tuesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d confirmed what had been assumed in political circles. What was it? 3. In San Francisco, lavender shirts worn with orange and black baseball jackets are more than a fashion statement. What does that wardrobe signify? 4. Many of the disenfranchised students in New York City's public schools may feel a special kinship with Joseph A. Fernandez, the Superintendent of the Miami-Dade County Schools, who was named as the new Schools Chancellor. Why? 5. In France, the T.G.V. Atlantique made its debut, a voyage that included passing through a rubber-cushioned tunnel. What is the T.G.V. Atlantique and why is the tunnel cushioned? 6. The ''untouchables'' is how one movie director referred to 25 American films recently designated cinematic treasures. Explain. 7. Researchers announced a discovery that they say may ultimately lead to the first practical test for Alzheimer's disease. What was it? 8. Deng Xiaoping selected the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, as China's paramount leader, bypassing Premier Li Peng. What is the significance of that? 9. The chief arbiters of Soviet art are planning a major sculpture show that will prove remarkable, if only because of what will not be on view. Explain. 10. Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Defense Minister, met in Cairo with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to explore ways of ending the stalemate on Palestinian elections. But Mr. Rabin's ability to negotiate was impeded. Why? 11. ''Between true yachtsmen, victory is pursued on the water and not in the courtroom,'' said a New York State appellate court, overturning a decision. What did the court's ruling do and what was in dispute? 12. Artists were divided over whether a statement by the Corcoran Gallery of Art was acceptable. What was the statement and what were the circumstances? 13. ''It's a bad step because in the eyes of world opinion, she had accepted the challenge of moving ahead in the fight against drug traffickers,'' said a Colombian official. To whom was he referring and what were the circumstances? 14. Although shoppers thronged to the new Abraham & Straus department store in Manhattan, there may be a problem. Why?

title: Durham Suspended
description: Leon Durham, a seldom-used first baseman with the St. Louis Cardinals, has been suspended for 60 days for failure to comply with the baseball commissioner's drug policy, the commissioner's office announced yesterday without issuing any other details. (AP)

title: Rights Panel Is Critical of Care of Disabled Newborns
description: A report issued today by the United States Commission on Civil Rights asserts that children born with severe disabilities ''continue to be denied'' adequate medical treatment in violation of Federal anti-discrimination law.

title: John Leith, 90, Dies; Was a Dean at Lehigh
description: John Douglas Leith, a former dean at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., died Monday at the Meadowlark Hills Health Care Unity in Manhattan, Kan. He was 90 years old and had lived there since 1987. Mr. Leith, a graduate of the University of North Dakota, taught there until 1936. From 1937 to 1941 he was the director of student personnel at Teachers College, Columbia University. He joined the administrative staff at Lehigh University in 1946, was named dean of students in 1958 and retired in 1963.

title: M.T.A. Rejects Sex-Act Curbs By Metro-North
description: A Metro-North Commuter Railroad proposal to outlaw some sexual acts on trains and in stations was rejected yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board.

title: One Germany: Bonn's Quiet Yearning
description: Much as they welcomed the thousands of East Germans flooding over the Hungarian border, West Germans have greeted the unexpected revival of the ''German question'' with a mixture of deep emotion and some unease.

title: Bronx Cheers Now Stylish In Flushing
description: At a time when coffee, replays and gratification are often considered either instantaneous or worthless, maybe we have arrived at the point where five years is just too long for a memory to last. It has been almost that long since that early December evening when Met fans made the shocking discovery that propelled them through a winter and legitimized their team.

title: European Minds Who Fled Fascism
description: One of the less appreciated consequences of the rise of fascism in Europe in the 1930's was that it put an end to Europe's cultural and intellectual supremacy. That status was transferred to the United States in part by way of a small but historic emigration of the persecuted and the unwanted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 19 about the naming of conservators for Willem de Kooning's assets misstated part of an agreement that let the artist's daughter, Lisa de Kooning, and his lawyer, John Eastman, become co-conservators.

title: U.S. Also an Offender in Setting Nets in the Sea; South Korean Efforts
description: To the Editor:

title: Two U.S. Women in Crisis In the England of Thatcher
description: ''Strapless,'' the new film written by David Hare, the English playwright, is about two American women, sisters, who come to terms with their womanhood in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's England. The movie is about some of the perils of womanhood and what Mr. Hare sees as unbridled Toryism.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Players for Video Disks
description: There is an alternative to the videocassette recorder: the Laservision video disk player. LV's provide better pictures and sound than do VCR's, the disks never wear out and most of the new machines also play compact disks. The disadvantages are that most stores offer movie disks for sale only and not for rental (they generally cost about $25 to $35) and that you cannot record on disks. Here are some things to look for in an LV. Special Effects: Even the least expensive LV's (they cost about $500 and up) can produce great special effects on some disks (those labeled CAV). Models that can freeze frames and perform other special effects with all disks cost a bit more. Special dials on some players make it easy to zip to a desired scene, then scan it frame by frame. Sound: Most, but not all, Laservision players can also play compact disks. Conveniences in over-$1,000 players include changing up to three CD's, and a system to memorize and play a personalized selection of tracks each time a CD is played. Controls: LV's are generally operated by remote control, so many players have only rudimentary front-panel controls.

title: I.B.M. Duties Are Expanded
description: James A. Cannavino, who is in charge of the personal computer unit of the International Business Machines Corporation, has been given additional responsibilities, the company announced yesterday.

title: CAROLINAS REELING FROM DEVASTATION LEFT BY HURRICANE
description: Charleston, S.C., was reeling yesterday from the devastation left by the most powerful hurricane to hit the United States in two decades. Bridges were twisted, buildings leveled and television towers toppled as the storm raced ashore, then swept northward through the Carolinas.

title: Gabriel Giannini, 83, Aerospace Executive
description: Dr. Gabriel Maria Giannini, a physicist and aerospace equipment manufacturer, died of a stroke Wednesday at the Eisenhower Medical Clinic in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 83 years old and lived in Indio, Calif.

title: Wang Reaches Pact On $175 Million Loan
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., the struggling minicomputer maker, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a unit of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation to borrow up to $175 million, which the company needs to revamp its operations.

title: IN IRELAND, A TRIUMPH OF WILL; A Gangster Makes Good As a Father
description: Harry Plotnik has been kept under wraps for 20 years, but he is none the worse for wear. Harry is the glum Jewish gangster at the center of ''The Plot Against Harry,'' a funny, sharply drawn and appealingly modest film that very nearly missed seeing the light of day.

title: New Deal for Clayton
description: The Miami Dolphins and Mark Clayton reached a four-year contract agreement yesterday that could make Clayton one of the five highest-paid receivers in the National Football League. Clayton had sought that status during a seven-week holdout that ended 10 days ago when the team promised to negotiate a new deal in good faith.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS Drug Not for Children Hundreds of children with AIDS are dying prematurely because they cannot get the drug AZT. Page 8. Pierce Bars TV Coverage A House rule has allowed the former Secretary to bar television cameras when he testifies next week. Page 8. World's Biggest Tire Maker Michelin Group of France is acquiring Uniroyal Goodrich in a deal valued at $1.5 billion. Page 31. Colombian Shakeup Bogota's Justice Minister was reportedly asked to resign for ''dragging her feet'' in the drug war. Page 24.

title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December
description: The pilot and co-pilot of USAir Flight 5050, as well as other crew members, were not obliged by law or regulation to submit to drug or alcohol tests after the accident on Wednesday at La Guardia Airport in which two passengers died.

title: Growing Hole in Ozone Shield Is Discovered Over Antarctica
description: A hole has opened in the atmosphere's ozone shield above Antarctica, and scientists said yesterday the hole was growing at the same rate as one in 1987, which broke records and alarmed environmentalists.

title: Michelin to Acquire Uniroyal Goodrich
description: In a deal that will create the world's largest tire company, the Michelin Group of France agreed yesterday to acquire the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company in a transaction valued at $1.5 billion.

title: And You Don't Need a Key
description: People who jog or bicycle to work may want to consider an alternative: roller skating. Modern technology has refashioned the old metal skate into a lighter plastic model that snaps over a shoe.

title: Computers in the Toolbox
description: Shoppers at the Ridgefield Supply Company, a large hardware store and lumberyard in this affluent town just south of Danbury, are confronted by what appears to be a large video game in the center of the showroom.

title: IN IRELAND, A TRIUMPH OF WILL; A Particular Coming Of Age
description: Born in 1932 with cerebral palsy, the ninth of the 22 children his parents would eventually have (13 survived), Christy Brown grew up as an archetypal member of Dublin's working class - painfully poor, often deprived of essentials, yet also miraculously resiliant.

title: A Polish Director's Vision Of the Evil That Men Do
description: In ''A Short Film About Killing,'' Krzysztof Kieslowski, one of the most respected of the postwar generation of Polish directors, has the daring to build an argument against capital punishment around an utterly unsympathetic character.

title: Chrysler Cuts Stake In Mitsubishi
description: The Chrysler Corporation, taking a $310 million profit on a longstanding investment, has reduced its stake in the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation to 12.1 percent from 21.8 percent.

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Refuse To Extend an Expiring Truce
description: Salvadoran guerrillas said today that they would not extend a truce that runs out at midnight because the Government had not responded positively to their peace efforts.

title: Joseph G. Kvasnicka, Economist, Dies at 59
description: Joseph G. Kvasnicka, an international economist and former vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, died of cancer Tuesday at the Northwestern Memorial Hospice in Chicago. He was 59 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Lotus to Get Sybase Stake
description: The Lotus Development Corporation and Sybase Inc. said today that they were entering into a strategic alliance under which Lotus will acquire 15 percent of Sybase. The price of the deal was not disclosed.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter Sept. 16 from Adm. C. A. H. Trost on the Navy's Trident II missile program incorrectly identified the submarine Tennessee as a battleship.

title: Don't Liken Smokingnto oruguA ddciitno
description: To the Editor:

title: France Finds Evidence of Explosives on Jet
description: Officials investigating the wreckage of a French airliner that broke up over an African desert have found evidence of explosives on board the DC-10, the Government said tonight.

title: Mary Gail Conner, Executive, Weds
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Red Bank, N.J., Mary Gail Conner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Conner of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Aloysius Gallagher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Gallagher of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth D. Aldrich Jr. officiated.

title: Memorial Obliterates French Nazi Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Mistakes by Inexperienced Crew Blamed for Crash at La Guardia
description: Federal investigators said last night that a series of miscues by a relatively inexperienced cockpit crew had led to the aborted takeoff of a USAir jetliner that crashed into the East River at LaGuardia Airport Wednesday night, killing two passengers.

title: Bush Calls Courter's Race a Poll on G.O.P.
description: President Bush came to New Jersey today to endorse the Republican candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter, and paint a picture of the race as a nationally significant referendum on Republican policies and values.

title: In Fear, Settlers From Vietnam Leave Cambodia
description: Several thousand Vietnamese citizens living in Cambodia have recently returned to Vietnam, nervous about what will happen once Vietnamese soldiers complete their withdrawal from Cambodia next week, diplomats and relief officials said today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Review/Opera; A 'Mefistofele' That Mixes Its Symbols
description: The San Francisco Opera's new production of Boito's ''Mefistofele'' seemed initially attractive for the chance to hear Gabriela Benackova, a Czechoslovak soprano, in music in which she is infrequently encountered. Miss Benackova was fine, but the real attraction turned out to be the direction and design.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the British Broadcasting Corporation misstated its ownership.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;
With Hazardous Household Wastes
description: LEAD: Rhoda Becker got a jump on her fall cleaning recently. The result of her toil was a little unusual: 62 55-gallon drums of assorted fertilizers, oil-based paints, pesticides, household cleaning products and batteries, all from other people's homes.

title: New York Tax Cut Delay Means a Tax Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Liken Smoking to Drug Addiction; Stop Cigarette Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Confirms Powell
description: By voice vote, the Senate early today confirmed Gen. Colin L. Powell of the Army to be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He will succeed Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., who is retiring, on Oct. 1.

title: Bogota Justice Chief Was Ousted By President Barco, Aide Reports
description: Colombia's Justice Minister was asked to resign because she was ''dragging her feet'' on signing papers to extradite drug suspects for trial in the United States, a presidential aide said today.

title: Adobe Systems' Stock Repurchase
description: Adobe Systems Inc. said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $15 million of its common stock, or about 4.8 percent at recent prices, in the open market in the next few weeks. Adobe will use existing cash to pay for the shares, which will be bought at the discretion of the company's management.

title: White House Set Up Drug Buy in the Park For Bush TV Speech
description: Government agents lured a drug dealer to the park in front of the White House to buy crack for a prop in President Bush's televised speech on drugs, a move the President testily defended today.

title: Between Takeoff and Abort, Just Three Seconds to Judge
description: Pilots facing a split-second decision on whether to take off or abort the flight of a jet in trouble must rely on instinct and experience, and also on mathematical calculations. The decision to abort is particularly pressing at La Guardia Airport, which does not have long runways and is nearly surrounded by water and homes.

title: Panel Clears Zion's Doctors Of Wrongdoing in Her Death
description: After more than two years of hearings, a New York State Health Department panel has recommended that all administrative charges be dropped against the two doctors who treated 18-year-old Libby Zion in the hours before her death in 1984.

title: Yanks Become Spoilers And Hold Off Orioles
description: The race ran away from the Yankees long ago. It is lost somewhere in their collective memory, somewhere among the losses and the trades and the managerial changes that seem to be a part of every summer they play.

title: I.B.M. Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it plans to make an announcement Tuesday related to its Microchannel computer bus. Analysts said that the company is expected to introduce a faster version of the bus, which moves data inside the computer. I.B.M. is competing against the Compaq Computer Corporation, which is trying to establish a competing computer bus standard known as Extended Industry Standard Architecture. The company also said that it will introduce several new models of its PS/2 personal computer family to ''fill out the product line.'' A spokesman for the company would not comment further on the announcement.

title: Attempted Murder Charged In Police Officer's Shooting
description: The man accused of shooting an Essex County police officer in the back was arraigned today on an attempted murder charge, a sheriff's department spokeswoman said.

title: President's Choice For Post on Ethics Is Out of Running
description: A Houston judge and religious leader who was President Bush's choice to head the Office of Government Ethics has been removed from consideration as a result of a background check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, White House officials said today.

title: When Hurricane Ripped Charleston, It Rated as 10th Strongest to Hit U.S.
description: The hurricane that last night ravaged Charleston, S.C., surprised forecasters by gathering strength almost at the last moment to become the 10th most intense of the 137 hurricanes that have hit the United States coast in this century.

title: Jaguar Fights Tie With Ford
description: Jaguar P.L.C.'s board today characterized the Ford Motor Company's plans to buy a stake in the company as unwelcome and vowed to preserve the British luxury auto maker's independence.

title: Irving Berlin, Nation's Songwriter, Dies
description: Irving Berlin, the Russian-born minstrel whose songs like ''Cheek to Cheek'' and ''White Christmas'' became part of the fabric of American life, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan, just a few miles from the Lower East Side tenement he lived in when he wrote the first of his 1,500 songs. He was 101 years old.

title: Woman Held in Attack On Doctor at Hospital
description: A doctor at Bronx Lebanon Hospital was stabbed in the arm and chest last night by a woman wielding a barbecue fork, the police said.

title: Europeans Take Lead In Ryder's First Day
description: Led again by the inspirational and artistic leadership of Seve Ballesteros of Spain, the European Ryder Cup golf team this afternoon swept four four-ball matches against the United States, just as it did two years ago. This time, the sweep enabled the cup defenders to erase a 3-1 deficit after the foursome matches in the morning and take an impressive 5-3 lead after the first day of the event at the Belfry.

title: Whalers Sign Dineen
description: The Hartford Whalers yesterday announced the signing of Kevin Dineen, a right wing who last season led all scorers in the Adams Division of the National Hockey League with 89 points. Dineen received a four-year contract, the value of which was not disclosed.(AP)

title: Denise Dadas Wed to Richard Clarke
description: Denise Elizabeth Dadas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Dadas of Lake Forest, Ill., and Richard W. Clarke, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Ellsworth Clarke Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., were married yesterday at the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago. The Rev. David A. Donovan officiated.

title: 3 Nobel Resignations Over Rushdie
description: Three members of the Nobel Literature Prize selection committee have resigned over the body's refusal to speak out against threats against the British author Salman Rushdie, but the committee has refused to accept the resignations.

title: A BARRACKS BLAST KILLS 10 IN BRITAIN
description: At least 10 people were killed and 22 wounded today when an explosion ripped through a barracks at a marines' music school and damaged dozens of nearby homes in southeast England. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility.

title: America's Vietnam Trauma Is the Stuff of British Musical
description: Broadway, get ready for ''Miss Saigon,'' the $4.8 million Cameron Mackintosh musical about love, separation and tragedy in the Vietnam War. The spectacle, which brings ''Madama Butterfly'' into the 20th century, complete with the last American helicopter battering its way out of Saigon in 1975, has been leaving most of its opening-week audiences here in stunned, tearful appreciation.

title: Spending Is Up 0.9% as Incomes Rise 0.4%
description: In another sign of continued economic expansion, consumer spending increased by nine-tenths of 1 percent in August even though incomes rose just four-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Variety of Agencies Providing Aid to Hurricane Victims
description: A variety of Federal and other agencies are providing disaster relief because of Hurricane Hugo, including these:

title: Dr. William Hammon Dies at 85; A Pioneer in Fight Against Polio
description: Dr. William McD. Hammon, a public-health physician and medical missionary who conducted research into polio and tropical diseases, died Tuesday at his home in Seminole, Fla., where he had lived in retirement since 1973. He was 85 years old.

title: About New York; 2, Finally Alone, Instead Decide To Live as One
description: The invitation arrived a couple weeks ago. Two fat pink hearts and shimmering orchids graced the front. ''Two hearts that beat as one,'' it said. ''Jerilyn and Jorge.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 24 An explosion in a British barracks killed at least 10 people, wounded 22 others, and damaged dozens of homes in southeast England. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility. Page 1

title: Film Producer Named Editor of Variety
description: Peter B. Bart, the independent film producer, novelist and former newspaper journalist, will become editor of Variety on Oct. 9, the weekly newspaper's executive publisher, Gerard A. Byrne, announced yesterday.

title: Budget Deficit Down 11.7%
description: The Federal deficit for the first 11 months of the fiscal year was 11.7 percent smaller that a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Walsh to Ask Cowboys For Trade by Deadline
description: Steve Walsh, the Dallas Cowboys' rookie backup quarterback who has not played since an exhibition game on Aug. 26, is hoping the Cowboys will trade him to another National Football League team within the next three weeks, before the trading deadline on Oct. 17.

title: Patents; Sending Messages To Electronic Pagers
description: Using a technique he calls ''word guessing,'' Bernard N. Riskin of New Hope, Pa., has invented a computer system that he says makes it much easier to transmit written messages to electronic pagers through an ordinary Touch-Tone telephone.

title: Belgian Deal by Bass
description: Bass P.L.C., the British brewing and leisure company, said today that it had acquired, through its Coral Racing subsidiary, 369 betting shops in Belgium from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. for an undisclosed sum. The shops operate under the name Tierce Franco-Belge.

title: Drug Inquiry Likely
description: The governing body of track in the United States will likely investigate charges of drug use by Florence Griffith Joyner and other American athletes, a spokesman for the organization said yesterday.

title: Army Clears West Point Doctor in Sex-Abuse Case
description: The United States Military Academy has cleared an Army gynecologist of charges of sexual abuse brought by three women at West Point who claimed that he hugged, kissed or fondled them and, in one case, had sexual intercourse.

title: Attic Of Failed Miracles
description: The attic is filling up with electronic miracles. The good old personal computer went up just yesterday. ''Old'' means it was bought in 1985, ''good'' that it worked until last Aug. 2.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Mercedes Mile foot race, Fifth Avenue between 62d and 86th Streets will be closed today from 1 P.M. to 2 P.M.

title: Child-Care Plan Raises Church-State Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Sadism Seen In Johnson Rule
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: LEAD: DONALD WESTWOOD calls it ''bringing Mohammed to the mountain.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My redwood deck is in the shade, and after heavy rain the wood gets slimy and slippery. I have a similar problem with a blacktop tennis court. What can I do?

title: HAUNTED WORDS
description: Richard Lederer's entertaining column ''Haunted Words'' (On Language, Sept. 3) fails to mention one hardy perennial among bogus word derivations: the one that traces tip, in the sense of gratuity, to the phrase ''to insure promptness.'' Actually, there's no acronym involved; the word simply reflects the fact that 18th-century pub habitues used to ''tip'' (i.e., tap) a coin on the counter when it came time to settle up with the gentleman in the apron. LOUIS JAY HERMAN New York, N.Y.

title: KILLING OFF DAISY
description: HENRY JAMES AND THE ''WOMAN BUSINESS'' By Alfred Habegger. 288 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $34.50.

description: The marriage of Sara L. Herbert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. Herbert of Uniontown, Pa., to Bruce R. Galloway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Galloway of Forest Hills, Queens, took place last evening at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: THE PAST HAS FLED
description: HIGHER GROUND A Novel in Three Parts. By Caryl Phillips. 218 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Planting in the Fall
description: LEAD: FOR several years, nurseries and garden centers have displayed banners with slogans like ''Fall is for planting.'' Horticulturists have always known this is true, but home gardeners somehow strayed from planting in the fall.

title: The Sea That Unites Also Divides
description: EVERY day more people than ever in communities from Stonington, Conn., to Mamaroneck, N.Y., from City Island in the Bronx to Oyster Bay, L.I., are pleading the case for the Long Island Sound.

title: The Riches of Those Who Sought Refuge
description: ''The Exiles,'' Richard Kaplan's two-hour documentary on Channel 13 tonight at 7, uses as its spoken epigraph a poem that begins, ''We are the last ones. Question us.'' Although delivered by an actress in an offputtingly affected way, the poem, written by Hans Sahl, one of the hundreds of intellectuals, scholars and artists who found their way to America from Nazi-dominated Europe, is on the mark. The power of this ambitious work lies in the memories of the men and women who found refuge in America and repaid their new country with their remarkable talents.

title: Bittersweet Freedom
description: For 250 days he was No. 78900316, housed in the ''celebrity wing'' of the New York City jail on Rikers Island. Now free, Bernhard H. Goetz hopes to put all that behind him. Since 1974, when he shot four young men on a subway because, he said, he thought they were going to rob him, Mr. Goetz has been praised as a hero and condemned as a villain. He was sentenced to a year in jail, but got time off for good behavior. He now says he is thinking of leaving New York, where his every step is dogged by the press. Said his lawyer, ''He may be out of prison, but he's virtually under house arrest.''

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Planting in the Fall
description: LEAD: FOR several years, nurseries and garden centers have displayed banners with slogans like ''Fall is for planting.'' Horticulturists have always known this is true, but home gardeners somehow strayed from planting in the fall.

title: Campus Life: Pennsylvania; Coffee, Bagels And a Side of Art At a Student Cafe
description: When Sydney Thornbury, a University of Pennsylvania senior, moved into her freshman dormitory in 1987, all she and her father, Will, wanted after a day of unpacking was a good cup of coffee in a relaxing place. But after searching, the Los Angeles native finally settled for a nondescript restaurant. Her father told her, ''Someone at this school should open a good coffee shop.''

title: Judges Reverse Ban on Cliffs Notes Parody
description: Ruling in a case that involved a parody of Cliffs Notes, the study guides that have helped a few million students avoid over-indulging in Shakespeare and Dickens, the Federal appeals court in New York handed down a decision Friday that seemed destined for First Amendment textbooks. The court ruled that the parody can be distributed.

title:
GARDENING;
A Few Tips for Planting in the Fall
description: LEAD: FOR several years, nurseries and garden centers have displayed banners with slogans like ''Fall is for planting.'' Horticulturists have always known this is true, but home gardeners somehow strayed from planting in the fall.

title: Everybody Loves Solar Energy, But...
description: ON A SUMMER MORNING, just before dawn, the sky turns a coppery gold above the Mojave Desert, a 15,000-square-mile expanse of sand and sagebrush in southern California. In the handful of communities clinging to the two-lane highways crisscrossing the desert, nothing breaks the quiet except for the occasional trucker pulling over at a dusty drive-in.

title: Acting Out Conflicts In the Workplace
description: HOW do you boss around a friend? Not easily, say the experts. Yet increasing numbers of companies routinely promote employees from within, without realizing that new managers and supervisors need some special training in order to deal with former peers successfully, said Robert M. Steed, whose business is developing training programs for corporate clients.

title: THE GUIDE
description: FIVE TOWNS WALK

title: Villains of the World! Hollywood Beckons
description: Wanted: a new public enemy. Height, weight, sex, age and racial origins immaterial as long as the public enemy is sadistic, effete and strictly dishonorable.

title: Decades of Change: A Look Back At China in Chaos
description: It is Shanghai in 1927. Chiang Kaishek is conducting a bloody purge of his erstwhile allies, the Communists. In the old black-and-white film, boyish-looking suspects are interrogated by laughing policemen, then held in a cage by a guard brandishing an executioner's sword and finally dispatched by a shot to the back of the head.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The best time to buy assets may be when it is hardest to raise money.'' Warren E. Buffett, chairman, Berkshire Hathaway Corporation

title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: TROUBLE THE WATER. By Melvin Dixon. (University of Colorado/Fiction Collective Two, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95.) The poet and scholar Melvin Dixon's first novel, which won the 1989 Charles H. and N. Mildred Nilon Excellence in Minority Fiction Award, is a slim, poetic work. In the Southern Gothic tradition, Mr. Dixon's intricate narrative features an intense, brooding atmosphere, twisted passions, unsettling appearances and disappearances and uncanny intuitions. Yet for all the story's mystery and mysticism, it centers on the plight of a very down-to-earth character. A professor of American colonial history, Jordan Henry is the only black on the teaching staff of a small Massachusetts college. When racial trouble erupts on the campus, Jordan and his wife are ripe for a change of scene. Their journey is secured with a letter summoning Jordan home to Pee Dee, N.C., for his grandmother's funeral. Although Mother Harriet raised Jordan when his mother died in childbirth, they have been estranged for 20 years, ever since the teen-aged Jordan hitchhiked north to extricate himself from the hammerlock of her consuming hatred for his father, Jake Williams. Mother Harriet goaded her young grandson, even slyly trained him, to avenge his mother's death - to kill his father. And when Jordan returns south neither the back-country community nor his own soul will allow him to dodge all this unfinished business. Jordan draws courage, as he did as a boy, from his identification with the nearby Pee Dee River, but unfortunately Mr. Dixon's lyrical prose cloys with his insistent personification of its ever-changing waters. The only other false note is the unconvincing scene of violence between Jordan and his father. On balance, however, ''Trouble the Water'' is a success - primarily for its suspenseful, satisfying portrayal of Jordan Henry as he pursues grace in a fallen world.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE PATAKI FARM;
Making Changes to Save The Land and a Tradition
description: LEAD: THIS is the year the Pataki farm, open for 65 years and worked by four generations of the Pataki family, almost went under. This is also the year the owner, 77-year-old Louis Pataki, and his 44-year-old son, George, the Republican State Assemblyman and a lawyer, decided not to let that happen.

title: What Happens When Prodigies Grow Up
description: Ever since the rise of public concerts in the 18th century, child prodigies have been a regular part of the music scene. By the 1760's, Leopold Mozart was hauling his son Wolfgang around Europe, impressing court and commoner alike with the youngster's artistic prowess. Of course, Wolfgang was treated as a glorified carnival act, a musical freak of nature. And even today prodigies hold that dual fascination for audiences: on the one hand we value their sheer musical abilities; on the other we marvel at the novelty of adult expression emanating from a child's body.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My redwood deck is in the shade, and after heavy rain the wood gets slimy and slippery. I have a similar problem with a blacktop tennis court. What can I do?

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: VISIT BY 'GISELLE'

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If the ground is not too soggy, continue planting, especially perennials, new shrubs and young trees. Start planting if bulbs are beginning to arrive from mail-order nurseries or buy early selections from garden centers; bulb planting will continue well into next month. House plants should be indoors except Christmas cactus and jade plants, which remain outside so flower buds set. Why?

title: Using Social Security Checks for Greater Need
description: People who do not need their Social Security payments to live on are being asked to give them to charity under a novel fund-raising strategy being introduced by United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''However disastrous the hurricane was, it may have had one healthy result. It hopefully will help rein in some of the unwise development we have had along the coast.'' - Gered Lennon of the South Carolina Coastal Council. [ 1:6. ]

title: Miss Noli Weds Brian Silverman
description: Suzanne Noli, a daughter of Mary Noli of Sayville, L.I., and the late Robert Noli, was married yesterday to Brian Silverman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Silverman of White Plains. Judge Arthur Kellman of White Plains City Court officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Brazil Team Captures a World Bridge Title
description: After a day of wildly oscillating play, Brazil won the world contract bridge team championship for the N.E.C. Bermuda Bowl here this afternoon. This was the first time in the 40-year history of the event that a third world team has captured the title, though the Brazilians have won other world titles. This broke a string of seven victories by the United States, which in earlier years was dominated by Italy.

title: A Potter Who Found Art in the Mississippi Mud
description: George E. Ohr, a turn-of-the-century wizard at the potter's wheel who made witty, frequently erotic paper-thin vessels in Biloxi, Miss., is to be celebrated this week in his first museum retrospective.

title: A Colombian Campaigns Amid Risks of Drug War
description: From the front of the airplane, the candidate emerged blinking into the bright sunshine of this Andean metropolis. He greeted a crowd of local politicians and then plunged happily into a forest of microphones.

title: Susan S. Lloyd, Designer, Weds John W. Karrel
description: Susan Storrs Lloyd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lloyd of Palm Beach, Fla., and Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to John Whipple Karrel, the son of Frances Whipple Karrel of West Redding, Conn., and the late Oscar Karrel. The Rev. Loring S. Ensign of the Southport Congregational Church performed the ceremony at the Southport home of the bride's parents.

title: Nebraska Trounces Minnesota by 48-0
description: Ken Clark ran 18 times for 100 yards and 2 touchdowns today as Nebraska avoided a slow start for the first time this season and continued its 27-year domination of Minnesota, beating the Gophers, 48-0.

title: The Tiniest Restaurant in New Canaan
description: WHEN Paul L'Abbee, owner of L'Abbee Fine Catering in Scotts Corners, a hamlet in Pound Ridge, N.Y., decided to open a small retail store in New Canaan five months ago, he put in three tables and a few chairs for customers who wanted to sit a minute while ordering takeout salads, entrees and desserts.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GIDEON AHOY! By William Mayne. 156 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95. (Ages 11 and up)

title: BRITISH EXAMINING SECURITY AT BASES
description: British defense officials said today that they had ordered a general review of security at military installations after an Irish Republican Army bomb attack that killed 10 members of the Royal Marines Band Friday.

title: Miss Kelty Weds Charles Law Jr.
description: Susan Ellen Kelty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Kelty of Bronxville, N.Y., and Shelter Harbor, R.I., and Charles Blair Law Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Blair Law of Lyons Falls, N.Y., were married in Bronxville yesterday. Msgr. Patrick J. Sheridan officiated at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church.

title: Restricting Illegal Apartments
description: THE time-honored Long Island tradition of one house, one family, is being severely tested as more and more apartments are being carved into existing homes, usually in contravention of the housing codes.

title: Gold Glows Bright by the TV Light
description: I LOVE jewelry. Gold is my favorite four-letter word, which is why the home-shopping channel on cable television caught my eye.

title: Miss Dunne Weds Engineer
description: Sheila Mary Dunne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Dunne of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Elizardi Rogan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William David Rogan of Bellevue, Wash. Msgr. Donald J. Pryor officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye. Mrs. Rogan, 25 years old, is an operations supervisor at Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company, the brokerage concern in New York. Her husband, 26, is a project engineer at Jansen & Rogan, engineering consultants in New York.

GARDENING;

description: A grain elevator exploded in this southwestern Minnesota town Friday, killing 2 people and injuring t3. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known.

description: It's a move without precedent. On Nov. 15, in time for Christmas, ''Batman,'' currently the sixth-strongest box-office attraction of all time and still pulling briskly, will be released by Warner Home Video at a suggested price of $24.98.

description: Tufts University's student handbook was a few weeks late this fall, and there was nothing funny about it.

NONFICTION

One of the first things a journalist new to Detroit learns is that information about Mayor Coleman Young and about the city government's inner workings is hard to come by.

title: 1-Yard Touchdown Lifts Penn State
description: Tony Sacca overcame a mediocre passing day on a 1-yard rollout touchdown with 44 seconds left to give Penn State a 7-3 victory over Boston College today.

title: Geraldine Baum, Reporter, Marries
description: Geraldine Baum and Michael Oreskes were married yesterday evening at the Fairfield, Conn., home of the bride's mother, Louise Baum. Rabbi Alexander Schindler officiated.

description: Diane Leslie Morra, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry J. Morra of Toms River, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Walker Oatis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Oatis of New York. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Give Japan a Target and Say 'Import!'
description: Japanese tariff rates are only 6.4 percent, even lower than those of the United States, Canada or the European Community. But even so,, gaining market access in Japan is an experience not unlike attaining justice in Franz Kafka's novel ''The Trial.''

title: OPEC Is Back and Feeling Flush
description: OPEC's lean years are over. After nearly a decade of steep falls in revenues, wild price fluctuations, shrinking demand for oil worldwide and confrontation with the West, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seems to be coming into its own once more.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
PEOPLE IN PAIN
