title: A QUESTION OF TRUST
description: I am sure Nicole has some problems resulting from her parents' divorce - all children do - but if Paul Mandelbaum really wants her friendship, he'd better stop trying to ''shrink out'' her every word and action. Her questions indicate no obsession with ''destruction and loss.'' She doesn't save 40 different things so ''she exerts a little control over the world.'' She collects things. Just enjoy her, Paul, and you'll do fine. MARY MILLER Los Angeles

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; A $300 Million Downtown Bridgeport Plan
description: FOR more than 20 years, Bridgeport - known to its detractors as the ''gritty city'' - has been struggling to redevelop its business district, but it has never taken the big step.

title: Investors Confront a New Europe
description: IMAGINE A EUROPE THAT RESEMBLES the United States, a continent in which people and goods move freely across state borders with nary a customs or immigration officer to interrupt the flow.

title: Doldrums Troubling Housing Developers
description: WITH birch trees and rhododendrons spread across their lush lawns, seven new town houses at the Racquet Club on Long Island Sound look like the pride of loving homeowners. But a wasteland of mud ponds and hardpan that surrounds this manicured oasis in Centerville, L.I., offers evidence of big plans gone awry.

title: Commuter Misses the IRT
description: SURELY this can't be me at 7:39 on a Monday morning, panting after a mad dash through closing doors amid a crowd of suits and briefcases and Wall Street Journals. Shouldn't I be in bed at this time, with no pressure to rise for at least another 15 minutes? But that was before I became . . . Commuting Man!

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: PETER SCHWAB;
When the U.S. Isn't Always a Good Guy
description: LEAD: IN the heat of the Vietnam War in 1967, Peter Schwab began teaching a course at Adelphi University on Long Island about the war and United States foreign policy in Indochina. Today, that war is history, but the course itself, transplanted to the State University of New York at Purchase in 1971, is still going strong.

title: GROUP OF 7 WARNS ON RISE OF DOLLAR
description: Economic ministers from the seven largest industrial democracies said today that a further rise in the dollar could undercut efforts to promote a healthy global economy, and they vowed fresh cooperative efforts to try to keep a lid on the dollar.

title: Police Say Princeton Deaths May Be Work of Serial Killer
description: The Mercer County, N.J., authorities are investigating whether a serial killer may be responsible for two fatal stabbings and a near-fatal stabbing in less than six months.

title: Pakistanis View U.S. as Friend, Suspiciously
description: A year after the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in a plane crash, a public-opinion poll asked Pakistanis if they thought he was the victim of a conspiracy and, if so, who were the likely conspirators.

title: Review/Opera; New Staging of 'Lulu'
description: The San Francisco Opera's new production of Alban Berg's ''Lulu'' counts as Lotfi Mansouri's 42d with the company, but his first since he became its new general director. When he was appointed to the job, he indicated that he would play down stage direction and concentrate on administration. Given the disappointing flatness of this ''Lulu,'' seen Wednesday night, that sounds like a wise decision.

title: Pitchers' Duel Fizzles As Mets Clobber Expos
description: The pitchers their teams acquired at great cost to pitch them to the National League East championship opposed each other yesterday in a game that had no impact on the division race.

title: Cynthia Gregory to Dance with Connecticut Ballet
description: THE ballerina Cynthia Gregory moved to West Redding four years ago, and now, she said, she has found the perfect arrangement.

title: Woman Is Held in Stabbing Of Doctor in Bronx Hospital
description: A Bronx woman who the police said appeared to be deranged stabbed a doctor with a barbeque fork Friday night in an emergency room at Bronx Lebanon Hospital.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: While some of us were off enjoying the last days of summer, the makers of cameras and film have been busy flooding the photo-shop shelves with new goodies. Here's a brief run-down some of the newsworthy recent introductions:

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: DECADES of experience have shown that when cities go down, schools go bad. The reverse, however, does not appear to hold true. Most New Jersey cities have made modest or even spectacular recoveries, their schools have not always reflected the new prosperity.

title: Tax Revolt an Open Question
description: LEAD: FEWER than 300 votes in each of two primary elections this month have changed the political map in Suffolk County while suggesting the strength of the Long Island property-tax revolt.

title: Hugo Is the Latest Episode of Weather In the Extreme
description: FROM the great drought and heat wave of 1988 to the monster hurricane that smashed Charleston, S.C., on Thursday and Friday, the last 16 months have brought a startling sequence of out-of-the-ordinary weather to the United States.

title: Uneasy Merchants Back Plan to Rid Main Street of Panhandlers
description: JOSEPH S. LOMBARDO has lived in Middletown all of his 74 years, including 53 years as owner of the Friendly Barber Shop on Main Street, and he wholeheartedly supports a proposed ban on panhandlers who, he said, are ''all over Main Street.''

title: Some War; Meanwhile, Crack Undermines America
description: George Bush got his first big role as a drug warrior back in 1982 when he was Vice President and Ronald Reagan put him in charge of a task force to stop drugs entering Florida. Later that year, Mr. Reagan called for more task forces - ''a major initiative that I believe can mark a turning point in the battle against crime.''

title: New Kinds of Work and Workers Take Shape
description: To the Editor:

title: Cunningham Draws All Eyes to Him
description: On a muggy September night with the moon over Miami, the Philadelphia Eagles finished their preseason schedule by edging the Miami Dolphins. The Eagles were dressing in their locker room, scurrying to return to Philadelphia to continue earnest work on a season full of promise.

title: Purdy House Shows Off Its Latest Restoration
description: LEAD: THE Jacob Purdy House, built in 1721 and standing on Purdy Hill on Park Avenue in White Plains, has been restored. Today at 1:30 P.M., the public is invited to a celebration of that restoration, complete with fife and drum music and tours of the four-room Colonial dwelling.

title: Soviet Artists Warm To American Themes
description: LEAD: VLADIMIR STELMASHONOK, a prominent Soviet portrait artist and Communist Party member, dug his milk-white feet into the sizzling sand and lumbered to the Atlantic. Pausing just long enough to drop his load - canvases, brushes, pens, watercolors and a sketch pad - he peeled off his shirt and plunged into the moment: his first trip to the Jersey

title: A VOICE TO SHATTER TRADITION
description: LEAD: REVERBERATIONS The Memoirs of Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau. Translated by Ruth Hein. Illustrated. 376 pp. New York: Fromm International. $24.95.

title: Amy Whittlesey, A Student, Weds
description: St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Amy Elizabeth Whittlesey, the daughter of Faith R. Whittlesey of Philadelphia and the late Roger W. Whittlesey, to George D. O'Neill Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Neill of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. John S. Keefer officiated.

title: 'I Just Got Married . . . '
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; One Baseball Man Who Got His Chance
description: The way it works in Cito Gaston's career, opportunity doesn't just knock, it drives up to the curb and puts on the emergency brake.

title:
TO START WITH...;
A MONUMENTAL FRIENDSHIP
description: LEAD: MORT MEYERSON, A MULTIMILLIONAIRE investor and sometime corporate executive, stands on the empty stage, proudly gazing out over the soaring vault of Dallas's spanking-new concert hall. For most of a decade, as chairman of the building committee, he had nursed the project along, smoothing many a ruffled feather.

title: FEWER PEOPLE ARE DYING, BUT WHY?
description: LEAD: HEART FAILURE A Critical Inquiry Into American Medicine and the Revolution in Heart Care. By Thomas J. Moore. 308 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title:
INVESTING;
Paper Stocks for Good Times and Bad
description: LEAD: Paper stocks are the classic cyclicals. When the economy turns down, sales slip for cardboard boxes, business stationery and newsprint. As long as investors fear the economy will slow, the stocks will continue trading at below-market multiples. But three companies - the International Paper Company, the Mead Corporation and the Scott Paper Company - are worth considering because they have some reasonably stable product niches.

title: Anti-Abortion Protesters Arrested at Bronx Clinic
description: Scores of anti-abortion demonstrators were arrested yesterday while trying to block the entrance to an abortion clinic in the Pelham section of the Bronx.

title: 2 Benjamin Franklin Books Stolen From Library at Penn
description: Two rare books printed or written by Benjamin Franklin and worth up to $60,000 were stolen from the University of Pennsylvania library, the police said today.

title: A MANLY MAN THAKES HIS ACT ON THE ROAD
description: KEEP THE CHANGE By Thomas McGuane. 230 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Chancelor Shalala Joins the Police In a Raid on Underage Drinkers
description: Some students at the University of Wisconsin expressed ''shock and surprise'' when the school's chancellor, Donna E. Shalala, accompanied the city's police last weekend on raids of local parties where underage drinking was reportedly taking place.

title: Image-Makers In Takeover Land
description: ON THE AFTERNOON OF Tuesday, June 6, Lawrence A. Rand, a partner and senior vice president of the Manhattan public relations firm of Kekst & Company, was driving home to Westchester County with his son, Allan. ''My car phone rang at Madison and 51st,'' he recalls. ''It was Glenn Britt, the chief financial officer of Time Inc. He said, 'Your information was correct. We just heard from Marty Davis.' '' Rand pulled his BMW to the curb, gave the wheel to his son and headed toward Time headquarters in Rockefeller Center.

title: Review/ Theater; Faust and the Devil Go to Heaven
description: Faust and Mephistopheles go to heaven together, embraced by God, in Else Lasker-Schuler's ''I & I,'' a wild play that upends not only Goethe but also many Western literary, religious and historical traditions. Lasker-Schuler, a Jewish poet who fled Germany when the Nazis took over in 1933, wrote the play in Jerusalem in the early 40's and was still revising it when she died in 1945. Now the first English translation of the German text, by Beate Hein Bennett, is being staged by Judith Malina at the Living Theater, 272 East Third Street.

title: Carolyn Bekkedahl Wed in Delaware
description: Carolyn Bekkedahl, a daughter of Capt. Clifford Lewis Bekkedahl, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Bekkedahl of Westfield, N.J., and Michael Thomas Skrak 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Thomas Skrak Jr. of Chicago, were married yesterday at Seagate Manor in Dewey Beach, Del. The Rev. Michael Sparough, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: AFRICANS IN AWE OF THE CITY
description: THE SETTING SUN AND THE ROLLING WORLD Selected Stories. By Charles Mungoshi. 202 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. Paper, $8.95.

title: Characters Shine In 'Tom Jones'
description: ISN'T it rash of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival to take on a panoramic period piece that demands fluidity of movement, elegance of decor, an intrinsic lightness of touch and consistency of style? It isn't likely that even an occasional visitor to the festival's performances of its namesake playwright would consider those among the company's graces. Perversely, then, here is ''The Lusty and Comical History of Tom Jones,'' flaunting just what it hasn't got.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture caption today on page 62 of The Business World, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about women and golf, identifies Susan Okon as an employee of Shearson Lehman Hutton. After the article went to press, Ms. Okon left that company.

title: Trades Helped to Improve Rangers and Padres
description: Dealing in a whirlwind manner that made Trader Jack McKeon envious, Tom Grieve, the Texas Rangers' general manager, last December made 3 trades involving 15 players and signed a notable free agent. All in a 48-hour span.

title: A Storehouse of Public Opinion
description: A broadcast reporter called the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research in Storrs, the largest collection of national and international poll questions, to confirm a report. Could the center provide statistics supporting the contention that for the first time a majority of Americans say they favor a woman's right to an abortion?

title: Plumbing the Unknown in South Africa
description: AT his inauguration as President of South Africa last week, F. W. de Klerk assured his country and the world that an era of change lay ahead after four decades of apartheid. President de Klerk cast his inaugural address as a ''message of hope'' to a multiracial constituency whom he defined as ''all sensible South Africans'' and ''all reasonable people'' prepared to join his Government in an evolutionary transition.

title: Pretoria Stops Anti-Apartheid March
description: After tolerating technically illegal demonstrations for the last week and a half, the Government today cracked down on protest against apartheid by preventing a huge march by black and white women through the South African capital.

title: Where Guide Dogs Begin Training
description: LEAD: EVERY two weeks, Elana Levine opens up her home in Guilford to a raucus group of youngsters who have utter disregard for decorum and are intent on roughhousing. ''This is socialization,'' Mrs. Levine said with an indulgent smile as three oversized Labrador retriever puppies tumbled through the room.

title: Gooden to Forgo Rest of Season
description: Dwight Gooden has decided to forgo the last week of the season and save his right shoulder for next year. ''I'm just going to call it a year,'' Gooden said yesterday before the Mets' game with Montreal. ''That's what I decided. The situation the team is in, there's no sense for me to take a chance. If we were one or two games out, I would pitch. I could pitch now, but I wouldn't be 100 percent. Now I figure I might as well wait until next year and be 100 percent going into spring training.''

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Charlotte Frank has bachelor and master of arts degrees, is working on a doctorate in education and is a vice president of a large corporation. John Canemaker is head of the animation department at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. Nancy Holmes's novel ''Nobody's Fault'' is to be published by Bantam early in 1990. They don't have a lot in common, except for one thing. ''I hate that machine,'' Ms. Holmes said. ''I've given up,'' Mr. Canemaker said. ''I think it's a genetic problem.'' ''I become totally incompetent when I face it,'' Ms. Frank said. It's a sad state of affairs - for not only can they not operate the darned thing but the darned thing, more commonly called a VCR, is also beginning to gnaw at their self-confidence.

title: Suburbs Try Their Own Kind Of Drug War In the Schools
description: CONFRONTED with a growing responsibility to warn children about drugs, schools in the New York metropolitan region have reached beyond normal channels for help.

title: Rich, Complicated and Demanding Cezannes
description: Every so often there comes along an exhibition that we absolutely had to have. One such - and it goes straight to the top of its class - is ''Cezanne: The Bathers,'' at the Kunstmuseum in Basel. Like the exhibition of late Cezanne at the Museum of Modern Art in 1977, and like the exhibition ''Cezanne: The Early Years'' that was seen in Paris, London and Washington in 1988-89, it digs deep, and in a new way, into one of the supreme subjects of Western art.

title: A Night for Singles at a Blood Center
description: LEAD: 'WHAT a great opportunity to meet all these good-looking women,'' John Cholin, a 40-year-old engineer from Oakland, said as he surveyed the reception room at the Bergen County Regional Blood Center here one recent evening.

title: Patients' Families: More Doors Open
description: Family Friends is grateful for the article ''Volunteers Open Homes to Families of Patients'' [ Sept. 3 ] . Our nonprofit organization provides housing in private homes for family members of patients receiving specialized or emergency care in Westchester hospitals. Within the last year we have grown beyond our fondest hopes and now have more than 25 volunteer families who have provided more than 500 days of cost-free housing to family members of patients being treated in our area hospitals.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The naming of Hugh Southern as the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera continues a pattern, now 17 years old, of putting the job in the hands of men with executive experience but little or no operatic background. There can be little doubt that this is a decision calculated to further consolidate power in the hands of James Levine, who first joined the Met in 1973 as principal conductor and acquired the title of artistic director in 1986.

title: IN THE ANTIPODES
description: WHAT'S THE NEXT step for a globally minded entrepreneur who already enjoys the cachet of having his name affixed to a business school? (Vide, the William E. Simon Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Rochester.) An export program, of course.

title: Quebec Separatists Jockey for 90's Power Play
description: Jacques Parizeau, leader of Quebec's separatist Parti Quebecois, leaned into a microphone here this week and offered a familiar vision of the predominantly French-speaking province as a sovereign state.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Jule des Pres: Cereal Artist
description: LEAD: By borrowing an idea from ancient folklore, Jule des Pres is attracting a following here with simple parcels of wheat, oats and rye. Her signature look is a dense, twine-wrapped bunch of wheat stalks standing rigidly in a woven willow basket.

title: Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education
description: THE 1989 school board budgets are history. The pros and cons have been hashed and rehashed. The anti-tax groups have been heaped with calumny. They have been called demagogues for daring to suggest that schools are not akin to motherhood.

title: Prospects; When Jaguar Is the Prey
description: Last week the Ford Motor Company announced plans to acquire up to 15 percent of Jaguar P.L.C., the British maker of prestige automobiles. The offer was not welcomed by Jaguar, whose stock in London rose from $6.40 on Monday to $9.18 on Friday. The company is currently valued at about $1.68 billion. Three automobile experts and a Jaguar enthusiast give their views of Ford's offer. Ronald Glantz Automobile analyst, Montgomery Securities, San Francisco.

title: Beirut's Guns Silent; Some Exiles Return
description: After more than six months of fierce artillery battles, the guns of Lebanon's warring Christian and Muslim factions were silent today as their representatives agreed on measures intended to bring the country back to a semblance of normalcy.

title: How to Read Hopkins
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Litchfield, N.H.;
Suburbia, 'Going Urban'
description: LEAD: A SUBDIVISION with custom-built homes that will be priced well beyond the average house price of $145,000 for this town of 5,000 residents has been started by a developer here. Local officials see it as an example of what they would like the town to become.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Tennis Fan Finds Fun Ill-Served
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Sweet Jewish New Year
description: ROSH HA-SHANAH, the Jewish New Year, begins Friday evening. One symbolic food for the holiday is honey, which signifies a sweet New Year.

title: A RACE OF SUPERFOXES
description: LEAD: FRANKY FURBO By William Wharton. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. Paper, $12.95.

title: New York Region's Housing: No Signs of Return to Boom
description: More than a year after the great housing boom of the 1980's came to an end in New York City and its suburbs, the inventory of unsold homes has grown, demand remains sluggish and experts see no clear signs of improvement.

title: Taking Liberties?
description: Just when Richard M. Nixon was hoping it was safe to turn on the television again, he got wind of yet another Watergate movie in the works. For months, Mr. Nixon's lawyers tried to persuade ABC not to broadcast the program, ''The Final Days,'' based on the 1976 book by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein that turned a harsh light on end of the Nixon Presidency. One of Mr. Nixon's lawyers implied that the former President might sue the network, saying that the drama infringed on Mr. Nixon's ''right to privacy and his right to use his name and image to promote his own writings.'' If this gave ABC qualms, it didn't let on. A spokesman said last week that the show would go on, unchanged, next month.

title: Cubs Moving Closer to Title
description: In this improbable season for the Chicago Cubs, an improbable hero emerged today and helped nudge the club a game closer to a division championship.

title: ACTING,PREACHING AND FALLING
description: FORGIVEN The Rise and Fall of Jim Bakker and the PTL Ministry. By Charles E. Shepard. Illustrated. 635 pages. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.95.

title: Banks Take Blows On Foreign Debt
description: Some big banks took big steps to deal with their problem third world loans. J. P. Morgan added $2 billion to its loan-loss reserves, a move that is expected to give it a $1.8 billion loss in the quarter and a loss for the year. Chase Manhattan put aside an additional $1.15 billion and forecast a loss of $1.12 billion this quarter. Manufacturers Hanover added $950 million to reserves and said it expected a quarterly loss of $775 million. Executives of the banks said the arrangement worked out earlier this month between Mexico and its creditor banks showed a need to recognize the possibility of greater losses on third world loans. For many banks the agreement will mean accepting a 35 percent reduction in the value of their Mexican loans. American banks took similar actions in 1987, setting aside billions of dollars. *

title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo
description: IN THE >CRACKDOWN on >crack and other drugs, there may be no >magic bullet, but >drug kingpins, narco-terrorists and even >casual users - not to mention >carpers on the sidelines - can expect >zero tolerance.

title: Suzanne Hooper, an Editor, Is Married
description: Suzanne d'Harcourt Hooper, the managing editor of the publications program at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, and Michael Christie Huebsch, a vice president and senior portfolio manager at Blackstone Financial Management in New York, were married yesterday at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Stephen Kent Jacobson officiated. Mrs. Huebsch is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian S. Hooper of Devon, Pa. A graduate of Denison University, she received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University. Her father retired as the chairman and chief executive officer of the IOT Corporation, a transporter of petroleum products now known as Maritrans Partners. The bride is a granddaughter of Elizabeth H. Shober of Devon.

title: 3 Couples Make 'Baby' A Welcome Arrival
description: EVERY parent knows the story of ''Baby,'' the musical by David Shire, Richard Maltby and Sybille Pearson now at the Arena Players' Main Stage Theater in East Farmingdale. Every friend of every parent will recognize the characters in ''Baby.'' In fact, everyone who is or ever was a wanted baby from a middle-class home will find ''Baby'' recognizable. It is also charming musical theater.

title: CRIME
description: Early in Martha Grimes's 10th mystery, THE OLD SILENT (Little, Brown, $18.95), Richard Jury of Scotland Yard finds himself in need of ''a calm book'' - something to stave off one of those bouts of melancholy to which this romantic detective is inclined, and to ease the bleakness of a winter's day in Yorkshire. He notices that an attractive woman stopping at the inn where he's staying is reading Camus's ''Myth of Sisyphus.'' (''Not a calm book at all.'') He also notices when she pulls out a gun in the dining room and shoots her husband dead.

title: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Additional Alternatives To the Shoreham Plant
description: Regarding the article ''Despite Shoreham's Closing, Energy Alternatives Exist'' (Aug. 13) by Thomas A. Twomey Jr.:

title: LARGE, UNCONTAINABLE HEROINES
description: OBSCENE GESTURES FOR WOMEN By Janet Kauffman. 110 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Waterfront Developer Picked
description: The Battery Park City Authority has named a developer for a waterfront condominium, clearing the way for the construction of a long-planned Holocaust museum.

title: Vanished Monuments to Argentine Austerity
description: People turning out to enjoy the sun in the parks and plazas of Buenos Aires in the Southern Hemisphere's first week of spring had an unpleasant surprise: Several statues and other sculptures had been stolen.

title: WESTERN SAGA: A CLASH ON THE PRAIRIE
description: CHEYENNES AND HORSE SOLDIERS The 1857 Expedition and the Battle of Solomon's Fork. By William Y. Chalfant. Illustrated by Roy Grinnell. 415 pp. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press. $24.95.

title: Yankee Affair Captures The Man o' War by 5 1/2
description: Yankee Affair, who was beaten by just a length after a wide trip in the Arlington Million three weeks ago, found a soft Belmont Park turf course and a softer field to his liking yesterday and bounded away to a 5 1/2-length victory in the $470,400 Man o' War Stakes.

title:
FOCUS: Suburban Boston;
Condo Sellers Turn to Creative Marketing
description: LEAD: WITH sales listless in the suburban Boston condominium market, developers are offering a variety of incentives to buy - including below-market mortgage rates and lease-to-buy options. In at least one case, the developers will even purchase buyers' homes.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Putting Rainwear To the True Test
description: Last week New York endured quite a bit of what the weather forecasters on television call ''thundershower activity'' and the rest of the English-speaking world calls rain. Whatever, the stuff came down in buckets, creating Lake Ticonderoga-sized puddles at every corner.

title: Georgia Deaver: Calligrapher
description: Georgia Deaver has applied her art to opera programs (San Francisco and Seattle) and to beer cans (Sapporo Silver). But she draws the line at counterfeit college diplomas or people who want ''something very tight and clunky'' not in keeping with the free-flowing letter forms she prefers.

title: Question Of the Week; Do College Fotball Polls Mean Anything?
description: Since major sports rankings are ultimately determined by win-loss records at season's end and since man cannot absolutely predict the future, then pre- and midseason rankings are fictions. But they are meaningful fictions. Without polls, college sports interest would be localized to Ann Arbor, Austin or Lexington. Polls are necessary to transfer fan interest from the local level to the national. Polls take the energy of sports enthusiasm, spread over the entire country, and focus it on a few teams.

title: Promising Treatment for Skin Wounds
description: MR. W., a 69-year-old resident of Centereach, has been a diabetic for 20 years. This year, he has had several diabetic skin ulcers, or surface wounds, on his legs and feet that have resisted healing as a result of the poor blood flow and nerve damage caused by the disease.

title: Rapid Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Debt, Foreign Investors Worry Washington
description: Although details of the meeting were not disclosed, when Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner sat down to breakfast on Friday with Alfred Checchi, the leader of the investment group that is buying Northwest Airlines, it is likely Mr. Skinner had some strong things to say. The meeting was described as a private talk about Northwest's fitness to operate under new management, but the transportation secretary doubtlessly expressed concern about recent trends in the airline industry that are worrying many Government officials, both in the Administration and Congress.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My redwood deck is in the shade, and after heavy rain the wood gets slimy and slippery. I have a similar problem with a blacktop tennis court. What can I do?

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;
The Sport of Royalty Makes a Comeback Among Commoners
description: LEAD: Handicappers would probably give them a Minus 2, but the players at the new Southampton Hunt and Polo Club seem glad just to have found a relatively inexpensive way to play one of the world's most expensive sports.

title: FICTION
description: LAST THINGS. By Madison Jones. (Louisiana State University, $17.95.) Finishing Madison Jones's eighth novel is like waking up from someone else's nightmare - or maybe being released from someone else's paranoid fantasy. That's because, although the fears that materialize in ''Last Things'' may not be anything like the reader's own, they still have a scary, spiky grip. As ''Last Things'' begins, Wendell Corbin has returned, against his better judgment, to his birthplace in the Deep South, the ironically named Bliss County. Here he intends to take up graduate studies with Leonard T. Rathbone, who, like Wendell, is a zonked-out fan of both William Blake and marijuana. But as quick as you can say cannabis, Wendell, who had done some dealing in his undergraduate days, is set up in a drug sale and given the chance, as a condition of his release by the corrupt arresting officers, to become a soldier in the illegal drug-running operation of a local businessman, Jason Farrow. Wendell's assignments include getting rid of a busybody who happens to have guessed what Farrow is up to and is also, conveniently enough, the hateful mother-in-law of Tricia Harker, a Nietzsche-obsessed woman that Wendell has taken up with. Wendell's uneasiness over his illicit activities eventually prevails, and he blows the whistle on the chicanery - but without producing quite the results he had intended. Although ''Last Things'' ends as an exploration of what can happen when middle-class morality is flouted, it begins as if it's going to be another satire of academia. But although there's a shift of gears midway, going from first to second certainly gives ''Last Things'' a surge of giddy power.

title: 'Active' Speakers Have Their Needs
description: It may never spark a widespread trend, but a rising number of serious audio fans are opting for loudspeakers that contain their own built-in amplifiers. Called ''active'' speakers, such designs aim at the specific matching of speakers and amplifiers within a single structural unit. As one engineer explains it, ''In an active speaker, the amplifier knows the speaker it is driving.''

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Early Ways of Farming On View in Westchester
description: The disappearing agricultural heritage of Westchester County is just part of the appeal of Muscoot Park, a 777-acre area of rolling fields and dense woodland that includes a turn-of-the-century-style farm.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The 1989 World Team Championships now ending after two weeks have been greatly aided by the marvels of modern technology. NEC, a giant Japanese computer corporation, is the major sponsor and provided a wide range of equipment.

title: POSTINGS: 388 East 88th St.; 46-Story Condo Rising
description: One of the tallest buildings on the Upper East Side, a 46-story tower that is to house 163 condominium apartments, is under construction at the southwest corner of 88th Street and First Avenue on the site of what was a Children's Aid Society building. The $82 million project, named Leighton House and carrying the address 388 East 88th Street, is being undertaken by the General Atlantic Realty Corporation, which bought the society's five-story building. As part of the deal, General Atlantic also renovated the adjoining Rhinelander Children's Center at 350 East 88th Street for the society.

title: When Just Owning a Car Is a Hazard
description: Did you hear the one about the guy who puts a ''No Radio'' sign on his car, goes off to a party and returns to find his car window smashed and a handwritten note saying, ''Get One.''

title: Yorktown Is Granted a Hearing on I.B.M. Toxic-Waste Plan
description: PROMPTED by an outpouring of letters from concerned residents, state officials agreed last week to hold a public hearing on the International Business Machine Corporation's request to store hazardous and toxic waste at its Yorktown site.

title: First Conviction Based On DNA Use Is Upheld
description: The first murder conviction in the nation based on the use of DNA ''fingerprinting'' has been upheld by the State Supreme Court.

title: Social Events
description: The Tram to Morocco

title: Bulletproof Vest Saves Officer as Suspect Is Killed
description: A uniformed police officer was shot in the back yesterday in Brooklyn, but his life was saved by a bulletproof vest, the police said.

title: Jennifer Cannon Weds
description: First Lieut. Jennifer Anne Cannon, U.S.A.F., and First Lieut. Warren Woodward Michelsen, U.S.A.F., both stationed at Fairchild Air Force Base in Spokane, Wash., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert W. Gish, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Damon House in Mica, Wash.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bellport
description: LEAD: ON a walk down Main Street in Bellport, one is likely to see parked cars with windows rolled down and keys in the ignition. In this unspoiled village on the South Shore of Long Island, the foremost concern is not crime. It is maintaining tradition.

title: As Giuliani Edges Right, His Party Is Skeptical
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI began last week to put together the pieces of a Republican Party shattered even more than usual by a bruising primary battle.

title: Police Leader Likens Rival Group to Klan
description: The president of a group of minority police officers has labeled a rival group that consists primarily of white officers as racist. The comments on Thursday have prompted some members of the minority group to distance themselves from the description.

title: Playwriting and the Creative Process
description: ONE morning last month in a rehearsal studio on the campus of Princeton University, a playwright, a couple of actors and a director were sitting around, talking about a scene. It concerned a retired, widowed teacher on the brink of suicide. His colleague and best friend, a homosexual, tries to talk him out of it, and offers to move in with him. To understand the playwright's intentions, the director and the actors were exploring the implications of the two men's relationship. In turn, the playwright explained some lines and deleted others. Two days later, in another space on the university grounds, the now-revised scene, titled ''The Heart Engages,'' was one of several dramatic sketches being given a staged reading before an audience consisting mostly of other playwrights and directors. As a result of the audience response, the director's and actors' perceptions of the characters were confirmed. During a post-performance discussion, the playwright himself arrived at a new perspective on the scene he wrote.

title: Budapest Finds Coat of Arms Suits It Better Than Red Star
description: The red star, the symbol of Communist rule in the Eastern bloc for four decades, will be removed from all public buildings in Hungary to reflect the country's move toward a multiparty democracy.

title: ABOUT YOUR BOOK ...

The revisions, made at the request of developers, owners and tenants of industrial sites, constituted an effort to clarify the events and terms under which compliance is required.

title: The High-Risk World Of Colombian Politics

He is Senator Ernesto Samper Pizano, the governing party's leading presidential candidate, and his predicament points up the risks of political life in Colombia.

title:

Gossip: Say That Again?

description: France's Transport Ministry said today that the flight recorders of the DC-10 that crashed in the African desert on Tuesday supported the hypothesis that a bomb had exploded on the plane.

title: Where the Troops and Observers Are
description: Here are existing or planned operations of United Nations peacekeeping forces and observers. Middle East United Nations Truce Supervision Organization: 296 observers assist peacekeeping forces in Lebanon and the Golan Heights. Created in 1948. United Nations Disengagement Observer Force: 1,329 troops and observers monitor disengagement between Israel and Syria on the Golan Heights. Created in 1974. United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon: 5,851 troops provide buffer between Israel and Lebanon. Created in 1978. Kashmir United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan: 36 observers monitor cease-fire between India and Pakistan. Created in 1949. Cyprus United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus: 2,122 soldiers and 34 police officers seek to prevent fighting between Greek and Turkish parts of island. Created in 1964. Afghanistan United Nations Good Offices Mission to Afghanistan and Pakistan: 40 military observers were sent to oversee Soviet withdrawal. Created in 1988. Persian Gulf United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Group: 412 military observers monitor cease-fire in Iran-Iraq war. Created in 1988. Namibia United Nations Transitional Assistance Group: 4,500 troops and 1,000 policemen oversee Namibia's transition to independence from South Africa. Created in 1988. Central America United Nations Observation Group in Central America: Undetermined number of observers are to oversee the regional peace plan. Created in 1989. United Nations Observation Mission for the Verification of Elections in Nicaragua: Team of 70 are to observe elections planned for next year. Created in 1989.

title: Soviet 'Soldiers' Dance to a Peaceful Beat
description: Oddly - or perhaps not -the exceedingly well-traveled Alexandrov Red Army Song and Dance Ensemble from the Soviet Union is making its United States debut only this fall on a North American tour that began this month at the City Center.

title: Denial Suppresses Moments of Magic
description: WHEN we are young, we have sudden loves. An article of clothing or a toy catches our eye and totally captivates us for the moment. Getting the object is the be-all and end-all of our existence. All too often, our parent or grandparent imposes his or her superior wisdom and all our hopes and passionate desires are dashed and lost forever. The sensible solution becomes ashes in our mouth.

title: A BATTLE FOR BRANDS PROPELS BUYOUTS
description: The consolidation among fragrance makers over the past year has dramatically reordered the industry. For instance, Unilever PLC, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products conglomerate, entered the market in 1987 and is now the nation's third-largest fragrance producer. Over the last few years, Avon Products Inc., the market leader, has moved even farther ahead of its closest competitor, Estee Lauder. And Revlon Inc. has fallen to fourth place, from second in 1981, chiefly because it focuses on inexpensive fragrances, which are steeply discounted.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: I am a black male of a slightly earlier generation than Anthony Walton (''Willie Horton and Me,'' by Anthony Walton, Aug. 20). I, too, was born of a background of Southern sharecroppers. My father was able to leave his father's sharecropping home under protest (he was the oldest male and he was, therefore, a valuable resource on the farm). He left in order to go to school. He became a physician and developed a modicum of economic success. I was privileged to receive an Eastern prep-school education and a degree from Harvard. My professional education should have allowed me to move more freely in society than I can. However, early on, I learned it wasn't possible for me to enjoy the freedoms enjoyed by my many white friends with whom I went to school.

description: THIS IS MOSTLY ABOUT LUCK. SPECIFICALLY IT is about how William J. Levitt, the builder who practically invented the modern suburbs, made his own good luck through a series of astute moves and enjoyed its rewards with gusto for nearly 50 years, and how after conspiring in his own bad luck, he is enduring the turn of fortune with grace in his old age. At 82, he fends off a plague of creditors, but he does not brood as he watches other, younger builders flaunt their wealth as he once did.

title:
MUSIC;
Orchestras Look in New Directions

title: READING FOOD: THERE'S MYTHOLOGICAL CONSTRUCTION IN MY SOUP
description: ''Food is good to think,'' Claude Levi-Strauss has said, and it is certainly good to read. American commercial publishers who once thought of cookbooks as strictly ''How-to'' now embed recipes in costly illustrated works that dramatize the rise of food from kitchen to library, where readers who never lifted pot or pan whet their chops each season over cookbooks, reading them as travel literature, social comedy, utopian fantasy, pastoral romance. Similarly, American university presses that once ignored food as a trivial pursuit have jumped on the culinary bandwagon to produce works as unpretentious as ''Chicken Foot Soup'' (Rutgers University, 1980) and as encompassing as ''Food and Evolution: Toward a Theory of Human Food Habits'' (Temple University, 1987). What has happened in the last decade is a revolution in the way Americans think and read food.

title: A Talent for Bad Luck and Intense Commitment
description: ''Ariel'' ends with an inadvertently funny touch, a wonderful case of humor gained in translation. You have to hear it to believe it, but ''Somewhere Over the Rainbow'' is extremely funny sung in Finnish, as it is over the closing credits of Aki Kaurismaki's film. It will be shown today at 4:30 and tomorrow at 6:15 as part of the New York Film Festival. Accidental though that comic touch is, it perfectly suits the skewed perspective and intentional dark humor of Mr. Kaurismaki's story about a man with an extraordinary talent for making his bad luck infinitely worse.

title: Lovers Get A Second Chance In 'Bird on a Wire'
description: While the actress Goldie Hawn sat knitting a sweater for her baby son, her co-star, Mel Gibson, entertained the film crew with magic tricks, and tigers prowled a make-believe jungle nearby. Such was the scene here recently during production of ''Bird on a Wire'' in surroundings that sometimes looked more like a game farm than a film set. The last 10 minutes or so of this action comedy take place in an indoor zoo, complete with steamy jungle and real animals, that was constructed for the movie inside a six-story studio in this west coast Canadian city.

title: Life With Mother Was a Parade of Great Artists
description: What a time to be without a tape recorder! Benny Goodman, who had comparatively recently discovered the joys of classical music, was there, in my family's Manhattan apartment, and, along with Milton Katims, the violist, and Benny's famous jazz partner, the pianist Teddy Wilson, had just finished playing the Mozart Clarinet Trio under the watchful eye of my mother, the pianist Nadia Reisenberg. It was a long time ago - I was just a teen-ager - but I remember vividly that, after the Mozart, Benny and Teddy swung into some improvisations, the first of which was a totally spontaneous, absolutely delicious takeoff on the main theme of the Trio finale.

title: 'I CAN'T TELL YOU HOW SAD LIFE IS'
description: THE YEAR OF THE ZINC PENNY By Rick DeMarinis. 174 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: FICTION
description: THE CROWN: A Tale of Sir Gawein and King Arthur's Court. By Heinrich von dem Turlin. Translated by J. W. Thomas. (University of Nebraska, $25.) Readers accustomed to high-minded, nostalgic versions of the King Arthur tales may be surprised, amused, perhaps even shocked by this rollicking story by the 13th-century Austrian poet Heinrich von dem Turlin. J. W. Thomas's is the first translation into any modern language of ''Die Krone'' (''The Crown''), a compilation of oral folklore and medieval chronicles fashioned here into a cleverly plotted adventure novel. Lancelot, Guinevere and even Arthur are minor characters in this work. The focus is on Sir Gawein, whose exploits are, in turn, bold, violent, tender, sensual and sometimes intentionally ludicrous. The knight is presented as the savior of Arthur's court (which is located, in this version, in Brittany), the idealized center of culture and social pleasure. However, Gawein is untroubled by complex or deep feelings and often seems to trounce his foes for the sheer excitement of it. Marvelous, grotesque images abound and extraordinary monsters are dispatched with suitable ferocity. Events like these turn Gawein's quest for the Grail, one of the book's subplots, into a surreal journey through Purgatory. Magic is often integral to the story line, but the descriptions of court life - festivals, castles, costumes, jousts, hunts - are rendered in vivid, realistic detail. In contrast to the familiar British Arthurian romances, there is no suggestion in von dem Turlin's work that the age of chivalry is doomed. At the end, Gawein captures a stone guaranteeing perpetual victories for his monarch, and even receives the gift of eternal youth from a castleful of maidens. King Arthur's court lives on - and now, with this lively translation of ''The Crown,'' a new collection of its legends can be enjoyed by a wide audience.

title: Counselor To The King
description: THE INVESTIGATION BEGAN IN DECEMBER OF 1986. Officials from Britain's Department of Trade and Industry descended upon the London headquarters of Guinness P.L.C., a huge liquor conglomerate. When the charges were lodged five months later, Ernest W. Saunders, the chairman, and a number of leading British business figures stood accused of stock manipulation in connection with Guinness' $4.1 billion takeover of Distillers Company. At the heart of the case was a letter to a lawyer from Olivier Roux, an executive of the Boston-based management consulting firm of Bain & Company. Roux, on loan to Guinness, had served as controller and financial director of the British company and as a member of its board of directors. In his letter he defended his own actions and implicated Ernest Saunders. Roux was not charged. Saunders, who says Bain's behavior in the case was ''ruthless,'' is scheduled to face trial in January.
