title: Review/Theater; Revising History of Lincoln
description: The great American game of discovering the ''real'' assassin of a President or other major public figure is stretched to its most absurd limit in ''The Man Who Shot Lincoln,'' a play by Luigi Creatore that opened Thursday night at the Astor Place Theater.

title: Pseudo-Liberal Hogwash?
description: To the Editor:

title: Holden Caulfield's Subversive Message Is Distrust of Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: Big 2d Quarter for Clemson
description: Wesley McFadden scored on runs of 6 and 12 yards, and Mitch Belton started a 21-point second quarter with a blocked punt as Clemson defeated Maryland today, 31-7.

title: Miss Marciw Wed To Robert Griffin
description: Elizabeth Ann Marciw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steve Marciw of Pocono Manor, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert H. Griffin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John F. Griffin of Longmeadow, Mass., at St. Mary of the Mount Roman Catholic Church in Mount Pocono, Pa. Msgr. Arthur J. Kaschenbach officiated.

title: U.S. Misses Chance to Tie in Ryder
description: With the Americans in good position to move up to a tie with the European team in the 28th Ryder Cup matches, two of the best United States pro golfers let the final four-ball match slip away over the last three holes today.

title: Lake Champlain Is Searched for a 1776 Gunboat
description: Under slate gray skies on the waters of Lake Champlain, it is easy to imagine the day in October 1776 that Benedict Arnold scuttled two of his gunboats off Schuyler Island.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS END WITH PROGRESS ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union ended two days of talks here today by proclaiming progress on a broad array of arms control issues.

title: HOT STUFF
description: In the article ''Hot Stuff'' (Food, July 23), Regina Schrambling writes: ''Apparently there's no scientific logic for it, but hot climates and spicy food seem to go together like chocolate and vanilla.'' The surgeon George Crile believed they do indeed go together, and cited a physiological basis for it in his autobiography, published posthumously in 1947.

title: Review/Theater; A Homily in African Song and Dance
description: If enthusiasm were all it took, most shows would be hits and ''Goree,'' a homily about self-discovery told primarily through African song and dance, would be a smash.

title: POSTINGS: Faux Colonial; Clock Tower Mall
description: A 60-foot-high clock tower is being built as the centerpiece of a small retail and commercial mall under construction in the Brewster, N.Y.

title: Age 1, Going Strong
description: ''It's Happy Birthday DKNY,'' Donna Karan said as she welcomed retailers to her showroom Friday for the first presentation of her less-expensive line's spring collection. Just one year old and carried in 365 stores throughout the country, DKNY is one of the biggest successes on Seventh Avenue. The line is expected to make $90 million worth of sales for 1990.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $162,000 477 First Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, pool; taxes $4,200. Farmingdale $194,000 324 Vancott Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old splanch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, partial basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,800. Glen Head $372,500 29 Garfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; new kitchen, c/a, fireplace, greenhouse; taxes $4,000. Hicksville $160,000 81 Woodbine Drive North 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement work room; taxes $2,000. Massapequa $195,000 343 Massachusetts Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, finished basement, Florida room; taxes $4,300. Sayville $150,000 27 Harp Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,200. OTHER AREAS Enfield, Conn. $125,000 27 Alban Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old ranch; wraparound deck, woods at rear; taxes $1,168. Ossining, N.Y. $460,000 103 River Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; family room w/fireplace, new eat-in kitchen, deck, sprinkler system, 0.5 acre; taxes $6,588. Bradley Beach, N.J. $85,000 1104 Beach Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, h/w floors, front porch; taxes $1,547.

title: Hoping a Trip Helps Young Find Compass
description: Not just miles but worlds marked the distance from the fancy sailboats on Lake Michigan to the impoverished South Side neighborhood of Bill Pinkney's childhood.

title: Beware the Conversation Miser
description: IT'S fashionable these days to complain about widespread rudeness, and with good reason. So I think I'll jump on the bandwagon. But I won't be referring here to tailgating motorists or discourteous salespeople. These are strangers.

title: SIMIAN SOJOURN
description: LEAD: THE DELUGE AND THE ARK A Journey Into Primate Worlds. By Dale Peterson. Foreword by Jane Goodall. Illustrated. 378 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: 'Heart Condition' Raises the Specter Of Bigotry
description: Considering Hollywood's preference for escapism, it is surprising to see the cameras turning on a spate of strong, controversial movies about racial conflict. ''Do the Right Thing'' and ''Mississippi Burning'' have drawn large audiences as well as reams of divided critical commentary, and more stories about racial prejudice are to hit the theaters during the next year. ''It's interesting how many movies are exploring this area,'' says Steve Tisch, the producer of ''Heart Condition,'' a comedy about racism filmed around Los Angeles this summer.

title: Design; OPEN HOUSE: HANGING OUT NEW SHINGLES
description: NO TYPE OF HOUSING HAS BEEN more closely copied during the past decade than the shingle-style house. The reasons are many. As architects have taken a new look at forms from the past, they have come to appreciate the scores of shingled houses built during the early decades of this century. From a practical point of view, shingled exteriors make sense. Along the shores of the Atlantic, for example, these houses age gracefully. Moreover, this style of building is instantly comforting. The traditional gabled rooflines, rambling porches and welcoming, centered front door commonly identified with the shingle style conform to our old-fashioned notion of home.

title: Kimi C. Puntillo, TV Aide, Is Bride
description: St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kimi Carmela Puntillo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Puntillo of Sands Point, L.I., to William Richard Collins. The Rev. Jeffrey Johnston performed the ceremony.

title: Sports of The Times; Why the Mets Didn't Win: Dr. K
description: Now some of the Mets are blaming the club shrink for their shrinking season.

title: Sudden Support for National Health Care
description: PROPOSALS that might once have been denounced as socialized medicine or ignored as too costly are now getting serious consideration in Washington, with various plans for insuring America's health receiving the support of labor, industry and the medical establishment.

title: Groups Taking Donations for Aid to Storm Victims
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's Department of Puerto Rican Community Affairs in the United States has asked that donations to assist victims of Hurricane Hugo be sent to the American Red Cross or branch offices of three banks that are setting up special accounts for Puerto Rican disaster assistance. The banks are Banco Popular, Banco de Ponce and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: Christopher Who?
description: To the Editor:

title: DISTORTIONS IN THE GLASS
description: APPLAUSE By Carol Muske. 53 pp. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $8.95. DIEN CAI DAU By Yusef Komunyakaa. 64 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $18; Paper, $9.95.

title: WHAT POE DIDN'T KNOW
description: RAVENS IN WINTER By Bernd Heinrich. Illustrated. 379 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Alexandra Goldsmith, Merchandiser, Is Married to Dr. J. Randall Forbes
description: Alexandra Goldsmith, a daughter of Dr. William M. Goldsmith and Dr. Marianne G. Goldsmith of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Dr. J. Randall Forbes, the son of James Forbes of San Francisco and Janice Forbes Geil of Auburn, Calif. The Rev. John Schulle, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Newspaper Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: Return to the Killing Fields
description: On April 12, 1975, soon after Lon Nol, Cambodia's President, had fled the country, the United States withdrew its forces from the capital. Sydney Schanberg, then a New York Times correspondent, and Dith Pran, his Cambodian assistant, stayed on to cover the story of the battle-scarred country under the control of the Khmer Rouge and their leader, Pol Pot. Eight days after the evacuation, Dith Pran was forced, with hundreds of thousands of other Cambodians, to march from Phnom Penh to the countryside. There, he was to endure almost four years of unremitting horrors.

title: Don't Blame Johnny Carson
description: To the Editor:

title: CampusLife: Canisius; Students' Backing Of Athletic Field Puts It on Campus
description: Sandwiched onto the Canisius College campus, between a subway stop and the basketball arena, is a new $4 million athletic field where next Saturday the college's football team will play its first game on campus.

title: WHO'S WHO IN ISLAMBAD
description: BREAKING THE CURFEW A Political Journey Through Pakistan. By Emma Duncan. 313 pp. New York: Michael Joseph/Viking. $22.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Do College Fotball Polls Mean Anything?
description: Unfortunately, yes. Until the bowl games are formulated into a playoff tournament (Rose Bowl winner vs. Orange Bowl winner, to play the winner of the Fiesta and the Sugar, and so on, for example), the poll will be the only way to decide the national champion. Mythical national champion, that is. We can eliminate the word mythical once a playoff tournament has been devised. Thus bowl games would still be played and bowl revenue would not be lost. Until then, the poll is the only way to decide the national champion. Shouldn't the national champion be decided on the field rather than by a group of sportswriters sitting at their desks? STEVEN L. SCHEY Hoboken, N.J.

title: Robert M. Gray, Ad Executive, 85
description: Robert M. Gray, an advertising executive who devised the ''Tiger in Your Tank'' gasoline campaign for Exxon in the mid-1960's, died Friday at the Twelve Oaks Hospital in Houston. He was 85 years old and lived in Houston.

title: Brumfield Retires
description: He rode Kauai King to victory in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in 1966. He rode 4,572 winners in 33,222 mounts, earning purses totaling $43,557,499. Now, saying it is ''time to do it,'' Don Brumfield is retiring after 35 years as a jockey.

title: Rapid Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: McGUIRE AIR SHOW

title: New York's New Schools Chief Has a Super-Decentralization Plan
description: EVEN before he arrives in New York City in January to take over the public schools, Joseph A. Fernandez has clearly signaled what he intends to do when he gets here.

title: C.W. Post Upsets Hofstra by 23-14
description: Dave Shanahan rushed for a school-record 197 yards in 43 carries and scored on a 2-yard run as C. W. Post upset previously undefeated Hofstra, 23-14, yesterday at Hickox Field in Brookville, L.I.

title: Works in Progress; Avanti
description: TRAVELERS TO ROME HAVE long known that when their flights land, their journeys aren't over. An hour from town if the traffic is cooperative, the airport has never been joined to the city's rail system. Next year, however, after seven years of construction, the Italian State Railway Company expects to open a 26-kilometer stretch of track that will connect Leonardo da Vinci Airport with Ostiense station, near St. Paul's basilica. Most of the line is subterranean, but within the airport itself, where work is underway, the tracks are elevated and are being covered over in paneling supported by yellow steel pipes (above). According to Arturo Pandolfo, who is managing the project for the State Railway Company, the system will run both nonstop and local trains, reducing travel time into the city to between 10 and 15 minutes. The system will have the capacity to run its six-car trains every 10 minutes, and he expects it will handle up to 4,000 passengers per hour. ''But our system is flexible,'' he says, speaking in a phone interview through a translator. ''We can increase hourly capacity by adding up to four cars to trains.''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IN PRAISE OF IMPERFECTION: My Life and Work, by Rita Levi-Montalcini. Translated by Luigi Attardi. (Basic Books, $9.95.) With the powers of that imperfect engine called the brain, an Italian neuroscientist discovers a chemical that makes nerve fibers grow and wins a Nobel Prize. This is ''an arresting story of someone who insisted on being herself rather than someone else's idea of herself,'' Victor K. McElheny said here last year. ''With great immediacy, she shows us how she has constructed her life.'' VANISHED, by Mary McGarry Morris. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) Without really meaningJU to, Aubrey Wallace, a dull-witted middle-aged road worker, runs off with Dotty Johnson, a 14-year-old runaway who has just murdered the father who sexually abused her. Rounding out their makeshift family with a stolen baby, they embark on a five-year odyssey of cheap motels and truck stops. ''Melodramatic as these events sound, they are presented with such authority by Ms. Morris that they hum with both the authenticity of real life and the mythic power of fable,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. ''This is a startling and powerful debut.'' THE LAST LION. Winston Spencer Churchill: Alone 1932-1940, by William Manchester. (Laurel/Dell, $13.95.) In the second volume of this popular biography, William Manchester asks why it took so long for Britain to wake up to Churchill's warnings about the Nazis. ''Mr. Manchester has a warm and affectionate admiration for Churchill,'' Kenneth Harris said here last year. Though historians may quibble at an occasional interpretation, ''thousands will read this book with great satisfaction.'' THE ASSIGNATION, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) These very short stories by Joyce Carol Oates ''have the transient shock effects of a newspaper headline,'' James Atlas said here in 1988. ''Holdups, shootings, random attacks are regular occurrences. Reading Ms. Oates, you get the feeling that it's dangerous out there.'' TOLSTOY, by A. N. Wilson. (Fawcett Columbine, $14.95.) As he died in a train station, fleeing his home and family for a destination unknown, Tolstoy proclaimed: ''I cannot go to sleep. I am always composing. I write and it all links itself together like music.'' In trying to explain how the novelist built so inescapable a mental prison, A. N. Wilson has written ''passages [ that ] display an uncanny intimacy with the alchemy of Tolstoy's art,'' Michael Ignatieff said in The Book Review last year. FEEDING THE EAGLES, by Paulette Bates Alden. (Graywolf, $8.) When these short stories about a Southerner exiled in Minneapolis were published last year, our reviewer, David Dawson, said the author ''serves notice that you don't have to trot out the standard cliches -lecherous evangelists, okra, uncles with two first names, Co'Cola - to write about the South.'' WRITING A WOMAN'S LIFE, by Carolyn G. Heilbrun. (Ballantine, $6.95.) A humanities professor who writes mysteries tells how literature has conspired to make women seem more like men want them to be. In January, our reviewer, Wendy Martin, said, ''If Carolyn Heilbrun's astute and provocative book had been available 25 years ago, most of my friends and I could have been spared considerable grief.'' NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS, by Richard Wilbur. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) This collection of verses by the man named poet laureate of the United States in 1987 won a Pulitzer Prize. Last year Robert Richman said here that Richard Wilbur ''enriches his verse by showing a willingness to face the dangers entailed in the quest for what Wallace Stevens called the 'truth that cannot be arrived at by reason alone.' '' THE FEMALE ANIMAL, by Irene Elia. (Holt, $12.95.) Concentrating on the females of the species, an anthropologist writes about the sex lives of insects, fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals, including people. The work ''differs from other such books in that it focuses on female animals,'' Patricia Bridges said here last year. ''There is an underlying male orientation in most scientific literature, and a book that upends this stereotype presents a refreshing view.'' THE ACORN PLAN, by Tim McLaurin. (Norton, $7.95.) In this novel about life in a Southern mill town, Bubble Riley tries to save his nephew, Billy, from becoming a violent drunk. '' 'The Acorn Plan' is about excess - too much drinking, fighting, pride, family history - and Tim McLaurin conveys his understanding of such things in a clear Southern voice,'' Chris Goodrich said here last year. LISTENING OUT LOUD: Becoming a Composer, by Elizabeth Swados. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A young composer provides a practical guide to the highs and lows of breaking into the profession. Earlier this year, our reviewer, Michael Kimmelman, said the book ''usefully caters to the broadest possible audience - those who think Mozart is the crown prince among composers and those who think Prince is a modern Mozart. [ She has ] drawn a neat and well-reasoned map that every young composer would do well to consult.'' REAL ESTATE, by Jane DeLynn. (Ballantine, $3.95.) A relationship that doesn't work becomes trapped in an apartment about to go co-op. Despite some overbearing diatribes, this novel is ''an on-target, wickedly funny tale of musical apartments, malfunctioning appliances and misplaced passions,'' Ellen Feldman said here last year.

title: TOUGH RED UNION
description: UPHEAVAL IN THE QUIET ZONE A History of Hospital Workers' Union, Local 1199. By Leon Fink and Brian Greenberg. Illustrated. 298 pages. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Warriors Sign Blab
description: The Golden State Warriors, who already have three 7-footers scheduled for camp, have signed Uwe Blab, an unrestricted free agent, to a one-year contract. Terms of the contract were undisclosed, but the 7-foot-1-inch Blab made $280,000 last season as a center with the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Some Lessons From Avis for UAL Buyout
description: At 2 P.M. on the first Thursday of every month, thousands of employees at Avis Inc., the nation's No. 2 rental company, walk off their jobs. With their company's blessing they gather for employee-management sessions that are at the heart of Avis's two-year-old experiment with employee ownership. From these meetings, held across the country, have come such innovations as multilingual information cards for international customers at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York and a way to deter car theft in Baltimore.

title: FASHION: Browsing On Lower Fifth; New Word for Shopping: Flatiron
description: The Flatiron district, bounded by Broadway on the east, Seventh Avenue on the west and 23d and 14th Streets on the north and south, may become to the 90's what SoHo and Columbus Avenue were to the 80's -New York's hottest shopping area. Named for the 1902 Flatiron Building, on 23d Street where Fifth Avenue and Broadway meet, the district, and especially its showcase stretch of Fifth Avenue, offers clothing from the inexpensive to the eyebrow-raising.

title: The Best Way To Hear Jazz Is to See It
description: To learn the mechanics of jazz, there's nothing like recordings. Over repeated playing, every note can be caught, every harmony parsed. But unlike symphonic music, which can be perfected in recordings, or rock, which is often born and nurtured on tape, jazz has not let itself be reduced to its sounds. Jazz has a spirit that eludes the microphone, like ghosts that aren't reflected in mirrors. Enjoyable and vital as recordings are, jazz demands to be heard (and seen) live.

title: The Age of the Hierarchy Is Over
description: In 1854 my great-great-grandfather founded a small glass manufacturing business, the Union Glass Company. Today it is a global corporation known as Corning Inc. Until a few years ago, like most American companies, Corning had a traditional business structure more appropriate to the 19th century than the intense competitive environment of the 20th. The corporate hierarchy, with tasks strictly defined by organization charts and tightly drawn job descriptions, was deeply rooted in our history.

title: Insurance Adjusters Finding Astronomical Property Loss
description: LEAD: Hurricane Hugo is shaping up to be the most costly storm in terms of property damage that ever blew into the United States, according to early reports from insurers, who have dispatched a small army of claims adjusters in the Southeast.

title: Benching Urged For Power Nouns
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A CAR IS NOT A HOME
description: THE HISTORY OF LUMINOUS MOTION By Scott Bradfield. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: A proof specimen of a $20 territorial gold piece has been sold for a reported price of $1,350,000, the highest amount ever paid for an American numismatic item.

title: Beauty; FACING UP TO THE 90'S
description: WHEN KARL LAGERFELD UNVEILED HIS FALL COUTURE collection for the house of Chanel, he introduced a parade of new beauties who seemed far removed from the upright image of this venerable fashion institution. The three models shown here, he believes, display a changing sense of attractiveness.

title: Erica deGroot Weds
description: Erica deGroot, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willem deGroot of Burlington, Vt., was married yesterday to David Adam Lustgarten, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bennett P. Lustgarten of Ardsley, N.Y., and Saltaire, L.I. Justice of the Peace Ingrid Cichoski of Richmond, Vt., performed the ceremony at the nondenominational Round Church in Richmond.

title: Katherine McWhorter Wed
description: Katherine Elizabeth McWhorter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McWhorter of St. Louis, was married last evening to Dr. Philip Alan Seibel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Seibel of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Lawrence Siegel and the Rev. William Hague, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Kennedy-Warren building in Washington. Mrs. Seibel, 30 years old, was until recently the correspondence supervisor in the Washington office of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. She graduated from the University of the South. Dr. Seibel, 35, is a staff psychiatrist at the Terrell (Tex.) State Hospital. He graduated from Princeton University and Albany Medical College.

title: SOVIET PARLIAMENT TO WEIGH A PLAN FOR RIVAL PARTIES
description: An official working group of the Soviet legislature has drafted a law that would legalize the creation of alternative political parties and give them equal rights with the Communist Party, according to those involved in the project.

title: SIGNING UP CELEBRITY PROMOTERS TO GIVE PERFUMES STAR APPEALZ
description: A glut of perfumes has sent manufacturers scurrying for new ways to distinguish their brands from the masses. And signing up celebrities as promoters is their favorite new tool.

title: FROM THE CAMPUSES: ADVENTURES IN PUBLISHING
description: How much simpler this country would be if it had stalled out at 13 states. Most of the complicated mountains, climates and ethnic cultures would lie west of the border, as would all of the intimidating plains and deserts. Visiting the Great Lakes would be a foreignJU adventure.

title: Lice: Equal-Opportunity Scourge
description: ''MOM,'' she says, two days after her return from sleep-away camp, ''my head itches.'' I check her head, praying for dry scalp, and there I see the little white buggers clinging to her hair, hardly visible to an untrained eye. ''Lice,'' I scream in terror.

title:
INVESTING;
Tax-Free Trust Yields
description: LEAD: Investors truly can judge tax-free unit investment trusts by their advertised yields, thanks to a new policy that the Securities and Exchange Commission began enforcing this summer.

title: Friendly Rivalry For Old Friends
description: They were an odd couple in the St. Louis Cardinals' training camp in 1979.

title: The Third World Debt Crisis Reshapes American Banks
description: UNITED STATES banks are being reshaped as the problem of lending too much to third world countries continues to haunt them. As they are gradually being forced to raise more money to cushion themselves against future loan losses, banks are selling more assets, issuing new stock and pulling out of businesses that are not sufficiently profitable.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: STEPHEN LONGSTREET made his New Jersey art debut 74 years ago in his native New Brunswick. Of course he was only 8 years old, but that should not surprise anyone who has followed the career of this prolific artist, novelist and playwright.

title: Melissa Lesbines, A Pianist, Marries
description: Melissa Ann Lesbines, a concert pianist, was married yesterday to John Anthony Cheek, a founding member of the Omni Ensemble chamber music group in Brooklyn and a piano teacher at Concordia College in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Robert O'Connor performed the ceremony at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Wethersfield, Conn.

title: T.A.C. May Open an Inquiry
description: Senior officials of The Athletics Congress are meeting in New York this weekend to decide what, if anything, to do about accusations that Florence Griffith Joyner, Carl Lewis and other prominent American track and field athletes have used performance enhancing drugs.

title: ONCE BITTEN, TWICE SHY
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC HAS UN-leashed Nipper, the terrier that for so many years graced the labels of RCA Records.

title: A COVENANT WITHTHE SOIL
description: FARM A Year in the Life of an American Farmer. By Richard Rhodes. Illustrated by Bill Greer. 336 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: In Search of Sovereignty: The Cambodian Torment
description: Nov. 9, 1953 The kingdom of Cambodia, with Prince Norodom Sihanouk as monarch, is established as an independent state, effectively ending French control. Over the next 15 years, Prince Sihanouk struggles to maintain Cambodia's precarious neutrality. August 1969 The American-backed Marshal Lon Nol becomes Prime Minister under Prince Sihanouk, who delegates much of his power to the general. The United States begins military operations against Vietcong forces in Cambodia during the Vietnam War. March 18, 1970 Marshal Lon Nol deposes Prince Sihanouk as head of state and the Prince goes into exile in China, where he forms an alliance with the Communist Khmer Rouge, which had opposed him in Cambodia. Oct. 9, 1970 The Khmer Republic is proclaimed by the Lon Nol Government, ending Cambodia's 24 years as a constitutional monarchy. April 17, 1975 The Khmer Rouge guerrillas defeat Marshal Lon Nol's forces and take over Cambodia. Prince Sihanouk is reinstated as head of state. The Khmer Rouge imposes a brutal reorganization of society in which more than 1 million Cambodians die. April 2, 1976 Prince Sihanouk resigns and Pol Pot of the Khmer Rouge becomes Prime Minister. Dec. 25, 1978 Vietnam invades Cambodia. On Jan. 7, Pol Pot flees as Cambodia's capital, Phnom Penh, falls to the Vietnamese. A Hanoi-backed Government is installed. June 22, 1982 A Cambodian government-in-exile representing three guerrilla groups is formed with Prince Sihanouk as President, Khieu Samphan of the Khmer Rouge as Vice President and Son Sann as Prime Minister. April 5, 1989 Vietnam announces that all its troops will be withdrawn from Cambodia by Sept. 27. Aug. 30, 1989 Peace talks involving 19 nations and Cambodia's warring factions collapse with the scheduled withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia less than a month away.

title: Right Change for Small Change
description: The 35th Congress had the good sense to abolish the half-penny in 1857. The 101st should do likewise with the penny. But that's not what Congress has in mind. A House subcommittee will vote this week on a bill the Senate has already passed, to make U.S. coins look more ''patriotic.'' Why not make them more practical? Reform would abolish the penny and the half-dollar, and finally create a useful dollar coin.

title: Outrageous Acts Give Way to Eccentric Sculpture
description: In the early 1970's you could have bet good money that Chris Burden would not be having a museum retrospective in the late 1980's. At the time, Burden was one of the bad boys of contemporary art, a Conceptual artist specializing in grueling and sometimes gruesome performance works, also known as Body Art.

title: UPDATE: September 24, 1989
After 17 Years, A Director Reappears
description: Twenty-five years ago, a young unknown Japanese director named Hiroshi Teshigahara sent tremors through the world of cinema with a film of stunning originality, awesome power and technical brilliance. Called ''Woman in the Dunes,'' it won the Special Jury Prize at the 1964 Cannes Film Festival. A spectacular debut, agreed European film critics; and later in the same year acclaim greeted the film in America when it was shown at the New York Film Festival. Its impact was not quickly forgotten: nearly 20 years later, when the Film Society of Lincoln Center featured it again in a retrospective of the finest films from the first two decades of the New York Film Festival, ''Woman in the Dunes'' was the hottest ticket of the event.

title: How AIDS Made the Drug Regulators Speed Up
description: UNDER intense pressure from advocates for AIDS patients, the Food and Drug Administration has begun to make fundamental changes in the way it approves drugs for patients who are fatally ill. If the experiment works, the battle against AIDS may provide a model for regulating many other types of drugs in the future.

title: Elizabeth Ehrlich, a Student, Marries
description: Elizabeth Ehrlich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ehrlich of Bloomington, Ind., was married yesterday to Peter V. Dumanian, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ara Dumanian of Chicago. The Rev. Carl E. Munger, a Congregational minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents at Indiana University. Her father is the university's president.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Flattery, Fortissimo

title: MORE MONEY THAN ANYONE ELSE
description: FORTUNE'S CHILDREN The Fall of the House of Vanderbilt. By Arthur T. Vanderbilt 2d. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.95.

title: Has Kellogg Lost Its Snap?
description: Until last week it had seemed a fait accompli: In two years, Horst W. Schroeder, the 48-year-old president and chief operating officer of the Kellogg Company, would be the cereal giant's next chief executive. Yes, the 19-year Kellogg veteran had a reputation for being abrasive - at a company with a cozy, family-style culture. And no, he had not stemmed Kellogg's slide in market share since he took over the No. 2 spot last December.

title: Andrea Fry Weds Richard R. Blake In Pennsylvania
description: Andrea Victoria Fry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Fry of Reading, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Randolph Blake Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blake of Chestnut Hill, Pa. The Rev. Walter Krieger performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in Reading.

title: CONSUMER RATES
17 Killed and 38 Wounded In Rocket Attack on Kabul
description: At least 17 people were killed and 38 wounded when rebels unleashed the most ferocious attack on the Afghan capital in weeks, hospital and Government officials said today.

title: VOTER DRIVE SET FOR NEW JERSEY
description: Prodded by a national voting-rights organization and an executive order by Gov. Thomas H. Kean, state agencies in New Jersey are preparing for a voter registration effort that could significantly alter the makeup of the state's electorate.

title: Monday Myth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hot or Not, Partygoers Dance The Night Away
description: The hottest party of the week, literally, was the New York Philharmonic's opening-night Viennese Ball on Wednesday in a mammoth tent in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. The 1,100 guests, wearing the requested black and white, found themselves in a sumptuous setting without air-conditioning. The tent's sides could not be rolled up, and the guests started to melt. Men were told to remove their jackets, but it didn't spoil things. Most people sweated it out, dancing into the wee hours.

title: Sidney R. Pine, Lawyer, 79
description: Sidney R. Pine, a lawyer, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lessons Learned From a Silent Clock
description: THE clock on my living-room wall is one of my favorite things. It is a chime clock from Germany bought in 1971 from an elderly jeweler who lived with his wife in my hometown.

title: Correction
description: A listing of college football schedules on Aug. 27 incorrectly listed Boston University's games. The university's schedule is: Sept. 9, Delaware; Sept. 15, at West Chester; Sept. 23, at Dartmouth; Sept. 30, Massachusetts; Oct. 7, at Richmond; Oct. 14, at William & Mary; Oct. 21, Rhode Island; Oct. 28, at New Hampshire; Nov. 4, Maine; Nov. 11, at Connecticut; Nov. 18, at Villanova.

title: ISLAND HERITAGE
description: THE LINE OF THE SUN By Judith Ortiz Cofer. 291 pp. Athens, Ga.: The University of Georgia Press. $19.95.

title: U.S. Democrats Teach Politics to Hungarians
description: In a lakeside resort owned by the Communist Party's elite guard, an offshoot of the American Democratic Party sent representatives recently to teach Hungarian opposition leaders techniques to help them take power from the Communists in coming elections.

title: COLD FUSION CONFUSION
description: LEAD: ON MARCH 23, DR. B. STANLEY Pons of the University of Utah and Dr. Martin Fleischmann of England's University of Southampton announced that, working together, they had created nuclear fusion at room temperature in a test tube.

title: Question Of the Week; Do College Fotball Polls Mean Anything?
description: In college football, there are about 105 Division I-A teams and 89 I-AA teams in the nation. Not to mention about 116 Division II and 213 Division III teams. With so many teams, it is difficult to compare one team's record to another since their competition may have varied greatly.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE BASQUE HOTEL. By Robert Laxalt. (University of Nevada, $17.95.) A quiet lyricism suffuses this semiautobiographical novel about growing up in Nevada during the Prohibition and Depression years. ''The Basque Hotel'' is an episodic story focused on Pete, a Basque teen-ager whose parents operate a boarding house in Carson City (''the smallest capital in the United States''), enjoy brief prosperity, then return to the family's traditional work of sheepherding.

title: Dr. Helain Landy To Wed a Lawyer
description: The engagement of Dr. Helain J. Landy and Eli J. Dicker, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Herman Dicker of Flushing, Queens, has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Landy of Cranbury, N.J. A December wedding is planned.

title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say
description: Administration officials concede that the goal President Bush set forth in his drug-policy address to the nation three weeks ago - ''victory over drugs'' -cannot be achieved in this generation.

title: Name-Dropping
description: Arjune, by yet another name, was back out of sight last week. Mr. Arjune, who went into the Federal Witness Protection Program last year after his battle with New York City crack dealers led to the murder of a police officer guarding his home, turned up in Spokane, Wash., recently. Mr. Arjune, who was known locally as Amos Hardeen, accused the Spokane police of racial bias after his arrest on traffic charges. He said the only way to end the harassment was to reveal that he was a protected witness. The police denied any bias, but the case won't be coming to court soon, in any event. With Mr. Arjune's identity revealed - for the second time since he went into Federal protection, his lawyer said - Federal agents whisked him and his family away to parts unknown.

title: 'Balance' Is Boring
description: To the Editor As former chairman of the department of communications at C.C.N.Y., as former director of programming at WNET, as one of the producers of a new series on civil liberties and as a Jew, I was interested in Walter Goodman's discussion of the ''Days of Rage'' [ ''Public TV Juggles a Hot Potato,'' Sept. 3 ] .

title: Drug Abuse To Be Focus Of Hearing
description: NEW JERSEY, whose turnpike the authorities say has become a major channel for illegal drugs flowing into New York and whose cities are home to some 200,000 cocaine and heroin users, will convene a Congressional field hearing tomorrow in which local experts will testify on the narcotics problem in the northern part of the state.

title: Denver Graffiti Fighters Protest AIDS Murals
description: A state-financed project to remind drug users that they can help to avoid AIDS by not sharing needles has run into trouble with Denver's beautification campaign.

title: Pilar Uribe Marries Dr. D. F. Buxton, a Surgeon
description: Maria del Pilar Uribe, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Luis Enrique Uribe of New York and Ibague, Colombia, was married yesterday to Dr. Douglas Francisco Buxton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jorge N. Buxton of New York and Buenos Aires, at St. Gertrude's Roman Catholic Church in Bayville, L.I. The Rev. Theodore E. McCarrick performed the ceremony.

title: As the Market Becomes Flooded, Sales Sink
description: The American market is soaked in perfume. Manufacturers have been introducing 30 to 40 new fragrances a year - up from only 20 to 25 annually in the early 1980's. But instead of invigorating sales, it has made matters worse.

title: Miss Solomon, Writer, Marries
description: Deborah Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Solomon of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York to Dr. Kent Sepkowitz, a son of Dr. Samuel Sepkowitz of Oklahoma City and the late Enid Sepkowitz. Rabbi Levy Derby officiated.

title: McEnroe Praised For Team Style
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article today on page 22 of The Business World, part 2 of The Times Magazine, about Mario Baeza, a partner at the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, appears without a byline.

title: Bush Clean Air Plan Called Energy Policy in the Making
description: As members of Congress and interest groups look more closely at President Bush's clean air proposal, many are saying it is not just an anti-pollution plan but a national energy policy in the making.

title: TALKING: Interim Leases; Handle With Caution
description: ANYONE seeking to buy an apartment this fall in a New York City rental building undergoing conversion into a cooperative or condominium is likely to be offered an ''interim lease.''

title: An Increasing Need For Special Education
description: Re: ''Plan to Revamp Special Education Draws Criticism,'' Aug. 6:

title:
DINING OUT;
Appealing Italian Cuisine in Fanwood
description: LEAD: Rudolfo Hisna, the intimate, upholstered room is the setting for some appealing Italian fare. Formerly the Golden Goose, Rudolfo has been open since last December. Retaining the stylish decor but adding lovely bouquets of flowers and installing fairly polished, European-style service, the new management seems eager to please.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
Arnold & Porter Cuts a Big Deal
description: LEAD: AFTER a two-year search for a new headquarters, Arnold & Porter, the capital's largest law firm, has negotiated a 20-year lease with the Kaempfer Company that includes a sweetener of 30 percent ownership of a 12-story, 800,000-square-foot building to be developed on K Street. The deal is thought to be the largest private-sector lease in the district's history.

title: IRELAND WITHOUT THE TEARS
description: WALLED GARDENS Scenes From an Anglo-Irish Childhood. By Annabel Davis-Goff. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Laura Mosedale, Writer, Marries
description: Laura Paddock Mosedale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Munger Mosedale of New York and Star Island, Minn., was married yesterday to Matthew Mansfield Horgan, a son of John Poole Horgan 2d of New Canaan, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Joan Horgan. The Rev. Guthrie Speers, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the New Canaan home of the bridegroom's father.

title: Insisting On Disaster
description: William Bennett, the Bush drug czar, thinks the United States made a mistake when it repealed Prohibition in 1933. We would be better off if it were a crime to buy a drink.

title: Architects Must Listen to the Melody
description: Goethe once described architecture as frozen music; if he was right, could cities be described as congealed concertos? Maybe this is stretching an already flimsy metaphor, but music, architecture and cities do share one striking characteristic. Just as agreeable music requires both solo and ensemble playing, and great architecture needs expanses of serenity to provide the setting for moments of soaring drama so, too, successful cities demand an underlying melody. The pleasures of Venice or Florence are not only the wonderful churches and civic buildings but also the rich fabric of the more numerous commonplace structures in which people live and work. It is the common streets that provide character in a city - the white terraces and squares of Georgian London, or the brownstones of 19th-century New York. For great cities are the result not only of celebrated master architects but also of the dozens of smaller talents who provided the less dramatic but equally precious background buildings.

title: Review/Theater; 1960's Dream of 'Midsummer Nights'
description: Few plays travel more easily to different times and places than ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' The Public Theater moved it to fin de siecle Brazil to open its Shakespeare Marathon and the Royal Shakespeare Company put it somewhere in limbo in its new staging at Stratford-on-Avon last spring. Now the Musical Theater Works has, with not a few liberties, plopped it down in Laguna Beach, Calif., circa 1965, and set it to music under the title ''Midsummer Nights.'' Like the 60's, the result turns out to be a very mixed bag of tricks. That is not to say ''Midsummer Nights,'' which is being presented at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, is without its merits. It is a frothy show with lively tunes by Kevin Kuhn and some sassy and clever lyrics by Bryan D. Leys. But once the game of matching Shakespeare's characters to their namesakes in Laguna Beach is exhausted, there is little to fill the gaps between songs.

title: Israelis Training Groups of Arabs To Halt Uprising
description: Palestinian residents in this city and several nearby villages say groups of Arabs armed and trained by the Israeli military have formed loose militias and are regularly assaulting their neighbors, bolstering the army's effort to quash the Palestinian uprising.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Pursuing the Dream Home in a Soft Market
description: LEAD: IN spite of the stagnant housing market, Long Island builders are opening new projects. A total of 2,969 building permits - usually issued when construction is imminent - were issued in Nassau and Suffolk from January through June. And perhaps because of that stagnation, buyers are still looking for their dream houses.

title:
DINING OUT;
Authentic Mexican Cuisine in Yonkers
description: LEAD: DINERS fed up with the gloppy, micro-waved hodgepodge dished out by most Mexican eating spots have, as of last May, a viable alternative - Corridos Mexicanos. This charming, friendly restaurant cooks up some of the hands-down best Mexican food in the area.

title: Campus Life: Villanova; Living Off Campus Could Be Tougher In Two Townships
description: Responding to complaints of parking problems, loud parties and more Villanova students living in one house than the law allows, the Haverford Township Planning Commission voted unanimously this month to restrict off-campus housing for students.

title: INSIDE
description: Glimmer of Hope in Lebanon

title: Review/Cabaret; Sondheim in Vignettes
description: When Helen Schneider performs ''Broadway Baby,'' the show-stopping centerpiece of her cabaret act, ''Schneider Sings Sondheim'' at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, the tuxedo-clad singer suddenly becomes a doe-eyed flapper flaunting a New York street-moll accent and a mock ingenuousness that only partly conceals a ruthless ambition. Interpreting the song as though she were auditioning for a producer in the front row, Ms. Schneider brings out double-entendres that one didn't even suspect were in the lyric, as she bats her eyes at ''Mr. Producer'' and implies that her shabby apartment could become their love nest if he would put her on the stage.

title: Transfer Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Enfield, Conn. $125,000 27 Alban Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old ranch; wraparound deck, woods at rear; taxes $1,168. Hamden, Conn. $169,250 49 Belmont Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath 50-year-old colonial; fenced-in yard, finished basement; taxes $1,774. Meriden, Conn. $130,000 80 Highland Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; enclosed porch, breakfast bar in kitchen; taxes $1,238. Ossining, N.Y. $460,000 103 River Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; family room w/fireplace, new eat-in kitchen, deck, sprinkler system, 0.5 acre; taxes $6,588. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $525,000 Pheasant Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, pond, lake, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $5,865. Waccabuc, N.Y. $291,000 138 Hunt Farm Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old saltbox colonial; basement office, family room, exercise room, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $6,052. OTHER AREAS Millburn, N.J. $219,500 20 Bailey Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 44-year-old colonial; fireplace, full basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,975. Passaic, N.J. $109,000 27 Pine Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 69-year-old colonial; landscaped yard, full basement; taxes $1,161. Bayport, L.I. $162,000 477 First Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, pool; taxes $4,200.

title: Asbestos Removal In Perspective
description: The article ''Schools to Spend Millions to Comply With Asbestos Law'' [ Sept. 10 ] accurately indicates the problems, both financial and practical, that schools are having in complying with the Environmental Protection Agency's regulation of the Federal law.

title: Landscape Photography As Envisioned by Women
description: A SHOW that comes to Lehman College Art Gallery from the Tweed Art Museum in Duluth, Minn., ''Reclaiming Paradise,'' is a selection of landscapes by 20 female photographers.

title: Review/ Pop; Spontaneous Interaction in a Tribute
description: As machine-made textures and jittery hip-hop rhythms make the sound of pop-soul music increasingly resemble a video-game arcade, good old-fashioned soul music is coming more and more to seem like a classic American style.

title: THAT'S ALL FOLKS
description: PANATI'S EXTRAORDINARY ENDINGS OF PRACTICALLY EVERYTHING AND EVERYBODY By Charles Panati. Illustrated. 470 pp. New York: Perennial Library/Harper & Row. Cloth, $22.50; Paper, $10.95.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
When the Leaves Drop, The Bark Shows Off
description: LEAD: Gardeners frequently forget about the winter months in their gardens. But several plants can be selected for their dramatic appeal when there are no leaves on trees or shrubs to provide competition.

title: Nursing-Home Waits: More Help Needed
description: Your article [ ''Waiting for a Nursing-Home Bed,'' Aug. 13 ] on the problems for the elderly and their families inherent in waiting for nursing-home placement is right on target. It properly describes the pain and feelngs of displacement that waiting for available nursing-home beds engenders. The requirement that anyone needing such placement must accept the first available nursing-home bed available within a 50-mile radius can and sometimes does cause serious problems.

title: SCHOOL SPANKING DEBATED AS ABUSE
description: When Gerald Winsett, a junior high school principal, paddled a 13-year-old boy in May, he thought he had simply done his job in accordance with state law, which permits corporal punishment.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: North Attleboro, Mass.;
Oz-Theme Mall Makes Debut
description: LEAD: NEW ENGLAND'S largest developer of retail space has teamed up with a New York concern to open one of the region's largest shopping centers, the three-story, million-square-foot Emerald Square Mall, whose theme is ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl Is Upset by Gomez: Andres Gomez of Ecuador, ranked 30th in the world, upset Ivan Lendl, the world's No. 1 player, 1-6, 7-6, 9-7, yesterday in the semifinals of the Count of Godo tournament in Barcelona, Spain. Gomez will face Horst Skoff of Austria in today's final of the clay court event. Skoff beat Alberto Mancini of Argentina, 1-6, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Navratilova in Final: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova swept into the finals of the Virginia Slims of Dallas yesterday, dispensing with No. 3 Manuela Maleeva 6-2, 6-3. In tonight's final, Navratilova will meet the winner of the Monica Seles-Anne Smith match, which followed.(AP) Chang Advances: Top-seeded Michael Chang, who has not lost a set in four matches here, beat Scott Davis, 6-4, 6-4 yesterday in the semifinals of the Volvo Tennis men's tournament.(AP) Weight Lifting Soviet Superheavyweight Wins: A Soviet superheavyweight, Aleksandr Kurlovich, hoisted 1,012 pounds to win the over-242 pounds division yesterday in Athens. The 296-pound three-time world champion narrowly missed setting a world record for total weight. Kurlovich's 33-year-old teammate, Leonid Taranenko, who holds the world superheavyweight jerk record at 585 pounds and total weight record at 1,045 pounds, withdrew from the meet an hour before the competition.(AP) Horse Racing Cauthen on St. Leger Winner: The American jockey Steve Cauthen swept to the front two furlongs from home on Michelozzo and rode to an eight-length victory yesterday in the 213th running of the St. Leger, the final classic of the British thoroughbred season at Ayr, Scotland. The race was postponed a week ago because of a dangerous course at Doncaster and moved to Ayr.(AP) Golf Canipe Leads by a Shot: David Canipe shot a six-under-par 64 yesterday and took a one-shot lead after the third round of the $400,000 Southern Open at Columbus, Ga. The 36-year-old Canipe, 133d on the money list with $84,000, got the last of his six birdies on No. 18, knocking in a 20-footer to gain the stroke advantage over Dave Rummells and Jay Haas. Canipe was at 198, which was 12-under-par after 54 holes. Rummells had a 67 and Haas a 64, including five birdies on his last six holes. (AP) Wright Takes Lead: Pam Wright, a rookie, shot a 5-under-par 67 today to take the third-round lead of the LPGA MBS Classic over Rosie Jones and Nancy Lopez, who broke the course record with 65s. Wright, with a 54-hole total of 10-under-par 206, had a late run of four birdies on the back side to steal the show from Jones, who set the Los Coyotes Country Club course record and then watched Lopez match it moments later.

title: Rainmaker: Mario Baeza Of Devevoise
description: MARIO BAEZA LOOKS TROUBLED. IT IS A GRAY Tuesday morning in June and Baeza, a partner at the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton in New York, is sitting with a group of his colleagues in his 22d floor office, a diamond-shaped room with a dramatic view of Third Avenue.

title: Army's Defense Is Solid
description: Army's defense stopped Wake Forest inside the 15-yard line three times in the fourth quarter and the Cadets earned a 14-10 victory today. It was a game in which a previously untested sophomore quarterback, Willie McMillian, emerged as the offensive hero when he completed his only pass on a 60-yard touchdown play.

title: From the Classical Guitar To a New African Sound
description: THIS season the Connecticut Classical Guitar Society, founded in 1985, has almost doubled its concert schedule, to more than 100 events throughout the greater Hartford area. As a result, the society is now one of the largest nonprofit guitar organizations in the United States, as well as one of the country's most active presenters of classical guitar concerts.

title: Andre Blumenthal, 85, Textile Executive
description: Andre Blumenthal, a retired textile executive and civic leader, died of cancer Friday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 85 years old.

title: Campus Life: Oregon; Fraternities Learn Costly Lessons In Fire Safety
description: Fall festivities at the University of Oregon's fraternities might be a bit subdued this year because of the prospect of paying for improvements to meet the city's fire code.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: ROBIN LEEDS;
''Kids Are Safe in School Buses''
description: LEAD: WHEN Robin Leeds was named executive director of the Connecticut Operators of School Transportation Association, all she knew about school buses, she said, was that ''they were yellow and my children spent a lot of time riding on them.'' That was nearly eight years ago and Mrs. Leeds has since amassed considerable knowledge of the subject.

title: Libraries Celebrate Banned-Book Week
description: LEAD: IN 1985 a group of parents in North Salem wanted to ban the book ''Ordinary People'' from the local schools. The book by Judith Guest, later made into a movie, dealt with teen-age suicide, which had occurred in the town. In addition, the book contained sex scenes and profanity.

title: Anne Marie Sapienza Weds
description: Anne Marie Sapienza, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Sapienza of Williamsville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Gary A. Paranzino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony D. Paranzino of Ambler, Pa. Msgr. Joseph D. Joseph, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. John Maron Maronite Catholic Church. Mrs. Paranzino, 28 years old, is the listings manager for Manhattan Apartments Inc. in New York.

title: After Hugo, a Storm Over Beach Development
description: Besides the ravages of its roaring winds and surging tides, Hurricane Hugo has left behind a vexing question with millions of dollars at stake: What can be rebuilt on South Carolina's battered coast?

title: Yonkers Primary Hearing Set
description: A Yonkers Councilman who has played a major role in the fight against a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan forced a delay in the certification of the Republican Party primary results last week after a recount turned an apparent Primary Day victory into a defeat.

title: Bill Barron, Tenor Saxophonist, Composer and Teacher, Dies at 62
description: Bill Barron, a saxophonist, composer and professor of music at Wesleyan University, died of cancer Thursday in Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 62 years old and lived in Middletown.

title: A Man of Action and Uncommon Abilities
description: He's big, rugged and speaks in a raspy voice. So sometimes it's easy to forget that Nick Nolte is a skilled actor with a body of memorable films behind him and the uncommon abilities to be convincing as a man of action and a man of intellect and, when necessary, to rise above mediocre material.

title: A Soccer Tale
description: The Cleveland Crunch of the Major Indoor Soccer League has signed its No. 1 draft choice, Simon Keith of the University of Las Vegas, but that's only half the story. Keith has been living the last three years with a transplanted heart.

title: POSTINGS: 317 Montville Units; An Hour By Bus to Midtown
description: The first 24 units of what is planned to be a 317-unit condominium development in Montville in Morris County, N.J., were put on sale this month and 20 have been sold. Named Montville Chase, the development, at Changebridge Road and Church Lane, is to feature a variety of units ranging from one-bedroom apartments on a single floor to three-bedroom duplexes.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a new center in Valhalla to aid the hearing-impaired misidentified the woman with Edith Shapiro. She was Renata Scheder.

title: Don DeLillo Wins Irish Fiction Prize
description: Don DeLillo was awarded the first International Fiction Prize on Monday at a ceremony in Dublin. The award, worth about $54,000, was presented to Mr. DeLillo for ''Libra,'' his novel about the assassination of President Kennedy, which was published last year by Viking.

title: Retrospective: Barbara Morgan at 89
description: BARBARA MORGAN has just turned 89 and the retrospective she is having in the Davison Art Center, at Wesleyan University in Middletown, is a fitting celebration.

title: Quarterback Runs As Yale Triumphs
description: Darin Kehler, Yale's daring and fleet quarterback, ran through the rain for three touchdowns in the second half today as the Elis defeated Lehigh, 33-17, at the Yale Bowl.

title: Sarah Watson Weds Joseph Anderson
description: Sarah Ann Watson, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Watson of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Michael Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley T. Anderson of Binghamton, N.Y., at the Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn. The Rev. Laura Hiller Brumbaugh, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Man Hurt in Bias-Linked Attack
description: A 23-year-old black man was beaten by a white man in lower Manhattan Friday night in what the police say was a racially motivated fight.

title: The Bridges Between Able and Disabled
description: I AM a 40-year-old physically disabled woman. I've been disabled since birth and get around on crutches or in a wheelchair. I have an undergraduate degree in sociology and a graduate degree in education, and I'm employed as a switchboard operator at the headquarters of a local bank. I enjoy going out with friends, writing and listening to soft rock music.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Children Can Survive A Divorce
description: LEAD: DIVORCE is once again in the news with the publication of Judith Wallerstein's important new study examining the emotional impact of divorce upon children.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: Minimalism continues to thrive even though it is never likely to win its upholders a great following among the fans. Yet there is something fascinating to see how little an outstanding minimalist needs to win a game. Besides, the top minimalists win a lot.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LONG WHARF AT 25

title: Food; Loafing Around
description: FOR BREAD LOV-ers, these are glory days. Restaurants and bakers have thrown out their recipes for flavorless, mass-produced rolls and are filling the breadbasket with robust creations. Even all-purpose breads are far from bland. Light, crusty rounds of country-style sourdough and dense, moist whole-grain loaves go with everything from soup to cheese, and make superior sandwiches. Breads have also become highly specialized. Savory focaccias covered with sun-dried tomatoes, olives and anchovies are rich enough to make light meals. Honeyed focaccias stuffed with fruit are sweet enough to serve for dessert.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Ferry Makes Debut
description: When Il Messaggero Roma defeated Vismara Cantu, 90-86, yesterday, most of the Italian basketball league game's attention was focused on Danny Ferry and Brian Shaw, the young American stars who defected from the National Basketball Association. In his first regular-season game for the Rome-based team, Ferry, the No. 2 pick - by the Los Angeles Clippers - in the 1988 draft, scored 25 points. Shaw, a rookie guard for the Boston Celtics last season, finished with 19 points. Ferry hit 10 of 17 shots. Shaw made 39 percent of his field-goal attempts. They each had seven rebounds.(AP)

title: 24 CITIES BUT NO CIGAR
description: DIARY OF A MAD PLAYWRIGHT By James Kirkwood. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: DATA BANK: Sept.24, 1989
Baskets That Go Beyond Vessels
description: THERE'S nothing functional about the baskets that Norma Minkowitz creates. Indeed, although the Westport artist's work is included in ''The Tactile Vessel: New Basket Forms'' at the American Craft Museum in New York through Nov. 12, it is doubtful whether her poetic sculptural forms of crocheted thread, painted and stiffened, are really baskets at all.

title: POSTINGS: 30-Year Tax-Exempt Bonds; A $22.8 Million A.S.P.C.A. Expansion
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, one of the nation's largest and oldest philanthropies, is to float $22.8 million in revenue bonds with the help of New York City to help pay for the largest expansion of its facilities in the metropolitan area in its 123-year history. Under the unusual plan, the 30-year, tax-exempt, civic-facility bonds are to be issued next month by the New York Industrial Development Agency, with proceeds to be used to build two animal shelters in Manhattan, one of which will be part of a new national headquarters.

title: C. L. Taben Wed To Eve Leventhal
description: Eve Leventhal, the daughter of Mrs. Murray A. Weber of New York and the late Benjamin F. Leventhal of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Charles Lawrence Taben, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Taben of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Nina Mizrahi performed the ceremony at the New York Academy of Art.

title: About Cars; Slow Down, Roast's Ready
description: John Russell and I were on 10th Avenue in New York on Thursday, dripping sweat and fighting traffic in a Plymouth Voyager. And what the heat and urban ugliness brought back were memories of another such van and heaped-up snow in Spencer, Idaho.

title: TO RELAX OR STAY ALERT, NEW MOOD-ATLERING SCENTS
description: Fragrances are no longer just another luxury. Now, manufacturers say they have merits in behavioral therapy. ''This is a new category of fragrance,'' said Annette Green, vice president and administrator of the Fragrance Research Fund Ltd., a group of 20 manufacturers formed nearly a decade ago to study the psychological effects of fragrances.

title: MAVERICK ON TIPTOE
description: SOLITARY SONG By Pauline Koner. Illustrated. 305 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $26.95.

title: For Cambodians, Joy and Foreboding
description: With the last of Vietnam's troops scheduled to leave Cambodia on Tuesday, residents of this capital are dancing again, but the celebrations have a frenzied character, tempered by foreboding that they will be cut short by the Khmer Rouge guerrillas.

title: No Regrets For Thrift
description: The drawl on the other end of the line sounded like Syd Thrift's. It spoke of baseball and games as if nothing had changed, as if he were still a part of it, even though he hasn't been since Aug. 30, the day he resigned as the Yankees' senior vice president of baseball operations and returned home to Fairfax, Va.

title: Kossuth's Idea Is Timely
description: Fissures in the Communist bloc are widening with stunning speed. Who would have thought the new lineup would be Soviet-Polish-Hungarian reformers against East German-Czechoslovak-Rumanian orthodoxies, with Bulgaria mum?

title: ROLL OVER, WAGNER
description: BACKSTAGE AT THE COACH HOUSE CONCERT HALL, a music club in San Juan Capistrano, south of Los Angeles, the drummer Stewart Copeland is getting ready for a tryout gig with his new rock group Animal Logic. The drab dressing room is hardly high enough to stand up in. To get to it, the players must walk through the kitchen with its greasy, tiled floor. But Copeland is at home here. During the early days of his now disbanded rock group The Police, which Copeland founded, he and Sting and the guitarist Andy Summers played hundreds of clubs like the Coach House.

title: U.S.C. Crushes Ohio State
description: Todd Marinovich, a redshirt freshman, threw for four touchdowns, including a Southern Cal-record 87-yard pass play, as the Trojans routed Ohio State, 42-3, today.
