Wonica)

title: The Education Governors
description: For only the third time, a President has convened the nation's governors to discuss a single issue. President Bush has the opportunity this week to follow through on his campaign pledge to be the education President.

title: The Greening of Corporate Women
description: LEAD: ON A FRIDAY MORNING IN EARLY summer, Kathy Hoyne Smith, a 35-year-old account manager for advertising sales and services at Reader's Digest, left her Manhattan office at 10:45 and headed for Grand Central Station. There she met Peter Teese and John Donnelly, media planners in their 20's from Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency, whom she had invited to play golf at her club in Greenwich,

title: Low-Interest Mortgage Program Ignored
description: WITH affordable housing at a premium and home ownership an impossible dream for many, a two-year-old state program that provides low-interest, low-down payment mortgages has remained largely ignored by brokers, bankers and even bargain-hunting home buyers.

title: Tests of Organisms With Altered Genes Gain Panel Support
description: Field testing of genetically modified plants and microorganisms ''will not pose any hazard'' to the environment if done carefully under existing laws, a National Academy of Sciences panel has concluded.

title: Virtuosi Keeps Expanding Its Reach
description: THE Philharmonia Virtuosi calls itself ''the county's most active performing-arts organization,'' and this season the ensemble will be presenting seven different series of subscription concerts, two in New York City and the others in Purchase, Valhalla, New Rochelle, Scarsdale and Peekskill.

title:
LONG BRANCH JOURNAL;
Once Bustling Resort Looks Beyond Its Past to the Future
description: LEAD: URSULA CAPUTO remembers growing up in the downtown area here in the 1950's, when Long Branch was a bustling summer resort. ''There were boardinghouses, and people from Newark and the Oranges and New York would rent,'' she said. ''Nobody locked their doors, and Saturday night was boardwalk night, and people got dressed up to go on the boardwalk.

title: Campus Life: Vassar; Turning to Offer A Helping Hand To the Elderly
description: About 150 students, administrators and faculty and staff members at Vassar College left the campus this month to help 25 community organizations, including the Dutchess Manor Home for Adults and the Dutchess County Mental Health Association.

title: Barbara L. Mills, Banker, Marries
description: The marriage of Barbara Louise Mills to William Floyd Henagan took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Dana Fearon officiated. Mrs. Henagan, 30 years old, is a daughter of Bradford Mills and Elizabeth Leisk Mills, both of Princeton, N.J. A graduate of Princeton University, she is a general partner in Bradford Associates, a merchant banking firm in Princeton. Her father, formerly the president of the Government-sponsored Overseas Private Investment Corporation in Washington, is the managing partner of Bradford Associates.

title: Beijing Puts Khmer Rouge on Shorter Leash
description: As a new round of civil war threatens Cambodia, diplomats here say China finds itself in the awkward position of wanting the Khmer Rouge troops it supports neither to win nor lose.

title: For the House, Painting by Numbers
description: COLORS used to have names, not numbers. Hamilton Blue. Jamestown Blue. Newburyport Blue. Now those colors are No. 36, HC-148 and HC-155. We learned how to play the color numbers game this summer when we painted the exterior of our house.

title: Elliott and Ivan Win Miles
description: Running hard so he could ride in ease, Peter Elliott of Britain outsprinted the favored Abdi Bile of Somalia yesterday to win the men's Mercedes Mile down Fifth Avenue after Paula Ivan of Rumania had swept to an expected victory in the women's race.

title: Louisa Campbell, A Writer, Is Wed
description: Louisa D. Campbell, a writer of children's books under the pen name Liza Alexander, and Sven D. Travis, a commercial artist, were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Carleton Lee officiated.

title: Review/Music; Young Chamber Group Illuminates the Present
description: The Atlantic Sinfonietta, a three-year-old chamber group that specializes in new and unusual music, devoted its Wednesday evening concert at St. Peter's Church to 20th-century works for flute, harp, strings and voice. The performances were polished and expressive, and had an inner glow that cast a flattering light on the music at hand.

title: NONFICTION
description: WHERE THE RIVERS RAN BACKWARD. By William E. Merritt. (University of Georgia, $24.95.) William E. Merritt, who served as an enlisted combat engineer in Vietnam, was asked by one of his former teachers to talk to her class about the war. He declined and wrote ''Where the Rivers Ran Backward'' instead. It is a fascinating mosaic of reminiscences about Mr. Merritt's fellow soldiers, their weapons, their travails and training and their war. Mr. Merritt has a zoom lens for an eye and a broadcast-quality tape recorder for an ear. He focuses sharply on people, like a Flying Tiger Airlines stewardess who, when the troop plane arrives at Saigon, gives her soldier passengers the by-rote piffle about having ''an enjoyable stay'' and then bursts into tears. There is also a tank crew washing their monster in a river, apparently to expiate their anger, hatred and despair, and ''cursing God.'' There is even a colonel who, on presenting Mr. Merritt with a Purple Heart, offers congratulations and adds: ''I hope you win many more of these.'' To Mr. Merritt, now an attorney in Portland, Ore., the soldiers' Vietnam in 1968 was a place of scary, lonely night watches and ubiquitous post exchanges (''Places you couldn't go without air cover you could find a PX''). Mr. Merritt's comrades are profane, funny, hyperbolic, frightened, sad and exuberant. Impressions, actions and conversations are set down in the form of short vignettes, laced with snatches of song lyrics and the noise of weapons, and paced like a nasty firefight. ''Where the Rivers Ran Backward'' is a well-crafted evocation of the tragic zaniness of wars and the quiet perseverance of the men who fight them.

title: Time for Bush to Back Up His Speeches With Action
description: Nearly three-quarters of the way through the first year of the new Administration, extraordinarily little of major significance has been produced in Washington. As a Governor, a citizen and a Democrat, I think we have given an appropriate period of deference to the new Administration. It is time now for a different approach.

title: MONEY MAKES LOVE GO ROUND
description: LIMITED PARTNERSHIPS By Lisa Zeidner. 256 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $18.95.

title: LOUD AND SILENT
description: LESSONS IN LAUGHTER The Autobiography of a Deaf Actor. By Bernard Bragg as signed to Eugene Bergman. Illustrated. 219 pp. Washington: Gallaudet University Press. $17.95.

title: ARts Groups Listen and Wait
description: ARTS administrators in the county have kept an ear tuned to Washington during their preparations for a new cultural season. Their concern has been for the health and survival of the National Endowment for the Arts, whose fate has been the subject of heated Congressional debate.

title: Honey, They Shrunk the Camcorder
description: Sony's obsessive penchant for miniaturization has found formidable expression in its CCD-TR5 camcorder. It's the smallest and lightest yet.

title: Mideast Scholar to give 1990 Jefferson Lecture
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced that Bernard Lewis, a scholar of Middle Eastern History, will deliver the 1990 Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities.

title: Why the U.S. Closed the Door Halfway on Soviet Jews
description: FOR 20 years, the United States and Israel have denounced the Soviet Union for severely restricting the right to emigrate. Now that Moscow is allowing record numbers of Soviet Jews and Pentacostals to leave, it is not clear where they will go.

title: Outdoors; Fishing for Smallmouth Bass
description: Many fly fishermen regard the smallmouth bass as something to pursue when trout are off their feed, a species that, although acrobatic and strong, does not require much savvy to catch.

title:
Hers;
He Drives Me Crazy
description: LEAD: EVEN BEFORE THE President was seen driving around recently to promote the virtues of ethanol, Barbara Bush announced that she wouldn't ride in a car driven by her husband because he was out of practice. My husband is never more dangerous than when he is ''in practice,'' i.e. the summer and fall months when we drive out to Long

title: Managing Musical Superstars
description: YO-YO MA SITS IN THE OFFICE OF HIS MANAGER, Lee Lamont, taking notes on a yellow legal pad. The slim, bespectacled cellist has flown to New York from Boston to talk with Lamont, who has orchestrated his rise to stardom, about his plans for a two-part television special. Ma reels off a long list of artists to whom he has written, inviting them to appear on the shows, which will explore how music is created and performed. ''When can we begin to move on this?'' he asks Lamont, whose company, I.C.M. Artists Ltd., is putting up almost half the funds for the project.

title: THE WAY I LIVE NOW
description: I share similar experiences with David Leavitt and agree with him on many facts about the AIDS epidemic (''The Way I Live Now,'' July 9). However, I feel the need to express another point of view about what it was like to have worked in the middle of this crisis.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Minnesota Twins have signed Juan Berenguer, one of their six players who could have opted for free agency after the season, to a two-year contract extension. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Berenguer, who is making $625,000 this season, is used mostly as a setup relief pitcher. He has an 8-3 record, 3.71 earned run average and three saves in 54 relief appearances. . . . For the second straight time, James Martin of Penn State, a four-time wrestling all-American and the 1988 National Collegiate Athletic Association champion at 126 pounds, has been named as the GTE Academic All-American of the year. Martin, of Danville, Pa., was selected in a vote by the 1,400-member College Sports Information Directors of America. With a 3.94 grade point average in pre-medicine, Martin received an N.C.A.A. postgraduate scholarship and now attends the Hershey Medical School.

title: Four Health Care Vigilantes
description: Medical costs continue to run wild despite widespread efforts by the nation's employers to contain them. The cost of the typical company medical plan is projected to rise by 20 to 25 percent this year, according to the latest surveys, after increasing by 15 to 20 percent last year.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the play ''Love Letters'' at the Promenade Theater gives an incorrect date for the first performance by Josef Sommer and Colleen Dewhurst.

title: The Koreans' Big Entry Into Business
description: LIKE other newcomers to these shores, many Korean immigrants here speak little English, want to start their own businesses, are short on cash and cannot get the time of day from the bank loan officer. So they go to a ''kye,'' a kind of private banking club, where a loan of $20,000 or $30,000 can be had without applications or even a promissory note - at a usurious rate of 24 percent or higher.

title: Margaret Stimpson Weds
description: Margaret Anne Stimpson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Irving Stimpson of Wellesley, Mass., and Rye, N.H., was married yesterday to Thomas Dawson Gaillard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dawson Gaillard of Greenwich, Conn., at the Wellesley Congregational Church. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Gaillard, 25 years old, is a graduate of Wellesley College. Mr. Gaillard, 27, a graduate of Williams College who earned an M.B.A. degree from Harvard University, is a manager of business development at Hunter Environmental Services, a consulting concern in Southport, Conn.

title: Private Lives Exist Beyond Public Roles
description: Growing up, I thought that to be successful, accepted or even loved, I had to win. I had to be the best: altar boy, student, athlete. And subtly, between the lines - it was never specifically addressed or expressed - I was taught that anything less was unacceptable.

title: State Eliminates Public Suggestion Box
description: LEAD: A LACK of response has prompted officials to eliminate the public suggestion box. The director of the State Suggestion Program, James G. Bennett, said last week that the program, which has been operating since 1953, will continue to be open to state employees but that the three-year-old public portion has been eliminated.

title: The Democrats Struggle, but Energetically
description: THE capital echoes these days with the clash of a newly assertive Democratic Congress and an amiable but equally unyielding President.

title: NONFICTION
description: EVEN MISSISSIPPI. By Melany Neilson. (University of Alabama, $24.95.) ''Even Mississippi'' is the memoir of a white University of Mississippi graduate's work with Robert Clark, a black Mississippi legislator, in his Congressional campaigns of 1982 and 1984 against a race-baiting Republican. Mr. Clark's losses lay the groundwork for Mike Espy's 1986 victory as the state's first black Congressman. This is an eloquent, moving book on several levels. In 1967, when Melany Neilson was 9 years old, Mr. Clark was the first black elected to the state House of Representatives, where he was for several years ostracized. Her reminiscences of childhood on a farm in Mr. Clark's district reveal innocence receding into doubt. ''It was a curious fact about this time that the familiar threat of violence did not make us wonder, and only the silence, the peaceful days, struck us as a strange surprise,'' she writes. In the best of these scenes, the author's father shouts at Chet Huntley and David Brinkley's newscasts in the late 1960's. By 1982 he is openly supporting Mr. Clark. Ms. Neilson's portrait of Mr. Clark is deftly drawn. We see a champion of the poor, a kind, pragmatic man, ever aware of white impressions. There is a priceless scene when C. B. (Buddie) Newman, a segregationist seeking to become Speaker of the Mississippi House, sinks on bended knee, asking Mr. Clark's support. More affecting are the passages recounting Ms. Neilson's evolution as a white among blacks, seeking a new Mississippi.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bradley Beach $85,000 1104 Beach Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, h/w floors, front porch; taxes $1,547. Farmingdale, L.I. $194,000 324 Vancott Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old splanch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, partial basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,800.

title: Sheryl Haft Married To Jeffrey Scott Flug
description: Sheryl Alecia Haft and Jeffrey Scott Flug were married yesterday evening at Temple Bethel in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Philip Berger.

title: Catherine Amdur Weds Scot Small
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Catherine Richardson Amdur, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Allen Amdur of Allenhurst, N.J., to Scot McCauley Small. The bridegroom is a son of Francis M. Small Jr. of Aptos, Calif., and Karna Small of Washington. The Rev. Thomas T. Crenshaw performed the ceremony.

title: Columbia's Trip Is a Rough One
description: Ray Tellier's first road game as Columbia's head coach got off to a rough start even before the Lions left the Morningside Heights campus Friday afternoon.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner; The Freshest of Fish And a Taste of Spain
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Cafe Greco

title: Girl Makes History in New Jersey Game
description: Leanne Bollinger is listed among the promising newcomers on the Long Branch High School varsity football team. That's not a milestone because girls have tried out for boys' teams before.

title: TWO YEARS IN A CANOE
description: PADDLE TO THE AMAZON By Don Starkell. Edited by Charles Wilkins. Illustrated. 319 pp. Rocklin, Calif.: Prima Publishing & Communications/ St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: The Roots Of the Ridiculous
description: This Thursday's opening of the late Charles Ludlam's first play, ''Big Hotel,'' at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, directed by Everett Quinton, marks the first revival of this bohemian epic in 22 years.

title: Time to Take the Financial I.Q. Test
description: Many people pride themselves on how much they know - or think they know - about financial matters. Yet accountants and financial planners say misconceptions are rife among their clients. And when it comes to money, the professionals say, ignorance is definitely not bliss. The following questions and answers on investments and taxes can give you a sense of your financial I.Q. You may find that it is time to sit down and review the A B C's of personal finance.

title: A Rematch for District Attorney
description: FOUR years ago, Paul W. Pickelle, a Democrat from Scarsdale and a member of the Special State Prosecutors Office, resigned to seek elected office in the county, specifically, the post of District Attorney, which was firmly in the grasp of an experienced Republican, Carl A. Vergari.

title: Moscow Sets Aside Big Obstacle to Arms Treaty
description: The new strategic arms control initiative put forth by the Soviet Union here on Friday appears to remove the principal obstacle to a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In the ''Talking: Title Transfer'' column on Sept. 17, the discussion about avoiding inheritance taxes failed to mention that a parent giving a home to a child would have to pay a Federal gift tax on the current worth of the home ($800,000 in the example).

title: 2 Neighborhoods Celebrate Restoration of Their Bridge
description: A century-old wooden bridge in Brooklyn, closed for repairs since 1985, was reopened yesterday with flags and brass bands in a ceremony that officially reunited two neighborhoods on opposite sides of the Gowanus Canal.

title: PLANS GO UNUSED AS STORM PASSES
description: Ten thousand sandbags stayed in storage. Refrigerators remained fully stocked. Hastily dug drainage ditches stayed relatively dry. And, throughout the New York metropolitan region, carefully crafted emergency plans were rendered unnecessary. No one was complaining. ''Having gone through Hurricane Gloria four years ago,'' said Brendan Sexton, New York City's Sanitation Commissioner, ''I'm sure we wouldn't have normal operations for a month'' had Hurricane Hugo turned eastward, a turn for the worse for New York City.

title: The Bad Old Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed-Race Generation Emerges but Is Not Sure Where It Fits
description: Robin Tarver dreads the arrival of the first form, perhaps a school application, perhaps a medical certificate, that will ask her to list her daughter's race. She knows that 2-year-old Ryan Jean's curly black hair, black eyes and sandy-brown skin mark her as black, in traditional American terms. But ''to call her black denies what she gets from me,'' said Mrs. Tarver, who is white.

title: Investigators Look Beyond Pilot Error to Seek Explanation for USAir Crash
description: Federal investigators looked beyond pilot errors yesterday and began examining a host of other questions in the search for an explanation of the aborted takeoff and crash of a USAir jetliner into the East River at La Guardia Airport last week.

title: Leaders of Carmelite Order Support Moving of Convent
description: Leaders of the Roman Catholic Carmelite order said today that they supported moving one of their convents from the site of the Auschwitz death camp in Poland as many Jewish groups have demanded.

title: The Mystery Of the Single Shoe
description: I never realized that others were intrigued by the mystery of shoes on highways, streets and country roads. But for the record, it isn't always just one shoe found sitting in pristine solitude.

title: HERE COME NORDSTROM
description: As a transplant from the East Coast, I found it hard, at first, making the adjustment to friendly smiles and good service when I moved to Seattle. Now I'm a ''local Seattlelite''; I wait for traffic lights to change before crossing the street and I'm accustomed to excellent service at Nordstrom.

title: Caring for Finished Wood Floors
description: FINISHED wood floors are durable and easy to care for. With regular maintenance and prompt repair when necessary, they will retain their original appearance for many years.

title: 'Trixie True' Taps Out The Secret
description: WHAT, one may wonder, is ''Trixie True, Teen Detective'' doing in a theater that has staked its reputation on a venturesome, intelligently chosen repertory?

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Out Cold 1988. HBO. $89.99. Laser disk, $39.95. Closed captioned. 1 hour 31 minutes. R. Malcolm Mowbray's essentially British comedy, which just happens to be set in California, is about two butchers, business partners and friends, Dave (John Lithgow) and Ernie (Bruce McGill) - Ernie is frozen to death in a meat locker- plus Ernie's dangerously pragmatic wife (Teri Garr). ''Though the story, which devotes a lot of energy to the disposing of the frozen Ernie, could easily have degenerated into broad farce, the cast and Mr. Mowbray keep it drily witty all the way through.'' (Janet Maslin) Bambi 1942. Disney. $26.99. 1:09. LD, $39.99. CC. G. When the feature-length animated musical, five years in the creating, opened at Radio City, the Times critic wrote: ''Walt Disney's wizards have caught much of the breathless and breathtaking fantasy of Felix Salten's tremulous story of the little fawn who grew up in the woodland with his assorted playmates and finally became a great forest prince like his father.'' Slaves of New York 1989. RCA/Columbia. $89.95. LD, $49.95. 2:05. R. James Ivory's film, starring Bernadette Peters, Chris Sarandon and Mary Beth Hurt, is based on Tama Janowitz's short stories about various denizens of the downtown art scene. It ''has no intrinsic shape of its own'' and ''simply drifts from situation inviting the audience to soak up atmosphere . . . which isn't remotely as offbeat or unconventional as the peripheral trappings make it appear.'' (Maslin) The Dream Team 1989. MCA. $89.95. LD, $34.98. CC. 1:53. PG-13. Michael Keaton, Christopher Lloyd, Peter Boyle and Stephen Furst play four institutionalized mental patients on their way to a baseball game who are separated from their doctor and chaperone and find themselves on their own in the wilds of Manhattan. The problem with Howard Zeff's comedy is ''that it's not funny too much of the time. On those occasions when it is funny, the humor less often prompts laughter than mute appreciation of the talents of the principal performers.'' (Vincent Canby) Gone With the Wind 1939. MGM/UA $89.95. LD, $49.95. 3:51. CC. G. This is a 50th-anniversary reissue of a film that the Times critic of the day called ''the greatest motion mural we have seen and the most ambitious film-making venture in Hollywood's spectacular history.'' Margaret Mitchell's epic love story of Rhett Butler (Clark Gable), the handsome soldier of fortune, and Scarlett O'Hara (Vivien Leigh), the plantation belle, is told against the background of the Civil War and the physical destruction of the South. The Last Days of Pompeii 1935. Turner. $19.98. 1:36. No rating. Preston Foster stars as a blacksmith-turned-gladiator in a biblical drama from the makers of ''King Kong.'' A critic of the day appraised it as an ably managed historical work that loses something by bringing in a foolish little romance. ''But the hero of the occasion is Basil Rathbone,'' the critic added, ''whose Pilate is a fascinating aristocrat, scornful in his hauteur and sly in his reasoning.'' Powwow Highway 1989. Cannon. $89.95. 1:31. R. Two Cheyenne Indians - Philbert Bono (Gary Farmer), a scene-stealing mystical giant, and Buddy Red Bow (A. Martinez), an angry Vietnam veteran - team up for a weeklong journey in Philbert's new jalopy. Philbert is searching for some kind of spiritual core in contemporary American Indian life and Buddy is ostensibly coming to the aid of his sister, arrested on trumped-up drug charges. It aims for a sweetly comic tone and includes some sadly affecting glimpses of life among American Indians who have lost touch with their past, but ''most of the film simply ambles along at a genial pace.'' (Maslin)

title: Mistreating Venerable Walls
description: OLD stone walls course through our neighborhood in fits and starts, depending on how the developer could work them into the plans of our subdivision many years ago. Where possible, stretches of some walls were left fairly intact, to serve as boundaries for our irregular one-acre lots; others, parted and abandoned, were left as mere stubs of their former selves.

title: The Dutch Find New Treats In America
description: Atlanta-based architect who introduced the atrium to the modern hotel. Portman is developing a 100-acre complex of office towers, hotels and shops 18 miles from the hurly-burly of downtown Atlanta and hoped to whet the Dutch investor's appetite.

title: Lithuania Declares Annexation by Moscow Void
description: The Legislature of Lithuania today voted to declare the 1940 Soviet annexation of the republic invalid, thus supplying what could ultimately become the legal basis for secession.

title: A Tune-Up For The Market
description: THE ECONOMIC MOOD IS CHANGING. We see it in the public reaction to the Exxon Valdez oil spill and the company's initial skirt-lifting response. We find it again in the public and Congressional outrage over the sleaze in the savings and loan industry and the Pentagon scandals, not to mention Wall Street, where Masters of the Universe pull down eight-figure incomes while giving us a meaner and nastier business environment.

title: Bush Will Back National Goals on Education
description: President Bush is willing to be the first President to endorse setting national educational goals and standards by which improvements can be measured, Administration officials say.

title: U.S. Is Taking a New Look at Indochina
description: The Bush Administration is reassessing its policy toward Indochina after the failure of a monthlong international conference to devise a political settlement for Cambodia.

title: Fatal Jet Accidents Highest Since 1968, Killing 275 People
description: With 10 fatal accidents involving large United States commercial jets, this year is already the worst since 1968, when there were 12, according to statistics from the National Transportation Safety Board. And the 275 deaths this year, including two this week at La Guardia Airport, are the highest toll since 1979, when 348 died.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BY THE RIVERS OF BABYLON: And Other Stories. By Jorge de Sena. Edited by Daphne Patai. (Rutgers University, $19.95.) For Jorge de Sena, the Portuguese poet, critic and teacher who died in 1978, writing, like love, is an act of possession. This collection of short stories, selected from two volumes in Portuguese and deftly translated by Daphne Patai and others, contains work done by Sena over the course of more than 20 years and two exiles, first from his native land and then from Brazil to the United States.

ART;

Among the works the orchestras are to perform during the 1989-90 season are Marc Neikrug's Violin Concerto (1982), Walter Piston's ''Three New England Sketches'' (1959), Lukas Foss's ''Time Cycle'' (1960) and David Carlson's ''Rhapsodies'' (1986).

NEW JERSEY Q & A: C. DOUGLASS MAMPEE;
Fighting the War Against Pests

description: Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher told Poland's new Government this week that Washington would help lure private credits and investment here but did not offer more immediate aid than President Bush brought with him when he visited Warsaw in July.

description: A woman on life support died this week after a utility company disconnected power to her home instead of the house next door.

title: NONFICTION
description: NONFICTION PARSON'S MILL. By Timothy Lewontin. (University Press of New England, $14.95.) A delightful, surprisingly absorbing account of a year's labor in a New Hampshire sawmill, ''Parson's Mill'' approaches the gung-ho participatory journalism that George Plimpton performed in his athletic days. Overeducated and underqualified for mainstream white-collar employment, Timothy Lewontin and his wife seek solace and survival in the mountain towns of New Hampshire, where his parents had owned a summer vacation home. An advertisement brings him to a mill that, in his childhood, was a distantly glimpsed symbol of order and simplicity. At Parson's Mill, Mr. Lewontin's painful acquisition of the sawyer's craft grows into a personal, characteristically American quest for integrity in hard labor, told with a lucid sincerity that shimmers with insight. His co-workers, even if they were boorish or bigoted, cast shadows as long as the ash logs they send to the mill's whirling blades. Mr. Lewontin, now a writer living near Boston and the operator of a woodworking shop, waxes cosmic about the various machines, but finds the essence of Yankee enterprise in ''tall, lean, creaky-looking'' Henry Parsons, the mill's tyrannical, saturnine owner. Wise, weird and mystically capable of reading the grain in a virgin log so that it can be cut for maximum profit, Mr. Parsons is a failure at management, the only skill American entrepreneurs still take for granted. ''Parsons could not reconcile his need for laborers with his own belief that every real man ought to be independent,'' Mr. Lewontin writes. ''If he could have run the place himself, he would have.'' Mr. Lewontin uses incidents and events around the mill to contrast the nobility of honest labor with the ignobility of the workers. When the mill ultimately closes and its parts are auctioned off, we share his loss and his gratitude for the privilege of knowing laborers of such dignity, character and strength.

description: Margaret Mary Shannon, an account executive for the Chicago advertising agency of Bentley, Barnes & Lynn, and Dirk Edward Johnson, a correspondent in the Chicago bureau of The New York Times, were married yesterday at St. Hedwig Roman Catholic Church in Chicago. title: Review/Dance; Art Colony Offers Results of Summer
description: Every summer, the Yard, an arts colony on Martha's Vineyard, provides choreographers with space and time to create new works, some of which are later shown in New York City. This summer's choreographers offered a program Thursday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace. As usual, the quality of the productions varied. Nevertheless, all suggested that a summer at the Yard can be choreographically profitable.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
State Offers Low-Cost 100% Home Financing
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency is offering $21.5 million in 100 percent financing to low- and moderate-income families who do not have enough cash for down payments and closing costs.

title: Sincerest Flattery or the Subtlest Form of Dishonor?
description: ThE Kimbell Art Museum is Texas's finest postwar building, and one of the nation's. It is a late masterwork of the greatest architect of our time, Louis Kahn, and while it is not by any means a perfect museum, it is very nearly a perfect building. Indeed, it is one of the few museums anywhere that would be pleasurable to visit even if it contained not a single work of art; Kahn's concrete vaults, washed with Texas sun filtered through curved metal reflectors, are at once gentle and powerful, serene and alive. The building's walls are of travertine, set within a frame of concrete; in Kahn's characteristic manner, the rich material and the harsh material enter into a dialogue, as do the oak and aluminum of the interior, each substance bringing greater meaning to the other. The Kimbell is a series of ruminations about the nature of space and light, and it has the ability, so rare among buildings of our age, to challenge us and comfort us at the same time. Although the Kimbell was designed in the late 1960's and finished in 1972, it is in many ways a palazzo as much as it is a museum; with only 20,000 square feet of regular exhibition space on its main floor, its scale is less that of an institution than a great house. Given the impressive quality of the museum's collection, formed by its founding director, Richard Brown, and expanded through significant acquisitions by its director since 1980, Edmund P. Pillsbury, it is not surprising that the Kimbell is often compared to museums like the Frick Collection in New York or the Phillips Collection in Washington; although it does not exist in a former house, as these other institutions do, like them it offers great art in an intimate setting. The Kimbell is now about to break significantly from the model of these institutions, for it is preparing to expand its building. The plans have been drawn not by Kahn, who died in 1974, nor by any of his close associates, but by Romaldo Giurgola, an eminent architect who was a part of Kahn's circle in Philadelphia in the late 1950's and early 1960's. Mr. Giurgola, a former chairman of the department of architecture at Columbia University, has designed numerous large commercial and institutional buildings, including the recently completed Houses of Parliament in Canberra, Australia; his work is widely respected, although it has never, to be sure, engendered the admiration bordering on worship that Kahn's has.

description: Mary Jo Budesa, the daughter of Mary Ellen Utell of Asharoken, L.I., and the late Joseph G. Charles Fink performed the ceremony at St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church in Northport. Mrs. Fornshell, 27 years old, is a financial analyst in the consumer banking group of Chemical Bank in New York. Her husband, 32, is an associate in the New York law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren.

title: A QUESTION OF TRUST
description: Paul Mandelbaum's account of his first outing alone with his girlfriend's 10-year-old daughter, Nicole, was touching (About Men: ''A Question of Trust,'' Aug. 6). It's nice to know there are caring men who are searching for ways to win the trust of new young people in their lives. His anxiety is understandable, but I think he is off to a good start and can relax a little. All children ask questions about loss and destruction, not just those whose parents have split up. And his low-key assurances are just right. JANE SHEAR Binghamton, N.Y.

title: SPEAKING THE PRINCE'S ENGLISH
description: BRITAIN'S PRINCE OF Wales, Prince Charles, for the last several years the battering scourge of the post-modernist architects, has been speaking his mind on another serious matter. He has been commenting on the way the citizens of today's Britain speak and write their own language. ''Bloody badly,'' is his royal conclusion.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: God forbid, you criticize a Spike Lee film or scoff at a tirade by the Rev. Al Sharpton. ''Racist'' is the charge. Anthony Walton's paranoid article continues on the same track. Notre Dame and Brown notwithstanding, a temporary doorman refuses to let him pass. What's the big deal? Who gets a cab in the rain in New York City anyway? Is everything related to race?

title: Clarifying a Position On Skills Testing
description: I plead guilty to only one of the several indictments Howard Berridge charges me with (Letters to the New Jersey Editor, Aug. 20). After reading Mr. Berridge's letter, I went back to my own and, scrutinizing it from his point of view, I found that my ''foolish frenzy'' seems in retrospect to be a bit of a wild pitch. But I plead not guilty to all other charges and most emphatically to the charge that, in constructing a ''specious case'' for my position, I intended to deceive my readers.

description: Beans are an exception to the general belief about canned food: if it comes from a can, it will not taste like much. Though canned beans are frowned upon by chefs, they are one of the few canned foods that do not differ significantly in texture and taste from fresh food cooked at home.

title: Korea's Snake Imports
description: A demand for health potions has encouraged frog and snake imports to South Korea, a Government report said last week. An Agriculture and Fisheries Ministry report to the National Assembly on imports of foreign food items said the value of South Korea's imports of snakes in the first half of this year climbed to $380,000, surpassing the $295,000 for all of 1988. South Korea also imported $48,000 worth of frogs in the first six months of this year, compared with $37,000 all of last year, the report said.

title:

False Tolerance, False Unity
description: LEAD: Pluralism requires tolerance. But a pluralistic society undermines its ability to deal with its most serious problems when differences are denied and tolerance is transformed into a false sense of unity. Yet, our political, social and religious leaders do their best to convince us that differences among people are never profound and always reconcilable.

description: Under a blue arch of autumn sky, salvage crews recovered the last sections of a shattered USAir jet from the East River at La Guardia Airport yesterday, as investigators examined the dripping wreckage in a search for the cause of last week's aborted takeoff and crash.

title: Education and Work: The Missing Link
description: The applause President Bush deserves for taking the dramatic step of convening an education summit meeting with all 50 governors risks being the sound of one-hand clapping unless a prominent connection is made between education and work and competitiveness.

title: Reader's Digest Names Chiefs for New Groups
description: The Reader's Digest Association Inc. has hired Thomas M. Kenney, who most recently has been an investment banker specializing in buying and selling magazine publishing companies, to be president of a newly formed Magazine Publishing Group.

description: The military Government announced today that Haiti will hold a general election next year, transferring power to a civilian President.

title: Experts See Nuclear Energy as Cure for Global Warming
description: The cure for the greenhouse effect, the warming of the atmosphere that is believed to be caused by the burning of fossil fuels, is a huge shift to nuclear-generated power, speaker after speaker told delegates at a World Energy Conference meeting this week.

title: Deal for a Del Monte Unit Said to Be Near
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. was in final talks last night to sell the canned food and processing unit of its Del Monte subsidiary for $1.47 billion to an investment partnership led by Merrill Lynch & Company, Wall Street sources said yesterday. An official announcement of the deal is expected today, the sources added.

title: Review/Theater; Vanessa Redgrave in 'Orpheus': Matching Artistic Sensibilities
description: The fusion of Vanessa Redgrave and Tennessee Williams is an artistic explosion that was bound to happen, and the wonder is that we had to wait until Peter Hall's revival of ''Orpheus Descending.'' Williams and Miss Redgrave were made for each other because they are brilliant theater artists in the same way. They run at life bravely, openly, without defenses and without fear of their inevitable destruction, like great, beautiful deer bounding across a highway after dark.

description: HE'LL be 32 years old on Nov. 19, but Ottis Anderson is running for the Giants as if his age were the same as the number on his uniform.

In an agreement reached last week, its subsidiary Penguin USA will acquire W. H. Smith Publishers, the second-largest bargain book company.

Mosenthal. Regiana Ryan, a justice of the peace from Sherman, officiated.

description: The Mets gave their fans something to remember on Fan Appreciation Day yesterday: a symbol of their summer of 1989 - the squandered four-run lead, the five-run ninth inning for the other guys.

title: Medical Management of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,277,000 for the quarter and $5,777,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income The losses from discontinued operations in the latest periods are related to the company's sale of certain of its non-medical real estate assets and the anticipated sale, subject to stockholder approval, of its remaining non- medical real estate. The company began operations on Sept. 23, 1988 when it acquired an existing ophthalmic surgery center and began providing non-medical support services to certain medical corporations wholly owned by Medical Management's majority stockholder. The 1989 results included the accounts of Medical Management and its wholly owned subsidiaries. Prior year amounts reflected the combined accounts of the medical corporations. The latest year's results from continuing operations were adversely affected by charges of $818,000 and $1,818,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, in connection with severance arrangements and the impact of increased overhead costs. Results for the prior year included $1,440,000 of compensation expense recognized in the second quarter upon the sale of the company's stock to certain officers and $2.1 million and $2,345,000 of salary expenses for the company's majority stockholder in the second and third quarters, respectively.

title: New York G.O.P. Chairman's Suit Seeks to Keep His Finances Secret

description: Chinese exiles and opposition figures from around the world ended an inaugural meeting today establishing the Federation for Democracy in China, an umbrella group that aims to coordinate worldwide opposition to the Beijing Government.

description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees' Cary Stymies Orioles
description: The day ended when a lazy pop fly dropped into Steve Sax's glove near second base. A game was lost, another chance suddenly gone. But almost with a collective shrug, the Baltimore Orioles seemed to dismiss their unhappy fortune. There was still time.

title: Outdoors: Fly-Fishing for Atlantic Salmon
description: FROM the porch of the Black Rapids Fishing Lodge, I watched the Miramichi slide seaward in the moonlight and was content.

description: World Economy on Stage Mexico's top debt negotiator says banks' increased reserve cushions could mean fewer third-world loans.

Ryder Rally Fails U.S.
description: The United States fought from behind and worked into position to win back the Ryder Cup today, but failed to do so because of a series of 18th-hole disasters that befell the team's early finishers.

title: Lebanon's Truce Holds; Ports Active
description: This city's air and sea ports resumed normal activity today after agreement by Lebanon's warring factions to an Arab-negotiated peace plan.

title: A Child and Her Baby Sitter Are Found Dead in Bronx
description: A 41-year-old woman was found beaten to death early yesterday and the 19-month-old girl she had been baby-sitting was found dead in a garbage bag a few hours later in an apartment complex in the Bronx, the police said.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Washington Talk; Bush's Travels Show Him as Clumsy and Deft
description: President Bush's travels have been an exercise in salesmanship. The past week has shown him, in a political sense, at his clumsiest and at his most deft. Here is one take from the road: The President was pressed by reporters, as he toured a tree farm in Wells, Me., about Federal agents who lured a drug dealer to a park in front of the White House to provide dramatic rhetoric and a prop for Mr. Bush's speech on drug policy.

title: Zelie Daniels, Actress, Wed
description: Zelie Nina Daniels, the daughter of Col. Jack Daniels, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Daniels of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday to Carl Andrew Pforzheimer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Pforzheimer 3d of Scarsdale, N.Y. Judge Miriam Cedarbaum of Federal District Court in New York officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents. The bride, a graduate of the University of Utah, is an actress. Her father is a senior lecturer at the International Wine Academy in the Napa Valley in California. Mr. Pforzheimer, a graduate of Harvard University, is a chef. His father is a managing partner of Carl H. Pforzheimer, New York investment bankers.

title: Topics of The Times; Izzy Baline's Century-Plus
description: When Irving Berlin complained that 20th Century Fox paid Rodgers and Hammerstein more for ''Oklahoma!'' than it offered him for ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' the studio argued that he shouldn't care; he was so rich he'd have to give 91 percent to the Government. ''You don't understand,'' Mr. Berlin explained. ''I came to this country from Russia, and look what's happened to me. The country has been wonderful to me. I love this country. I love to pay taxes.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we continue to let children who are born in poverty fail to get the kind of education that will allow them to participate in our economy and our society productively, then some time in the 21st century this nation will cease to be a peaceful, prosperous democracy.'' -Brad M. Butler, former chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company. [ A1:2. ]

title: IPM Technology Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $58,000. The company said the latest year's net included a charge of $615,000 from the settlement of litigation and a charge of $420,000 from fees associated with a merger agreement.

title: Joycelyn Eichler Weds Adam Kenner
description: Joycelyn Margot Eichler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Burton Eichler of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Adam F. Kenner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kenner of Boonton, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Amiel Wohl and Cantor Helene Reps officiated at Temple Israel in New Rochelle.

title: Appeals Made To Jewish Voters In Mayor Race
description: The two major candidates for New York City mayor spent the day yesterday in aggressive pursuit of the city's Jewish voters, with stops in the Orthodox neighborhoods of Brooklyn and back-to-back appearances at a Shalom Festival in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx.

title: In the Drug War, Medellin Is a Reluctant Fighter
description: In the war on drugs, Colombia's most violent city would like to bow out on the ground of conflict of interest.

title: Swapo Leader Asks Whites' Help
description: More than 50,000 people filled Windhoek's main stadium today to hear Sam Nujoma, the leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization, urge the white minority to join in the Namibian independence process. It was Mr. Nujoma's first speech since returning 10 days ago from almost 30 years in exile.

title: 4 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week includes today's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills, followed by one for two-year notes tomorrow and a four-year note auction on Wednesday.

title: Review/Television; Connie Chung's 'Saturday' Features James Earl Jones

If the title of ''Saturday Night With Connie Chung'' were not enough to get the point across, the array of photographs of pretty Ms. Chung that began the hour, at 10 P.M. Saturday on CBS, certified her new incarnation.

title: Tijuana Journal; U.S. Athletes Advised: Get Your Steroids Here!
description: As tourists cross the border from San Diego, they are likely to be given fliers urging the aspiring Olympian or All-America athlete to stop by the nearest pharmacy and choose from what is advertised as ''Steroids: Largest Selection Anywhere, at Wholesale Prices!''

title: On Prison Barge, All Hands Battle Drugs
description: In a room so humid that its painted aluminum walls sweated, Eric Lewis bolted to his feet and strode to the center of a circle of men, most of whom are like himself: young, street-hewn and black. They are also drug addicts on the mend behind bars.

France and Australia Kill Pact on Limited Antarctic Mining and Oil Drilling

He said that while Australia's decision against supporting the treaty was discouraging, the United States continues to support it. He said the convention was not on the agenda for the 15th Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting, to be held in Paris next month.

description: Mexico's chief debt negotiator said during the weekend that the move by three large American banks to increase their cushion against bad third world loans could make it more difficult for some nations to get new loans.

description: When George Bush was the American representative to the United Nations in the early 1970's, he gave so many cocktail parties and dinners at his Waldorf Towers residence that he became known as ''Perle Mesta Bush.''

description: A Federal official was quoted today as saying the Rockwell International Corporation did not withdraw as operator of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons but was dismissed because the Government was ''fed up.''

title: In Campaign, Courter Aims To Pin Down His Identity

description: In a memo to employees, A&M Records last week confirmed recent reports that it had agreed to sell the record company to Polygram Records.

title: How Tall? No: How Long?
description: New York City has been trying to rebuild the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle for nearly five years. The controversial plan has been in and out of court. A parade of black umbrellas protested the shadows that, many New Yorkers feared, would darken Central Park. The project's been redesigned twice to meet objections to height and bulk. Finally, even its most articulate critics accepted the scaled-down compromise. Yet opponents insist on pursuing a lawsuit to block construction - at a grave cost to New York.

title: Granato Painfully Recalls First Year
description: He had, with guts and a season's worth of grimaces, endured the sticks across the back and the breakneck crashes into the boards, only to find himself unable to let go of the ache in his chest when it was all finally over.

title:
THE MEDIA BUINESS: ADVERTISING;
Coors Tries Humor to Sell New Brand
description: LEAD: TO market a new brand of beer called Keystone, the Adolph Coors Company and its Chicago advertising agency, Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, have created a humorous television campaign aimed at the fantasies of many male beer drinkers.

title: New York's Daily News Prepares for a War With Its Union
description: The Daily News has begun a campaign of tough talk and sophisticated public relations intended to help wrestle far-reaching concessions from its 10 labor unions in negotiations expected to start in about two months.

title: Albert A. Marks Jr. Is Dead at 76; Ex-Chief of Miss America Pageant
description: Albert A. Marks Jr., the chairman and executive producer of the Miss America Pageant for 25 years, died yesterday of complications from a heart attack on Sept. 11. Mr. Marks, who was 76 years old and lived in Margate City, N.J., died at Shore Memorial Hospital in Somers Point, N.J.

Little of Barrington, R.I., to Mark Charles Schmidt-Fellner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Schmidt-Fellner of Riverside, Conn., took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers officiated. The bride, 28 years old, graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and Wesleyan University. Her father teaches at Greenwich Academy. Mr. Schmidt-Fellner, 29, a graduate of the University of Virginia, is a commodities specialist with Elders Futures in New York. His father retired as a vice president of Amax, the metals company.

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
2 First Hawaiian Titles Added by Its President
description: LEAD: Walter A. Dods Jr., the president of First Hawaiian Inc., has assumed the additional titles of chairman and chief executive, succeeding John D. Bellinger, who died of heart failure on Sept. 17.

description: The Resolution Funding Corporation, established by the Government earlier this year to help rescue the savings and loan industry, is likely to provide preliminary details this week about how it intends to sell $30 billion worth of securities over the next two fiscal years, credit market analysts said.

description: b-Included a tax credit of $10,000. c-Included tax credits of $38,000 and $121,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Signs of Bomb in Cargo Hold Found in Downed French Jet
description: The head of a team investigating the downing of a French DC-10 last week over the Sahara said today that traces of explosives had been found in a cargo hold in the front of the aircraft.

title: Market Place; Nuclear Write-Off To Success Story
description: THE recent history of the CMS Energy Corporation is something of a Cinderella story. Five years ago the company's main asset, a nuclear power plant under construction in Michigan, became entangled in regulatory and financial disputes and construction problems. Financial disaster seemed imminent when it abandoned the nuclear plant after spending $4.1 billion on it.

title: Let the Death Penalty Be Ended Deliberately
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: Shares for Ex-Mets Q. It hardly seems likely, but suppose that the Mets and the Toronto Blue Jays were to meet in the World Series, with Lee Mazzilli and Mookie Wilson playing against their former Met teammates. Suppose also that Toronto were to win the Series, entitling Mazzilli and Wilson to at least some portion of the winners' shares. But since they joined the Blue Jays on Aug. 1, after playing the first two-thirds of the season with New York, wouldn't Mazzilli and Wilson be eligible for some portion of the losers' shares as well? How would this be resolved? A. For Mazzilli and Wilson, the idea of having your cake and eating it would come down to each player getting a piece of each pie, with one important condition: the player's total share could not exceed a full share of the winning team. According to the rules, any player on a team's roster from June 1 until the end of the season is eligible for a full share. If the player is traded after June 1, he still qualifies for a partial share as voted upon by his teammates. That means Mazzilli and Wilson would be eligible for part of the Mets' losing share and part of the Blue Jays' winning share this season.

title: Commercial International Corp reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $227,000, or 5 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of change in accounting principle. The company said the change in accounting principle represents a change, effective June 1, 1987, in CIC's method of accounting for certain costs pertaining to the production of inventory.

title: U.S. ASKS SOVIETS TO AGREE TO CUTS IN CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The United States has asked the Soviet Union to consider a proposal under which the two sides would make deep cuts in their arsenals of chemical weapons before a global treaty is reached on banning poison gas.

title: 2 Top Officers of American Healthcare Quit as Part of Plan
description: American Healthcare Management Inc., the Dallas-based hospital management company that has been operating in bankruptcy proceedings for two years, has announced that its two top executives and founders, John A. Bradley and David A. Huff, have resigned in keeping with a reorganization plan approved by creditors.

title: Antley Receives Ban From Belmont
description: The Belmont Park stewards said yesterday that they would not permit Chris Antley to ride because of information they had received from the jockey's former agent and from officials of the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Toppling a Tower of Compromise
description: Three years almost to the day after Congress approved the Tax Reform Act of 1986, that monumental legislation, the product of dozens of carefully drawn political and economic trade-offs, seems likely to be torn apart by lawmakers in votes this week.

title: Wide Open Spaces
description: The tectonic plates that underlie the American way of living are making loud, grinding noises. Something big is going on in the real America that most of us who live inside urban beltways are missing: proximity is losing its power.

title: Impending U.S. Jobs 'Disaster': Work Force Unqualified to Work
description: David T. Kearns, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, calls it ''the makings of a national disaster.''

title: A Bicycle Windshield for More Speed and Warmth
description: A products designer who rides his bike to work has invented a windshield that he says will help you cycle faster and stay warmer.

title: Gorbachev's Anti-Magic; Lionized Abroad Yet Tormented at Home, He Is Falling Short of Soviet Expectations
description: One of the great contradictions of Mikhail S. Gorbachev is that while the outside world grows more and more captivated by his skill and charm, much of his own country seems increasingly immune to the magic.

title: Topics of The Times; The Carriage Horse Question
description: Mayor Koch has scheduled a hearing for today to help him decide whether or not to sign a measure to protect carriage horses in New York City. The need for the bill is obvious.

title: FDP Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ferruzzi Expects Big Loss
description: Gruppo Ferruzzi said Friday that it could suffer losses of up to $100 million from its commodity trading business this year.

title: Financial Officials Fear Global Trade Imbalance
description: In stretch limos and blue pinstripes, the global finance community gathers in Washington this week to try to create a favorable global economic environment in the 1990's.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova Beats Seles: Martina Navratilova defeated Monica Seles yesterday to win the Dallas women's pro tournament in Texas. In the first meeting of the world's No. 2 player and the precocious 15-year-old rookie pro, who are both left-handed, Navratilova took the final, 7-6, 6-3, in 1 hour 21 minutes.(AP) Gomez Triumphs: Andres Gomez of Ecuador won the 27th Count of Godo tournament by defeating Horst Skoff of Austria in the men's singles final yesterday in Barcelona, Spain. Gomez won, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) AUTO RACING Berger Wins: Gerhard Berger of Austria drove his Ferrari to victory yesterday in the Portuguese Grand Prix in Estoril.(AP) Another Victory for Waltrip: Darrell Waltrip slipped past Rusty Wallace and Dale Earnhardt for the lead with 46 laps left yesterday and won the Goody's 500 at the Martinsville Speedway in Virginia. He averaged 76.571 miles an hour.(AP) GOLF A First for Schulz: Ted Schulz shot a four-under-par 66 yesterday to win the Southern Open in Columbus, Ga., his first PGA Tour title. One shot behind were Tim Simpson and Jay Haas.(AP) Lopez Rallies: Nancy Lopez recovered from a shaky start and shot a 2-under-par 70 for a two-stroke victory over fast-closing Alice Ritzman and the rookie Pam Wright yesterday in the MBS Classic in Buena Park, Calif. Lopez had a 72-hole total of 11-under 277. Wright shot a 73 and Ritzman a 67 to tie at 279.(AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL Wagner Wins in Pride Bowl: Greg Harris scored three touchdowns on runs of 1, 73 and 10 yards to lead Wagner (3-0) to a 35-11 victory over Davidson in the 11th annual Pride Bowl yesterday at Schools Stadium in Newark. Harris finished with 156 yards and 14 carries.(AP) GYMNASTICS Bruce Takes All-Around Title: Wendy Bruce won the all-around title yesterday at the United States world championship team trials at Arizona State University in Tempe, earning one of eight spots on a squad that will compete in the women's world championships next month in West Germany. Brandy Johnson missed the trials with a viral infection. She won the United States championship in Minneapolis in July and her 77.020 points counted for her score here.(AP)

title: Another Timely Field Goal Lifts Arizona
description: For the second consecutive Saturday night in Tucson, Ariz., Doug Pfaff became a hero. His 35-yard field goal, with 1 minute 1 second to play, became the difference in Arizona's 20-17 victory over Washington.

title: Removal of Asbestos Delays Subway Use For at Least a Week
description: New York City transit officials said yesterday that it will take at least another week before workers finish removing asbestos from a 10-block stretch of the IND Eighth Avenue subway line and before service can be restored to normal.

description: To the Editor:

Gotbaum of Chevy Chase, Md.

description: ''The Time Guardian'' is an Australian science-fiction film that steals bits of ''The Terminator,'' ''Star Wars,'' ''Star Trek'' and ''Mad Max,'' and ends up being more boring than ''Dune.'' This strange mix begins in the year 4039, when a few pathetic human survivors of ''the neutron wars,'' are threatened by part-human robots that resemble life-size Transformer toys.

title: Solidarity Journalist to Run State Television
description: A Solidarity journalist has been appointed to run Poland's state-owned television and radio, ending the Communist Party's control of broadcasting since the late 1940's.

title: Unassuming Storefronts Believed To Launder Drug Dealers' Profits

The regulators say these storefront money-transmitting and check-cashing operations are sending billions of dollars to drug dealers in South America and Asia.

title: The Best Way to Fight the Mob
description: For two decades, Federal crimefighters have pursued the mob with 14 regional strike forces that coordinate the F.B.I. and other agencies. It is an effective way to fight organized crime yet it has aroused the jealousies of the 94 local U.S. Attorneys. Now Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, a former U.S. Attorney who never liked the strike force system, has ordered it scrapped. Congress is right to resist.

title: Ilene Lieberman Is Wed
description: Ilene Lieberman, the associate director of development for the New York Philharmonic, and Jon H. Sprance, a restorer of fine art, were married yesterday at the Bird and Bottle Inn in Garrison, N.Y. Donald McGrath, the town clerk of Cold Spring, N.Y., officiated. Mrs. Sprance, 32 years old, graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., and received a master's degree in performing arts management from Adelphi University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jason Lieberman of Brewster, N.Y. Mr. Sprance, 35, a son of Anne Sprance of Yonkers and the late Henry G. Sprance, attended Pratt Institute.

title: Campaign Matters; On a Free Ride, Council Leader Bides His Time

The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Meisel of Great Neck, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bienenstock of New York.

title: Robert Akin Jr., 85, Hudson Co. Chairman
description: Robert M. Akin Jr., the chairman of Hudson International Conductors, died, apparently of a heart attack, Thursday at his home in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 85 years old. Mr. Akin joined the company, which was formerly the Hudson Wire Company and now makes high-temperature conductors, in 1924. He became president and chairman in 1946 and was president until 1971. The company was founded by his father in 1901, and held many patents in wire-making machinery and processes.

title: Sooner Federal S & L reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary writeoff of goodwill of $34.5 million. c-After an extraordinary gain of $3,639,000, or $1.78 a share, from early repayment of borrowings.

title: Emily Kohlberg, Teacher, Weds A. J. Greenberg
description: Emily Carol Kohlberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kohlberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Andrew Joel Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Greenberg of New York, were married yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck.

title: Rams Escape, 41-38
description: Greg Bell rushed for 221 yards and scored twice today as the Los Angeles Rams defeated the Green Bay Packers, 41-38.

title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver
description: Motorists who are stopped for erratic driving have long faced tests to detect alcohol. Now, more and more, they are being tested for drugs as well.

title: New Schools Chief: An Innovator and Taker of Risks
description: In two years as Superintendent of Dade County Public Schools, Joseph A. Fernandez earned a national reputation as an innovator and risk taker. He forged links between the business community and the schools, invested schools with more decision-making power and spearheaded a successful drive for a $980 million bond issue to build 49 schools for a woefully overcrowded system.

title: Advance Circuits reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Net loss The company said both year-ago losses included a provision of $10 million for writedown of facilities.

title: Micron Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Centennial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and year net income were adversely affected by the creation of a $4.6 million reserve for the writedown of property carried on the books at cost to net realizable value.

title: Rite for Colorado Player
description: A memorial service will be given this afternoon in Boulder, Colo., for Sal Aunese, the former University of Colorado quarterback who died of cancer Saturday night.

title: Tool Orders Rose 18.8% Last Month
description: Orders for American-made machine tools rebounded in August, advancing by 18.8 percent over the July level as orders from the automotive industry increased significantly, a trade group said in a monthly report to be released today.

title: Countrywide Credit Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Corcoran Board to Meet on Dismissing Director
description: The board of the Corcoran Gallery of Art will meet Monday on whether to dismiss the museum's director, Dr. Christina Orr-Cahall, whose decision to cancel a photographic exhibition by Robert Mapplethorpe threw the institution into summerlong turmoil.

title: OPEC Battling to Save Troubled Quota System
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries struggled tonight to save its crumbling production system, as more of its members sent clear signals that they planned to increase output to meet the rising demand for OPEC oil worldwide.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY State banking regulators around the country have found that thousands of small inner-city businesses through which immigrants send money to relatives are also being used to launder drug money. The regulators say these storefront money-transmitting and check-cashing operations are sending billions of dollars to drug dealers in South America and Asia. [ Page A1. ] Orders for American-made machine tools rebounded in August, advancing by 18.8 percent over the July level, as orders from the automotive industry increased significantly. [ D1. ] The Tax Reform Act of 1986 seems likely to be torn apart by lawmakers in votes this week, almost three years to the day after Congress approved the monumental legislation. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Lomas Financial sought court protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, frustrated by creditor talks that had dragged on since June. The company said it had halted payments indefinitely on $2.1 billion in debt. [ D1. ] RJR Nabisco was in final talks last night to sell Del Monte's canned food and processing unit for $1.47 billion to a partnership led by Merrill Lynch, Wall Street sources said. [ D1. ] Two top executives and founders resigned at American Healthcare Management, in keeping with a reorganization plan. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Mexico's chief debt negotiator said it could become harder for some nations to get new loans because three large American banks have increased their cushion against third world loans. [ D1. ] Trade imbalances are high on the agenda of the global finance community as it gathers for meetings of the World Bank and I.M.F. [ D8. ] The cure for the greenhouse effect is nuclear-generated power, numerous speakers said at the World Energy Conference in Montreal this week. But others questioned that approach. [ D2. ] OPEC is struggling to save its quota production system, as more of its members sent clear signals that they planned to increase production to meet the rising demand for oil. [ D2. ] Negotiators took the first steps last week in multilateral trade talks in Geneva toward writing rules to liberalize trade in banking, tourism and other services. [ D3. ] For executives in China, political posturing is a way of life, and the chairman of the state-owned China International Trust and Investment has a keen sense for when and how to do it. [ D8. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Fashion magazine readers will have more difficulty distinguishing between advertising and editorial content, the boundaries of which are increasingly blurred. Magazines. [ D9. ] New York's Daily News has begun a campaign of tough talk and sophisticated public relations intended to help wrestle far-reaching concessions from 10 labor unions in negotiations expected to start in about two months. The contracts expire March 30. [ D9. ] Pearson P.L.C. is about to become the third international publishing conglomerate in a year to enter the bargain-book field. [ D9. ] Foote, Cone & Belding created a humorous television campaign - for Adolph Coors's new Keystone line of beers - that appeals to the fantasies of many male beer drinkers. Advertising. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Resolution Funding Corporation is likely to provide preliminary details this week about how it intends to sell $30 billion worth of securities over the next two fiscal years, credit market analysts said. Credit Markets. [ D7. ] The Supreme Court faces a heavy docket of antitrust disputes. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ D2. ] CMS Energy is something of a Cinderella company. Five years ago, financial disaster seemed imminent; now it is hailed as possibly one of the best buys in the energy business. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Material Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The latest second quarter and 6 months' losses included a $7 million pre-tax restructuring charge.

title: Ellen Shaer Marries Peter S. Krieger
description: Ellen Ruth Shaer, a senior associate in the investment banking department at Kidder Peabody & Company, was married yesterday to Peter Schafmeister Krieger, a financial analyst at W. R. Grace & Company, both in New York. Justice A. Frederick Meyerson of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated at the Water's Edge Restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Tokheim Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,710,000, or 42 cents a share, from implementation of new accounting standard and gains realized on the sale of fixed assets.

description: Share earnings were adjusted for 50 percent stock dividend declared earlier this year. Revenue represented net revenue.

title: Rachel List Offers Ballet Along With Clog Dancing
description: It must delight Rachel List to know that dancing can involve many different kinds of movements. Every work Rachel List and Company presented Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater had its own kinetic personality.

title: Egypt's Plan Needs a U.S. Shoulder
description: Egypt has ignited hope for a dialogue that might lift the Israeli-Palestinian conflict off the streets and onto the negotiating table. But President Mubarak can't do the job alone. The United States has to weigh in, visibly and vigorously.

title: EAC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $431,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $52,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,262,000, or 65 cents a share, for the 6 months.

Montana Stuns the Eagles
description: With 8 minutes 14 seconds left to play and the Philadelphia Eagles leading the San Francisco 49ers by 28-17 today at Veterans Stadium, the brash, upstart Eagles had not quite begun celebrating a victory.

title: No Signs of Russian Backlash in Baltic States
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental Homes Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Maine Fair Promotes Pure Food and Rural Values
description: Egg rolls sold at the Common Ground Country Fair this weekend were stuffed with five organically grown vegetables and wrapped in crisp dough made from whole wheat and unbleached flours.

title: Out of the Pool
description: What happens to Olympic swimmers who use up their college eligiblity but still have a year of school until they earn their degrees?

title: Smith Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bridge
description: The victory of Brazil in the world team championship here Saturday was not a big surprise to experienced observers. Four years earlier a similar but slightly stronger American team beat Brazil on the last board in a semifinal Bermuda Bowl match.

title: Every 100 Years
description: A century or so ago, when a group of major leaguers played a series of games in Britain as part of a barnstorming world tour, the visit produced contradictory reactions.

title: Flame Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AEL Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-The company said it plans to invest about $8 million in the development effort of its AEL Defense Corp. unit with a GM Hughes Electronics unit to develop and build an upgraded version of the Navy's AN-ALR-67 radar warning receiver. To provide for this commitment, the company said it established a contract provision in its second quarter for the full amount of the expected investment, which is included in the quarter's net loss

title: For a Top Female Runner, Patience Pays in Long Run
description: LIKE a movie star who struggles for years before becoming an overnight success, Gordon Bloch, New York's leading female runner, seems to have suddenly vaulted ahead of the pack. But she credits a long and gradual development as the underpinning of her recent performances and says road racers must be patient in their hopes for a competitive breakthrough.

title: Though Racial Politics Lurks, It Is Muted in Virginia Contest
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the campaign for governor in Virginia misstated a political policy of Senator Harry F. Byrd. He followed a strict ''pay as you go'' policy on public spending, declining to issue bonds for schools and hospitals. Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr., a Byrd protege, abandoned the policy in 1965.

title: Corrections
description: A headline Saturday on an article about monitoring of a Vietnamese military withdrawal from Cambodia misidentifed the observer force that the Cambodian Government is seeking. It would be international, but not sponsored by the United Nations.

title: Belcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Marshals Seize Apartments Of Suspected Drug Dealers
description: Federal marshals and the city police seized the public housing apartments of two suspected drug dealers during an early morning raid, taking advantage of stronger Federal drug laws, authorities said.

title: Cobi Foods reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Somerset Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Total reserves for possible loan and specific other real estate owned losses amounted to $8.5 million at Aug. 31, up from $3.1 million a year ago.

title: Bankruptcy Filing By Lomas
description: Frustrated by creditor talks that had dragged on since June, the Lomas Financial Corporation today became one of the largest financial companies to seek court protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Horizon Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $45,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: GEAC Computer reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $5,650,000, or 25 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Canadian financial products division. Results are in Canadian dollars.

The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE LEGAL COMMITTEE

title: 2 Minor Quakes in California
description: A small earthquake jolted downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, about two hours after another minor quake east of the city. No injuries or damage were reported. The afternoon earthquake measured 2.4 on the Richter scale, said Hall Daily of the California Institute of Technology; a quake of magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans. About two hours earlier, a quake measuring 2.9 shook an area about 55 miles east of Los Angeles, near Rialto.

title: Charleston Rushes to Preserve Heritage From Waters
description: In this three-century-old city, where appreciation of the past is perhaps the highest civic virtue, the initial exhilaration of surviving Hurricane Hugo has faded as residents realize much work lies ahead merely to repair the storm's damage.

title: U.N. Study Says 1 Billion Suffer From Diseases
description: One billion people around the world are in poor health, malnourished or suffering with diseases ranging from malaria and river blindness to AIDS, the World Health Organization said in a report released today.

title: Murder Charges Filed in a Car Theft Case
description: A 20-year-old man was charged with murder today after he reportedly stole a car and then deliberately slammed it into a highway guardrail in an effort to shake off a man who was clinging to the outside of the car, the police said.

title: San Francisco Journal; Views of Wretchedness By Children Born to It
description: Twelve-year-old Shemika Skipworth had no idea, when she began writing, that she would one day be a guest of honor at a book-publishing party, fingers cramped from signing too many autographs.

title: Canada Southern Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $104,000, or 1 cent a share. The company said results were affected by sharply reduced oil prices, substantial increases in lease operating costs, a doubling of depreciation and depletion charges and a 25-percent increase in general and administrative expense resulting from costs incurred in lawsuits relating to the Kotaneelee gas field. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: A Film Maker's Witty and Poetic Last Word
description: From the start of his career, in the 1920's, to his death last June at the age of 90, Joris Ivens discovered stories hidden in elegant nonnarrative images. The Dutch film maker's ''Rain,'' the 15-minute silent black-and-white film he made in 1929, is no more or less than scenes of Amsterdam's streets and canals before, during and after a rainstorm. Yet it created a miniature artistic drama of human responses to nature.
