From a close-up of raindrops in a puddle to an overhead shot of a street blanketed with black umbrellas, its blend of lyricism, realism and wit had a huge influence on future documentary film makers.

title: Bakker Is Expected to Testify in His Own Defense
description: Jim Bakker, the former television evangelist, is expected to testify in his own defense this week as his trial on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges nears its close.

title: Review/Magic; Doing the Classics, but Oversize and Loud
description: Hurricane Hugo did not show up in New York on Friday night, and for all anyone knows, maybe it was Siegfried and Roy, the master magicians who opened at Radio City Music Hall that night, who made it disappear. After all, they made everything else except the audience vanish in a blaze of brilliant wizardry.

title: Peggy Koch Wed To B. S. Palmer
description: Peggy Ann Koch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Koch Jr. of New York and East Orleans, Mass., was married yesterday to Briggs S. Palmer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Palmer of Fort Myers, Fla. The ceremony was performed at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., by the Rev. John Buehrens, a Unitarian minister. Mrs. Palmer, an independent producer of television commercials, is a graduate of the Nightingale-Bamford School and the University of Vermont. Her father is the chairman of R. N. Koch, a jewelry company in New York. The bride is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Koch of Long Branch, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Katharine Weill Koch and the late Stephen M. Dryfoos.

title: Yield to Jays? Brewers Refuse
description: Joey Meyer's three-run double broke a sixth-inning tie and the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 8-3, today to keep their slim playoff hopes alive in the American League East.

title: Lisa Berzok and Lance Hanf Marry
description: Lisa Anne Berzok, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Berzok of New York and Atlanta, was married yesterday to Lawrence Porter Hanf, the son of Marilyn H. Buckley of Anchorage and Charles D. Hanf of Berkeley, Calif. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's parents.

title: Erly Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $259,000. Year-ago results are restated to give effect to discontinued operations and a 10 percent stock dividend in October 1988.

title: Arch Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Group Plans to Import an AIDS Drug
description: Angered by what they see as the exorbitant price of a major drug used against AIDS symptoms, a New York group is offering to help people fill their prescriptions in England, where the drug is available at a fraction of its cost here.

title: Rig Count Rises a Bit
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil in the United States increased last week by two, to a total of 967, continuing a slow but steady rise, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the count stood at 917.

title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System
description: Drug-related criminal cases in the Federal courts have increased to the point where they are squeezing out many civil cases, according to the head of the office that runs the Federal court system.

title: Philips Agrees To Merrill Bid
description: Philips Industries, which makes components for the construction and transportation industries, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by a subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company for $25.50 a share, or about $750 million.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-1 President Bush told the U.N. that the United States will destroy 80 percent of its chemical weapons if the Soviet Union agrees to cut its stockpile to the American level. Page A1

title: INSIDE
description: Pierce Is Not Ready For Hearing, Lawyers Say Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. will not be prepared for a Congressional hearing on Tuesday and will face ''unpleasant options,'' his lawyers said today. Page A20. Ward Turns in His Badge Benjamin Ward said his battle with asthma is forcing him to resign as Police Commissioner as of Oct. 22. His chief deputy, Richard J. Condon, will replace him. Page B1. Long-Jailed Mother Is Freed Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, jailed in Washington for 25 months for contempt of court in a child custody case, was released yesterday after an appeals court ruling. Page A18. Bomb in Colombian Resort A bomb exploded in the Hilton hotel in Cartagena and two doctors at a convention there were reported killed.

title: Fear Rises at Site of Bronx Slayings
description: Residents of the Bronx building where a mother of three and the toddler she was baby-sitting were found dead Sunday were watching their children more closely and guarding their doors yesterday, trying to come to terms with the slayings.

title: Hauser Chemical Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEAL IS EXPECTED FOR SONY TO BUY COLUMBIA PICTURES
description: Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. has received a $3.4 billion cash offer for the company from the Sony Corporation of Japan, and the board is expected to approve the sale, possibly as soon as tomorrow, a person close to the talks said.

title: Dinkins Urges More Financing Of Drug Centers
description: David N. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee for mayor, yesterday used the backdrop of an East Harlem drug rehabilitation center and the presence of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to push for more Federal financing for the treatment of crack addicts.

title: KEY RATES
Books of The Times; The Bell Tolls Again, This Time in Eritrea
description: To Asmara By Thomas Keneally 290 pages. Warner Books. $18.95.

title: 2 Dead and 50 Hurt in Fire on Danish Ferry
description: A fire broke out at dawn today on a luxury Danish ferry in the North Sea while most of its 650 passengers and crew were asleep. Two passengers were reported killed and as many as 50 injured.

title: END THE 'SCOURGE' OF CHEMICAL ARMS, BUSH SAYS AT U.N.
description: President Bush, saying it was time ''to rid the earth of this scourge,'' told the United Nations today that the United States would destroy 80 percent of its chemical weapons if the Soviet Union agreed to cut its stockpile to the American level.

title: Sale of a Del Monte Unit To Investors Agreed On
description: RJR Nabisco said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the processed food unit of its Del Monte subsidiary for $1.475 billion to an investor group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Opposition Parties in India Stage A Huge Rally in Quest for Unity
description: India's political opposition, from the Communist left to the conservative Hindu right, mounted its broadest show of unity today with a huge rally intended to advance its campaign to bring down Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in elections.

title: Vietnamese Quit Cambodia Today But Face Heavy Burdens at Home
description: For a country about to enjoy what could be its first prolonged period of peace in many decades, Vietnam today displays little sense of celebration.

title: New York Fed On Reserves
description: In comments made yesterday to a group of international bankers, E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, gave what was interpreted as another official response to the increases in reserves taken last week by three leading American banks.

title: A Gorbachev Deadline on Armenia Issue
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned the leaders of two southern republics today that they have two days to negotiate an end to an extraordinary rail blockade that has paralyzed Armenia.

title: Oryx Will Sell Energy Properties
description: The Oryx Energy Company has agreed to sell a group of oil and gas interests in Texas, Oklahoma and 10 other states to the Houston-based American Exploration Company for $114 million. A spokesman for Oryx said the properties, which have combined production equivalent to 10,000 barrels of oil a day and proven reserves of 3 million barrels, were among the company's least profitable operations for a variety of reasons. He said their sale, expected to close on Nov. 30, would yield an after-tax gain of $22 million.

title: OPEC Talks Hit Snags
description: Negotiations among OPEC members struck snags late today in the effort to reach a new agreement to curb violations of production quotas and put a floor under prices.

title: U.S. Proposal on Chemical Weapons: Not Much
description: LEAD: President Bush's proposal at the U.N. for mutual reductions of U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons stocks, and last weekend's agreement in Wyoming, have raised hopes for a global ban on chemical weapons. Both initiatives, however, are largely meaningless and the current euphoria over the prospects for chemical disarmament is misplaced, unless Washington and

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Tumble
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply in light trading yesterday, as a falling dollar and a coming wave of new issues persuaded dealers to sell securities.

title: Presidential Collage at the Met: Rembrandts, Russians, Radiance
description: President Bush made history last night. He became the first President to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art since Rutherford B. Hayes opened the Met in 1880. Not only did he look at a few Rembrandts and Vermeers, he stayed for dinner.

title: Utah Teachers Boycott to Protest Education Budget
description: Nearly 20,000 Utah teachers boycotted classrooms today to protest what they say is chronic underfunding of one of the nation's most crowded public school systems.

title: Visit by Bush Snarls Traffic on East Side
description: President Bush's 12-hour visit to New York City yesterday caused a series of traffic tie-ups, especially on the East Side, officials said.

title: Investments By Lodestar
description: The Lodestar Group, a New York-based investment fund that specializes in corporate mergers and acquisitions, has acquired an 8.8 percent stake in Marshall Industries and a 6.4 percent stake in ADC Telecommunications Inc.

title: Memories Recalled By Dent's Return
description: It has been 11 seasons since Bucky Dent broke Boston's heart with one unsettling swing of his bat. The home run that sailed into the afternoon sky and fell gently into the screen above Fenway Park's Green Monster remains a black day to Red Sox fans, an unforgettable memory to Dent.

title: What Fate for Remains of a Library's Irreplaceable Collection?
description: To the Editor:

title: McClatchy Buys Papers
description: McClatchy Newspapers Inc. announced today that it had signed a $74.1 million agreement to acquire three South Carolina daily newspapers from the Observer Publishing Company of Raleigh, N.C. The newspapers are The Herald of Rock Hill, the Island Packet of Hilton Head and The Beaufort Gazette. McClatchy said the transfer of ownership would take place on Jan. 1 and would also include five ancillary publications. The Herald has a daily circulation of about 28,000, the Island Packet, 10,000 and The Beaufort Gazette, 9,000. McClatchy publishes six dailies and seven smaller newspapers in California, Washington and Alaska. Its flagship paper is The Sacramento Bee.

title: Mahamat Soumailia, Chadian Official, 36
description: Mahamat Soumailia, Chad's Minister of Planning and Cooperation since 1987, was killed last Tuesday in the crash of a DC-10 airliner flying from Chad to France. The plane went down over Niger in a suspected terrorist bombing. He was 36 years old and lived in Ndjamena, the capital of Chad.

title: Senate Leaders Tentatively Agree To Increase Money to Fight Drugs
description: Tentatively resolving a deadlock over money for the campaign against drug abuse, Democratic and Republican Senators tonight agreed to increase spending to $8.8 million in 1990, a level that is $900 million more than President Bush has requested.

title: Rival Lebanese Legislators to Meet in Saudi Arabia
description: Despite a serious violation of Lebanon's four-day-old truce, Christian and Muslim members of Parliament agreed today to meet in Saudi Arabia on Saturday to discuss a charter for national reconciliation.

title: With Sun Entry, St. Louis Is 2-Paper Town
description: The St. Louis Sun began publication this morning, the first time in three years St. Louis has had two major dailies.

title: Panel Votes to Keep Congress Mailings, Reversing Big Votes
description: Senate and House negotiators voted today to continue free Congressional mass mailings, reversing lopsided votes in both houses that sought to end the practice and use the savings to combat illegal drugs.

title: Peoples Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from a loan loss provision of $11,000 for the quarter and income from a loss loss provision of $350,000 for the year. c-Included income from loan loss provisions of $300,000 and $1,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: High Prices In Japan Cited
description: Despite their higher per-capita income, the Japanese have less purchasing power than consumers in other advanced industrial countries because Japan's prices are so high, the nation's Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Strom Relief Effort Organized to Aid Charleston Victims
description: A relief effort to help hurricane victims in Charleston, S.C., and the surrounding area has been set up at the Charleston City Hall. The phone number for those wishing to help is 803-720-3838.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Emergency Aid in Puerto Rico
description: Officials handed out $300 emergency checks today to people who lost their homes in Hurricane Hugo, which caused an estimated $1 billion damage to Puerto Rico.

title: Hialeah's Sad Effort At Mediocrity
description: The John Galbreath family once owned Hialeah Park, the tropical showplace in Miami that is still the nation's most gorgeous racetrack. This winter, the Galbreath horses are among hundreds from New York that will be barred from stabling at Hialeah, for a most unusual reason: first-class horses are no longer welcome because Hialeah is determined to become a third-class track.

title: Rival's Connaught Bid Is Topped by Merieux
description: Institut Merieux S.A. made an $800 million (Canadian) takeover offer today for Connaught Biosciences Inc., setting the stage for a bidding war between the French company and a Swiss-American team vying for the Canadian vaccine maker.

title: Bengals Defeat Browns
description: Boomer Esiason threw three touchdown passes and Jim Skow led a second-half defensive surge as the Cincinnati Bengals beat the Cleveland Browns, 21-14, tonight.

title: Benefit for Soviet Jews Is to Feature Performers
description: The violinist Isaac Stern and the pianist Vladimir Feltsman are to highlight a benefit at 8 P.M. Thursday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The musicians, who are to perform together for the first time, will play the first movement from Franck's Sonata in A major.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Barker Sells Two Units
description: Charles Barker P.L.C., a British marketing and communications company, last week sold Charles Barker Ltd., its public relations subsidiary, to Corporate Communications P.L.C., a British public relations concern that is the parent of Donley Communications. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Barker also sold its Ayer Barker unit, a consumer advertising agency, to N. W. Ayer in a stock swap. The transactions leave Barker with only one operating group, an employee recruitment agency.

title: Drug Emporium reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said all share earnings information is adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 10.

title: By Design; Rajah Regalia
description: This trend is rich. Nevertheless, the fad for piling on jewelry that might have come from a rajah's trove is becoming a fashion movement, part of the interest in design elements from the East.

title: Dick Clark Productions reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Overcoming 18th Hole Determines Winners
description: It creeps over the body - turning the knees to jelly so they wobble, tightening the shoulder and arm muscles so they don't swing easily, drying the throat and soaking the palms, fevering the brow and freezing the brain. It's the lonely golfer's worst enemy: pressure.

title: Where Bush Stands After Eight Months
description: The American public thoroughly approves President Bush's handling of his job, more than it did of his immediate predecessors at the same time in their terms. But it also doubts whether many of Mr. Bush's programs will really work, Article, page A26.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: A Peek at New Talent, and the New Spring Season
description: Beaded boleros with the Statue of Liberty, the Eiffel Tower or images from Picasso, Matisse or pop art embroidered in front or back. Tight stretch-fabric tops, pants of all lengths, short skirts and jump suits. Crisply tailored jackets and soft, drifty chiffon skirts.

title: Anderson and Rooney Sent to Utica by Devils
description: How much the Devils have upgraded their team was reflected in today's demotion of two players who were viewed as indispensable last season.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amdura Corp., Denver, retained Morgan Stanley & Co. as a financial adviser on whether to sell its Crosby and Harris businesses to reduce debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Outgrowing A Need to Be Outrageous
description: RICHARD KIRSHENBAUM and Jonathan Bond, the bad boys of American advertising, are growing out - and growing up.

title: Film Festival; The Legacy of the Atomic Bomb On One Family in Hiroshima
description: Forty-four years after the fall of the Third Reich, artists in every discipline are still attempting to come to terms with the meaning of the Holocaust. They will continue as long as the Holocaust survives in memory. There will always be something more to say. Some events are not easily reduced to the dimensions of art, which is less a reflection on art than on the capacity of men to stage new Armageddons that elude their own comprehension.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in The Home Section on Thursday with the Where to Find It column about out-of-print children's books misstated the telephone number of the Bryn Mawr Book Shop in Manhattan. Its number is (212) 744-7682.

title: A.&P. Profit Rises by 20.7%
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company posted a 20.7 percent quarterly profit gain on an 11.2 percent increase in sales, it reported today.

title: Corcoran Board Delays Vote On Resignation Request
description: The board of the Corcoran Gallery of Art today postponed a vote on whether to ask for the resignation of the gallery's director but decided to appoint a task force to study staff morale.

title: Narita Journal; An Airport Is Being Strangled by Relentless Foes
description: Traffic moves briskly to and from Tokyo's international airport here on a glorious afternoon, in keeping with Japan's image of grace and machine-like efficiency. But as soon as one crosses the guarded, barbed wire boundary into the airport compound, another side to this country emerges.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Newsweek President
description: Newsweek magazine yesterday named Alan G. Spoon as president. Mr. Spoon has been a vice president of Newsweek's parent company, the Washington Post Company, since 1987. Before that he was a marketing and finance vice president at The Washington Post.

title: Otto Kraushaar, 87, Ex-Head of Goucher
description: Otto F. Kraushaar, former president of Goucher College, died Saturday at his home in Baltimore after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Axel Johnson Completes Its Search for a Chief
description: Axel Johnson Inc., a privately held industrial company with $580 million in annual sales, has named Paul E. Graf president and chief executive after a search for a new manager.

title: Lilly Insulin Plant Planned in France
description: Eli Lilly & Company said it would build a $115 million plant in eastern France to make genetically engineered human insulin to treat diabetes. The factory, coupled with a new plant in West Germany, will triple Lilly's capacity to make genetic insulin by the early 1990's. Lilly is also building a $150 million insulin plant near its Indianapolis headquarters.

title: Ward's Successor Now Runs Daily Operations
description: Richard J. Condon, who was named Police Commissioner yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch, brings to the job skills as a diplomat and negotiator, as well extensive experience in fighting corruption.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Ford Motor Company's purchase of a stake in Jaguar P.L.C. referred incorrectly to a British Government regulation issued when the state-owned company was turned over to the private sector. The Government banned the purchase of more than 15 percent of the company's stock by a single buyer until the end of next year.

title: Nine Suspensions By Italian Bank
description: The Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, at the center of a storm over $3 billion in unauthorized loans to Iraq, has suspended nine United States-based executives and obtained emergency financing, bank officials said last week.

title: Home Resales Up in August
description: Sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in August to the highest level in six months as buyers took advantage of lower mortgage rates, a real estate group reported today.

title: MONY Real Estate Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a credit of $985,000 due to gains from sale of investments.

title: Hamilton Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,584,000, or 15 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Review/Theater; A Shaggy-Dog Comedy on a Trip of Digression
description: The approach to global travel taken by Armand, the peripatetic hero of Jeffrey Klayman's ''Indiana Dog,'' is the opposite of that of Phileas Fogg in ''Around the World in 80 Days.'' Fogg wants to move as fast as he can; Armand has a surfeit of time. As he sees the world, he ages from a young rebel to a veteran of foreign voyages.

title: Poll Finds Broad Support for Bush but Skepticism About Drugs and Taxes
description: The American public thoroughly approves of the way President Bush is handling his job and supports most of his programs, but doubts whether many of them, including Mr. Bush's highly publicized plans to fight illegal drugs and clean up the environment, will really work.

title: New Jersey Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Argentine Chief, at U.N., Presses Falklands Stand
description: President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina strongly reasserted his country's claim to sovereignty over the Falkland Islands today in advance of talks with Britain next month on normalizing relations after the 1982 war over the islands.

title: 2 Commodity Brokers Sued
description: Two investors in commodity futures options, accusing two brokerages of fraudulent sales ploys, filed class-action suits today for $800 million in losses and damages.

title: Critic's Notebook; Seeking the Truth Amid a Chorus of Video Voices
description: If VCR's, cassettes, camcorders, satellite dishes and the other paraphernalia of the video age had made their appearance 40 years earlier, George Orwell would not have written ''Nineteen Eighty-Four.'' That is one of the messages left by a recent edition of ''The Koppel Report.'' As Ted Koppel put it, television is ''falling into the hands of the people.'' Video cameras, recorders and players are so inexpensive, so small and light, so easy to use that countless little brothers and sisters can become producers and distributors of material that exasperates and confounds Big Brother. It's a blessing, but as Orwell would undoubtedly have recognized, a mixed one.

title: Vermont American Bids
description: The Vermont American Corporation said it had received several proposals for its acquisition in response to its previously announced solicitation of buyout bids. The company said that a special board committee was reviewing the proposals but that there could be no assurance that a transaction would result. The company did not say how many bids were received.

title: Yellow Menace
description: Since spring, picnickers and hikers in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and northern California have been plagued by a population explosion of yellow jackets, the aggressive wasp with a painful and potentially fatal sting.

title: Gelman Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a net credit of $240,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting.

title: Pantera's Makes Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Pantera's Corporation, owner of the Pizza Inn restaurant chain since 1987, filed for protection last week under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. The filing came less than a week after its two largest lenders, Kleinwort Benson Ltd. and Lloyds Bank P.L.C., unexpectedly called in $35.5 million in secured loans made to finance the pizza chain's acquisition.

title: Economists Are Optimistic
description: The economy will continue to grow through 1990, forestalling a recession until at least 1991, top business economists said today.

title: Bass's Son Tries to Recover Historical Film From Russia
description: It was shot as a home movie in the 1930's, with haphazard scenes from the life in exile of the great Russian bass Fyodor Chaliapin eventually spliced together by his family into a 16-millimeter black-and-white film that lasts under 20 minutes.

title: Major Study Aims to Learn Who Should Lower Cholesterol
description: AFTER years of advising many Americans to lower their blood cholesterol levels to prevent heart attacks, Federal health officials are about to begin a major study to determine whether that advice holds true for women, and the elderly of both sexes. Women make up the bulk of the population and the elderly suffer the vast majority of heart attacks.

title: With September's Rains Come Baby Showers
description: ''Teeming autumn, big with rich increase,'' is what Shakespeare called it. At maternity wards all over the country, it's called chaos.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday about the Japanese department store chain Mitsukoshi Ltd. misstated its sales. For the 1988 fiscal year they totaled 643.4 billion ($5.0 billion), and for the 1989 fiscal year 712.6 billion ($5.6 billion). Figures are calculated at the conversion rates for the end of each February, the last month of the fiscal year.

title: I.B.M. Sets Joint Deal in Automation
description: Two of the nation's most influential makers of machinery and production systems for the global electronics industry, Texas Instruments Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation, said today that they would seek contracts to automate large factory operations together.

title: Securities Bill Advances
description: The House of Representatives passed a bill today to increase cooperation between the Securities and Exchange Commission and foreign agencies in investigations of insider trading and other securities fraud. The bill gives the S.E.C. authority to make sure records from foreign securities agencies get confidential treatment and to disclose information involving foreign authorities. The bill was passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate.

title: 76ers Sign Payne
description: The Philadelphia 76ers signed their first-round draft choice, Kenny Payne, to a five-year contract. The 6-foot-8 Payne, drafted 19th over all, was Louisville's second leading scorer behind Pervis Ellison with 14.5 points and 5.7 rebounds a game. (AP)

title: Canonie Environmental Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Howard B. Wolf Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Avery International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
5-Year Probation
description: Southeastern Louisiana University's dormant men's program was placed on a five-year probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday for recruiting violations. The school has scuttled its program for 1989-90 because of budget problems. No players can be signed during this academic year and only seven basketball scholarships can be given for 1990-91.(AP)

title: NEC Shows Color Laptop Computer
description: The NEC Corporation introduced what it said was the first color laptop computer available in the United States. The company said it expects to start shipping the laptop, the Prospeed CSX, in mid-October. It will retail for $8,499 to $9,499, depending upon storage capacity.

title: Food Lion Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: The company said the third quarter pretax provision for LIFO was $5,100,000, compared with $750,000 a year-ago. The 9 months pretax LIFO provision was $15,259,000, compared with $6,250,000 a year-earlier.

title: Business and Health; Damage Control On Contact Lens
description: THE contact lens industry's chances of reaching $1 billion in sales next year may have been set back by research showing that the risk of contracting serious illnesses increases if the lenses are worn overnight.

title: Giuliani Has Taunt for Dinkins: He's a 'Jesse Jackson Democrat'
description: Responding to his opponent's repeated taunt that he is a ''Ronald Reagan Republican,'' Rudolph W. Giuliani said after an appearance at an Orthodox Jewish private school yesterday that he could just as easily call David N. Dinkins a ''Jesse Jackson Democrat.''

title: Dinkins Gaining Support Among Business Executives
description: New York City's business community, without an incumbent mayor to support for the first time in 16 years, is largely following the public-opinion polls and finding a familiar face in David N. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee.

title: Interest Widens in Bid To Buy Bloomingdale's
description: Marvin S. Traub, the chairman and chief executive officer of Bloomingdale's, has received expressions of substantial interest from foreign retailers and other investors in his quest to buy the chain he has worked for for almost 40 years.

title: T.A.C. Plans For Inquiries
description: Officials of The Athletics Congress met with attorneys for nearly six hours yesterday in Manhattan to discuss the means by which T.A.C. will investigate current and future accusations of the use of performance-enhancing drugs by United States track and field athletes.

title: Mr. Bush's Modest Momentum
description: President Bush, the man who once yearned for the political momentum he called ''big mo,'' yesterday generated some diplomatic momentum toward arms control. There's somewhat less than meets the eye in his proposal before the United Nations to speed destruction of U.S. chemical weapons. But it could nevertheless improve the climate for control of these horrifying weapons.

title: Gold and Platinum Rise; Silver Off on Profit Taking
description: Prices of gold bullion advanced yesterday, buoyed by the sharp drop in the dollar's value against major foreign currencies and, to a far lesser extent, weakness in the domestic stock and bond markets. While platinum prices rose with gold, many silver traders decided to take profits.

title: Friends and Colleagues Remember Sidney Hook
description: Friends, colleagues and admirers assembled at New York University yesterday to commemorate Sidney Hook, the philosopher, author and social critic who died on July 12 at the age of 86.

title: Studies Confirm Cholesterol-Heart Attack Link; The Fault in the Milk
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Investor's Daily Entering Texas
description: Investor's Daily, a national business newspaper, reached an agreement today to be printed and distributed in Texas by The Dallas Times Herald.

title: Midtown Steam Pipe Bursts; Asbestos Is Released
description: An asbestos-lined steam pipe exploded under a sidewalk in midtown Manhattan early yesterday, sending a column of steam 300 feet into the air and spraying a block of East 40th Street and part of Madison Avenue with mud and debris, some of it contaminated with high levels of asbestos.

title: Notebook; Bills Rely on Revitalized Offense
description: Back in August in the Hall of Fame game in Canton, Ohio, after the Buffalo Bills had been dominated by the Washington Redskins, 31-6, many believed the sputtering and boring Bills' offense of 1988 had returned for an encore. Too much reliance on the run, too little variety in play calling and no featured deep-passing threat meant the Bills would be doomed to be, at best, only a playoff team.

title: Chandler Out of Action
description: The Indianapolis Colts' quarterback Chris Chandler will undergo surgery for a torn knee ligament next week and is likely to miss the entire season, but the All-Pro running back Eric Dickerson hopes to play Sunday against the Jets at the Meadowlands.

title: Companies Step In Where the Schools Fail
description: At the huge Motorola Inc. plant here, assembly line workers like Carritha Wells are being paid to learn not about electronic circuit boards or cellular telephones but about how much a pound of grapes would cost if 2Z pounds cost $3.25.

title: Giants' DeOssie Will Be Out With a Broken Toe
description: For the Giants, it was another victory and another bad injury to the defense.

title: For Education: National Strategy, Local Control
description: LEAD: The education summit meeting that convenes tomorrow in Charlottesville, Va., marks a historic moment for American education. This bold initiative could not be more timely.

title: Phillies Eliminate The Mets
description: Realistically, the Mets were eliminated from the pennant race days ago. Mathematically, they were finally eliminated last night.

title: Doctor Discloses Hinckley Suicide Try in '83
description: A psychiatrist treating John W. Hinckley Jr. disclosed today that the Presidential assailant tried to kill himself in 1983 and still suffers from severe mental illness that makes him highly dangerous.

title: Quayle Tries to Quiet Japan's Trade Concerns
description: Rushing through a series of meetings with Japan's leadership, Vice President Dan Quayle brought a message of cooperation and reconciliation to America's biggest economic rival today, declaring that the United States' alliance with Japan should not be overshadowed by trade disputes.

title: Deal for H.M.S.S.
description: SecoAmerica Inc., a diversified services company that is the American arm of the Secom Company Ltd. of Japan, signed a definitive agreement to acquire H.M.S.S. for $50 a share, or $250 million, and said it would commence a tender offer later this week for the home health-care services company. H.M.S.S.'s shares soared $14.125 today, to $48.875, in over-the-counter trading. Its gain of 40.7 percent was the highest of the day.

title: Quebec, Rejecting Separatists, Re-elects Liberals
description: Quebec citizens voted decisively today to re-elect the Liberal Government of Premier Robert Bourassa, again rejecting the separatist Parti Quebecois.

title: NASA Ends Unmanned Launchings in Florida; Shuttle Damaged
description: After more than 400 liftoffs, NASA today launched an unmanned rocket, the last one it will loft into space here.

title: Laurence Felmus, 82, Professor of Obstetrics
description: Dr. Laurence B. Felmus, a retired clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology and a founding member of the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of pancreatic cancer Sept. 12 in Scottsdale, Ariz., where he had lived in retirement since 1968. He was 82 years old.

title: Looting on St. Croix Linked to Island's Tensions
description: As food and other relief supplies poured into St. Croix today, residents and Federal officials began asking why, of a dozen Caribbean islands devastated by a hurricane last week, only one erupted in widespread violence and looting.

title: Strikers Act at Peugeot
description: Strikers at a Peugeot S.A. plant in Mulhouse in eastern France occupied one of its two foundries this morning, a company spokesman said. The foundry produces components including pistons, but the plant had sufficient stocks to continue working, he added. It was producing about 50 cars an hour this morning compared with the usual capacity of 80 an hour. Some 650 workers were still on strike today at Mulhouse with another 400 absent. The work force totals 12,000.

title: Park Electrochemical reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Before special income of $792,000, or 15 cents a share, due to SFAS 96 adoption.

title: Bridge
description: Six members of the United States women's team faced major difficulties Sunday in leaving this city because a strike by pilots on Australian domestic lines meant that some of them had to sit about waiting for a plane that might never depart. But they were all euphoric in the glow of victory.

title: Tree Planted by President Vandalized in Spokane Park
description: A tree planted by President Bush in Riverfront Park last week has been vandalized and is probably unsalvageable, officials said today.

title: If O'Brien Is Hitting His Stride, It's Timely
description: The Jets don't face the Miami Dolphins again until Nov. 12, but Ken O'Brien can't wait that long to prove his revival is real.

title: Coping in Hugo's Aftermath
description: Charleston, S.C.: Chilly, heavy rain has impeded relief efforts, slowing work on restoring electricity, although electrical service was restored to hospitals. The city remained patrolled by the National guard to prevent looting. A curfew remained in force. Sumter, S.C.: This community 180 miles from the coast remained without food, water and electrical power. Myrtle Beach, S.C.: With a curfew still in effect, storm-struck beaches here were still barred to residents because of contamination from seeping sewage. Garden City, S.C.: This exclusive resort in the Grand Strand area of the South Carolina coast remained barred to residents by the National Guard, but some looting was reported. Isle of Palms, S.C.: Residents of this off-shore barrier island returned briefly by ferries after being evacuated before the storm, which smashed houses and swept aside a bridge link to the mainland. Moncks Corner, S.C.: Power was being returned to this town, though ruyral areas outside it may be without electricity up to three weeks. Florence, S.C.: About 65 percent of the electrical power has been restored in Florence County, which indludes this city in the eastern part of the state, but it may be up to a week before most of the rural areas will regain power. Charlotte, N.C.: Life is still extensively disrupted in the largest city in the state, which has about 375,000 residents. The city returned to work with its traffic lights extensively disrupted, and about half its residents were still without electricity. Statesville, N.C: This community of 30,000 residents was hard hit by winds exceeding 60 miles an hour. There were no deaths. A partial shutdown of electricity has continued. Oak Island, N.C.: A cluster of three villages on this island suffered an estimated $36 million damage when the hurricane slammed them with a tidal surge. There were no casualties since all residents had been evacuated before the arrival of the surge. National Guard personnel maintained round-the-clock watch to forestall looting. Holden Beach, N.C.: This small beach community, also on an off-shore barrier island, suffered damage estimated at $30 million, but also had no casualties since its few hundred residents were evacuated before the tidal surge struck. Ocean Isle, N.C.: This barrier island suffered $20 million in damage, mainly from the tidal surge, but no casualties because of evacuation. Bald Head Village, N.C.: This community on a small island, located about 2 1/2 miles off of the mainland of North Carolina, was completely flooded by the tidal surge. Pumps have been sent here to siphon water off roadways.

title: Q&A
description: Fried Fish Q.Why don't fish suffer from the high pressures deep in the ocean? And what prevents fish from being electrocuted when lightning strikes? A.All fish have internal pressures that are equal to the pressures outside their bodies at their normal depths, said Edward Brinton, a research biologist at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California at San Diego. This is true of both tissues and the gas-filled bladders in the abdominal cavity that many fish have, he said.

title: Valley Federal Savings Bank (Ind) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Morrison Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
Charlotte Closes Its Schools In the Slow Work of Recovery
description: More than half of this city of 373,000 people was without electricity today as heavy rains slowed efforts to repair power lines and houses damaged by a weakened Hurricane Hugo.

title: PHP Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results included an extraordinary expense equaled to 20 cents a share to cover settlement of a lawsuit.

title: UTL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $203,839 for the quarter for a change in an estimate of costs related to sold real estate, and an extraordinary tax credit of $343,698, or 8 cents a share, for the year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,896,744 for the quarter related to early retirement of debt, and an extraordinary credit of $3,178,441, or 75 cents a share, for the year, from the early retirement of debt.

title: U.S. Seeks Information On UAL Buyout Plans
description: The Transportation Department, expressing concern about the role of foreign companies in the acquisitions of United States airlines, said yesterday that it had asked United Airlines for information about a proposed $6.75 billion buyout of its parent, the UAL Corporation, by management, employees and British Airways.

title: Surge in Resources For I.M.F. Forecast; East-Bloc Role Seen
description: The member nations of the International Monetary Fund are likely to agree by the end of the year to increase the fund's resources by as much as 67 percent, or $80 billion, officials said today.

title: Ben Ward, Professional Cop
description: Benjamin Ward had plenty of critics. At times he seemed to go out of his way to encourage them. But in nearly six years as New York City's Police Commissioner, Mr. Ward, who announced his resignation yesterday, built a record of admirable law enforcement leadership.

title: WSMP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 11
description: b-Included a one-time gain on the disposal of assets of approximately $805,000, net of income taxes, or 33 cents a share. The company declared a regular quarterly dividend of 4 cents a share, payable Oct. 27, 1989, to shareholders of record on Oct. 13, 1989.

title: Ethics Attacks Heat Courter-Florio Debate
description: In a biting exchange of attacks and counter-attacks, the two major candidates for governor of New Jersey tonight charged each other with ethical lapses and portrayed one another as ideological outsiders in this moderate suburban state.

title: H.E.R.O.  Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The results are in Canadian funds. The company said the favorable effect on earnings of increased sales, reduced interest costs, and a lower tax rate were largely offset by the adverse impact of exchange rate movements and increased cost of sales.

title: Giuliani Has Taunt for Dinkins: He's a 'Jesse Jackson Democrat'
description: Responding to his opponent's repeated taunt that he is a ''Ronald Reagan Republican,'' Rudolph W. Giuliani said after an appearance at an Orthodox Jewish private school yesterday that he could just as easily call David N. Dinkins a ''Jesse Jackson Democrat.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an investigation of two fatal stabbings in Mercer County, N.J., described one slaying incompletely. The victim, an art teacher and swimming coach at the Hun School in Princeton, was killed in a parking lot in Hamilton Township, not at the school.

title: Commissioner on Agenda
description: The National Football League said today its club owners would meet Oct. 10 in either Chicago or Dallas to attempt to elect a new commissioner.

title: Surgery for Ellison
description: Pervis Ellison, picked No. 1 over all by the Sacramento Kings in last June's National Basketball Association draft, will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow to remove bone spurs from his right foot and ankle.

title: HOUSE PANEL TOLD PIERCE IS UNREADY
description: Lawyers for Samuel R. Pierce Jr. warned Congress today that the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development would not be prepared for a scheduled Tuesday hearing in the House, leaving Mr. Pierce with ''unpleasant options.''

title: Market Place; Buyers Wanted For 'Junk Bonds'
description: DEALERS in the battered ''junk bond'' market are preparing for offerings of more than $800 million in new securities this week, and with some traditional investors backing away from the market, Wall Street brokers are working to find new buyers, even among individual investors.

title: Krone and Bravo Suspended for Fight
description: The Meadowlands Race Track stewards last night suspended the jockey Julie Krone for 15 days and the jockey Joe Bravo for 5 days for ''unsportsmanlike conduct'' as a result of their fight after the seventh race Saturday night. Krone and Bravo exchanged punches after Krone accused Bravo of repeatedly interfering with her mount during the race. The two jockeys had hit each others' horses with their whips deliberately, according to the stewards.

title: Careers; Updating The Training Of M.B.A.'s
description: GRADUATE schools of business have been struggling with change in recent years. Their administrators face problems such as how to make courses more globally oriented, what to do about foreign languages, and how to instill values like leadership and creativity in students.

title: Updating a Hard Disk
description: SHE had a disk problem, and she didn't want a chiropractor. She wanted me.

title: Review/Music; A Second Arrangement For 'Arias and Barcarolles'
description: Leonard Bernstein's new song cycle, ''Arias and Barcarolles,'' had its second local performance with the New York Chamber Symphony under Gerard Schwarz. The first, earlier this month, used Mr. Bernstein's original scoring for piano-duet accompaniment. Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y, we heard an arrangement for strings and percussion by Bright Sheng.

title: Stanley Vogel, 71; Founded Casual Corner
description: Stanley W. Vogel, a retired businessman and co-founder of a chain of 800 Casual Corner clothing stores, died Saturday at the Wintonbury Continuing Care center in Bloomfield, Conn. He was 71 years old and suffered a stroke in June.

title: Golden Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Cubs, Giants Lose but Clinch Ties
description: The Chicago Cubs missed a chance to clinch a tie for the National League East championship tonight when a Montreal pinch-hitter, Jim Dwyer, singled with one out in the 10th inning to give the Expos a 4-3 victory.

title: Ward Resigns, Citing Problem With Asthma
description: Benjamin Ward resigned yesterday as Police Commissioner after a tumultuous six-year tenure in which he increased the numbers of minorities and women on the force, raised educational standards for officers and tried to battle an explosion in drug-related crime.

title: Review/Art; Examining the Role of the Blues
description: ''The Blues Esthetic: Black Culture and Modernism,'' which is on view at the Washington Project for the Arts through Dec. 9, is a celebration of black culture and an attempt to define Afro-American art. Its strength is its ability to demonstrate that the blues has played a key role in the art of many black Americans and that it has been a source of fascination and inspiration for many other modern artists.

title: Tanker Runs Aground in Gulf
description: A tanker loaded with 21.6 million gallons of crude oil from Venezuela ran aground early today in the Gulf of Mexico near an approach to the Mississippi River. ''There's no leak or anything,'' said Chief Petty Officer Michael Robling of the Coast Guard. ''It's aground in the mud and sand down there.'' He said the tanker, the Universal Monarch, radioed the Coast Guard about 1:30 A.M. that she had run aground. The ship is registered in Panama, Mr. Robling said.

title: Rentown Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Neoterik Health Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Hooker Corp. Receivables
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation will purchase $75 million of certain receivables of the L.J. Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer that owns the Bonwit Teller and B. Altman department stores. Hooker, which had filed in

title: Blue Jays Trying to Avoid Panic
description: It was over a span of days in late July that the Blue Jays began to sense the phenomenon. Balls that had never made it to the outfield walls of the recently occupied Skydome were now carrying over them. Home runs consequently abounded, and thus so too did an entire range of speculation, theories embracing metaphysics as well as meteorology.

title: Carolina Freight Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Drops 22.42
description: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday on the heels of a steep decline in the dollar and in bond prices.

title: LTX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and the year is after an extraordinary tax credit of $810,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: James H. Porterfield, Former Executive, 79
description: James H. Porterfield, a retired public relations executive, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Fort Meyers, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Heavy Rains Delay the Vast Cleanup in the South
description: Four days after a hurricane smashed into the coast here, driving winds and rain dumped misery upon misery, hampering cleanup efforts from Georgia to North Carolina.

title: Plexus Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Suspects in Park Attack Said to Be Giving Details
description: Lawyers for five of the six defendants accused of raping a jogger in Central Park in April expressed unhappiness yesterday with a published report on statements reportedly made by their clients to prosecutors shortly after the attack.

title: 3 Top Officers Are Quitting Suzuki Unit
description: Plagued by poor sales of its cars and continuing doubts among drivers about the safety of its Samurai sport-utility vehicle, the American Suzuki Motor Corporation announced a management shake-up today. Four top executives are being transferred or have resigned.

title: 13 Justices Nominated, As Leaders Rule Roost
description: New York City Democratic leaders, exercising one of their few remaining prerogatives, quietly ''made'' 13 new State Supreme Court justices in the last week.

title: Neutralizing Poison Gas
description: In reaffirming American support for a chemical weapons ban from a United Nations podium yesterday, President Bush rejected recommendations by the American military and calls by conservatives that he back away from a treaty banning poison gas.

title: Rowe Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Share earnings and average shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split effective April 13, 1989. Year-ago quarter and 9 months' results ended Aug. 31.

title: Dollar Falls As Central Banks Act
description: The dollar dropped sharply today after the United States and its economic allies sent a strong message that they wanted a decline.

title: 65 Senators Urge Baker to Deny Arafat a Visa
description: More than 65 senators have signed a letter urging the Bush Administration to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat if he seeks permission to come to the United States to address the United Nations.

title: Whittier Journal; '87 Quake Still Stirs A City's Fears
description: Two years after an earthquake devastated this southern Californian city, Shirley Campbell is still waiting to put her good china back in the glass cabinet in her dining room.

title: Ali Hafid, Drummer In 'Zorba,' Dies at 54
description: Ali Hafid, a Moroccan drummer whose onstage performances in the Broadway musical ''Zorba'' enhanced his popularity, died of lung cancer Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pennington's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Indonesia Takes Steps to Protect Rain Forests
description: Moments after a helicopter lifts off from a forest base camp northwest of here, the scars of development appear among the tumultuous greens of the tropical rain forest: the felled trees, the bulldozers, the bright orange mud of the logging roads, the smudges of smoke alongside, where slash-and-burn farmers have followed the loggers in.

title: What Fate for Remains of a Library's Irreplaceable Collection?; Corporations Favored
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Bush Hold the Conservatives?
description: LEAD: With a now forgotten speech to a 1985 Washington dinner in honor of Nackey Loeb, widow and successor of William Loeb, New Hampshire's controversial right-wing publisher, George Bush launched his strategy to consolidate conservative support behind his Presidential bid. Mr. Bush had been attacked fiercely in the 1980 primary by William Loeb and was never the favorite in any case of Republican conservatives; his move was seen as political slumming in Washington.

title: Glamis Gold Ltd reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Osicom Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Saber-Tooth Social Life: Primeval Compassion
description: WHEN Fred P. Heald looks into a tray of bits of bone, chocolate brown with the asphalt that has permeated them for tens of thousands of years, he sees packs of saber-toothed cats on the prowl in a violent world but relating to one another with remarkable benevolence.

title: Ban on Antley Continues
description: The Belmont Park stewards announced yesterday that they would continue to refuse to allow Chris Antley to ride, pending the completion of an inquiry by the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: House Passes Phone Measure
description: The House of Representatives passed a bill today to require independent long-distance telephone companies to identify themselves and disclose their rates to callers.

title: Social Security No Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: East German Leader, Long Absent, Reappears
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, reappeared in public today, more than five weeks after undergoing gall-bladder surgery. But the pressures on his Government continued to mount with the growing strength of a fledgling movement that seeks political change.

title: Clean Harbors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Excerpts From Bush's Speech at the Opening of the U.N. General Assembly
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address yesterday to the United Nations General Assembly, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Bees and 'Yellow Rain': A New Explanation
description: GIANT Asian honeybees go on mass defecation flights to keep cool, researchers have reported, in what may be an explanation for ''yellow rain,'' which the United States Government once called a Soviet biological weapon.

title: Connecticut Lotto to Expand
description: The State Gaming Policy Board, as expected, today approved an expansion of the state's lotto game to 44 numbers, and lottery officials immediately began a promotion of the new game. The lotto game, in which players pick six numbers from 40, will expand to 44 numbers Saturday. Lottery officials have said they hope the new game, with its longer odds, will pay off bigger grand jackpots and attract more bettors to reverse slumping ticket sales.

title: Review/Music; Straining Out the Religion
description: The double bill at Town Hall on Friday night, featuring Milton Cardona and his group, Eye Aranla, and Frisner Augustin and his group, La Troupe Makandal, brought up a handful of issues about the meeting of different cultures. Labeled ''Music of the Spirits,'' the performances, with David Byrne of Talking Heads as host, drew from the Santeria and voodoo religious traditions that were imported to Puerto Rico and Haiti from West Africa. The music, wrenched from its religious function, was obviously presented with an audience of nonparticipants in mind - nonparticipants who might not have been there without the pull of Mr. Byrne's name.

title: Mack Has Surgery
description: The Cleveland Browns' fullback, Kevin Mack, underwent surgery for torn cartilage in his left knee yesterday at the Cleveland Clinic and is expected to remain out of action until the Browns' game with Pittsburgh on Oct. 15, a Browns spokesman said. Mack missed the first three games because of an N.F.L. suspension imposed after he pleaded guilty to a cocaine charge this summer.(AP)

title: Wiggins Is Signed
description: Mitchell Wiggins, recently reinstated after a ban because of a drug violation, agreed to a one-year contract with the Houston Rockets for a reported $250,000.

title: Radyne Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: 2 Killed and 1 Wounded by Bomb At Hotel in Colombian Resort City
description: A bomb exploded tonight in the Cartagena Hilton Hotel on the Caribbean, killing two doctors and wounding another, the chief of the police in that coastal resort said.

title: United Illuminating Co reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $188,786,768 from a change in accounting principle resulting from the adoption of SFAS 90. c-Net income and after a gain of $2,681,280, or 19 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment resulting from the adoption of SFAS 90.

title: Patterns
description: Keiko Eclipsed

title: G.M. to Start '90 Model Year By Offering Large Discounts
description: In a surprising move intended to forestall a drop in retail sales and to spur its dealers to stock cars more aggressively, the General Motors Corporation today applied substantial discounts to its 1990 car and truck lines through cash rebates and subsidized financing.

title: Bush Finds One Israeli Is Never Enough
description: President Bush got caught in the crosswinds of Israeli politics yesterday.

title: New Board Chooses Head for Falconbridge
description: Falconbridge Ltd., a big Canadian mining company recently taken over by Noranda Inc. and Trelleborg A.B., will be headed by Alex G. Balogh, a seasoned Noranda mining executive.

title: Report Finds Energy Department Liable for Nuclear Plant Penalties
description: An Energy Department report on contracts with the companies that run its troubled bomb plants shows that the Government is liable for criminal fines levied against the companies by state or other Federal agencies.

title: Review/Music; In Pete Seeger's Tradition
description: Although contemporary folk music that perpetuates the left-wing populism of Pete Seeger is much less abundant today than in the 1960's, that tradition is far from extinct. Bright Morning Star, a versatile New England-based sextet, and the Washington Sisters, a folk duo from Columbus, Ohio, who appeared at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening in the Voices of Change festival, are both relatively youthful acts for whom music and liberal politics are virtually inseparable.

title: Management Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Case For Slavery
description: Across the country, a scattered but influential collection of intellectuals is intensely engaged in making the case for slavery.

title: Studies Confirm Cholesterol-Heart Attack Link
description: To the Editor:

title: The Latest for Desktop Publishers
description: THE Seybold Computer Publishing Conference, which drew thousands of graphics arts and publishing professionals to San Francisco last week, often shows expensive and esoteric technology for producing newspapers, magazines, advertisements, and other complex documents. But, this year's exposition featured some hardware and software products for casual desktop publishers.

title: Eagle Telephonics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included losses of $169,000 for the quarter and $49,000 for the 9 months, both for inventory writeoffs and other non-recurring items.

title: Data Translation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Oil-Dri Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Polish Foreign Minister Pledges No Withdrawal From Warsaw Pact
description: In his first major foreign policy address, the Foreign Minister of Poland said today that his country ''has no intention of destabilizing the existing international order.'' Diplomats said the remark by Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski meant that Poland would not leave the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet-led European Communist military alliance.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Worthington Foods Inc. to Partners & Shevack for its Morningstar Farms line of cholesterol-free products, with a budget of $2 million to $5 million.

title: Insituform East Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Express International Corp., Darien, Conn., an air freight concern, named Dennis M. Dolan vice president and chief financial officer.

title: China Factories Ordered Closed
description: China's top leader, Deng Xiaoping, has ordered some rural factories to be closed because they use resources that should go to state companies, the official Economic Information newspaper said today.

title: Seaman and Its Lenders Reach Pact
description: The Seaman Furniture Company, the nation's second-largest furniture retailer, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with its senior lenders that would allow it to reorganize its debt.

title: PRISON RELEASES A DEFIANT MOTHER
description: A mother imprisoned for 25 months for defying a court order in a child custody case drove out of the District of Columbia jail tonight, stopping briefly to tell reporters and supporters that she was ''happy and very grateful'' that her confinement was over.

title: Chess-Playing Computer Closing In on Champions
description: THE time when a computer wrests the world chess championship from a human being may be approaching. Last Thanksgiving, Deep Thought, which won the world computer chess championship in May, defeated a human grandmaster, Bent Larsen of Denmark, who is ranked 96th among all chess players in the world. And just recently, this same computer defeated another grandmaster - me.

title: Witness Describes PTL Deal
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell offered Jim Bakker $300,000 and other benefits to remain silent after Mr. Falwell took over the PTL ministry, the chief builder of the ministry's Heritage USA theme park testified today.

title: Steinhardt Reports Bag Maker Stake
description: The New York investor Michael H. Steinhardt has acquired a 5.06 percent stake in the American Western Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Steinhardt said that he had acquired the American Western shares for investment purposes but might consider seeking control of the company.

title: Car Sales in Mid-September Surged Forward by 10.2%
description: Sales of cars built in the United States surged by 10.2 percent in mid-September, as buyers continued to buy 1989 models to beat price increases for the 1990 model year.

title: Bright Future Predicted For Hispanic Citizens
description: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos has been too pessimistic about the condition of Hispanics in the United States, Linda Chavez, a former staff director of the Civil Rights Commission declared in Congressional testimony today.

title: Light-Sensitive Chemicals Join Arsenal of Anti-Cancer Weapons
description: WHERE chemotherapy and surgery have failed, doctors surgeons are increasingly turning to an unusual new weapon in the treatment of cancer: red light.

title: For the Children, Colombia, Is a Very Scary Place to Be
description: Perched on a school sofa, her white socks and black shoes swinging a few inches from the floor, Catalina, who is 11 years old, remembers setting out with her mother on a recent Saturday to buy a birthday present.

title: Arizona Holiday for Dr. King May Face Ballot Test in 1990
description: A new law in Arizona establishing a holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was challenged today. Opponents who filed papers with the Secretary of State's office were trying to force a statewide vote on the issue.

title: John E. Hunt, 79, Ex-Jersey Congressman
description: John E. Hunt, a Republican who lost his seat in the House of Representatives to James J. Florio in 1974, died Friday at Underwood-Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Pitman, N.J. He was hospitalized two weeks ago for treatment of a heart condition.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a caption yesterday about an organic food fair in Maine misstated its location. It was in Windsor - not Augusta, nine miles to the wes

title: Dalai Lama Meets Jews From 4 Major Branches
description: An unusual Buddhist-Jewish dialogue took place here today between the Dalai Lama, a major spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, and a group of six Jewish scholars.

title: Railroad Power Cut in Bronx
description: Power was cut off in a Bronx section of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad for 35 minutes yesterday evening as the police searched the tracks for a gun used in a shootout. No weapon was found while the power was off along Park Avenue from East 169th to East 170th Street. The shooting, in which one man received arm and shoulder wounds, occurred in a nearby lobby on Webster Avenue as two men argued over a woman, said a police spokesman, Officer Edward Feeney. One of the men, Anthony Idolman, 36 years old, of 3240 Bailey Avenue in the Bronx, was arrested, Officer Feeney said.

title: 2 Drown in Floods After Florida Downpour
description: A daylong downpour left 30 city blocks with up to 10 feet of water. Two people drowned in their cars, the authorities said today.

title: Smart as a Sea Otter
description: ALASKAN sea otters apparently know how to tell whether butter clams, their favorite food, are contaminated with the paralyzing poisons that make up red tide.

title: Temple Plans Bid
description: Temple Holdings Ltd. said it planned a proxy fight for control of the board of Sea Containers Ltd. Temple has offered to acquire Sea Containers for $63 a share in cash, or $1.03 billion, but the Bermuda-based ferry and cargo concern has rejected the offer as inadequate.

title: Young Koreans See U.S. as Dividing Their Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Herman Malamood, City Opera Tenor, 57
description: Herman Malamood, a New York City Opera tenor who also sang at the Metropolitan Opera and major European houses and had an active career as a cantor, died of cancer Saturday at his Manhattan home. He was 57 years old.

title: Stroh Brewing to Sell Major Brands to Coors
description: LEAD: The long-term trend toward consolidation in the American beer industry continued yesterday as the family-owned Stroh Brewing Company of Detroit agreed to sell most of its brands and breweries to the Adolph Coors Company for $425 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: Rock Artists Protest Near White House
description: Rock-and-roll and rap musicians rallied across the street from the White House today to protest what they said were efforts to censor their music.

title: Partisan Battle Over the Federal Budget Heats Up
description: The war of words between the Bush Administration and Congressional Democrats intensified today as the House of Representatives moved toward consideration of a tax and budget package that has become a critical test for the new Democratic leadership.

title: Classical Composers Are in the Spotlight of Films
description: To the rhythm of agitated, driving music, images race by on a television screen: a horse-drawn carriage; a smiling little boy in a powdered wig; a terrified young man at a desk; lightning; a black-hooded figure; flames.

title: The Orient Express, a Train With a Past
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Sick Man Waits
description: June and Frank, a poor elderly couple I know in West Philadelphia, don't follow Congressional debates. But this week, their lives may be drastically affected. The House will decide the fate of the catastrophic-health insurance program. Plagued by cost overruns and a revolt of upper-income families who pay a disproportionate share of the expense, the program may be repealed. Even if it's not, Congress will trim coverage and raise premiums.

title: Hungarian Serenade: Wooing Voters and the West
description: The Communist leadership is casting about for ways out of Hungary's deep political and economic predicaments that will appeal to two critical quarters: the West and the Hungarian electorate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Public Relations Award
description: The widespread scare over tampering with Tylenol pills in 1982 and 1986 posed the ultimate corporate public relations challenge. Lawrence G. Foster, the vice president for public relations who managed Johnson & Johnson's response to those crises, was awarded the 1989 Gold Anvil Award of the Public Relations Society of America last week.

title: Rivalry in '92 Barcelona Olympics Starts Early
description: Hard-working, prosperous and deeply proud of their Catalan language and culture, the people of Barcelona make no secret of their belief that their city's selection as the site for the 1992 Olympic Games is further proof that they are just a touch superior to other Spaniards.

title: Tiffany's Lure for Japanese Retailer
description: The five models stepped down the runway in Giorgio Armani fashions, swaying to a rock beat, but they finished with a telling flourish: Arrayed around the three-story corporate symbol of the Japanese retailing giant Mitsukoshi, the women dropped their poses and bowed humbly to the audience.

title: Helene Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shares outstanding and share earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 1, 1989.

title: Migrant Job Program Baffles Mexico
description: A new United States immigration program, aimed at preventing potential labor shortages in American agriculture over the next four years, is causing confusion and controversy throughout Mexico, which is expected to supply most of the workers for the plan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I only regret that the people of New York may not understand as keenly as I do the extraordinary contribution you have made to upholding the law in this city.'' -Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, in his letter of resignation to Mayor Edward I. Koch. [ B4:3. ]

title: Yogi Says It's Over On the Field
description: Yogi Berra announced today that he was getting out of uniform after a career as a star catcher, a manager and a coach going back to 1946.

title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash
description: The Queens District Attorney announced yesterday that evidence on last week's fatal crash of a USAir jetliner at La Guardia Airport would be presented soon to a grand jury, raising the possibility of criminal charges against the cockpit crew.

title: Our Towns; A Price of Color Is Turning Down A Dream House
description: Funny how the same 80-by-100-foot lot can look so different to two people.

title: American Recreation Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Revenue represented operating revenue. American Recreation's improvement in it results included gains on the sale of assets and reductions in corporate expenses and non-consolidated operating losses.

title: U.N. Says Billions Are in Poor Health
description: One billion people around the world are in poor health, malnourished or suffering with diseases ranging from malaria and river blindness to AIDS, the World Health Organization said Sunday.

title: Venezuela Eases Stance On Its Debts
description: Trying to revive negotiations with commercial banks, the Government of Venezuela is dropping its demands for 50 percent debt reduction and offering other proposals it believes will be more acceptable to the banks.

title: Oxford Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
Digital Equipment Demonstrates Chip Packaging
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation demonstrated technical breakthroughs today that it said would allow the packaging of multiple computer chips at densities up to 30 times greater than is possible with current printed circuit board technology. Higher densities reduce the time a signal takes to travel between chips.

title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4
description: A 15-year-old boy has been sentenced to six years in the Rhode Island Training School after pleading guilty to killing four neighbors, three of them over the Labor Day weekend, the other in 1987, when he was 13.

title: John Frederick Ecker, Stockbroker, 58
description: John Frederick Ecker, a former stockbroker with the Laidlaw and Shields investment companies, both of Manhattan, died of cancer Thursday at McGuire's Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond. He was 58 years old and lived in Tappahannock, Va.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Antarctic Minerals Convention, a treaty governing the exploitation of mineral resources, misstated the views of Ray Arnaudo, director of the polar programs division of the National Science Foundation. He said that while Australia's decision against supporting the treaty was discouraging, the United States continues to support it. He said the convention was not on the agenda for the 15th Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting, to be held in Paris next month.

title: Hearty Lamb Dish For Fall's Debut
description: MY family loves lamb - roasted, grilled, sauteed or stewed. Often we roast or grill the leg, which is less expensive than the rack or chops. For braising and for stew we sometimes use the breast, a very inexpensive, moist and flavorful cut.

title: Lovers of Greaseless French Fries Take Note
description: DEEP frying is one of the trickier techiques for home cooks to master. When done incorrectly, it can result in sodden, heavy, indigestible food. Properly prepared, deep-fried food is light, brittle and greaseless.

title: John Koehler, 85, Former Federal Official
description: John T. Koehler, a former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and acting chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 85 years old.

title: CUSTODY STRUGGLE PRESSED IN CAPITAL
description: A newly freed Dr. Elizabeth Morgan and her former husband, Dr. Eric Foretich, played out the conflicting versions of their bitter dispute over the custody of their child before the national press today while related court proceedings remained on hold.

title: New Israeli Thicket; Mubarak's Plan for Palestinian Elections Propels Jerusalem Toward Coalition Crisis
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the rest of Israel's right wing are pleading, threatening and fighting to kill a peace plan offered by Egypt that every other interested party has enthusiastically embraced.

title: Presidential Safety, and the Public's
description: No New Yorker wishes the President anything but a safe visit when he comes to town. But no President ought to wish a day of annoyance, even danger, on a whole city for the sake of his security. George Bush's trip to New York this week to address the United Nations once again demonstrates the need to reassess procedures for such visits.

title: In Memory of a Son: Pension of $2 a Month
description: The family of Tran Van Thiep provides a reminder of the cost of the long Cambodian war to the Vietnamese.

title: Toys 'R' Us to Open Stores In Japan Within Two Years
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest chain of specialty toy stores, said yesterday that within two years it would open several stores in Japan, one of the most difficult markets for American companies to enter.

title: Court Bars Radja From Playing for the Celtics
description: Comparing the Celtics' signing of a Yugoslav player to poaching, a Federal judge in Boston issued a preliminary injunction yesterday that prohibits Dino Radja, a highly regarded 6-foot-10-inch forward, from playing for the Celtics.

title: George Patterson, 80, Ex-Pipeline Executive
description: George S. Patterson, former chairman and chief executive of the Buckeye Pipe Line Company in Manhattan and the Everglades Pipe Line Company in Port Everglades, Fla., died of pneumonia on Sunday at Bethesda Hospital in Gulfstream, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Gulfstream.

title: Drug Penalty for Nunn
description: Freddie Joe Nunn, 27, starting defensive end for the Cardinals, was suspended for 30 days by the National Football League yesterday for violating provisions of the league's substance-abuse policy. The Cardinals' general manager, Larry Wilson, said Nunn had entered a treatment center in the Phoenix area.(AP)

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Lauder's Lowered Voice
description: Ronald Lauder spent an astonishing $13 million while losing the recent Republican mayoral primary election in New York City. As the Conservative Party nominee, he now pledges to confine his spending in the general election to $1.5 million.

title: Ward Bids Farewell as 'a Cop's Cop'
description: Hoping he would be remembered as ''a policeman, a cop's cop,'' Benjamin Ward said his public farewell yesterday as New York Police Commissioner in much the same way that he seemed to have run his department for six years - with pride, concern, combativeness, emotion and an edge of humor.

title: Kosher Cooking: Goodbye Derman, Hello Sushi
description: SUNDOWN on Friday marks the beginning of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, when Jewish families across the nation will sit down, as Jewish families have for centuries, to traditional meals of roast chicken, tsimmes, beef flanken and kreplach soup.

title: Review/Television; The Long Fight for China, 40 Years After It Ended
description: Linking fascinating newsreels to remarkable interviews with participants on both sides of China's long civil war, ''China in Revolution, 1911-1949'' makes an absorbing two hours of history. This admirable documentary, produced by Sue Williams and Kathryn Dietz and being shown tonight at 9 o'clock on Channels 13 and 49, is public broadcasting's observation of the 40th anniversary of the formation of the People's Republic of China.

title: General Obligation Bonds Priced by New York City
description: New York City yesterday tentatively priced $700 million in general obligation bonds through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
