title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the new Goh Annex of the phillips Collection in Washington misstated financial help provided by two banks and two foundations. They are paying for the opening ceremonies, not for the annex, which was financed by other donations from foundations and individuals.

title: 11 Suspensions End
description: The N.F.L. yesterday reinstated 11 players suspended in the preseason after testing positive for steroid use: Sean Docter, Tom Docter and Matt Jaworski of Buffalo; Maurice Douglas of Chicago, Keith Uecker of Green Bay, Mark Mraz of the Los Angeles Raiders, Vince Amoia and Bobby Riley of the Jets, Ron Solt of Philadelphia and Keith Henderson and Rollin Putzier of San Francisco.

title: Rosh ha-Shanah Journey To Hasidic Master's Tomb
description: Shortly before his death in 1811, Rabbi Nachman of Bratslav, a Hasidic master known for his mystical teachings, asked his followers to come and pray at his grave each year on Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.

title: For Fuming Motorists, a Memorable Presidential Visit
description: The preparations began shortly before 10 A.M. Monday, when New York City police officers and traffic agents closed First Avenue and the northbound lane of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, Manhattan's main traffic arteries on the East Side.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday about effects of cholesterol reduction referred incorrectly in some copies to findings of the 1987 Helsinki Heart Study. There were more gastrointestinal problems among patients treated for high cholesterol levels with the drug gembfibrozil, but the difference was not statistically significant.

title: A.T.& T. to Buy Istel In First British Move
description: Moving to expand its international presence in information services, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would acquire Istel Ltd., a privately held information and technology services company based in London, for $280 million in cash.

title: CBS and Turner in Deal On Olympics Coverage
description: CBS and the Turner Broadcasting System announced an agreement yesterday granting Turner the rights to carry some events of the 1992 and 1994 winter Olympics for $50 million in fees. It will be the first time that a cable network will carry any part of the winter Games.

title: Machinists Said To Spurn UAL
description: In the next few days, the machinists' union will notify the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, that it wants to negotiate a new contract rather than participate in a buyout of the company by its pilots and management, a person close to the union said yesterday.

title: About New York; From Clear Lake To Manhattan: A Life's Design
description: On Feb. 3, 1937, Lon Whitney began a letter to his family in Clear Lake, Iowa, thusly:

title: Maning Obregon, 50, Illustrator In the World of Fashion, Is Dead
description: Maning Obregon, a fashion illustrator for more than 30 years, died last night at his home in Manhattan. He was 50 years old.

title: Mansell Suspended From Spanish Race
description: Nigel Mansell of Britain was suspended yesterday from the Spanish Formula One Grand Prix Sunday by the International Federation of Automobile Sports, the sport's governing body. Ferrari team officials said they would appeal the decision but would not replace Mansell in the race.

title: '91 Shift for Swiss Bonds
description: Switzerland's three big stock exchanges announced plans today to switch bond trading from exchange floors to computer screens in 1991. If the project gets official approval, bond dealers in Zurich, Geneva and Basel will no longer have to go to the exchanges and can stay at their banks to transact deals on their screens. The three exchanges want to free floor space for other business, like a growing trade in share warrants.

title: A Proposed Soviet Law Limits Press Censorship
description: Three committees of the Soviet legislature have quietly approved a proposed press law allowing any citizen or group to publish newspapers, magazines or books, and forbidding Government censorship of the press before publication.

title: Guilty Pleas in Pentagon Fraud
description: Three men and a Los Angeles-based military contractor pleaded guilty today to bribery or conspiracy charges stemming from a six-year scheme to win contracts from the Marine Corps.

title: Bankrupt and Immoral on Cambodia
description: Vietnamese troops have finally left Cambodia. But with no agreed transition plan, Cambodians face a stark contest between the Vietnamese-installed Hun Sen regime and the genocidal Khmer Rouge. And the Bush Administration now has to face the bankruptcy of its policy of backing Prince Sihanouk along with his Khmer Rouge allies and of opposing Hun Sen. Morality and practicality require a new approach.

title: 2 More Tests of Bomber Cut Short
description: Two more test flights of the Stealth bomber were cut short last week, on one occasion because a crack in an engine gearbox caused a recurring oil pressure problem, the Defense Department said today.

title: Schools Trying to Link Good Jobs and Skills
description: Teachers used to tell Gaylon Jefferson he should stay in school if he wanted a good job, but he says he did not see the point then. He knew too many people who had high school diplomas and were still working at McDonald's.

title: Karlis a Viking
description: Rich Karlis, a barefooted place-kicker who played seven seasons for the Denver Broncos before being released last month after not signing a contract, signed a one-year contract with the Minnesota Vikings yesterday and will be kicking for them on Sunday against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Teddy Garcia, who missed three short-range kicks last Sunday in a 27-14 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, was waived.(AP)

title: Book Notes
description: Protesting Protesters

title: For Mandatory Siestas
description: To the Editor:

title: About Education
description: If President Bush wants to be known as the education President, he competes with Lyndon B. Johnson, his only predecessor with that title. The way Mr. Johnson gained that distinction seems relevant to the education meeting that begins today.

title: A's Move to Brink of Title
description: The Oakland Athletics gained at least a tie for the American League West championship last night with a 4-3 victory over the Texas Rangers. In the American League East, the Toronto Blue Jays drew one step closer to the division title.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the campaign for governor in Virginia misstated a political policy of Senator Harry F. Byrd. He followed a strict ''pay as you go'' policy on public spending, declining to issue bonds for schools and hospitals. Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr., a Byrd protege, abandoned the policy in 1965.

title: Jersey Race May Go
description: The New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, site of the 1988 United States Olympic trials, will not take place next year unless a major sponsor provides about $500,000 before the end of the year, and that is unlikely, said Mike Rowe, general manager for Giants Stadium and Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority took over as producer of the race last year and lost an undisclosed sum.(AP)

title: Courter Wrote to the Army on Wedtech's Behalf
description: Representative Jim Courter, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, asked the Secretary of the Army to give the Wedtech Corporation ''every consideration for a procurement contract'' in 1981, according to a letter introduced yesterday at the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx.

title: China Buys More Wheat
description: China has bought an additional 300,000 metric tons of United States wheat for delivery in the 1989-90 marketing year that began June 1, the Agriculture Department said today. The sales were reported to the department by private exporters as required by law. The latest sales increased to more than 4 million tons the amount of American wheat that China has purchased for the 1989-90 season. Last year's sales totaled 8.1 million tons.

title: New Step for Clean Air: A Natural Gas Bus
description: The value of natural gas as a clean-burning alternative to gasoline and diesel fuels has long been known, and large numbers of conventional engines have been converted to its use. Now, in anticipation of increasingly stringent Federal emissions standards for urban areas, at least one manufacturer has developed a mass- transit bus designed from the outset to be powered by natural gas.

title: Robert F. Rogers, 58, Producer at NBC News
description: Robert F. Rogers, a television producer at NBC News, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 58 years old. In 1961, Mr. Rogers joined NBC as a writer for David Brinkley. He produced more than 40 documentaries on wars, national and foreign affairs and human-interest subjects.

title: The Pop Life
description: Rickie Lee Jones

title: You Spent $100 for Dinner And Ate What? Beef Cheeks?
description: THE menu at Amphycles, a new and already highly praised restaurant in Paris, listed among its main dishes joues de boeuf braisees aux carottes confites: succulent, fork-tender meat with a pleasant suggestion of fibrousness in a rich brown sauce with buttery carrots. Delicious. The others at the table were poised for samples and murmured their delight.

title: Excerpts From the Speech by Shevardnadze Before the General Assembly
description: Following are excerpts from the address yesterday by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union to the United Nations General Assembly. The speech was translated by a United Nations interpreter and recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. . . . Yesterday we listened with close attention to the speech of President George Bush of the United States, a statement which in our view contained a number of very important and interesting ideas.

title: Lessons
description: Politicians like to point out that it costs at least $20,000 a year to keep someone in prison - the same amount it costs for a year at Harvard.

title: Fernandez Retains A Hot Arm and Bat
description: On a night when several of his teammates rested, Sid Fernandez did not.

title: Off-Duty Soldiers Trade Gunfire At a House Linked to Drug Sales
description: A dozen off-duty soldiers from Fort Lewis engaged in a 30-minute gun battle last weekend against a group of alleged drug dealers.

title: U.S. Issues Rebound Somewhat
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday, rebounding from Monday's big selloff.

title: New Jersey Offers Parkway Bonds
description: A $238 million negotiated bond issue by the New Jersey Highway Authority was tentatively priced through a group of underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Durables Orders Jump 3.8%
description: Durable goods orders jumped a surprising 3.8 percent in August for the best gain in eight months, the Commerce Department said today, but fresh signs of weakness in the industrial sector crept into the monthly report.

title: Is Rap Music as Harmful to Black Youth as White Institutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Herbert J. Buchsbaum, Obstetrics Professor, 55
description: Dr. Herbert J. Buchsbaum, chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at the Medical College of Wisconsin, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Milwaukee. He was 55 years old.

title: World War II Vatican Role Must Be Recognized
description: To the Editor:

title: A Twainlike Twist for Flint, Mich.
description: America has an irrepressible new humorist in the tradition of Mark Twain and Artemus Ward. He is Michael Moore, the writer, producer and director of the rude and rollicking new documentary feature ''Roger and Me.'' Much in the manner of those 19th-century forebears, Mr. Moore celebrates the oddities of the American frontier, once defined by the historian F. J. Turner as ''the meeting place of savagery and civilization, where democracy is strengthened.''

title: Hugo Food Drive At Ball Games
description: Officials at all five Atlantic Coast Conference schools and at least one Southeastern Conference school have agreed to collect donated canned goods at their games Saturday for victims of Hurricane Hugo.

title: Yes on Start, for Now
description: A new myth has suddenly materialized: By hanging tough, President Bush has brought the Soviet Union around to the U.S. positions in the strategic arms talks. The Soviets did soften their stand last weekend on two of the toughest issues, Star Wars and sea-launched cruise missiles. But the truth is that they haven't acceded to the U.S. position; they have offered only to defer both questions until after a Start treaty is signed.

title: Stephenson Retires
description: Dwight Stephenson, 31 years old, the four-time All-Pro center of the Miami Dolphins, announced his retirement yesterday. The announcement ended his attempt to come back from a severe knee injury suffered in December 1987, when he was hit by Marty Lyons of the Jets as the Jets were returning a fumble. Until then, Stephenson had never missed a National Football League game because of an injury.(AP)

title: City Opera Warns Strikers It May Cancel the Season
description: The New York City Opera has warned its orchestra and the union representing its performers that if the musicians' two-week-long strike is not settled by Oct. 8, the company will cancel the rest of the season, scheduled to end Nov. 19.

title: A Drug War, With Little Ammunition
description: The key to understanding the Administration's national drug strategy lies not in reading President Bush's lips but in reading his proposal's fine print. The closer one looks, the clearer it is that the budgeteers have gutted the President's and drug czar William Bennett's strategy.

title: Brown U. to Strengthen Rules Against Racism
description: Brown University will tighten its student policies against racism, but will not sell the rest of its stock holdings in companies with ties to South Africa, its president says.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Capital Markets Assurance Corp. said Ram Wertheim, a former associate at the law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, had joined it as senior vice president and general counsel.

title: Short-Term HBO Pact Seems Likely for Tyson
description: That ''lifetime'' deal rumored to be in the works between Home Box Office and Mike Tyson is likely to end up merely as an extension until early 1992 of the present seven-fight, $26.5 million deal.

title: Lowe Tucker Expected To Announce a Deal
description: Lowe Tucker Metcalf is expected to announce tomorrow that it has agreed to acquire Homer & Durham, a small New York agency.

title: Paul Cioffi, 94, Dies; Physicist at Bell Labs
description: Paul Cioffi, a physicist at Bell Laboratories, now A.T. & T. Bell Laboratories, for more than 40 years, died of liver cancer Sunday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: Dylex Hires Adviser
description: Dylex Ltd. said today that it had retained Financo Inc. to advise it on a possible sale or restructuring of its United States clothing chain, the Foxmoor Specialty Stores Corporation. The company had previously indicated it would explore a restructuring or sale. Foxmoor operates 595 women's specialty stores in United States shopping malls. Financo is a New York mergers and acquisitions adviser specializing in the merchandising industry.

title: Books of The Times; 'Antagonists,' but With a Common Purpose
description: The Antagonists Hugo Black, Felix Frankfurter and Civil Liberties in Modern America By James F. Simon Illustrated. 312 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: DELTA AND F.A.A. FAULTED ON CRASH
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today criticized Delta Air Lines and the Federal Aviation Administration, saying they had failed to tighten discipline among the airline's pilots until after a fatal crash in Dallas in August 1988.

title: Side Effects Noted in High Doses of New AIDS Drug
description: Researchers have found that an experimental AIDS drug, dideoxyinosine, or DDI, causes severe side effects at high doses. They have begun to worry that wide distribution of the drug planned as a major experiment in the Federal drug approval process could produce similar toxic effects among many AIDS patients.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE great underused resource for home cooks is fish bones, which are readily available and are the foundation for endless soups and sauces. Most fishmongers happily give them away, and the stocks you make with them can be frozen for a month or more.

title: Darlington Hoopes, Socialist, 93; Twice Party Choice for President
description: Darlington Hoopes, a longtime leader of the Socialist Party who was its candidate for President in 1952 and 1956, died Monday at the Leader Nursing Center in Sinking Spring, Pa. He was 93 years old and had been a resident of Reading, Pa.

title: No One Leading Football Cheers For School Team
description: When the Montpelier High School football team takes the field this year, something will be missing: cheerleaders.

title: Y.&R. in Deal For Landor
description: Young & Rubicam said yesterday that it would acquire Landor Associates, a leading corporate identity firm based in San Francisco. A spokesman for Y.&R. refused to disclose the terms of the deal.

title: Surgery for Mitchell
description: Stump Mitchell, running back for the Phoenix Cardinals, had surgery on his left knee yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Phoenix, likely ending his nine-year N.F.L. career. Mitchell was injured in Sunday's 35-7 loss to the Giants.(AP)

title: Johnson Fights the Odds In Effort to Stay a Devil
description: The competition for jobs on the Devils is so fierce this season that Mark Johnson, the smallest and second-oldest player on the team, is facing a tough battle to find a place for himself after suffering three injuries last season.

title: Wells Fargo to Buy California Bank
description: Continuing its expansion in Southern California, Wells Fargo & Company signed an agreement to purchase the Torrey Pines Group of Solana Beach, Calif., owner of the Torrey Pines Bank. The purchase price will be $31 a share, or about $74.5 million. Of the purchase price, at least 52 percent will be paid in Wells Fargo common stock, and the rest in cash.

title: Company Gets Founder Back
description: ASK Computer Systems Inc. said today that Sandra Kurtzig, its founder, had returned full time as chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Accounting Merger Talks Called Off
description: Arthur Andersen & Company and Price Waterhouse said yesterday that they had abandoned their efforts to create the world's largest accounting firm. The firms would not comment on why they had ended their discussions beyond saying that their ''differences could not be resolved within a realistic time frame.''

title: Trains Roll Into Armenia, Ending Blockade
description: Freight trains began rolling into Armenia today, ending a monthlong blockade by the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, according to official Soviet reports.

title: Dow Closes Up a Bit After Losing Big Gain
description: Stocks ended slightly higher yesterday after losing substantial early gains on a late wave of futures-related trading.

title: Quebec Premier Turns Attention to Charter Accord
description: After winning a landslide re-election over the separatist Parti Quebecois in a provincial election, Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec turned his attention today to the uphill battle to gain ratification of a constitutional accord cementing Quebec's place in the Canadian confederation.

title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.
description: The President of Guatemala appealed to the United States today to use the aid it is giving the Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras to speed up their return and resettlement in Nicaragua.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Press Freedoms Soviet legislators are quietly pushing through a draft press law to allow private publishing and forbid Government censorship. Page A8. Cubs Clinch Division Title The Chicago Cubs, who have not won a pennant in 44 years or a World Series in 81 years, won their second division title in five years. Page A25.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about efforts to import pentamidine, a drug used to treat AIDS symptoms, referred incorrectly to the anti-fungal drug fluconazole. It is available free for patients who cannot tolerate other therapies or in whom the therapies have failed.

title: Mix-Up Exposes Spy in Terror Group
description: A breakdown in communications between police and intelligence officials in West Germany last October compromised a valuable agent inside a Palestinian terrorist group, preventing authorities from obtaining information that might have warned them of the December 1988 bombing of a Pan American jetliner over Scotland, American officials said.

title: Pacemaker Uses Voyager Nuclear 'Battery'
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Counsel Runs for Post
description: Richard J. Phelan, the special counsel in the House ethics inquiry that led to the resignation of Speaker Jim Wright earlier this year, announced his candidacy for public office today. Mr. Phelan, 52 years old, said he would seek the Democratic nomination for president of the Cook County Board. The office is considered second only to that of Mayor of Chicago in terms of political power in the area. The Cook County Board administers the county hospital and dozens of other services.

title: British Telecom Names North American Head
description: British Telecom, which has been increasing its activities in the United States, yesterday named Michael L. Ford as the president of its North American unit.

title: Saks and Field Likely to Draw Global Bids
description: The proposed sale of the 46 Saks Fifth Avenue stores and of the 26 Marshall Field & Company stores by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. is expected to draw substantial interest from domestic and foreign companies, merger specialists and retailers said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. And 3 P.M. Legal Committee - 10 A.M.

title: Vermont's Top Court Punishes an Ex-Justice
description: Having found one of its retired justices guilty of misconduct, the Vermont Supreme Court today reprimanded him and suspended him from judicial duties.

title: Pierce's Statement to Panel
description: Following is the statement that Samuel R. Pierce Jr. read today to a House subcommittee investigating irregularities at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, as provided by his lawyers.

title: 1 Is Killed and 20 Are Hurt In Fighting at Illinois Prison
description: An inmate was killed and 20 people were injured today when gang-related fighting broke out among more than 300 inmates at the maximum-security prison here, prison officials said.

title: Eric Bernard, 57, Dies; Ran Restaurant Chain
description: Eric Bernard, chairman and chief executive officer of Ground Round Inc., a national restaurant chain, and a former president of the Holiday Inn chain, died suddenly Monday in a hotel in Delray, Fla., while traveling. He was 57 years old and lived in Boston and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are so many people that have lost a part of themselves, and for them this is something that will last forever. If we ever saw anything to top old Hugo, we would be gone from the face of the earth.

title: After Hurricane, Relief Gives Way to Despair
description: Only today did Debra Deas stop and think about what comes next. After the worst week of her life, the future is the most frightening part of all.

title: Black and White Death Rates Continue to Differ, Study Says
description: Although the health of the overall American population is improving, there is a continuing disparity in the death and illness rates of blacks and whites, with blacks dying younger and having higher infant mortality rates than whites, a Government report released today says.

title: Its Pumps Repaired, San Juan Gets Water
description: Water flowed from the taps of San Juan homes today for the first time since Hurricane Hugo knocked out the city's pumps eight days ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES B.A.T. said it would sell its vast retailing empire, including the Saks and Marshall Field chains, as part of a revamping aimed at thwarting Sir James Goldsmith's $21 billion hostile takeover bid. [ Page A1. ] The Saks and Marshall Field stores are expected to draw substantial interest. [ D5. ] Citizens and Southern plans to merge with Sovran Financial in a deal that would create the nation's 11th-largest bank. [ D1. ] Toys ''R'' Us said it would begin selling toys in Japan within two years, in a venture with McDonald's (Japan). [ D1. ] Peter Guber is expected to replace Victor A. Kaufman as president and chief executive of Columbia Pictures. [ D1. ] Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse will not merge, saying they could not resolve differences. [ D1. ] CBS and Turner Broadcasting agreed on a deal for the cable network to carry some Olympic events in 1992 and 1994. [ D2. ] I.B.M. plans to increase significantly the speed of its Personal System/2 computers. [ D16. ] Sun Oil is expected to begin test-marketing a cleaner-burning gasoline. [ D4. ] A.T.& T. will pay $180 million for Istel, a privately held information and technology services company in London. [ D4. ] United Airlines' machinists want to negotiate a new contract rather than participate in a buyout of UAL. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL The European Community proposed $660 million in economic aid for Hungary and Poland next year. [ A1. ] In agreeing with I.M.F., the Bush Administration has committed itself to more ambitious aid to Poland than the direct assistance it proposed. [ A13. ] MARKETS The dollar held its own despite aggressive dollar-selling by central banks of the Group of Seven. [ D1. ] Stocks ended slightly higher after losing substantial early gains on a late wave of futures-related trading. [ D8. ] Shares sold short and not yet covered rose 1.1 percent in over-the-counter trading in the four weeks ended Sept. 15, Nasdaq reported. [ D26. ] Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly, rebounding from Monday's big selloff. [ D15. ] Yields were slightly down for C.D.'s and money market accounts. [ D25. ] A forecast of ideal harvest weather sent some grain futures prices lower, but the selloff helped to bolster cattle prices. [ D18. ] THE ECONOMY Three men and a military contractor pleaded guilty to bribery or conspiracy charges stemming from a scheme to win contracts from the Marine Corps. And a Federal grand jury indicted two men, including a military consultant, Thomas Muldoon. [ D1. ] Durable goods orders jumped 3.8 percent in August for the best gain in eight months. [ D20. ] The U.S. oil and gas industry continued to contract last year, as did the value of its known reserves. [ D17. ] TECHNOLOGY A mass-transit bus designed to be powered by natural gas is in the works. [ D6. ] Union Carbide hopes to eliminate large amounts of harmful solvents in spray paints. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Can U.S. networks pay less for rights to the Olympic Games? Two researchers say yes. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Some people on Wall Street wonder whether investment banks need safeguards against their bridge loans. Market Place. [ D8. ] American magazine publishers have begun to look overseas, especially Europe. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: Having Fun With Jack Benny, for Opera's Sake
description: As Bob McGrath explains it, the Ridge Theater troupe, of which he is artistic director, is at its best in developing pieces with a political edge. But he added that they also enjoy ''taking American pop icons, playing with them and distorting them.''

title: Magazine Publishers Look Abroad
description: SEVERAL American magazine publishers whose concerns have been largely domestic have begun to look with increasing interest at foreign lands, especially Europe.

title: Honda 1992 Target
description: The Honda Motor Company has set a sales target of 2.5 million cars worldwide in 1992, a company spokesman said. Honda's 1992 North American sales target is one million cars, of which 510,000 will be made in the United States, 80,000 in Canada and the rest imported from Japan. Honda forecasts 1989 sales of more than 800,000 in North America.

title: World War II Vatican Role Must Be Recognized; Poles and the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Speech at Tufts: Zoned Out
description: Tufts University is divided, both literally and figuratively. A new university policy, intended to protect students from harassment, has brought First Amendment rights into conflict with the ideals of an academic community. The issue is this: Should a university limit free speech to create a proper environment for learning? Or does the very nature of education require exposure to even offensive speech?

title: Top Position at Hytek Is Filled by a Director
description: Hytek Microsystems Inc. said yesterday that Alan W. Baldwin had assumed the position of chairman, chief executive and chief operating officer, effective immediately. Mr. Baldwin has been a director since June 1988 and has served as a consultant.

title: 3 Workers Are Electrocuted As Wire Touches Scaffolding
description: A 69,000-volt electrical wire touched scaffolding being moved at a construction site Monday, killing three workers and injuring three others.

title: Explosive Found in Niger Crash
description: Investigators say they have found traces of the powerful explosive Semtex in remnants of the French DC 10 airliner that crashed in Niger on Sept. 19, killing 171 people, two French newspapers reported today.

title: First Bank Fills Position
description: The First Bank System, based in Minneapolis, has elevated a director, Richard L. Schall, to acting chairman. Mr. Schall, 59 years old, will lead the search to replace DeWalt H. Ankeny Jr., who resigned last week after First Bank said that it expected a large charge-off against its third-quarter earnings and that it might reduce its work force by 20 percent. Mr. Schall is the retired vice chairman and chief adminstrative officer of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the department store chain. He has been a First Bank director since 1987.

title: Survey Says Mid-Sized Companies Debate Leaving
description: One in every five medium-sized businesses in the New York metropolitan area is considering leaving New York, and most of those would move to New Jersey, according to a survey released yesterday by Bank Leumi.

title: Tiananmen Killings Not a 'Tragedy,' Chinese Party Chief Says
description: The Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, said today that the army's suppression of the democracy movement in early June, in which hundreds of people were killed, was not a ''tragedy,'' and he refused to rule out more death sentences for the movement's leaders.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Lendl Persists and Wins: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, ranked No. 1 in the world, survived two tie breakers yesterday to win in the first round of the Bordeaux Passing Shot tournament in Bordeaux, France. Lendl beat Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-7, 6-1.(AP) Rally Helps Yugoslav: Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia fought off Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico to score a 7-5, 7-6 victory in the first round of the Volvo of San Francisco tournament on Monday. The 6-foot-6-inch Zivojinovic fell behind by 5-1 in the second-set tie breaker, but reduced his errors and forced Lavalle into many mistakes to take the set, 8-6.(AP) Upsets in Sicily: Second-seeded Martin Jaite of Argentina and third-seeded Tomas Muster of Austria lost in upsets yesterday in the first round of the International Championship of Sicily tournament in Palermo. Jaite lost to Stefano Pescosolido of Italy, 6-3, 6-7, 6-3. Muster lost to Pavel Vojtisek of West Germany, 6-4, 6-1.(AP) BOXING Two Americans Defeated: Two American medal hopefuls, Terry McGroom and Skipper Kelp, were beaten yesterday in quarterfinal matches at the world amateur championship in Moscow.(AP) GOLF A Winner by 2 Shots: Mike Joyce of the Huntington Golf Club shot a one-over-par 71 yesterday to win the Metropolitan senior championship in White Plains with a 36-hole total of 143. Carl Lohren of the North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, L.I., trailed Joyce with a 73-145. (AP)

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY: While pushing my year-old daughter in a stroller down Fifth Avenue at the recent book fair, I came across Dr. Lawrence Balter, a child psychologist. It seemed like a good opportunity to ask for some expert advice.

title: Budget Roundup; Bush Raises Ante in Fight to Cut Capital Gains Tax
description: President Bush today upped the ante in his battle to reduce the maximum tax rate on capital gains, vowing to fight Congressional Democrats for it even if the battle prolongs a budget impasse and brings cuts across the board in spending for domestic and military programs.

title: Tigers Extend Anderson Pact
description: The Detroit Tigers ended speculation that Manager Sparky Anderson might retire and extended his contract for two years today. Anderson, only the third manager in franchise history to have 100 or more defeats, will be with the club through 1992.

title: Brewer to Fight Stroh Takeover
description: The S&P Companies said it would file suit in Federal District Court to block the acquisition of most of the brands and breweries of the Stroh Brewing Company by the Adolph Coors Company. S&P is a privately held San Francisco company that owns the Pabst, Pearl, Falstaff and General brewing companies.

title: 'STAR WARS' FUNDS CUT IN THE SENATE
description: The Senate voted tonight to reduce President Bush's budget for the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program by $800 million, reversing a practice of protecting the program from deep cuts sought by the House and opening the way for the first annual budget reduction in its five years of existence.

title: Jens Norgaard, Football Player, 72
description: Jens Norgaard, who played on the University of Iowa's 1939 Ironmen football team and was a decorated pilot in World War II, died Sunday in Burlington, Wis., after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

title: New Jersey Debate: Long on Quips, Loose on Facts
description: New Jerseyans were confronted with a burst of political imagery Monday in the first debate in the race for governor as Representative Jim Courter and Representative James J. Florio painted portraits of each other with pointed quips and dabs of dirt.

title: Teen-Ager Charged in Blast That Killed 6
description: An 18-year-old man has been charged with murder and arson in an explosion that killed six Kansas City firefighters at a construction site in November.

title: Eating Well
description: BREAKFAST entrees offered by fast-food restaurants over the last decade, and more recently by makers of frozen microwaveable products, have expanded the consumer's choices, but the customer may be paying a nutritional price for convenience.

title: Youth Is Arrested for Selling Crack That Bush Displayed
description: A teen-ager was arrested today on charges of selling the crack that President Bush displayed on television to illustrate the seriousness of the nation's drug problems.

title: With Bush in Elf Land
description: Long ago when radio mattered, ''Let's Pretend'' was a good entertainment show for children. Now it's the sport of grown-ups, and not the kind of grown-ups you expect to find clowning around either, but grown-ups who become testy when asked why they play ''Let's Pretend'' instead of tending to business.

title: Michael Scott Is Dead; Trade Editor Was 65
description: Michael Scott, a publisher and editor of trade publications, died of a heart attack last Thursday at Group Health Hospital in Seattle. He was 65 years old and had lived in Seattle since 1977.

title: It Chills, Freezes and Cooks
description: A new appliance that can chill beer, keep ice cream frozen and cook pizza has been designed to minimize energy use. The Microfridge, which sells for $429, is a three-piece appliance consisting of a compact refrigerator, a separate freezer compartment and a small microwave oven.

title: Is Rap Music as Harmful to Black Youth as White Institutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lufthansa Orders 20 Airbus A321's
description: West Germany's state-controlled airline, Lufthansa, said its supervisory board had approved orders for 20 twin-engine Airbus A321 airliners. It also agreed to convert options into firm orders on two more Airbuses and a total of 20 Boeing 737's.

title: People
description: * Thomas Carey has been promoted to executive vice president of the international division of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, a unit of the Omnicom Group, and Peter Rosow and Richard Levenson were named to replace him as joint managing directors of D.M.B.& B./New York.

title: GREEK LAWMAKER IS SLAIN IN ATHENS
description: A gunman today killed a prominent politician, the son-in-law of the man expected to be the next Prime Minister, and a leftist guerrilla group asserted responsibility.

title: A Federal Grant for Testing Aims at State-by-State Data
description: The Department of Education is giving a $58.5 million grant to the Educational Testing Service to expand its national assessments of student performance to provide state-by-state information for the first time.

title: Article 829589 -- No Title
description: Business leaders, politicians and poll-takers say that across this state both Republicans and Democrats, employees and employers, are unhappy with what happened under the Capitol dome in the spring when Connecticut confronted its budget deficit.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates at the weekly auction of commercial paper held yesterday by Citicorp were up for the first time in a month.

title: Market Place; Questions Raised On Bridge Loans
description: WALL STREET investment banks traditionally feared committing large amounts of their own capital to finance a client's deals. But, in 1985, the firms discovered that sizable short-term loans could bring large profits, and so fear was pushed aside and they began extending bridge loans for corporate refinancings.

title: Topics of The Times; Red Dye Sneak Attack
description: Red Dye No. 3 is an artificial color additive that brightens cosmetics, drugs and foods - notably maraschino cherries. Animal tests show it is also a carcinogen. Whether the potentially dangerous dye remains on the market will be decided this week when House and Senate conferees complete the 1990 agriculture appropriations bill.

title: Great Kills Favors Koch But Supports Giuliani Bid
description: In Great Kills, S.I., a three-bedroom town house sells for $140,000, but a round-trip drive to Manhattan can cost $10 in tolls. Well-tended lawns slope gently toward tidy marinas, but the main roads running past them are clogged with cars and flood at the first heavy rain. It is a place where peace comes at a price.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: New York Moves to Help Poorly Rated Teachers
description: ''But what should YOU be doing when the kids are doing the problems from the board?'' Irene Metviner asked the teacher.

title: Review/Recital; A Pianist's Emphasis: Technique and a Good Time
description: Nikolai Petrov is a burly, hearty Russian bear of a pianist who has plenty of technique and sees no good reason why a piano recital shouldn't be an hour of fun. He plans his programs around unifying themes, but not stern ones like the heroism-and-death cycle a young Greek pianist brought to Lincoln Center a few seasons back. Mr. Petrov's Carnegie Hall program on Friday evening was called ''Invitation to the Dance'' and it was a bull's-eye.

title: Leo Gottlieb, Lawyer, 93
description: Leo Gottlieb, a lawyer and former president of the New York County Lawyers Association, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.

title: Red Sox Score 8 In the First
description: All that is left now is to play the final games as if they mean something, even if they don't amount to slightly more than a spring game in Florida. So the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox met again tonight and trudged through an unsightly nine innings at Fenway Park.

title: Guards Quell A Disturbance In Rikers Jail
description: Forty-eight inmates at Rikers Island barricaded themselves in their cell block before dawn yesterday and set mattresses afire before 200 correction officers quelled the disturbance with tear gas, New York City Correction Department officials said.

title: New Sun Gasoline Expected
description: The Sun Oil Company is expected to announce Wednesday that it will begin test-marketing a cleaner-burning gasoline, according to sources in the petroleum industry.

title: Philippine Gunmen Kill 2 U.S. Civilians
description: Two American employees of a United States military base were killed by gunmen at the installation Tuesday afternoon, shortly before Vice President Dan Quayle arrived for a state visit.

title: Sisters-in-Law Killed in Brooklyn
description: Two women were fatally shot and the uncle of one of them was critically wounded yesterday as two children looked on during what the police said appeared to be an attempted robbery by three gunmen in an apartment in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Football's Minors Try To Survive First Year
description: When the Pocono Mountaineers arrived here at the new City Island Sports Complex two weeks ago for a minor league football game against the Harrisburg Patriots, team officials stared at the modern and well-equipped playing field.

title: Thinking About SETI
description: When the mail brought a big package about the Search for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence, or SETI, my knee-jerk reaction was that first we need to find more terrestrial intelligence.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Tucson Electric Power Company said it would take a $15 million charge against earnings because a unit in the automobile leasing business had been cut off by its creditors. Tucson Electric said it might suffer additional losses from its $59 million investment in the indirect subsidiary, the Brookland Financial Corporation. Brookland is a subsidiary of Tucson's Sierrita Resources Inc. unit.

title: White House Plans to Aid Poland Through I.M.F.
description: The Bush Administration is working on a new ''package of support'' for Poland that relies strongly on the International Monetary Fund to channel money to the new Government in Warsaw as part of a major multilateral effort, White House officials said.

title: Taiwan Picks Yonkers Company for Subway Cars
description: A Japanese-owned rail car manufacturer here that has built subway cars for the New York City and PATH systems was awarded a $170 million contract today to build the first 132 subway cars for a new mass-transit system under construction in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: Ivy League Giving Up Its Army Competition
description: The Ivy League wants no part of Army. Cornell and Yale have canceled scheduled games against the Cadets in recent seasons, and Army has only two Ivy games left, the first of which will be played Saturday at West Point.

title: KEY RATES
Rate Changes Set By GTE Airfone
description: GTE Airfone Inc. said it planned to revise its rates for airline in-flight telephone service. Starting Oct. 1, passengers who use the GTE Corporation subsidiary's service will be charged $2 for each minute and a $2 setup fee for each call. Airline passengers now pay $7.50 for the first three minutes and $1.25 for each additional minute. The rates are for calls within the United States and Canada, including Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: Pope Appeals to World's Muslims To Help Save a 'Dying' Lebanon
description: Pope John Paul II issued an extraordinary appeal to the world's Muslims today, urging them in impassioned terms to help save Lebanon, which, he said, ''is dying before our very eyes.''

title: Economic Scene; Olympians Play, U.S. TV Pays
description: ABC paid $309 million for broadcast rights to the 1988 winter Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta. Western European television paid a total of $5.7 million.

title: Article 864089 -- No Title
description: The European Community's executive commission today proposed a $660 million economic aid program for Hungary and Poland next year, more than double the total already pledged by the industrial democracies this year.

title: U.S. Judge Backs Extradition Of Accused Terrorist to Israel
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a naturalized United States citizen accused in a 1986 terrorist attack on a bus in the West Bank could be extradited to Israel to stand trial for murder and other charges resulting from the attack.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture on Saturday with an article about the crash of USAir Flight 5050 at La Guardia Airport was published in error. It showed William Kerrigan, a Pan American pilot who was a passenger on the plane, not the plane's pilot.

title: Cubs Take First Title Since '84
description: Using a measure of self-reliance, a hoped-for assist from the Pittsburgh Pirates and an unexpected late-game boost from the Montreal Expos, the Chicago Cubs won the National League East last night. They became the first major league team to secure a division championship this season.

title: I.B.M. Increasing Speed of PS/2 Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was preparing to increase significantly the speed of its Personal System/2 personal computers.

title: Addenda
description: * William Wiener, a former executive with BBDO and Ogilvy & Mather, has formed Advertising and Media Advisers, a media strategy concern.

title: Dr. Joseph B. Lenzner, Dentist, 86
description: Dr. Joseph B. Lenzner, a retired dentist, died of a heart attack yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Investor Purchases 5.1% Stake in Katy
description: Richard L. Otte, an Illinois investor, has purchased a 5.1 percent stake in Katy Industries. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Otte said that he purchased the shares as an investment. Katy, based in Elgin, Ill., is a holding company that has interests in businesses ranging from waste-to-energy plants to cookie production.

title: With Vietnamese Out, Cambodia Faces Bitter Fight
description: What Vietnam says is its last column of troops in Cambodia began moving through this border crossing early this morning, nearly 11 years after Vietnamese soldiers invaded Cambodia and ousted the brutal Khmer Rouge Government of Pol Pot.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ACS Industries, Woonsocket, R.I., said its chairman was offering to take the company private in a $5.50-a-share buyout offer.

title: Nearly Half of U.S. Rural Bridges Found Lacking
description: Nearly half the bridges in rural America are ''structurally deficient or functionally obsolete,'' an Agriculture Department report says.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: A $660 million aid plan for Hungary and Poland next year was proposed by the European Community. The figure is double the total already pledged by the industrial democracies this year. Page A1

title: C. Wallace Floody, 71; Led P.O.W. Breakout
description: C. Wallace Floody, whose heroics in World War II in engineering a tunnel out of a German prisoner of war camp were featured in the movie ''The Great Escape,'' died on Monday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: U.S. and Its Allies Sell Dollars
description: The central banks of the leading industrial democracies sold dollars aggressively again today but the dollar held its ground, after falling sharply on Monday.

title: Wine Talk
description: A CASUAL glance at the label and you might conclude that there is yet another new winery in California, one called Silver Birch. Well, take another look. This wine is made from the silver birch tree, and is produced here in northern Scotland at what is, so far as anyone can determine, the world's northernmost winery.

title: Review/Opera; 'Aida' Shows Its Suitability As Opener for the Met Season
description: ''Aida'' and opening night at the Metropolitan Opera were made for each other. Verdi provided, in the triumphal scene, not only all the excuses any company needs for spectacular middlebrow fun but also three intermissions. The breaks allow maximum time for the dress parades and lobby hobnobbing that can reconcile many first-nighters to the necessity of paying close attention to the predicament of the Ethiopian slave torn between love of her country and love for its Egyptian conqueror.

title: Soviets, Welcoming Bush's Plan On Chemical Arms, Go Further
description: The Soviet Union today welcomed the United States proposal for immediate cuts in the two nations' chemical-weapons arsenals but suggested going further and banning production of the most advanced types of chemical arms, which Washington wants to retain.

title: Removing the Hazards in Spray Paints
description: If a gas is compressed to almost the density of a liquid, it often begins to act like a liquid. The Union Carbide Corporation plans to take advantage of this property to eliminate large amounts of harmful solvents in the paints that are sprayed on automobiles, appliances and furniture.

title: British Conglomerate to Sell Off Saks and Marshall Field Chains
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said today that it planned to sell its vast retailing empire, including the well-known Saks and Marshall Field stores, as part of a dramatic effort to preserve its independence.

title: Grade School Principal Quits Over Ties to Male Prostitute
description: Another man who was involved with the same male prostitute as Representative Barney Frank has resigned as principal of the Chevy Chase Elementary School.

title: Russian Ballet Items On Show at Gallery
description: ''One Hundred Years of Russian Ballet, 1830-1930,'' an exhibition of rare archival material and costumes from the Leningrad State Museum of Theater and Music, will be on view through Oct. 20 at the Eduard Nakhamkin Fine Arts Gallery, 1055 Madison Avenue, at 80th Street.

title: Mets Kick Counselor, Not Cooler
description: rrWhen Dwight Gooden tested positive for drugs in 1987, he was entrusted to a psychiatrist, Dr. Allan Lans of the Smithers Alcoholism and Treatment Center.

title: 2 Big Banks In the South Will Merge
description: The Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta, which repelled an unwanted takeover bid earlier this year, yesterday announced plans to merge with the Sovran Financial Corporation, Virginia's largest banking company.

title: Producer Likely to Head Sony-Owned Columbia
description: Peter Guber, one of Hollywood's top producers, is expected to replace Victor A. Kaufman as president and chief executive of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., should the Sony Corporation buy Columbia, a person involved in the acquisition talks said yesterday.

title: Schools Try to Adjust To a New Job Market
description: For decades, students who dropped out of high school had a kind of refuge. At a time when industry needed a steady supply of raw labor, they could usually find work in factories.

title: Dallas AIDS Survey Is Begun Amid a Furor Over Its Worth
description: After two years of false starts, Federal officials took the first steps yesterday toward beginning a national survey aimed at finding out how many Americans are infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Pierce Refuses to Answer Committee's Questions
description: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. refused today to answer questions from Congress about political favoritism in Federal housing programs, citing his Fifth Amendment right against compelled self-incrimination.

title: Hunting Rembrandt's Skeleton
description: In an effort to recover the bones of one of this city's greatest sons, scientists are peeling away thin layers of soil on the spot where they hope Rembrandt van Rijn was buried more than 300 years ago.

title: Bridge
description: Most enthusiasts who do not read this column rely daily on five major syndicated efforts. The youngest of these is the Aces column, founded two decades ago by the late Ira Corn Jr. The other four are associated with some the great figures in the early history of the game.

title: Food Notes
description: Sweet Wines . . .

title: Once Again, Louisianians Get Chance to Vote on Tax Increase
description: For the second time this year, Louisiana is trying to reinvent prosperity. The state's voters, who rejected a tax referendum in April, will go to the polls again on Oct. 7 to consider a tax increase intended to lift the state's nearly flat economy.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were slightly down during the week that ended yesterday.

title: Tax Exemption Would Boost Blood Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry A. Denehy, Executive, 69
description: Harry A. Denehy, an executive of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, died of a heart attack Friday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Huntington.

title: British Trade Deficit Lower
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit eased to $3.69 billion in August from a revised shortfall of $3.99 billion the previous month, but it was still the fourth-largest gap ever, the Government said today.

title: Suspect Denied Bail in Attack In Bensonhurst
description: A judge yesterday denied bail for the young man accused of firing the fatal shots in the Bensonhurst racial slaying and said that prosecutors had a strong case against him.

title: Helms Hires 1960's Civil Rights Figure as Adviser
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, who has often criticized the civil rights movement, has hired James H. Meredith, who was the first black to enroll at the University of Mississippi, as a domestic policy adviser.

title: Peter Bommarito Is Dead at 74; Led Rubber Workers for 15 Years
description: Peter Bommarito, who headed the United Rubber Workers Union from 1966 to 1981, died of cancer Monday at the Akron General Medical Center in Ohio. He was 74 years old and lived in Mogadore, on the outskirts of Akron.

title: Don't Help Pol Pot. Try Him.
description: Sometimes, nations are compelled to opt for the moral high ground rather than comply with a policy of alleged pragmatism that may produce an ethical abomination. Such is the situation in Cambodia today.

title: Potatoes Come To Power
description: A NEW guest came to the power lunch last winter: the potato. For years the power lunch was the dominion of dishes like pasta with wild mushrooms followed by plain grilled fish. But on Feb. 9 at 1:15 P.M., John Fairchild, publisher of Women's Wear Daily, assumed his accustomed perch in the Grill Room of the Four Seasons in Manhattan and ordered a baked potato.

title: On Holidays, Some Jews Say 'Mangia'
description: LEAD: WHILE American Jews of East European heritage enjoy a Rosh ha-Shanah meal this weekend of, say, gefilte fish, matzoh ball soup, roast turkey and carrot tsimmes, Italian-American Jews may sit down to striped bass, chicken soup with pasta, zucchini pudding and ceciarchiata, balls of dough glued together with honey.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase by 1.1% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday a 1.1 percent rise in short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended on Sept. 15.

title: Chinese in U.S. Report Harassment by Beijing
description: Chinese students in the United States say they have been harassed by representatives of the Beijing Government and threatened with reprisals if they take part in demonstrations on Sunday to show support for the democracy movement in their homeland.

title: Washington Talk; On Quayle In Search Of an Image As a Leader
description: Vice President Dan Quayle arrived in the Philippines tonight to discuss the future of American bases there, and he was confronted by several hundred left-wing demonstrators chanting, ''Quayle go home!''

title: 3 Networks Gain Viewers
description: Last week was the first of the new season, and viewer interest in what the three major networks had to offer was reflected in a 10-percentage-point increase over the previous week in the number of viewers watching ABC, CBS and NBC during prime time. The three-network share of the prime-time audience was 72, the highest since February, when CBS broadcast the mini-series ''Lonesome Dove,'' and the other networks countered with specials.

title: Apple Loses Court Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court ruled Monday that Apple Computer Inc. and its top officers must go to trial on the question of whether its optimistic statements about a office computer disk drive called Twiggy misled investors.

title: Real Estate; Developing City-Owned Marsh on S.I.
description: A REAL estate project on land owned by the people of New York City in an area of Staten Island few of them have ever seen may over the years add millions of dollars to the city's coffers.

title: Addy Oppenheimer Fieger, Composer, 58
description: Addy Oppenheimer Fieger, a composer whose songs were recorded and performed by Tommy Dorsey, Dean Martin and Sylvia Syms, among others, died of ovarian cancer Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 58 years old.

title: Starring Zsa Zsa and the Police
description: ''When he was chasing me I thought of the Gestapo. I can't help it. I wasn't scared in Europe. We had the Nazis, the Russian tanks. But I was here scared on Olympic and La Cienega. I didn't believe that an American taxpayer could be treated like this.''

title: Ravenna Journal; After the Unthinkable, the Sky Show Must Go On
description: He would be less than human, Capt. Giampaolo Miniscalco said, if he had no second thoughts about what he does for a living. Any sensible person would, he added, even if most people would probably call his job less than sensible.

title: 2 Movies Called 'Black Rain'
description: Two movies with the same title, ''Black Rain,'' have arrived almost simultaneously.

title: Is Rap Music as Harmful to Black Youth as White Institutions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Black-Footed Ferrets Ready For a Comeback in the Wilds
description: The populaton of black-footed ferrets, once believed extinct, is growing in captive breeding, and the first of the animals will eventually be set free near this tiny community in north-central Wyoming.

title: Asa Paul Ruskin, 60, Doctor and a Professor
description: Asa Paul Ruskin, director of rehabilitation medicine at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a ruptured abdominal aneurysm yesterday, his 60th birthday, at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. He lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Music; Early-Music Series Opens Season
description: Music Before 1800, the early-music series presented at Corpus Christi Church (529 West 121st Street), opened its 15th season on Sunday afternoon with a program that veered close to the modern edge of its mandate. In a joint concert, the Classical Quartet and members of the Mozartean Players gave solid, robust performances of Haydn and Mozart chamber works composed between 1778 and 1794.

title: Baseball's Other Hot Contests; Big Hitters Vie for Batting Crown but Might Not Admit It
description: Some players don't like to talk about it or even admit they know anything about it or are part of it.

title: Head of CUNY Graduate School Agrees to Retire
description: The president of the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York will retire under an agreement aimed at ending a power struggle between him and the university's Chancellor over leadership at the school, university trustees and administrators said yesterday.

title: Oil and Gas Industry Continues to Contract
description: The nation's oil and gas industry continued to contract last year, as did the value of its known reserves, but companies still operating raised their exploration budgets to the highest level since 1985, according to Arthur Andersen & Company.

title: Meeting on Education Starts Today in Virginia
description: President Bush will face the most important test yet of his pledge to be ''the education President'' here Wednesday when he assembles Cabinet members and the nation's governors to a two-day conference on education.

title: Morgan's Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $255,000 for the quarter and $562,000 for the 6 months.

title: A Self-Taught Film Maker Creates a Comic Hit
description: Judging from the frozen smile on his face, the standing, cheering ovation caught Michael Moore by surprise. The film maker, a solitary figure wearing a nylon-mesh baseball cap, stood awkwardly before an audience of 500 cheering filmgoers. They had just seen his first movie, ''Roger and Me,'' at the Toronto International Film Festival this month.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: NINE-YEAR-OLD Stacey Pitzrick recently told a playmate about her grandmother and three brothers living in Seoul. ''We don't know if any of what she said is true,'' said Deborah Pitzrick, who, along with her husband, Jerry, adopted Stacey from Korea when she was 8 1/2 months old.

title: Lennar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CBS News Is Investigating Charges It Used Staged Film
description: CBS News said yesterday that it was investigating allegations that the film it used purporting to show events during the war in Afghanistan in 1984 was staged and misrepresented by a freelance photographer. The film was carried on the ''CBS Evening News'' with Dan Rather.

title: Luther Medical Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Calendar of Events; Folk Art and Photos
description: History and Folk Art, New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street; 212-873-3400.

title: International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest quarter and 6 months' results included a pre-tax gain of $3,692,000 from the sale of a Canadian business, partially offset by $1,096,000 in costs associated with a reorganization. Year-ago quarter sales restated to conform to 1989 quarter presentation. Both year-ago periods' nets included gains of $345,000 and $4,514,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the sale of U.S. flour-milling business.

title: Consul Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Clarcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,133,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,233,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $889,000, or 11 cents a share, and $3,348,000, or 42 cents a share,, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The latest quarter and 9-month nets included $2,421,000 in expenses associated with a restructuring.

title: Mont Saint-Sauveur Intl Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $338,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $276,000, or 3 cents a share, for year-ago period. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Film Festival; A Sanskrit Epic About Gods, Warriors and Magic
description: ''The Mahabharata'' is above all a great yarn about a family feud. In reacting to American performances of Peter Brook's nine-hour theatrical interpretation of the Sanskrit poem that is India's national epic, critics tended to gloss over its raw narrative power. In the film version, however, the story is everything. In translating ''The Mahabharata'' from a theater piece into a film, Mr. Brook has trimmed it to just under three hours. Theatrical ritual has been minimized without sacrificing a sense of gravity, and the action has been opened up outdoors where the actors ride real horses into battle.

title: Sanmark-Stardust Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Share figures are restated to reflect a 5-for-3 stock split declared in December 1988.

title: Orbit Instrument reports earnings for Year of June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,674,000. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $907,000 and an accounting adjustment gain of $400,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Giuliani Drops Comedian Over Remarks
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the comedian Jackie Mason would no longer have a role in his mayoral campaign, after a newspaper quoted Mr. Mason as making racially charged remarks about blacks and Jews.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included extraordinary charges related to early retirement of debt of $950,000 for the quarter and $9,250,000 for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $15,300,000, or 70 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-Included an extraordinary charge related to early retirement of debt of $1,750,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $10,100,000, or 47 cents a share, from a capitalization of inventory costs.

title: Summagraphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Greentree Software reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sam Pierce Takes the Fifth
description: Samuel F. Pierce, whose career had been a series of distinguished ''firsts'' and ''onlys,'' this week became a sad third: the third member of a Presidential Cabinet ever to plead the Fifth Amendment before Congress.

title: El Carmen Journal; Blacks of South America Fight 'a Terrible Silence'
description: A high wall separated dusty cotton fields from a cool garden of acacia, bougainvillea and elephant vines coiled around towering palms. Relaxing on the plantation house veranda, Edilberto Lobaton coiled his fingers around a cold beer and savored the view.

title: Party Treasurer Says Democrats Rebound From Money Slump
description: The Democratic National Committee got a bullish report today from Robert A. Farmer, the party treasurer, who said the party had overcome a slow start in its 1989 fund raising.

title: Youth Is Arrested for Selling Crack That Bush Displayed
description: A teen-ager was arrested Tuesday on charges of selling the crack that President Bush displayed on television to illustrate the seriousness of the nation's drug problems.

title: Time for Ms. America (and Mr. America)
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Die as Plane Crashes On Grand Canyon Tour
description: A sightseeing plane crashed into a wooded hill near the Grand Canyon Airport here today, killing 10 people and injuring the 11 others aboard.

title: Opening in New York
description: The New York Sports Museum and Hall of Fame, the largest regional all-sports museum in the country, will open within two years in New York City, planners said yesterday.

title: Haas Proposal Is Rejected
description: The Commercial Intertech Corporation, a maker of hydraulic and other products in Youngstown, Ohio, said today that it had rejected an unsolicited buyout offer of $27.50 a share, or $355 million, from Haas & Partners Inc., a buyout group.

title: War: 1 Percent. Drugs: 54 Percent.
description: What do you think is the most important problem facing this country today?

title: Hoffman-La Roche Accord With Cetus
description: The Cetus Corporation reached an agreement with Hoffman-La Roche Inc. to develop pharmaceutical products based on Cetus's research in the field of oncogenes. Oncogenes are altered versions of normal genes that have been shown to cause cancer. Under the agreement, Hoffman-La Roche will help finance research and development at Cetus for five years. Hoffman will have the option to receive exclusive rights to market the resulting products worldwide, paying Cetus a royalty. Cetus can also be co-marketer in limited circumstances.

title: Braniff Halts Flights Amid Cash Squeeze
description: Braniff Inc. canceled most of its 150 flights yesterday afternoon amid a growing cash squeeze.

title: Review/Dance; Amid Gray Stones, Sadness and a Sense of the Primeval
description: In her haunting new dance solo, ''Requiem for the Living'' the experimental choreographer Molissa Fenley sits, kneels or lies on the floor -always encircled by stones.

title: Athletics Repeat as Winners in West; Giants Stumble to Title
description: Major league baseball's western division titles were finally settled last night as the season's dominant team, the Oakland A's, captured the American League West running away by trouncing the Texas Rangers, 5-0, in Oakland while the San Francisco Giants clinched the National League West only after the Cincinnati Reds defeated the second-place Padres in San Diego.

title: HURRICANE DAMAGE SLOWS AID EFFORT
description: Truckloads of food and teams of skilled workers arrived here today, six days after a hurricane swept through this port city. Thousands of residents of South Carolina's Low Country continued to live in public shelters, and fallen trees hampered the distribution of food and water and the restoration of electric power.

title: Penobscot Shoe Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net income

title: S.A.Y. Packaging Inc reports earnings for Year to June 3
Fuhr Dismisses Agent
description: Grant Fuhr, a goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers, announced yesterday in Edmonton that he had severed relations with his agent, Rich Winter, after deciding that Winter had not always acted in Fuhr's best interest. On June 10, Fuhr announced his retirement. He said he did not want to play because he was not receiving the respect he deserved and said he planned to sell cars. After sitting down for a talk with Glen Sather, the Oilers' general manager, Fuhr abandoned his retirement plans. (AP)

title: Team Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago net earnings results included a gain of $142,000 from investment tax credit and a gain of $283,000 from tax credits.

title: Spelling Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said figures included results of Worldvision Enterprises Inc. and Laurel Entertainment Inc. from the date of their acquisition, March 1. Results for the lastest fiscal year included $6 million from American Broadcasting Co. related to series commitments not fulfilled; this amount was substantially offset by the writedowns. Results for fiscal 1988 included non- recurring income of $3.5 million from ABC related to modification and extension of an agreement.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Money-Fund Yields Stable
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were unchanged to slightly higher for the week that ended yesterday.

title: At a Preview, a Steamy Social Bazaar
description: OLIVER BLICKSILVER selected one perfect radish from an array of crudites at the International Antique Dealers Show benefit last week. He was about to eat it when his fiancee, Margot Manning, waving a zucchini spear, cried, ''Wait! Is that radish vetted?'' ''Of course,'' Mr. Blicksilver replied, chomping away. The wares at the show were vetted for authenticity by experts, something its organizers said gave their new exhibition an edge on the competition, the Winter Antiques Show. Nobody vetted the 1,800 guests at the benefit last Friday, but three tall, blond chairwomen - Blaine Trump, Catie Marron and Dailey Pattee - greeted them with synchronized smiles near the entrance to the exhibition, at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Patriots to Start Flutie
description: Coach Raymond Berry, saying the slumping New England Patriots need a spark, benched Tony Eason as his starting quarterback yesterday and replaced him with Doug Flutie. Eason, struggling to rebound from two injury-plagued seasons, played poorly in losses to Miami and Seattle after doing well in a 27-24 season-opening victory against the Jets. Berry said Eason would be the third-string quarterback behind the 5-foot-10-inch Flutie and Steve Grogan on Sunday at Buffalo. (AP)

title: Celtics Plan to Buy a Radio Station
description: A week after disclosing that it had purchased a television station, the Boston Celtics L.P. announced today that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire WEEI, the team's flagship radio station.

title: Besicorp Group Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Arnold Johnson Is Dead at 84; A Leading American Communist
description: Arnold Johnson, a member of the national leadership of the Communist Party for many years, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Saks Chairman Plans Buyout
description: Melvin Jacobs, the chairman and chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue, said yesterday that he and the staff of the 46-store chain ''will definitely try to buy the company and are hopeful that we will win this game.'' Saks and Marshall Field &

title: Michael Sullivan, 54, A Telephone Executive
description: Michael J. Sullivan, president of the Empire City Subway Company, a subsidiary of New York Telephone, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital after being stricken on Broadway and 42d Street, on his way to a meeting. The cause of death has not been determined. He was 54 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: 3 Soldiers Killed by Wild Shell
description: Artillery fire at a practice range overshot its target today and struck a group of about 80 soldiers standing in formation, killing 3 and injuring 23 others, officials said.

title: East Europe: Superpowers Quietly Shake Hands
description: The Bush Administration and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union appear to have come to at least a tacit understanding about how their countries should relate to the Eastern Europe now emerging from the cold war.

title: Oracle Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said that in accordance with SFAS No. 86, $3,029,000 and $999,000 of software development costs, net amortization, were capitalized in the quarters ended Aug. 31, 1989 and 1988, respectively. Share earnings reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: Article 976589 -- No Title
description: The National Bank of Greece and a United States subsidiary have agreed to pay more than $2 million in fines for violations involving receipt of deposits in four states, the Federal Reserve said this week. Neither the bank nor the subsidiary, the National Mortgage Bank of Greece, based in Queens, admitted any wrongdoing, the Fed said.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING Longo Sets World Record: Jeannie Longo of France set a world record for five kilometers yesterday, covering the distance in 6 minutes 14.135 seconds at Mexico City. The record surpassed the mark of 6:14.813 she set on Sept. 16, 1987, in Colorado Springs.(AP) BOXING Griffin Advances: Eric Griffin of Houston scored a victory last night in the world amateur championships at Moscow and moved within one victory of a gold medal in the 106-pound division. The 21-year-old Griffin earned his third victory of the tournament by outpointing Kim Dok Nam of North Korea, 20-10. (AP) TENNIS Jarryd Gains: Anders Jarryd upset eighth-seeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the Volvo of San Francisco tournament. Also gaining a quarterfinal berth was fifth-seeded Kevin Curren of Barton Creek, Tex., who defeated Todd Witsken of Carmel, Ind., 6-4, 3-6, 6-1.(AP) PRO HOCKEY Islanders Defeat Devils: The Islanders, with more regulars in their lineup than the Devils, posted a 6-3 exhibition game victory over the Devils last night before a sparse crowd at Nassau Coliseum.

title: A Brooklyn Home Aglow With Time
description: THE Austrian-born artist David O'Clock will not reveal his real last name (It is ''unpronounceable,'' he says), but it is safe to say that the former stage designer is obsessed with time.

title: Bridge
description: There are times when opposing activity indicates that a normal contract is undesirable. On the diagramed deal from the recent world team championships in Perth, Australia, most North-South pairs played in three no-trump and failed by at least one trick.

title: A Machine to Control PC Network
description: A start-up computer company introduced a set of machines today that analysts and industry officials predicted could open up a new battlefront in the computer industry.

title: Campaign Matters; Are Debates An Opportunity Or a Minefield?
description: rrHistory is fickle when it comes to declaring the winner in political debates. Victory, it turns out, does not always go to those who score the most debating points, but to those candidates, like Abraham Lincoln in 1858 or John F. Kennedy in 1960, who have the most to gain and the least to lose.

title: Outdoors; A Contest for Callers of the Wild
description: If you cherish the notion that you are a skillful caller of ducks and geese, you might wish to enter the contest that will be part of the Long Island Wildfowl Carvers' annual decoy show, Saturday and Sunday at the Sands Point Preserve in Port Washington.

title: Offering by New York City Is Repriced to Lower Yields
description: New York City's issue of $700 million in general obligation bonds, which was initially priced on Tuesday, has been revised and repriced to offer slightly lower yields in the longer maturities. Serial bonds running from 1990 to 2002 remained unchanged.

title: Henley Group Plans To Become 2 Concerns
description: The Henley Group Inc. said today that it planned to separate into two public corporations: a real estate concern called Henley Properties Inc. and a new industrial company, the Henley Group Inc.

title: Angeion Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and share earnings was less than one cent a share. The company became public July 5, 1988.

title: Top Yield Is 7.20% On Texas Bonds
description: The Texas Municipal Power Agency is offering $196.1 million in refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.20 percent for bonds due 2002 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Swarthmore Journal; Life's Quest Rewarded, 84 Trillion Miles Away
description: ''That's my baby,'' said Prof.

title: Article 074489 -- No Title
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is seeking a new and much tougher round of penalties against polluters it says are still dumping chemicals and untreated wastes into the Grand Calumet River in northwest Indiana, one of the nation's most highly industrialized and contaminated waterways.

title: AFP Imaging Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Appeal on Guard Ruling
description: Gov.
