Rudy Perpich said Tuesday that he was asking the United States Supreme Court to review an appeals court's decision upholding a Federal law that stripped governors of their veto power over National Guard training missions. Congress enacted the law after several governors, including Mr. Perpich, had objected to deployment of National Guard personnel on maneuvers in Central America, where the governors felt there was a danger of military involvement.

title: D'Amato Rating Is Down in Poll
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's job approval rating has fallen to its lowest point in more than six years, an independent poll reported today.

title: Dense-Pac Microsystems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Net income

title: Cabano Expeditex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 22
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $804,000, or 7 cents a share. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hartmarx Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Corruption Trial for Papandreou Is Ordered by Greece's Parliament
description: In the same forum where Andreas Papandreou dominated Greek political life for more than a decade, Parliament voted early today to order the former Prime Minister to stand trial on criminal charges, including bribery and receiving stolen funds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Burger King Campaign: 'Break Rules'
description: REELING from years of stagnant growth, the acquisition of its parent company and almost annual changes in advertising agencies, the Burger King Corporation yesterday opened the latest chapter in its marketing melodrama by telling consumers, ''Sometimes you've gotta break the rules.''

title: Dow Up 9.12 on Late Buying of Blue Chips
description: A late round of futures-related buying pushed blue-chip stocks higher yesterday, but the overall market was mixed on moderate volume.

title: Triple Play Not Enough To Stop Cubs
description: One night after celebrating the clinching of the National League East title, the Cubs kept their momentum going with a 7-2 victory tonight over the Montreal Expos despite hitting into a triple play for the second time this season.

title: Ex-Astronaut to Head General Dynamics
description: William A. Anders, one of three astronauts who circled the moon on Christmas Eve 1968, has been named the next chairman and chief executive of the General Dynamics Corporation, the big military supplier, effective Jan. 1, 1991.

title: Downtrodden Cowboys Awaiting Arrival of the Giants
description: When the Giants travel to Dallas to play the Cowboys on Sunday, they will find that America's Team has become America's Nightmare.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Magazine Ad Offends Chains
description: Several department and grocery-store chains have removed seven women's magazines from their shelves because the publications contained an ad showing a nude woman. Wal-Mart Stores, Vons and

title: National Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the results included a charge of $2.5 million, before taxes, for the accelerated depreciation of certain assets due to the expected restructuring of the company's voice centers in conjunction with the US Sprint contract termination in February 1990.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: ''YOU'RE going to love this,'' a friend said, and handed me a paperback titled ''Suddenly at the Priory.'' She was not referring to the book's literary quality - it has none - but to its subject: a Victorian murder. I have many books about Victorian murders, none of them fiction and almost all of them about women who may, or may not, have had access to antimony. Or arsenic. Or chloroform. I visualize a Victorian medicine cabinet, skulls and crossbones row on row.

title: INSIDE
description: Charter Battle Begins

title: Market Place; Earnings Outlook Mediocre to Poor
description: WITH the third quarter drawing to a close, Wall Street is expecting a mediocre to poor profit performance from corporate America and sees little reason to expect that to change in the final three months of 1989.

title: Fuller (H.B.) Co (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Gelman Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included credit from cumulative effect of $240,000 on prior periods of an accounting change for income taxes recorded in the quarter ended Oct. 31, 1989.

title: Sony Has High Hopes For Columbia Pictures
description: By the time Norio Ohga left Sony headquarters here tonight, certain that his quest for one of Hollywood's hottest properties was finally successful, he was well on his way to transforming the company that more than any other has symbolized the breakthroughs of Japanese business in the decades since World War II.

title: Juno Lighting reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included gain of $165,000, or 2 cents a share, from change in method of accounting for income taxes. Juno said the latest quarter and 9 months' figures included the consolidated results of Indy Lighting Inc., acquired in November 1988.

title: Canseco's Lukewarm 900 Line
description: rrIn baseball, 900 has never been much of a number. Henry Aaron and Babe Ruth didn't hit that many homers. Tris Speaker didn't even hit that many doubles. Cy Young didn't pitch that many victories. No team has ever had that high a winning percentage. Nobody ever made a fuss over a 900th hit or a 900th strikeout. The only 900 number of any significance in baseball is 938, Lou Brock's record career total of stolen bases.

title: DEALS
description: Baseball YANKEES (AL) - Obtained Fred Toliver, pitcher, from the San Diego Padres to complete the trade that sent Mike Pagliarulo, third baseman, to San Diego. HOUSTON (NL) - Announced the retirement of Craig Reynolds, infielder, effective at the end of the season. Senior Pro Baseball GOLD COAST - Signed Stan Bahnsen, pitcher, Orlando Gonzalez, first baseman; and Bobby Ramos, catcher. ORLANDO - Signed J. R. Richard, pitcher, and Tom Paciorek, first baseman. ST. LUCIE - Signed Don Cooper, pitcher, and Garth Iorg, infielder. ST. PETERSBURG - Signed Marc Hill, catcher. WINTER HAVEN - Signed Bernie Carbo and Ben Oglivie, outfielders; Ferguson Jenkins, pitcher; Dalton Jones, infielder, and Rick Wise, pitcher. Basketball WASHINGTON (NBA) - Signed Grady Mateen, center, and Lashaun McDaniel, guard. GRAND RAPIDS (CBA) - Signed Tracy Pearson, center. Football BUFFALO (AFC) - Signed James Lofton, wide receiver. Placed Derrick Burroughs, cornerback, on the injured reserve list. DALLAS (NFC) - Promoted Eric Brown, defensive back, from the developmental squad to the active roster. Added Warren Bone, tight end, and Gary Wilkerson, defensive back, to the developmental squad. PHOENIX (NFC) - Signed Tony Baker running back. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Resigned Tom Holmoe safety. Waived Steve Hendrickson linebacker. Announced the retirement of Jeff Stover, defensive end. SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed Jeff Chadwick wide receiver. Released Willie Bouyer wide receiver. Waived Johnnie Johnson, safety. BRITISH COLUMBIA (CFL)- Traded Gerald Roper, guard, to Ottawa for Leo Groenewegen, guard. EDMONTON (CFL) - Dave Richardson, guard, on the injured list. OTTAWA (CFL) - Released Byron Williams, wide receiver. SASKATCHEWAN (CFL) - Placed Bryan Illerbrun, guard, to the injured list. TORONTO (CFL) - Added Willie Pless, linebacker, to the practice roster. WINNIPEG (CFL) - Added Robert Mimbs, running back, to the practice roster.

title: Mattresses In Any Size Or Shape
description: AT the factory under the Bruckner Expressway in the Bronx, mattresses, box springs and daybeds have been made in the same manner for 57 years. ''All done by hand, start to finish,'' said Ted Marschke, the president of Charles H. Beckley, a manufacturer of custom bedding.

title: Quest BioTechnology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company did not recognize revenues in the latest quarter.

title: Many Drown in Lake Victoria
description: A boat ferrying 40 fishermen and traders from Mfanganu Island to the Kenyan mainland capsized in Lake Victoria on Tuesday, newspapers reported today. The Daily Nation said 33 people drowned.

title: Hasbro to Stop Animal Testing
description: Hasbro Inc. said Tuesday that it would no longer use white rats, rabbits and other animals to test children's cosmetics for safety.

title: Fairchild Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,258,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,458,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $4,202,000, or 29 cents a share, and $5,511,000, or 39 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary tax credits of $3,678,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,426,000, or 38 cents a share, for the 6 months. The company said earnings from discontinued operations in the year- ago quarter and 6 months included a $2.5 million gain on sale of a discontinued operation. Year-earlier results are restated to reflect discontinued operations for the period ended July 3, 1988.

title: NASA's Reliance on Contractors Is Seen as Eroding Its Capabilities
description: The space agency, long known for its technical expertise, has become so dependent on private contractors that it may be losing its ability to manage its operations, maintain safety and control costs, senior officials say.

title: Some of Hong Kong's People Get Pledge of Post-'97 British Refuge
description: The British Foreign Secretary outlined new proposals today that he said would make it easier for some Hong Kong citizens to move to Britain if China limits their Western-style freedoms after it takes control of the British crown colony in 1997.

title: Cement Makers Fault Mexicans
description: A group of seven cement manufacturers has complained to Federal officials that Mexican competitors are unfairly selling cement in the United States at cut-rate prices.

title: FMS and Fidelity to Join
description: The FMS Financial Corporation and the Fidelity Mutual Savings and Loan Association signed a letter of intent on Tuesday pledging to combine operations. FMS Financial is the holding company for Farmers' and Mechanics' Savings Bank, which has its administrative offices in Burlington Township, N.J., and seven branches throughout Burlington County. Fidelity Mutual, based in Westmont, operates two branch offices in Camden County.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Education page on Sept. 20 listing salaries of college chief executives referred incorrectly to the president of Rockefeller University. He is Joshua Lederberg. The chart also omitted a source for the figures. It was The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Perennials: The Fancy Isn't Fleeting
description: THE passion for perennials continues. Gardeners hate to admit that fashions in plants wax and wane, but it seems that no one is wearying just yet of this extraordinary group, whose renaissance began a decade ago. And since the planting and transplanting of perennials traditionally continues through autumn, gardeners have time aplenty to alter their gardens and dreams.

title: Rise in Disciplining of Doctors Is Reported
description: Disciplinary actions against American doctors have risen steadily in recent years, reflecting more stringent state regulation and news media focus on the misbehavior of doctors, officials of the Federation of State Medical Boards said today.

title: American League; Jays Maintain One-Game Edge
description: The tightest race in major league baseball drew a notch tighter last night as the Toronto Blue Jays and the Baltimore Orioles won games against noncontending opponents and their battle for the American League East championship came down to a final squeeze in Toronto this weekend.

title: OPEC Meeting Fails To Set New Quotas
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries came close today to dismantling its system of quotas, ending a meeting without agreement on how much oil each of its members will produce in the final quarter of the year.

title: Keeping the Best Gardens a Joy Forever
description: IN the past decade, not just gardening but garden visiting has become one of America's most popular pastimes. On Sunday, at an open house here at the Ruth Bancroft Dry Garden, 20 miles east of San Francisco, a new chapter begins in American garden history. The event will introduce the Garden Conservancy, a national organization devoted to preserving exceptional American gardens for public viewing.

title: LOSS OF $4 BILLION IS FOUND IN AUDIT OF MORTGAGE FUND
description: An independent audit of several Federal funds that insure mortgages shows that they had a record loss of $4.2 billion last year.

title: Northwest Deal Seen Changing
description: The Secretary of Transportation has persuaded the group that acquired Northwest Airlines to reduce the investment of a foreign airline in the deal, and is expected to use the case as a precedent for a new policy on how much equity a foreign carrier can put up in the buyout of a domestic airline, an airline-industry official said yesterday.

title: 'STAR WARS' FADING AS MAJOR ELEMENT OF U.S. STRATEGY
description: After six years of steadily increasing financial support, the space-based anti-missile program that President Reagan said would make nuclear weapons ''impotent and obsolete,'' is facing a declining budget and a diminishing role in American military planning.

title: Unhappy Birthday
description: Forty years ago this Sunday, from the wall overlooking Tiananmen Square, Mao Zedong declared the establishment of the People's Republic of China. For the crowd waving red banners in the square, and for millions of Chinese elsewhere, it was a moment of hope for a reborn China, united and democratic.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $8,660,000, or 8 cents a share, for the latest year and $12,018,000, or 11 cents a share, for 1988.

title: 'The Bellarosa Connection'
description: The subject of memory pervades Saul Bellow's intriguing but ultimately elusive new novella, ''The Bellarosa Connection,'' which is the second short work of fiction, after ''The Theft,'' that the 1976 Nobel laureate in literature has brought out as a paperback original this year.

title: U.N.A.  Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Olco Petroleum Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago figures have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: E. L. Pavlo, 83, Dies; A Designer of Bridges
description: E. Lionel Pavlo, a civil engineer and specialist in suspension bridge design, died Sept. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Johannesburg Acts to Ease Segregation
description: The city of Johannesburg opened swimming pools and recreational centers to all races today and proceeded with plans to desegregate buses.

title: Philip Morris Executive To Retire at End of Year
description: John M. Richman, vice chairman of the Philip Morris Companies Inc. and head of its Kraft General Foods division, plans to retire at the end of the year and open a Chicago office for the New York City law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

title: The Warp and Weft of History, on Display
description: A story has it that when Franco Scalamandre - a man who knew more than most about the place of fabrics in history - heard after World War II that atomic power was being considered for peaceful uses, he cried out: ''Hurry up! Make a split-atom textile!''

title: Stalled Talks in Phone Strike Due to Resume
description: Officials of the Nynex Corporation and the two unions representing 60,000 of its employees are expected to resume bargaining today for the first time in nearly two weeks. But spokesmen for each side said they did not expect a quick resolution to the strike, which is in its eighth week.

title: AutoInfo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Chrysler Buyback Plan to Continue
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it was continuing its stock repurchase program to reduce its outstanding common stock to 200 million shares from about 232 million shares. Chrysler said it was making the statement in response to inquiries regarding its sale last week of about 45 percent of its holdings in the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan.

title: School Bus Safety Costs 1 Cent a Day per Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxi Panel Rejects Plan for 400 New Medallions
description: A proposal to issue 400 new yellow-cab medallions, the first since 1937, was rejected yesterday by the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission. Opponents argued that the city did not need more taxis than the 11,787 it already has.

title: David Rowe, 65, a Management Consultant
description: David Knox Rowe, a retired management consultant, died of heart failure yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 More Airports to Get Advanced Bomb Detectors
description: Detroit, Washington and Frankfurt have been added to the list of cities receiving the first new bomb detectors the Federal Aviation Administration is installing at domestic and foreign airports, the agency said yesterday.

title: Golden Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PEN Celebrates Freedoms Gained in Eastern Europe
description: The members of International PEN seemed joyful about the limited return of freedom of expression to eastern Europe when they gathered here this week for the group's 54th annual congress.

title: Terrell Says End Is Near, But Wins
description: Walt Terrell knows this feeling. He knows it because he has sensed it before, in New York with the Mets, then in Detroit and San Diego. And now here.

title: Irving Berlin Is Buried In a Private Ceremony
description: Irving Berlin was buried Tuesday afternoon at a private ceremony in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

title: LEARNING JUST WHAT PLANTS DO
description: To children growing up in New York City, it may seem that fruits and vegetables are grown in supermarkets, that trees are street decorations set 30 feet apart on the sidewalk and that plants are native to small ceramic pots dotting the windowsill.

title: Roadway Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
Israeli Faces Prison For Meeting Arafat
description: An Israeli prosecutor today demanded a prison term for the longtime peace campaigner Abie Nathan for meeting Yasir Arafat last year in violation of an Israeli terrorism law.

title: Cavaliers Sign Mokeski
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers yesterday signed Paul Mokeski, a 7-foot free agent center-forward with nine seasons of experience in the National Basketball Association. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. The 32-year-old Mokeski played for the Milwaukee Bucks for the last six and a half seasons.(AP)

title: Apparel America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The acquisitions of Mayfair Industries and Primo Designs accounted for 152 percent of the increase in sales in the 6-month period ended July 31, 1989, while the Robby Len swimwear division accounted for 11 percent.

title: Reeds Jewelers reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $446,000, resulting from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: Inquiry Finds Rudder Flaw In Jet Crash
description: Examination of the USAir jetliner that plunged into the East River last week on a takeoff from La Guardia Airport shows a rudder misalignment that has drawn major attention from investigators.

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies of Sports Pages on Tuesday, showing a lone golfer after the Ryder Cup matches, misidentified him. He was Fred Couples, not Mark Calcavecchia.

title: Latest Pentagon Report Lifts Shadow of Soviet Menace, a Bit
description: It is not quite a paean to perestroika. But the Pentagon issued a new report on the Soviet military today that is a far cry from the catalogue of the Soviet empire's evils published annually by the Reagan Administration - and even a bit more muted than the public statements of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

title: Warriors Send Sampson To Kings for Petersen SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL; Patriots to Start Flutie SPORTS PEOPLE:PRO HOCKEY; Fuhr Dismisses Agent SPORTS PEOPLE: SPORTS MUSEUM; Opening in New York
description: Ralph Sampson, twice the College Player of the Year and the National Basketball Association's top rookie in 1984, was traded by the Golden State Warriors last night for Jim Peterson, a center-forward for the Sacramento Kings. The trade is contingent upon both players' passing physical examinations.

title: Review/Television; 'Lost Angeles,' a Bleak Story of the Homeless
description: During the summer of 1987, the City of Los Angeles moved about 600 homeless people from the streets to a temporary tent city and promised them help in getting jobs. Tom Seidman, a young documentary maker, brought camera and sympathy into this urban camp ground; his painfully close-up report, ''Lost Angeles: The Story of Tent City,'' can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: Thomas Mulroy, 84, Chicago Civic Leader
description: Thomas R. Mulroy, a lawyer who was a former president of the Chicago Crime Commission, died Monday at Lakeland Hospital in Elkhorn, Wis., after suffering a stroke on Saturday. He was 84 years old and lived in Lake Geneva, Wis.

title: Less Than Frank About the Mail
description: With great bravado, the Senate earlier this month voted to eliminate free postage for Congressional mass mailings and to use the money saved to help drug-addicted pregnant women. The House, not to be outdone, ringingly endorsed the idea this week by a vote of 245 to 137.

title: Treasuries Dip in Light Trading
description: As dealers struggled to absorb a new $7.75 billion issue of four-year notes, prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in light trading yesterday.

title: Prudential Sues Three Law Firms
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America filed a $31 million lawsuit yesterday against three law firms, arguing that their negligence and legal malpractice had caused it heavy losses.

title: Keystone Chief Says Buyout Is 'Feather in Career Cap'
description: George S. Bissell, who 10 years ago acquired the Keystone mutual funds for the Travelers Corporation, is now part of an investment group that is buying the mutual funds from the insurance company.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about magazine publishers beginning publications abroad omitted the end of a comment from Paul DuCharme of Grey Advertising. His comment, on the sale of international advertising packages in magazines, was: ''If we look at it on a discount basis, we'd expect to get that space for free. But the European media won't want to give it away for free. I can't see international advertising packages.''

title: Groups Taking Donations to Help Hurricane Victims
description: A relief effort to help hurricane victims in Charleston, S.C., and the surrounding area has been set up at the Charleston City Hall. The phone number for those wishing to help is 803-720-3838.

title: Hope and Dissent Blend In Education Conference
description: President Bush opened his education conference with the nation's governors today in an atmosphere of hope tinged with division and uncertainty over how best to improve the nation's ailing schools.

title: Group Offers Money In AIDS Survey Protest
description: A gay rights group that opposes a national survey aimed at finding out how many Americans are infected with the AIDS virus offered $100 today to the first person who refuses to participate in the door-to-door survey.

title: Image Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net income figures are on a pro forma basis. This is the company first quarterly result announcement since the successful sale of its initial public offering on Aug. 17. The company said per share results do not reflect the 1,495,000 shares sold in its initial public offering.

title: Mubarak's Offer: A Dramatic Test
description: President Hosni Mubarak's offer to bring Israelis and Palestinians together for peace talks on Egyptian soil is rational, sober and respectful of Israeli sensitivities. If such initiatives are blocked by the rejectionism that frustrated peace openings in the 1980's, there will be little to expect beyond the defeat of realism and escalating violence in a region packed with deadly weaponry.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BUILDING a small corner closet is not too difficult, even for novice carpenters. Because the closet walls bear no weight of the ceiling above, they can be made with lightweight materials and they require only minimal fastening. But it is wise to consult a building inspector before beginning.

title: Stride Rite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $566,000 and $1,850,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $1,723,000, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principles.

title: VWR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Pepsi-Cola Sets Shift Overseas
description: Pepsi-Cola International, a unit of Pepsico Inc., said yesterday that it was realigning its overseas soft drink operations and had named Christopher A. Sinclair as its president.

title: Hydrogen Pushed as Motor Fuel
description: Recent advances in the efficiency of cells that convert solar energy to electricity are increasing the possibility of using hydrogen as a practical, low-polluting motor vehicle fuel, according to a new study by two Princeton University physicists that was released here today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Patricia Stewart and Alan Saperstein have been named executive vice presidents of Campbell-Mithun-Esty/ New York.

title: Small Business Repays Investor Confidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Of the Forgetfulness of a Memory Expert
description: The Bellarosa Connection By Saul Bellow 102 pages. Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: Aska of Japan Buys Stake in Christie's
description: Christie's International P.L.C., the fine art auction house, said the Aska International Company of Tokyo bought the 7.2 percent stake sold by the Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court. The secretary of Christie's, David N. Allison, said the company was uncertain of Aska's goals in acquiring the stake. Mr. Holmes a Court acquired his shares in December. He told the auction house earlier this month that he intended to sell the stake.

title: Toyota Increases 1990 Prices by 1.8%
description: The Toyota Motor Company raised its prices in the United States for the company's 1990 cars by an average of 1.8 percent, or by about $178, from the final 1989 retail price. The company said the increase was its first since the 1989 models were introduced last fall. It said the 1990 prices reflected installation of more safety equipment, new-model changes and product upgradings.

title: 1980 Soviet Rocket Accident Killed 50
description: The Soviet Union ended decades of secrecy today by opening the world's busiest spaceport to foreign journalists and revealing one of the worst disasters of the space age - an explosion of a Vostok rocket during fueling that killed 50 people in 1980.

title: New Hewlett Work Station
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a new computer work station today that is based on its proprietary HP Precision Architecture, which uses reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, for faster operation. At a base price of $19,375, the HP 9000 Model 834CH is now the least expensive entry in the company's HP-PA line. Delivery is estimated at eight weeks.

title: Canada Seen as Major Haven For Laundering Drug Money
description: Canada is quickly becoming a major haven for laundering illegal drug profits from the United States, law-enforcement authorities from both countries say.

title: I.B.M. Sees Shortfall In Profits
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings would be sharply lower than expected because of delays in introducing products, the effects of a stronger dollar and a switch by some customers to leasing, rather than buying, its products.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Philip Morris Exceeds $2 Billion in Ad Spending
description: With the added expenses of its newly acquired Kraft Inc. subsidiary, the Philip Morris Companies last year became the first company to spend more than $2 billion in advertising and promotions, according to an annual list published by Advertising Age magazine.

title: Fed Approves Banks' Deal
description: The Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday approved the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's purchase of 11 New York-area branches and a public accommodation office from Goldome of Buffalo.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aircoa Hotel Partners L.P., Denver, a hotel operator, closed the sale of its Kona Village Resort, Hawaii, for $55 million to Kona Village Associates.

title: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
93 Kilos of Cocaine Seized, Some Labeled 'Bush'
description: Federal investigators confiscated 93 kilos of cocaine in a raid on a house in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday, and the name Bush was written on several of the packages, law enforcement officials said.

title: On-Line Software International reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $151,000 related to the reacquisition of debt. c-Net loss and included an extraordinary credit of $1,310,000 related to the reacquisition of debt. Results for the latest first quarter included about $600,000 of non-recurring charges related to repositioning the company's case product offerings. Certain expenses for 1988 have been reclassified.

title: MDS Health Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Tom Bradley Topped Dinkins in White Vote; Peace and Harmony?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Harry A. Denehy, an executive of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons who died Friday, misstated his age. He was 59 years old, not 69.

title: Sensormatic Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,653,000.

title: Election Fever in Chicago Schools As Parents File for Council Seats
description: In the first test of Chicago's ambitious plan to transfer power from the central education board to parent-led councils at each of the city's public schools, 7,972 parents have declared their candidacies so far.

title: Gadgets Taken to Cambodia Ease Strain of Foreign Press
description: The invasion of at least 250 representatives of the foreign press here to report what Vietnam and Cambodia say is the final withdrawal of Hanoi's troops has strained the resources of this isolated country, which is still recovering from the depredations of Khmer Rouge rule.

title: Classical Niche, Modern Refrigerator
description: TIRED of that unsightly refrigerator? Byron Bell, an architect, came up with a novel solution for Winston and Carole Kulok, who live in a 150-year-old Greek Revival house in Greenwich Village.

title: Abortion Drug Developer Gets Lasker Award
description: The developer of a drug that brings on abortion early in pregnancy was named yesterday as a winner of the Lasker Award, one of the most prestigious medical research prizes.

title: Cognos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said its restructuring resulted in a $1.5 million pre-tax charge to income in the latest second quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Palme Case: A Field Day for the Conspiracy Set
description: Three years and seven months after Prime Minister Olof Palme was killed in central Stockholm, and two months after a 42-year-old derelict was convicted of the crime, the Palme case refuses to go away.

title: Star Wedtech Witness Takes His Final Curtain
description: Mario Moreno, the Government's star witness in the bribery case against Representative Robert Garcia, was on the witness stand yesterday blandly describing bribes and lies, influence-peddling, slush-fund payoffs, stock manipulation, fake passports and foreign bank accounts.

title: Hungary's Parliament Backs Free Expression
description: The Hungarian Parliament passed a law today that gives people the right to express opinions or advocate political and social change, further expanding freedom of speech before multiparty elections next year.

title: Compromise Is Proposed on Helms Amendment
description: A possible compromise emerged today as a House-Senate conference committee met for the first time to consider the so-called Helms amendment to restrict Federal grants for obscene or indecent art.

title: A Historic Florida Pool Is Renewed
description: IN 1924 the artist Denman Fink and the architect Phineas Paist transformed a coral rock quarry into what Florida postcards soon called ''the most beautiful outdoor swimming pool in the world.'' With its green lagoons, shady porticoes, vine-covered loggias and tile-roofed towers, the ''Venetian pool'' in Coral Gables became the perfect backdrop for William Jennings Bryan and others expounding the virtues of Florida.

title: Cypress Opposes U.S. Memories Concept
description: Cypress Semiconductor Inc. said today that its president, T. J. Rodgers, had offered an alternative to the proposed joint venture that is intended to revive production in the United States of the most commonly used memory chips.

title: Recognition Trial Opens
description: A Dallas company tried to win a $400 million contract to build mail-sorting equipment by buying a member of the United States Postal Service's board of governors, a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: In Son's Slaying, a Father Finds His Mission
description: For Moses J. Stewart, a black security guard whose 16-year-old son, Yusuf K. Hawkins, was surrounded by a gang of young whites a month ago and shot to death, this is a time of bitter reawakening.

title: Samuel S. Haber, 66, Textile Executive, Dies
description: Samuel S. Haber, president of Samuel Haber's Sons, a division of QST Industries, Inc., international distributors of textile linings and other apparel components, died of cancer Sunday at Michael Reese Medical Center, Chicago. He was 66 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Prime Medical Services reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $14,513,000. The company said 1989 results included a provision for closing several low margin cardiac centers and expenses relating to the company's lawsuit against former management and directors.

title: Correction
description: Lloyd N. Cutler's article Monday misidentified the sponsor of a Senate bill to control automatic assault weapons and a provision of the bill. The sponsor is Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. The bill would bar the domestic sale (not the manufacture) of such weapons.

title: Fearing Dickerson, Jets Shake Up Defensive Line
description: With a league low of one sack, the Jets revamped their defensive line today. The three players they moved to the line may not be any better at chasing quarterbacks, but they can stop runners.

title: Nantucket Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,805,249, or 68 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,227,902, or 46 cents a share, for the 6 months, and after an extraordinary credit of $257,000, or 10 cents a share, for the both periods. The company said year-ago periods' nets from discontinued operations included a gain of $2,184,151 from disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Democrats Propose Major Cuts In Expanded Medicare Program
description: In an effort to avoid total repeal of expanded health insurance for older Americans, House Democratic leaders today proposed eliminating most major features of the program and the surtax that helps pay for it.

title: Cambodian Factions Cry Sham in Hanoi's Pullout
description: A new diplomatic struggle is being waged here over Vietnam's announcement of the withdrawal of its occupation forces from Cambodia, with Cambodian opposition leaders trying to convince the nations of the world that the pullout is a sham.

title: Catholics Meet on Gay Role in Clergy
description: More than 100 people from Roman Catholic institutions in the New York area gathered here today to discuss a subject rarely talked about openly - homosexuality among priests, nuns and religious brothers.

title: Soviet-U.S. Fish Net Plan
description: Seeking to protect a declining population of salmon and other fish in the North Pacific, United States and Soviet negotiators have agreed to cooperate in monitoring the use of giant drift nets that sweep up large amounts of sea life, the State Department has announced.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; First Nationwide Bank Gives Account to Y.&R.
description: During a week in which its New York headquarters were closed for a day by a steam-pipe explosion, Young & Rubicam has found solace in San Francisco. Yesterday, the agency's office there was awarded the advertising account of First Nationwide Bank. Y.&R. edged out J. Walter Thompson and Wells, Rich, Greene to win the account, which an agency spokesman said was worth between $15 million and $20 million.

title: Security Tightened for Officials
description: Several senior Government officials have received added security to deter possible attacks by Colombia's drug rings, an Administration official said today.

title: New Study Says Diuretics Raise Heart Attack Risks
description: Diuretics, the most widely used class of drugs against high blood pressure, can cause biochemical changes that make people more susceptible to heart attacks, researchers have found.

title: Ellison Has Surgery
description: Doctors at University Medical Center in Sacramento, Calif., said yesterday they successfully removed bone spurs on the right foot and ankle of Pervis Ellison, the Sacramento Kings' No. 1 draft choice this year. Dr. Richard Marder, the team's orthopedic surgeon, said Ellison was released as an outpatient after the 30-minute operation. Full recovery is expected in six to eight weeks, Dr. Marder said. The 6-foot-10-inch, 225-pound Ellison, from the University of Louisville, remains unsigned.

title: Abortion Opponents Protest at Prosecutor's Home
description: Opponents of abortion demonstrated Tuesday night at the home of a city solicitor, who called the protest an intimidation effort that would not stop him from prosecuting Operation Rescue's leader on trespassing charges.

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Chip Sales Seen Rising in '89
description: Sales of the worldwide semiconductor industry are projected to reach $49.1 billion in 1989, up 9 percent from $45 billion in 1988, a trade group reported today.

title: United Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $369,000, or 3 cents a share, and $764,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included a charge due to the reversal of a tax credit of $241,000. The year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restated to correct the amortization of product introduction costs previously reported.

title: American Western In Carlisle Merger
description: The American Western Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by Carlisle Plastics Inc. for $12.50 a share in cash, a lower price than the companies had agreed upon. Based on American Western's 5.6 million shares outstanding, the offer has a value of $69 million, but with the assumption of debt, American Western valued the deal at $115 million.

title: The Rolling Stones Add Fifth Concert at Shea
description: The Rolling Stones' ''Steel Wheels'' tour has added a fifth date to its Shea Stadium performances, on Tuesday, Oct. 10, at 7 P.M. The date, which precedes by two weeks the band's sold-out four-night stand at Shea, became available when the New York Mets were eliminated from the National League East pennant race on Monday. All seats are reserved, with tickets going on sale tomorrow at 9 A.M. They may be purchased at all Ticketmaster outlets or may be charged by calling (212) 307-7171, (516) 888-9000, (201) 507-8900 or (914) 965-2700. The ticket price is $30, plus any local service charge. There is a limit of eight tickets per person.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bertelsmann Music Group, a music and video production company that is a unit of Bertelsmann A.G. of West Germany, named Joel M. Schoenfeld senior vice president and general counsel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Canada is becoming a money haven for drug profits as traffickers try to avoid American banking laws intended to curb money laundering, law enforcement officials say. Page A1

title: Pending Issues In Airline Deal
description: HAL Acquisition Inc., an investment group including Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, that has agreed to acquire Hawaiian Airlines, said today that ''numerous unresolved issues'' remained in its negotiations with the unions of the Honolulu-based airline.

title: Master Joker Who Never Forgets
description: After nearly seven decades in show business, Bob Hope has a joke for every occasion. In the new fireproof vault in the gatehouse of his six-acre estate, there are 16 filing cabinet drawers filled with folders labeled by categories: golf miscellaneous, golf American Presidents, gambling, gay liberation, dieting, pollution, religion, weather, dude ranches. In the old vault down the hall, there are 15 steel drawers of jokes he has rejected.

title: State Farm Claims
description: The State Farm Insurance Company said Tuesday that it expects damage claim payments from Hurricane Hugo to exceed $500 million in the Carolinas and Virginia, more than three times what the company has ever paid out for a single disaster. State Farm said payments in South Carolina alone would be more than $400 million. The previous record payout by the company for a single disaster - $165 million - occurred in 1983 when a hurricane struck the Texas Gulf Coast.

title: Master Joker Who Never Forgets
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 27

title: Sale to Sony Approved By Columbia Pictures
description: The board of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. yesterday approved the sale of the company to the Sony Corporation for $3.4 billion in cash.

title: Hershiser's Enemy: Dodger Bats
description: Orel Hershiser already endorses baby shampoo, pizza, soft drinks, watches, underwear and cars. He should add barometers to his portfolio.

title: Mr. Bush's I.O.U. for Poland
description: ''There may be no greater opportunity before us all today than the challenges of Poland and, more broadly, Eastern Europe,'' President Bush said at yesterday's International Monetary Fund meeting. After months of hesitation, he recognizes the urgency of Poland's needs and acknowledges that the U.S. ''must do more.''

title: Maxwell Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Agnew Fisher, 82, Cup Races Photographer
description: Agnew Fisher, a photographer who documented the America's Cup races on film for 20 years, died of cancer Monday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: Kollmorgen Move
description: The board of the Kollmorgen Corporation terminated the company's agreement to merge into the Vernitron Corporation after Vernitron decided not to proceed with the transaction. Kollmorgen said the board had approved a restructuring plan, which contemplated selling its electronic interconnections business. Kollmorgen, based in Simsbury, Conn., also makes optical instruments and parts for electric motors. Kollmorgen also plans to file a lawsuit in the Superior Court of Connecticut seeking the recovery of damages from Vernitron for breaching the merger agreement.

title: Corrections
description: The On Stage column in Weekend on Friday misidentified the holder of a Fulbright Fellowship. He is Lloyd Richards, director of ''The Piano Lesson,'' not the playwright August Wilson.

title: Review/Opera; Stratas as 3 Heroines in 'Trittico'
description: The words opera and drama do not necessarily add up to an oxymoron, even if nights when they may seem to contradict each other are all too common. The second evening of the Metropolitan Opera's season, on Tuesday, proved the point triumphantly with Puccini's ''Trittico,'' a triple bill in which the leading soprano role in each work was assumed by Teresa Stratas.

title: Computer Chip Starts Angry Debate
description: A computer industry conference in San Jose, Calif., last week might well be remembered for the way discussions on a dry technical subject were transformed into a passionate dispute over whether the balance of power in the computer world will soon shift. By the time the conference on chip design had ended, the debaters had called each other liars and invoked on their behalf everything from a plea for the welfare of a generation of children to a warning not to sully the good works of legendary computer designers.

title: Who Lost Gorbachev?
description: The most resentful political question asked by American conservatives after World War II was ''Who lost China?'' The imputation was that Western irresolution, inspired by subversives in high places, enabled Mao to seize control from Chiang. Liberals hotly replied that China was never ours to lose, but the accusation-laden question bedeviled them for a decade.

title: Farm Credit Issue Totals $2.8 Billion
description: The Farm Credit System Banks yesterday priced a four-part consolidated systemwide bond issue totaling about $2.8 billion. It is being sold through the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation and a nationwide group of securities dealers and banks.

title: Koch Orders Hiring Freeze, Citing a $400 Million Gap
description: Facing what he said was a $400 million budget gap, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday imposed a municipal hiring freeze that is to remain in effect until the budget can be balanced.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Personal Health
description: Knee braces are fast becoming the most widely used ''crutch'' among American athletes, both recreational and professional, even though evidence for their effectiveness remains scarce.

title: Senate Votes $9.4 Billion for Drug War
description: After a week of deadlock, the Senate agreed today on a $9.4 billion financing plan for President Bush's anti-drug strategy, more than $1 billion above the amount requested by Mr. Bush.

title: Perseverance Pays Off for 49er Cornerback
description: Joe Montana, Jerry Rice, Roger Craig and Ronnie Lott are often mentioned first on a team loaded with Pro Bowl players. But several others are also integral parts of the San Francisco 49ers' machine-like operation, and a key cog is Darryl Pollard, who describes his being with the Super Bowl champions as ''a miracle.''

title: Tom Bradley Topped Dinkins in White Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Proposes High-Speed Train for Texas
description: A private group today announced a proposal to build what it hopes will be the nation's first high-speed train, similar to those that travel at speeds up to 185 miles an hour in Europe and Japan. The proposed route would be from Houston to Dallas and the trip would take about 90 minutes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Anyone who calls me a racist should be shot in the street like a horse.'' - Jackie Mason. [ B12:4. ]

title: Swissair And S.A.S. Link Seen
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System and Swissair said yesterday that they would hold simultaneous news conferences today in Stockholm and Zurich, and industry experts said the two had probably agreed to buy small stakes in each other and reached a joint marketing arrangement.

title: Courter and Florio Favor the Death Penalty, but Differ
description: One major issue between the two candidates for governor is this: The Republican favors the death penalty, and the Democrat . . . favors the death penalty.

title: Tom Bradley Topped Dinkins in White Vote; If Goldin Were Black
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Is Urged to Order Death For Night Stalker Murders
description: A prosecutor urged a jury today to recommend death in the gas chamber for Richard Ramirez, saying he killed for simple gratification.

title: Matco Mart reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $247,110, or 7 cents a share. The sales for both 9-month periods were not available. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Coalition Opposing Charter Revision Starts Its Campaign
description: The public campaign over the future shape of New York City's government began yesterday as a coalition of about 50 elected officials, former officials and leaders of community boards and civic groups said they would work to defeat the proposed City Charter.

title: Quayle Meets With Aquino And Is Hopeful About Bases
description: Although he was hounded by anti-American demonstrations and haunted by the killings of two Americans here Tuesday, Vice President Dan Quayle said today that he was confident the Philippines will renew its bases treaty with the United States.

title: More Tests for Tritium Reactors
description: In a move that could further delay the production of a scarce gas needed for nuclear warheads, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins today ordered additional testing of the Government's tritium reactors before they are restarted.

title: New Airport for Denver Gains Final Approval
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today gave final approval for a new airport outside Denver and signed a $60 million grant to help get the project under way.

title: Ketema Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months' results unavailable as the company was spun off from Ametek Inc. and began operating independently on Dec. 1, 1988.

title: Q&A
description: Hard-to-Slide Doors Q.Our glass sliding doors have become very hard to open and close. They slide on an aluminum track at the bottom and are gradually shaving off bits of the track. Lubrication helps only a little. The door that slides cannot be easily removed because the outer door is fixed and there are aluminum flanges on the inside that preclude taking the door off from the inside. Since I can't get the door off, I can't check the mechanism to repair the door. Can you help? A.Most sliding doors have thin sheaves or narrow wheels set into the bottom of the door and these are what ride on the track. It seems one or more of the doors' sheaves are broken or worn out, or the ball bearings on the inside are shot. Either way, the door must be lifted off the track to get at the bottom and replace the sheaves. Usually the door can be removed by lifting it straight up (when partly open) and swinging the bottom end inward until it clears the track.

title: Federal Paper Board Co reports earnings for 12wk to Aug 9
Appealing To Younger Tigers
description: THE ambiance of many of New York City's beleaguered university clubs is defined by overcooked food and underdone interiors. Seeking to update its image and attract younger alumni (including women), the Princeton Club, at 15 West 43d Street, has embarked on a $7.5 million transformation with Robert Venturi (class of '47) as the architect.

title: Comex to Test Hand-Held Computers to Record Trades
description: The Commodity Exchange Inc. announced yesterday that it would begin floor-testing hand-held computers that are intended to prevent trading abuses of the sort that led to the Federal investigation earlier this year of commodities traders in New York and Chicago.

title: Replacing a Chair Seat of Fiber Rush
description: LEAD: Most old wooden chairs with rounded seat rails can be renewed with Shaker tape, splint or natural or synthetic-fiber rush. The choice is yours.

title: INTERNATIONAL AID SOUGHT FOR POLES
description: President Bush called for greater international economic assistance for the new Government of Poland today, pledging that the United States would be ''out in front of this effort'' to insure success. But he offered few details about what the United States would do.

title: Mets' Finishing in Turmoil on Field and Off
description: The Mets made more news off the field yesterday than on it.

title: Former Aide Says Helmsley Took Millions
description: A former Helmsley company executive, who seeks million of dollars in damages, has asserted in a lawsuit that Leona Helmsley illegally took tens of millions of dollars from her husband, Harry B. Helmsley.

title: Isco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cabletron Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Cabletron said net income, share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma except for the three months ended Aug. 31, 1989, because the company went public in May 1989.

title: Weakness In Prices Widespread
description: Across the country, companies are reporting difficulty in raising prices - providing strong anecdotal evidence that inflation, for the moment, is not a problem.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: The Phantom Ph.D. Gap
description: LEAD: Many researchers have been predicting faculty shortages for the late 1990's and beyond, but a recent study has added a twist.

title: Party Decor Native To America
description: TOTEMS of the times: at a benefit at the Columns gallery for the American Indian College Fund last week, the decor matched the message. The gallery's 12 columns were transformed into contemporary totem poles.

title: Ann Honeycutt, 87, Former Radio Producer
description: Ann Honeycutt, an author and radio producer, was found dead on Tuesday in her home in Manhattan. She was 87 years old and had been ill for some time after a stroke.

title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License
description: Chris Antley, acknowledging a recurrence of his drug-abuse problems, has voluntarily surrendered his jockey license to the State Racing and Wagering Board and has pledged to seek further professional treatment for his cocaine use.

title: Rochester Community Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Figures for 1988 have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: At Milan Fair, There's Vitality If Not Practicality
description: ALTHOUGH only Italian manufacturers exhibited, there was an international flavor; although the fair was held at Milan's sprawling, outlying fairgrounds, dozens of openings, exhibits and ambitious events drew visitors to the center of the city. The 29th Salone del Mobile di Milano, the Milan furniture fair, and Euroluce, the lighting fair, from Sept. 20 to Sept. 25, reflected the eclectic state of affairs that marks the modern design scene.

title: Credit Government Scientists With Developing Anti-AIDS Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Bilzerian Gets 4 Years in Jail And Is Fined $1.5 Million
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor who became one of the wealthiest corporate raiders of the 1980's, was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison and fined $1.5 million for nine counts of violating securities laws, conspiracy and other crimes.

title: Former Top Aide to Pierce Refuses Panel's Questions
description: The former executive assistant to Samuel R. Pierce Jr. refused to answer questions today from a House panel investigating abuses in the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Benjamin Busch, Lawyer, 77
description: Benjamin Busch, a lawyer and a law professor, died on Sept. 15 at his home in Lakeville, Conn., after a long illness. He was 77 years old. Mr. Busch specialized in international law. He was a partner in the Manhattan firm of Katz & Sommerich from 1946 to 1976. He then became of counsel to Hamburger, Weinschenk, Molnar & Busch in Manhattan. He was also an adjunct professor of international law at the New York Law School. He graduated from the St. Lawrence University law school in 1933.

title: New Coach, Same Result; Johnson Is Gone but Miami Is Still Winning
description: Art Kehoe thought he owed Dennis Erickson, the new coach at the University of Miami, a warning. So earlier this month, Kehoe, who is an assistant offensive line coach at Miami, told his boss to be prepared: there might be a touch of lunacy at the final practice before the opening game against Wisconsin.

title: At Armory, Did Serious Mean Better?
description: CRAMMED with a global assortment of period objects, New York's newest antiques fair - its first to be vetted for authenticity - ended a six-day run yesterday with mixed reviews.

title: New Panel to Seek Reforms for Colleges
description: The retired presidents of two universities that emphasize athletic success as well as academic achievement said today they would lead a commission that would seek the causes of the problems plaguing intercollegiate sports and then try to persuade colleges to make changes.

title: Gordon F. Miller, 82, a Teacher and Coach
description: Gordon F. Miller, a former teacher, coach and athletic director who was known as Moose to generations of students at the Horace Mann School in the Bronx, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Senate Debating Helms Amendment
description: A surprise debate cropped up in the Senate tonight when Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who wrote an amendment to restrict Federal grants to art considered ''obscene,'' took the floor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Members Only Offers New Anti-Drug Drive
description: The policeman on the beat is the focus of a new advertising campaign by Members Only. Since 1986, the men's apparel manufacturer has devoted its entire advertising budget to anti-drug advertising.

title: 5 NWA Officers Quit As Checchi Takes Over
description: In an executive upheaval at NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, Steven Rothmeier, chairman, and four top executives resigned yesterday. Alfred Checchi, who recently bought the airline, named himself chairman of the parent company and the airline unit as well, in consultation with his investing partners. He also named his longtime business associate, Frederic V. Malek, president of both the parent and the airline.

title: East Germans Swell Embassy in Prague
description: A new rush of East Germans onto the grounds of the West German Embassy in Prague has prompted a major new crisis in the drama of the East German mass migration that began this summer.

title: Books of The Times; A Cast of Characters Afloat On History's Indifferent Sea
description: A History of the World in 10 1/2 Chapters By Julian Barnes 307 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Review/Opera; 'Porgy and Bess': Catfish Row at the Met
description: The contemporary world does not often intrude on the Metropolitan Opera, but there it all was on Wednesday evening: a hurricane battering Charleston, S.C.; a cocaine dealer plying his trade on the street; racially biased police officers; sex, violence and evangelism flourishing side by side . . . but, of course, you have guessed that the opera was ''Porgy and Bess,'' Gershwin's tuneful investigation of the folkways of Catfish Row in the 1930's. First produced by the company in 1985, ''Porgy'' has returned in a restaging by Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater.

title: Afghan, at U.N., Says Rebel Campaign Has Failed
description: Afghanistan's Foreign Minister told the General Assembly today that the American-backed guerrillas had lost any chance of winning a military victory against his Government this year as the summer fighting season draws to a close.

title: Prices Ease, and Trading Is Light
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased slightly in thin trading yesterday, as dealers reacted to the sale of a large list of mortgage-backed securities by selling Treasury issues.

title: Auctions
description: Mid-Season Sales

title: Panel Told Agencies Risk Abuse in Yielding Purchase Controls
description: Two Cabinet agencies have given up their control over billions of dollars in contracts by turning over purchasing and management to private contractors and other agencies, the internal inspectors of the departments told a Senate panel today.

title: Washington at Work; Democratic Chief Faces Uphill Battle in Effort to Rouse a Troubled Party
description: At a Democratic fund-raising event Wednesday night, when the singer Paul Simon was introducing his last song, ''An American Tune,'' he noted gently that he had sung the song for Jimmy Carter's inauguration and said, ''I don't think you guys have been in there since.''

title: Anne M. Lindsey, A Student, Weds
description: Anne Marie Lindsey, a daughter of Richard A. Lindsey of Lafayette, Ind., and the late Pearl Lindsey, and Michael Roy Penn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley W. Penn of New York, were married yesterday at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Associate Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, First Department, performed the ceremony.

title: Feminism Brings Truce to Battle of Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title: Autocrat With a Regal Manner, Marcos Ruled for 2 Decades
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos was as tough as he was debonair, and he came to rule the Philippines with an iron hand before popular unrest forced him to flee in 1986 after two decades in power.

title: Sports People: PRO BASKETBALL; Stipanovich Retires Because of Bad Knee
description: A knee injury so bad he ''can't even cut the grass'' forced Steve Stipanovich of the Indiana Pacers to announce his retirement yesterday.

title: Top 2-Year-Old Colts Lost for Big Weekend
description: This weekend was supposed to be a crucial one for this year's 2-year-olds, with Red Ransom running in New York and Summer Squall in Chicago, heading toward an inevitable showdown for the juvenile title.

title: Maverick's Battle Is Uniting His Enemies
description: This northern Fairfield County town of 22,000 people has gone head to head with the state in opposing the construction of a new state jail, with the charge led by a 42-year-old lawyer named Roderick J. MacKenzie Jr. The problem is that Mr. MacKenzie, who is also First Selectman of Newtown - the town's top elected official - seems to have about as many enemies as the jail.

title: Neighbor Held in Killing of Two in the Bronx
description: A part-time security guard from the Bronx was charged early yesterday with killing a child and her baby sitter last weekend.

title: Pitt Is Feasting on Opponents As Young Quarterback Emerges
description: For 99 years, football at the University of Pittsburgh has had a cyclical history of feast or famine. And now the banquet table is set again.

title: Here's the Joker in the Catastrophic-Care Pack; Nursing-Home Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Festival; A Blissful 'Mystery Train' From Jim Jarmusch
description: It's a slow night at the Arcade Hotel in Memphis ($22 a night for a double). Says the bellboy, as he reads from a tabloid, to the night clerk, who presides over a majestic account book, ''At the time of his death, Elvis Presley would have weighed 648 pounds on Jupiter.''

title: Court Issues Order Against Vernitron
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation said the Superior Court of Connecticut had issued a temporary order enjoining the Vernitron Corporation from acquiring the electric motor maker or any of its shares.

title: Henry E. Griffith, 74, a Plastics Executive
description: Henry Evans Griffith, a plastics industry executive, died Tuesday at the Rivercrest Nursing Home in Concord, Mass. He was 74 years old and lived in Concord.

title: Restaurants
description: If stars were awarded for the food's altitude on the plate, Gotham Bar and Grill would have no serious rivals. Alfred Portale, the I. M. Pei of contemporary American cooking, brings new meaning to the term haute cuisine with his skyscraper salads, towers of twirled pasta, high-rises of french fries and soaring desserts. A lesser talent might use such diversions to disguise substantive shortcomings, but for Mr. Portale, one of the most accomplished young chefs on the American scene, this is just his whimsical signature.

title: Groups Sue to Stop Shuttle Flight Because of Radioactive Payload
description: Three private groups filed a suit in Washington yesterday to stop the next space shuttle mission, which is to take aloft a nuclear-powered space probe that the three groups say could cause thousands of deaths by cancer if it is involved in an accident. The probe's power source is radioactive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Hopefully, friends and detractors alike will look beyond the man to see what he stood for -his vision, his compassion and his total love of country.'' - Ferdinand E. Marcos Jr. [ B7:1. ]

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW OF TECHNICAL COOPERATION AMONG DEVELOPING COUNTRIES - 11 A.M.

title: Gillette Settles Case on Product Cancer Risk
description: The Gillette Company, maker of the Liquid Paper typewriter correction fluid, agreed today to remove a cancer-causing ingredient from it and to pay $300,000 in penalties and costs to settle a legal action by environmentalists.

title: Beaune Journal; In Burgandy, Bacchus Is the God of Affluence Too
description: As far as the eye can see, small groups of grape pickers dot the hillside, hunching over the three-foot-tall vines to gather the dark purple pinot noir grapes and the gleaming green chardonnays that are so plump they seem ready to burst.

title: International Bankers Told of Soviet Reforms
description: The Supreme Soviet is about to take up legislation giving the State Bank of the U.S.S.R., or Gosbank, authority to issue foreign-exchange licenses to domestic banks, Yuri Ponomorev, a board member of the bank, said at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank here today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: Della Femina McNamee WCRS/ Boston will create a pro bono advertising campaign for the Scleroderma Association. Scleroderma is a life-threatening chronic tissue disease whose primary symptom is a hardening of the skin.

title: TV Weekend; Elizabeth Taylor's Star Turn as Williams's Aging Star
description: Princess Alexandra Del Lago in Tennessee Williams's ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' is an aging movie legend seeking a comeback after a seven-year absence from the screen. Imperiously demanding, she submerges her fears of growing old in alcohol, drugs and sex. She is what Williams called, not without affection, something of a monster.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Legal preserve opening its door to personal ads as search for romance (and profits) begins.
description: Can a young prosecutor slip and fall for a personal injury lawyer? Can a conservative corporate lawyer find romance with a public defender? Can a mergers and acquisitions specialist make a tender offer to a law professor? Soon some answers to these questions may emerge.

title: Borden to Cut 7,000 Jobs And 65 Plants
description: After a three-and-a-half-year buying binge in which it spent $1.7 billion and more than doubled the number of its plants, Borden Inc. reversed course yesterday. The nation's No. 1 dairy company said it will close or sell 65 of its 265 plants in the next two or three years and cut worldwide employment by 7,000 people, bringing its payroll down to 39,000.

title: Congress Votes Sharp Increase In Storm Relief
description: Congress approved $1.1 billion in emergency aid for hurricane victims in South Carolina, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands today amid bitter arguments over whether the Government was responding effectively to the storm's destruction.

title: Roll-Call Vote in House on Bill to Cut Capital Gains Tax
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 239 to 190 by which the House of Representatives today approved a capital gains tax cut backed by President Bush and rejected a Democratic alternative. A ''no'' vote was against an alternative proposal and for the lower tax rate. Voting ''yes,'' - for the alternative proposal - were 189 Democrats and 1 Republican. Voting ''no'' were 64 Democrats and 175 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. Two vacancies are in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: William Post Jr., 88; Film and Stage Actor
description: William Post Jr., an actor, died of a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Tuesday in Presbyterian Hospital in Oklahoma City. He was 88 years old and lived in Granite, Okla.

title: LIMITS ON ABORTION SEEM LESS LIKELY
description: Although new poll data indicate a high level of concern among supporters of abortion rights, political developments in half a dozen states suggest that pressure for restrictive legislation has eased, partly because abortion rights supporters have fought back effectively.

title: Few Choices for Braniff Ticket Holders
description: Travelers stuck with tickets for Braniff flights face an array of difficulties now that the airline has filed for bankruptcy protection and canceled most flights.

title: Bush Is Heard Too Well
description: Ronald Reagan was periodically embarrassed by saying things when he thought the microphone was off. It was President Bush's turn today.

title: G.M. Closing Extended
description: Continued slow sales of Chevrolet pickup trucks will add another week's layoff to the two-week shutdown at the General Motors Corporation's Moraine assembly plant. A company spokesman said Wednesday that the previously announced layoff of 2,500 workers will be extended until Oct. 23. The plant makes Chevrolet S-10 and S-15 pickup trucks.

title: Annenberg Gives Met A Gift of $15 Million
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art said last night that Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher, was giving it $15 million for acquisitions. Mr. Annenberg is also giving $5 million to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., and $5 million to the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash
description: An Amtrak passenger train bound from New York to New Orleans struck a fire truck and derailed tonight near Warrenton, Va., killing three firemen and injuring scores of people, the authorities said.

title: USAir Passenger Denies Tie to Plane's Pilots
description: A passenger who has been publicly linked with the pilot and co-pilot of the USAir jetliner that crashed at LaGuardia Airport last Wednesday night denies he told investigators he was with the crewmen in the hours before the fatal crash, the passenger's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Activity in the Final Hour Pushes Dow Up 21.85 Points
description: Stocks rose sharply in the final hour of trading yesterday on moderately higher volume.

title: Arthur A. Singer, 73, Founder of Exporter
description: Arthur A. Singer, a founder and retired president of the Singer Products Company, an exporter of machine tools and battery equipment, died of complications from a stroke Sunday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Plaza Nursing Home. He was 73 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Harvard Plans to Close a Public Service Placement Office
description: The new dean at Harvard Law School, the first law school to set up a separate placement program to help students find jobs in public service, plans to close the office, The plan by the new dean, Robert C. Clark, has led to protests by students worried that the school will abandon its commitment to support public interest law. Mr. Clark is considered an expert in corporate law who holds conservative views.

title: Bankruptcy Petition By Braniff
description: Braniff Inc., the nation's 15th-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, caught between the high cost of an aggressive expansion and the difficulty of securing financing in a troubled ''junk bond'' market.

title: On Stage
description: Teamwork, Relationships, Etc.

title: KEY RATES
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Hyatt Hotels, San Francisco, and Fisher Mountain Bikes, to Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley, San Francisco, with a combined budget of more than $1 million.

title: Stock of AMR Soars by $4.75
description: Stock in the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, soared $4.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $83.75, on speculation among investors that management might seek a buyout in cooperation with Donald J. Trump. Traders said that Bear, Stearns & Company, which has worked for Mr. Trump in other acquisitions, led the buying.

title: Senate Votes More Money for Anti-Missile Program
description: In a tactical move aimed at strengthening its bargaining position with the House, the Senate on Thursday reversed a decision it made Tuesday and voted to restore part of the money it cut from the anti-missile program.

title: Anderson Hoping To Trim Eagles
description: No matter how much Neal Anderson simply wanted to be Neal Anderson last season, the Chicago Bears tailback was the player filling Walter Payton's shoes.

title: Sales by Imperial
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, a San Diego-based savings-and-loan holding company, said it had sold more than $700 million of assets in the third quarter as part of an effort to shed $2 billion in assets by the end of the year to meet new regulatory requirements. The company said it sold $235 million in corporate bonds and $260 million in auto leases. The net effect will be a $1.4 million net loss in the third quarter, the company said. The company also said it would take an accounting loss, largely because of a $75 million to $80 million after-tax adjustment to its ''junk bond'' portfolio. Imperial also said it had a letter of intent to sell a $280 million credit-card portfolio to Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Hydraulic Product Maker's Stock Up
description: The stock of the Commercial Intertech Corporation, a maker of hydraulic products, soared today in over-the-counter trading, despite a statement by the company that it was not interested in being taken over. A company formed by Hass & Partners on Wednesday offered $27.50 a share for Commercial Intertech, but the company said it was not for sale.

title: Sports People: BOXING; Beating the Drums
description: George Foreman was talking about his fighting weight. In his current comeback, Foreman, who once held the heavyweight title, has won 19 straight bouts. He has performed at weights running north and south of 250 pounds and once even at a figure somewhere in the svelte 230's.

title: News Summary A3-9
description: InternationalA3-9 The U.S. has informed Israel that it intends to sell Saudi Arabia about 300 tanks and to take steps to meet Israel's security concerns if Jerusalem does not actively oppose the sale, American officials said. Page A1 Palestinians criticized Egypt's plan for peace in the occupied territories, but stopped short of rejecting it outright, an approach similar to that of the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat. A8 The party chief of the Ukraine, the second-largest Soviet republic, was removed from power by the Communist Party as rising nationalism and coalfield unrest shook his rule. A6 Moscow offers plan on aircraft limits A6 Afghan, at U.N., says rebel campaign has failed A9 A new rush of East Germans into the West German Embassy in Prague has shaped a major new crisis in the drama of the East German exodus. More than 2,000 East Germans now pack the complex's muddy grounds. A3 Colombia's former Justice Minister has reservations about Bogota's policy of extraditing suspected drug traffickers. After her recent resignation, she is living in the United States under heavy security. A3 An aid plan for Nicaraguan groups who are planning to oppose the Sandinistas in a coming election will be scaled down by the Bush Administration after Congress sharply criticized the proposal for being excessive and hastily conceived. A9 Beaune journal: A vintage grape harvest A4 National A10-17 A reduction in the capital gains tax was approved by the House, giving President Bush a significant legislative victory that wounds the new Democratic leadership. A1 A1 Georgia Isle vows to rebuild A14 The C.I.A. opposes a Senate proposal to create a Presidentially appointed inspector general with enhanced power to investigate wrongdoing in the agency. A1 The distribution of an AIDS drug will be permitted by the F.D.A. even though it is still being tested to determine if it is safe and effective. The move departs from the agency's historically cautious approach. A1 Public pressure for abortion limits seems to have eased across the nation, even though a new poll indicates a high level of concern among supporters of abortion rights. A1 A suit to stop a shuttle mission was filed. The shuttle will carry a nuclear-powered space probe that the complaintants say could cause thousands of deaths by cancer if it is involved in an accident. A10 An overhaul of the education system was agreed to by President Bush and the nation's Governors. They resolved to create goals for eliminating illiteracy, updating curriculums and holding teachers accountable for their performance. A10 Washington at Work: Ron Brown, the Democratic national chairman, faces the challenge of unifying and empowering a depressed Democratic Party that has gone 13 years without winning the White House. A12 Senate permits more money for ''Star Wars'' program A16 Panel told agencies risk abuse in yielding controls A14 A computer that reads handwriting was introduced. The machine, which only reads printed letters, is not the long-awaited electronic notebook, but it may help workers who record data on paper. D1 Bankruptcy is sought by Braniff D1 Anheuser buys theme parks D1 Amtrak train derails, killing at least two and injuring dozens A10 Regional B1-4 The presence of Jesse Jackson has become an important element in the New York City mayoral race. Rudolph Giuliani, the Republican candidate, hopes to gain the support of Jews who are disturbed by ties between Mr. Jackson and David Dinkins, the Democratic candidate. A1 Dinkins is endorsed by unions for uniformed workers B4 Apology by Jackie Mason B4 The largest group of Jewish refugees to arrive in the United States in a single day since the end of World War II touched down at Kennedy International Airport, taking advantage of a processing policy that ends tomorrow night. B1 Four large employment agencies in New York City have discriminated against black, Hispanic, female and elderly workers by steering them from jobs that had been ''reserved for whites,'' said the State Attorney General. B1 The New York principals' union warned that if the new Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, trys to duplicate the programs he instituted in Miami, a fiasco might result. B3 The building of a new state jail in Newtown, Conn., faces much local opposition.
