But protest efforts have been hampered because the town's top elected official, who is against the jail site, has many enemies. B1 For pregnant addicts, a clinic of hope B1 Brooklyn AIDS plan is rejected B3 Witness says the Garcias were overdrawn B3

title: Du Pont, Merck Set Drug Pact
description: Merck & Company and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced a long-term research and marketing agreement yesterday to develop a class of drugs to compete in the $6 billion market for heart treatments.

title: Sports People: AUTO RACING; Mansell to Appeal
description: Nigel Mansell of Britain, saying he never saw the black disqualification flag that ordered him out of the Portuguese Grand Prix on Sunday, said yesterday that he would appeal to the world body the $50,000 fine imposed on him and his suspension from this Sunday's Spanish Grand Prix.

title: Weighing Abortion Restrictions
Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Soviet Side Offers Plan to Narrow Differences on Limiting Aircraft
description: The Soviet bloc formally presented a new proposal in Vienna today that narrows the differences between the two sides on limiting aircraft, the main barrier to an agreement cutting conventional forces in Europe.

title: C.I.A. Mounts Drive to Defeat Plan for an Outside Inspector
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is mounting a determined drive to defeat a Senate proposal that would create a Presidentially appointed inspector general with enhanced power to investigate wrongdoing in the agency.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday READINGS BY WRITERS

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., said its shareholders had tendered about 40.4 million shares through Tuesday under a $28-a-share tender offer by IMA Acquisition Corp. The offer had been scheduled to expire Wednesday but was extended through Oct. 11.

title: Reviews/Art; An Interweaving of German and French Strands
description: All six paintings in Gregoire Muller's new show were done in La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland, a small city between Zurich and Geneva, where this Swiss-born artist has been living since 1987. They are at the same time softer and harder than the paintings he exhibited before leaving the United States. Away from the noise and excitement of New York, which he says he often misses, his struggle to expand his pictorial language and shape his esthetic of nightmare elegance has become a visible part of his work.

title: Associates Sets Credit-Card Deal
description: The Associates Corporation of North America said its affiliate, Associates National Bank of Pleasanton, Calif., had agreed to buy a national credit-card portfolio with outstanding balances between $425 million and $475 million from the First Interstate Bancard Company N.A.

title: Chevrolet's Incentive Plans
description: Trying to unload its 1989 cars to make room for new models, the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division expanded its incentive plans today and added rebates to move its inventory of cars and trucks from the expiring model year.

title: New York Sues Job Agencies In Bias Case
description: Four large Manhattan employment agencies have discriminated against job applicants who are black, Hispanic, female or deemed too old to hire by systematically steering them away from jobs that had been ''reserved for whites,'' the New York State Attorney General charged yesterday. He said the scheme was uncovered in an undercover investigation with the New York City Human Rights Commission.

title: Anheuser Is Buying Parks From Harcourt
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the nation's largest brewer, said today that it would pay $1.1 billion in cash to acquire four Sea World theme parks and other properties from Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc.

title: 25 Disabled People Held in Atlanta Bus Protest
description: Twenty-five disabled people who blocked more than a dozen Greyhound-Trailways buses to demand that wheelchair lifts be installed in them were arrested and put on Police Department buses that did have the devices.

title: Economic Scene; A Champion Of Fiscal Principle
description: WITH the showdown in Congress over the proposed cut in the capital gains tax fast approaching, Joseph A. Pechman, the economist who for four decades was regarded by both liberals and conservatives as the nation's leading authority on fiscal policy, was not here to play his usual role as ''happy warrior'' in the final phase of the battle. The House voted yesterday to support President Bush on cutting the tax, but the issue must still be fought out in the Senate.

title: Emerson Electric Pact With Bosch
description: The Emerson Electric Company of St. Louis and Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Stuttgart, West Germany, said they would form a joint corporation to acquire Vermont American, a Louisville, Ky., maker of power and hand tools and lawn and garden products, for approximately $440 million.

title: Peter Freudenthal, 55, Former Con Ed Official
description: Dr. Peter C. Freudenthal, former director of air- and land-use programs and environmental affairs for Consolidated Edison, died Wednesday at his home in Allendale, N.J., after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

title: Giants Want to Avoid Being Overconfident
description: The biggest danger the Giants will face Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys is not Troy Aikman or Herschel Walker or Jimmy Johnson or Elizabeth Taylor's coin flip. The main thing the Giants must contend with is overconfidence.

title: Review/Film; AIDS In a World Without Warnings
description: A morality tale about a young man named Kurt who spends his nights picking up women in a dance club and who dies of AIDS, ''On the Make'' is likely to be much more interesting to producers and agents than to general viewers. Filmed for a pittance -$120,000 - it is full of promise and talent, but not much drama or depth.

title: Big Pine Journal; Dusty Harvest Is Near After Long Water Wars
description: In the bitter water wars of California, there have been big winners and big losers. The Steward family has won some and lost some, but now the end seems near.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Balfour Maclaine Corp., a commodity exchange and brokerage firm, said Phillip L. Fondren had joined the firm as senior vice president.

title: Kenneth Brozen, 62, Houseware Designer Known for Plastics
description: Kenneth Brozen, a product designer and merchandising consultant, died of acute leukemia on Wednesday at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Race for Women
description: A five-kilometer race walk for women is to be held 9:30 A.M. Sunday in Central Park. Sponsored by Park Walkers, the race begins and ends at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue. There is a $7 registration fee. Information: 628-1317.

title: Here's the Joker in the Catastrophic-Care Pack
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hertz Account To Wells, Rich
description: Wells, Rich, Greene scored a major victory yesterday, winning the Hertz Corporation's advertising account. The account, worth $25 million to $30 million, had been at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on Wednesday misidentified the rock group on the recording ''Blind Man's Zoo.'' It is 10,000 Maniacs, not the Beastie Boys.

title: Airline Reservation Accord
description: Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Trans World Airlines said today that they had have a preliminary agreement to combine their computerized reservation systems into an Atlanta-based worldwide operation.

title: Annenberg Giving Met $15 Million for Acquisitions
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art said last night that Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher and a former Ambassador to Britain, was giving it $15 million for acquisitions. Mr. Annenberg is also giving $5 million for acquisitions to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. and $5 million to the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: New Computer Can Read Handwriting
description: In a development that may make computers accessible to people not accustomed to working on keyboards, a subsidiary of the Tandy Corporation introduced a 4.5-pound portable computer today that can read printed handwriting.

title: Jets Preparing for Colts With '88 Defensive Line
description: The Jets and the Indianapolis Colts were outclassed in their first two games this season and now each team has finally won. Comeback victories make a team feel better, even victories over teams without defenses: the Colts beat the the Atlanta Falcons, the Jets the Miami Dolphins.

title: In U.S. Exile, A Colombian Is Fearful Still
description: Monica de Greiff is pretty sure that Colombia's drug traffickers do not know where she and her family are living now.

title: Drug Move By Canada
description: Canada's Finance Minister said yesterday that the Government had asked Canadian banks to set up procedures voluntarily to detect illegal drug profits.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title:
About Real Estate;
Project With a New Look Rises in Brick Township
description: LEAD: Brick Township, one of the fast-growing communities in New Jersey's Ocean County, is getting a more elaborate form of housing in a 138-unit complex called Cambridge Walk and in several other developments.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News pages of Business Day in some editions on Wednesday misstated the ownership of Celestial Seasonings Inc. It is independent, having been sold by Kraft Inc. late last year.

title: Senator D'Amato's H.U.D. Connections
description: The deeper that investigators dig into the mess at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the more questions arise about the role of Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York. His declarations that he remained distant from the agency have never been plausible. The latest revelations make them simply unbelievable.

title: Carolina Isles After Storm: Salvaging the Shattered Past
description: For years, residents of this barrier island wondered what would happen if a powerful hurricane struck at high tide.

title: Outings for Shoe-Leather Sightseers
description: NEW YORK is a city best seen while on foot. Bird's-eye views may be inspirational - a chance to judge the celestial mighty mountain made by man - but it is the pedestrian who learns more quickly how it was all put together, how man makes the place run and even how the place makes man run. It is the comparative leisureliness of a walk that leaves the mind and imagination free to absorb the stunning contrasts that are the hallmark of New York living.

title: Managua Party Chief Splits From Coalition
description: An important opposition leader broke away from a 14-party coalition tonight, further weakening a fractious bloc that seeks to unseat the ruling Sandinistas in next year's elections.

title: Uniformed Workers' Unions Endorse Dinkins
description: Supported by New York City's major public-employee unions in the primary campaign, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee for mayor, is now winning endorsements from unions representing the uniformed forces and using them to challenge his opponent's claim to be the law-and-order candidate.

title: Fraternity Ousted by Ole Miss
description: The University of Mississippi has banned a fraternity for leaving two members naked and painted with racial slurs at Rust College, a mostly black school 25 miles north of here. Gerald Turner, the university's chancellor, said Wednesday that he had accepted a hearing panel's recommendation to ban the 90-member Beta Theta Pi chapter for three years, and had given the fraternity a week to close its house.

title: Baryshnikov Quits as Head Of American Ballet Theater
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov abruptly quit as artistic director of American Ballet Theater yesterday after a bitter dispute with the company's management and board over the troupe's finances and the removal of one of his staff members.

title: Roger Howell, 53, Ex-President of Bowdoin
description: Roger Howell Jr., president emeritus of Bowdoin College and a professor of the humanities there, died of heart failure Wednesday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland, Me. He was 53 years old and lived in Brunswick, Me.

title: Air New Zealand Plan
description: Air New Zealand plans to sell or lease its new Boeing 747-400 without ever using it after failing to reach a deal with pilots to fly the aircraft, the carrier's chairman, Bob Matthew, said today. The plane is scheduled to leave Boeing's Seattle plant in the next few weeks and Air New Zealand had planned to put it into service later this year. But the airline failed to reach an agreement with its pilots on terms and conditions for flying the plane.

title: Campeau Halts Dividends
description: The Campeau Corporation's board said yesterday that it would not pay dividends scheduled to be paid tomorrow on the company's series B preference shares, series C preference shares, series D preference shares and convertible subordinate shares.

title: Oh, Go Fly a Kite
description: Wind permitting, a kite-flying demonstration is planned on Sunday at 1 P.M. in the Great Lawn in Central Park, at 81st Street. The free event, called Fall Fling, is sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation and will also feature zydeco music by Loup Garou. Information: 360-8126.

title: Soldier in the Wall
description: The Prime Minister of Poland is strolling about his office, looking.

title: Review/Film; Indian Uprising in Montana
description: Franc Roddam's overheated action-adventure film ''War Party'' imagines an American political explosion that has not yet detonated: a group of young American Indians rises up violently against its redneck oppressors in the rugged high plains of Montana.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman's Post Filled At Reading & Bates
description: LEAD: Jack W. Bates, chairman and co-founder of Reading & Bates, will retire at the end of this month at age 70, the company's mandatory retirement age. D. Keith McIntosh, a 23-year veteran of the company, will succeed Mr. Bates as chairman and retain his titles of president and chief executive.

title: Sun to Begin New-Fuel Tests
description: The Sun Company announced this week that it would begin testing a series of reformulated fuels and gasolines in hopes of lowering harmful emissions by 1993.

title: Our Towns; At Testing Lab, Tomorrow's Gum Is Today's Secret
description: Stella Rieger answered immediately. ''My favorite experiment? The nonstick chewing gum. We got paid to sit here and chew gum.

title: U.S. TELLS ISRAEL IT PLANS TO SELL SAUDIS 300 TANKS
description: The Bush Administration has told Israel that it intends to sell Saudi Arabia about 300 United States Army battlefield tanks and will take steps to meet Israel's security concerns if Jerusalem does not actively oppose the sale, American officials said yesterday.

title: On Forging Relationships By Electronic Intermediary
description: Video monitors preside eerily over virtually every scene in the Canadian director Atom Egoyan's ''Speaking Parts,'' giving the film its chilly, high-tech cachet. In a board room, an absent film executive dominates his employees by means of a giant screen. In her solitary apartment, a spooky, lovelorn woman makes her VCR the centerpiece of a shrine. An ambitious actor says one thing while beside him, on a monitor playing his audition tape, he is seen and heard saying something else. In a very modern mausoleum, a woman mournfully watches the deceased on videotape.

title: For Pregnant Addicts, a Clinic of Hope
description: Amid brightly colored posters exclaiming the benefits of good nutrition and regular medical checkups, an educational video about pregnancy repeats itself endlessly on a television set in a living room-sized reception area where a dozen Harlem women await their obstetrician's call.

title: Cool, Geometric Paintings Of Robert Mangold
description: Sometimes it seems appropriate to think of Robert Mangold as a late - a very late - Renaissance painter. Of course, Mr. Mangold is no such thing; he's a contemporary American abstractionist who has been known since the end of the 1960's for eccentrically shaped monochrome surfaces that play host to cryptically outlined triangles, squares and circles. Yet when one walks through his exhibition at Galerie Lelong - a show of 11 paintings dating from 1964 to 1977 - covert, attenuated echoes of things Renaissance may be sensed.

title: Group Offers Money In AIDS Survey Protest
description: A gay rights group that opposes a door-to-door survey aimed at finding out the extent of infection with the AIDS virus offered $100 Wednesday to the first person who refuses to participate in it.

title: At the Movies
description: 'Johnny Handsome'

title: Swissair and S.A.S. Announce Pact
description: Swissair and the Scandinavian Airlines System agreed today to acquire up to 10 percent of each other and to unify some traffic routes and travel services.

title: Ku Klux Klan Chapter Wants To Adopt Part of a Highway
description: A Ku Klux Klan chapter has applied to take part in North Carolina's Adopt-a-Highway litter program, in which volunteers get a stretch of road to keep clean and a road sign with their name on it.

title: CBS Officials Promise to Rebut Afghan Charges
description: Reports that faked battle film was broadcast during coverage of the fighting in Afghanistan in 1984 will be answered ''point by point'' as soon as CBS News completes its investigation, network executives and employees said yesterday.

title: Track Athletes Call for Drug Inquiry
description: Disturbed by recent allegations linking American track and field athletes to the use of performance-enhancing drugs, a ranking group of athletes today called on The Athletics Congress to appoint an independent investigator to look into the drug problems in the sport in the United States.

title: Today's Immigrants Learn English as Fast as Yesterday's Did
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: For Children Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE TOY FACTORY,'' the Royal Toysmith of the Castle will show children how to construct toys and games (participants should bring at least two tin cans the same size), 1 P.M. tomorrow, at the Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, near 79th Street, in Central Park. Reservations and information: 772-0210. ''THE SLEEPING BEAUTY,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic show with audience participation, with Brian McGovern and Imam, 2 P.M. Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Information: 924-1472. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' a magic, music and comedy show for young children, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sundays, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''ME AND MY SHADOW,'' a program of adventure into the world of shadows, with instructions on how to capture shadows and how to make shadowy creations, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Dairy in Central Park, near 64th Street. Reservations required: 397-3165.

title: Recital at St. Thomas
description: Gerre Hancock, the organist and choirmaster at St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53d Street, will play a recital at St. Thomas on Sunday afternoon at 5:15. The program includes music by Nicholas de Grigny, Johann Sebastian Bach and Max Reger. Admssion is free. Information: 757-7013.

title: Dining Out Guide: Pre-theater Dining
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Chantal Cafe * (July 14, 1989), 257 West 55th Street (246-7076) - Chantal Cafe is a modest and moderately priced little bistro where the key to enjoyment is staying with house standards like rack of lamb with rosemary, and steak pommes frites. From Monday to Saturday, a pre-theater menu is served from 5:30 to 7 P.M. (prix fixe, $17.95). Included are an appetizer, entree, salad and dessert. Among the main courses are medallions of monkfish with braised leeks and fennel, and paillard of chicken with green mustard sauce. Recommended a la carte dishes, like swordfish with tomato and ginger, and salmon with dill sauce, are available for a supplement. Da Tommaso * (Aug. 11, 1989), 908 Eighth Avenue, near 54th Street (265-1890) - Amid the commotion of the Broadway theater district, Da Tommaso is a tranquil spot that offers good traditional food at modest prices, and portions are enormous. Pastas are the high points here. Among the best are angel hair with clams in a bright garlic-fueled broth, and fettuccine with shrimp, radicchio and shallots. Other dependable options are lamb chops in white wine, Cognac and sage, and chicken scarpariello (boned and cooked with white wine, lemon and herbs). The best of the desserts is the attractively presented pear sorbet. Appetizers are $5.50 to $7.50, entrees $13.50 to $20. Dinner served 4:30 P.M. to midnight Monday to Saturday, 1 to 11 P.M. Sunday. La Caravelle ** (June 6, 1986), 33 West 55th Street (586-4252) - La Caravelle, the 29-year-old French restaurant in midtown, offers Old World charm in serene, comfortable surroundings. Appetizers might include poached shellfish with fines herbes, marinated striped bass with lime, or a plate of assorted hors d'oeuvres. Among the entrees are roasted duck with cranberry sauce; quenelles with crab meat and lobster sauce, and roast chicken with a sweet garlic sauce. Desserts include creme brulee, sorbets, souffles glaces and fresh fruit. The pre-theater menu is prix fixe at $35 and is served from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday. La Reserve *** (Aug. 25, 1989), 4 West 49th Street (247-2993) - This three-star restaurant's sedate and spacious dining room with large murals of a marshy wildlife reserve is comfortably appointed. Appetizer choices include a salad of grilled quail and mixed greens, shrimp in garlic cream sauce, and terrine de volaille. Some of the entrees are sweetbreads with asparagus and truffles, roast duck with kumquats, and halibut in a light vermouth and watercress sauce on a pallet of baby vegetables. The pastry chef produces some excellent desserts, chocolate charlotte and tarte Tatin among them. Pre-theater dinner is $39 prix fixe from 5:30 to 6:45 P.M Monday to Saturday. Symphony Cafe * (April 7, 1989), 950 Eighth Avenue, at 56th Street (397-9595) - Symphony Cafe's unpretentious menu and relatively moderate prices have made it a popular pre-performance restaurant among Carnegie Hall patrons. The three-course menu offers appetizers like salad of seasonal greens, eggplant terrine, and warm garlic sausage. Main courses include sauteed chicken breast with mustard sauce, petit filet mignon with pepper sauce, Maryland crab cakes, and pasta and fresh fish specials. Among the desserts are pastry, creme brulee and chocolate sundae. The $21 prix fixe menu is served 5 to 6:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday.

title: Atlanta Magazine Sale
description: The American Express Publishing Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Atlanta magazine from Metrocorp. Terms were not disclosed. Metrocorp, which also publishes Manhattan,inc., Philadelphia and Boston magazines, had acquired the Atlanta publication in 1987. In a memorandum to the staff, D. Herbert Lipson, chairman of Metrocorp, said American Express had initiated the deal. American Express said it planned no changes in staff or direction. The magazine, published monthly, claims a circulation of about 67,000.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Weighing Buyout
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said it was considering a leveraged buyout as an alternative to the $45-a-share offer from the Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd. The Randolph, Mass., chain said its franchise owners had offered to help finance a management buyout to keep the company in friendly hands.

title: Max Schreiber, 79; Served Housing Agency
description: Max Benjamin Schreiber, a former director of design and chief architect for the New York City Housing Authority, died of a brain tumor yesterday at the Calvary Hospice in the Bronx. He was 79 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: U.S. TO PARE AID IN NICARAGUA VOTE
description: The Bush Administration moved today to scale down its $9 million plan to help opposition groups in Nicaragua, after Republican and Democratic members of Congress sharply criticized the proposal.

title: Apology by Jackie Mason For Campaign 'Insensitivity'
description: A day after he refused to apologize for racially charged remarks about blacks and Jews that forced his disassociation from the mayoral campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the comedian Jackie Mason issued a formal apology yesterday ''for my insensitivity.''

title: Corrections
description: A Company News report in Business Day on Tuesday gave an incorrect location for a plant of Eli Lilly & Company. It is in Fergersheim, near Strasbourg, France.

title: A Generic Drug Fails F.D.A. Test
description: The Food and Drug Administration today told the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company that it had failed to demonstrate that its generic version of the anti-high-blood-pressure drug Dyazide was biologically equivalent to the original product.

title: Bush and Governors Set Education Goals
description: President Bush and the nation's Governors agreed today on the need to overhaul the nation's education system by creating a set of goals that will focus on eliminating illiteracy, reshaping curriculums and holding teachers accountable for their performance.

title: Machine vs. Mind
description: Chess playing is a notable accomplishment of the human mind. But computer programs have steadily improved and are now outwitting even the best human players. Is that a victory or defeat for human intelligence and creativity?

title: Review/Film; From Denmark, a Fairy Tale for Adults
description: Line Kruse, who plays the 11-year-old title character in the new Danish film ''Emma's Shadow,'' exudes an easygoing, mercurial charm that is the mark of a natural child actor. Portraying the neglected only child of an upper-class Copenhagen family in the 1930's, she has an expression that shifts from innocent curiosity to imperiousness with just a slight raising of the chin and narrowing of the eyes. Not many very young actors have conveyed so unaffectedly a sense of being to the manor born while retaining a childlike freshness. Miss Kruse's wonderfully natural performance accounts for much of the appeal of this modest fairy tale for adults, which opens today at the new Angelika Film Center.

title: R. P. Harriss, Journalist, 87
description: R. P. Harriss, the dean of Baltimore's working journalists, whose last column for The Baltimore Sun appeared Sunday, died of cancer Tuesday at Union Memorial Hospital in Baltimore. He was 87 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sondheim by Schneider

title: Corrections
description: An brief article in the Sports People column on Tuesday about the suspension of two jockeys at the Meadowlands Race Track cited their fines incorrectly in some editions. Julie Krone was fined $500, not $1,500; Joe Bravo was fined $200, not $500.

title: Pop/Jazz; A Sound Of Healing From Marrakesh
description: As the sun sets on the Jamaa el-Fna, the main square in Marrakesh, the bleached light slowly changing to a golden wash, musicians, storytellers, snake charmers and acrobats descend. Food vendors, their stalls piled high with herbs, spices, meat and chocolate, start cooking and the aroma of food mingles with the intense sound of drumming and singing. The music, played by groups of Gnawi musicians - descendants of West African slaves taken to Morocco 500 years ago - begins.Audiences crowd around and the trance-inducing music starts working as light turns to dark.

title: Empire of America
description: The Empire of America Savings Bank, which has struggled with recent operating losses, said it had a negative net worth and was anticipating a huge third-quarter loss. Kent Davis, chairman and chief executive, said the bank anticipated a third-quarter loss of about $150 million. The savings bank said it would continue to operate normally and that the projected losses would have no effect on its customers, employees or vendors. In July, when the bank announced a second-quarter loss of $54.2 million, Mr. Dixon predicted that continuing losses would eat up its common shareholders' equity by the end of the year. In a news release today, Empire said the equity had been depleted as of Aug. 31. Empire, with assets of $11 billion, operates 142 offices in New York, Texas, California and Michigan.

title: Odds Favoring Terreri For Devils Backup Spot
description: Coach Jim Schoenfeld of the Devils said after tonight's 5-3 exhibition triumph over the Islanders that a decision had been made on who would be the backup goaltender to Sean Burke.

title: Giants Can Win One for Merkle
description: And now, after 81 years, the Giants will get a chance to avenge Fred Merkle.

title: Democrats Vote to Rescind Part of Dukakis-Jackson Pact
description: Seeking to increase its influence in the Presidential nominating process, the Democratic National Committeevoted today to rescind part of a compromise on party rules that was worked out between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson at the 1988 convention.

title: Aquino Rejects Latest Callsfor Marcos Burial in the Philippines
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she would not allow the body of Ferdinand E. Marcos to be brought here for ''the safety of those who would take the death of Mr. Marcos in widely and passionately conflicting ways.''

title: The Infinite Variety of Velazquez at Met
description: ''VELAZQUEZ'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a show that no one ever expected to see. The first exhibition ever to be devoted to Velazquez, whether in Spain or anywhere else, it includes many great paintings by the pre-eminent master of the Spanish school. From the tiny head and shoulders of the poet Gongora (done when Velazquez was only 23 years old) to the tranquil mix of landscape, narrative and sainted portraiture in ''St. Anthony Abbot and St. Paul the Hermit,'' we know exactly where we are - in the presence, that is to say, of a painter who can make us feel both secure in the world and at one with it.

title: Israelis in Colombia Are Acting on Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokerage Is Suspended
description: A Philadelphia brokerage accused of manipulating the price of a publicly traded stock has been fined $50,000 and suspended from the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Review/Film; A Little Plastic Surgery In the Cause of Revenge
description: Because ''Johnny Handsome'' is a film by Walter Hill (''The Warriors,'' ''Streets of Fire''), it crams the following things into its first five minutes: gunfire, screeching brakes, a drug-popping hoodlum, a moll in black leather, a violent robbery, one murder, sinister masks, shattering glass. But because this is Mr. Hill's work, these ingredients are slapped together with high style. The moll is Ellen Barkin; the masks are eerie and sleek; the robbers are after rare antique coins; the guns shoot flames. Love it or hate it, Mr. Hill's work has hot blood and an ethos that is uniquely its own.

title: Market Place; Is Stock Swap Good for AVX?
description: THE ''go go years'' of the late 1960's may be coming back, but with an Asian flavor.

title: Russian Jews Come to U.S. In Big Group
description: The largest group of Jewish refugees to arrive in the United States in a single day since the end of World War II touched down at Kennedy International Airport yesterday.

title: Bringing Back the Bridges
description: The forced closing of the Williamsburg Bridge in April 1988 dramatized the effects of prolonged scrimping on routine maintenance. It is hardly the only New York City bridge to suffer such neglect. Now New Yorkers can applaud the start of a widespread rebuilding effort. An event last week in Brooklyn, the reopening of the Carroll Street Bridge over the Gowanus Canal, provides fresh evidence that the program is working.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: The Post Drops Real Estate
description: The weekly real estate section of The New York Post, established with much fanfare in 1987, has been canceled.

title: REPORT ON PRIEST ASSAILS UNIVERSITY
description: A committee of the American Association of University Professors says the Catholic University of America violated the Rev. Charles E. Curran's academic freedom by barring him from teaching theology after his published views on subjects like birth control and homosexuality were censured by the Vatican.

title: Maxicare Health
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said it had reached an agreement with its creditors on terms of the health maintenance organization's plan of bankruptcy reorganization. The company said it would file the plan in United States Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif., in October. While terms will not be disclosed before then, the company said it would distribute varying amounts of ''cash, debt and-or equities'' to creditors and shareholders.

title: Union Warns Fernandez on Proposals
description: The union that represents New York principals and assistant principals has found itself thrust into the spotlight with its warning that the incoming Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, would be foolish to try to duplicate the innovations he instituted in Miami.

title: Ferdinand Marcos, Ousted Leader Of Philippines, Dies at 72 in Exile
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, who ruled the Philippines for 20 years until he was ousted in 1986, died in exile here today at St. Francis Medical Center after a long battle with heart, lung and kidney ailments. He was 72 years old.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $191.6 million, to $349.23 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased by $453.6 million, to $83.76 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $199.1 million, to $113.4 billion. The 96 broker-dealer funds increased by $446.1 million, to $152.07 billion, the institute said.

title: Mayoral Rivals in New York Juggling the Jackson Factor
description: A full-page advertisement for Rudolph W. Giuliani this week in The Algemeiner Journal, the nation's largest Yiddish newspaper, declares, ''Let the people of New York choose their own destiny.''

title: Film Series to Feature Issues of 1950's and 60's
description: A film series reflecting the politics and social issues of the late 1950's and early 60's is to begin at 2 P.M. tomorrow with a screening of ''Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb'' at the Queens Museum, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Flushing. To run the next five Saturdays, the film series coincides with an exhibition on the 1964-65 World's Fair; both the series and the exhibition will run through Oct. 28.

title: INSIDE
description: Amtrak's Crescent Derailed A passenger train from New York to New Orleans hit a fire truck at a crossing in Virginia, killing at least three people. Dozens suffered injuries, mostly minor. Page A10. Suit Seeks to Bar Launching Three groups sued to stop the next space shuttle, charging that its cargo poses a cancer threat in the event of a launching accident. Page A11. A Record Day for Refugees The largest group of Jewish refugees to arrive in the United States in a single day since World War II touched down at Kennedy International Airport yesterday. Page B1. Baryshnikov Quits Early Mikhail Baryshnikov abruptly quit as artistic director of American Ballet Theater, citing conflicts with the company's management. Page C7.

title: HOUSE, 239 TO 190, VOTES BILL TO CUT CAPITAL GAINS TAX
description: The House of Representatives today approved a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, giving President Bush a significant legislative victory that wounded the new Democratic leadership.

title: Freddie Mac Sets A Note Program
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced the establishment of a medium-term note program that it hopes will give it more flexibility in issuing debt securities.

title: Poindexter Asking Access to Reagan Notes
description: A lawyer for John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser who is now facing trial in the Iran-contra affair, has asked a Federal district judge for access to any private notes that were kept by President Ronald Reagan and any kept by George Bush while he was Vice President.

title: AIDS Plan For Center Is Rejected
description: A proposal to develop a nursing home for people with AIDS in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, which had met vigorous opposition from community leaders, was turned down yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: F.D.A., in Big Shift, Will Permit Use of Experimental AIDS Drug
description: In a major departure from their usual cautious approach, Federal health officials said today that they would permit an experimental AIDS drug, DDI, to be widely distributed while it is still being tested to determine if it is safe and effective.

title: Tim Wengerd, 44, Choreographer And Ex-Martha Graham Dancer
description: Tim Wengerd, a leading dancer in the Martha Graham company until 1982, a choreographer and a founder of the Repertory Dance Theater of Utah, died of AIDS on Sept. 12 at his home in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 44 years old.

title: Kodak to Reorganize 11 Units Into 3 Groups
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which has been hurt by sliding earnings this year, announced yesterday that it would reorganize 11 business units into three operating groups.

title: Baseball's Final Days: The Best
description: Will it be a dazzling catch, or a last-inning home run, or good pitching stopping good hitting, the way it often happens in baseball? What will we remember from this weekend in Toronto?

title: Marvin Warner Case
description: Final approval of the $16 million bankruptcy settlement plan of the Ohio financier Marvin Warner was delayed Wednesday because of questions over court costs, a family trust and interest on back taxes. Judge George Proctor of Federal Bankruptcy Court set a Nov. 19 deadline to solve the problems.

title: Review/Cabaret; Taking Pop Songs Apart
description: It's pretty safe to assume that no cabaret act had dreamed of juxtaposing ''Welcome to the Jungle'' by Guns 'n' Roses with Stephen Sondheim's ''Weekend in the Country'' until the trio that calls itself Chris Durang and Dawne came up with the idea.

title: AIDS, Drugs, Need and Greed
description: Is there something wrong with the way drugs are developed? The extortionate price of AIDS drugs suggests a system with serious faults. Drug companies, far from boldly accepting high risk for high reward, have to be cajoled with subsidies and monopolies into taking a chance. Once they hit a winner, they use their monopoly position to charge sky-high prices.

title: Soviets Stripping Brezhnev Of Top Military Decoration
description: The Soviet Government pushed former President Leonid I. Brezhnev further into disgrace today by stripping him of the country's highest military honor.

title: Mozart at St. Paul's
description: Tashi, a flexible chamber group that includes the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman, the cellist Fred Sherry, the violinists Ida Kavafian and Theodore Arm, and the violist Steven Tenenbom, will perform the Mozart Quintet for Clarinet and Strings (K. 581) in a free concert at St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, today at noon. Information: 602-0760

title: Suspect Suffers Heart Attack
description: A 47-year-old Queens man who apparently suffered a heart attack after his arrest Wednesday night on a drug charge died early yesterday at Woodhull Hospital, the police said. The man, James Howa, of 17-12 Harman Street, in the Ridgewood section, had been charged with criminal possession of a hypodermic needle. He began suffering convulsions while in a holding cell in the 90th Precinct station house and was taken to the hospital at 11:12 P.M. on Wednesday, the police said. He was pronounced dead by hospital officials at 5:55 A.M. yesterday.

title: U.S. Agent Says Garcias Overdrew Bank Accounts
description: Representative Robert Garcia and his wife overdrew their bank accounts by thousands of dollars in the months before prosecutors contend they asked for bribes from the Wedtech Corporation, a Government witness testified yesterday.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: Tomorrow BOOK SALE, 702 Greenwich Street, at 10th Street; sponsored by the West Village Committee. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Proceeds benefit the Jane Street Garden. Information: 243-0762. Sunday WEST BROADWAY FESTIVAL, West Broadway, between Park Place and Walker Street. More than 300 artisans, with antiques, collectibles, leather goods, jewelry, food and entertainment. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: 809-4900. FESTIVAL '89, Union Square Park, 14th to 17th Streets; sponsored by WBAI-FM. Community-help organizations, crafts, food and entertainment. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Rain date, Oct. 8. Information: 764-6330. SUNDAY IN THE PARK ART SHOW, Hell's Kitchen Park, 10th Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets; sponsored by the West 47th-48th Streets Block Association. More than 30 artists. Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. Information: 581-3575. COLUMBUS DAY PARADE, East 182d Street and Arthur Avenue, Bronx; sponsored by the Alfieri di Belmont and the Arthur Avenue and 187th Street Merchants Association. Sunday at noon. Food and entertainment. FLEA MARKET, Wagner College, Solar parking lot, Howard Avenue and Campus Road, Grimes Hill, S.I.; sponsored by the College Alumni Association. Admission, 50 cents (25 cents for children). Information: (718) 390-3224.

title: Recent Soviet Offerings May Get Ratings by S.&P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, which does not now rate any debt obligation of the Soviet Union, is studying the possibility of including such a rating in its sovereign assessment service as a result of a flurry of Soviet international bond issues.

title: Victim and Sentence: Resetting Justice's Scales
description: After a 28-year-old drifter pleaded guilty last February to murdering Robin Smith and dumping her battered body in the wooded foothills of Mount Rainier, the woman's mother, Edna Smith, stood in court during sentencing to talk about her 21-year-old daughter.

title: Review/Film; A Bittersweet Homecoming For a Soldier, 17 Years Late
description: In ''Welcome Home,'' Kris Kristofferson plays Air Force Lieut. Jeremiah (Jake) Robbins, shot down in Cambodia and long presumed dead but now returning to his family after an absence of 17 years. His reappearance triggers the expected round of jaw-dropping, but beyond this it sets off surprisingly few sparks. This isn't a film in which dramatic things happen. It's a film in which Jake says things like ''I should never have come here'' and his wife, Sarah (played by JoBeth Williams), says things like ''Why did you have to come back?''

title: 14 Nations Take On New York Harbor
description: The boating season may be drawing to a close, but the biggest flurry of the racing season is planned for New York Harbor this weekend.

title: RESULT PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Drivers Are Shot In Two Holdups At a Bronx Park
description: A gunman in a ski mask shot two people in separate cars late Wednesday night in a parking lot near the Van Cortlandt Park stables where couples often go at night, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about the removal of magazines by grocery and department-store chains, because the October issues show a nude woman in an advertisement, mentioned one magazine incorrectly. The magazine, Elle, does not carry the ad and has not been removed.

title: Developer's New Gift Unwanted in Newark
description: Nobody at City Hall denies that Harry Grant has been generous to the city of Newark: He paid to gild the dome of City Hall with 24-karat gold, put up flagpoles and lay a fancy new sidewalk in front and last year, he donated a five-story Christmas tree.

title: U.S. Weighs New Delay in Nuclear Waste Project
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins has told a Senator from Nevada that the Government is considering a delay of at least two years in the start of underground work at a proposed nuclear waste dump there.

title: Review/Art; Mario Merz Works Complement the Guggenheim
description: It isn't often that a museum building seems tailor-made for an artist's work. Still less often is the structure in question as eccentric as Frank Lloyd Wright's implicitly organic Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, with its spiraling ramp measured off in shallow bays, its great open well and its ribbed and rounded glass roof. Nonetheless, just such a fusion has been achieved between the Guggenheim's architecture and the work of Mario Merz, the grand old man of contemporary Italian art.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sette Mezzo

title: Hirohito Death Cut Sales, Amway Says
description: The illness and death of the Japanese Emperor, Hirohito, cut into the Amway Corporation's sales growth for the fiscal year that ended Aug. 31, company officials said. William Nicholson, Amway's chief operating officer, said commerce in Japan accounts for 35 percent of the company's business.

title: Edelman Sued On Datapoint
description: A suit was filed yesterday against Asher B. Edelman contending that the veteran takeover specialist had improperly purchased 30 percent of the shares of the Datapoint Corporation, a computer networking company, in an effort to thwart a bid to oust him from the Datapoint board.

title: Singers and Dancers Of Eritrea to Perform
description: The first performance in the United States of an ensemble of singers and dancers from Eritrea takes place today during a varied seven-hour program sponsored by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front.

title: Future Of Mets' Manager Unresolved
description: Senior executives on the Mets acknowledged yesterday that they were deliberating Davey Johnson's future as manager of the team, but insisted that the decision had yet to be made and was not expected to be made for a week or so.

title: UKRAINE REMOVES ITS PARTY LEADER
description: The Communist Party in the Ukraine today ended the 17-year-rule of its party boss, whose firm control of the second-largest Soviet republic had been shaken by rising nationalism and coal miners' unrest.

title: Sports People: PRO BASKETBALL; Petrovic's Prognosis
description: Drazen Petrovic of the Portland Trail Blazers should recover faster than expected from back surgery, a doctor said yesterday.

title: N.Y. Justice: Not Color-Blind
description: LEAD: The lenient treatment of the defendants charged in the killing of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn is further proof that it pays to be white when you go to court.

title: Greek Coalition Is to Resign; Elections Are Set for Nov. 5
description: Just hours after Parliament voted to try former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou for corruption, Greece's conservative-Communist coalition announced today that it would resign by next week and that elections would be held Nov. 5.

title: Palestinians Express Doubts But Don't Reject Egypt's Plan
description: Prominent Palestinians from the occupied territories expressed serious doubts about Egypt's 10-point peace plan today, but stopped short of rejecting it.

title: Here's the Joker in the Catastrophic-Care Pack; Deficit Secret Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Buys Guber-Peters
description: Just a day after it spent more than $3 billion to buy Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., the Sony Corporation today paid $200 million for the Guber-Peters Entertainment Company, the producers of ''Batman,'' ''Rain Man'' and ''Flashdance.''

title: Ambiguous Bronze Sculptures by Ronald Jones
description: Ronald Jones's latest sculptures are very elegant and very ugly. His show at Metro Pictures consists of five shiny bronzes that seem to mimic the curvaceous abstractions of Jean Arp, all of them perched on wood and stone pedestals directly copied from Brancusi. Mr. Jones once used the word suave to describe these objects and that is precisely what they appear to be.

title: Kyocera and AVX Agree To Merge in a Stock Swap
description: Two of the most important companies in the manufacture of ceramics for high technology, the Kyocera Corporation of Japan and the AVX Corporation, which is based on Long Island, announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a deal worth about $531 million.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Scofield in a Trio John Scofield, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Barrow Street (242-1785). John Scofield, a brittle, often brilliant guitarist, has found his ideal working situation in a trio. His long, harmonically ambitious lines reel and course through the tumult of the drums, with the bass giving just hints of the background harmony. And Mr. Scofield has a wry sensibility when it comes to choosing tunes, as well: a complicated funk piece by the Meters will sit next to his own sleek compositions, or ''Body and Soul.'' Sets tonight and tomorrow are at 10, 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; on Sunday, at 10 P.M. and midnight. The cover is $15, and there is a $6 minimum. A Scam From Memphis

title: Feminism Brings Truce to battle of Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Mad and Busy Day In Ludlam's First Venture
description: In Act II of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's ''Big Hotel,'' a bellhop starts sobbing over esthetics. ''I've lost the thread of the narrative!'' he cries over and over, and no wonder. Wandering about the Big Hotel in his call-for-Philip-Morris costume, the bellhop has stumbled upon a crucifixion. The victim bears an uncanny resemblance to Charlie Chan.

title: Why I Came In From the Cold
description: LEAD: In ''The Russia House,'' his newest novel, John le Carre introduced glasnost into espionage.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; U S Sprint's Street-Corner Marketing
description: THE U S Sprint Communications Company has achieved remarkable success by using advertising and marketing as a one-two punch. First, it spent tens of millions of dollars on advertising intended to portray itself as a technologically sophisticated alternative to A.T.&T., then it enlisted a growing army of part-time salespeople to promote its long-distance service at busy street corners, county fairs, shopping malls and just about any place where people have gathered.

title: Patents; Producing Hormones In Farm Animals
description: Scientists affiliated with the Salk Institute of Biological Studies, a nonprofit research organization in San Diego, have patented a method of producing hormones in genetically engineered farm animals.

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Up
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.16 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was up from a rate of 10.03 percent last week. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.70 percent this week, the same rate as the week before, Freddie Mac said.

title: Dolphin Suspended
description: Mark Brown, a Miami Dolphins linebacker who expressed bitterness toward management when he ended a two-month contract dispute Tuesday, was suspended without pay yesterday by Coach Don Shula. ''I felt that in the days he's been here, he hasn't given the effort in our practices,'' Shula said. ''This was obvious not only to me but to the defensive coaches as well. It also had to be obvious to his teammates. We expected him to come in here and go to work, but he didn't.''

title: U.S. Forest Harvest Is Nothing Like the Tropics; Cathedral Pines
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Insurer May Bar Stake
description: Rosewood Financial Inc. and its president, Mark W. Hobbs, said yesterday that they hoped to raise their stake in the First Executive Corporation to a commanding 29.7 percent from 9.7 percent, but analysts said the insurer's chairman, Fred Carr, would probably try to block the attempt.

title: A New Razor For Gillette
description: The Gillette Company, bruised in recent takeover battles, plans to introduce a new razor next week that the company is touting as a ''revolutionary new shaving system.''

title: Hope for Hong Kong
description: Following the bloodbath in Tiananmen Square and the ascendancy of hard-liners in Beijing, British citizens in Hong Kong worried about what might happen to them after the scheduled 1997 reversion of the Crown Colony to Chinese control. Their anxiety threatened to turn into panic when Margaret Thatcher's Government greeted their plight with indifference and racist declarations. Now comes a welcome sign that London is trying to devise a more honorable response.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the ''Washington at Work'' article yesterday, about Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, referred incorrectly in some copies to Representative Dan Rostenkowski. He is from Illinois.

title: Patents; Quigg Is Resigning
description: Donald J. Quigg announced this week that he was resigning as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher had previously been reported to have decided to replace Mr. Quigg, who became commissioner in 1985. Attorneys close to the Patent Office believe the White House will nominate Harry F. Manbeck, chief patent counsel for the General Electric Company.

title: Reading Between Lines Of Toy Warning Labels
description: A toy producer is poised to start warning that one of its products might pose a choking hazard to young children, signaling a major change in the way toys are labeled.

title: U.S.-Style Personnel Moves Are Jolting Japanese Banks
description: Japanese financial institutions, having developed American-style merger specialists, are suddenly finding themselves the targets of American-style personnel shake-ups.

title: Senate Vote On the Arts
description: Here is the 62-35 roll-call by which the Senate early this morning tabled and effectively killed an amendment by Senator Jesse Helms supporting a ban on Federal aid for obscene art. A yes vote was a vote to table and thus kill the amendment, while a no vote was a vote to sustain the amendment. Voting yes were 43 Democrats and 19 Republicans. Voting no were 10 Democrats and 25 Republicans. xxx denotes senators not voting. Adams, D-Wash., yes; Armstrong, R-Colo., no. Baucus, D-Mont., yes; Bentsen, D-Texas, xxx; Biden, D-Del., yes; Bingaman, D-N.M., yes; Bond, R-Mo., yes; Boren, D-Okla., yes; Boschwitz, R-Minn., yes; Bradley, D-N.J., yes; Breaux, D-La., no; Bryan, D-Nev., no; Bumpers, D-Ark., yes; Burdick, D-N.D., yes; Burns, R-Mont., no; Byrd, D-W.Va., no. Chafee, R-R.I., yes; Coats, R-Ind., no; Cochran, R-Miss., no; Cohen, R-Maine, yes; Conrad, D-N.D., no; Cranston, D-Calif., yes. D'Amato, R-N.Y., yes; Danforth, R-Mo., yes; Daschle, D-S.D., yes; DeConcini, D-Ariz., no; Dixon, D-Ill., yes; Dodd, D-Conn., yes; Dole, R-Kan., no; Domenici, R-N.M., yes; Durenberger, R-Minn., yes. Exon, D-Neb., no. Ford, D-Ky., no; Fowler, D-Ga., yes. Garn, R-Utah, no; Glenn, D-Ohio, yes; Gore, D-Tenn., yes; Gorton, R-Wash., yes; Graham, D-Fla., yes; Gramm, R-Texas, no; Grassley, R-Iowa, no.

title: Review/Film; Antiques Dealer Finds Love and Trouble
description: ''The Girl in a Swing'' has nothing at all to do with the ''The Girl in the Red Velvet Swing,'' the vivid 1955 melodrama about Stanford White's and Harry Thaw's lethal passion for Evelyn Nesbit. This film is also supposedly about deadly passions, but it is most memorable for all the inexplicable omens and dangling ends that linger after the movie is over. This is the kind of muddled suspense story that leaves viewers watching the credits and wondering, ''Huh?''

title: INSIDE
description: China's Line Hardens

title: The Setback for Advanced TV
description: Proponents of a national effort to make American companies competitive in future television manufacturing are scrambling to regain lost momentum after a decision by the Commerce Department to abandon its plans for a focused initiative on HDTV, as the new technology is called.

title: Review/Film; Soldiers Haunted by Events Of a Forgotten Battlefield
description: ''Shell Shock,'' the term that gives Yoel Sharon's earnest little docudrama its title, isn't a strictly accurate name for an ailment that the Israeli film examines with a studious tenderness. Gideon (Asher Tsarfati) and Micha (Dan Turgeman), the two Israeli soldiers at the center of the story, both suffer from what is now known clinically as post-traumatic stress disorder.

title: Clash on Inspector Is Latest of Many
description: The dispute between Congress and the Central Intelligence Agency over the C.I.A. inspector general's office stems from fundamentally different views of how best to root out wrongdoing and mismanagement at a clannish, fiercely protective agency in which some employees are trained in the art of deception.

title: Blue Jays Win in 11th and Lead Orioles by 2
description: Lloyd Moseby moved slowly up the line to first base, his eyes on the ball he had just launched toward the ceiling of the Skydome.

title: Kremlin Confronted on Baltic Recruits
description: The Lithuanian Legislature today called on the authorities in Moscow to allow Lithuanian military recruits to do their mandatory service in their homeland.

title: Why Give Times Sq. Precedence Over Other Deteriorating Sites?
description: To the Editor:

title: Noviye Gromyki Journal; Once Again, Chernobyl Takes a Toll
description: Reaping the whirlwind of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster is proving a far more harrowing task than the farmers of Byelorussia first feared.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pulaski Day Parade, Fifth Avenue between 26th and 52d Streets will be closed tomorrow from noon to 4 P.M.

title: Review/Music; From Bits of Jack Benny, a Quasi Opera
description: Some composers struggle for recognition, achieving it only after years or not at all. Others seem to leap effortlessly to prominence. Something like that latter career trajectory may be the happy fate of John Moran, a 24-year-old from Lincoln, Neb., who had the good fortune to be befriended by Philip Glass and other New Yorkers and who now finds his ''Jack Benny,'' an hourlong quasi opera, ensconced at the La Mama experimental theater, 74A East Fourth Street, through Oct. 15.

title: Agents Seize 20 Tons of Cocaine In Raid on Los Angeles Warehouse
description: Breaking a $6 padlock on an unguarded warehouse in the San Fernando Valley, drug agents seized a cache of at least 20 tons of cocaine and more than $10 million in cash today in what they said was the biggest drug haul in history.

title: Review/Music; Debut of Violin-Piano Duo
description: Lucie Robert, a violinist, and Jeffrey Cohen, a pianist, are married, are both on the faculty of the Manhattan School of Music, and have been performing as a concert duo since 1981. At their New York debut performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, it was evident from the outset that they were not a violinist and accompanist, but a true chamber music duo.

title: Savimbi Is to Urge U.S. To Join Talks on Angola
description: The Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi, who is to visit Washington next week, intends to ask the Bush Administration to mediate an end to Angola's 14-year civil war.

title: Flyers Trade 2, Maybe
description: In what might turn out to be a shrewd piece of maneuvering, the Philadelphia Flyers traded Pete Peeters, a goaltender, and Keith Acton, a center, to the Winnipeg Jets on Thursday for future considerations. Both players might return to the Flyers as early as Tuesday as the future considerations, although both general managers denied on Thursday that a return trade had been agreed to.

title: Thomas Keller, Rowing Official, 64
description: Thomas Keller, president of the International Rowing Federation since 1958, died of a heart attack Thursday night in Monte Carlo. He was 64 years old.

title: Dickerson Emerges on 50-50 List
description: For the first time in Eric Dickerson's career, the star runner is going into a game listed as questionable, or 50-50 to play.

title: CHINESE CHIEF SETS HARD POLICY LINE
description: In its most sweeping declaration of policy since leadership changes in June, the Communist Party acknowledged some mistakes today but called for vigilance against what it described as efforts by the West to subvert the Chinese Government and institute capitalism.

title: Plunk And Yanks Shake the Ho-Hums
description: The fact is, the last three games had a kind of ho-hum feeling to them, creating an urge to watch between yawns and a hope not to get hit by a foul ball. But in the midst of last night's nothingness at the Stadium, there were some noteworthy events.

title: Mets Make Late Dash for Second
description: The Mets, maligned and mauled lately, made a late dash toward second place tonight and passed some personal milestones on the way as they swept a doubleheader from the Pittsburgh Pirates behind the powerful pitching of Frank Viola and David Cone.

title: Bridge; World championship play forced the Americans and Canadians to face the 'Multi.'
description: When the world team championships were played recently in Perth, Australia, the American and Canadian players constantly found themselves having to counter the ''Multi,'' a convention that is barred in almost all events controlled by the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Under Attack, Giuliani Calls His Ads 'Fair'
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday angrily defended his criticism of David N. Dinkins's association with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and said their economic policies and support for unions would bankrupt New York City.

title: Bennett Chastised for Comments on 'Pap'
description: The White House chastised William J. Bennett today for speaking his mind about what he called the ''pap'' delivered by some of the nation's governors at their education conference with President Bush this week.

title: 2d Murder Charge In Hernandez Killing
description: A man described by the police as a middle-level heroin dealer was indicted Thursday in the killing of Maria Hernandez, the Brooklyn woman who fought along with her husband to rid her block of drug dealers.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
There's No Monopoly On Misery
description: LEAD: The love poems have hardly begun. Within a fortnight, they will come from anyone who ever purchased a blue baseball cap with a red C, anyone whose devotion has ever been directed toward that hallowed ground between the corners of Clark and Addison and Waveland and Sheffield on the North Side of Chicago.

title: U.S. Weighs Dismissing Bloch But Has an Evidence Problem
description: The State Department is weighing the dismissal of Felix S. Bloch, the diplomat under suspicion of espionage, but has run into difficulty because a vital piece of evidence may not be usable in a personnel decision, officials said today.

title: Curbs on 'Medicaid Mills' Draw Criticism
description: At a doctor's basement office in Washington Heights, a line of 50 people stretched up the stairs and out onto Broadway. Medicaid records indicate that the doctor spends an average of less than two minutes per patient, diagnosing nearly everybody as suffering from the same form of hypertension and needing a $45 prescription.

title: Stanley Friedman, Scapegoat for the Corrupt
description: LEAD: After winning the Republican nomination for Mayor, nothing could have been more natural for Rudolph Giuliani than his attempt to associate his Democratic opponent, David Dinkins, with Stanley Friedman, the fallen Bronx Democratic leader. If it had not been for his successful prosecution of Mr. Friedman, Mr.

title: Fiery 'Aida' at the Met
description: Some unexpected excitement flared in the fourth act of ''Aida'' at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday night, when one of the enormous braziers perched on tripods on either side of the stage flamed up like an outdoor grill with too much charcoal lighter fluid.

title: Trying to Fulfill Some High Expectations
description: The season began with so much expectation and flair, and perhaps too much promise. There was Frank Baur from little Lafayette College on the cover of Sports Illustrated.

title: Stocks Mixed on Decline in Dollar
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday, restrained by a softer dollar.

title: NEIGHBORS THWART NARCOTICS CLINICS
description: Neighborhood opposition has eclipsed shortages of money as the biggest obstacle to opening drug-treatment clinics in New York, treatment experts say.

title: Explosion Disrupts Service On Seventh Avenue IRT Line
description: An explosion behind a circuit breaker room in the Seventh Avenue IRT line in lower Manhattan last night cut subway power lines, disrupting service for almost three hours between Chambers and 96th Streets, Transit Authority and Fire Department officials said.

title: Conferees Reject Helms Proposal To Restrict Financing of the Arts
description: A House and Senate conference committee today rejected a proposal to prohibit Federal financing of art that violates broadly defined moral standards.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 4 about the nomination of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro for president in Nicaragua described the Somoza family's assumption of power incorrectly. The United States Marines withdrew from Nicaragua in 1933 after helping to install Gen.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal for a Presidentially appointed inspector general for the Central Intelligence Agency referred to Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma incorrectly in some editions. He is a Democrat.

title: Submarine Runs Aground
description: A new nuclear submarine, the Pennsylvania, ran aground early this afternoon as it was entering Port Canaveral, but no damage was reported and tugs freed the craft about two hours later, the Navy said. The 560-foot 16,600-ton vessel, equipped to fire Trident missiles, was commissioned Sept. 9 in New Groton, Conn. Canaveral is the base where submarines take on missiles for test-firing.

title: Metrotech Agrees to Pay $2 Million to Aid Tenants
description: In a settlement that keeps one of New York City's largest real-estate projects on schedule, developers of the Metrotech project in downtown Brooklyn said yesterday that they had agreed to pay $2 million in benefits to a group of tenants who are being displaced.

title: Ewing's Blocks to Help A Children's Charity
description: Patrick Ewing of the Knickerbockers, whose annual income reportedly exceeds more than $3 million, will divest himself of part of that fortune by donating $100 to the Children's Health Fund every time he blocks a shot during the regular National Basketball Association season. The 7-foot center from Georgetown University blocked 281 shots in 80 games last season and has averaged about 230 a season in his four years with the Knicks.

title: Aquino Is Resolute on Marcos-Burial Ban
description: Rejecting new appeals from newspaper editorials and many politicians, President Corazon C. Aquino reiterated today that the family of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos would not be permitted to bring his body to the Philippines for burial.

title: Tennessee and Auburn Have Something to Prove
description: Johnny Majors, an all-America tailback at Tennessee from 1954 to 1956, was gleefully welcomed home to Knoxville in 1977 as the anticipated savior of a downtrodden football program. The coach arrived fresh from leading undefeated Pittsburgh to the top national ranking in 1976.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Broken Electronic Equipment
description: Does it pay to fix dead or ailing electronic gear when the warranty has run out? Even though repair prices tend to be high, the cost can be worth it if the circumstances are right. Each problem is individual.

title: Looking for the New Among 1990 Cars
description: ''New'' and ''improved,'' two of the most overused words in automotive parlance, are being invoked once more this autumn as manufacturers dangle their 1990 models before a driving public that may be less expectant than ever before.

title: Navy Reports Encounter With a Soviet Ship
description: A Soviet warship fired in the direction of a United States fighter plane last week in the Mediterranean, the Navy said today, describing the incident as purely accidental.

title: Northwest Deal Reached, but KLM Objects
description: Bowing to pressure from the Bush Administration, the investment group that has taken over Northwest Airlines agreed today to reduce the equity held by KLM, the Dutch airline, and to restrict KLM's power on Northwest's board.

title: Surgery for Belcher
description: Tim Belcher of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who pitched his eighth shutout of the season Wednesday night, had surgery Thursday to remove a bone spur and cartilage chips from his pitching hand.

title: Kevin Roche Honored For Redesign of Zoo
description: The architect Kevin Roche has been awarded the Brendan Gill Prize for his redesign of the Central Park Zoo. The award, sponsored by the Municipal Art Society, is the second given for contributions to the quality of life in the city; the recipient last year was Rudolph Burckhardt, a photographer and film maker.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section on Wednesday about a series of lectures on olive oil at the Mid-Manhattan Library misstated the telephone number for information. It is (212) 340-0944.

title: Queens Drug Kingpin Reportedly Pleads Guilty
description: In an unusual secret court proceeding, Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, once described as the dominant power in heroin and cocaine distribution in southeastern Queens, has pleaded guilty to two Federal racketeering-related murder charges, law-enforcement authorities said, adding that Mr. Nichols is cooperating with investigators.

title: This Little Piggy Got None
description: September, and the sun vanishes early. Chill comes with night, and furnace wants oil, gas, electricity, money, money, money.

title: Senate Would Speed Reparations To Survivors of Internment Camps
description: After an emotional debate, the Senate voted today to speed and guarantee the payment of reparations to Japanese-Americans who were interned during World War II.

title: Excerpts From Arts Debate in Senate
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate Thursday night and early this morning on a proposal to prohibit Federal support for obscene or indecent art. The comments of Senator John C. Danforth were provided by his office; the other Senators' comments were transcribed by The New York Times through the facilities of C-SPAN. John C. Danforth Republican of Missouri

title: Not-So-Petite Foot Is Not Alone
description: Are American feet getting bigger? Apparently they are. Stores are carrying larger shoe sizes than ever before. And now a woman who wears a size 11 can find stylish footwear in most department stores. Why are feet growing? Anatomists, physicians and manufacturers say Americans are getting taller and heavier, and feet come in proportion to body size. The population is also getting older, and feet spread with age. Last but not least, fitness-minded Americans want comfortable shoes.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: Israelis Cut Jail Terms of 3 Who Beat an Arab to Death
description: The Israeli Army today cut short by three months the jail terms of three soldiers convicted in the fatal beating of a Palestinian in custody.

title: Australian Boys' Choir
description: Two vocal groups from Australia -the Australian Boys' Choir and the Vocal Consort - will make their New York debuts on Oct. 10 at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 146 West 46th Street. The Boys' Choir, which celebrates its 50th anniversary this year, has 30 singers from 8 to 14 years old; the 12 members of the Vocal Consort are alumni of the Boys' Choir. The concert will include the American premiere of ''Sea Changes,'' a one-act opera by the Australian composer Ian Cugley. Tickets are $7. Information: 841-9514.

title: ICN Biomedicals
description: ICN Biomedicals Inc. of Irvine, Calif., said it would acquire the biomedical business of Flow General Inc. for about $41 million. ICN will also assume about $25 million in debt. The biomedical business manufactures and distributes products to research laboratories, pharmaceutical companies and biotechnology companies. It had sales of about $100 million in the year ended June 30. Flow General said the sale would allow it to focus on the electronics and software businesses. ICN, a division of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., said the acquisition would strengthen its biotechnology research business and give the company a significant presence in Europe.

title: Reviews/Music
description: The Melodies Of Zimbabwe

title: From the Algonquin, a Talk Show on the Arts
description: In an unusual forum to be heard weekly on public radio in New York and Los Angeles, people in the arts like Jules Feiffer, Edward Albee, Larry McMurtry, Wendy Wasserstein and Vartan Gregorian will discuss various topics in the Rose Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title:
TOMORROW'S NEW YORK;
New York's Next Crisis: Worse Than 1975
description: LEAD: Rudolph Giuliani intones that ''crime, crack and corruption'' are the ''prime issues'' of this campaign. David Dinkins is running on the proposition that he can heal the city's racial divisions and ''bring people together.'' While these are exemplary goals, they have little to do with the real problem facing the city: an impending municipal crisis that will make 1975's fiscal problems seem handily manageable by comparison.

title: Red Sox Win on a Walk
description: The Boston Red Sox have at least tied for third place in the American League East by defeating the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-4, tonight when a reliever, Chuck Crim, walked Rick Cerone with the bases loaded and two out in the bottom of the ninth inning.

title: A Call for a Corcoran Resignation
description: Just hours after the trustees of the Corcoran Gallery of Art named a committee to decide the fate of its director, the president of a major museum fund-raising group called for her resignation.

title: Gradco Systems
description: The chairman of Gradco Systems Inc., Keith B. Stewart, said Thursday that he was ''actively pursuing'' a leveraged buyout of the Irvine, Calif., office automation company. Mr. Stewart said no proposal had been submitted to the board of directors and there was no assurance a transaction would occur, but he made the announcement in response to unusual trading activity in the company's stock. Shares of Gradco, traded over-the-counter, closed at $18.375 today, up 87.5 cents a share, after gaining $1.125 on Thursday.

title: Chilly Days for East Germans Outside Embassy in Prague
description: The rain has gone, giving way to crisp and cold weather, and there is no sign of a resolution to the case of 2,500 or so East Germans camped out on the grounds of the West German Embassy in Prague.

title: Sylvia Traube, Psychiatrist, Is Dead at 79
description: Sylvia Gould Traube, a physician and psychiatrist for almost 40 years, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old. Dr. Traube graduated from Boston University's medical school in 1950, after taking time out from her studies to work in the defense industry. She was an intern at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn and a psychiatric resident at the Veterans' Administration Hospital in Montrose, N.Y. She was also a research associate at Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research and at Memorial Hospital for Cancer.

title: How the G.O.P. Can Nail Down the Black Vote
description: In 1985, New Jersey's Governor, Thomas H. Kean, won 62 percent of the black vote in his re-election bid. He swept the state's urban areas and crept close to carrying the cities of Newark and Camden. Was this an aberration or the beginning of a trend that will dissipate the Democratic Party's monopoly on black votes?

title: Review/Music; Columbus Home Fom New World as Opera
description: On the towering pedestal that interrupts the flow of traffic along the Paseo de Colon stands a statue of Christopher Columbus, his right arm outstretched. On Sunday evening that one raised finger seemed to be pointing in the direction of Pittsburgh.

title: Gabor Convicted of 3 Charges In Confrontation With Officer
description: A Municipal Court jury today convicted the entertainer Zsa Zsa Gabor of three misdemeanor charges resulting from her confrontation with a police officer who stopped her car last June.

title: Restored Nyack Theater Named for Helen Hayes
description: The Tappan Zee Playhouse, a historic turn-of-the-century theater in Nyack, N.Y., that was severely damaged by several fires in the late 1970's, will be restored and reopened by early 1991 as the Helen Hayes-Tappan Zee Performing Arts Center.

title: During Public Wake, the Un-rich Honor Marcos
description: When Ferdinand E. Marcos fled Manila three and a half years ago for exile here, his presidential briefcase was empty but for a Philippine flag.

title: U.S. Forest Harvest Is Nothing Like the Tropics; Federal Land Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping Center Groups Combine
description: General Growth Management Inc. agreed to acquire the Center Companies in a deal that would create the fourth-largest shopping center management company in the United States. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Judge Proposes Compromise on Banned Film
description: A judge has said that a 22-year-old ban on the public showing of a film that depicts brutality in a state prison hospital for the mentally ill may be lifted if the faces of many of the inmates are blurred.

title: Soviet Troops Exposed to Atomic Test in '54
description: "After the atomic strike, there were not only no landmarks left on the terrain, but the area itself became unrecognizable," the newspaper said.

title: Catherine CosentinoMarried in Phoenix
description: Catherine M. Cosentino, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Cosentino of Massapequa Park, L.I., was married yesterday in Phoenix to Robert F. Boyer Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Boyer of Oaklandon, Ind. The Rev. Robert Skagan officiated at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: Top-Grade Issues Gain on Wall St.
description: Declining interest rates made Wall Street a fertile environment in the third quarter for American companies seeking to borrow, so long as their bonds were investment grade.

title: Hispanic Groups Organizing Drive for a Full Census Count
