description: In the largest effort ever undertaken by Hispanic Americans to gain political power, advocacy groups are organizing a campaign to turn out the highest possible count in the 1990 census.

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Decline 0.7%
description: Prices farmers received for raw products dropped seven-tenths of a percent from August to September, leaving the monthly average also seventh-tenths of a percent below the level a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Compromise Reached on Spotted Owl
description: A House-Senate conference committee today approved a compromise meant to protect the spotted owl while allowing the logging that endangers its habitat in the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Credit-Card Rates
description: Interest rates on bank credit cards are up an average one-quarter of a percentage point since the beginning of the year, despite the glut of cards in the marketplace. To retain card holders as rates rise, banks have extended periods for interest-free payments to make their cards more attractive, and many have eliminated annual fees. For people who carry over a balance, a low interest rate is desirable. But if you pay off your charges in full each month, look for a card with no annual fee. Many of these have variable rates, generally tied to short-term Government securities, with quarterly adjustments. Remember that since Sept. 1, the Government has required all issuers of credit cards to include full fee and rate details in applications and solicitations. Here are some cards that are among those with the lowest annual percentage rates, two with fixed rates (F) and two with variable rates (V). $ Bank APR Annual Fee People's Bank, Bridgeport, Conn. 13.5 F $25 Empire of America, Amherst, N.Y. 13.75 F $18 USAA Fed Savings, San Antonio 15.21 V None Manufacturers Bank of Wilmington, Del. 16.6 V None Source: Bank Credit Card Observer, Princeton, N.J.

title: Thornburgh Loses Court Ruling on Secrets in Iran-Contra Case
description: A Federal appeals court in Richmond ruled today that the Attorney General may not seek a review of decisions on the disclosure of classified information that were made by a trial court in an Iran-contra case.

title: Zabriski Triumphs in Dodge Open
description: Bruce Zabriski of Oyster Bay, L.I., who played on the PGA Tour without much success last year, is developing a habit this year of winning golf tournaments in New Jersey sponsored by automobile manufacturers.

title: Sonics and Gaze Agree on Contract; Mullin Stays a Warrior
description: Andrew Gaze, whose long-range shooting helped Seton Hall University climb to within a point of winning the national collegiate basketball championship last April, will sign a professional contract with the Seattle SuperSonics next week.

title: Your Money; Gains-Tax Sales: Caution Advised
description: Thanks to the House of Representatives, investors across the country have visions of capital gains windfalls dancing in their heads. But before selling any assets in the expectation that gains will be subject to a more favorable tax treatment than under the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which taxes them as ordinary income, investors are well advised to consider the economics of holding versus selling.

title: Imperial Ties Loss To Savings Bill
description: Elaborating on a statement made Thursday, the Imperial Corporation of America said new savings and loan legislation forcing it to write down the value of its ''junk bond'' portfolio would mean a net loss in the third quarter of $75 million to $80 million.

title: Spelling TV Concern May Be Put Up for Sale
description: Spelling Entertainment Inc., responsible for such hit television series as ''Dynasty'' and ''Love Boat,'' said today that it might put itself up for sale.

title: Leading Indicators Post 2d Consecutive Increase
description: A Government index used to forecast the nation's economic course rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the second consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Simmons Raises Stake in Lockheed
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier, has raised his stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 10.43 percent from 9.46 percent.

title: In Quest for Pennant, a Racial Milestone
description: Baseball has had its share of thrilling races over the years, but never before have two black managers met on the final weekend, with one of them about to become the first black manager in a league championship series.

title: Susumu Yamashita, 84, Mitsubishi Director
description: Susumu Yamashita, a retired director and corporate secretary of Mitsubishi International Corporation, based in Manhattan, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Mendham, N.J.

title: Chen Boda, 85, Leader of Chinese Purges in 60's
description: Chen Boda, a senior aide to Mao Zedong who was convicted in 1981 of crimes during the Cultural Revolution, died on Sept. 20 at his home in Beijing, the Hong Kong press reported Thursday. He was 85 years old.

title: Tracking the Life and Art Of Thelonious Monk
description: A recurrent image in Charlotte Zwerin's remarkable documentary, ''Thelonious Monk: Straight, No Chaser,'' is of the jazz pianist slowly spinning around in what appear to be deliberate attempts to disorient himself. Although the film offers no explanation for this penchant, the picture of the pianist whirling like a child playing games with himself is an apt metaphor for his revolutionary piano style. As the abundant musical soundtrack illustrates, his spare, knotty pianism, with its restless stop-start rhythms and percussive insistence, maintained a perspective on life and art that was defiantly off-center, obsessively exploratory and deeply personal.

title: U.S.-China Falling-Out: Much Smoke but No Fire
description: At almost every opportunity, Chinese officials like Teng Teng, the Deputy Minister of Education, like to fulminate about American interference in China's affairs.

title: Woman Stabbed While Sleeping In Parked Van
description: A New Jersey woman was stabbed in the throat early yesterday morning as she slept in the rear of her van in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, then died as she was driving in search of help, the police said.

title: Control Data Searching for A New Chief
description: The Control Data Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Robert M. Price, said yesterday that the company's board had established a committee to select his successor as chief executive - a position he plans to give up in the next three months.

title: Anne S. Loftus, Community Board Manager, 64
description: Anne S. Loftus, district manager for Community Board 12, which covers the area from 155th Street to the northern tip of Manhattan, died of a heart attack Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 64 years old. Mrs. Loftus, a native New Yorker, had held the post since October 1980. She was in charge of monitoring the delivery of city services and conducted monthly meetings with the representatives of city agencies to discuss neighborhood needs.

title: Man Shot in Subway; Suspect Is Arrested
description: A Manhattan man was shot yesterday when he tried to stop two men from stealing his wife's handbag, the police said.

title: Campeau Stores Deny Crisis Reports
description: Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, the two American retail subsidiaries of the Campeau Corporation, said yesterday that they were paying for merchandise with cash from operations and borrowed money and that they should be able to meet their needs through the end of the year.

title: The Uses of Celebrity
description: Jackie Mason is a professional, a gifted comic who has earned considerable celebrity. What got him into trouble this week was trying to spend that celebrity as an amateur on a very different kind of stage: politics.

title: Why Give Times Sq. Precedence Over Other Deteriorating Sites?; Not Porn Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Wagner Dynasty Is Inspired By Service Ideal
description: ''I'll tell you a funny story,'' the Mayor said.

title: Overlooked in Virginia: Little Kids
description: As he stood at the conference on American education this week, President Bush saw only dimly the one need that stands out most sharply on the horizon: the youngest children.

title: Judge in Garcia Trial Made Faces And Ruled Unfairly, Lawyer Says
description: Representative Robert Garcia's lawyer complained Thursday that the Federal judge who is presiding over Mr. Garcia's bribery trial made faces during defense presentations to the jury and ruled unfairly against the defense, according to a court transcript released yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music; A Miniaturist Takes On Beethoven, With Boldness
description: The first two weeks of the New York Philharmonic season at Avery Fisher Hall have offered a curious melange of music. The music itself wasn't so curious, but instead of two discrete groupings of repertory in two subscription programs, there have been bits and pieces from last week's opening-night gala mixed in with new selections.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Evernden Beats Chang: Kelly Evernden of New Zealand scored the biggest upset of his career yesterday, beating second-seeded Michael Chang, 6-0, 6-1, to move into the semifinals of the Volvo of San Francisco tournament. It was the worst defeat the 17-year old French Open champion has suffered in his pro career. Evernden is ranked 65th in the world and Chang 5th.(AP) Lendl Defeats Leconte: Ivan Lendl defeated Henri Leconte of France, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Passing Shot tournament at Bordeaux, France. Jaime Yzaga of Peru, seeded fourth, beat Casio Motta of Brazil, 7-6, 6-2, and will meet Lendl in the semifinals.(AP) Mancini Is Upset: Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia rallied to upset top-seeded Alberto Mancini of Argentina, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Championship of Sicily tournament in Palermo.(AP) GOLF Course Record Broken: Jim Carter shot an 11-under-par 61 yesterday, the lowest round on the PGA Tour this year, but Tom Pernice Jr. still led by one stroke after the second round of the Centel Classic in Tallahassee, Fla. Carter's round broke the Killearn Country Club course mark of 62, set in 1982 by Larry Rinker. The tour record of 59 was set by Al Geiberger at the Memphis Classic in 1977.(AP) Daniel Moves Into Lead: Beth Daniel shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Pat Bradley in the first round of the San Jose Classic in California.(AP) Charles in Front: Bob Charles hit 17 greens in regulation and shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday for the first-round lead in the Space Coast Senior Classic in Melbourne, Fla.(AP) U.S. Defeats Argentina: The United States defeated Argentina, 3-0, at St. Andrews, Scotland, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the Dunhill Cup, where it will play Ireland, the defending champion. Tom Kite shot a 70 to defeat Vicente Fernandez, who matched par 72. Mark Calcavecchia beat Miguel Fernandez, 72-77, and Curtis Strange beat Eduardo Romero, 68-70.(AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL Brooklyn 23, St. Peter's 6: Armando Cataldi threw three touchdown passes last night for Brooklyn College. Cataldi finished 15 for 25 for 214 yards for the Kingsmen (1-1). He threw second-quarter scoring passes of 17 yards to Mike Lorenzo and 12 yards to Ted McRay. Paul Fedel, who had 7 receptions for 143 yards, scored on a 26-yard pass from Cataldi in the third quarter. Ray Konopka scored on a 1-yard run in the fourth quarter for the Peacocks (0-1).(AP) Idaho 30, Montana, 24: John Friesz threw for a career-high 437 yards and Idaho withstood a late-game Montana rally as the Vandals defeated the Grizzlies, 30-24, in a Big Sky Conference football game Thursday night at Moscow, Idaho. (AP) HOCKEY Islanders 2, Sabres 2: Glenn Healy's 36-save performance helped lift the Islanders to a 2-2 exhibition tie with the Buffalo Sabres last night at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y. The Islanders scored the only goal of the first period at 17 minutes 51 seconds on Pat LaFontaine's power-play shot to the lower corner.(AP) YACHTING Raritan Leading: A sailing team from the Raritan Yacht Club of New Jersey took advantage of a brisk southwesterly breeze in New York Harbor yesterday and took the lead in the first day of the International Yacht Club Challenge.

title: KEY RATES
Pope's Words on Jews Reverse No Doctrines
description: To the Editor:

title: Bogota Chief, at U.N., Asks U.S. to Curb Drug Demand
description: President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia called on the United States and other nations today to curb the demand for drugs and to cut other assistance that he said the countries were giving to drug producers in the third world.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Books of The Times; Two Accounts of What It Means to Be Disabled
description: Seeing Voices A Journey Into the World of the Deaf By Oliver Sacks Illustrated. 180 pages. University of California Press. $15.95. I Raise My Eyes to Say Yes A Memoir By Ruth Sienkiewicz-Mercer and Steven B. Kaplan Illustrated. 225 pages. A Richard Todd Book/Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: Rebels Say They Will Reject Salvadoran Cease-Fire Offer
description: Representatives of guerrillas fighting the Government of El Salvador said today they would not accept even an unconditional cease-fire offer without guarantees for safety and political opportunity for the rebels.

title: Treasury Issues Recover After Early Drop
description: Many banks borrowed excess reserves, also known as Federal funds, from other banks and institutions yesterday, to show lower liabilities on their third-quarter statements, sending the Federal funds rate well above 9 percent briefly. That, along with a weaker dollar, depressed the prices of Treasury securities early in the day, dealers said.

title: Letter: On Ecology; Help Brazil Preserve the Amazon
description: To the Editor:

title: Jesse Silberstein, Advocate for Elderly, 77
description: Jesse Silberstein, an advocate for the elderly, died of cancer Wednesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Bush Defends Carolina Relief Efforts
description: President Bush today defended his Administration's handling of relief efforts for hurricane victims as he traveled past a vista of wrecked buildings, shattered pine forests and mangled vehicles in this state.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cooper Life Sciences Inc., said it had notified Cooper Development Co., Menlo Park, Calif., a developer of health-care products, that because of a delay in reaching an overall settlement with Cooper Cos. Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a maker of surgical products, it would re-evaluate its proposed merger with Cooper Development.

title: T.A.C. Urges Cooperation
description: The president of The Athletics Congress said yesterday that the recommendations of its Athletes Advisory Committee, including the idea of appointing an independent investigator to look into drug use, were similar to ideas favored by the T.A.C. leadership.

title: Long Drought, Then a Flood
description: An 86-year-old woman whose Social Security files had been lost, depriving her of increased benefits that she should have been receiving for 17 years, received a check for $19,000 in back payments Thursday. Asked how she would spend the money, the recipient, Irene O'Neil, said: ''I haven't any idea. But I have eight grandchildren and two sons, and I'm sure I can find some place for it.''

title: Free chamber Music Series
description: A free series of Friday chamber music concerts sponsored by the Juilliard School begins on Oct. 13 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center. The concert will feature the Cardinal Brass Quintet in a program of works by Malcolm Arnold, Britten, Mozart and Franck. Concerts in the series are scheduled through May 2. Although the performances are free, reserved tickets are required: 874-7515.

title: Patents; Advances In Conductor Materials
description: ResearcherS at the International Business Machines Corporation have won patent approval for superconductor materials that are said to operate at higher temperatures than any other materials developed thus far, as well as for the process to make the superconductors.

title: Conflict Arises On Jet's Rudder In USAir Crash
description: The flight recorder from the USAir jet that crashed at La Guardia Airport last week shows that the plane's rudder was severely misaligned long before the ill-fated takeoff attempt, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Sports People column yesterday about the George Foreman-Gerry Cooney heavyweight fight on Jan. 15 misstated the site. It is Convention Hall in Atlantic City.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS WORKING TO DEVISE THEIR OWN TAX CUT
description: Democrats in the Senate are searching for a less sweeping reduction in the capital gains tax than the one approved Thursday by the House of Representatives.

title: Baker Says U.S. Wants Jerusalem To Decide Now on Peace Proposal
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated yesterday that the United States felt it was time for Israel to decide whether or not it stood behind its own peace proposal.

title: Harcourt Brace Stock Plunges
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. stock plunged today amid warnings that the $1.1 billion paid for its theme parks would do little to relieve the publisher's debt. Harcourt's stock price dropped almost 25.4 percent on the New York Stock Exchange, falling $4.125 a share, to $12.125. It was the most active issue on the Big Board, with more than 3.6 million shares traded.

title: Prosecutor Bores In as Bakker Testifies
description: Four weeks after suffering a ''panic attack'' that forced a brief halt in his trial, Jim Bakker took the witness stand today to give his version of the meteoric rise and calamitous fall of his religious empire.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Wednesday, showing counties in the Carolinas that had been declared disaster areas after Hurricane Hugo, misidentified a South Carolina county. It is Horry County, not Norry.

title: Arizona Court Ends Mecham Bid for Office
description: Former Gov. Evan Mecham today lost a bid to have the Arizona Supreme Court restore him to office and to order the state to pay him more than $600,000 in legal fees and back pay.

title: Big Winnings On 3 Long Shots
description: Three long shots added up to a trifecta payoff of $92,799.40 in the fourth race tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: 51 Lebanese Legislators Fly To Peace Talk at Saudi Resort
description: Lebanese Christian and Muslim members of Parliament headed for Saudi Arabia today to take part in an Arab-sponsored peace conference in the latest attempt to end their country's 14-year civil war. But there is skepticism here that they will succeed.

title: A GUILTY VERDICT FOR ABORTION FOE
description: The director of an anti-abortion group today was found guilty of trespassing and illegal assembly in a demonstration at an Atlanta abortion clinic during the 1988 Democratic National Convention.

title: Teachers Praise Bush's Effort to Set a New Education Agenda
description: School superintendents, union leaders and teachers were virtually unanimous yesterday in praising the efforts of President Bush and the nation's governors in setting a national agenda for education.

title: In Carolina Fishing Hamlet, Tired Cleanup Amid Doubts
description: A heavy fog lifted late this morning, and weary townspeople once more began hauling furniture out in the sun to dry and taking up shovels and hoses to remove the muck from their homes.

title: August A. Busch Jr. Dies at 90; Built Largest Brewing Company
description: August Anheuser Busch Jr., the master showman and irrepressible salesman who turned a small family operation into the world's largest brewing company, died yesterday at his home in suburban St. Louis County, Mo. He was 90 years old and had recently been hospitalized with pneumonia.

title: Dollar Falls On Selling By Allies
description: After a week of relentless effort to lower the value of the dollar, the United States and its economic allies succeeded yesterday in forcing the currency below key levels against the West German mark and the Japanese yen.

title: Ford Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company announced that it would offer cash incentives on certain 1990 car and truck models. Ford follows the lead of two of its competitors, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, both of which already offer cash rebates on a variety of 1990 models. The new plan offers cash rebates varying from $600 on Tempo sedans to $1,250 on the Bronco II sports utility vehicle. Incentives are also being offered on the Mercury Topaz and Ford Ranger.

title: For Argentines, the Free Ride Is Very Much the Way of Life
description: Soon after Alberto Trezza was named president of the Argentine railroad system, he took the overnight train to Bahia Blanca, the country's main port city.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 Are free rides hurting Argentina? Although subsidies and favors have become a cornerstone of Argentine life, they are being scrutinized for cuts by the new Government. Page 1

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Heroin Smuggler Is Given 27 Years
description: A man described by prosecutors as one of the world's largest heroin smugglers was sentenced yesterday to 27 years in prison with no possibility of parole.

title: Withhold Aid to Somalian Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Give Times Sq. Precedence Over Other Deteriorating Sites?; Try Movable Facades
description: To the Editor:

title: In Scarsdale, an After-Dinner Speech on Golf and Racism
description: When Earl G. Graves, the editor and publisher of Black Enterprise magazine, was asked to help begin this year's local United Way drive, ''we were hoping for an evening of interest and excitement,'' said Florence David, the chapter's executive director.
